text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: For a million years, humans lived off hunting,
label: Paragraph

text: food gathering, and fishing. From the
label: Paragraph

text: perspective of our advanced world today we
label: Title

text: tend to look back at this and wonder how
label: Paragraph

text: we could even have survived given all the
label: Paragraph

text: difficulties. We once labeled these people
label: Paragraph

text: savages or barbarians, and then we called
label: Paragraph

text: them primitives. More recently we call them
label: Paragraph

text: hunter-gatherers, as if all they do is obsess
label: Paragraph

text: about food acquisition. But the !Kung, who
label: Paragraph

text: have lived in the Kalahari Desert in Botswana
label: Paragraph

text: for hundreds of thousands of years, spend
label: Paragraph

text: only about 40 percent of their time hunting
label: Paragraph

text: and gathering. The rest of the time, they do
label: Paragraph

text: what most of us might do: they socialize,
label: Paragraph

text: dance, cook, and rest.
label: Paragraph

text: In the Kalahari, rmongongo trees, which
label: Paragraph

text: produce tasty and nutritious nuts by the
label: Paragraph

text: thousands, proliferate in mile-long groves.
label: Paragraph

text: Tubers can be dug from the ground, and
label: Paragraph

text: animal herds migrate through the territory,
label: Paragraph

text: easy prey for a canny hunter and his poison-
label: Paragraph

text: tipped arrows. The !Kung live in camps that
label: Paragraph

text: are rebuilt every year near seasonal water
label: Paragraph

text: oles. Women make the huts around a
label: Paragraph

text: common campfire, usually under the shade
label: Paragraph

text: of a large tree. The huts are not really to live
label: Paragraph

text: in, since people tend to live mainly outdoors,
label: Paragraph

text: ut serve as storage areas for tools and as
label: Paragraph

text: shade on a hot day. The modern world has
label: Paragraph

text: ittle respect for its venerable ancestors.
label: Paragraph

text: Because of forced relocations, mining on
label: Paragraph

text: their territory, and fences cutting across their
label: Paragraph

text: land, the 'Kung people’s survival into the
label: Paragraph

text: next decades is much in doubt. It is not the
label: Paragraph

text: natural world that endangers them, but our
label: Paragraph

text: civilized world.
label: Paragraph

text: As populations expanded, groups would
label: Paragraph

text: bud off to form new communities in the next
label: Paragraph

text: valley or further along the shores. In this way,
label: Paragraph

text: the first groups of people left Africa some 1.5
label: Paragraph

text: million years ago with a second group, our
label: Paragraph

text: human ancestors, following around 60,000
label: Paragraph

text: BCE to slowly yet persistently colonize the
label: Paragraph

text: globe, reaching the southern tip of South
label: Paragraph

text: America around 13,000 BCE. First Society
label: Caption

text: people, however, were not nomads as is so
label: Paragraph

text: mistakenly assumed. Instead they tended to
label: Paragraph

text: live within prescribed and familiar territories,
label: Paragraph

text: moving seasonally between winter camps
label: Title

text: near rivers and upland summer camps for
label: Paragraph

text: hunting and fishing. The ancient people of
label: Paragraph

text: Australia, for example, moved in predictable
label: Paragraph

text: cycles: in some parts of the year they lived
label: Paragraph

text: in relative isolation, and in other parts
label: Paragraph

text: they would get together for large annual
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial and social events.
label: Paragraph

text: During the Ice Age (ca. 25,000 BCE-
label: Paragraph

text: ca. 15,000 BCE), humans faced a global
label: Paragraph

text: phenomencn the likes of which we have
label: Paragraph

text: never seen since. The extreme cold, which
label: Paragraph

text: sent massive, mile-deep ice sheets far to
label: Paragraph

text: the south of the polar regions, impacted
label: Paragraph

text: Europe in particular. But the people there
label: Paragraph

text: did not leave. This was not because they
label: Paragraph

text: were trapped. It was because those areas
label: Paragraph

text: ad become a hunter's paradise, with bears,
label: Paragraph

text: ions, and, above all, huge herds of horses,
label: Paragraph

text: reindeer, and mammoth moving across the
label: Paragraph

text: grassy landscape. The Gravettian Culture was
label: Paragraph

text: the first to master the cold. They developed
label: Paragraph

text: leather-making and the needle to create fur-
label: Paragraph

text: ined clothing, boots, and jackets. In great
label: Paragraph

text: festivals, they congregated near caves where
label: Paragraph

text: artists had painted brilliant images of animals
label: Paragraph

text: on the walls and ceilings. What form of magic
label: Paragraph

text: these places produced is still unknown, but
label: Paragraph

text: the quality of the art staggers the imagination
label: Paragraph

text: even today. The animals were painted not
label: Paragraph

text: as carcasses but as living creatures moving
label: Paragraph

text: and breathing, and were made by artists who
label: Paragraph

text: had practiced their skills over a lifetime. As
label: Paragraph

text: the weather warmed, the hunters moved to
label: Paragraph

text: the east, crossed Siberia, and around 13,000
label: Paragraph

text: BCE crossed Alaska to enter the open plains
label: Paragraph

text: of North America. Called the Clovis People,
label: Paragraph

text: they hunted mammoth and then, when the
label: Paragraph

text: mammoth were all hunted out, they switched
label: Paragraph

text: to bison. Their sacred landscapes include
label: Paragraph

text: Seminole Canyon in Texas, with its ancient
label: Paragraph

text: rock art depicting shamans and sacred
label: Title

text: animal spirits.
label: Paragraph

text: 1.2 Haida settlement, Canada
label: Caption

text: The warming of the weather raised the
label: Paragraph

text: levels of the oceans, separating Japan from
label: Paragraph

text: China, and England from mainland Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: It created vast rivers, swamps, and forests
label: Paragraph

text: teeming with animals and plants, drawing
label: Paragraph

text: humans to the river shores. It was, one
label: Paragraph

text: might say, an age of affluence. At Lepenski
label: Paragraph

text: Vir along the Danube River, a settlement of
label: Paragraph

text: triangular huts emerged. The people there
label: Paragraph

text: caught sturgeon, a fish that averaged some 3
label: Paragraph

text: meters long. Why go hunting when catching
label: Paragraph

text: one fish would feed an entire community?
label: Paragraph

text: The nearby forests provided a wide
label: Paragraph

text: assortment of berries, mushrooms, and nuts
label: Title

text: to complement the diet. Nor was this village a
label: Paragraph

text: solitary community. Similar villages lined the
label: Paragraph

text: shores, and their inhabitants traveled by boat
label: Paragraph

text: to connect with each other for ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: events.
label: Paragraph

text: Half a world away, another affluent
label: Paragraph

text: society emerged along the northwest coast
label: Paragraph

text: of Canada. It was a favorable site for many
label: Paragraph

text: reasons. It was in a pocket of relatively mild
label: Paragraph

text: weather, the result of cross-Pacific winds; it
label: Paragraph

text: was also sited along the migration path of
label: Paragraph

text: whales, and salmon came in the thousands
label: Paragraph

text: to swim upstream to spawn. Huge cedar
label: Paragraph

text: trees, sacred to the Haida, provided material
label: Paragraph

text: for houses and boats. The tree was not just
label: Paragraph

text: “wood.” Its red color and sweet smell were
label: Paragraph

text: indicators of its connection to the world of
label: Paragraph

text: the spirits. Linear settlements sprang up
label: Paragraph

text: along the shore, cornposed of large, clan-
label: Paragraph

text: based community houses facing the water.
label: Paragraph

text: Each house was a sacred diagram designed
label: Paragraph

text: in relation to the cosmos, which for the
label: Paragraph

text: Haida was divided into three shamanistic
label: Paragraph

text: zones: the sky world, the earth, and the
label: Title

text: oceanic underworld. The building's frame
label: Paragraph

text: systern consisted of massive roof beams,
label: Paragraph

text: often more than half a meter in diameter
label: Paragraph

text: and spanning the width of the house, which
label: Paragraph

text: ranged from 7.5 to 15 meters. These beams
label: Paragraph

text: were supported by posts carved to represent
label: Paragraph

text: important family ancestors or supernatural
label: Title

text: beings associated with the family’s history.
label: Paragraph

text: Walls were clad with split-cedar planks tied
label: Paragraph

text: horizontally between paired upright poles.
label: Paragraph

text: lt was not just rivers and shores that
label: Paragraph

text: attracted human habitation to make the first
label: Paragraph

text: settled communities, but also the emerging
label: Paragraph

text: great rain forests. The Bambuti in Congo still
label: Paragraph

text: today pay homage to a forest spirit, Jengi,
label: Paragraph

text: whose power is thought to ernanate through
label: Paragraph

text: the world. Jengi is seen as a parental figure
label: Paragraph

text: and guardian. Society is organized around
label: Paragraph

text: individual households consisting of a husband,
label: Paragraph

text: a wife, and their children, forrning settlements
label: Paragraph

text: that can number up to about fifty residents.
label: Paragraph

text: The women build the huts that, in the shape
label: Paragraph

text: of upside-down baskets, are made out of a
label: Paragraph

text: frame of saplings and clad with leaves. Other
label: Paragraph

text: rain forest cultures developed in Brazil, Central
label: Paragraph

text: America, and Southeast Asia.
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning around 10,000 BCE in some
label: Paragraph

text: places, the great First Society traditions that
label: Paragraph

text: had sustained human life for so long began to
label: Paragraph

text: change. Instead of hunting animals, humans
label: Paragraph

text: began to herd them, and instead of gathering
label: Paragraph

text: and tending plants, they began to domesticate
label: Paragraph

text: a few chosen plants and grow them in
label: Paragraph

text: organized fields. These changes altered
label: Paragraph

text: 1.3 Village scene
label: Caption

text: the imaginaries of the spirit world. Cattle in
label: Paragraph

text: particular were seen as living gods, requiring
label: Paragraph

text: daily attendance and a culture of respect. They
label: Paragraph

text: were not killed for food but were sacrificed
label: Paragraph

text: to mark special events in the life of the
label: Paragraph

text: community. Among the Dinka in the Sudan, a
label: Paragraph

text: man knows his cattle by special names, sings
label: Paragraph

text: songs to them, and sleeps next to them for
label: Paragraph

text: long periods of time. Cattle are sacrificed only
label: Paragraph

text: on special occasions, such as at weddings or
label: Paragraph

text: funerals. Although only a few cattle-centric
label: Paragraph

text: societies remain today, the impact of this
label: Paragraph

text: worldview can be felt even in modern religions.
label: Paragraph

text: Just as important was the shift from
label: Paragraph

text: gathering plants to farming. Rice in southern
label: Paragraph

text: China and eastern India, millet in Africa and
label: Paragraph

text: northern China, wheat and barley in the
label: Title

text: Levant, and corn in Guatemala—all rose from
label: Paragraph

text: being just one of thousands of plants that
label: Paragraph

text: humans tended to the precious focus of effort
label: Paragraph

text: and devotion. The combined transformation
label: Paragraph

text: of our relationship to animals and plants
label: Title

text: produced a new way of life: agropastoralism.
label: Paragraph

text: While today we call this period the birth of
label: Paragraph

text: agriculture, we have to remember that crops
label: Paragraph

text: like rice and barley were not raised as food.
label: Paragraph

text: They were gods. We have so secularized food
label: Paragraph

text: production today that we forget that the birth
label: Paragraph

text: of what we call agriculture coincided wit!
label: Paragraph

text: profound transformations that deified certain
label: Paragraph

text: foods and thus, it might be said, guaranteed
label: Paragraph

text: the proper and complex work ethic needed for
label: Paragraph

text: their production. The impact on women was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly profound; harvesting, grinding,
label: Paragraph

text: storing, and cooking were all largely women’s
label: Paragraph

text: work, as was pottery making, basket weaving,
label: Paragraph

text: and, of course, the raising of children.
label: Paragraph

text: The emergence of pastoral and agropastoral
label: Title

text: cultures produced village societies organized
label: Title

text: around chiefs with more or less power
label: Title

text: depending on circumstances. Villages were
label: Paragraph

text: well calibrated to meet the needs of the
label: Paragraph

text: animals, to deal with the calendar of planting
label: Paragraph

text: and harvesting, and to produce the necessary
label: Paragraph

text: equipment for life, such as the bowls and
label: Paragraph

text: containers that stored grain and water and
label: Paragraph

text: that allowed fermentation and cooking to
label: Paragraph

text: take place. These activities were all governed
label: Paragraph

text: by ritual practices and unwritten rules of
label: Paragraph

text: behavior that shaped the destiny of all. But
label: Paragraph

text: village society could not spread just anywhere.
label: Paragraph

text: It needed the right combination of good soil
label: Paragraph

text: for farms, grasslands for cattle, forests for
label: Paragraph

text: firewood, and upland areas for hunting—and,
label: Paragraph

text: of course, water and salt.
label: Paragraph

text: The Mesopotamian highlands were perfect
label: Paragraph

text: for such agropastoral societies, and beginning
label: Paragraph

text: around 9000 BCE compact villages began to
label: Paragraph

text: spread along the slopes above the great rivers
label: Paragraph

text: 1.4 Pottery making
label: Caption

text: in the plains. A similar expansion took place
label: Paragraph

text: along the Sahel in Africa, where sorghurn was
label: Paragraph

text: the main plant, as well as in the foothills of the
label: Paragraph

text: Baluchistan Mountains (barley), in northern
label: Paragraph

text: China (millet), and along the Yangtze River
label: Paragraph

text: (rice). By 5000 BCE these places had also
label: Paragraph

text: established themselves as profoundly different
label: Paragraph

text: from the First Society worlds that neighbored
label: Title

text: them, even if they maintained some aspects of
label: Paragraph

text: the older traditions. Whereas the agropastoral
label: Paragraph

text: tradition in Mesopotamia, the Indus Valley,
label: Paragraph

text: China, and Egypt remained confined by their
label: Paragraph

text: ecological niches, a remarkable transformation
label: Paragraph

text: took place in Europe, where between 9000.
label: Paragraph

text: and 4000 BCE, agropastoral cultures rnoved
label: Paragraph

text: slowly along rivers and shores to reach even
label: Paragraph

text: northern Ireland. There the newcomers thrived
label: Paragraph

text: and built one of the greatest structures of
label: Paragraph

text: the time, Newgrange, a vast artificial mound
label: Paragraph

text: with a sacred chamber in its interior that was
label: Paragraph

text: designed to mark the first rays of the winter
label: Paragraph

text: solstice.

text: RITUAL CENTERS
label: Title

text: n the agropastoral environment, humans
label: Title

text: egan to think and act differently than
label: Title

text: their First Society ancestors had. Forests
label: Paragraph

text: jad to be chopped down, clay had to be
label: Paragraph

text: gathered for pots that then had to be fired in
label: Paragraph

text: ilns, granaries had to established, animals
label: Paragraph

text: tended to, wool harvested and made into
label: Paragraph

text: cloth; plants that were once considered
label: Paragraph

text: food were now thought of as weeds that had
label: Paragraph

text: to be culled from gardens and farm plots.
label: Paragraph

text: Decisions had to be made about priorities;
label: Paragraph

text: children had to learn their respective roles as
label: Paragraph

text: adults; and priests had to secure the privilege
label: Paragraph

text: of the divine. Customs had to be followed
label: Paragraph

text: about social ranking, finding a mate, and
label: Paragraph

text: building a house. Herds could die because
label: Paragraph

text: of disease or predators, and crops could be
label: Paragraph

text: lost to pests or carelessness. Grains could
label: Paragraph

text: rot, and neighboring tribes could attack.
label: Paragraph

text: The marshaling of energies that the village
label: Paragraph

text: required, the stratification of gender activities
label: Paragraph

text: along with the creation of a new set of
label: Paragraph

text: powerful gods in privileged communication
label: Title

text: with the elites, produced a type of cognitive
label: Paragraph

text: revolution. The cohesiveness that this
label: Paragraph

text: required is impressive, and in many parts of
label: Paragraph

text: the globe the village world is still the glue that
label: Paragraph

text: holds society together.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the first sites where we see the
label: Paragraph

text: transformation is Nabta Playa in what is
label: Paragraph

text: today southern Egypt, some 80 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: west of Abu Simbel. It is now an inhospitable
label: Paragraph

text: desert, but in 9000 BCE it was next to a large
label: Paragraph

text: lake with pastured shores. The site featured
label: Paragraph

text: a circle of slender upright stones, the main
label: Paragraph

text: stones being four pairs set close together.
label: Paragraph

text: Compared to Stonehenge, built 6.000 years
label: Paragraph

text: later, the circle is small, measuring roughly
label: Paragraph

text: 4 meters in diameter, but its purpose was
label: Paragraph

text: similar: to organize time according to the
label: Paragraph

text: seasons. Two of the stone pairs are aligned
label: Paragraph

text: north-south, the other two pairs northeast-
label: Paragraph

text: southwest. They aided in the observation
label: Paragraph

text: of the motion of the sun and probably of
label: Paragraph

text: the constellation Orion. Priests and their
label: Paragraph

text: associated clans probably came to live at
label: Paragraph

text: Nabta Playa permanently, with the population
label: Paragraph

text: swelling periodically with the seasonal arrival
label: Paragraph

text: of herder tribes who would have come from
label: Paragraph

text: far afield with their cattle for large celebratory
label: Paragraph

text: O
label: Title

text: events. By 3500 BCE, however, Nabta Playa
label: Paragraph

text: had become increasingly arid: the lake
label: Paragraph

text: dried up, and the site was abandoned. The
label: Paragraph

text: exodus from the Nubian Desert to the Nile
label: Title

text: River played a large role in the development
label: Paragraph

text: of social differentiation in the pre-dynastic
label: Paragraph

text: cultures of the Nile Valley. One important link
label: Paragraph

text: between Egypt and the ancient cattle cult
label: Title

text: of Nabta Playa was Hathor, the goddess of
label: Paragraph

text: fertility.
label: Paragraph

text: Another ritual site was on top of a hill near
label: Paragraph

text: the village of Urfa in southeastern Turkey.
label: Paragraph

text: Here, too, the now arid site was once a lush
label: Paragraph

text: forest. The oldest layer of the site appears
label: Paragraph

text: to date back to around 9000 BCE. The
label: Paragraph

text: structures, called Gébekli Tepe, consist of
label: Paragraph

text: several circular dry-stone walls, each of which
label: Paragraph

text: contains monolithic pillars of limestone up to
label: Paragraph

text: 3 meters tall. Since there is no indication of
label: Paragraph

text: any roof covering, it seems that the circles
label: Paragraph

text: were open-air ritual chambers. They are now
label: Paragraph

text: called temples, but it is unlikely that they
label: Paragraph

text: were temples in the sense of being used
label: Paragraph

text: by a priesthood with organized devotional
label: Paragraph

text: practices. What went on in these spaces is
label: Paragraph

text: not known, but they most certainly had links
label: Paragraph

text: to ancestor cults and might have been used
label: Paragraph

text: in conjunction with mortuary rituals. The
label: Paragraph

text: floors consisted of a concrete-like substance
label: Paragraph

text: made of burnished lime. A low bench runs
label: Paragraph

text: around the inside of the circle walls. The
label: Paragraph

text: pillars show detailed reliefs of foxes, lions,

text: cattle, wild boars, herons, ducks, scorpions,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: demonstrating that precision work—even
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Ritual Center (ca. 3500-3000 BCE) in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and structures, and, of course, Stonehenge
label: Paragraph

text: (ca. 3000 BCE}, we have four ritual centers—
label: Paragraph

text: and there are certainly countless more—that
label: Paragraph

text: served as gathering places and eventually
label: Paragraph

text: as religious centers for newly settled
label: Paragraph

text: communities. Niuheliang will be discussed
label: Paragraph

text: in this chapter; Stonehenge, perhaps the
label: Paragraph

text: last of the great early ritual centers, will be
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Around 3500 BCE something quite
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable happened in four places on
label: Paragraph

text: the earth: groups of people developed
label: Title

text: something that we today call cities. This
label: Paragraph

text: transformation was not as natural as one
label: Paragraph

text: might assume, even though it was dependent
label: Paragraph

text: on several thousand years of village life and
label: Title

text: the necessary cohesion that came with it. In
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamia, the farmers in the hills at first
label: Paragraph

text: stayed away from the vast, overgrown, flood-
label: Paragraph

text: prone swamps of the Tigris and Euphrates
label: Title

text: Rivers. But an intrepid group must have set
label: Paragraph

text: out one day to try their luck. Finding a knoll,
label: Paragraph

text: they dug up the reeds, planted barley, and
label: Paragraph

text: carved out canals, activities that were hugely
label: Paragraph

text: labor-intensive. It was a success, built on the
label: Paragraph

text: simple premise that by doing one thing well—
label: Paragraph

text: growing barley—the inhabitants of an isolated
label: Paragraph

text: place could trade for everything that they did
label: Paragraph

text: not have. They created the wheel to speed
label: Paragraph

text: up travel; they created writing to document
label: Paragraph

text: trade transactions; they created city-scaled
label: Paragraph

text: gods to protect them; they laid the foundation
label: Paragraph

text: for laws and regulations; and they created
label: Paragraph

text: walls to defend their precious grain surpluses
label: Paragraph

text: on which the entire operation depended.
label: Paragraph

text: The first cities of Mesopotamia were thus
label: Paragraph

text: experiments in an extreme landscape. They
label: Paragraph

text: were governed by an elite, with most of the
label: Paragraph

text: work done by slaves from nearby conquered
label: Title

text: regions. Some cities thrived, some did not,
label: Paragraph

text: but over time, the power and wealth that they
label: Paragraph

text: created for themselves pushed their destiny
label: Title

text: forward. In Egypt, the story is similar, but
label: Paragraph

text: here the rise of cities—more like sprawling
label: Paragraph

text: villages—was the consequence of the rapid
label: Paragraph

text: influx of refugees from the expanding Sahara
label: Title

text: Desert. Prior to about 5000 BCE the Nile was
label: Paragraph

text: an unruly, lightly populated, swampy river,
label: Paragraph

text: but with the drier climate that created the
label: Paragraph

text: desert, thousands of people came with their
label: Paragraph

text: animals and agricultural skills. Over tire they
label: Paragraph

text: refashioned the Nile into a fertile paradise.
label: Paragraph

text: The intensity of this foreshadowed the rise
label: Paragraph

text: of a controlling elite who became first chiefs,
label: Paragraph

text: then gods.
label: Paragraph

text: 1.7 Gobekli Tepe, near Urfa, Turkey
label: Caption

text: In India along the Indus River, cities also
label: Paragraph

text: emerged, spectacular in nature, because
label: Paragraph

text: unlike in Mesopotamia and Egypt where the
label: Paragraph

text: building material was largely mud-dried brick,
label: Paragraph

text: here the inhabitants made kiln-fired bricks
label: Paragraph

text: that could not only withstand the test of time
label: Paragraph

text: but also allowed them to build close to the
label: Paragraph

text: river, and to build pools, drainage systems,
label: Paragraph

text: and multistory houses. Ships from these
label: Paragraph

text: cities traded with the Mesopotamians
label: Title

text: to the north.
label: Paragraph

text: In China, the development of cities had
label: Paragraph

text: a slightly different cast. Village communities
label: Paragraph

text: had formed in the south in the swarnpy
label: Paragraph

text: regions around Hangzhou Bay and the
label: Title

text: Yangtze River estuary, where rice could
label: Paragraph

text: be planted. Villages were also forming in
label: Paragraph

text: the north where people had long since
label: Paragraph

text: discovered the value of millet, a hardy plant
label: Paragraph

text: that grows on hillsides. Here people used
label: Paragraph

text: a form of architecture well-known in the
label: Paragraph

text: north since 25,000 BCE, the pit house. Dug
label: Paragraph

text: partially into the ground with a superstructure
label: Paragraph

text: of thatch held in place by posts and beams,
label: Paragraph

text: these communal buildings were dry and
label: Paragraph

text: warm and the focus of a range of ritual
label: Paragraph

text: activities. Unlike the Mesopotamian cities,
label: Paragraph

text: which were import-export centers, these
label: Paragraph

text: dense villages were more self-sustaining as
label: Paragraph

text: they attained the scale of cities. There were
label: Paragraph

text: areas for the manufacturing of pottery and
label: Paragraph

text: bronze, just as there were areas reserved for
label: Paragraph

text: the elites.
label: Paragraph

text: 1.8 Elam, a typical Mesopotamian city with
label: Caption

text: walls and towers, as depicted in this bas-relief
label: Paragraph

text: commemorating Assyrian king Ashurbanipal’s
label: Caption

text: conquest and destruction of the city in 647 BCE.
label: Paragraph

text: These first cities produced a concentration of
label: Paragraph

text: wealth and power that was to have significant
label: Paragraph

text: implications for the destiny of humans and
label: Title

text: indeed for their definition of thernselves
label: Paragraph

text: as “civilized.” But as much magic as they
label: Paragraph

text: worked on the human imagination, these
label: Paragraph

text: cities’ experimental nature should not be
label: Paragraph

text: forgotten. Cities were made; they were also
label: Paragraph

text: made to be destroyed. The Chinese, in fact,
label: Paragraph

text: would continuously destroy their cities; with a
label: Paragraph

text: new dynasty, the old capital was often burned
label: Paragraph

text: or leveled and the inhabitants forced to
label: Paragraph

text: relocate. The Mesopotamians and Egyptians
label: Paragraph

text: glorified their destruction of enemy cities, and
label: Paragraph

text: so it went on—until even today.
label: Paragraph

text: Although urban densities were able to pull
label: Paragraph

text: a large amount of resources into their orbits,
label: Paragraph

text: around 3500 BCE they constituted only a tiny
label: Paragraph

text: percentage of the world population, maybe as
label: Paragraph

text: small as .001 percent. Most people lived in
label: Paragraph

text: spread-out village societies, and many more
label: Paragraph

text: lived in a world with no agriculture at all, as
label: Paragraph

text: humans had for hundreds of thousands of
label: Paragraph

text: years.
label: Paragraph

text: BEGINNINGS OF CHINA’S
label: Title

text: CIVILIZATIONS
label: Title

text: In China, the shift to an agricultural/village
label: Paragraph

text: world took place around 9000 BCE. There
label: Paragraph

text: was, however, no single “origin” of Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: civilization. Instead, there was a gradual
label: Paragraph

text: multinucleated development taking place
label: Title

text: somewhat independently at first, with the
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis to the south on rice and to the
label: Paragraph

text: north on millet and pigs. Rice grew wild
label: Paragraph

text: and was then domesticated on the swampy
label: Paragraph

text: shores and in the delta of the Yangtze River.
label: Paragraph

text: Millet, which prefers a cooler climate, grows
label: Paragraph

text: wild on hillsides, where it over time was
label: Paragraph

text: also domesticated. Pigs played a role in
label: Paragraph

text: village life from early times and, along with
label: Paragraph

text: sheep, were introduced to northern cultures
label: Paragraph

text: by 5000 BCE, if not earlier. By 4000 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: especially in the north, small but well-
label: Paragraph

text: organized regional cormmunities emerged.
label: Paragraph

text: These included the Hongshan Culture
label: Paragraph

text: 4700-2900 BCE) to the north of Bohai Bay
label: Paragraph

text: in Inner Mongolia and Hebai Province, and
label: Paragraph

text: the Yangshao Culture (5000-3000 BCE) in
label: Paragraph

text: Henan Province. Geographically between the
label: Paragraph

text: two, and developing later, was the Longshan
label: Paragraph

text: Culture (3000-2000 BCE) in the central
label: Paragraph

text: and lower areas of the Yellow River. The
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of walls around communities is a
label: Paragraph

text: clear indication that the political landscape
label: Paragraph

text: was very much in flux. To the north, villages
label: Paragraph

text: were generally composed of pit houses
label: Paragraph

text: that, whether large or small, trace their
label: Paragraph

text: ancestry back to 20,000 BCE and possibly
label: Paragraph

text: earlier. Pit houses were used throughout
label: Paragraph

text: Inner Asia by steppe hunters. People to the
label: Paragraph

text: south developed houses on stilts, a natural
label: Paragraph

text: response to the swampy soil of the rice
label: Title

text: paddies.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: earlier.

text: Another structure of interest to archaeologists

text: valley. On the ground level, the mound is
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: was placed near the top. Artifacts found
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: clay crucibles used for smelting copper.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the top of a hill is a surprising place
label: Paragraph

text: to melt copper, the structure seems to have
label: Paragraph

text: been meant for ritual events. Burial grounds
label: Paragraph

text: on hills seem to mark the north and south
label: Paragraph

text: extremes of the moonrise in the east. All
label: Paragraph

text: in all, this center contains the essential
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: In the valleys of the Yellow River we see
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of several compact villages,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Banpo (near the modern-day city of
label: Paragraph

text: Xi'an), which dates to about 4500 BCE and
label: Paragraph

text: was part of the Yangshao Culture. It was
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by a ditch or moat 5 to 6 meters
label: Paragraph

text: wide, probably for drainage and defense. The
label: Paragraph

text: homes were circular structures of mud and
label: Paragraph

text: wood with overhanging thatched roofs, all
label: Paragraph

text: raised on shallow foundations with fire pits at
label: Caption

text: the center. Entrance ramps sloped down into
label: Paragraph

text: the dwelling. Such pit houses, with furs lying
label: Paragraph

text: on the floors and hanging from the inner walls
label: Paragraph

text: for insulation, were comfortable places to live.
label: Paragraph

text: If the timber bears could be kept dry and the
label: Paragraph

text: thatch was properly maintained, a pit house
label: Paragraph

text: could last twenty years. The dead were buried
label: Paragraph

text: in the back of nearby sacred caves or in
label: Paragraph

text: simple pits outside the village in a communal
label: Paragraph

text: burial area. The remains of children, it seems,
label: Paragraph

text: were interred in urns just outside their homes.
label: Paragraph

text: Within the town there were large open plazas
label: Paragraph

text: and storage holes, and at the center of the
label: Paragraph

text: village was a large house, presumed a clan
label: Paragraph

text: or community center, which was built of a
label: Paragraph

text: heavy timber construction. One area of the
label: Paragraph

text: village was dedicated to the production of
label: Paragraph

text: pottery, indicating the emergence of craft
label: Paragraph

text: specialization. Pottery was used not only in
label: Paragraph

text: daily life but also in mortuary rituals.

text: In terms of religion, the Hongshan and
label: Paragraph

text: Yangshao cultures were shamanistic. A
label: Paragraph

text: shaman is an intermediary between the
label: Paragraph

text: natural and the spiritual worlds who travels
label: Title

text: between these worlds in a trance. A tomb
label: Paragraph

text: at Puyang, dating from about 4000 BCE, is
label: Paragraph

text: likely that of a shaman priest. It was made
label: Paragraph

text: in the shape of a single, squarish room with
label: Paragraph

text: a lobed space at the rear. A man was buried
label: Paragraph

text: in the pounded earth floor, flanked by a
label: Paragraph

text: dragon on one side and a tiger on the other,
label: Paragraph

text: both painstakingly and beautifully made of
label: Paragraph

text: hundreds of shells. Dragons and tigers, still
label: Paragraph

text: central to Chinese Confucian symbolism,
label: Paragraph

text: are considered to be prospectors in both
label: Paragraph

text: life and death. Hill ranges, especially those
label: Paragraph

text: with prominent peaks, are considered to be
label: Paragraph

text: dragons.
label: Paragraph

text: Along the Yangtze River, farrners had
label: Paragraph

text: developed rice as their prime staple by
label: Paragraph

text: around 5000 BCE, if not earlier. It was a
label: Paragraph

text: labor-intensive crop that required level fields
label: Paragraph

text: and the precise monitoring of water levels.
label: Paragraph

text: The first culture to master rice farming was
label: Paragraph

text: the Hemudu. Given the swampy nature
label: Paragraph

text: of the land, the people at Hernudu built
label: Paragraph

text: elevated houses that served for both living
label: Paragraph

text: and storage. The houses were also ritual
label: Paragraph

text: centers. This house type was introduced by
label: Paragraph

text: rice growers to other parts of the world, most
label: Paragraph

text: notably to Japan and the Philippines.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: (3400-2250 BCE), located in the Yangtze
label: Paragraph

text: River delta, we see the emergence of

label: Title

text: Though evidence of the Neolithic occupation
label: Paragraph

text: of India dates back to 10,000 BCE, settled
label: Paragraph

text: cultures began to emerge around 7000
label: Paragraph

text: BCE, in the eastern hills of the Baluchistan
label: Paragraph

text: Mountains in today’s Pakistan. It was an
label: Paragraph

text: agropastoral environment typical for the age,
label: Paragraph

text: allowing farming along the slopes above the
label: Paragraph

text: river, herding in the flat lands of the valley,
label: Paragraph

text: and hunting in the hills and mountains.
label: Paragraph

text: Around 6500 BCE, one community seemed
label: Paragraph

text: to rise in importance and became the first in
label: Paragraph

text: a long line of proto-urban environments that
label: Paragraph

text: were soon to grow here. Known as Mehrgarh,
label: Paragraph

text: it was strategically located overlooking the
label: Paragraph

text: Kachi Plain southeast of modern Quetta
label: Paragraph

text: near the Bolan Pass, an important gateway
label: Paragraph

text: connecting South Asia to the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: continent. Its five-thousand-year history
label: Paragraph

text: can be traced from a village to a regional
label: Paragraph

text: trading center that covered, at the peak of its
label: Paragraph

text: development, an area of 200 hectares.
label: Paragraph

text: By 3500 BCE, its occupants had mastered
label: Paragraph

text: extensive grain cultivation. Dominating the
label: Paragraph

text: urban landscape were mud-brick buildings
label: Paragraph

text: presumed to be granaries, designed as multi-
label: Paragraph

text: roomed rectangular structures with a long
label: Paragraph

text: narrow corridor running more or less down
label: Title

text: the center. The absence of doors suggests
label: Paragraph

text: that grain was fed from the top, as it would
label: Paragraph

text: be into a silo.
label: Paragraph

text: MESOPOTAMIA AND THE BALKANS
label: Title

text: The shift to village-world farming took place
label: Paragraph

text: in the Levant around 9000 BCE. During a
label: Paragraph

text: few centuries of cold weather, two plants
label: Paragraph

text: in particular seemed to thrive, wheat and
label: Paragraph

text: barley. The locals figured out how to tend
label: Paragraph

text: these grasses into larger and larger patches.
label: Paragraph

text: This, combined with the domestication of
label: Paragraph

text: sheep and goats and the herding of cattle,
label: Title

text: produced a culture far different from that of
label: Paragraph

text: their ancestors. Ritual practices changed,
label: Paragraph

text: as did gender roles. Clan lineages became
label: Paragraph

text: important, and with clans there emerge
label: Paragraph

text: chieftains, who along with ritual specialists
label: Paragraph

text: managed the complex sequence of activities.
label: Paragraph

text: By 8000 BCE, a network of agropastoral
label: Paragraph

text: villages had forrned in the highlands of the
label: Paragraph

text: Levant and from there spread eastward into
label: Paragraph

text: the upland reaches above the Euphrates
label: Paragraph

text: River and even northward into the Balkans.
label: Paragraph

text: As village communities developed in
label: Paragraph

text: the hills of the Levant and overlooking
label: Title

text: the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers, one
label: Paragraph

text: commodity was sought after in particular:
label: Paragraph

text: obsidian. This black volcanic rock with
label: Paragraph

text: its sharp edges could be fashioned
label: Paragraph

text: into small blades that were attached to
label: Paragraph

text: sickles. The result was a much faster
label: Paragraph

text: harvesting time. The problem was that
label: Paragraph

text: obsidian was a rare commodity that
label: Paragraph

text: came from the mountains in Anatolia.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: moved across rooftops and descended into

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: from Catal Hilyiik
label: Title

text: The principal deity was the mother
label: Paragraph

text: goddess. Figurine representations of her,
label: Paragraph

text: made of a variety of materials, have been
label: Paragraph

text: found throughout the village. One statue,
label: Caption

text: remarkable for its bold three-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: design, is of a voluminous seated wornan
label: Paragraph

text: giving birth. The chair on which she sits has
label: Paragraph

text: armrests in the shape of lions. The figurine
label: Caption

text: represented fecundity and regeneration,
label: Paragraph

text: and was part of the widespread mother-
label: Paragraph

text: goddess worship typical of European and
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean late Stone Age and early
label: Title

text: Bronze Age societies.
label: Paragraph

text: Catal HUyUk was at the northern end
label: Paragraph

text: of a zone of developing urbanization that
label: Paragraph

text: reached from Jericho (in Israel) to Tell Aswad
label: Paragraph

text: (in Syria) and Susa (in Iran). Jericho was a
label: Paragraph

text: major city—probably the largest in the whole
label: Paragraph

text: area. Like Catal Hiiyik, it had the benefit of
label: Paragraph

text: local mines. Susa had the benefit of a well-
label: Paragraph

text: established network of nearby villages in the
label: Paragraph

text: Zagros Mountains, which constituted a close
label: Paragraph

text: supply of metals. The Karun River, a river no
label: Paragraph

text: less important than the Tigris and Euphrates,
label: Paragraph

text: connected the city to the world at large;
label: Paragraph

text: grains, figs, and lemons were raised in the
label: Paragraph

text: river's broad valley.
label: Paragraph

text: Tell es-Sawwan
label: Title

text: The climate in Mesopotamia back then was
label: Paragraph

text: cooler than it is today, meaning that the
label: Paragraph

text: verdant valleys of the Tigris and Euphrates
label: Paragraph

text: Rivers were far different from the deserts
label: Paragraph

text: found in the region today; in the highlands,
label: Paragraph

text: forests were interspersed with steppes and
label: Paragraph

text: savannas rich in flora and abounding with
label: Paragraph

text: goats, boars, deer, and foxes. Farmers
label: Paragraph

text: worked in the valley, but the community lived
label: Paragraph

text: in the more easily fortifiable hills. Shepherds
label: Paragraph

text: lived in the steppe regions between the farms
label: Paragraph

text: and the deserts. In the areas around the
label: Paragraph

text: Black Sea, one would have found a similar
label: Paragraph

text: fabric of habitation, except there the locals
label: Paragraph

text: discovered that their hills contained obsidian,
label: Paragraph

text: copper, and salt, which became important
label: Paragraph

text: commodities for trade. Around 5000 BCE the
label: Paragraph

text: two worlds cohered into recognizable cultural
label: Title

text: formations: the Vinca in Romania and the
label: Title

text: Samarra in Iraq. A few places stood out, like
label: Paragraph

text: Jericho (in Israel) and Tell Aswad (in Syria,
label: Paragraph

text: 30 kilometers east-southeast of Damascus),
label: Paragraph

text: which were larger than the rest. Also
label: Paragraph

text: important was Catal HUytk in Turkey, which
label: Paragraph

text: was a key source of obsidian, a volcanic glass
label: Paragraph

text: that was needed for sickle blades.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most important groupings
label: Paragraph

text: of villages dating from this period (6000-
label: Paragraph

text: 3500 BCE) was located just to the east of
label: Paragraph

text: a rain-fed agricultural zone that arches
label: Paragraph

text: northeastward from the northern tip of the
label: Paragraph

text: Persian Gulf along the flanks of the Zagros
label: Title

text: Mountains. Among these settlements was
label: Paragraph

text: Tell es-Sawwan, on the left bank of the Tigris
label: Caption

text: near Samarra. It started as a small village
label: Paragraph

text: that became fortified, growing over time into
label: Paragraph

text: a substantial community. The plan shows a
label: Paragraph

text: clear hierarchy, with the important buildings
label: Paragraph

text: in the southern half. The central building is
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrical and has a hall or corridor down
label: Paragraph

text: the center; it was built at a later stage in
label: Paragraph

text: the development of the village. Its purpose
label: Paragraph

text: is unknown, but it was possibly a granary.
label: Paragraph

text: There are about seven or eight houses that
label: Paragraph

text: have nearby areas for sheep and goats. The
label: Paragraph

text: basic building material was mud and timber;
label: Paragraph

text: the mud was mixed with reeds and dried in
label: Paragraph

text: a mold to create bricks, an innovation that
label: Paragraph

text: remains a characteristic of the region even
label: Paragraph

text: today. Rooms were rectilinear, measuring,
label: Paragraph

text: on average, about 1.5 by 2 meters. The
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal roofs were made of beams of oak
label: Paragraph

text: on which were placed a layer of branches
label: Paragraph

text: and reeds sealed with mud, bitumen, and
label: Paragraph

text: gypsum. The interior wall surfaces were
label: Paragraph

text: decorated with gypsum plaster, which
label: Paragraph

text: had been developed as early as 7000 BCE
label: Paragraph

text: and which was to remain a central part of
label: Paragraph

text: building construction in the entire area.
label: Paragraph

text: From the extensive outcrops of rock gypsum
label: Paragraph

text: in northern Iraq and Syria, stone blocks
label: Paragraph

text: were mined, stacked, and burnt to form
label: Paragraph

text: an easily transportable white powder. This
label: Paragraph

text: building material was not only used locally
label: Paragraph

text: but also exported as a trade commodity.
label: Paragraph

text: The development of trade in craft goods,
label: Paragraph

text: pottery, building materials, and metal objects
label: Title

text: stimulated the economies of the region and
label: Paragraph

text: played a central part in its drift toward craft
label: Paragraph

text: specialization and urbanization. The Samarra
label: Paragraph

text: Culture produced abundant grain, which was
label: Paragraph

text: then exported to surrounding regions.
label: Paragraph

text: Though we often think of the Tigris and
label: Paragraph

text: Euphrates region as the birthplace of urban
label: Paragraph

text: civilization, the truth is that civilization—if
label: Paragraph

text: that complex and awkward word can be
label: Paragraph

text: used, at least in this area—was the product
label: Paragraph

text: of a combined culture in which some people
label: Paragraph

text: raised grain while others built mines. The
label: Paragraph

text: oft repeated image of Mesopotamia as a
label: Paragraph

text: “Fertile Crescent” is flawed if one does not
label: Paragraph

text: add the Metal Crescent that embraced it. In
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamia, grain and metal were mutually
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcing commodities. The principal
label: Paragraph

text: copper-producing areas stretched from the
label: Paragraph

text: Caspian Sea through Anatolia and around the
label: Title

text: Black Sea.
label: Paragraph

text: An important early Copper Age society,
label: Paragraph

text: known as the Vinca Culture, flourished from
label: Paragraph

text: 5500 to 4000 BCE in an area that stretches
label: Paragraph

text: from present-day Bosnia to Romania.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas the Mesopotamians developed mud-
label: Paragraph

text: brick walls covered with plaster to protect
label: Paragraph

text: the walls against moisture, the Vinca lived in
label: Paragraph

text: freestanding rectangular houses with walls
label: Caption

text: made of wattle and daub. The roofs were
label: Paragraph

text: pitched and made of thatch. Their ritual
label: Paragraph

text: world was intense. The Vinca had house
label: Paragraph

text: shrines with an assortment of strangely
label: Paragraph

text: carved deities that governed fertility and that
label: Paragraph

text: spoke to the ancestors or gave omens.
label: Paragraph

text: 1.27 Vinca statuette
label: Caption

text: The Taurus Mountains in eastern Anatolia,
label: Paragraph

text: known for their tin mines, played an equally
label: Paragraph

text: important part in the West Asian economy,
label: Paragraph

text: since tin was needed, along with copper,
label: Paragraph

text: to make bronze. Though there were many
label: Paragraph

text: copper-producing areas, tin was more rare.
label: Paragraph

text: An ancient tin mine was discovered at a site
label: Paragraph

text: named Géltepe, which was a large village
label: Paragraph

text: from around 3290 to 1840 BCE. The miners,
label: Paragraph

text: using narrow shafts, brought cassiterite
label: Paragraph

text: ore to the surface, where it was crushed,
label: Paragraph

text: washed, and smelted with charcoal in small
label: Paragraph

text: crucibles rather than in the large furnaces
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of copper-smelting sites. By
label: Paragraph

text: measuring the enormous deposits of slag
label: Paragraph

text: (600,000 tons in one pile), researchers have
label: Paragraph

text: ascertained that this was a major site during
label: Paragraph

text: much of the early and middle Bronze Age.
label: Paragraph

text: Metal began to play an important part in
label: Paragraph

text: international relations in the third millennium
label: Title

text: BCE. Around 2350 BCE, Sargon of Akkad
label: Caption

text: invaded Anatolia from his lowland base to
label: Paragraph

text: secure trade routes. In records that have
label: Paragraph

text: been found, he boasts that a single caravan
label: Paragraph

text: carried about 12 tons of tin, which can make
label: Paragraph

text: 125 tons of bronze—enough to equip a large
label: Paragraph

text: army. Today it is widely accepted that mining
label: Paragraph

text: was responsible for vast deforestation and
label: Paragraph

text: played an important part in the desertification
label: Paragraph

text: of western Asia.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Eridu and Uruk
label: Title

text: With this in mind we can now better
label: Paragraph

text: understand the rise of the first cities in the
label: Paragraph

text: marshes of the Tigris and Euphrates areas.
label: Paragraph

text: Though villages spanned the area from
label: Paragraph

text: the Levant into northern Syrian and Iraq,
label: Paragraph

text: few people ventured into these marshes,
label: Paragraph

text: overgrown with tall reeds, useful for boats
label: Paragraph

text: and thatching but little more. It was an
label: Paragraph

text: extreme landscape that had no lumber for
label: Paragraph

text: roof beams, and no metal or even stone. But
label: Paragraph

text: around 5000 BCE we see the first atternpts
label: Paragraph

text: to transform this landscape. Societies gave
label: Paragraph

text: up their partial dependency on an integrated
label: Paragraph

text: farming-hunting lifestyle and concentrated
label: Title

text: on farming alone, the aim being to produce
label: Paragraph

text: huge grain surpluses that would be traded
label: Paragraph

text: for other things. These cities were not secular
label: Paragraph

text: adventures. They were built at the command
label: Paragraph

text: of the deities who in a sense sponsored these
label: Paragraph

text: — Older agricultural area
label: Title

text: ee coastline
label: Title

text: surplus-making enterprises. In Mesopotamian
label: Paragraph

text: mythology it was never the humans who
label: Paragraph

text: created cities, but the gods themselves.
label: Paragraph

text: But back in the realm of the humans,
label: Paragraph

text: the making of these places did go hand in
label: Paragraph

text: hand with technical advances. The Tigris
label: Paragraph

text: and Euphrates, unlike the Nile, flooded
label: Paragraph

text: before the harvest, in April and May; this
label: Paragraph

text: had made lower-lying reaches unusable for
label: Paragraph

text: agriculture. But sedimentation brought by the
label: Paragraph

text: rivers tended to build up natural levees that
label: Paragraph

text: farmers could reinforce, allowing the canal
label: Paragraph

text: bed to become somewhat higher than the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding countryside. Farmers could then
label: Paragraph

text: make openings in the levees to feed water
label: Paragraph

text: into the irrigation channels, as they still do
label: Paragraph

text: today. Aerial photography has recently proven
label: Paragraph

text: the extensive nature of these ancient canals
label: Paragraph

text: and dikes, some of them more than 100
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers in length.
label: Paragraph

text: 1.30 Temple atop the stone-faced platform at Eridu, near Abu Shahrain, Iran
label: Caption

text: The relationship with the rivers was a
label: Paragraph

text: delicate and dangerous one. The systern was
label: Paragraph

text: vulnerable to flood, war, and neglect. Records
label: Paragraph

text: from Ur deal repeatedly with repair work.
label: Paragraph

text: But the investment was worth the effort. In a
label: Paragraph

text: few centuries the area became an economic
label: Paragraph

text: engine unparalleled anywhere in the world
label: Title

text: except in Egypt. Though these cities are
label: Paragraph

text: discussed in relationship to advances in
label: Paragraph

text: agriculture, what we really see are cities
label: Paragraph

text: serving by necessity as export and import
label: Paragraph

text: centers.
label: Paragraph

text: Eridu and Uruk were, in a sense, modern
label: Paragraph

text: cities dependent on a single economy of
label: Paragraph

text: grain, requiring the control and movement
label: Paragraph

text: of goods. It thus stands to reason that it was
label: Paragraph

text: here that the wheel came into its full use
label: Paragraph

text: to haul loads over long distances, and that
label: Paragraph

text: standardized weights were invented at this
label: Paragraph

text: time. Another innovation was one of the great
label: Paragraph

text: civilizational achievernents: writing, which
label: Paragraph

text: was put to practical use to record trade
label: Paragraph

text: transactions and keep up with inventory.
label: Paragraph

text: Concomitant with this was the development of
label: Paragraph

text: a legal and archival system. Evidence of the
label: Paragraph

text: impact this made can be found in vestigial
label: Paragraph

text: remnants of words deeply embedded in our
label: Paragraph

text: present-day language. In Ur, the ancient title
label: Paragraph

text: designating “king” is /uga/, which is probably
label: Paragraph

text: the origin of the Latin word fex (“law”) and
label: Paragraph

text: the English word /ega/. And another ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamian word, pala, referring to the
label: Paragraph

text: garment of kingship, constitutes the root of
label: Paragraph

text: our word palace.
label: Paragraph

text: We see the emergence of a cormplex religious
label: Paragraph

text: world in tune with the equally complex life of
label: Paragraph

text: urban civilization. The mother goddess, who
label: Paragraph

text: had ruled in many places throughout Eurasia,
label: Paragraph

text: now had to compete with an expanding list of
label: Paragraph

text: divine presences—including powerful male
label: Title

text: gods who tied society firmly into a network of
label: Paragraph

text: obligations. Significantly, the mother goddess
label: Paragraph

text: Apsu, who controlled the oceans, was “killed”
label: Paragraph

text: by her son Ea, earth, who divided her unruly
label: Paragraph

text: waters into chambers. Concurrent with the
label: Paragraph

text: shift was the emergence of a priestly class
label: Paragraph

text: responsible for all aspects of society, from
label: Paragraph

text: religion to administration to technology. The
label: Paragraph

text: priestly class was responsible not only for
label: Paragraph

text: the proper communication with the deities
label: Title

text: through food sacrifices and ritual events, but
label: Paragraph

text: were also the architects of increasingly larger
label: Paragraph

text: buildings to stage their power.
label: Paragraph

text: The culture that first began to master
label: Paragraph

text: the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers as early as
label: Paragraph

text: 5000 BCE was known as the Ubaid. Around
label: Paragraph

text: 3000 BCE, they were superseded by the
label: Paragraph

text: Sumerians, who were to no small degree the
label: Paragraph

text: first modernizers, replacing old and well-
label: Paragraph

text: established traditions with new and better-
label: Paragraph

text: organized ones. Eridu was located on the
label: Paragraph

text: banks of the Euphrates in the delta, which
label: Paragraph

text: has since silted up so that the ancient site is
label: Paragraph

text: now located 90 kilometers inland. Originally,
label: Paragraph

text: however, Eridu had easy access to boats
label: Paragraph

text: coming up from the south.
label: Paragraph

text: 1.32 Temple XVI-XVIII at Eridu
label: Caption

text: The temple at Eridu was rebuilt seventeen
label: Paragraph

text: times (4500-3800 BCE), with each effort
label: Paragraph

text: built directly over the earlier one, and with
label: Paragraph

text: each one being bigger and taller, resulting in
label: Paragraph

text: a massive building, a veritable mountain of
label: Paragraph

text: bricks. The earliest temple was a sirnple box
label: Paragraph

text: with an altar at the back and an oven outside
label: Paragraph

text: in the front, where sacred bread offerings
label: Paragraph

text: were prepared. The last ternple, positioned
label: Paragraph

text: on an enormous plinth of clay bricks, was
label: Paragraph

text: painted in vibrant colors and was visible for
label: Paragraph

text: miles. It had a form defined by rhythmically
label: Paragraph

text: spaced buttresses, and though roughly
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular in shape, it had an irregular
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter. A flight of steps at the center of the
label: Paragraph

text: broader side led up to the entrance, where
label: Paragraph

text: a shallow vestibule gave access to a large
label: Paragraph

text: central room oriented lengthwise. Ancillary
label: Caption

text: spaces, probably used as reliquaries, were
label: Paragraph

text: located at the corners.
label: Paragraph

text: a

label: Caption

text: The chief deity was Ea, son of the mother
label: Paragraph

text: goddess Apsu; he was not only an earth god
label: Paragraph

text: but also manifest in “sweet waters.” He was
label: Paragraph

text: seen as crafty, for he “avoids rather than
label: Paragraph

text: surmounts obstacles, goes round and yet gets
label: Paragraph

text: to his goal.” Ea, who in some accounts made
label: Paragraph

text: human beings by mixing his own essence
label: Paragraph

text: with that of his brother, Enlil (the earth and
label: Paragraph

text: storm god), was also worshipped as the god
label: Paragraph

text: of wisdom and as a friend to humankind.
label: Paragraph

text: Images of Ea show hirn wearing a cloak
label: Paragraph

text: of fish scales, and fish bones have been
label: Paragraph

text: discovered near the offering table at Eridu.
label: Caption

text: A text written somewhat later states that
label: Paragraph

text: When Ea rose, the fishes rose and adored
label: Paragraph

text: him,
label: Paragraph

text: He stood, a marvel unto the deep...
label: Paragraph

text: To the sea it seemed that awe was upon him;
label: Paragraph

text: To the Great River terror seemed to hover
label: Paragraph

text: around him

text: While the south wind stirred the depth of the
label: Paragraph

text: Euphrates.*
label: Paragraph

text: The Temple at Eridu served as a prototype
label: Paragraph

text: for later efforts: a statue made about a
label: Paragraph

text: thousand years later, in 2150 BCE, shows the
label: Paragraph

text: plan of a temple with similar attributes. It is
label: Paragraph

text: no sketch, but a precise plan with door and
label: Paragraph

text: pilasters drawn in, all to scale. It is placed
label: Paragraph

text: on the lap of King Gudea of Lagash and, in
label: Paragraph

text: its accuracy and precision, leaves no doubt
label: Paragraph

text: as to the planning that went into these early
label: Paragraph

text: temple designs. Its position on the king's
label: Paragraph

text: lap also proves that the plan was more than
label: Paragraph

text: just a convenience of the builders: it was an
label: Paragraph

text: expression of the claim to legitimacy of the
label: Paragraph

text: monarch and his sacrosanct function.

text: 1.34 A size comparison of Eridu, Susa, and Uruk
label: Caption

text: Uruk developed into a significant, large city
label: Paragraph

text: with a possible population of fifty thousand. It

label: Paragraph

text: PRE- AND EARLY DYNASTIC EGYPT
label: Title

text: North Africa was once a vast, fertile savanna
label: Paragraph

text: of scrub forests and pasturelands that was
label: Paragraph

text: populated by humans early on. It was here,
label: Paragraph

text: as we have seen at Nabta Playa, that cattle
label: Paragraph

text: were first domesticated. But in the sixth
label: Paragraph

text: millennium BCE, a dramatic warming affecting
label: Paragraph

text: the whole globe changed North Africa bit by
label: Paragraph

text: bit into the endless stretches of sand that we
label: Paragraph

text: now call the Sahara Desert. The populations
label: Paragraph

text: moved either westward to Morocco, Spain,
label: Paragraph

text: and beyond, or eastward to the banks of the
label: Paragraph

text: Nile. The density of the Nile River population
label: Paragraph

text: was unlike anything one would have seen
label: Paragraph

text: anywhere else in the world at that time;
label: Paragraph

text: that it did not overwhelm the social systern
label: Paragraph

text: was predicated on several conditions, one
label: Paragraph

text: being that the local elites quickly learned to
label: Paragraph

text: define themselves as divine, assuring the
label: Paragraph

text: mechanism by which to protect and isolate
label: Paragraph

text: their power. This meant that Egyptian religion
label: Paragraph

text: never went through a chthonic phase based
label: Title

text: on the mother goddesses and caves that
label: Paragraph

text: were common in many places in Eurasia and
label: Paragraph

text: the Mediterranean and that would thrive in
label: Paragraph

text: places like Crete and Malta for a long time.
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian religion was from the start a religion
label: Paragraph

text: for the elite alone. There were no epic tales
label: Paragraph

text: of communal destiny, but rather myths of
label: Paragraph

text: heroic actions of kings who passed the torch

text: Another factor that stabilized Egypt's

text: The tombs of the First Dynasty (3100-

text: important early city about 100 kilometers
label: Title

label: Caption

text: are outside of town under the face of an
label: Paragraph

text: imposing cliff. A gorge opens out dramatically
label: Paragraph

text: through the cliff at that spot and, according
label: Paragraph

text: to some scholars, this opening was regarded
label: Paragraph

text: as the entrance to the netherworld. The site
label: Paragraph

text: was accessed by a processional route from a
label: Paragraph

text: valley temple. The oldest tombs, of Narmer
label: Caption

text: and Aha, are rather simple brick-lined rooms
label: Paragraph

text: placed in the ground and covered with a
label: Paragraph

text: wooden roof at ground level. Aha’s tomb

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: were most likely large cuts of ox meat, as well
label: Paragraph

text: as freshly killed waterbirds, loaves of bread,
label: Paragraph

text: dried figs, and jars of beer or wine, each
label: Paragraph

text: bearing Aha’s official seal. Beside his tomb
label: Caption

text: more than thirty ancillary graves for servants
label: Caption

text: and animals were laid out in three neat rows.

text: The design and the decoration of these
label: Paragraph

text: tombs clearly anticipates the development
label: Paragraph

text: of the mastaba (from the Arabic word for
label: Paragraph

text: “bank”). The grandest was the tomb of King
label: Paragraph

text: Djed at Saqqara (ca. 3100 BCE), just outside
label: Paragraph

text: of Memphis. Some argue that the complex
label: Paragraph

text: niche pattern in the walls represented
label: Paragraph

text: wooden or reed construction; others have
label: Paragraph

text: suggested an influence from Mesopotamia
label: Paragraph

text: or the Near East. Only the five central
label: Paragraph

text: chambers, dug into the earth, constitute
label: Paragraph

text: the tomb. The whole was roofed over and
label: Paragraph

text: plastered to appear as a solid but colorful
label: Paragraph

text: plateau set against the sand. There was a
label: Paragraph

text: low bench surrounding the superstructure
label: Caption

text: at the base of the main exterior wall; on
label: Caption

text: this platform were laid about three hundred
label: Paragraph

text: clay-modeled bull's heads provided with real
label: Paragraph

text: horns. The facade was was painted white,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas the innermost panels of the large
label: Paragraph

text: niches were painted red.
label: Paragraph

text: In this early stage of Egyptian culture,
label: Paragraph

text: there was no temple architecture such as
label: Paragraph

text: one might find in the Mesopotamian cities,
label: Paragraph

text: where religious practices, highly visible
label: Paragraph

text: around the ziggurat temples, unified broad
label: Paragraph

text: swaths of society. Instead, architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: defining the interface between life and
label: Paragraph

text: death, was reserved for the elite. Its place
label: Paragraph

text: 1.40 Tomb of King Djed at Saqqara
label: Caption

text: in society was thus more limited, but its
label: Paragraph

text: purpose could not have been more drarnatic.
label: Paragraph

text: Death for the Chinese involved the handing
label: Title

text: down of family memories and could be
label: Title

text: articulated spatially with house shrines and
label: Paragraph

text: fragile wooden temples on earthen mounds.
label: Paragraph

text: In Egypt, death—in religious terms—was a
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic event only for the ruler, with his (or
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes her) spirit rising majestically over
label: Paragraph

text: the trivialities of domesticity and family in a
label: Title

text: specially constructed, simulated house with
label: Paragraph

text: all the accoutrements of a comfortable life.
label: Paragraph

text: What went on in that “house,” and how the
label: Paragraph

text: spirit moved about, ate, and drank, was a
label: Paragraph

text: matter of great concern, since it was thought
label: Paragraph

text: to determine the flow of history in the present
label: Paragraph

text: time and beyond. But the “house” was only
label: Paragraph

text: half of the equation. Death in Egypt had an
label: Paragraph

text: inside and an outside shape. Entombing the
label: Paragraph

text: “house” at the scale of the landscape was the
label: Paragraph

text: structure’s outside shape. Eighty percent of
label: Paragraph

text: King Djed's mastaba was nothing more than
label: Paragraph

text: a mass of walls and spaces linking these two
label: Paragraph

text: scales. The architect’s job, in essence, was
label: Paragraph

text: to bring the inner and outer manifestations of
label: Paragraph

text: the ruler’s death into unity.

text: EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENTS
label: Title

text: Europe's complex geography of shorelines,
label: Paragraph

text: rivers, and mountain ranges made it unlikely
label: Paragraph

text: that it would arrange itself into a single
label: Paragraph

text: civilizational unit like those in Egypt, China,
label: Paragraph

text: and India. Furthermore, because of the
label: Paragraph

text: difficulties of transplanting grain northward
label: Title

text: into different climatic regions, Europe was
label: Paragraph

text: only fully settled around 3500 BCE. Because
label: Paragraph

text: European cultures developed without the
label: Title

text: history of agricultural domestication, their
label: Title

text: focus was not on family matriarchal histories
label: Paragraph

text: through which such knowledge was, by
label: Paragraph

text: necessity, handed down, but on the clans
label: Paragraph

text: that could pull communities together for
label: Paragraph

text: defense, war, and trade. This explains why
label: Paragraph

text: 1.43 Passage grave on Ile Longue, South
label: Caption

text: Brittany, France, ca. 4100 BCE
label: Caption

text: the Europeans did not develop a temple
label: Paragraph

text: culture or, for that matter, a more complex
label: Paragraph

text: priestly culture until much later.
label: Paragraph

text: But unlike in Mesopotamia, where
label: Paragraph

text: death was still a relatively informal affair,
label: Paragraph

text: or in Egypt, where death-as-eternal-life
label: Paragraph

text: was in essence reserved for the elites, the
label: Paragraph

text: Europeans magnified death around clan
label: Title

text: lineages, building a variety of stone and
label: Paragraph

text: mound structures in places that preserved
label: Paragraph

text: clan memories and that served as places
label: Title

text: for ceremony, gathering, and trade. Barrow
label: Caption

text: tombs or passage graves, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of a passageway made of large
label: Paragraph

text: stones, sometimes ornamented with carvings
label: Paragraph

text: and paint and mounded over by tons of dirt
label: Paragraph

text: and clay. Examples can be found throughout
label: Paragraph

text: Europe—in Portugal, Sardinia, France, and
label: Paragraph

text: England, and as far north as Norway—as
label: Paragraph

text: well as in Morocco, and span the period
label: Paragraph

text: from 5000 BCE to 2500 BCE. The Portuguese
label: Paragraph

text: tombs are among the oldest. The ceilings of
label: Paragraph

text: some of the central chambers were corbelled
label: Paragraph

text: with stones placed closer and closer toward
label: Paragraph

text: the center of the space till they meet at the
label: Paragraph

text: top. An example of this can be found in the
label: Paragraph

text: passage grave on lle Longue, South Brittany,
label: Caption

text: Newgrange
label: Title

text: Of the various constructions that were made
label: Paragraph

text: in Europe at the time, few could compete
label: Paragraph

text: with the great mound of Newgrange, dating
label: Caption

text: to about 4000 BCE. But this was no tornb.
label: Paragraph

text: Basically it was a clock with one tick,
label: Paragraph

text: designed to mark the winter solstice at the
label: Paragraph

text: end of December, indicating the passage
label: Paragraph

text: of the season and the promise of a new
label: Title

text: beginning, while also serving as a particularly
label: Paragraph

text: powerful moment to access the spirit of
label: Paragraph

text: the ancestors. Thousands of people frorn
label: Paragraph

text: the various clans congregated at the site to
label: Paragraph

text: participate in dances, revelry, the buying and
label: Paragraph

text: selling of cattle, and, above all, memorial
label: Paragraph

text: services for the deceased. The structure was
label: Paragraph

text: not isolated but set in a sacred landscape
label: Paragraph

text: with various mounds in the vicinity, and
label: Paragraph

text: would be used for centuries to come. It was
label: Paragraph

text: sited on the western slope of the river Boyne.
