text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: By the beginning of the third millennium BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: the various river-oriented civilizations were
label: Paragraph

text: primed for rapid cultural developrnent. There
label: Paragraph

text: were at the time six principal cultural hubs:
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt, Mesopotamia, Margiana, the Indus,
label: Title

text: China, and Europe. In all these places, elites
label: Paragraph

text: emerged who ruled not just by force, but with
label: Paragraph

text: some form of divine or ancestral blessing.
label: Paragraph

text: Generally speaking, when things went well,
label: Paragraph

text: this was attributed to the gods; when things
label: Paragraph

text: went badly, this was seen as a sign of divine
label: Paragraph

text: displeasure.
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamian cities were the most
label: Paragraph

text: unusual since they were created in the
label: Paragraph

text: context of an extreme landscape of marshes
label: Paragraph

text: that were converted into agricultural land.
label: Paragraph

text: The first Mesopotamian cities can be
label: Paragraph

text: considered risk societies, based on the
label: Paragraph

text: gamble that producing huge surpluses
label: Paragraph

text: of grain would allow them to trade for
label: Paragraph

text: commodities that were not readily available.
label: Paragraph

text: The cities thus became ritual centers in
label: Paragraph

text: their own right, where the relationship to the
label: Paragraph

text: sacred was organized and mastered with
label: Paragraph

text: calendric precision. The elites who governed
label: Paragraph

text: the city were devotees of a complex pantheon
label: Paragraph

text: of gods who in turn “governed” all aspects
label: Paragraph

text: of nature, even human. The elites operated
label: Paragraph

text: in close alliance with a priestly class for
label: Paragraph

text: whom huge temples were built in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: artificial mountains rising in colorful terraces.
label: Paragraph

text: The ziggurats at Eridu and Ur were by far
label: Paragraph

text: the most extensive buildings of the age,
label: Paragraph

text: Arabian Sea
label: Title

text: testament to the wealth flowing to the cities.
label: Paragraph

text: They were prestige buildings, made just as
label: Paragraph

text: much by “deities” as by human labor. The
label: Paragraph

text: cities that were built around them consisted
label: Paragraph

text: of a dense fabric of houses. Most buildings
label: Paragraph

text: were made of mud brick with wooden roofs.
label: Paragraph

text: Outside the walls, along the canals, one
label: Paragraph

text: would have found a vast network of small
label: Paragraph

text: villages that were controlled by the temple.
label: Paragraph

text: But these cities had limits on how far their
label: Paragraph

text: authority could reach, and so they existed
label: Paragraph

text: in tense alliances with similar cities up and
label: Paragraph

text: down the river.
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt, less prone to invasion, developed
label: Paragraph

text: a clear dynastic power structure and a
label: Paragraph

text: consistent set of religious traditions from an
label: Paragraph

text: early age. Furthermore, due to the seasonality
label: Paragraph

text: of local agriculture, farm workers could be
label: Paragraph

text: summoned by the pharaohs to perform
label: Paragraph

text: forced labor on building projects. Zoser's
label: Paragraph

text: mortuary temple, built on an unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: scale, was one of the first monumental stone
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in the world. The mastery of stone
label: Paragraph

text: masonry is one of Egypt's great contributions
label: Paragraph

text: to architecture. The expansive mortuary
label: Paragraph

text: complex answered to the intricate cosmology
label: Paragraph

text: used by its Egyptian elites. The building was
label: Paragraph

text: made for a dead pharaoh who was deemed
label: Paragraph

text: to be still “alive” and thus in need of the
label: Paragraph

text: illusion of rulership in perpetuity. His spirit
label: Paragraph

text: was embodied in a statue, called the Ka
label: Paragraph

text: statue, which was ritually fed and housed in
label: Paragraph

text: a special chamber so that he could see the
label: Paragraph

text: western sunset through a small hole.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, around 2500 BCE, people moved
label: Paragraph

text: down from the Baluchistan Hills and settled
label: Paragraph

text: in the river valleys that define the eastern
label: Paragraph

text: edge of the South Asian subcontinent—those
label: Title

text: of the Indus and the now dried-up Ghaggar-
label: Paragraph

text: Hakra Rivers. The Indus/Ghaggar-Hakra
label: Paragraph

text: region was the first urban civilization in
label: Paragraph

text: the true sense of the word. The reason for
label: Paragraph

text: its success is obvious. The 900-kilometer-
label: Paragraph

text: long valley is hemmed in to the north
label: Paragraph

text: and south by vast stretches of dry and
label: Paragraph

text: rainless mountains and deserts. One can
label: Paragraph

text: imagine it as a linear oasis. Irrigation here
label: Paragraph

text: was easier than in Mesopotamia, and the
label: Paragraph

text: plentiful supply of trees allowed for the early
label: Paragraph

text: development of fired bricks that withstood
label: Paragraph

text: the ravages of water better than mud brick.
label: Paragraph

text: More than a thousand cities and towns have
label: Paragraph

text: been discovered spread over 650,000 square
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers, an area roughly equivalent to that
label: Paragraph

text: of modern-day France. Though these cities
label: Paragraph

text: were distant frorn each other, they shared
label: Paragraph

text: a common language and a standardized
label: Title

text: system of weights and measures. Thousands
label: Paragraph

text: of terra-cotta seals depicting a wide range
label: Caption

text: of human, animal, and mythical forms have
label: Paragraph

text: been found, each with distinctive markings
label: Paragraph

text: that are presumably letters of an alphabet.
label: Paragraph

text: The inhabitants, about whom we still know
label: Paragraph

text: very little, seemed to have called themselves
label: Paragraph

text: something akin to Meluhha. That, at least, is
label: Paragraph

text: what the contemporaneous Mesopotamians
label: Title

text: called therm. Ships carried bricks, beads,
label: Paragraph

text: lumber, metals, and lapis lazuli up the
label: Paragraph

text: Persian Gulf to the cities of Mesopotamia,
label: Paragraph

text: where such items were scarce. The nature
label: Paragraph

text: of the return freight is uncertain, since few
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamian objects have been found at
label: Paragraph

text: the Indus. The area between Mesopotamia
label: Paragraph

text: and the Indus was also urbanized with cities
label: Paragraph

text: such as Tepe Yaha and Jiroft, in the once
label: Paragraph

text: fertile and expansive Soghun Valley. Tepe
label: Caption

text: Yaha specialized in mining a highly desired
label: Paragraph

text: stone used to make ritual bowls. Not far
label: Paragraph

text: away was Jiroft, an even larger city, which
label: Paragraph

text: specialized in the production of highly prized,
label: Paragraph

text: golden-flecked lapis lazuli.
label: Paragraph

text: This Zone of Interconnection was linked to
label: Paragraph

text: a fourth civilizational area that had been
label: Paragraph

text: developing around the Oxus River and was
label: Paragraph

text: known as the Adronovo Culture. It was
label: Paragraph

text: based at first around small villages, but two
label: Paragraph

text: large cities were eventually built (in today's
label: Paragraph

text: Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan) that were
label: Paragraph

text: not only of great size but were designed
label: Paragraph

text: with great geometrical precision. The area,
label: Paragraph

text: drawing on the steppe landscape of inner
label: Paragraph

text: Asia, was a center of extensive pastoral
label: Paragraph

text: communities.
label: Paragraph

text: In China the first recorded dynasty, the
label: Paragraph

text: Xia dynasty, emerged around 2100 BCE. We
label: Paragraph

text: find there a horizontal civilization of villages
label: Paragraph

text: and towns unified around palace centers.
label: Paragraph

text: One of these was Erlitou (1900-1500 BCE).
label: Paragraph

text: Lying on the Yi River, a tributary of the Luo
label: Paragraph

text: River, Erlitou was located at the foothills of
label: Paragraph

text: the mountains and served as an interface
label: Paragraph

text: zone between the mountain area rich in
label: Paragraph

text: ore and the plains rich in grain. The palace
label: Paragraph

text: complex was surrounded by a 2-meter-thick
label: Paragraph

text: rammed earth wall that set it apart as an
label: Paragraph

text: ancestral ceremonial center for the elites. The
label: Paragraph

text: elites made extensive rituals that required
label: Paragraph

text: vessels and other instruments. This meant
label: Paragraph

text: that craftspeople lived near the palaces.
label: Paragraph

text: In this way, cities emerged not as temple
label: Paragraph

text: economies as in Mesopotamia, but as a
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of palace economies. In both
label: Paragraph

text: cases, small elites ruled over large swaths of
label: Paragraph

text: population because of their association with
label: Paragraph

text: the gods and ancestral deities. But whereas
label: Paragraph

text: in Mesopotamia important ritual events were
label: Paragraph

text: something on the order of public spectacles,
label: Paragraph

text: in China such rituals garnered esteem
label: Paragraph

text: because they were highly private.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, Europe, between about 5000,
label: Paragraph

text: and 3500 BCE, had slowly transformed into
label: Paragraph

text: an agropastoral world of interconnected
label: Title

text: villages. Large polities never developed,
label: Paragraph

text: meaning that there was no centralization
label: Paragraph

text: of power and nothing that could be called
label: Title

text: cities. It was a world still governed by
label: Paragraph

text: sacred landscapes and ancestor rituals. The
label: Paragraph

text: most famous sites are Carnac in France,
label: Paragraph

text: Stonehenge in England, and Newgrange in
label: Paragraph

text: Ireland. But there were hundreds of lesser
label: Paragraph

text: sites, from Scotland south to Portugal.
label: Paragraph

text: Around 2800 BCE commenced the spread
label: Paragraph

text: of the Beaker People, whose origins are still
label: Paragraph

text: debated but who most likely came from the
label: Paragraph

text: Balkans. They are named after their culture's
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive pottery drinking vessels. Known for
label: Paragraph

text: their advanced metalworking skill, the Beaker
label: Paragraph

text: People left their traces in various locations.
label: Paragraph

text: They arrived in England, where they
label: Paragraph

text: encountered such sites as Stonehenge, which
label: Paragraph

text: they took over and redesigned, orienting it
label: Paragraph

text: to the sun rather than to the moon. While
label: Paragraph

text: physically this was largely a matter of
label: Paragraph

text: fine-tuning, the cultural implications this
label: Paragraph

text: reorientation presupposes are imponderable.
label: Paragraph

text: Stonehenge, since 3000 BCE, when the
label: Paragraph

text: first stone circle was built, becarne a huge
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial zone attracting people from
label: Paragraph

text: far afield. There they awaited the sacred
label: Paragraph

text: moment of winter solstice, when contact
label: Paragraph

text: with ancestors was most propitious. Far
label: Paragraph

text: to the south, on the island of Malta in the
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean, emerged an astonishing
label: Paragraph

text: culture that built large “caves” mounded over
label: Paragraph

text: with tons of earth. The small island eventually
label: Paragraph

text: had a dozen or so of these structures,
label: Paragraph

text: probably used as places where supplicants,
label: Paragraph

text: under the spell of singing and hallucinogenic
label: Title

text: drugs, would experience dream visions. Since
label: Paragraph

text: there were many more of these temples than
label: Paragraph

text: the local population could possibly need, it is
label: Paragraph

text: quite likely that this was a sacred landscape
label: Paragraph

text: that also served people from surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean communities, who would
label: Paragraph

text: arrive by boat. Stonehenge and Malta
label: Caption

text: represent the last such sacred landscapes.
label: Paragraph

text: In other places, the ritual world was being
label: Paragraph

text: pulled increasingly toward the city. In fact, the
label: Paragraph

text: great accomplishment of the Mesopotamian
label: Title

text: cultures was precisely to equate city with
label: Paragraph

text: ritual center.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from an agropastoral zone that
label: Paragraph

text: stretched west to east just below the Sahara
label: Paragraph

text: Desert, the rest of Africa was still First
label: Paragraph

text: Society, as was all of the Americas. But
label: Paragraph

text: the Americas should not be written off as a
label: Paragraph

text: “hunter-gatherer” world. Many communities
label: Paragraph

text: had developed into affluent societies. The
label: Paragraph

text: Northwest Coast peoples in Canada, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, thrived from about 3000 BCE until
label: Paragraph

text: the arrival of the Europeans in the 19t!
label: Title

text: century, one of the most enduring First
label: Paragraph

text: Society cultures in the Americas. Another
label: Paragraph

text: site of importance was in the area to the
label: Paragraph

text: north of the Mississippi River delta. The
label: Paragraph

text: yearly flooding of the river allowed large
label: Paragraph

text: annual ceremonies to take place on a bluff
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking the river, called Poverty Point,
label: Paragraph

text: where a massive artificial mound, seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: in the shape of a bird, was built. It seers that
label: Paragraph

text: different tribes helped build the mound with
label: Paragraph

text: clay brought to the site in basketfuls from
label: Paragraph

text: their home areas. To the east of the great
label: Paragraph

text: mound there was a 300-meter-wide dance
label: Paragraph

text: area surrounded by raised ridges on which
label: Paragraph

text: temporary huts were erected. Communal
label: Paragraph

text: construction of such large ceremonial sites
label: Title

text: became an important aspect of what is now
label: Paragraph

text: called the Mississippi Culture, which lasted
label: Paragraph

text: into the 16th century.
label: Paragraph

text: In Peru, we see a remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: transformation. Intrepid farmers left their
label: Paragraph

text: hillside terraces on the Andean mountain
label: Title

text: slopes for the arid valleys along the Pacific
label: Paragraph

text: Coast. The intent was purposeful. The newly
label: Paragraph

text: arriving farmers channeled the river waters
label: Paragraph

text: to grow cotton for the making of fishing
label: Paragraph

text: nets, and gourds to be used as floats. But
label: Paragraph

text: they were not fishermen. The fishermen
label: Paragraph

text: lived on the coast, and they traded with the
label: Paragraph

text: newly arriving agriculturalists in a way that
label: Paragraph

text: was mutually beneficial. It was a novel and
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary arrangement that first took
label: Title

text: place at what is now called Caral, about 200
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers north of Lima.
label: Paragraph

text: 2.3 Mnajdra Temple, Malta
label: Caption

text: he Zoser Mortuary Complex and the
label: Title

text: temples of Malta bring to the fore a way
label: Paragraph

text: of understanding the originating power of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture—as models. Today we tend to
label: Paragraph

text: think of models simply as practical devices
label: Title

text: used in the preparation of a design. Yet the
label: Paragraph

text: history of architecture is filled with structures
label: Title

text: that serve as built models. The Zoser
label: Paragraph

text: Mortuary Complex is entered through a portal
label: Paragraph

text: that leads past a corridor of colurnns painted
label: Paragraph

text: to look like gigantic reeds. The visitor literally
label: Paragraph

text: passed through a scaled-up model of the
label: Paragraph

text: swampy shores of the Nile, symbolizing not
label: Paragraph

text: just the transition between life and renewal
label: Title

text: but also the difference between the human
label: Paragraph

text: and divine scales. Egyptians continued to
label: Paragraph

text: build such scaled-up models; their colurmns
label: Paragraph

text: are all large models of flower bundles, richly
label: Paragraph

text: painted and even emitting, in principle at
label: Paragraph

text: 2.2 Zoser Pyramid, Saqqara, Egypt
label: Caption

text: least, a divine fragrance. Architecture as
label: Paragraph

text: model is even more obvious in Malta, where
label: Paragraph

text: the temples are models of caves, purposely
label: Paragraph

text: dark and mysterious. The Maltese also made
label: Paragraph

text: some of the earliest known representations
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings in history. The purpose of
label: Paragraph

text: these small models, no more than a few
label: Paragraph

text: centimeters across, is unknown, but it has
label: Paragraph

text: been suggested that they served as tokens
label: Paragraph

text: given to devotees after a visit. They were
label: Paragraph

text: more than trinkets; they were living pieces of
label: Paragraph

text: the temple, which in turn was itself a living
label: Paragraph

text: entity; thus, a model was a sure way to link
label: Paragraph

text: its owner to the life force of the temple. The
label: Paragraph

text: use of architecture as model remained a
label: Paragraph

text: key element of its core purpose. Even the
label: Paragraph

text: stepped structures of Caral are models of
label: Paragraph

text: sacred mountains, created to charge up or
label: Paragraph

text: enhance the potency of the landscape.

text: THE INDUS GHAGGAR-HAKRA
label: Title

text: CIVILIZATION
label: Title

text: The Indus Ghaggar-Hakra civilization went
label: Paragraph

text: through roughly four phases of development:
label: Paragraph

text: 1. The urbanization of the Ghaggar-Hakra
label: Title

text: River valley, ca. 2800 BCE
label: Caption

text: 2. The rising dominance of four cities—
label: Title

text: Harappa, Mohenjo-Daro, Rakhigarhi, and
label: Paragraph

text: Ganweriwala—ca. 2500 BCE
label: Paragraph

text: 3. The new urbanization of areas south and
label: Title

text: east, ca. 2200 BCE
label: Caption

text: 4. The post-decline reurbanization of the
label: Title

text: Ghaggar-Hakra River, ca. 1700 BCE
label: Caption

text: The period around 2500 BCE was generally
label: Paragraph

text: one of expansion and prosperity throughout
label: Title

text: West Asia and the Indus. Certainly the cities
label: Paragraph

text: along the Ghaggar-Hakra River were being
label: Paragraph

text: enlarged, and their builders became world
label: Paragraph

text: masters of hydrology. Burnt bricks were used
label: Paragraph

text: to construct huge platforms that served as
label: Paragraph

text: the bases for the cities and for defensive
label: Title

text: walls, but also to control floodwaters. And
label: Paragraph

text: most important, elaborate interconnected
label: Paragraph

text: drainage systerns were designed to disperse
label: Paragraph

text: storm waters. A central drain under the
label: Paragraph

text: main gate of Harappa still stands in place.
label: Paragraph

text: lonetheless, the Indus flooded many times,
label: Paragraph

text: each flood burying the city under a thick
label: Paragraph

text: ayer of silt. Harappa was rebuilt at the same
label: Paragraph

text: spot at least eight times. It is thought to have
label: Paragraph

text: ad a population of about fifty thousand.
label: Paragraph

text: There were also specialized cities, such
label: Paragraph

text: as a port and mining towns. Dholavira had to
label: Paragraph

text: solve a hydroengineering problem opposite of
label: Paragraph

text: Harappa's: Because the city sits in a very dry
label: Paragraph

text: area, the issue was not keeping floodwater
label: Paragraph

text: out, but ensuring that enough water could
label: Paragraph

text: e harvested for the dry season. The solution
label: Paragraph

text: was a Series of strategically located dams
label: Paragraph

text: that controlled water during a flood and
label: Paragraph

text: also directed some of the water to huge,
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular, shallow man-made lakes that
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded the city and that could be tapped
label: Paragraph

text: in summer. In Lothal, a port city, water was
label: Paragraph

text: let through a sluice into a vast rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: tank that some speculate functioned as a dry
label: Paragraph

text: dock for seafaring vessels.
label: Paragraph

text: The largest cities were divided into an upper
label: Paragraph

text: town, which was on the highest ground and
label: Paragraph

text: had large palaces and ceremonial spaces,
label: Paragraph

text: and a lower town, which had most of the
label: Paragraph

text: housing. The upper town usually had its own
label: Paragraph

text: wall within the general wall that surrounded
label: Paragraph

text: the whole city. At Dholavira the boundary wall
label: Paragraph

text: was over 9 meters thick. Burials were often
label: Paragraph

text: under mounds just outside the city. Though
label: Paragraph

text: these cities clearly had a social hierarchy
label: Paragraph

text: with a strong ruling class (confirmed by the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that they were divided into sections
label: Paragraph

text: with larger and smaller houses), there is

text: little evidence of a centralized kingship,
label: Paragraph

text: as there was in contemporaneous Egypt,
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamia, and China. In the same
label: Paragraph

text: vein, there are no large ternples. As to their
label: Paragraph

text: religious system, terra-cotta seals show a
label: Paragraph

text: plethora of supernatural animals—unicorns
label: Title

text: in particular. There is also the depiction
label: Paragraph

text: of a proto-Shiva-like divinity sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: shown sitting in the lotus position. He wears
label: Paragraph

text: bull horns on his head and seems to be
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Early in the second millennium BCE, the
label: Paragraph

text: Ghaggar-Hakra begun to dry up. The reasons
label: Paragraph

text: are debated, but it seems an earthquake
label: Paragraph

text: in the Himalayas caused one of its major
label: Paragraph

text: tributaries to change course and drain into
label: Title

text: the Indus, depleting the Ghaggar-Hakra.
label: Paragraph

text: Its waters collected in an inland lake that
label: Paragraph

text: spawned a successful maritime community
label: Paragraph

text: around its shores. Subsequently, the lake,
label: Paragraph

text: too, dried up, bringing about the final
label: Paragraph

text: phase: the abandonment of the entire
label: Title

text: Indus Ghaggar-Hakra region. Where the
label: Paragraph

text: people went is still debated, but the majority
label: Paragraph

text: probably dispersed eastward to the plains of
label: Paragraph

text: the Ganges River. Some, however, may have
label: Paragraph

text: gone westward and relocated as far away as
label: Paragraph

text: Assyria, causing a ripple effect of disruptions
label: Paragraph

text: that were felt all the way to Egypt.

text: 2.8 Urban fabric of Mohenjo-Daro, in Sindh Province, Pakistan
label: Caption

text: 2.7 An entrance gate to Harappa, near Sahiwal, Pakistan
label: Caption

text: Mohenjo-Daro
label: Title

text: Mohenjo-Daro was the dominant city of the
label: Paragraph

text: southern Indus. The Indus, which originates
label: Paragraph

text: in the high Himalayas, is frequently subject
label: Paragraph

text: to ice floes and landslides that can hold
label: Paragraph

text: back its waters for a while but that eventually
label: Paragraph

text: give way, resulting in huge flash floods. To
label: Paragraph

text: guard against these, the two largest building
label: Paragraph

text: areas of Mohenjo-Daro were raised high on
label: Paragraph

text: a platform of bricks designed to disperse the
label: Paragraph

text: floodwaters through a series of culverts. (The
label: Paragraph

text: site of Mohenjo-Daro itself receives very little
label: Paragraph

text: rain.) Under the main streets were drains
label: Paragraph

text: running to settling tanks, which could be
label: Paragraph

text: accessed and cleaned.
label: Paragraph

text: Mohenjo-Daro’s neighborhoods were inward
label: Paragraph

text: looking. The main streets were lined with the
label: Paragraph

text: largely blank walls of houses, and even the
label: Paragraph

text: secondary streets usually did not have any
label: Paragraph

text: major houses opening directly onto them.
label: Paragraph

text: Accessible by alleys only, the houses faced
label: Paragraph

text: into open courtyards, with the larger ones
label: Paragraph

text: often having two stories, the upper level built
label: Paragraph

text: of wood. The number of rooms in houses
label: Paragraph

text: varied from two to more than twenty. A good
label: Paragraph

text: number of the rooms contained wells, and
label: Paragraph

text: the larger ones had bathrooms and toilets.
label: Paragraph

text: 2.9 Plan: The upper town of Mohenjo-Daro
label: Caption

text: Located at the intersection of the major north-
label: Paragraph

text: south and east-west streets, the Great Bath
label: Caption

text: of Mohenjo-Daro, as it is called, was very
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: measures that deliberately diminished the

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: is as expressive as the eyes, which were

text: once inlaid with stone, resulting in an active

label: Paragraph

text: Around 2150 BCE, the Akkadian
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: to the plains, contributing nothing to the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: on kingdoms in the old Sumerian south. The
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The political structure was thus a type of

label: Paragraph

text: state. The chief god was Anu. Below him

label: Paragraph

text: the water god whom we encountered in
label: Paragraph

text: Eridu. Nanna, the moon god who ruled in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: lower level. He measured tirne and provided
label: Paragraph

text: fertility. Senior members of the pantheon
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: while deities of lesser rank were associated
label: Paragraph

text: with smaller urban centers. There were over
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: powers, although one of the priests’ principal

label: Paragraph

text: activity in Sumerian society.

label: Paragraph

text: superstitions and subscriptive behavior.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The sides would have been plastered
label: Paragraph

text: This building represents a shift in the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: death and its associated religious practices.
label: Paragraph

text: The low-lying mastabas of the pharaohs were
label: Paragraph

text: no longer considered worthy of rulers, who
label: Paragraph

text: now ranked among the gods. In classical
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian, the word for tomb actually meant
label: Paragraph

text: a “house of eternity” or, more precisely, a
label: Paragraph

text: “house for eternity.” The pyramids were
label: Paragraph

text: certainly built for eternity, but they were now
label: Paragraph

text: defined differently, as “the place where one
label: Paragraph

text: ascends.” And this might explain the steps,
label: Paragraph

text: since that was a literal form of the Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: glyph, namely a set of giant steps.
label: Paragraph

text: After Zoser, the pharaonic institution
label: Paragraph

text: began to assert its cosmological narrative
label: Paragraph

text: with ever-greater force and precision. One
label: Paragraph

text: of the places where this manifests is a cult
label: Paragraph

text: center for the falcon-god Menthu not far from
label: Caption

text: Medamud, a provincial town 5 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: northeast of Karnak at Thebes. The
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuary, which dates frorn about 2500 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of a roughly lozenge-shaped
label: Paragraph

text: enclosure 83 meters at its widest, surrounded
label: Paragraph

text: by a high wall with a gate to the east. The
label: Paragraph

text: interior contains a grove of trees and two
label: Caption

text: burial mounds that could be interpreted as
label: Paragraph

text: the primeval mounds appearing above the
label: Paragraph

text: waters of chaos.

text: With Snefru (2613-2589 BCE), who ruled
label: Paragraph

text: during the Fourth Dynasty, one sees the
label: Paragraph

text: maturity of the Medamud prototype. But it
label: Paragraph

text: took Snefru several tries. His first project
label: Paragraph

text: was the step-faced pyramid at Meidum.
label: Paragraph

text: The location of the two tomb chambers was
label: Paragraph

text: innovative. Separated horizontally in the Zoser
label: Paragraph

text: temple complex, here they are placed one on
label: Paragraph

text: top of the other, the lower one representing
label: Paragraph

text: the chthonic aspect of the Egyptian religion.
label: Paragraph

text: Snefru abandoned the building after fifteen
label: Paragraph

text: years of work and started another, larger
label: Paragraph

text: pyramid complex 50 kilorneters north, near
label: Caption

text: Dahshur. Originally planned to be a towering
label: Paragraph

text: 150 meters high, it was too bold, and the
label: Paragraph

text: ground gave way under part of it. In an effort
label: Paragraph

text: to save the building, the designers added a
label: Paragraph

text: kink or bend to reduce the weight and angle
label: Paragraph

text: of the slope, which is why it is today called
label: Paragraph

text: the Bent Pyramid.
label: Paragraph

text: The failure forced Snefru to ask his builders
label: Paragraph

text: to return to the Step Pyramid at Meidum.
label: Paragraph

text: They added a layer that transformed it into a
label: Paragraph

text: true pyramid, but this time only after careful
label: Paragraph

text: preparation of the ground. (In Roman times,
label: Paragraph

text: the stone facing was removed to be made
label: Paragraph

text: into stucco. Hence it is possible to see the
label: Paragraph

text: original form.) Still, it was not enough for
label: Paragraph

text: Snefru. He constructed a third pyramid
label: Paragraph

text: two miles north of the Bent Pyramid. Not
label: Paragraph

text: as steep as the earlier ones, it is called the
label: Paragraph

text: Red Pyramid because of the reddish cast of
label: Paragraph

text: the stone. This is where Snefru is actually
label: Paragraph

text: buried. Construction was so well thought
label: Paragraph

text: out that despite the weight of the 2 million
label: Paragraph

text: tons of stones on the roofs of the chambers,
label: Paragraph

text: cracks have yet to appear. The harmonious
label: Paragraph

text: proportions of the form and the perfection
label: Title

text: of the system of tomb chambers made it the
label: Paragraph

text: model for subsequent tombs.

text: The structure of Stonehenge as we see it
label: Paragraph

text: today is in fact a combination of the last two
label: Paragraph

text: phases of its several revisions and dates from
label: Paragraph

text: between 2500 and 1800 BCE, making it more
label: Paragraph

text: or less contemporary with Ur in Mesopotamia
label: Paragraph

text: and the end of the age of pyramids in Egypt.
label: Paragraph

text: This is important because there is a tendency
label: Paragraph

text: to overstate the primitivism of Stonehenge,
label: Paragraph

text: when in actuality it was an advanced Bronze
label: Paragraph

text: Age structure. Furthermore, Stonehenge
label: Paragraph

text: must be contextualized as the last in a
label: Paragraph

text: line of such artificially enhanced sacred
label: Paragraph

text: landscapes, a history that stretched back at
label: Paragraph

text: least two thousand years. Newgrange was
label: Paragraph

text: a similar site in that it was an important
label: Paragraph

text: regional ceremonial attractor, but it dates
label: Paragraph

text: to a thousand years before Stonehenge.
label: Paragraph

text: Today, because Stonehenge is isolated in the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, it is difficult to visualize the area
label: Paragraph

text: as a sacred landscape. In the immediate
label: Paragraph

text: area, hundreds of burial mounds would have
label: Paragraph

text: been visible, sorne dating back to the fourth
label: Paragraph

text: millennium BCE.
label: Paragraph

text: 2.38 Plan: Stonehenge, ca. 2500 BCE
label: Caption

label: Title

text: The first version of Stonehenge, dating to
label: Paragraph

text: about 3000 BCE, was consistent with the
label: Paragraph

text: circular henges of that age, except that
label: Paragraph

text: this one was an impressive 100 meters
label: Paragraph

text: across, with two or perhaps three spaces
label: Paragraph

text: left open for access to the inside of the
label: Paragraph

text: circle. Two alignments were built into it:
label: Paragraph

text: one astronomical, at the northeast entrance
label: Caption

text: toward the northernmost rising of the moon,
label: Paragraph

text: and the other to the cardinal point to the
label: Paragraph

text: south at the other causeway.
label: Paragraph

text: Around 2500 BCE, the Beaker People
label: Paragraph

text: transformed Stonehenge from a local temple
label: Paragraph

text: to a focal point for a larger civilizational entity.
label: Paragraph

text: They filled the area for miles around with
label: Paragraph

text: their circular burial mounds and founded
label: Paragraph

text: a new city to the northeast of Stonehenge,
label: Paragraph

text: now called Durrington Walls, which was
label: Paragraph

text: defended by circular defensive walls 480
label: Paragraph

text: meters across. Their wealth shows up in their
label: Paragraph

text: graves. In one grave, archaeologists found
label: Paragraph

text: gold ornaments as well as bronze pins from
label: Paragraph

text: Bohemia, blue faience beads from Egypt, and
label: Paragraph

text: amber beads frorn northern Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: At the center of the Beaker People’s
label: Caption

text: cosmology was a connection between
label: Paragraph

text: the smelting of ore and the sun. For this
label: Paragraph

text: reason they had to redesign Stonehenge,
label: Paragraph

text: transforming its orientation from the moon
label: Paragraph

text: to the sun. To do this they rotated the axis
label: Paragraph

text: an almost imperceptible 3 degrees eastward
label: Paragraph

text: to coincide with the rising midsummer

text: winter risings and settings. Though the

text: in dispute, Stonehenge's latitude, as it turns
label: Paragraph

text: out, is the only one in Europe where this

text: combination is even possible.

text: The most significant change attributed to

text: the Beaker People was the addition of a ring

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: eavy, medium-grained rock, harder than
label: Paragraph

text: granite. The Beaker People also constructed,
label: Paragraph

text: about 1 kilometer north of Stonehenge, what
label: Paragraph

text: archaeologists call a cursus—a 3-kilorneter-
label: Paragraph

text: long, 100-meter-wide rectangular form,

text: slightly beveled at the ends. Created by

text: incising a ditch into the landscape, it lies
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: uilt, it is laid out with great precision. Its

text: purpose is unknown, even though there are

text: other cursi scattered across the region, some

text: predating the arrival of the Beaker People.

text: The precision was remarkable. The tops of
label: Paragraph

text: the lintels, once they were in place, never
label: Paragraph

text: varied more than 10 centimeters from the
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal. Such carefully worked stone is not
label: Paragraph

text: typical of other English henges, where stones
label: Paragraph

text: were usually left natural, perhaps because
label: Paragraph

text: they were seen as possessing a magical,
label: Paragraph

text: chthonic presence. The Sarsen Ring was
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of a particular type, for it was in
label: Paragraph

text: reality something akin to carpentry in stone.
label: Paragraph

text: Possibly the designers were replicating in
label: Paragraph

text: stone a wooden prototype, or perhaps they
label: Paragraph

text: were seeking to enhance the power of the
label: Paragraph

text: stone structure by embodying in it the more
label: Paragraph

text: familiar techniques of woodworking.
label: Paragraph

text: In the final phase of Stonehenge’s
label: Paragraph

text: transformation, some of the bluestones that
label: Paragraph

text: had been removed were brought back to
label: Paragraph

text: the site, with some being erected within
label: Paragraph

text: the Sarsen Ring and others placed in a
label: Paragraph

text: horseshoe configuration. Such a horseshoe
label: Paragraph

text: was uncommon in England, but occurred
label: Paragraph

text: more frequently across the channel in
label: Paragraph

text: Brittany. The implications of this have yielded
label: Paragraph

text: much speculation, but it is almost certain that
label: Paragraph

text: southern England and French Brittany were
label: Title

text: at this time part of a single cultural province.

text: As a result of climatic cooling, so it is
label: Paragraph

text: thought, the culture that built Stonehenge
label: Paragraph

text: devolved into a hamlet society, with little
label: Paragraph

text: capacity to continue the great architectural
label: Title

text: accomplishments of its predecessors. In the
label: Paragraph

text: shadowy remnants, a druid culture emerged
label: Paragraph

text: that contributed practically nothing to the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural legacy of England.
label: Paragraph

text: How Stonehenge was used has been
label: Paragraph

text: debated for well over a century, and new
label: Paragraph

text: insights are still arising. It was once assumed
label: Paragraph

text: that the site was a celestial clock—a clock
label: Paragraph

text: with one tick, which pointed to the rebirth
label: Paragraph

text: of the year. This is now seen as too limited
label: Paragraph

text: an understanding of the site. It was a site of
label: Paragraph

text: magic, a site where people would congregate
label: Paragraph

text: to communicate with ancestors and to bury
label: Title

text: their dead, physically and ritually, while
label: Paragraph

text: engaged in ceremonial socializing, feasting,
label: Paragraph

text: and dancing.

text: MEGALITHIC TEMPLES OF MALTA
label: Title

text: Around 4000 BCE, settlers arrived at the
label: Paragraph

text: Maltese archipelago, a string of rocky islands
label: Title

text: between Sicily and the North African coast.
label: Paragraph

text: There they set up farms and traded with Sicily
label: Paragraph

text: and Sardinia for flint, obsidian, and other
label: Paragraph

text: nonnative materials, tools, and foods. Today,
label: Paragraph

text: without modern technology, the island would
label: Paragraph

text: be relatively inhospitable, given that there
label: Paragraph

text: are few trees and no natural water sources.
label: Paragraph

text: But in ancient times there must have been
label: Paragraph

text: natural springs and an environment suitable
label: Title

text: for agriculture, for the Maltese flourished for a
label: Paragraph

text: thousand years, between 3500 and 2500 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: more or less contemporaneously with the Old
label: Paragraph

text: Kingdom in Egypt.
label: Paragraph

text: In Egypt, there had been a rapid shift to a
label: Paragraph

text: complex cosmology controlled by the elite.
label: Paragraph

text: But in Malta, religion revolved around the
label: Paragraph

text: ancient mother-goddess cult. Malta should
label: Paragraph

text: not, however, be seen as more primitive,
label: Paragraph

text: but rather as a place where the goddess
label: Paragraph

text: cult not only survived but thrived. It is also
label: Paragraph

text: unlikely that Malta was completely isolated.
label: Paragraph

text: In fact, the large number of temples, far
label: Paragraph

text: exceeding the needs of the local population,
label: Paragraph

text: implies that the island was a type of religious
label: Paragraph

text: destination. People came to the island for
label: Paragraph

text: oracles and to communicate with ancestors.
label: Paragraph

text: Ceremonies seem to have involved sleeping
label: Paragraph

text: and dreaming.
label: Paragraph

text: The temples share common characteristics.
label: Paragraph

text: The outer walls were made of raw, undressed
label: Paragraph

text: megalithic stones set vertically in the ground
label: Caption

text: and forming an oval. How the massive, multi-
label: Paragraph

text: ton stones were brought to the sites remains
label: Paragraph

text: a mystery. Archaeologists have found parallel
label: Paragraph

text: ruts along which the stones might have
label: Paragraph

text: been pulled, possibly on round stones used
label: Paragraph

text: as rollers, but these ruts do not lead to the
label: Paragraph

text: temple in efficient lines (they zigzag through
label: Paragraph

text: the landscape), nor are they always parallel.
label: Paragraph

text: The interior spaces of the ternples were
label: Paragraph

text: defined by their own stones, meticulously
label: Paragraph

text: dressed and set up to create lobed
label: Paragraph

text: chambers, the surfaces of which were
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes finished with plaster and then
label: Paragraph

text: painted. The spaces between the outer and
label: Paragraph

text: inner walls were filled with dirt and rubble,
label: Paragraph

text: and the whole was mounded over to form
label: Paragraph

text: artificial hills with interior caves. How the
label: Paragraph

text: spaces were roofed is still debated. Corbelled
label: Paragraph

text: Neolithic tombs can be found in Spain and
label: Paragraph

text: Portugal, but given the absence of such
label: Paragraph

text: stonework, it seers likely that the roofs
label: Paragraph

text: were supported by timber beams. A model
label: Paragraph

text: of a tomb, made by the ancient builders
label: Paragraph

text: themselves, shows that these buildings
label: Paragraph

text: conformed to a clear prototype. This small
label: Paragraph

text: model, the size of a matchbox, is the
label: Paragraph

text: earliest architectural model in the world. Its
label: Paragraph

text: purpose is not known, but it is possible that
label: Paragraph

text: it was a type of souvenir, proving that the
label: Paragraph

text: recipient had indeed visited the temple and
label: Paragraph

text: participated in its ceremony.
label: Paragraph

text: 2.44 Plans of temple complexes on Malta drawn at the same scale and orientation: Ggantija (above left) and Tarxien (above right)

text: he nature of the rituals for which these

text: structures were built has been lost to history.
label: Paragraph

text: But statuettes of heavyset earth goddesses
label: Paragraph

text: found on the sites are evidence of a cult
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to fertility, death, and renewal.
label: Paragraph

text: he deities, sore sitting upright, others
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the temples themselves—squat, rounded
label: Paragraph

text: igures harboring a mysterious, bodily inner
label: Paragraph

text: world. Animal bones and statuettes testify to
label: Paragraph

text: the ritual offerings and sacrifices that were
label: Paragraph

text: ikely associated with the cult. Many temples
label: Paragraph

text: contained carved or freestanding stone altars,
label: Paragraph

text: and most had libation stones with wells for
label: Paragraph

text: iquid offerings to the earth. The later temples
label: Paragraph

text: ave a type of plaza in front of them that
label: Paragraph

text: were equipped with stone benches, indicating
label: Paragraph

text: that the temples were used for communal
label: Paragraph

text: gatherings where people waited for priestly
label: Paragraph

text: announcements or perhaps for their turn to
label: Paragraph

text: enter.
label: Paragraph

text: The earliest temple on the Maltese
label: Caption

text: archipelago is Ggantija, part of a cluster of
label: Paragraph

text: temples situated on the island of Gozo. Used
label: Caption

text: continuously for hundreds of years, it dates
label: Paragraph

text: to around 3500 BCE. It was a double temple,
label: Paragraph

text: nearly 30 meters long. The temple had a floor
label: Paragraph

text: of crushed limestone slurry that formed a
label: Paragraph

text: hard, concrete-like surface. The portals from
label: Paragraph

text: chamber to chamber were huge post-and-
label: Paragraph

text: lintel configurations of megalithic stones. The
label: Paragraph

text: exterior was monumental and simple. The
label: Paragraph

text: core cloverleaf configuration to the west was
label: Paragraph

text: built first. Two more lobed chambers were
label: Paragraph

text: then added along its entry passage. Later,
label: Paragraph

text: a second temple was built adjacent to the
label: Paragraph

text: first and enclosed within the original mound.
label: Paragraph

text: The reasons are unclear. Perhaps the local
label: Paragraph

text: population expanded and exceeded the
label: Paragraph

text: original temple's capacity. Perhaps a plentiful
label: Paragraph

text: harvest year prompted the farmers to renew
label: Paragraph

text: their thanks to the earth goddess. Whatever
label: Paragraph

text: the reason, generations of Maltese continued
label: Paragraph

text: to regularize and expand the design, testing,
label: Paragraph

text: refining, and reproducing the archetypal
label: Paragraph

text: shape at different scales, with different
label: Paragraph

text: orientations, and with varying numbers of
label: Paragraph

text: chambers.
label: Paragraph

text: The temple at Tarxien, built around
label: Paragraph

text: 2500 BCE, is the most complex of the
label: Paragraph

text: surviving temples. The imposing concave
label: Caption

text: facade of the main temple was composed of
label: Paragraph

text: finely coursed stone, with larger blocks at the
label: Paragraph

text: base and smaller blocks at the roof, which
label: Paragraph

text: corbelled outward to form a small cornice.
label: Caption

text: Within, pairs of symmetrical chambers were
label: Paragraph

text: built successively deeper over the centuries,
label: Paragraph

text: one connected to the next by dual trilithon
label: Paragraph

text: portals and connecting passageways. At
label: Paragraph

text: nearby Mnajdra is a complex of three temples
label: Paragraph

text: of the same period, overlooking an oval court.
label: Paragraph

text: The southern temple is aligned such that the
label: Paragraph

text: equinox sunrise illuminates its main axis.

label: Caption

text: The peoples of the Americas can be
label: Paragraph

text: classified according to their ecological zones.
label: Paragraph

text: The oldest cultures were on the vast steppes
label: Paragraph

text: of North America, but whether they had by
label: Paragraph

text: this time developed the tipi as their distinctive
label: Paragraph

text: habitation is not known. Affluent shore
label: Paragraph

text: cultures had developed along the Pacific
label: Paragraph

text: coast of Canada, along the southern stretches
label: Paragraph

text: of the Atlantic coast of North America (from
label: Paragraph

text: Georgia to Florida), in the great flood marshes
label: Paragraph

text: of the lower Mississippi River, and finally in
label: Paragraph

text: the great rain forests of Mesoamerica and
label: Title

text: the Amazon. By 3500 BCE, the Mississippi
label: Paragraph

text: River delta people began constructing large
label: Paragraph

text: mounds as part of their ceremonial culture.
label: Paragraph

text: They were the first to construct such mounds
label: Paragraph

text: in the Americas. Mound making was an
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to construct ceremonial landscapes
label: Title

text: that brought in people from far away for ritual
label: Paragraph

text: exchanges. It remained a tradition in the
label: Paragraph

text: southeast areas of North America until the
label: Paragraph

text: arrival of the European colonizers.
label: Paragraph

text: Around 3500 BCE important
label: Title

text: transformations were also taking place in
label: Paragraph

text: the western uplands of the Amazon, and
label: Paragraph

text: it is to this area that our story turns, since
label: Paragraph

text: it holds the key to the transformations that
label: Paragraph

text: were to take place first in Peru and then in
label: Paragraph

text: Mesoamerica. The rain forests were home to
label: Paragraph

text: an astonishing variety of plants and animals,
label: Paragraph

text: making them an important incubator of
label: Paragraph

text: human social networks. People formed tribes,
label: Paragraph

text: and developed a slash-and-burn gardening
label: Paragraph

text: technique to better harness cashew, cocoa,
label: Paragraph

text: and Brazil nuts, as well as the all-important
label: Paragraph

text: manioc, used to make bread, soups, and
label: Paragraph

text: fermented drinks. The process began slowly
label: Paragraph

text: around 10,000 BCE as the rain forests began
label: Paragraph

text: to expand. Groups pushed higher and higher
label: Paragraph

text: into the mountains, where they encountered
label: Paragraph

text: the potato, maybe around 5000 BCE. These
label: Paragraph

text: people are not considered agriculturalists,
label: Paragraph

text: however, because as far as we know they did
label: Paragraph

text: not develop irrigation, one of the elements
label: Paragraph

text: associated with agriculture. That changed
label: Paragraph

text: around 3000 BCE, when a group of intrepid
label: Paragraph

text: farmers settled in a high Andean valley that
label: Paragraph

text: still today seems impossibly arid and remote,
label: Paragraph

text: and began a farming community there based
label: Paragraph

text: on irrigation. Using the slope of the valley to
label: Paragraph

text: their advantage, they tapped the stream and
label: Paragraph

text: fed the water horizontally to garden plots.
label: Paragraph

text: Their method worked, and soon the dusty
label: Paragraph

text: valley was turned into a gardener’s paradise.
label: Paragraph

text: Such activities were never just “farming” but
label: Paragraph

text: were part of a sacred landscape; and it is
label: Paragraph

text: now known how that landscape was defined.
label: Paragraph

text: Archaeologists call the place La Galgada—
label: Paragraph

text: and the settlement was no casual affair, but
label: Paragraph

text: organized around a powerful family clan and
label: Paragraph

text: its sharnanistic leaders. And to emphasize
label: Paragraph

text: 2.49 Galgada ruins today
label: Caption

text: the authority of the clan lineage, the elders
label: Paragraph

text: over time developed a unique architectural
label: Paragraph

text: form, an ancestor mound. The clan leaders,
label: Paragraph

text: who were also probably shamans, met in
label: Paragraph

text: something akin to a sweat lodge, a flat-
label: Paragraph

text: topped chamber that could hold about
label: Paragraph

text: fifteen people. The idea of sweat lodges,
label: Paragraph

text: a widespread phenomenon, developed in
label: Paragraph

text: Siberia and was brought to the Americas by
label: Paragraph

text: its ancient settlers. At Galgada, when the
label: Paragraph

text: chief died, he was ritually wrapped in a fetus
label: Paragraph

text: position and buried in the lodge, which was
label: Paragraph

text: then mounded over and a new one built on
label: Paragraph

text: top. Over the centuries, the mound grew
label: Paragraph

text: higher and higher in the shape of a stepped
label: Paragraph

text: mound. Its surface was plastered and
label: Paragraph

text: probably painted red.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the history of agriculture is often
label: Paragraph

text: told as a story of Peru, it is really a story of
label: Paragraph

text: the Amazonians, who, with their thousands of
label: Paragraph

text: years of experience, took the step to what we
label: Paragraph

text: call agriculture by moving into the mountains
label: Paragraph

text: and developing irrigation and controlled
label: Title

text: farming.
label: Paragraph

text: Caral
label: Title

text: The experiment at Galgada was such
label: Paragraph

text: that soon other groups were setting out
label: Paragraph

text: to transform mountains into farmscapes.
label: Paragraph

text: The most ambitious group tackled what
label: Paragraph

text: might seem an almost impossible task—to
label: Paragraph

text: transform the uninhabitable coastal Peruvian
label: Title

text: desert into a fertile plain. The shores had
label: Paragraph

text: supported fishing communities for thousands
label: Title

text: of years. The fishing here is among the best
label: Paragraph

text: in the world, but these fishing communities
label: Paragraph

text: were isolated, and could only trade north
label: Paragraph

text: and south. Enter the highlanders who
label: Paragraph

text: arrived at the Supe River floodplain, and in
label: Paragraph

text: a few decades made it into Peru's first great
label: Paragraph

text: agricultural center. Known as Caral, it was
label: Paragraph

text: first settled around 2600 BCE. The farmers
label: Paragraph

text: brought with them two plants in particular,
label: Paragraph

text: plants that they knew the fishermen would
label: Paragraph

text: need—cotton and the gourd. Cotton was
label: Paragraph

text: needed for fishing nets, and the gourds
label: Paragraph

text: served as floats. In essence, the farmers
label: Paragraph

text: supplied the fishermen with advanced
label: Paragraph

text: equipment, and in return got fish. It was
label: Paragraph

text: a brilliant arrangement, but it required a
label: Paragraph

text: strict regime on the part of the Supe Valley
label: Paragraph

text: farmers. At the center of the community
label: Caption

text: were the shaman elites, who governed by
label: Paragraph

text: a mixture of ancestral and divine right from
label: Paragraph

text: a huge central plaza, roughly 500 meters
label: Paragraph

text: by 175 meters, that was surrounded by
label: Paragraph

text: Rage
label: Title

text: 2.50 Circular sunken plaza, Caral, Peru
label: Caption

text: an extensive array of buildings, platform
label: Paragraph

text: mounds, smaller mounds, and two major
label: Paragraph

text: sunken circular plazas, all sited along a
label: Paragraph

text: bluff overlooking the river and its agricultural
label: Caption

text: fields. Brightly painted, the structures would
label: Paragraph

text: have stood out against both the green fields
label: Paragraph

text: below and the yellowish gray of the arid
label: Paragraph

text: mountains above. The ceremonial center
label: Paragraph

text: was probably activated by a special ritual
label: Paragraph

text: class, with events certainly taking place daily.
label: Paragraph

text: Some events probably involved the larger
label: Paragraph

text: community in multiday festivals of dance,
label: Paragraph

text: music, and feasting. Archaeologists have
label: Paragraph

text: found flutes made of condor and pelican
label: Caption

text: bones, as well as horns made of llama and
label: Paragraph

text: deer bones. The site had formally arranged
label: Paragraph

text: residential complexes for the elite. The rest of
label: Paragraph

text: the inhabitants, namely the farmers, lived in
label: Paragraph

text: a network of hamlets of thatch houses near
label: Paragraph

text: the fields that were dispersed throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: valley.
label: Paragraph

text: mound (160 by 150 meters and 18 meters
label: Paragraph

text: high) is perched on the northern end of
label: Paragraph

text: the site, at the very edge of the terrace
label: Paragraph

text: from which it overlooks the valley. It was
label: Paragraph

text: constructed in two major phases. First, the
label: Paragraph

text: mound walls were built by filling open-mesh
label: Paragraph

text: reed bags with cut stones. Five other platform
label: Caption

text: mounds join with it to form a C-shaped plaza
label: Paragraph

text: facing south. Just beyond its open mouth,
label: Paragraph

text: at the center of a low mound, is a sunken
label: Paragraph

text: circular plaza 50 meters in diameter.
label: Paragraph

text: If the main plaza, surrounded by
label: Paragraph

text: mounds high above the valley floor, creates
label: Paragraph

text: the impression of a vast bounded space
label: Paragraph

text: reminiscent of a high valley plateau, then
label: Paragraph

text: the circular sunken plaza, reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: the later kivas of North America, repeats
label: Paragraph

text: that space on a smaller scale, perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: corresponding to the principles of the
label: Paragraph

text: earth. Although the ceremonial structures
label: Paragraph

text: of the early Andean civilizations have the
label: Paragraph

text: outline of a pyramid and are usually called
label: Paragraph

text: pyramids, it is more accurate to refer to them
label: Paragraph

text: as platform mounds. This is because they
label: Paragraph

text: were conceptually conceived as a series of
label: Paragraph

text: platforms. (Pyramid is from a Greek word
label: Paragraph

text: that describes Egyptian structures.) What the
label: Paragraph

text: native Americans called their structures is
label: Paragraph

text: unknown. The word pyramid will, however,
label: Paragraph

text: be used here in cases where convention has
label: Paragraph

text: already established it as part of a name.

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: How much different our world would be today
label: Title

text: had the carmel and horse not existed. The impact
label: Paragraph

text: of the camel was felt first. Traditionally, the great
label: Paragraph

text: economic centers had all relied on boats or
label: Paragraph

text: oxcarts as the primary means of transport. With
label: Paragraph

text: the camel, traders could now cross the deserts
label: Paragraph

text: and mountains that stretch thousands of miles
label: Paragraph

text: east and west and cut Asia into separate north
label: Title

text: and south regions. By the middle of the second
label: Paragraph

text: millennium BCE, caravans with as many as six
label: Paragraph

text: hundred animals were plying trade routes across
label: Paragraph

text: the desert plains. The first place to monetize this
label: Paragraph

text: trade was a city called Mari. Located in modern-
label: Paragraph

text: day Syria on the western bank of the Euphrates,
label: Paragraph

text: it flourished as a trade center and city-state from
label: Paragraph

text: 2900 BCE until 1759 BCE. It was located halfway
label: Paragraph

text: between the Persian Gulf and the upland reaches
label: Title

text: of the river. In other words, it was designed as
label: Paragraph

text: a short cut to the Mediterranean and thus was
label: Paragraph

text: perfectly sited to collect and distribute goods.
label: Paragraph

text: But this was not a city in the conventional old-
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamian sense. It did not really produce
label: Paragraph

text: anything but instead was an entrepét city, a
label: Paragraph

text: transshipment hub of the third millennium. That
label: Paragraph

text: the city was a perfect circle makes sense.
label: Paragraph

text: The palace, thought to have been built by King
label: Paragraph

text: Zimri-Lim (r. 1779-1757 BCE), had at its core
label: Paragraph

text: a vast rectangular throne room, at the entrance
label: Caption

text: of which was a statue of a maiden holding a jug
label: Paragraph

text: of water from which water actually poured. It
label: Paragraph

text: was meant to impress the visitor that here in the
label: Paragraph

text: desert, water could be poured away. Behind the
label: Paragraph

text: throne room, protected by a guardroom, were
label: Paragraph

text: special storage areas where the king kept his
label: Paragraph

text: most precious items. Nearby was an area for
label: Paragraph

text: the bureaucrats who recorded what went in and
label: Paragraph

text: out of the city. Contrast Eridu with Mari: the first
label: Paragraph

text: was a ritual center designed for the agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: production of surplus and dependent on an
label: Paragraph

text: exchange economy primarily through boats
label: Title

text: (canals and seaports) and oxcarts, whereas the
label: Paragraph

text: latter was dependent on the rapid turnover of
label: Paragraph

text: goods. More than 25,000 tablets in the Mari
label: Paragraph

text: archives have survived, including economic
label: Paragraph

text: reports and juridical texts. The records describe
label: Paragraph

text: an astonishing abundance of material and food
label: Paragraph

text: going through the city, including prized spices
label: Paragraph

text: such as coriander, cumin, saffron, and cloves;
label: Paragraph

text: and even ice, a luxury item imported from the far-
label: Paragraph

text: off mountains. The records also show that things
label: Paragraph

text: did not always go smoothly. Letters describe the
label: Paragraph

text: difficulties of moving a massive shipment of some
label: Paragraph

text: 360,000 liters of barley. Another record tells how
label: Paragraph

text: flour that had been shipped to feed an army had
label: Paragraph

text: been destroyed by ants.

label: Caption

text: The camel at this stage of history was still a
label: Paragraph

text: relatively local Mesopotamian phenomenon,
label: Paragraph

text: but its use expanded eastward until it finally
label: Paragraph

text: reached China, where its impact would be
label: Paragraph

text: felt around 800 BCE during the Zhou dynasty.
label: Paragraph

text: The new transcontinental network would
label: Paragraph

text: become the economic engine of Eurasia until
label: Paragraph

text: the arrival of colonialism in the 16th century.
label: Paragraph

text: In the second millennium BCE another
label: Paragraph

text: quadruped entered the scene: the horse.
label: Paragraph

text: Domesticated around 3000 BCE on the vast
label: Paragraph

text: Eurasian steppe, the horse played a dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: role in history well into the modern age. And
label: Paragraph

text: this was not just because the horse was
label: Paragraph

text: fast; it also conferred a significant military
label: Paragraph

text: advantage in that riders with bows and
label: Paragraph

text: arrows could now rule supreme. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: in the middle of the second millennium
label: Paragraph

text: BCE, Central Asia—from the Bactrian-
label: Paragraph

text: Margiana Archaeological Complex society in
label: Title

text: Turkmenistan to the Indus Ghaggar-Hakra
label: Title

text: region in the south—went into a period of
label: Paragraph

text: turmoil and decline. An ecological disaster—
label: Paragraph

text: the drying up of the Ghaggar-Hakra River—
label: Paragraph

text: certainly played a part in creating a political
label: Paragraph

text: vacuum. But just as important during this
label: Paragraph

text: period were large groups of horse-centric
label: Paragraph

text: people that called themselves Aryas and
label: Paragraph

text: are now known as Aryans, who moved into
label: Paragraph

text: northern India. Since their structures were
label: Paragraph

text: built of wood rather than brick, very little
label: Paragraph

text: tangible evidence of this period has survived.
label: Paragraph

text: The newcomers brought with them not only
label: Paragraph

text: horses, but also a sacred oral tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: mythologies and legends. Around 1500 BCE
label: Paragraph

text: these were assembled and written down.
label: Paragraph

text: This was the beginning of the so-called Vedic
label: Paragraph

text: period, named after a Sanskrit Indo-European
label: Paragraph

text: word that means “knowledge.”
label: Paragraph

text: West Asia also experienced a state of
label: Paragraph

text: flux and instability. Assyria, Babylon, and
label: Caption

text: other Mesopotamian cities were overrun
label: Paragraph

text: by horse-mounted invaders of unknown
label: Title

text: provenance, the Mitanni and Kassite people,
label: Paragraph

text: who had moved in from the north or east.
label: Paragraph

text: A similar situation existed with the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: Sea People, who conquered the Nile Delta
label: Paragraph

text: (ca. 1300-1200 BCE) and from whom the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptians learned how to make chariots and
label: Paragraph

text: better bows. Also arnong the newcomers
label: Paragraph

text: to West Asia were the Hittites, who settled
label: Paragraph

text: in Anatolia around 1600 BCE. There, in the
label: Paragraph

text: north-central region, they founded Hattusas,
label: Paragraph

text: a capital with numerous temples. They
label: Paragraph

text: brought in scribes from Syria to maintain
label: Paragraph

text: their records in cuneiform script, creating
label: Paragraph

text: voluminous state archives. The Hittites and
label: Paragraph

text: the Egyptians became the preeminent land
label: Paragraph

text: powers in western Asia.

text: The Thiodaisia festival involved a dance

label: Paragraph

text: in one case in midair, waiting to be caught
label: Paragraph

text: in the open arms of a woman. Given that the
label: Paragraph

text: entire landscape was sacred, the Minoans
label: Paragraph

text: did not build temples but rather palaces,
label: Paragraph

text: the largest of which was at Knossos, built
label: Paragraph

text: around 2000 BCE on top of a prior Neolithic
label: Caption

text: settlement. It was rebuilt and enlarged in
label: Paragraph

text: 700 BCE after a large earthquake. The
label: Paragraph

text: palace contained residences, kitchens,
label: Paragraph

text: storage rooms, bathrooms, ceremonial
label: Caption

text: rooms, workshops, and sanctuaries.
label: Paragraph

text: here were sophisticated infrastructural
label: Paragraph

text: installations, ventilation systems, and
label: Title

text: groundwater conduits. In storage basements,
label: Paragraph

text: archaeologists have found elephant tusks
label: Paragraph

text: rom Syria and copper ingots from Cyprus.
label: Paragraph

text: Though we do not know what role the
label: Paragraph

text: priest-king who ruled there assumed, it is
label: Paragraph

text: clear that the palace, with its many different
label: Paragraph

text: inds and sizes of interior spaces, terraces,
label: Paragraph

text: courtyards, and platforms, represented a
label: Paragraph

text: mosaic of interwoven activities. It was part
label: Paragraph

text: palace, part warehouse, part factory, part
label: Title

text: religious center. It was laid out around a
label: Paragraph

text: large rectangular courtyard with several
label: Paragraph

text: entrances converging onto it. The courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: was surrounded by verandas at the upper
label: Paragraph

text: levels, allowing views into its space. Because
label: Paragraph

text: of the verandas, windows, porches, steps,
label: Caption

text: and doors that folded open into the sides
label: Paragraph

text: of the walls, the visual interrelationship
label: Paragraph

text: between inner and outer space is particularly
label: Paragraph

text: intricate—more so than in any other palace
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of this period.
label: Paragraph

text: Flanking the courtyard was the throne
label: Paragraph

text: room, which had built-in gypsum benches

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: and wings of an eagle and the body of a
label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: strength and vigilance. The floor was panted
label: Paragraph

text: red. The benches, though at seat height,
label: Paragraph

text: were probably used to hold votive offerings.
label: Paragraph

text: Opposite the throne was a water basin to
label: Paragraph

text: which steps descended and which may
