text: EGYPT: THE NEW KINGDOM
label: Title

text: The Nile Delta of Egypt, around 1720 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: was invaded and occupied by the Hyksos,
label: Paragraph

text: also called the Sea People, who ruled Lower
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt from their capital, Avaris, until driven
label: Paragraph

text: out by Ahmose | of Thebes in 1567 BCE. The
label: Paragraph

text: origin of the Hyksos, and even their name,
label: Paragraph

text: remains the subject of scholarly debate.
label: Paragraph

text: n 1550 BcE, Ahmose |, founder of the
label: Caption

text: Eighteenth Dynasty (called the New Kingdom,
label: Paragraph

text: a rule of dynasties lasting until 1070 BCE),
label: Paragraph

text: was able to throw off the Hyksos and regain
label: Paragraph

text: control over the country. The Hyksos, despite
label: Paragraph

text: eing enemies of Egypt, brought to Egyptians
label: Paragraph

text: some previously unknown things: not only the
label: Paragraph

text: chariot, but also new techniques of bronze
label: Paragraph

text: working and pottery, new breeds of animals,
label: Title

text: new crops, and a particularly powerful
label: Paragraph

text: composite bow.
label: Paragraph

text: The return of stability in Egypt meant
label: Paragraph

text: the vigorous trade in goods on which so
label: Paragraph

text: many Near Eastern societies depended
label: Paragraph

text: could recommence. Furthermore, with the
label: Paragraph

text: continuing troubles in Mesopotamia, Egypt
label: Title

text: began to dominate the region. Seeking to
label: Paragraph

text: wy
label: Title

text: er
label: Title

text: guarantee the borders against the all-too-
label: Paragraph

text: volatile political environment, the Egyptians
label: Title

text: marched into Syria and besieged Nineveh
label: Paragraph

text: and Babylon. No longer isolationists, as they
label: Paragraph

text: had been in the Old Kingdom, they now
label: Paragraph

text: became colonizers. Their turquoise mines
label: Paragraph

text: in the Sinai were reopened, and Ekron and
label: Paragraph

text: other cities controlled by the Philistines
label: Title

text: traded with Egypt in pottery and metals.
label: Paragraph

text: An important change that came with the
label: Paragraph

text: reestablishment of unity involved religion: no
label: Title

text: longer only the purview of the elite, it now
label: Paragraph

text: comprised larger sections of society. Festivals,
label: Paragraph

text: processions, and celebrations that could draw
label: Paragraph

text: thousands of participants were introduced.
label: Paragraph

text: The New Kingdom saw the rise of large
label: Paragraph

text: temple institutions that played an important
label: Paragraph

text: part in hosting these mass celebrations. As
label: Paragraph

text: a consequence the temple priests rose in
label: Paragraph

text: power and played an increasingly large role in
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian politics.
label: Paragraph

text: 3.23 Egypt, ca. 1500 BCE
label: Caption

text: Waset (Thebes)
label: Title

text: During the period of the New Kingdom, the
label: Paragraph

text: capital of Egypt was Thebes, where the family
label: Paragraph

text: that had thrown out the Hyksos came from.
label: Paragraph

text: The Egyptian name for Thebes was Waset,
label: Paragraph

text: the “city of the scepter.” It was located on a
label: Paragraph

text: small rise of the middle of the Nile floodplain
label: Caption

text: that became, during the inundation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Nile, a quasi-island. Thebes was the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: name for the city that eventually stuck.
label: Paragraph

text: The prime deity of Thebes was the ram-
label: Paragraph

text: god Amun-Re, the god of the sun and the
label: Title

text: heaven and the omnipresent father of the
label: Title

text: kings who guaranteed world order. The
label: Paragraph

text: ascendency of Thebes mean that Amun-Re
label: Paragraph

text: was elevated to the status of a national deity.
label: Paragraph

text: At least a dozen temples were built over a
label: Paragraph

text: five-hundred-year period, from about 1500
label: Paragraph

text: to 1000 BCE. The site spans both sides of
label: Paragraph

text: the Nile and includes the Valley of the Kings,
label: Paragraph

text: where many of the pharaohs were buried.
label: Paragraph

text: Thebes had been used as a burial site since
label: Paragraph

text: around 2000 BCE, but with its new prestige
label: Paragraph

text: as imperial capital, it also became the royal
label: Paragraph

text: site. The first temple at the site was erected
label: Paragraph

text: around 1970 BCE and was a rather modest
label: Paragraph

text: structure. Thutmosis | began enlarging the
label: Paragraph

text: Karnak temple complex at Thebes around
label: Title

text: 1530 BCE. Queen Hatshepsut added her
label: Paragraph

text: temple on the west bank (ca. 1470 BCE),
label: Paragraph

text: and Amenhotep III started work on Temple of
label: Paragraph

text: Luxor around 1350 BCE; the temple-building
label: Caption

text: activity culminated in the efforts of Seti | and
label: Paragraph

text: Ramesses I|, who made significant additions
label: Paragraph

text: to Karnak and Luxor around 1280 BCE. From
label: Paragraph

text: then on the complex went through periodic
label: Paragraph

text: expansions and transformations until the 5th
label: Title

text: century BCE.
label: Paragraph

text: At the ritual core of all of this construction
label: Paragraph

text: was a simple, small chamber in the Karnak
label: Paragraph

text: temple—essentially a sacred dry-dock, which
label: Paragraph

text: held a barque through most of the year. The
label: Paragraph

text: barque chamber Queen Hatshepsut built,
label: Paragraph

text: which was dismantled by her successors,
label: Paragraph

text: has been uncovered and reconstructed at
label: Paragraph

text: Karnak, but not on the original site. The 3.24 Barque chamber at Karnak
label: Caption

text: chamber was made of special red quartzite
label: Paragraph

text: stone (thus its name, the Red Chapel) on
label: Paragraph

text: a base of black diorite. The current barque
label: Caption

text: chapel, built by Philip III of Macedonia
label: Caption

text: around 340 BCE, follows the idea of the
label: Paragraph

text: original and contains only two rooms: one
label: Paragraph

text: where the offerings were presented, and
label: Paragraph

text: one with a stone base on which the barque
label: Caption

text: rested. On special occasions the barque was
label: Paragraph

text: carried out of the temple in the context of a
label: Paragraph

text: great popular celebration and taken to various
label: Paragraph

text: sites depending on calendric requirements.
label: Paragraph

text: Though a boat, this barque never got wet but
label: Paragraph

text: instead was transported by priests on their
label: Paragraph

text: shoulders. When it crossed the Nile, it was
label: Paragraph

text: placed on a special boat.
label: Paragraph

text: 3.25 Relief carving showing the barque being ceremoniously carried at Karnak
label: Caption

text: Some sixty festivals were celebrated in
label: Paragraph

text: Thebes annually. Some took place within the
label: Paragraph

text: temple confines; others involved moving cult
label: Paragraph

text: images from temple to temple. The three
label: Caption

text: most important of these traveling festivals
label: Title

text: involved Amun; his wife, Mut, the Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: mother goddess; and Mut's son, Khonsu, the
label: Paragraph

text: lunar deity.
label: Paragraph

text: 1. Preeminent was the Opet (“secret
label: Caption

text: chamber”) festival during which the statues
label: Paragraph

text: of Amun, Khonsu, and Mut were escorted
label: Paragraph

text: from Karnak to the Temple of Luxor. At a
label: Paragraph

text: particular moment during the events, the
label: Paragraph

text: deity “spoke” to confirm the legitirnacy of the
label: Paragraph

text: king. The god's legitimization of the king was
label: Paragraph

text: reciprocated by gifts to the temple from the
label: Paragraph

text: royal family. The festival took place during
label: Paragraph

text: Akhet (roughly our September), the season
label: Paragraph

text: when the Nile flooded, and lasted for eleven
label: Paragraph

text: days, but as time progressed, the number
label: Paragraph

text: of festival days grew. The journey from
label: Paragraph

text: Karnak to Luxor was made over land along
label: Paragraph

text: a processional street; the return journey was
label: Paragraph

text: made along the Nile by boat.
label: Paragraph

text: 2. The Beautiful Feast of the Valley
label: Caption

text: coincided with a celebration of the dead in
label: Paragraph

text: which Amun, Mut, and Khonsu would travel
label: Paragraph

text: to the western shore to visit the gods of the
label: Paragraph

text: West and the deified dead kings. The festival
label: Paragraph

text: came to be associated with renewal and
label: Paragraph

text: regeneration. It occurred during the second

text: Karnak has two entrances: one for those
label: Paragraph

text: arriving from the direction of the Nile, to

text: accommodate the barque procession, and
label: Paragraph

text: the other frorn Luxor. The Nile entrance had
label: Paragraph

text: its own harbor. Both entrances are defined
label: Paragraph

text: by a series of majestic pylons. To the north of
label: Paragraph

text: the enclosure is a small sanctuary dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: to Ptah, who was sometimes seen as an
label: Paragraph

text: abstract form of the Self-Created One. He
label: Paragraph

text: was intimately connected with the plastic
label: Paragraph

text: arts and especially with the mysteries of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and stone masonry.
label: Paragraph

text: A pylon (from the Greek word for “gate”)
label: Paragraph

text: is a high, inclined, and slightly trapezoid-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped wall with a large central entrance
label: Paragraph

text: guarding a sacred precinct. It was often
label: Paragraph

text: accented by tall flagpoles and obelisks whose
label: Paragraph

text: tops were sheathed in gold plating. The two
label: Paragraph

text: flanks of the pylon, formal and imposing,
label: Paragraph

text: symbolized the mountain ranges that hem in
label: Paragraph

text: the Nile. Their form was a purely symbolical
label: Paragraph

text: expression of Egyptian power. Though all
label: Paragraph

text: architectural forms of the period—such as
label: Paragraph

text: the ziggurat in Mesopotamia, the megaron
label: Paragraph

text: in Greece, and the processional paths in
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt—had symbolical value, the pylon
label: Paragraph

text: gates were among the earliest architectural
label: Paragraph

text: forms that condensed wall, gate, and
label: Paragraph

text: cosmology into a single declaration of power.
label: Paragraph

text: he Egyptian word for pylon was bekhnet,
label: Paragraph

text: which implies vigilance. Thus it relates to
label: Paragraph

text: the watchtower-like nature, if not the actual
label: Paragraph

text: unction, of these structures. Flagpoles were
label: Paragraph

text: placed along the front of the pylons, the poles
label: Paragraph

text: and flags representing, for the Egyptians, the
label: Paragraph

text: presence of a sacred precinct at the most
label: Paragraph

text: asic level.
label: Paragraph

text: Like huge billboards, the pylons also
label: Paragraph

text: proclaimed, in image and text, important
label: Paragraph

text: events in the role of the donor-king. On
label: Paragraph

text: one, the seventh pylon of Karnak, a huge
label: Paragraph

text: Thutmosis Ill is shown holding a club
label: Paragraph

text: and taking a swing at a cluster of enemy
label: Title

text: soldiers—depicted smaller—whom he
label: Paragraph

text: seemed to seize by the hair. Beneath his
label: Paragraph

text: feet, in three rows, are the names of the
label: Paragraph

text: conquered cities and peoples, also listed
label: Paragraph

text: in three rows. The conquest of the Lybians,
label: Paragraph

text: Hittites, and Bedouins are particularly
label: Paragraph

text: vigorously portrayed. The pylons were most
label: Paragraph

text: often covered with a fine layer of stucco and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Queen Hatshepsut, daughter of Thutmosis I,
label: Paragraph

text: the fifth pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty,
label: Paragraph

text: was a charismatic and controversial figure
label: Paragraph

text: in her role as a female monarch. She ruled
label: Paragraph

text: for twenty years, during a particularly strong
label: Paragraph

text: moment in the Egyptian economy. It is
label: Paragraph

text: presumed that after her death, Thutmosis III,
label: Paragraph

text: her stepson, ordered the systematic erasure
label: Paragraph

text: of her name from any monument she had
label: Paragraph

text: built, including her temple at Deir el-Bahri.
label: Paragraph

text: Some of her monuments were destroyed
label: Paragraph

text: outright. Such destructions were not
label: Paragraph

text: uncommon in Egyptian history. Her mortuary
label: Paragraph

text: temple, however, played a key role in the
label: Paragraph

text: processional events as the temporary resting
label: Paragraph

text: place for the barque during the Beautiful
label: Title

text: Feast of the Valley.
label: Paragraph

text: The temple, built by Senmut, her
label: Paragraph

text: architect, combined mortuary temple,
label: Caption

text: processional way, rock-cut tomb, and
label: Title

text: ancillary chapels into one synthetic unity
label: Title

text: with no parallel in Egyptian architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Inner court i) is" '

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: area that was called Djeseret, or “sublime
label: Paragraph

text: place,” which was dedicated to Hathor,
label: Paragraph

text: a mother goddess as well as the goddess
label: Paragraph

text: of love and beauty. A preexistent Hathor
label: Paragraph

text: chapel on the site was positioned directly
label: Paragraph

text: under an impressive cliff and built partially
label: Paragraph

text: into Hatshepsut’s temple. The temple was

text: An innovation was the use of terraces leading

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: morning as Re-Horakhty.) The rooms for the

text: out of the rock itself.

text: of the temple that are part of a wall and pier
label: Paragraph

text: system that foreshadows later development.
label: Paragraph

text: Also, instead of using the usual lotus motifs
label: Paragraph

text: for the capitals, here the columns are fluted
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: itself. A series of successively smaller
label: Paragraph

text: telescoping roorns then leads to the sanctuary,
label: Paragraph

text: where the barque was stored. From there, one
label: Paragraph

text: gained access to a hall, placed at right angles
label: Paragraph

text: to the axis, which was defined as the mythical
label: Paragraph

text: place of the path of the sun. Three doors
label: Caption

text: opened to rooms, one for each of the cult
label: Paragraph

text: images of the divine triad: Amun; his spouse,
label: Paragraph

text: Mut, the mother of gods; and their son, the
label: Paragraph

text: moon god Khonsu. They all “gathered” here
label: Paragraph

text: during the Beautiful Feast of the Valley.
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian temples, unlike Mesopotamian
label: Paragraph

text: temples—or even later, Greek and Roman
label: Paragraph

text: temples—were not conceived as finalities.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead, they could grow, be changed, get
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilt, and even be allowed to decay over
label: Paragraph

text: time. In the case of Luxor, rulers added
label: Paragraph

text: courts and hypostyle halls as indications of
label: Paragraph

text: their support and patronage. The Amun-Re
label: Paragraph

text: Temple, for exarnple, grew steadily toward
label: Paragraph

text: the Nile, with new gateways being added and
label: Paragraph

text: others redesigned. In this case, the temple
label: Paragraph

text: is not axially aligned but follows the gentle
label: Paragraph

text: easterly bend of the processional route, as
label: Paragraph

text: it was extended in later building campaigns
label: Paragraph

text: farther and farther to the northeast.

label: Caption

text: Egyptian Columns
label: Title

text: The Egyptians were the first not just to
label: Paragraph

text: develop advanced stone work, but also to
label: Paragraph

text: develop the column as more than just a load-
label: Paragraph

text: bearing device—it had symbolic importance.
label: Paragraph

text: Reeds and flower stalks bundled around
label: Title

text: poles were used to demarcate sacred spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Mostly, the columns were covered with stucco
label: Paragraph

text: and painted in vibrant colors. Because we
label: Paragraph

text: tend to see colurnns as purely structural
label: Paragraph

text: devices, we can easily forget that for the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptians, the column was a denotative form.
label: Paragraph

text: The most common plant themes were the
label: Paragraph

text: palm, the lotus, and the papyrus. For lotus
label: Paragraph

text: capitals, there was the so-called bud form,
label: Paragraph

text: which was usually used in outer courts, and
label: Paragraph

text: the open form, found in a temple's central
label: Paragraph

text: area. At the Hatshepsut mortuary temple, one
label: Caption

text: finds fluted cylindrical columns, representing
label: Paragraph

text: bundled reeds, with plain square capitals
label: Paragraph

text: that were to have a profound impact on the
label: Paragraph

text: columns developed by the Greeks.
label: Paragraph

text: The preferred structural support for
label: Paragraph

text: columns was bedrock, but where that was
label: Paragraph

text: not possible, they rested on a broad base that
label: Paragraph

text: in turn rested on a cone-shaped stone below
label: Paragraph

text: the surface of the floor to further distribute
label: Paragraph

text: the weight. Foundations were often made of
label: Paragraph

text: compacted sand several meters deep, the
label: Paragraph

text: sand creating an even distribution of the
label: Paragraph

text: forces.
label: Paragraph

text: 3.41 Papyrus column, bundled shaft
label: Caption

text: The Djed pillar was the archetype of the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian column. It ernerged in the early
label: Paragraph

text: history of ancient Egypt and, though its
label: Paragraph

text: meaning is much debated, it most likely
label: Paragraph

text: derived from a harvest ritual and came to
label: Paragraph

text: represent the creation myth. Its importance
label: Paragraph

text: grew over time to represent the world
label: Paragraph

text: holding up the sky, and as such it came
label: Paragraph

text: to represent the idea of stability and
label: Paragraph

text: permanence, important themes in Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: dynastic definition. The pillar as it was used
label: Paragraph

text: in ceremonies was associated with the god
label: Paragraph

text: Sokar in association with Osiris, the god of
label: Paragraph

text: the dead.

text: Egyptian Design Methods
label: Title

text: Texts relating to architecture, surveying, and
label: Paragraph

text: town planning make it obvious that Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture had risen to the level of a
label: Paragraph

text: distinct craft. Architectural plans—drawn on
label: Paragraph

text: stones, some of which have survived, and
label: Paragraph

text: most certainly on papyrus, though none of
label: Paragraph

text: these have survived—indicate a high level
label: Paragraph

text: of coordination between planning a building
label: Title

text: and its construction. Beside the titles of royal
label: Paragraph

text: architect, builder, and overseer of works,
label: Paragraph

text: there were also priest-architects who had
label: Paragraph

text: access to secret books that had plans and
label: Paragraph

text: specifications for buildings and statues.
label: Paragraph

text: There was even a goddess of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and reckoning, Seshat, who begins to appear
label: Paragraph

text: in Egyptian records in about 2500 BCE. She
label: Paragraph

text: is depicted as bearing a seven-pointed star
label: Paragraph

text: or rosette on her head, sometimes above a
label: Paragraph

text: wand. She was also the goddess of the art of
label: Paragraph

text: writing.
label: Paragraph

text: The king himself played an important part
label: Paragraph

text: in the planning and the symbolic execution
label: Title

text: of a structure. In one mural, Thutmosis II is
label: Paragraph

text: shown performing the ceremony of staking
label: Caption

text: out the ground plan of a temple using a
label: Paragraph

text: special “plan net,” a netlike webbing of
label: Paragraph

text: rope with knots that marked off locations.
label: Paragraph

text: The procedure consisted of stretching a
label: Paragraph

text: net along the axis and then spreading it
label: Paragraph

text: out to determine the basic points of the
label: Paragraph

text: construction. To form a right angle, for

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: was connected to the physiology of the
label: Paragraph

text: body. The eye was seen as one unit, with
label: Paragraph

text: each of the parts measuring a fraction. This
label: Paragraph

text: unit was named after Hequat, who was a
label: Paragraph

text: goddess represented by a frog: she was also
label: Paragraph

text: the sign of fertility. The name is fitting, since
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian mathematics involves a system of
label: Paragraph

text: leapfrogging over various fractions to achieve
label: Paragraph

text: the desired answer. The carving of a column
label: Paragraph

text: and capital was thus a shortcut for these
label: Paragraph

text: operations.

text: HITTITE EMPIRE
label: Title

text: The Hittites settled in Anatolia around
label: Paragraph

text: 1600 BCE, choosing the site of their capital,
label: Paragraph

text: Hattusas, with an eye toward dominating
label: Paragraph

text: the intersection of two important trading
label: Title

text: routes. One ran from the Aegean coast, from
label: Paragraph

text: a harbor later to become Ephesus, to the
label: Paragraph

text: Black Sea. The other ran southward, from
label: Paragraph

text: the Black Sea port of Amisus (Samsum)
label: Caption

text: to the headwaters of the Euphrates. To
label: Paragraph

text: further stimulate trade, the Hittites permitted
label: Paragraph

text: Assyrians to set up posts for their donkey and
label: Paragraph

text: camel caravans in eastern Anatolia, such as
label: Paragraph

text: the one at Kanesh, 20 kilometers northeast
label: Caption

text: of Kayseri and only 100 kilometers southwest
label: Paragraph

text: of Hattusas. At its height, the Hittite Empire
label: Paragraph

text: stretched into the Levant, leading to conflict
label: Paragraph

text: with the Egyptians and to the famous battle
label: Title

text: for Kadesh (1275 BCE) in northern Syria. After
label: Paragraph

text: the battle, which was a draw, the two parties
label: Paragraph

text: wrote up a treaty that guaranteed peace
label: Paragraph

text: and security throughout the area, allowing
label: Paragraph

text: the cities along the Syrian coast to grow in
label: Paragraph

text: importance and also creating a power shift
label: Paragraph

text: away from Mesopotamia toward the eastern
label: Title

text: Mediterranean. A cuneiform version of this
label: Paragraph

text: treaty, found at Hattusas, hangs today in an
label: Paragraph

text: enlarged copy at the United Nations Building
label: Caption

text: to demonstrate the age-old importance of
label: Paragraph

text: international treaties.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the Hittite economy was basically
label: Paragraph

text: agricultural, the Hittites conducted a lively
label: Paragraph

text: export in copper, bronze, and later, most
label: Paragraph

text: prized of all, iron. Many of the mines were
label: Paragraph

text: in the vicinity of Bokar-Maden in the Taurus
label: Paragraph

text: Mountains. The main military strength of
label: Paragraph

text: the Hittites lay in the intensive development
label: Paragraph

text: of new weapons, such as the light horse-
label: Paragraph

text: drawn chariot with its six-spoked wheels. It
label: Paragraph

text: contributed greatly to speed and mobility
label: Paragraph

text: in battle. The Sumerians had already had
label: Paragraph

text: chariots pulled by wild asses, but their wheels
label: Paragraph

text: were made of solid wood. Egyptian chariots
label: Paragraph

text: held only two men, while those of the Hittites
label: Paragraph

text: held three—the driver and two soldiers, one
label: Paragraph

text: each for attack and defense.
label: Paragraph

text: The Hittites, similar to the Mesopotamians,
label: Paragraph

text: had a vast pantheon of intermarried gods and
label: Paragraph

text: goddesses, in the center of which was the
label: Paragraph

text: male weather god, symbolized by a bull. His
label: Paragraph

text: 3.47 Hittite Empire
label: Caption

text: consort controlled the rivers and the sea but
label: Paragraph

text: was also sometimes known as a sun goddess.
label: Paragraph

text: Even though ternples were important for the
label: Paragraph

text: Hittites, they also had outdoor sanctuaries.
label: Paragraph

text: In this they were much more like the
label: Paragraph

text: Minoans than either the Egyptians or the
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamians. One such sanctuary is
label: Paragraph

text: Yazilikaya, a little over a kilorneter to the
label: Paragraph

text: northeast of Hattusas, to which it was
label: Paragraph

text: connected by a processional way. It had a
label: Paragraph

text: pantheon of gods chiseled into the face of
label: Paragraph

text: the cliff, perhaps showing them arriving at
label: Paragraph

text: the house of the weather god for the spring
label: Title

text: festival.

label: Title

text: Hattusas (modern Bogazkéy), situated at
label: Paragraph

text: the juncture of two ancient trade routes in
label: Paragraph

text: north-central Turkey, lies on the northern
label: Paragraph

text: slope of a ridge where a high plateau begins
label: Paragraph

text: to descend toward a valley. Of the many
label: Paragraph

text: temples in the city, the most notable was the
label: Paragraph

text: so-called Temple |, squarish in plan with an
label: Paragraph

text: annex in the back. It took up an irregularly
label: Paragraph

text: shaped city block and was composed
label: Paragraph

text: principally of storage cells for sanctuary
label: Title

text: treasure and food. Archaeologists have found
label: Paragraph

text: jars of Cretan and Mycenaean provenance
label: Title

text: there. The storage room walls were very
label: Paragraph

text: thick, suggesting that the building was two
label: Paragraph

text: or three stories high. The entire complex,
label: Paragraph

text: including the vast number of storercoms,
label: Paragraph

text: measures 160 by 135 meters. The temple
label: Caption

text: was built of limestone, whereas the annex
label: Paragraph

text: that contained the sacred statues was built
label: Paragraph

text: of granite, indicating its special status as
label: Paragraph

text: well as, most likely, the presence of Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: masons, since it is unlikely that the Hittites
label: Paragraph

text: would have developed the skill of carving
label: Paragraph

text: granite so rapidly on their own. The courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: was entered through a symmetrically laid out
label: Paragraph

text: gate, square in plan and divided into nine
label: Paragraph

text: spaces. In the rest of the plan there was an
label: Paragraph

text: 3.49 Area plan: Hattusas (Bogazkéy), Turkey
label: Caption

text: attempt to balance the right and left sides
label: Title

text: of the courtyard. In the northeast corner
label: Caption

text: was a washhouse, while a portico at the far
label: Paragraph

text: end gave access to the sacred spaces in the
label: Paragraph

text: annex. The cult statues were in the larger
label: Paragraph

text: of the two rooms to the northwest and were
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to the sun goddess, while the other
label: Paragraph

text: room was dedicated to the weather god. All in
label: Paragraph

text: all, the building is an aggregation of different
label: Paragraph

text: elements: the gate, the court, and the annex.
label: Caption

text: The most important event at the temple
label: Paragraph

text: was a springtime festival at which the
label: Paragraph

text: combat of the weather god and a dragon
label: Title

text: was acted out or recited. During the festival,
label: Paragraph

text: the king and queen, accompanied by jesters
label: Title

text: and musicians, would enter through the
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial gate on the eastern wall and
label: Caption

text: proceed to a stone basin, where the king
label: Paragraph

text: would perform a ritual hand washing using
label: Paragraph

text: water poured from a jar made of gold. From
label: Paragraph

text: there he would enter the ternple courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: through the monumental gate. A master of
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonies then prepared the king and the
label: Paragraph

text: assembled dignitaries for a feast, perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: in the colonnade of the courtyard or in the
label: Caption

text: throne room itself. The Hittites, like the
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamians, employed no columns or
label: Paragraph

text: capitals in their architecture. Instead, they
label: Paragraph

text: -— Sanctuary
label: Title

text: 3.50 Plan: Temple |, Hattusas
label: Caption

text: grouped rooms around paved courts. In
label: Paragraph

text: contrast to Sumerian temples, which had
label: Paragraph

text: dark and mysterious interiors because the
label: Paragraph

text: rooms received daylight frorn windows high
label: Caption

text: up in the walls, Hittite temples had tall
label: Paragraph

text: windows starting close to floor level. Such
label: Paragraph

text: windows were placed on both sides of the
label: Paragraph

text: cult statue and would have bathed it in light.
label: Paragraph

text: The Hittites also employed colonnades in a
label: Paragraph

text: type of wall-and-pier system that enriched
label: Paragraph

text: their spatial vocabulary considerably. And
label: Paragraph

text: finally, Hittite architects strove for a deliberate
label: Paragraph

text: tension between symmetry and asymmetry
label: Title

text: that has parallels with Minoan architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: There are other differences from
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamian temples. The cella of a
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamian temple communicated
label: Title

text: with the courtyard through an intervening
label: Paragraph

text: antechamber or antechapel, so that the
label: Paragraph

text: congregation in the court would have a clear
label: Paragraph

text: view of the god’s statue in its niche. In Hittite
label: Caption

text: temples, the cult room was approached
label: Paragraph

text: indirectly, through side rooms; the statue
label: Paragraph

text: would therefore not have been visible from
label: Paragraph

text: the court. This has led archaeologists to
label: Paragraph

text: conclude that the cel/a was reserved for
label: Paragraph

text: priests or a corresponding elite who alone
label: Paragraph

text: were admitted to the sanctum.

text: MYCENAEAN CIVILIZATION
label: Title

text: The Mycenaeans, from parts unknown,
label: Paragraph

text: settled in Greece around 2000 BCE. There,
label: Paragraph

text: ike the Hittites, they quickly coalesced
label: Paragraph

text: into a unified Bronze Age social order.
label: Paragraph

text: The numerous harbors and islands of the
label: Paragraph

text: Peloponnese lent themselves to a system
label: Paragraph

text: of regional chieftains or kings operating
label: Title

text: under the umbrella of the lord of Mycenae,
label: Paragraph

text: to whom they were connected by ties of
label: Paragraph

text: lood, tribal loyalties, language, and old
label: Title

text: memories of origins as reflected in their
label: Paragraph

text: myths. Commanding a powerful fleet, the
label: Paragraph

text: lord of Mycenae could ensure his city-state’s
label: Paragraph

text: foremost position. After the decline of Minoan
label: Paragraph

text: dominance over the Mediterranean, the
label: Paragraph

text: reach of Mycenae extended to all the Aegean
label: Paragraph

text: islands, including Rhodes and Cyprus. The
label: Paragraph

text: Mycenaeans traded with Sicily, southern Italy,
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt, Sardinia, and the countries bordering
label: Title

text: the Black Sea, leaving trading outposts along
label: Paragraph

text: the way. Their form of power was a novelty
label: Paragraph

text: in world history. They were not centralized
label: Paragraph

text: and had no land-based army. But it was
label: Paragraph

text: precisely this that propelled them into world
label: Paragraph

text: events. Tribal affiliations created small but
label: Paragraph

text: fiercely loyal fighters. They developed their
label: Paragraph

text: own export commodities. Their carpenters,
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: for example, used ivory from Syria with great
label: Paragraph

text: skill to adorn furniture. Their metallurgical
label: Paragraph

text: skill was legendary; Mycenaean bronze
label: Paragraph

text: swords have been found in Romania. There
label: Paragraph

text: were obviously interactions with the Minoans,
label: Paragraph

text: from whose long culture the Mycenaeans
label: Paragraph

text: borrowed elements of wall decorations and
label: Paragraph

text: building techniques. Mycenaean architectural
label: Paragraph

text: sensibilities were their own, however, and
label: Paragraph

text: centered on the megaron, or great hall.
label: Paragraph

text: Nestor's palace complex at Pylos, of which
label: Paragraph

text: we hear much in Homer’s Odyssey, was built
label: Paragraph

text: between 1300 and 1200 BCE. Predominant is
label: Paragraph

text: the megaron, a square room with four fluted
label: Paragraph

text: columns in the center of which is an elevated
label: Paragraph

text: hearth 4 meters in diameter; the room was
label: Paragraph

text: vented by a clerestory ceiling. The floor was
label: Paragraph

text: plastered and decorated with a grid, the
label: Paragraph

text: fields of which were painted with nonfigural
label: Paragraph

text: patterns.
label: Paragraph

text: The walls were covered with an elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: series of frescoes showing animals,
label: Paragraph

text: musicians, and individuals carrying offerings
label: Title

text: and a bull sacrifice. On the wall near the
label: Caption

text: throne (to-no in Mycenaean Greek, whence
label: Paragraph

text: comes the word “throne”), was a drawing of
label: Paragraph

text: an octopus with special symbolical meaning.
label: Paragraph

text: Did the slippery, multi-armed organism
label: Paragraph

text: resemble the adept, multi-zoned Mycenaean
label: Paragraph

text: social structure? The throne was made of
label: Paragraph

text: wood, plated in gold and ebony.
label: Paragraph

text: Behind the great hall were two storage
label: Paragraph

text: rooms for valuables and containing large pots
label: Title

text: for storing oil. The residential quarters were in
label: Paragraph

text: a discrete block at the eastern corner. There
label: Paragraph

text: was even a room with a bath made of terra-
label: Paragraph

text: cotta. Access to the megaron was more direct
label: Paragraph

text: than the labyrinthine approach at Knossos.
label: Paragraph

text: From the outside, one entered through an
label: Paragraph

text: H-shaped propyfon (the word literally means
label: Paragraph

text: “before the gate”) with a single colurnn
label: Paragraph

text: dividing the path into two, much as one
label: Paragraph

text: would have found in Crete. It did not lead to
label: Paragraph

text: a hall or corridor but into a courtyard, where
label: Paragraph

text: a porch of columns and a set of doorways
label: Caption

text: formed the entrance into the megaron.
label: Paragraph

text: To the right of the entrance was the guard
label: Paragraph

text: room, and to the left, the palace archives and
label: Paragraph

text: records of trade transactions. Before entering
label: Paragraph

text: the megaron, a visitor would first have been
label: Paragraph

text: led to a room on the left side of the courtyard,
label: Paragraph

text: which was a place for ritual preparation.
label: Paragraph

text: The palace was located on a ridge with a
label: Paragraph

text: protected port about 5 kilometers from the
label: Paragraph

text: sea, right on the trade route that worked its
label: Paragraph

text: way through the Peloponnese.
label: Paragraph

text: 3.53 Overview of Mycenae, Greece ~
label: Caption

text: Mycenaean palaces were much more
label: Paragraph

text: than residences; as at Knossos, they were
label: Paragraph

text: administrative centers and the locus of the
label: Title

text: region's industrial production. The Palace
label: Paragraph

text: of Pylos, for example, employed around
label: Paragraph

text: 550 textile workers and 400 workers in the
label: Paragraph

text: metallurgical industry. There were also other
label: Paragraph

text: types of artisans, such as goldsmiths, ivory
label: Paragraph

text: carvers, stone carvers, and potters. These
label: Paragraph

text: people lived in nearby hamlets.
label: Paragraph

text: The most dominant city of the time was
label: Paragraph

text: Mycenae itself. Though today the city seems
label: Paragraph

text: remote, this was not the case in 400 BCE. It
label: Paragraph

text: straddled a shortcut through the Peloponnese
label: Paragraph

text: between the broad and protected Argos
label: Title

text: harbor and a port on the Bay of Corinth,
label: Paragraph

text: and thus connected Crete and the eastern
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean with the markets in Italy and
label: Paragraph

text: beyond. Situated on the side of a mountain, it
label: Paragraph

text: was easily protected.
label: Paragraph

text: Mycenae was defended by thick ring
label: Paragraph

text: walls that were built around 1450 BCE. Part
label: Paragraph

text: of this formidable defense work consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: a cyclopean wall named for the seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: superhuman strength it must have taken to
label: Paragraph

text: move these immense boulders. In other parts
label: Paragraph

text: one finds regular rows of blocks of stone
label: Paragraph

text: fitted without mortar. One enters the citadel
label: Paragraph

text: through the famed Lion Gate, which might
label: Paragraph

text: imply a connection to, or at least familiarity
label: Paragraph

text: with, Hattusas.
label: Paragraph

text: Palace compound
label: Title

text: Lower town
label: Title

text: Burial tholos
label: Title

text: Just to the right after entering the citadel
label: Paragraph

text: is a large circular burial fhofos placed on
label: Paragraph

text: the flat top of a purpose-built conical hill,
label: Paragraph

text: about 6 meters high. It has six chambered
label: Paragraph

text: tombs containing gold, silver, and bronze
label: Paragraph

text: burial treasures. Entrance to this circle was
label: Paragraph

text: certainly restricted to the elite, who accessed
label: Paragraph

text: it from a bridge that connected it to a set
label: Paragraph

text: of ritual buildings, also placed on a high
label: Paragraph

text: stone podium. There were no temples in the
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamian sense. Sacred rituals were
label: Paragraph

text: performed in buildings that were similar
label: Paragraph

text: to houses, except that they were better
label: Paragraph

text: ornamented and made with more refined
label: Paragraph

text: material.
label: Paragraph

text: The lower town and the burial circle were
label: Paragraph

text: originally outside the citadel walls, but
label: Paragraph

text: were later encased by a more expansive
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter wall. The palace, placed at the
label: Paragraph

text: top of hill, was protected by its own set of
label: Paragraph

text: walls. Unlike the Egyptian pharaohs, who
label: Paragraph

text: were placed in pyramids, and later in secret
label: Paragraph

text: caves, the Mycenaean dead were displayed
label: Paragraph

text: within the city at a place where memory
label: Title

text: and narrative were most likely to converge.
label: Paragraph

text: Later Greeks would call the gathering of
label: Paragraph

text: people in commemorating places a choros.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, Homer would emerge, long after the
label: Paragraph

text: Mycenaean age had waned, recounting the
label: Paragraph

text: tales of Mycenaean heroes, arnong them
label: Paragraph

text: Agamemnon.
label: Paragraph

text: 3.54 Megaron at Palace of Pylos, Mycenae
label: Caption

text: Treasury of Atreus
label: Title

text: Beginning in the late Bronze Age, the
label: Paragraph

text: kings were buried outside the city in great
label: Paragraph

text: beehive—or tholas—tombs, monumental
label: Paragraph

text: symbols of wealth and power. The one at
label: Paragraph

text: Mycenae, the Treasury of Atreus, is the
label: Paragraph

text: most famous and the most finely built. It
label: Paragraph

text: consists of a great circular chamber, some
label: Paragraph

text: 15 meters in both diameter and height, cut
label: Caption

text: into the hillside and entered by a corridor—a
label: Paragraph

text: dromos—about 36 meters long and 6 meters
label: Paragraph

text: wide. The tomb was roofed by a corbelled
label: Paragraph

text: dome made of finely cut ashlar blocks. A
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular room, the burial chamber proper,
label: Paragraph

text: was tucked in next to the central one. The
label: Paragraph

text: whole was covered with earth to form a
label: Paragraph

text: conical hill. The high facade at the entrance
label: Caption

text: was flanked by two half-columns of green
label: Paragraph

text: porphyry—a stone native to Egypt—carved
label: Paragraph

text: with chevrons and spirals. Though fitted
label: Paragraph

text: with Minoan-style capitals, their bulbous
label: Paragraph

text: proportions foreshadowed the transformation
label: Paragraph

text: the capitals would undergo subsequent to the
label: Paragraph

text: Dorian invasion. The stone lintel above the
label: Caption

text: door was elaborately decorated with running
label: Paragraph

text: spirals and other patterns.

text: POVERTY POINT
label: Title

text: First reported in 1873, the semi-elliptical
label: Paragraph

text: ridges of Poverty Point were thought to
label: Paragraph

text: be natural formations. It was only in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1950s, when the site was viewed from the
label: Paragraph

text: air, that archaeologists realized they were
label: Paragraph

text: artificial constructions. Located in the lower
label: Paragraph

text: Mississippi Valley of West Carroll Parish,
label: Title

text: Louisiana, near both the Gulf Coast and
label: Paragraph

text: the confluence of six major rivers, Poverty
label: Paragraph

text: Point is not a unique construction. Similar
label: Paragraph

text: earth mounds had been built along the
label: Paragraph

text: Mississippi River dating as far back as 4000
label: Paragraph

text: BCE. Humans probably moved into this area
label: Paragraph

text: around 6000 BCE, and the reason is obvious:
label: Paragraph

text: it was one of the richest areas in plants
label: Paragraph

text: and wildlife in North America. There were
label: Paragraph

text: seasonal migrating ducks, fish of various
label: Title

text: kinds, and deer in the forests, not to mention
label: Paragraph

text: a wide variety of edible plants and nuts,
label: Paragraph

text: including hickory nuts, pecans, acorns, and
label: Paragraph

text: walnuts. All this made for an affluent world.
label: Paragraph

text: The massive spring floods allowed people to
label: Paragraph

text: communicate with each other via canoes.
label: Paragraph

text: Trade was extensive and included chipped-
label: Paragraph

text: stone projectile points and tools, ground-
label: Caption

text: stone plummets, and beads made from shells
label: Paragraph

text: and stones. There is clear evidence that
label: Paragraph

text: trade reached as far north as what is now
label: Paragraph

text: Michigan.
label: Paragraph

text: The mounds served as places for ritual
label: Paragraph

text: gatherings that lasted for weeks and were
label: Paragraph

text: an important part of First Society life. These
label: Paragraph

text: gatherings entailed ceremonial gift giving,
label: Paragraph

text: socializing, singing, and dancing. In that
label: Paragraph

text: Motley Mound
label: Title

text: sense, this was not a village but a sacred
label: Paragraph

text: landscape that served as a magnet for people
label: Paragraph

text: from near and far, although the local tribe
label: Paragraph

text: might have lived there the year round.
label: Paragraph

text: The site consists of six concentric semi-
label: Paragraph

text: elliptical rings that enclose a vast open plaza
label: Paragraph

text: covering an area of about 14 hectares. Aisle-
label: Caption

text: like openings run between the rings, dividing
label: Paragraph

text: them into six sections, which are thought to
label: Paragraph

text: have stood over 2 meters high. It is thought
label: Paragraph

text: that visiting tribes built their huts on these
label: Paragraph

text: mounds for the festivals. In and around
label: Paragraph

text: the complex were six to eight constructed
label: Paragraph

text: earthen mounds. The main plaza faced east
label: Caption

text: and overlooked the Mississippi River. This
label: Paragraph

text: was the site of elaborate dance ceremonies.
label: Paragraph

text: Someone looking along the aisles from the
label: Paragraph

text: center outward would have looked toward the
label: Paragraph

text: sun at the winter solstice in one direction,
label: Paragraph

text: and toward the sun at the summer solstice in
label: Paragraph

text: the other.
label: Paragraph

text: To the west of the site was a huge mound,
label: Paragraph

text: built on a patch of black soil that was
label: Paragraph

text: ritualistically covered with a layer of white
label: Paragraph

text: sand, probably symbolizing the forces of life
label: Paragraph

text: and death. The mound was made by the
label: Paragraph

text: different tribes, each carrying clay in baskets
label: Paragraph

text: from far away to the site. When finished, it had
label: Paragraph

text: the shape of a west-flying bird, which most
label: Paragraph

text: likely was meant as a communication device
label: Paragraph

text: for the ancestor spirits. How the shamanistic
label: Paragraph

text: rituals worked, whether on its summit or on
label: Paragraph

text: its slopes, is unknown. Today the mound is
label: Paragraph

text: overgrown with grass and trees, but originally
label: Paragraph

text: its clay surface would have been bare.

text: SHANG DYNASTY, CHINA
label: Title

text: Ancient Chinese historians talk of the ten
label: Title

text: thousand kingdoms that existed before
label: Title

text: the Xia dynasty (ca. 2070-1600 BCE), and
label: Paragraph

text: indeed, the rise of defensive fortifications
label: Paragraph

text: around cities was a testament to intra-urban
label: Paragraph

text: warfare. Arnmong these numerous city-states,
label: Paragraph

text: Xia came to control the territory on the Yellow
label: Paragraph

text: River, paving the way for the rise of the
label: Paragraph

text: Shang dynasty (ca. 1600-1050 BCE), whose
label: Paragraph

text: irst capital was Ao, known as Zhengzhou.
label: Paragraph

text: he Shang, who continually moved their
label: Paragraph

text: capital due to frequent natural disasters, left
label: Paragraph

text: Ao around the 13th century BCE. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: the capital's importance, centralization of
label: Paragraph

text: state power had not yet been developed.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, it was during the Shang dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: that the royal person came to be viewed as
label: Paragraph

text: a symbol of cosmic powers. While feasts for
label: Paragraph

text: the dead were commonplace, during the
label: Paragraph

text: Shang it seems that ordinary people were no
label: Paragraph

text: longer believed to become spirit ancestors.
label: Paragraph

text: In other words, the ancestors of the elite
label: Paragraph

text: became the spiritual ancestors of all. And,
label: Paragraph

text: since the royal ancestors were credited with
label: Paragraph

text: supernatural powers, divining their wishes
label: Paragraph

text: was a preeminent task placed in the hands of
label: Paragraph

text: a priestly class. The theocratic order thereby
label: Paragraph

text: established was to remain foundational
label: Paragraph

text: to the Chinese definition of rulership. The
label: Paragraph

text: king or his diviners would address an oral
label: Paragraph

text: “charge”—a question—to the ancestors
label: Title

text: using a prepared turtle shell or cattle scapula
label: Paragraph

text: ro A\Longshan
label: Title

text: Yellow Sea
label: Title

text: while applying a hot poker to produce a
label: Paragraph

text: series of heat cracks in the shell or bone.
label: Paragraph

text: he diviners then interpreted these cracks
label: Paragraph

text: as auspicious or inauspicious, after which
label: Paragraph

text: engravers carved into the surface of the shell
label: Paragraph

text: or bone the subject of the charge, sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: the forecast, and less frequently the result.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from the living ancestors, there were
label: Paragraph

text: an assortment of nature deities with various
label: Paragraph

text: legrees of abstraction.
label: Paragraph

text: It was during the Shang period that there
label: Paragraph

text: is the first clear evidence of the rise of cities
label: Paragraph

text: in China. They dominated the great northern
label: Paragraph

text: plain that was enclosed on the north, west,
label: Paragraph

text: and south by mountains or deserts and open
label: Title

text: to the sea on its eastern rim. The Huang
label: Paragraph

text: River and its tributaries flowed through the
label: Paragraph

text: plain from the mountains in the west. In
label: Paragraph

text: those days, the eastern parts consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: extensive marshes, and the coastline was
label: Paragraph

text: farther west than it is today. But the middle
label: Paragraph

text: zone, well watered and with fertile soil, was
label: Paragraph

text: an excellent place for agricultural exploitation.
label: Paragraph

text: It comprises a territory known as the Middle
label: Paragraph

text: Plain. In this, Chinese urbanism began in a
label: Paragraph

text: way that was fundamentally different from
label: Paragraph

text: in Mesopotamia, where cities began as
label: Paragraph

text: risky endeavors in the marshes. They were
label: Paragraph

text: dependent on extensive irrigation techniques,
label: Paragraph

text: and their power could rise and fall with the
label: Paragraph

text: next flood. The first Chinese cities were built
label: Paragraph

text: in much less stressful situations, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese did not yet have extensive irrigation.
label: Paragraph

text: These cities were at their core ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: centers for the elite, and for the construction
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings enormous sacrifices were made.
label: Paragraph

text: So much power did the elites have that
label: Paragraph

text: for the dedication of just one palace, 852
label: Caption

text: humans, 15 horses, 10 oxen, 18 sheep,
label: Paragraph

text: 35 dogs, and 5 fully equipped chariots
label: Caption

text: with horses and their charioteers were all
label: Paragraph

text: entombed. The centers had earthen walls,
label: Paragraph

text: usually of a roughly rectangular form. Though
label: Paragraph

text: they were not purely rectangular, they were
label: Paragraph

text: still governed by sacred principles. An
label: Paragraph

text: important difference between these early
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese cities and their Mesopotamian
label: Title

text: counterparts is that as ceremonial centers
label: Paragraph

text: they contained, either inside the walls or
label: Paragraph

text: nearby, workshop districts where the artisans
label: Paragraph

text: lived who made the bronze, jade, and pottery
label: Paragraph

text: objects that were necessary for the ritual
label: Paragraph

text: practices of the elites. In some sense the city
label: Paragraph

text: emerged as a production zone around the
label: Paragraph

text: ritual center.
label: Paragraph

text: Zhengzhou was immense, with its east
label: Paragraph

text: wall measuring 1.7 kilometers long. It was
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by small villages, workshop
label: Paragraph

text: areas, and bronze foundries. In the northeast
label: Paragraph

text: section of the city, just south of a small
label: Paragraph

text: hill,
label: Title

text: was a district of palaces and temples where
label: Paragraph

text: rammed earth (han fu) platforms of dif
label: Title

text: sizes supported large wood-framed bui
label: Paragraph

text: erent
label: Title

text: dings,
label: Title

text: the largest of which was 60 by 13 meters
label: Paragraph

text: and oriented to the cardinal points. That it is
label: Paragraph

text: located just south of the hill is no acci
label: Paragraph

text: ent,
label: Paragraph

text: as that was and remained the preeminent
label: Paragraph

text: position of Chinese palaces. Whereas t

text: 3.63 Plan and section: Tomb of Fu Hao, near Yin
label: Caption

text: At the beginning of the 14th century BCE, the
label: Paragraph

text: Shang established their capital, Yin, about 2
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers (1.2 miles) north of the modern
label: Paragraph

text: city of Anyang on the banks of the Huan
label: Paragraph

text: River. It too was a vast walled-in ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: center with palaces and temples for ancestral
label: Title

text: worship. There was a special mortuary
label: Paragraph

text: district for the elite, the tombs of which were
label: Paragraph

text: miniature cosmic diagrams. At the center
label: Caption

text: of a royal grave, for example, was a wood-
label: Paragraph

text: chambered tomb, decorated and painted and
label: Paragraph

text: placed some 12 meters belowground. Two
label: Caption

text: and sometimes four ramps led down from the
label: Paragraph

text: surface to the sides of the chamber, in the
label: Paragraph

text: center of which the king was buried. In some
label: Paragraph

text: tombs, guards were buried in the corners,
label: Paragraph

text: each with a dog and holding a weapon. One
label: Paragraph

text: tomb was for Fu Hao, one of the three wives
label: Paragraph

text: of a Chinese king. Fu is a term equivalent
label: Paragraph

text: to “queen”; Hao is her personal name. She
label: Paragraph

text: was no ordinary queen, but rather a military
label: Paragraph

text: commander. Her tomb was a square wooden
label: Paragraph

text: room at the base of a pit 7.5 meters deep.
label: Paragraph

text: The artifacts discovered in the tornb include
label: Paragraph

text: 460 bronze vessels used for ancestral
label: Caption

text: offerings. There were also about 16 human
label: Paragraph

text: sacrifices as well as 6 dogs, including an
label: Paragraph

text: armed man and a dog under the coffin to
label: Title

text: protect her in her afterlife. The tomb was
label: Paragraph

text: located within the ceremonial enclosure at
label: Paragraph

text: Yin (Anyang).

text: CIVILIZATION OF THE HIGH ANDES
label: Title

text: he transformation of arid Andean valleys into
label: Paragraph

text: larmscapes that began at Galgada around
label: Paragraph

text: 3000 BCE continued at Caral a few centuries
label: Paragraph

text: ater. But these grand experiments could not
label: Paragraph

text: jast forever. As Caral grew it became more
label: Paragraph

text: vulnerable to floods, and over time the soil
label: Paragraph

text: quality deteriorated. The valley's decline was
label: Paragraph

text: certainly seen as a message from the gods.
label: Paragraph

text: But the energy was not lost; it simply moved
label: Paragraph

text: to the next valley, Sechin Alto, some 110
label: Paragraph

text: ilometers north of Caral. As at Caral, the
label: Paragraph

text: culture in this valley arrived fully intending
label: Paragraph

text: to transform the river into an agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: universe. The people erected an astonishing
label: Paragraph

text: 300-by-250-meter platform mound rising an
label: Caption

text: imposing 44 meters above the surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: plain. The mound contained 2 million cubic
label: Paragraph

text: feet of fill, masonry, and conical mud bricks,
label: Paragraph

text: making it the largest construction in the
label: Paragraph

text: Americas at that time. It was augmented by
label: Paragraph

text: an almost 1-kilometer-long series of axially
label: Paragraph

text: aligned platforms, terraces, and circular pits.
label: Paragraph

text: As in the Caral Valley, the Sechin Alto
label: Paragraph

text: had were no cities in the technical sense,
label: Paragraph

text: but rather kilometer-long networks of hamlets
label: Paragraph

text: and farmsteads spread out next to the fields
label: Paragraph

text: where the slopes fan out before reaching the
label: Paragraph

text: valley floor. As more fields were created, new
label: Paragraph

text: micro-unities developed, related to one or
label: Paragraph

text: The Casma-Sechin valleys contain the largest
label: Paragraph

text: concentration of pre-Ceramic Period, Initial Period,
label: Paragraph

text: and Early Horizon sites along the Peruvian coast.
label: Paragraph

text: another of the preexisting centers. How much
label: Paragraph

text: friction there was between centers, if any, is
label: Paragraph

text: not known. The people, as would have been
label: Paragraph

text: typical throughout Peru, would travel to the
label: Paragraph

text: centers on ritual days. Trade was key to the
label: Paragraph

text: valley civilization’s survival. Obsidian came
label: Paragraph

text: from the highlands, and the wood used for
label: Paragraph

text: roofs and doorways came from a tree that
label: Paragraph

text: grows only between 1,500 and 3,000 meters
label: Paragraph

text: above sea level. Salt was also important for
label: Paragraph

text: the preservation of food and fish, with a
label: Paragraph

text: major source located 115 kilometers to the
label: Paragraph

text: north, near Salinas de Chao. Plant remains
label: Caption

text: from this site include both the white potato
label: Paragraph

text: and the sweet potato.
label: Paragraph

text: The site contains more than a hundred
label: Paragraph

text: platform structures aligned with two major
label: Paragraph

text: edifices separated by a distance of 1.3
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers. They are oriented 90 degrees to
label: Paragraph

text: the Casma River valley and along the western
label: Paragraph

text: side of a valley that opens into the Casma.
label: Paragraph

text: Between the two structures are several large
label: Paragraph

text: plazas, dominated by a structure known as
label: Paragraph

text: Moxeke, some 170 by 160 meters at its base
label: Paragraph

text: and 30 meters tall. It consists of stacked
label: Paragraph

text: platforms and is rectangular in plan, with
label: Paragraph

text: gently rounded corners. A staircase leads up
label: Caption

text: to a walled square enclosure on a terrace
label: Paragraph

text: halfway up. Behind this enclosure is another
label: Paragraph

text: staircase, this one between two separate
label: Paragraph

text: terrace mounds, both with ritual structures on
label: Paragraph

text: their tops.
label: Paragraph

text: 3.65 The Casma-Sechin valleys
label: Caption

text: Just as the white stones of the Parthenon in
label: Paragraph

text: Athens were once painted in various colors,
label: Paragraph

text: so too were these structures. In Peru, the
label: Paragraph

text: exteriors were painted in shades of red, the
label: Paragraph

text: ancient color of ritual and death, but over
label: Paragraph

text: time the color palette became more complex
label: Paragraph

text: and was used to portray animals, people, and
label: Paragraph

text: mythological scenes. Hindu temples might
label: Paragraph

text: serve as living examples of how buildings
label: Paragraph

text: were painted.
label: Paragraph

text: The outside walls of some of the terraces
label: Caption

text: were ornamented with figures painted light
label: Paragraph

text: red, emerald, white, and black. The size of
label: Paragraph

text: the 3-meter-tall figures indicates that they
label: Paragraph

text: were designed to be visible from quite a
label: Paragraph

text: distance. Furthermore, their placernent high
label: Paragraph

text: on the mound front and extending around on
label: Paragraph

text: either side serves to enhance their visibility to
label: Paragraph

text: the audience in the surrounding plazas.
label: Paragraph

text: The valley contains a most unusual building,
label: Paragraph

text: known as Huaca A, that is composed of 38
label: Paragraph

text: roughly square rooms packed into a large
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular building about 150 meters
label: Caption

text: long, with a courtyard in its center. The
label: Paragraph

text: organization of the roorns is complex. The
label: Paragraph

text: structure, symmetrical around both axes,
label: Paragraph

text: consists of four approximately equivalent
label: Paragraph

text: quadrants. Three large spaces define its
label: Paragraph

text: dominant central axis, with smaller rooms to
label: Paragraph

text: the sides. There are no shared walls between
label: Paragraph

text: the room units. The units, each with walls
label: Paragraph

text: about 2 meters thick, were constructed as
label: Paragraph

text: if they were freestanding elements, even
label: Paragraph

text: when placed next to one another. In some
label: Paragraph

text: instances there no usable space between
label: Paragraph

text: the units; in other instances, the rooms
label: Paragraph

text: are separated by corridors. There is also a
label: Paragraph

text: substantial increase in the elevation of room
label: Caption

text: floors as one moves away from the center.
label: Paragraph

text: he floor level of the corner rooms is 4
label: Caption

text: meters higher than the floor of the central
label: Paragraph

text: court. There can be no doubt that the rooms
label: Paragraph

text: held important commodities, since access to
label: Paragraph

text: the various rooms was regulated by wooden
label: Paragraph

text: gates and bar closures. The rooms are not
label: Paragraph

text: freely interconnected; most of the large
label: Paragraph

text: rooms are accessible only from the two large
label: Paragraph

text: 3.68 Reconstruction: Huaca A, near Casma, Peru
label: Caption

text: entrance lobbies. Similarly, the smaller rooms
label: Paragraph

text: can be accessed only through a carefully
label: Paragraph

text: designed system of corridors. The building
label: Caption

text: was Clearly meant to impress. Ascending the
label: Paragraph

text: central staircase, one enters an atrium and
label: Paragraph

text: is immediately confronted by an enormous
label: Paragraph

text: frieze of a pair of felines, 10 meters long and
label: Caption

text: about 6 meters tall, facing each other across
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance. The three-dimensional aspect
label: Paragraph

text: of the animals would have been enhanced
label: Paragraph

text: by the curvature of the atrium’s walls. A
label: Paragraph

text: low bench, 120 centimeters wide and 25
label: Paragraph

text: centimeters high, further accentuates the
label: Paragraph

text: frieze and may have served as a barrier to
label: Paragraph

text: discourage too close an approach. It seems
label: Paragraph

text: that the building was a sacred storehouse,
label: Paragraph

text: given that the remains of a variety of plant
label: Paragraph

text: foods such as peanuts, beans, and tubers
label: Paragraph

text: were found in the niches. And since other
label: Paragraph

text: items found there include turquoise beads,
label: Paragraph

text: a wooden figurine, and finely made textiles,
label: Paragraph

text: the storehouse was likely used not just for
label: Paragraph

text: food but for commodities of all sorts. The
label: Paragraph

text: building was clearly the focal point for the
label: Paragraph

text: bureaucratic and ritualistic activities of
label: Title

text: collecting and redistributing food and craft
label: Title

text: items.

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: It might seem counterintuitive that in a
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: so easily available that these same people
label: Paragraph

text: would master the production of corn. Unlike
label: Paragraph

text: wheat, barley, and rice, which in their edible
label: Paragraph

text: forms are relatively similar to their wild
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: years of genetic development. It seems that
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the El Salvador—Guatemala border, where a
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: in the modern sense. At any rate, it is clear
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: a god, which mean that planting corn was not
label: Paragraph

text: only an agricultural process but a theological
label: Paragraph

text: one. Soon, certainly before 1000 BCE, it was
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ash softened the kernels and allowed the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: untreated maize.

label: Caption

text: Corn came in different types and sizes and
label: Paragraph

text: was used in a variety of cuisines. One type
label: Paragraph

text: was used for cornmeal; another for roasting;
label: Paragraph

text: another for hominy, a type of grits; and yet
label: Paragraph

text: another for bread. For corn bread, the corn
label: Paragraph

text: was grated from the cob and made into a
label: Paragraph

text: milky mush—which could also be combined
label: Paragraph

text: with bean meal—and was slowly baked until
label: Paragraph

text: it became a type of cake. Some types of corn
label: Paragraph

text: were best when preserved, which was done
label: Paragraph

text: in the sun or over a fire. Corn could also be
label: Paragraph

text: used to make a fermented drink.

label: Paragraph

text: It was the Olmecs who set in play the corn-
label: Paragraph

text: centric worldview that would become the
label: Paragraph

text: marker of civilization in the Americas. They
label: Paragraph

text: did so by making a risky move, leaving the
label: Paragraph

text: wet forests for uninhabited marshes on the
label: Paragraph

text: east coast of Mexico. The only wildlife of
label: Paragraph

text: any size in these swampy areas were turtles
label: Paragraph

text: and birds. The Olmecs’ decision to build in
label: Paragraph

text: stone was even more extraordinary, since
label: Paragraph

text: the massive stones that they used had to
label: Paragraph

text: be dragged for many kilometers from the
label: Paragraph

text: mountains to the north. Two elements were,
label: Paragraph

text: however, in their favor: One was salt from
label: Paragraph

text: the shore, which they processed and used
label: Paragraph

text: to trade for many things they needed. They
label: Paragraph

text: also had bitumen from various oil seeps,
label: Paragraph

text: which was useful to make watertight baskets
label: Paragraph

text: and boats. It might be a stretch to compare
label: Paragraph

text: the situation to the modern-day difference
label: Title

text: between a family farrn and a corporate one,
label: Paragraph

text: but holding this difference in mind, even in
label: Paragraph

text: general terms, helps illurninate the drarna set
label: Paragraph

text: in play by the Olmecs. This was no gradual
label: Paragraph

text: expansion of plant-tending lifestyles; it was a
label: Paragraph

text: purposeful industrialization of the landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: This means that the Olmecs settled in the
label: Paragraph

text: region specifically to transform it from swamp
label: Paragraph

text: to a corn-producing center, controlled by
label: Paragraph

text: a cult of powerful personalities who were
label: Paragraph

text: probably part shaman, part deity, and part
label: Paragraph

text: ruler.
label: Paragraph

text: 4.5 A characteristic motif of Olmec

text: art was the were-jaguar, a human face
label: Paragraph

text: with the mouth of a jaguar
label: Title

text: The religious life of the Olmecs centered
label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: The volcano, a symbol frequently used in
label: Paragraph

text: Olmec imagery, was associated with the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: lightning, and rain. It was depicted as a
label: Paragraph

text: dragon with a gaping mouth representing
label: Title

text: the portal to the underworld. The sky was
label: Paragraph

text: ruled by a bird monster or sun god whose
label: Paragraph

text: energy powered the cosmos and made
label: Title

text: the plants grow. Underneath the dragon,
label: Paragraph

text: the Olmecs visualized a watery void out
label: Paragraph

text: of which the world was formed. The main
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: depicted as a jaguar, a shamanistic symbol
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: other forms—even human ones. The sexual
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: a snarling mouth, and a cleft head. The
label: Paragraph

text: Olmecs learned to drag and float stones and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of 160 kilometers. Most were chiseled into
label: Paragraph

text: jaguars or human heads by Olmec sculptors.

text: Unlike the angular and sharp features of

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: By 800 BCE, the innovative Peruvian shore
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: invaders, probably frorn the highlands; no
label: Paragraph

text: one knows for sure. The rise and decline
label: Paragraph

text: of these civilizations within a relatively short
label: Paragraph

text: time, along with the militarization of society,
label: Paragraph

text: must have had a powerful impact on the
label: Paragraph

text: psyche of the times and seems to have led
label: Paragraph

text: to a shift in ideological focus. Power shifted
label: Paragraph

text: to centers away from the coast to the rugged
label: Paragraph

text: highlands, the most important of which was
label: Paragraph

text: Chavin de Huantar, founded around 900 BCE.
label: Paragraph

text: It is located halfway between the Supe Valley
label: Paragraph

text: to the south and the Casma Valley to the
label: Paragraph

text: north, at a place where the Mosna River
label: Paragraph

text: narrows dramatically into a precipitous gorge.
label: Paragraph

text: There, at the convergence point of two major
label: Paragraph

text: passes crossing the snowcapped Cordillera
label: Title

text: Blanca, the Mosna meets the Wachesqua
label: Title

text: River at a triangular space wedged between
label: Paragraph

text: descending mountain slopes that is the only
label: Paragraph

text: flat area for miles around. Though seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: remote, Chavin de Huantar was only about a
label: Paragraph

text: six-day trek to the Pacific Ocean to the west
label: Title

text: and to the tropical forests to the east. The
label: Paragraph

text: tight valley could never have supported the
label: Paragraph

text: population density of Casma; agriculture here
label: Paragraph

text: was thus pursued by the more traditional
label: Paragraph

text: means of small terraced plots.
label: Paragraph

text: The temple of Chavin de Huantar was,
label: Paragraph

text: therefore, of a new type of institution deriving
label: Paragraph

text: its economy almost entirely from the draw
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: their open plazas and relaxed and generously
label: Paragraph

text: scaled monuments, here the temple was in
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: lesigned to enhance and produce certain

label: Paragraph

text: THE IRON AGE
label: Title

text: Scholars generally think that the forging
label: Paragraph

text: of iron was developed by the Hittites, who
label: Paragraph

text: kept the technique secret. Its development
label: Paragraph

text: had taken thousands of years of familiarity
label: Paragraph

text: with kilns, metals, and extraction methods,
label: Paragraph

text: until high-temperature smelting could be
label: Paragraph

text: mastered. But after the downfall of the
label: Paragraph

text: Hittites in 1200 BCE, the art of iron forging
label: Paragraph

text: spread, reaching China around 600 BCE.
label: Paragraph

text: Apart from China, there were five newly
label: Paragraph

text: emerging metal-oriented societies: the
label: Title

text: Urartians in Armenia, the Nubians in the
label: Paragraph

text: Sudan, the Etruscans in Italy, the Dorians
label: Paragraph

text: and lonians in Greece, and, somewhat later,
label: Paragraph

text: the Mauryans in India. As these cultures
label: Paragraph

text: were all marginal to the Mesopotamian/
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian civilizations, the consequences were
label: Paragraph

text: enormous. Iron, in other words, completely
label: Paragraph

text: changed the political and civilizational
label: Title

text: landscape; areas once peripheral to the
label: Paragraph

text: urbanized agro-centric, Mesopotamian/
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian heartlands became important, if not
label: Paragraph

text: dominant, players in the world economy.
label: Paragraph

text: lron was used to make weapons, of
label: Paragraph

text: course, but was also superior for crafting
label: Paragraph

text: agricultural implements like plows and
label: Title

text: wheels. With iron plows, the plains of
label: Paragraph

text: Sicily, the north coast of Africa, and
label: Paragraph

text: even the high plains of eastern Anatolia
label: Paragraph

text: became major grain-producing regions,
label: Paragraph

text: significantly lessening the need for grain
label: Paragraph

text: from Mesopotamia and Egypt. Iron farm
label: Caption

text: implements also had a profound impact
label: Paragraph

text: on the development of agriculture in sub-
label: Title

text: Saharan Africa, where for the first time, large-
label: Paragraph

text: scale agriculture and land clearing could be
label: Paragraph

text: undertaken. The African connection—which
label: Paragraph

text: was centered around Nubia and later
label: Paragraph

text: Aksum—exhausted itself around 600 BCE
label: Paragraph

text: largely because deforestation had led to
label: Paragraph

text: serious environmental degradation, which
label: Paragraph

text: made both mining and agriculture difficult
label: Paragraph

text: and had permanent negative consequences
label: Paragraph

text: for the economy.
label: Paragraph

text: The Urartians were conquered by the
label: Paragraph

text: Assyrians in order to secure a steady supply
label: Paragraph

text: of metal for their army. There is little left of
label: Paragraph

text: Urartian architecture, apart from remnants,
label: Paragraph

text: most of it having been destroyed by centuries
label: Paragraph

text: of warfare. The Nubians, who produced
label: Paragraph

text: extensive architectural works, continued
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian traditions. The Etruscans and the
label: Paragraph

text: Dorians were, however, newcomers, having
label: Paragraph

text: moved into the Mediterranean from the north.
label: Paragraph

text: Their views on the world were different from
label: Paragraph

text: that of the Egyptians and Mesopotamians,
label: Paragraph

text: leading them to create a highly refined civic-
label: Paragraph

text: legal description of the divine that was to
label: Paragraph

text: impact European architecture for centuries.
label: Paragraph
