text: THE ETRUSCANS
label: Title

text: The origin of the Etruscans is hotly debated.
label: Paragraph

text: Their language, which has only been partially
label: Paragraph

text: deciphered, does not belong to the Indo-
label: Paragraph

text: European language family. They settled
label: Paragraph

text: predominantly in the north part of the Italian
label: Paragraph

text: peninsula, between the Arno and Tiber
label: Paragraph

text: Rivers and on the west side of the Apennine
label: Paragraph

text: Mountains. This territory provided plenty of
label: Paragraph

text: metal ore, such as copper, iron, lead, and
label: Paragraph

text: silver, but the Etruscans appear to have
label: Paragraph

text: acquired the skill to exploit these metals prior
label: Paragraph

text: to settling in Italy; indeed, the presence of
label: Paragraph

text: these ores might have attracted these settlers
label: Paragraph

text: in the first place. For example, Volterra, one
label: Paragraph

text: of their main cities, twelve of which formed
label: Paragraph

text: the Etruscan League (Dodecapoli), was close
label: Paragraph

text: to Colline Metallifere (Metalliferous Hills). The
label: Paragraph

text: Etruscan city of Vulci, also part of the league,
label: Paragraph

text: was especially noted for its bronze work.
label: Paragraph

text: It was not just the Etruscans’ economic
label: Paragraph

text: acumen that differentiated them from the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding tribes but also their fantastic
label: Paragraph

text: belief structure, which relied heavily on
label: Paragraph

text: omens. The Etruscan aesthetic, as displayed
label: Paragraph

text: in the decoration of their graves, was
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneous, vivacious, and open to the
label: Paragraph

text: appreciation of other cultures—especially that
label: Paragraph

text: of the Greeks, whose goods and vases they
label: Paragraph

text: freely imported and copied. As a group, the
label: Paragraph

text: Dorians, lonians, and Etruscans all played an
label: Paragraph

text: important part in restoring the Mediterranean
label: Paragraph

text: Tyrrhenian Sea

text: Despite the settlements of the Greeks in

text: the south and center of Italy, the Etruscans
label: Paragraph

text: were able to maintain their hold over the
label: Paragraph

text: northern half of the Italian peninsula. There
label: Paragraph

text: they had a vibrant interaction with Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: the ascendant power, until they were finally
label: Paragraph

text: absorbed into the Roman Empire, to which
label: Paragraph

text: they contributed substantively. Many Etruscan
label: Paragraph

text: cities, like Veii, north of Rome, were, in their
label: Paragraph

text: heyday, as big as Athens, with a population
label: Paragraph

text: estimated as high as one hundred thousand.

text: cities has largely been lost, much can be

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: centuries BCE, as well as the Porta all’Arco

text: and the Porta di Diana, still bear witness to

text: Etruscan skills. The city gate of Perugia in
label: Caption

label: Title

text: he outward aspect of Etruscan religion
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: expense of stylistic unity—something that
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: on it. The particularities of the animal's liver
label: Paragraph

text: told the priest which deity to invoke. It was
label: Paragraph

text: probably meant to be aligned north-south.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the words used to describe this
label: Paragraph

text: liver was templum, which could refer to the
label: Paragraph

text: sky, to a consecrated area on earth, or toa
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: the celestial model. A fermpfum could thus be
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: area of the sky, in which the birds would be
label: Paragraph

text: observed.
label: Paragraph

text: A tempium, in other words, was a space
label: Paragraph

text: where humans, represented by priests
label: Paragraph

text: (augurs), could interact with the gods. In all
label: Paragraph

text: ancient Mediterranean and Mesopotamian
label: Title

text: cultures, nature was associated with divine
label: Paragraph

text: presences, but for the Etruscans, the gods
label: Paragraph

text: spoke through signs. This was not the case
label: Paragraph

text: in Mesopotamian religions, where gods
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Post-Mycenaean Greece was a period of

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: lonians along the Turkish coast came to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the Minoan and Mycenaean cultures. This
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: development from that of the Etruscans.
label: Paragraph

text: The Minoans and Mycenaeans, having had
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: visiting each other in their palaces. The
label: Paragraph

text: early Dorian religious practices took place
label: Paragraph

text: in natural settings, which made it easy to
label: Paragraph

text: incorporate some of the features and even
label: Paragraph

text: locations of Minoan religion into their own.

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: particular tree or grove.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The meaning of this sacrificial process is

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: did not take the fire back but punished
label: Paragraph

text: Prometheus by chaining him to a cliff and
label: Paragraph

text: having an eagle eat his liver. His liver would
label: Paragraph

text: grow back every day, only to be eaten
label: Paragraph

text: again. The sacrifice was thus part of a ritual
label: Paragraph

text: remembrance of humankind’s emergence
label: Title

text: into civilization and of their dependence
label: Title

text: on the gods for the regulation of their lives.
label: Paragraph

text: But the sacrifice also marked the difference
label: Paragraph

text: tween humankind and gods, for unlike
label: Paragraph

text: the gods, who existed in an ethereal form,
label: Paragraph

text: umankind had to work and show sincerity
label: Paragraph

text: to keep the communication alive. Only by
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: jove—could men demonstrate that they were

text: thankful to the deities. That is why a skinny

label: Paragraph

text: Nevertheless, Dorians, Minoans, and even
label: Paragraph

text: Etruscans had somewhat differing notions
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: intimate than that of the Greeks. Unlike the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptians, Greek sacrifice was connected to
label: Paragraph

text: the principles of farming and herding, rather
label: Paragraph

text: than to the palace garden. Bread and meat
label: Paragraph

text: were at the center of Greek sacrifice. Even
label: Paragraph

text: in the Christian Eucharist, which developed
label: Paragraph

text: later, the importance of bread and wine is
label: Paragraph

text: encountered in veiled form, a comparison
label: Paragraph

text: that raises important questions about
label: Paragraph

text: the influence of Greek practices on early
label: Title

text: Christianity. The importance of the Greeks’
label: Paragraph

text: attitudes toward sacrifice might easily be
label: Title

text: overlooked because so many of their altars
label: Paragraph

text: were removed when Christianity tried to
label: Paragraph

text: destroy any evidence of heathen practices. In
label: Paragraph

text: fact, in the early days of Greek religion, there
label: Paragraph

text: were no temples, only altars built out in the
label: Paragraph

text: open.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the earliest and most sacred of
label: Paragraph

text: the Greek altars, on the top of Mt. Lykaion
label: Caption

text: in the Greek Peloponnese, dates back to
label: Paragraph

text: 3000 BCE—Mycenaean times. It eventually
label: Paragraph

text: became associated with Zeus, the king of
label: Paragraph

text: the Greek gods, but whether that was true
label: Paragraph

text: in the earlier period is unknown. Below the
label: Paragraph

text: summit there was a stadium, indicating
label: Paragraph

text: the site’s association with an athletic
label: Paragraph

text: festival, a combination that was to become
label: Paragraph

text: another important element of many Greek
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuaries.
label: Paragraph

text: The Mt. Lykaion altar, like the Temple of
label: Paragraph

text: Hera at Samos (8th century BCE) consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: no more than a low enclosure of flat stones
label: Paragraph

text: forming a rectangle of about 2 by 3.5 meters.
label: Paragraph

text: Altars became larger as time progressed; the
label: Paragraph

text: one on the Acropolis at Athens, for exarnple,
label: Caption

text: from the 5th or 4th century BCE, could hold
label: Paragraph

text: a dozen bulls at one time. The Altar of Zeus
label: Caption

text: at Pergarnon, now in the Pergamon Museum
label: Caption

text: in Berlin, was the most spectacular of all.
label: Paragraph

text: Built from 197 to 159 BCE, it featured a flight
label: Paragraph

text: of steps on its west side and flanking lonic
label: Paragraph

text: colonnades. It stands on a five-stepped,
label: Paragraph

text: almost square plinth. The altar proper was
label: Paragraph

text: inside the court.
label: Paragraph

text: The altars were not necessarily aligned
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrically on axis with the ternple,
label: Paragraph

text: especially during the Archaic period. At
label: Paragraph

text: Samos, the altar, with its sacred tree, stood at
label: Paragraph

text: irst at an oblique angle, referring perhaps to
label: Paragraph

text: a different celestial moment than that of the
label: Paragraph

text: temple.
label: Paragraph

text: The emergence of the altar-plus-temple
label: Title

text: form coincided with the personification of
label: Paragraph

text: gods in statues and, once again, seems to
label: Paragraph

text: ave been part of the assimilation process
label: Paragraph

text: the Dorians underwent when they came into
label: Paragraph

text: contact with older Mediterranean practices.
label: Paragraph

text: Early Greek representations of their gods

text: show influences from both the Mesopotamian
label: Paragraph

text: and Egyptian cultures. But Greek
label: Paragraph

text: representations were rarely as diminutive as
label: Paragraph

text: the Mesopotamian and Minoan statues could
label: Paragraph

text: be, nor as large as the Egyptians’ often were.
label: Paragraph

text: And perhaps therein lies the origin of the
label: Paragraph

text: Greek advancement of the depiction of the

text: human figure. The earliest three-dimensional
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: together) were carved from wooden columns
label: Paragraph

text: or planks at a roughly life-size scale. The
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: an image that was shaped like a pillar or
label: Paragraph

text: column. The statues gradually came to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Emergence of the Greek Temple Form
label: Title

text: The earliest temples, built of mud bricks and
label: Paragraph

text: thatched roofs, were presumably modeled on
label: Paragraph

text: chieftains’ houses and consisted of a single
label: Paragraph

text: elongated, windowless room—a naos or cella
label: Paragraph

text: (from which the word cellar cormes}—that
label: Paragraph

text: was eventually divided into a pronaos and
label: Paragraph

text: naos. An example is the Ternple of Apollo at
label: Paragraph

text: Thermos (ca. 950 BCE) in the area of Aetolia
label: Paragraph

text: in western Greece, where a low stone wall
label: Paragraph

text: supported a high, steeply pitched thatched
label: Paragraph

text: roof. There were no side chambers, ancillary
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, or storage rooms. Soon a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: porch was added around the body of the
label: Paragraph

text: building to form an oblong shape, which over
label: Paragraph

text: time became regularized and systemized.
label: Paragraph

text: Later (ca. 630 BCE) we see, in the successive
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilding of the temple, the developrnent
label: Caption

text: of the temple form over time, ending in
label: Paragraph

text: the regularized form of later temples. The
label: Paragraph

text: last temple had an elongated form, with
label: Paragraph

text: proportions of almost 5 to 1 and a row of
label: Paragraph

text: columns down the center.
label: Paragraph

text: Though Greek ternples can be found facing
label: Paragraph

text: the various directions of the compass, more
label: Paragraph

text: than 80 percent were laid out to face the
label: Paragraph

text: sunrise, and most, more specifically, faced
label: Paragraph

text: toward the sunrise on the actual day of their
label: Paragraph

text: founding, which in turn coincided with the
label: Paragraph

text: festival day of the divinity to which the temple
label: Title

text: was dedicated. From this custom arises the
label: Paragraph

text: term orientation, primarily applied to the
label: Paragraph

text: direction of the axis of a temple. Temples,
label: Paragraph

text: jowever, were also sometimes oriented to
label: Paragraph

text: elements in the landscape, to a solitary peak
label: Paragraph

text: that suggested the presence of Zeus, or to
label: Paragraph

text: double peaks, which, reminiscent of a bull's
label: Paragraph

text: jorns, were equated with Zeus. The Greek
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuary was far from being a detached
label: Paragraph

text: and spiritual sphere. Symbolically, it was
label: Paragraph

text: representative of political, economic, and
label: Paragraph

text: military life as well as the well-being of the
label: Paragraph

text: city and the region. Many temples served as

text: as well as serving as armories.

label: Title

text: The Temple of Poseidon at Isthmia (ca.
label: Caption

text: 700 BCE), not far from Corinth, is among the
label: Paragraph

text: earliest known Greek temples. Its podium
label: Paragraph

text: measures 14 by 40 meters, with a central
label: Paragraph

text: row of five columns within the cella and
label: Caption

text: two in the pronaos. The cella was of stone,
label: Paragraph

text: but the columns and entablature were of
label: Paragraph

text: oak; the roof was low pitched and covered
label: Paragraph

text: in fired terra-cotta tiles—a Greek invention.
label: Paragraph

text: his temple represents an important break in
label: Paragraph

text: the development of temple design. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: the stones for Egyptian temples were of
label: Paragraph

text: irregular size, the ashlar blocks of this temple
label: Paragraph

text: were laid in regular courses all the way to
label: Paragraph

text: the roofline—a standardization of masonry
label: Paragraph

text: elements. Furthermore, in Egypt, a wall was
label: Paragraph

text: typically composed of two separate walls, the
label: Paragraph

text: gap between them filled with rubble. Here
label: Paragraph

text: the wall is a single vertical element. As with
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian temples, however, the wall was
label: Paragraph

text: covered with a thin coat of plaster that would
label: Paragraph

text: present to the viewer a smooth, continuous
label: Paragraph

text: surface broken only, in this case, by a series
label: Paragraph

text: of pilasters that responded to the rhythm of
label: Paragraph

text: the colonnade along the outside of the cella.
label: Caption

text: The site was fortified in about 1200 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: and ritual festivities were performed from
label: Paragraph

text: the middle of the 11th century BCE onward.
label: Paragraph

text: The Temple of Poseidon eventually attracted
label: Paragraph

text: the Panhellenic Games, called the Isthmia,
label: Paragraph

text: which took place every two years in honor of
label: Paragraph

text: Melicertes-Palaemon, or Poseidon. The altar
label: Caption

text: was a 30-meter-long structure in front of the
label: Paragraph

text: temple, with the sports field and stadium just
label: Paragraph

text: to the south.

text: KINGDOM OF KUSH
label: Title

text: Egypt had only one main export, grain, and
label: Paragraph

text: as the Greeks became more self-reliant, the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian economy began to falter. It had
label: Paragraph

text: no metal either, and in the end it fell victim
label: Paragraph

text: to the Iron Age. Not only was it conquered
label: Paragraph

text: by the distant Assyrians, Babylonians,
label: Paragraph

text: Persians, Greeks, and Romans, but for a
label: Paragraph

text: period even by the Nubians, who had been
label: Paragraph

text: at the sharp end of the Egyptian spear for
label: Paragraph

text: centuries. As a consequence of the imperial
label: Paragraph

text: expansion of the New Kingdom dynasties of
label: Title

text: Egypt into Nubia, these subjugated peoples
label: Paragraph

text: had adopted Egyptian religion, culture,
label: Paragraph

text: and weapons of war. The Nubians served
label: Paragraph

text: as valued mercenaries in the Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: army, worshipped Egyptian gods, and built
label: Paragraph

text: pyramids in which to entomb their rulers.
label: Paragraph

text: Nubia was rich in natural resources, notably
label: Paragraph

text: gold, with mines numbering in the hundreds
label: Paragraph

text: scattered over the desert. To extract the
label: Paragraph

text: metal from the veins of the quartz rock, the
label: Paragraph

text: rock was first cracked by means of fire, then
label: Paragraph

text: crushed into a powder by mills, and finally
label: Paragraph

text: washed to separate the ore, which was
label: Paragraph

text: melted into small ingots. The system was
label: Paragraph

text: hugely labor intensive but yielded, by one
label: Paragraph

text: estimation, 40,000 kilograms of gold a year,
label: Paragraph

text: an amount that would not be exceeded again
label: Paragraph

text: until the 19th century CE. With the demise
label: Paragraph

text: of the New Kingdom, Nubia, also known as
label: Paragraph

text: Kush, was free to assert itself and, during
label: Paragraph

text: the reign of Piye (747-716 BCE), conquered
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt and ruled there as the Twenty-fifth
label: Paragraph

text: Dynasty.
label: Paragraph

text: lron played an important role, for the Kushites
label: Paragraph

text: had learned the techniques of ironworking
label: Paragraph

text: from their Assyrian enemies. Though the
label: Paragraph

text: Kushites had iron, they did not have the fuel
label: Paragraph

text: with which to smelt it. For that they had to
label: Paragraph

text: turn southward, to the area around the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Meroé, where the ancient, largely unexcavated
label: Paragraph

text: slag heaps are still visible today. There the
label: Paragraph

text: Kushite pharaohs promoted the Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: religion and embarked on programs of temple
label: Paragraph

text: restoration.
label: Paragraph

text: At first, the center of the Kushite state was
label: Paragraph

text: at Napata, lying just above the fourth cataract
label: Paragraph

text: in the Nile River. Its focal point was the sacred
label: Paragraph

text: flat-topped mountain of Jebel Barkal, which
label: Paragraph

text: stands like a natural altar in the landscape a
label: Paragraph

text: few kilometers from the northern bank of the
label: Paragraph

text: Nile. In its shadow Ramesses II had already
label: Paragraph

text: built several temples, one of which was the
label: Paragraph

text: rather substantial Ternple of Amun. The
label: Paragraph

text: tombs at Napata are sited on both sides of
label: Paragraph

text: the Nile; they are all that is left of the Nubian
label: Paragraph

text: capital that once stood nearby. The early
label: Paragraph

text: tombs were round mastabas. These gave
label: Paragraph

text: way to pyramids mounted on high bases with
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive porches. During the last phase, at
label: Paragraph

text: the height of Kushite control over Egypt, the
label: Paragraph

text: rulers simplified the form to a pyramid and
label: Paragraph

text: porch. A group of these are located not too far
label: Paragraph

text: from Napata, near the modern town of Nuri.
label: Paragraph

text: They form a tight cluster, with the bigger ones
label: Paragraph

text: loosely lined up in row.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Under the Zhou, ritual halls became part
label: Paragraph

text: of the standard architectural vocabulary.
label: Paragraph

text: These halls were places where the elite
label: Paragraph

text: assembled according to their status in the
label: Paragraph

text: social hierarchy. The vessels would be
label: Paragraph

text: set out on the floor or low shelves in pre-
label: Paragraph

text: established order, with the rituals themselves
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied by chimes that marked noble
label: Paragraph

text: rank. A chime of sixty-five bells, which would
label: Paragraph

text: have required six musicians standing and
label: Paragraph

text: kneeling on both sides of the instrument, was
label: Paragraph

text: recovered from a Zhou dynasty tormb. The
label: Paragraph

text: hall was positioned in a central court entered
label: Paragraph

text: through a gatehouse. A reconstruction of the
label: Caption

text: ritual complex at Fengchu (1100-1000 BCE)
label: Caption

text: shows an axially symmetrical arrangement of
label: Paragraph

text: one-story buildings. In front of the entrance
label: Caption

text: there was a freestanding wall, which, as in
label: Paragraph

text: later Chinese structures, served to prevent
label: Paragraph

text: unwanted spirits from entering the complex.
label: Paragraph

text: The ritual platform was accessible by three
label: Paragraph

text: flights of stairs. The main construction was of
label: Paragraph

text: wood, with bronze used to bind and reinforce
label: Paragraph

text: structural elements at the joints.

text: THE ARYAN INVASION AND VARANASI
label: Title

text: As the cities of the Indus Ghaggar-Hakra
label: Paragraph

text: civilization were withering away, a group of
label: Paragraph

text: migrants, originating in Central Asia, made
label: Paragraph

text: their appearance. These Indo-Aryans, as
label: Paragraph

text: they are now called, were expert horsemen,
label: Paragraph

text: inventors of the chariot, and skilled in their
label: Paragraph

text: use of iron. They settled first around five
label: Paragraph

text: tributaries of the Indus River, but then, using
label: Paragraph

text: iron to chop down the forests, moved into the
label: Paragraph

text: fertile Gangetic Plains around 1200 BCE. Of
label: Paragraph

text: the numerous cities that came to be built, little
label: Paragraph

text: remains, since everything was made of wood.
label: Paragraph

text: By the year 1000 BCE, sixteen kingdoms and
label: Paragraph

text: semirepublics, known as mahajanapadas,
label: Paragraph

text: had developed. Warfare armong them
label: Paragraph

text: was constant, with victors absorbing the
label: Paragraph

text: vanquished and destroying their cities. By
label: Paragraph

text: 500 BCE, four mahajanapadas dominated:
label: Paragraph

text: Magacha, Kosala, Kasi, and the republican
label: Title

text: Vrajji Confederacy. Around 450 BCE, Magadha
label: Paragraph

text: became the dominant power by defeating
label: Paragraph

text: the Vrajji Confederacy as well as Kosala and
label: Paragraph

text: Kasi. Kasi’s capital, Varanasi, was spared the
label: Paragraph

text: normal fate of a conquered city and granted
label: Paragraph

text: special status as a pilgrimage site. It was
label: Paragraph

text: here that codification of Aryan rituals, as
label: Paragraph

text: elaborated in their oral treatises, took place.
label: Paragraph

text: What emerged was not a single doctrine, but
label: Paragraph

text: various philosophical schools ranging from the
label: Paragraph

text: materialist to the atheist.

text: Varanasi was so important as a center of
label: Paragraph

text: religious learning that in the 6th century BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: the famed Shakyamuni Buddha made
label: Paragraph

text: Varanasi his first stop after his self-
label: Paragraph

text: enlightenment. Numerous other influential
label: Paragraph

text: thinkers came to the city as well, including
label: Paragraph

text: Adi Shankara (9th centuryCE), whose
label: Paragraph

text: teachings and writings laid the foundations
label: Title

text: of Hinduism, which relied heavily on Vedic
label: Paragraph

text: ideas.
label: Paragraph

text: Vedic rituals did not require ternples
label: Paragraph

text: or even the creation of statues. They were
label: Paragraph

text: based on fire sacrifices of various kinds that
label: Paragraph

text: needed only brick platforms. Fire was the
label: Paragraph

text: agent that enabled the transformation of the
label: Paragraph

text: sacrificial food (matter) into smoke and air
label: Title

text: (energy). The water of the Ganges is also
label: Paragraph

text: sacred as another essential element of life. At
label: Paragraph

text: dawn every morning, thousands of devotees
label: Paragraph

text: gather on ghats—steps leading down to the
label: Paragraph

text: shore—to face the sun that rises across the
label: Paragraph

text: broad expanse of the Ganges River and is
label: Paragraph

text: reflected in its waters. Half immersed in the
label: Paragraph

text: river, they greet the sun by cupping the water
label: Paragraph

text: of the Ganges into their palms and pouring it
label: Paragraph

text: back into the river with arms extended. This
label: Paragraph

text: is followed by a slow turn of 360 degrees
label: Paragraph

text: while standing in place, a miniature act
label: Paragraph

text: of circumambulation. A quick dip in the
label: Paragraph

text: river completes the ritual. This ritual can
label: Paragraph

text: be repeated many times or performed with
label: Paragraph

text: greater elaboration that includes long chants
label: Paragraph

text: and sequences of yogic postures.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the river on a high, natural berm at a curve in

text: the river. Behind the berm, in a semicircular
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The open terrain of the Mesopotamian
label: Title

text: heartland exposed the Assyrians, who
label: Paragraph

text: controlled the northern river regions, to the
label: Paragraph

text: seminomadic intrusions of the Kassites, the
label: Paragraph

text: Hurrians, and subsequently, the Mitannians,
label: Paragraph

text: whose kingdom was to extend over all of
label: Paragraph

text: northern Mesopotamia. Assyria remained
label: Paragraph

text: under Mitannian rule until early in the 14th
label: Paragraph

text: century BCE, with only the core of its kingdom
label: Paragraph

text: more or less intact, forming a narrow strip
label: Paragraph

text: of land 150 kilometers long and only 40
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers wide along the western bank of the
label: Paragraph

text: Tigris River. After the Mitanni defeat at the
label: Paragraph

text: hands of the Hittites, the Assyrians reasserted
label: Paragraph

text: themselves, invading Syria and compelling
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean coastal cities like Tyre, Sidon,
label: Paragraph

text: Byblos, and Arvad to pay tribute. In 663 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: the Assyrians were even able to sack the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian city of Thebes. They were the first
label: Paragraph

text: 4.61 Plan: Dur-Sharrukin (Khorsabad), near Mosul, Iraq

text: to command a truly Iron Age army. Though
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: strict rule of divinely sanctioned warfare.
label: Paragraph

text: Their engineers built bridges, tunnels, moats,
label: Paragraph

text: and weapons of various sorts. By the year
label: Paragraph

text: 668 BCE, Assyria had control over Egypt and
label: Paragraph

text: the Nile River valley.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: western steppe, it was relocated by Assur-

text: Nasir-Pal II to Old Kalakh, now Nimrud, 64
label: Caption

text: kilometers to the north. But shortly thereafter,
label: Paragraph

text: Sargon II (r. 722-705 BCE) designed the
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable Dur-Sharrukin (Fort Sargon)
label: Caption

text: near the present-day village of Khorsabad.
label: Paragraph

text: Located 24 kilometers northeast of Nineveh,
label: Paragraph

text: the fortress/city controlled the main pass
label: Paragraph

text: route coming down from the mountains to
label: Title

text: the north, and its founding was intended to
label: Paragraph

text: fend off any threat of invasion by the northern
label: Paragraph

text: tribes. It was also a place where precious iron
label: Paragraph

text: ore could be funneled into the empire. In
label: Paragraph

text: plan, the city was a squarish parallelogram,
label: Paragraph

text: with the palace, ternples, and government
label: Paragraph

text: buildings all compressed into an autonomous
label: Paragraph

text: unit straddling the walls. In all, it covered 300
label: Paragraph

text: hectares of ground.
label: Paragraph

text: 4.62 View of palace compound of Dur-Sharrukin (Khorsabad)
label: Caption

text: On the northwest side, half within and half
label: Paragraph

text: without the circuit of the walls, protruding
label: Paragraph

text: into the plain like a great bastion, stood the
label: Paragraph

text: royal enclave. It rested on a 16-meter-high,
label: Paragraph

text: 10-hectare platform overlooking the city
label: Caption

text: wall and comprised more than two hundred
label: Paragraph

text: rooms and thirty courtyards. The palace
label: Paragraph

text: in the center opened around a large inner
label: Paragraph

text: court. It contained the public reception
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, which were elaborately decorated
label: Paragraph

text: with sculptures and historical inscriptions
label: Title

text: representing scenes of hunting, worship,
label: Paragraph

text: feasts, and battles. The harem, with separate
label: Paragraph

text: provisions for four wives, occupied the south
label: Paragraph

text: corner. The stables, kitchen, bakery, and
label: Paragraph

text: wine cellar were located at the east corner.
label: Paragraph

text: In the west corner stood the temple with
label: Paragraph

text: a multistage ziggurat, its seven floor levels
label: Paragraph

text: painted in different colors and connected
label: Paragraph

text: by ramps. Below this enclave, on the inner
label: Paragraph

text: side, was a Zone surrounded by its own walls
label: Paragraph

text: that held the administrative heart of the city
label: Paragraph

text: and the sumptuous houses of high-ranking
label: Title

text: officials. For some reason, but likely because
label: Paragraph

text: of its precarious position at the perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: of the empire, Sargon’s son and successor,
label: Paragraph

text: Sennacherib, moved the capital back to the
label: Paragraph

text: old established city of Nineveh.
label: Paragraph

text: The Assyrians, though possessing a
label: Paragraph

text: formidable military machine, were unable
label: Paragraph

text: to translate military success into economic
label: Paragraph

text: stability. This was largely because they
label: Paragraph

text: relocated vast numbers of people—estimates
label: Paragraph

text: are as high as around six million—in their
label: Paragraph

text: effort to thwart rebellion. Not only were
label: Paragraph

text: the resettled peoples unfamiliar with their
label: Paragraph

text: new lands, but many of their skills were no
label: Paragraph

text: longer appropriate. In essence, the Assyrians
label: Paragraph

text: obliterated their own tax base and quickly ran
label: Paragraph

text: out of money.

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Caption

text: who ruled between 604 and 562 BCE, started .
label: Paragraph

text: massive building projects. By 560 BCE, if
label: Paragraph

text: Babylon was certainly the most spectacular

label: Paragraph

text: Spanning the Euphrates, Babylon had two

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: terraces

text: and overlooked the plain and river

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: a different register of rooms in the north-
label: Paragraph

text: south direction. The throne room was located
label: Paragraph

text: lengthwise to the largest courtyard. It might
label: Paragraph

text: have been barrel-vaulted, given the size of
label: Paragraph

text: the walls. Typically for the age, the courtyards
label: Paragraph

text: were not symmetrically aligned with each

text: other. Access from one to the other was
label: Paragraph

text: through a type of gate room.

text: Babylonia's economic power was short-lived.

label: Title

text: 5.1 Parthenon, Athens
label: Caption

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: From China to Greece, religious, ethical,
label: Paragraph

text: and social thinking was undergoing various
label: Paragraph

text: evaluations that contrasted with centuries-old
label: Paragraph

text: traditions that had accepted the notion that
label: Paragraph

text: power was imposed from the top, by force
label: Paragraph

text: or by ancestral privilege, rather than that it
label: Paragraph

text: should be examined from a theorized point of
label: Paragraph

text: view. In the 6th century BCE, however, we see
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of a more conscious attempt
label: Title

text: to think though the question of ethics and
label: Paragraph

text: governance. In China, for example, Confucius
label: Paragraph

text: (551-479 BCE) envisioned a world defined by
label: Paragraph

text: reason and proper conduct, while Daoism,
label: Paragraph

text: which existed alongside Confucianism,
label: Paragraph

text: stressed a sort of quietist noninterference and
label: Paragraph

text: the paradox of complementary opposites.
label: Paragraph

text: In India, Buddha and Mahavira challenged
label: Paragraph

text: the highly stratified world of Vedic orthodoxy,
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizing the discipline of self-abnegation.
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism might have remained tangential to
label: Paragraph

text: history had it not been made a state religion
label: Paragraph

text: by Asoka (304-232 BCE), the creator of the
label: Paragraph

text: first empire of South Asia. Since Buddhism
label: Paragraph

text: at the time was largely an ascetic practice,
label: Paragraph

text: Asoka did not order the construction of large
label: Paragraph

text: temples, but set up pillars with the teachings
label: Paragraph

text: of the Buddha etched onto them. In western
label: Paragraph

text: and Central Asia we find Zoroastrianism, an
label: Paragraph

text: ethically based religion that perceived the
label: Paragraph

text: world as a struggle between good and evil.
label: Paragraph

text: Man was viewed as a potential helper of God,
label: Paragraph

text: capable of eradicating evil. And in Greece,
label: Paragraph

text: Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, and others engaged
label: Title

text: in vigorous debates about democracy, law,
label: Paragraph

text: and social philosophy. Athens, adopting
label: Caption

text: democracy, became seminal in prefiguring the
label: Paragraph

text: modern state.
label: Paragraph

text: Politically, however, the major player in
label: Paragraph

text: western and Central Asia was Persia. Filling
label: Paragraph

text: the vacuum created by the collapse of the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian, Assyrian, and Babylonian empires,
label: Paragraph

text: it extended its reach from northern India to
label: Paragraph

text: Greece, giving rise to new architectural forms
label: Paragraph

text: in the expansive capitals of Pasargadae and
label: Paragraph

text: Persepolis. Persepolis was a showplace of
label: Paragraph

text: prestige. It was not a city and not a fortress,
label: Paragraph

text: but an array of vast palaces for feasting and
label: Paragraph

text: banqueting, all set up on a terrace that made
label: Paragraph

text: it visible to the thousands of people who
label: Paragraph

text: came there annually to pay their respects to
label: Paragraph

text: the great kings. The Mediterranean, however,
label: Paragraph

text: remained firmly under Greek control, with the
label: Paragraph

text: Greeks, in the 5th century BCE, developing
label: Paragraph

text: an architectural vocabulary that was later to
label: Paragraph

text: become foundational for Roman architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Still today, the Parthenon is celebrated as one
label: Paragraph

text: of the greatest buildings in the world.
label: Paragraph

text: The famous battles between Greece
label: Title

text: and Persia can deflect us, however, from
label: Paragraph

text: understanding the geopolitical energy that
label: Paragraph

text: these two areas brought to the Eurasian
label: Paragraph

text: world. Persia was the link between the
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean Sea and India; and just as
label: Paragraph

text: Greece was working to expand its trade
label: Paragraph

text: relations with the agropastoral communities
label: Title

text: to their north, so too the Indians sought to
label: Paragraph

text: expand their connections to the south of the
label: Paragraph

text: subcontinent. These three regions—India,
label: Paragraph

text: Persia, and the Mediterranean/Black Sea—
label: Title

text: were knit into a tight economic unit.
label: Paragraph

text: Persia’s unsuccessful atternpt to
label: Paragraph

text: conquer Greece was to have unintended
label: Paragraph

text: consequences. It stimulated the fantasy and
label: Paragraph

text: ambitions of Alexander (356-323 BCE), who
label: Paragraph

text: conquered Persia and its territories. For a
label: Paragraph

text: while it seemed that the Greek Empire would
label: Paragraph

text: stretch all the way to the Indus River, but
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander's ambitions were cut short by his
label: Paragraph

text: death in Babylon in 323 BCE. The conquered
label: Paragraph

text: lands, divided among his generals, turned
label: Paragraph

text: into quasi-independent states and regional
label: Title

text: power centers. The strongest of these was
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt, ruled by the Ptolemies, who governed
label: Paragraph

text: from Alexandria. An equally important city-
label: Paragraph

text: state was Pergamon in Anatolia. The tiny
label: Paragraph

text: island trading city of Delos overtook Athens
label: Title

text: as the cosmopolitan trading hub in the
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean. The impact of Greek culture,
label: Paragraph

text: generally called Hellenism in lands far
label: Paragraph

text: from Greece, was huge. It was an aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: that tended toward realism, delicacy, and
label: Paragraph

text: emotional expression. The columns and
label: Paragraph

text: entabluatures of 9th-century CE Khmer
label: Paragraph

text: in Cambodia make it clear that, however
label: Paragraph

text: remotely, Hellenism was still a factor in the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural conversation. Knmer masons,
label: Caption

text: probably from India, knew nothing of the
label: Paragraph

text: Greeks, but the legacy persisted. The impact
label: Paragraph

text: of Hellenism made its way to China as well, in
label: Paragraph

text: the sculptural representations of Buddha.
label: Paragraph

text: n South America, the most important
label: Paragraph

text: cultural developments were well-organized
label: Paragraph

text: societies that inhabited the Peruvian
label: Title

text: lowlands: the Moche civilization to the north,
label: Title

text: and the Nazca tribes to the south. The
label: Paragraph

text: Olmecs, who had been the most influential
label: Paragraph

text: culture in Mesoamerica for some time, were
label: Paragraph

text: in decline by 400 BCE, having been replaced
label: Paragraph

text: by the Maya and Zapotec peoples, who were
label: Paragraph

text: making the transition from chiefdoms to small
label: Paragraph

text: states.

text: THE ACHAEMENID EMPIRE
label: Title

text: Settlers arrived on the Iranian plateau
label: Paragraph

text: sometime before or during the fifth millennium
label: Paragraph

text: BCE, with one of their ancient cities, Tepe Sialk
label: Paragraph

text: (in central Iran, near the present-day city of
label: Paragraph

text: Kashan), experiencing various occupations
label: Paragraph

text: until about 800 BCE. By that time, the area
label: Paragraph

text: had become known as Mede, and powerful
label: Paragraph

text: kings extended control southward over the
label: Paragraph

text: Elamite civilization located in the plains around
label: Paragraph

text: Susa. With the weakening of the Assyrians to
label: Paragraph

text: the west, one of the Median kings, Cyaxares
label: Paragraph

text: (625-585 BCE), invaded and destroyed their
label: Paragraph

text: capital, Nineveh, marching all the way to
label: Paragraph

text: the gates of Sardis, where he turned back
label: Paragraph

text: when a solar eclipse, interpreted as a bad
label: Paragraph

text: omen, occurred. The capital of the Median
label: Paragraph

text: kingdom at the time was Hagmatana (“Place
label: Paragraph

text: of Assembly”), located under the modern
label: Paragraph

text: city of Hamadan. The Median kingdom,
label: Paragraph

text: however, underwent a transformation when
label: Paragraph

text: the Persians, a branch of the Medians, tock
label: Paragraph

text: control under Cyrus the Great (559-530 BCE),
label: Paragraph

text: who picked up where Cyaxares had left off
label: Paragraph

text: and, in effect, united the Elamite, Median,
label: Paragraph

text: and Babylonian realms into the Achaemenid
label: Title

text: Empire (also known as the First Persian
label: Title

text: Empire) that extended from Anatolia to the
label: Paragraph

text: Persian Gulf. The ascendency of the Persians
label: Paragraph

text: had important geopolitical consequences in
label: Paragraph

text: that their lands were halfway between India
label: Paragraph

text: and the Mediterranean. They were well aware
label: Paragraph

text: of this, of course, and indeed, their existence
label: Paragraph

text: depended on extending trade in these two
label: Paragraph

text: directions.
label: Paragraph

text: Like all ermpires, the Persians went through
label: Paragraph

text: their expansionary mode, with famous military
label: Paragraph

text: campaigns by both Darius and his son
label: Title

text: Xerxes | (in 490 and 480 BCE, respectively)
label: Paragraph

text: against the Greeks. Both campaigns were
label: Paragraph

text: unsuccessful, but the Persian alliance
label: Paragraph

text: with the Phoenicians, who contributed
label: Paragraph

text: substantially to their fleet, brought prosperity
label: Paragraph

text: to the Levant and its cities along the eastern
label: Title

text: Mediterranean coast. Phoenician cities like
label: Paragraph

text: Byblos and Sidon experienced an economic
label: Paragraph

text: upturn. The Persians, seeing for the first time
label: Paragraph

text: the great buildings of Egypt and western Asia,
label: Paragraph

text: were eager to match these accomplishments.
label: Paragraph

text: From the lonians, Persia not only collected
label: Paragraph

text: taxes but also took their farnously skilled
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmen. An inscription of Darius’s relates
label: Paragraph

text: Greece/Phoenicia

label: Title

text: that the stonecutters who worked on his
label: Paragraph

text: palaces were from lonia, and the wood
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmen were brought in from Lebanon,
label: Paragraph

text: along with large boatloads of lumber.
label: Paragraph

text: By the year 500 BCE, the Achaemenid
label: Paragraph

text: Empire had grown to become the largest
label: Paragraph

text: and most important realm in Asia, especially
label: Paragraph

text: under Darius (522-486 BCE), who extended
label: Paragraph

text: the boundaries of the empire into the heart
label: Title

text: of Egypt; the Zhou dynasty in China, by
label: Paragraph

text: comparison, was still relatively isolated. The
label: Paragraph

text: numerous city-states in India were occupied
label: Paragraph

text: fighting each other. The Persians seemed
label: Paragraph

text: to have learned from the negative lesson
label: Title

text: of the Assyrians and Babylonians. Unlike
label: Paragraph

text: them, Persian rulers attempted to gain the
label: Paragraph

text: good will of their subject nations. Darius,
label: Paragraph

text: for example, allowed Jews to rebuild the
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Jerusalem, which was finished in
label: Paragraph

text: 516 BCE, the sixth year of his reign. Weights
label: Paragraph

text: and measures were standardized, and an
label: Paragraph

text: extensive road network was built—the first
label: Paragraph

text: organized system of roads in history. The
label: Paragraph

text: Royal Highway ran from Sardis, on the coast
label: Paragraph

text: of Anatolia, to Susa, where it linked up, by
label: Paragraph

text: means of western extensions, to the silk
label: Paragraph

text: routes and to Pasargadae and Persepolis,
label: Paragraph

text: the newly constructed Persian capitals. In
label: Paragraph

text: fact, apart from the Greece, India, and Egypt,
label: Paragraph

text: Persia was to a large extent surrounded by
label: Paragraph

text: nomads and pastoralists, none of whom had
label: Paragraph

text: extensive use of iron. It therefore stands to
label: Paragraph

text: reason that Persia was eager to bring all of
label: Paragraph

text: the Mediterranean into its realmn of influence.
label: Paragraph

text: Its failure to do so resulted in a double
label: Paragraph

text: world: the linear geography of the Persians
label: Title

text: brought together by the Royal Highway, and
label: Paragraph

text: the network geography of the Mediterranean
label: Title

text: controlled by the Greeks and Phoenicians.

text: In 546 BCE Cyrus established Pasargadae as
label: Paragraph

text: his capital, locating it at one of the starting
label: Paragraph

text: points for the caravan route northward
label: Title

text: across the Great Salt Desert. The city’s
label: Paragraph

text: administrative core is remarkable for its
label: Paragraph

text: spaciousness; palace, audience hall, altars,
label: Caption

text: and pavilions, all distant from each other yet
label: Paragraph

text: integrated into a parklike setting with trees,
label: Paragraph

text: watercourses, and gardens. The Egyptians
label: Caption

text: and Babylonians had palace gardens, but
label: Paragraph

text: such an expansive landscape of palaces,
label: Paragraph

text: gardens, and orchards was quite novel. It
label: Paragraph

text: was also a sacred landscape, for to the north
label: Paragraph

text: there was a sacred enclosure consisting of a
label: Paragraph

text: walled precinct with a series of flat terraces
label: Paragraph

text: supporting an open altar. Much later, the
label: Paragraph

text: Persian garden was to become the prototype
label: Paragraph

text: of Islamic gardens.
label: Paragraph

text: The Tomb of Cyrus the Great is located
label: Paragraph

text: not far from Pasargadae. Its cefla is 6 meters
label: Paragraph

text: high and rests on a six-level stepped plinth
label: Caption

text: that measures 13.5 by 12.2 meters at the
label: Paragraph

text: base. The entire 13-meter-high edifice
label: Paragraph

text: is of white limestone. Five huge slanted
label: Paragraph

text: stones make up the roof. The monument,
label: Paragraph

text: sitting boldly in the landscape, is an elegant
label: Paragraph

text: combination of sepulcher and sanctuary. The
label: Paragraph

text: building recalls similar, though more modestly
label: Paragraph

text: scaled, Greek lonian tombs. It was probably
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed by a courtyard.

text: Pasargadae as a capital was relatively
label: Paragraph

text: short-lived, for Darius designed his own
label: Paragraph

text: capital city, Persepolis—“the city of the
label: Title

text: Persians,” as the Greeks called it—located
label: Paragraph

text: 0 kilometers to the southwest and closer
label: Title

text: to the fertile lands along the coast. It was
label: Paragraph

text: an audacious move to a dramatic site at
label: Paragraph

text: the edge of a large plain, the Marv Dasht
label: Paragraph

text: basin, surrounded by cliffs. The palace is
label: Paragraph

text: located directly under the west-facing slope
label: Paragraph

text: of one of those cliffs. Construction went
label: Paragraph

text: through several phases between 515 and
label: Paragraph

text: 330 BCE. The first one involved cutting into
label: Paragraph

text: the irregular and rocky mountainside to level
label: Paragraph

text: a large platform 10 to 20 meters above the
label: Paragraph

text: ground and measuring about 300 meters
label: Paragraph

text: in length and 450 meters in width. The
label: Paragraph

text: foundations contained complex drainage
label: Paragraph

text: systerns and water channels.

text: The purpose of the vast foundation was
label: Paragraph

text: make sure that the buildings placed on it
label: Paragraph

text: commanded views across the valley. Of
label: Paragraph

text: the buildings themselves little remains,
label: Paragraph

text: since most of the walls were of mud brick,
label: Paragraph

text: stuccoed and brightly painted. What we
label: Paragraph

text: see today are the sections that were built
label: Paragraph

text: in stone: the columns, foundations, and
label: Title

text: carvings.
label: Paragraph

text: The northern part of the terrace, which
label: Paragraph

text: included the throne room (known also as
label: Paragraph

text: the Hall of a Hundred Columns), measured
label: Paragraph

text: 70 by 70 meters and represented the main
label: Paragraph

text: section of the complex; it was accessible
label: Paragraph

text: only to a restricted few. The southern section
label: Paragraph

text: contained the palaces of Darius and Xerxes
label: Paragraph

text: |, the harem, and a council hall. A huge,
label: Paragraph

text: defendable independent structure at the
label: Title

text: southwest corner, with separate areas for
label: Paragraph

text: different wares, served as the treasury.
label: Paragraph

text: Records found show that in the year 467 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: no fewer than 1,348 people were employed
label: Paragraph

text: in the treasury recording and documenting
label: Title

text: its holdings. The largest building, the
label: Paragraph

text: Apadana (“castle" in Persian), served as
label: Paragraph

text: the main reception hall; it had seventy-two
label: Paragraph

text: awe-inspiring fluted and tapered limestone
label: Caption

text: columns 7 meters high surmounted by bull-
label: Caption

text: or lion-shaped capitals. The ceiling beams of
label: Paragraph

text: cedar, ebony, and teak were gold plated and
label: Paragraph

text: nlaid with ivory and precious metals. The
label: Paragraph

text: general concept of a columnar hall dates to
label: Paragraph

text: early Median architecture: a palace-citadel
label: Title

text: in Gobin Tepe from the 8th century BCE had
label: Paragraph

text: a hall with thirty columns, as did Cyrus's
label: Paragraph

text: palace in Pasargadae. This hall, however,
label: Paragraph

text: was designed as a showstopper in scale and
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation.
label: Paragraph

text: An innovative design feature was a stone-
label: Paragraph

text: faced double staircase leading to the
label: Caption

text: Apadana, the great audience hall. The walls
label: Caption

text: depict rows upon rows of emissaries, soldiers,
label: Paragraph

text: and chariot drivers. It is a virtual film strip
label: Paragraph

text: from which we can see how the various
label: Paragraph

text: peoples of the vast empire dressed and what
label: Title

text: kinds of ornaments, weapons, and hairstyles
label: Paragraph

text: they sported. A group from India carries
label: Paragraph

text: a bag of gold; a group from Africa carries
label: Paragraph

text: tusks. These people are portrayed not as
label: Paragraph

text: sad and subjected, but as if in a celebratory
label: Paragraph

text: mood. One frieze shows a man, like an
label: Paragraph

text: usher, holding another man’s hand, guiding
label: Paragraph

text: him along. At the head of the staircase was
label: Paragraph

text: a gate, with black marble benches where
label: Paragraph

text: visitors could wait.
label: Paragraph

text: The frieze helps us understand the
label: Paragraph

text: meaning of this innovative structure. It was
label: Paragraph

text: the backdrop to a great annual celebration—
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps a new year celebration—with people
label: Title

text: arriving from all over to bring gifts, make
label: Paragraph

text: treaties, and socialize. The flatlands to the
label: Paragraph

text: west of the complex would have been filled
label: Paragraph

text: with tents of various types. The central
label: Paragraph

text: event for a visitor was to be received by the
label: Paragraph

text: Persian ruler in the Apadana, which probably
label: Paragraph

text: served as the setting for grand feasts, with
label: Paragraph

text: hundreds of people sitting on the floor around
label: Paragraph

text: large round platters, being entertained
label: Paragraph

text: by musicians and dancing women.
label: Paragraph

text: Persepolis might be imagined as a modern-
label: Paragraph

text: day convention center, where business,
label: Paragraph

text: socializing, and celebration are all intermixed.
label: Paragraph

text: GREECE AND THE MEDITERRANEAN
label: Title

text: If Persia's empire was based on a
label: Paragraph

text: comprehensive network of roads and the
label: Title

text: exchange of goods, the Greek enterprise
label: Title

text: was based on sea trade and manufacturing,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly of bronze and ceramic bowls.
label: Paragraph

text: Greeks plied the Mediterranean all the way to
label: Paragraph

text: Gibraltar in the west and the Black Sea in the
label: Title

text: east, founding dozens of cities and trading
label: Paragraph

text: posts. This trade network was a consequence
label: Paragraph

text: of competition among Greek cities and of the
label: Paragraph

text: gradual opening of the European hinterland
label: Title

text: to commerce. Massalia (now Marseilles,
label: Paragraph

text: France), for example, was founded in
label: Paragraph

text: 600 BCE as a trading outpost to facilitate
label: Paragraph

text: commerce with the Gauls. Many of the city-
label: Paragraph

text: states had their own colonies, with Miletus
label: Paragraph

text: alone having no less than some ninety
label: Title

text: colonies spread around the Mediterranean.
label: Paragraph

text: It was a brand-new economic model; one
label: Paragraph

text: might call it the urban franchise model.
label: Paragraph

text: When viewed together, the two contrasting
label: Paragraph

text: systerns—the landlocked one of Persia and
label: Paragraph

text: the maritime one of Greece—constituted a
label: Paragraph

text: large east-west geopolitical continuum that
label: Paragraph

text: remained viable until the breakup of the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman Empire in the 5th century CE.
label: Paragraph

text: The first Greek colonies were established
label: Paragraph

text: around 770 BCE by the Euboeans on the
label: Paragraph

text: island of Ischia (Pithekoussai) near Naples;
label: Paragraph

text: at Cumae in central Italy; on the island of
label: Paragraph

text: Naxos in the Cyclades; and at Leontini in
label: Paragraph

text: eastern Sicily. Around 710 BCE, the Achaeans
label: Paragraph

text: founded Sybaris and Croton in southern Italy.
label: Paragraph

text: The Spartans founded Tarentum around
label: Paragraph

text: 650 BCE, while Syracuse was founded
label: Paragraph

text: by the Corinthians in 743 BCE. All in all,
label: Paragraph

text: in a span of a hundred years, some thirty
label: Paragraph

text: colonies sprang up. The settlers maintained
label: Paragraph

text: close relationships with their mother cities
label: Title

text: and often appealed to them in times of war.
label: Paragraph

text: But the colonies also began to flex their
label: Paragraph

text: own military muscles. In 480 BCE Syracuse
label: Paragraph

text: defeated Carthage in the Battle of Himera,
label: Paragraph

text: and in 413 BCE it inflicted catastrophic
label: Paragraph

text: damage on Athenian forces, which lost two
label: Paragraph

text: hundred ships and thousands of soldiers.

text: Greek temple design changed considerably
label: Paragraph

text: in the middle of the 6th century BCE, as
label: Paragraph

text: wood was increasingly abandoned for
label: Paragraph

text: stone. This may have been partially due to
label: Paragraph

text: a desire for permanence, but it may also
label: Paragraph

text: ave been spurred by the influence of
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian architecture, with which the Greeks
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly came in contact.
label: Paragraph

text: At the time, the northern part of Egypt had
label: Paragraph

text: een divided among vassals of the Assyrian
label: Paragraph

text: Empire. Around 664 BCE, an Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: prince named Psamtik was banished to the
label: Paragraph

text: marshes. Plotting his return, he allowed the
label: Paragraph

text: Dorians to settle in Naucratis, on the western
label: Paragraph

text: edge of the Nile Delta, around 620 BCE on
label: Caption

text: the promise that they help with his military
label: Paragraph

text: ambitions, which were indeed successful.
label: Paragraph

text: He was able to defeat his rivals, break with
label: Paragraph

text: Assyria, and reunify Egypt. This opened a
label: Paragraph

text: series of mercantile exchanges between
label: Title

text: Egypt and Greece that was profitable to both.

text: One can follow the development of the
label: Paragraph

text: Doric order at the Temple of Poseidon at
label: Caption

text: Isthmia, where, by the tine of its completion
label: Paragraph

text: around 600 BCE, the oak columns were
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by stone columns. (A Roman visitor
label: Caption

text: in 176 CE reported a peculiarity: one oak
label: Paragraph

text: column was still standing.) Some of the first
label: Paragraph

text: stone columns were huge monoliths; others
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of superimposed drums of varying
label: Paragraph

text: heights and diameters.
label: Paragraph

text: The wealth of the Sicilian colonies helps
label: Paragraph

text: explain why many of the early Greek temples
label: Paragraph

text: were not in Greece, but in Sicily and Italy. At
label: Paragraph

text: Selinus, on the southern coast of Sicily, seven
label: Caption

text: temples were lined up on the acropolis and
label: Paragraph

text: a nearby ridge. They date from 570 BCE to
label: Paragraph

text: 409 BCE. At Paestum in central Italy, there
label: Caption

text: arose a temple of Hera (650 BCE), a temple of
label: Paragraph

text: Demeter (520 BCE), and a temple of Poseidon
label: Paragraph

text: (460 BCE). In contrast to the early temples
label: Paragraph

text: at Selinus, the later temple of Poseidon in
label: Paragraph

text: Paestum opened up the cella by means of
label: Paragraph

text: an inner colonnade and achieved closer
label: Paragraph

text: interaction between the body of the temple
label: Title

text: and the pteron, or columnar surround.
label: Paragraph

text: There was an important difference between
label: Paragraph

text: Greek and Egyptian stone preparation.
label: Paragraph

text: In Greece, stones were brought to the
label: Paragraph

text: construction site in an almost finished
label: Paragraph

text: state, whereas in Egypt, stones for colurnns
label: Paragraph

text: arrived at the site still quite rough (apart from
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal cuts}, with much of the finishing
label: Paragraph

text: taking place when the stones were in situ.
label: Paragraph

text: This difference would have significant impact
label: Paragraph

text: on Greek architectural developments, as it
label: Paragraph

text: would allow for an ever-increasing elaboration
label: Paragraph

text: of detail, proportion, and form.
label: Paragraph

text: Greek and Roman temples are described
label: Paragraph

text: according to the number of columns on
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance front, the type of colonnade,
label: Paragraph

text: and the type of portico. The Parthenon, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, is an octastyle peripteral temple
label: Paragraph

text: with hexastyle porticoes at both ends. The
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Zeus at Olympia is a hexastyle
label: Paragraph

text: peripteral temple with distyle in-antis porches
label: Caption

text: at both ends. The basilica in Paestum is a
label: Paragraph

text: rare enneastyle pseudodipteral temple with a
label: Caption

text: tristyle in-antis portico.
label: Caption

text: Almost all surfaces of the ternple—the steps,
label: Paragraph

text: columns, capitals, walls, even the figures on
label: Paragraph

text: the pediment—were painted in bright reds,
label: Paragraph

text: blues, yellows, and black. What we know
label: Paragraph

text: about the colors used for the ternples comes
label: Paragraph

text: from both archaeological and literary sources.
label: Paragraph

text: The pigments were made from minerals,
label: Paragraph

text: soot, ground stones, vegetables, and animal
label: Title

text: matter. The purple dye, for example, came
label: Paragraph

text: from shellfish; the yellowish color that was
label: Paragraph

text: applied to columns and bears came from
label: Paragraph

text: saffron. The colors were sometimes applied
label: Paragraph

text: with wax but usually on stucco.
label: Paragraph

text: Though today we may perceive Greek
label: Paragraph

text: temples as isolated objects, they were
label: Paragraph

text: actually framed in the landscape by a
label: Paragraph

text: temenos, or sacred precinct, which could
label: Paragraph

text: consist of something as simple as a row of
label: Paragraph

text: stones but could also be a built-up wall. The
label: Paragraph

text: temenos was the territory of the deity and had
label: Paragraph

text: to be approached in a prescribed manner
label: Paragraph

text: and entered only at a special place defined
label: Paragraph

text: by a propyion (i.e., pro-pylon, or “before the
label: Paragraph

text: gate”).

text: 5.18 Greek temple terminology

text: The most basic element of the temple was the
label: Paragraph

text: colonnade. Though so common today that it
label: Paragraph

text: might seem to be a natural architectural form,
label: Paragraph

text: it was actually a unique innovation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Greeks. Called a pteron, it was a sacred form
label: Paragraph

text: always reserved for temples. Pteron means
label: Paragraph

text: “wing” or “fin,” but also “oar” and “sail.”
label: Paragraph

text: It perhaps refers to early awnings placed
label: Paragraph

text: against buildings. But it also indicates that
label: Paragraph

text: the Greeks saw the building as a dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: location—as something that literally catches
label: Paragraph

text: the wind and hears the voices of the gods.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition, the pteron evoked the idea of a
label: Paragraph

text: grove of trees, especially because columns
label: Paragraph

text: were originally made of wooden trunks. The
label: Paragraph

text: pteron has also been associated with stout
label: Paragraph

text: soldiers forming a phalanx—a rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: military formation—symbolically protecting the
label: Paragraph

text: statue within the cefla.
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: bird. For these reasons it became

text: to top off a temple.

text: 5.19 Elements of the Doric order
label: Caption

text: The temple rested on a crepis, the base
label: Paragraph

text: of a building but also a shoe or sandal—a
label: Paragraph

text: footing, in other words, proper to the divine
label: Paragraph

text: presence. This foundation was constructed
label: Paragraph

text: from roughly dressed masonry that was
label: Paragraph

text: not concealed below the ground but was
label: Paragraph

text: designed to appear as steps leading up to
label: Paragraph

text: the platform on which the temple’s columns
label: Paragraph

text: rested.
label: Paragraph

text: The capital, which derives its name from the
label: Paragraph

text: Latin word caput (“head”), was in Greek
label: Paragraph

text: terminology the Aranion, which refers to the
label: Paragraph

text: top of the head or skull. The Doric capital,
label: Paragraph

text: carved out of a single stone block, consists of a
label: Paragraph

text: spreading convex molding, the echinus—a word
label: Paragraph

text: that was applied to almost anything curved and
label: Paragraph

text: spiny found in nature—and a low square block,
label: Paragraph

text: the abacus.
label: Paragraph

text: The column shaft tapers from the bottom
label: Paragraph

text: upward in the form of a delicate curve called
label: Paragraph

text: an entasis, or swelling. The shaft of a Doric
label: Paragraph

text: column almost always stands directly on the
label: Paragraph

text: floor, without a base. Early columns from the 6th
label: Caption

text: century BCE are often monolithic, but later the
label: Paragraph

text: shaft came to be composed of superimposed
label: Paragraph

text: drums, which were rounded by turning them on
label: Paragraph

text: a lathe.
label: Paragraph

text: The drums were doweled together with wooden
label: Paragraph

text: or bronze spikes enclosed in concavities at
label: Paragraph

text: the center. The shafts were fluted after the
label: Paragraph

text: columns were in place. There are usually twenty
label: Paragraph

text: broad and shallow flutes that meet to form
label: Paragraph

text: sharp edges, or arrises. The joints between the
label: Paragraph

text: columns would have been concealed by marble
label: Paragraph

text: stucco.
label: Paragraph

text: The steps were often too tall to ascend
label: Paragraph

text: comfortably, so a flight of stairs or a ramp was
label: Paragraph

text: provided at the entrance. This demonstrates
label: Paragraph

text: that the steps had nothing to do with the
label: Paragraph

text: necessities of construction, for they could
label: Paragraph

text: easily have been designed with more risers.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead, the steps were intentionally built to
label: Paragraph

text: make the temple appear as if it were rising on a
label: Paragraph

text: natural outcropping, cleaned and smoothed in
label: Paragraph

text: preparation for the building.

text: Athens
label: Title

text: The city of Athens had three main
label: Paragraph

text: components: the acropolis, which was the
label: Paragraph

text: great ritual and spiritual core of the city; the
label: Paragraph

text: agora, which was its economic hub; and the
label: Paragraph

text: urban fabric itself, where one found small
label: Paragraph

text: shrines and temples. The agora, probably
label: Paragraph

text: laid out in the 7th century BCE and developed
label: Paragraph

text: in the 5th and 4th centuries BCE with the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of temples to Hephaestus, Zeus,
label: Paragraph

text: and Apollo, was a unique Athenian invention.
label: Paragraph

text: It was a specially demarcated space outside
label: Paragraph

text: of the core of the city that brought together
label: Paragraph

text: the different dimensions of urban life. Though
label: Paragraph

text: often called a public space, it was just as
label: Paragraph

text: much a religious space as a social one. One
label: Paragraph

text: of the key temples overlooking the agora was
label: Paragraph

text: the temple to Hephaestus. Hephaestus was
label: Paragraph

text: the god of the smithies, and his presence
label: Paragraph

text: there was a testament to the role of bronze
label: Paragraph

text: casting in the Athenian economy. It was set
label: Paragraph

text: on a hill to the west, its elevated presence
label: Paragraph

text: signifying its importance.
label: Paragraph

text: The agora was also the site of the Leokoreion,
label: Paragraph

text: a small shrine associated with a well in the
label: Caption

text: northern part of the agora. It was narned after
label: Paragraph

text: the daughters of Leos, who were sacrificed
label: Paragraph

text: to save the city from a terrible plague. Also
label: Paragraph

text: on the agora was a stoa, a long colonnaded
label: Paragraph

text: building with shops on the back facing the
label: Paragraph

text: agora. These shops were for the more elite
label: Paragraph

text: merchants. Council meetings were held in
label: Paragraph

text: a building known as the bouleuterion. The
label: Paragraph

text: law courts were located there as well. The
label: Paragraph

text: central space was used for markets, ritual
label: Paragraph

text: gatherings, or the making of speeches and
label: Paragraph

text: pronouncements. But most importantly, the
label: Paragraph

text: area served as a market. One could find
label: Paragraph

text: almost anything in the agora: confectioners,
label: Paragraph

text: slave-traders, fishmongers, vintners, cloth
label: Title

text: merchants, shoemakers, dressmakers,
label: Title

text: merchants selling cookware and other
label: Title

text: “ . : household goods. Socrates famously taught

label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: a Athenian youth who enjoyed seeing the more
label: Paragraph

text: pretentious of their elders made fools of. One
label: Paragraph

text: listener was the young poet who became a
label: Paragraph

text: student of Socrates under the name Plato.

label: Caption

text: he ancient Dorians, when they arrived in
label: Paragraph

text: Greece from the north, had sacred groves
label: Paragraph

text: to which they would periodically go for
label: Paragraph

text: ritual communal events. What they learned
label: Paragraph

text: rom the Egyptians was to dramatize these
label: Paragraph

text: journeys into spectacular processions
label: Title

text: involving music and dancing. They did not,
label: Paragraph

text: jowever, hold processions with the deity as
label: Paragraph

text: the Egyptians did, and in this they held true
label: Paragraph

text: to their fundamental belief in the deity being
label: Paragraph

text: ixed in special, sacred places. Over time
label: Paragraph

text: the number of these processions multiplied,
label: Paragraph

text: with some becoming elevated to the level
label: Paragraph

text: of state protocol. One was the Dionysia, a
label: Paragraph

text: jarge Athenian festival in honor of the god
label: Title

text: Dionysus that was held in early spring. It
label: Paragraph

text: involved a procession of phalluses and
label: Paragraph

text: military equipment, and ended in theatrical
label: Paragraph

text: performances. A few weeks later, there was
label: Paragraph

text: the more official Panathenaic procession that
label: Paragraph

text: started at the Leokoreion and ended at the
label: Paragraph

text: acropolis. That it began at the Leokoreion was
label: Paragraph

text: an indication of the procession’s attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: connect deeply to the principle of sacrifice
label: Paragraph

text: and triumph.
label: Paragraph

text: The procession was an elaborate affair. For
label: Paragraph

text: months before, a team of maidens from
label: Paragraph

text: aristocratic families would weave a special
label: Paragraph

text: new garment for the deity in the temple. By
label: Caption

text: the late 5th century BCE the robe was as
label: Paragraph

text: big as a ship's sail and was, in fact, fixed
label: Paragraph

text: on the model of a ship mounted on wheels.
label: Paragraph

text: This ship-cart had a crew of priests and
label: Paragraph

text: priestesses wearing golden and colorful
label: Title

text: garlands. When all was set, a nocturnal
label: Paragraph

text: festival took place, and at sunrise a new fire
label: Paragraph

text: was fetched, carried in a torch race from
label: Paragraph

text: outside the city—where sacrifice was made
label: Paragraph

text: to Eros and Athena together—through the
label: Paragraph

text: agora, and up to the altar of Athena on
label: Paragraph

text: the acropolis. A procession then formed in
label: Paragraph

text: which all members of the community had
label: Paragraph

text: their place. The high point was the sacrifice,
label: Paragraph

text: in which more than a hundred animals
label: Paragraph

text: were slaughtered at the Great Altar, and
label: Paragraph

text: the meat distributed to the whole populace
label: Paragraph

text: in the agora. From 566 BCE onward an
label: Paragraph

text: athletic contest was added to the program
label: Paragraph

text: of activities, including foot races, wrestling,
label: Paragraph

text: horse racing, boxing, and javelin-throwing.
label: Paragraph

text: The frieze of the Pantheon seems to portray
label: Paragraph

text: such a celebratory procession. The narrative
label: Paragraph

text: of the frieze begins at the southwest corner,
label: Paragraph

text: where the procession appears to divide into
label: Paragraph

text: two separate files.
label: Paragraph

text: What does it represent? According to
label: Paragraph

text: traditional interpretation, it depicts the annual
label: Paragraph

text: Panathenaic procession. But this view,
label: Paragraph

text: though oft repeated, has been challenged
label: Paragraph

text: by scholars who argue that it must be a
label: Paragraph

text: representation of a mythological moment,
label: Paragraph

text: not a real procession involving mortals. Since
label: Paragraph

text: the pediments and metopes alll illustrate
label: Paragraph

text: mythological scenes, it is natural to reach
label: Paragraph

text: for a mythological explanation for the frieze
label: Paragraph

text: as well. John Boardman has suggested that
label: Paragraph

text: the cavalry portrayed on the frieze depict
label: Paragraph

text: the heroization of the soldiers who fell at
label: Paragraph

text: Marathon in 490 BCE, and that therefore
label: Paragraph

text: these riders were the Athenians who took
label: Paragraph

text: part in the last prewar Greater Panathenaia.
label: Paragraph

text: Chrysoula Kardar has ventured that the
label: Paragraph

text: relief shows an imagined first Panathenaic
label: Caption

text: procession as instituted under the mythical
label: Paragraph

text: King Kekrops.
label: Paragraph

text: A perplexing issue is that the frieze's
label: Paragraph

text: location high in the building's porch would
label: Paragraph

text: have made it difficult to see. In the museum
label: Paragraph

text: today, the figures are on eye level, whereas
label: Paragraph

text: originally they were 7 meters up. This
label: Paragraph

text: suggests that they were not meant to be
label: Paragraph

text: “seen” in the conventional sense.
label: Paragraph

text: Thomas Bruce, the Seventh Earl of Elgin,
label: Title

text: dismantled about two-thirds of the frieze and
label: Paragraph

text: had it shipped to England between 1801 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1806, and today the so-called Elgin Marbles
label: Paragraph

text: are in the British Museum, to the outrage
label: Caption

text: of many. In looking at the frieze, one has
label: Paragraph

text: to remember that it, as indeed the entire
label: Paragraph

text: building, was painted.
label: Paragraph

text: 5.23 Approach to the Parthenon from the Propylaea
label: Caption

text: The Parthenon
label: Title

text: Because of the constant warfare in ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Greece, almost every city was divided
label: Paragraph

text: into a lower town and an acropolis, which
label: Paragraph

text: literally means a “city on the height.” The
label: Paragraph

text: acropolis of Athens was no exception. It
label: Paragraph

text: sits on a great isolated slab of limestone
label: Paragraph

text: tilted toward the west side, from which it
label: Paragraph

text: had to be approached. Already fortified
label: Paragraph

text: with a wall by the Mycenaeans, it was held
label: Paragraph

text: to be invested with divine presences from
label: Paragraph

text: ancient times. The waters from a spring on
label: Paragraph

text: its southern flank are today still considered
label: Paragraph

text: to have healing powers. An olive tree rooted
label: Paragraph

text: to a rock on its summit was dedicated to
label: Paragraph

text: Athena. It was here that the Parthenon was
label: Paragraph

text: built under the political leadership of Pericles.
label: Paragraph

text: The building, replacing one that had been
label: Paragraph

text: destroyed by the Persians, was designed
label: Paragraph

text: by Ictinus (with advice from Callicrates and
label: Caption

text: Phidias) and built between 447 and 438 BCE.
label: Paragraph

text: Designed as a monument to Athena and
label: Paragraph

text: housing her sacred statue, it was bigger than
label: Paragraph

text: any temple ever before built on the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: mainland, its stylobate measuring 30.9 by
label: Paragraph

text: 69.5 meters. Early accounts of the temple
label: Caption

text: call it Hekatornpedos, or “hundred-footer,”
label: Paragraph

text: referring either to its overall width or the
label: Paragraph

text: length of the large eastern room of its cefa,
label: Paragraph

text: also known as the hekatompedos.
label: Paragraph

text: But size was not its only unusual feature:
label: Paragraph

text: the east and west facades were lined with
label: Paragraph

text: eight towering Doric columns, making the
label: Paragraph

text: Parthenon the only octastyle peripteral ternple
label: Paragraph

text: built in ancient Greece.
