text: The interior of the naos has been variously
label: Paragraph

text: reconstructed, in some places with a
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: opening in the center. It is clear, regardless,
label: Paragraph

text: that the columns in the naos supported a
label: Paragraph

text: second tier of smaller columns above, and
label: Paragraph

text: that there was a shallow rectangle in front
label: Paragraph

text: of the statue of Athena, possibly used as a
label: Caption

text: reflecting pool, although such a pool would
label: Paragraph

text: have been highly unusual. The building
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 5.26 Diagram of the curved stylobate and inclined vertical axes of the perimeter columns of the Parthenon
label: Caption

text: Underlying the construction is a system
label: Paragraph

text: of refinements that control the delicate
label: Paragraph

text: curvature of horizontal lines, the elegant
label: Paragraph

text: convergence of vertical lines, and the
label: Paragraph

text: nuanced size and spacing of the fluted
label: Paragraph

text: marble columns. The stylobate was not a
label: Paragraph

text: flat plane but rather like a section of a very
label: Paragraph

text: large sphere; it curved upward toward the
label: Paragraph

text: middle, rising 41 millimeters on its short
label: Paragraph

text: sides and 102 millimeters on its long flanks.
label: Paragraph

text: This curve was carried upward through the
label: Paragraph

text: entire structure, imparting a subtle upward
label: Paragraph

text: curvature even on the architrave, the cornice,
label: Paragraph

text: and nearly every “horizontal” line of stone.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, every column was given an
label: Paragraph

text: entasis, or a slight bulging of the middle of
label: Paragraph

text: the column's shaft. The entasis measures
label: Paragraph

text: only 20 millimeters of deviation from a
label: Paragraph

text: straight line. Moreover, each of the forty-six
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter columns was tilted slightly inward,
label: Paragraph

text: with the corner column tilting on a diagonal.
label: Paragraph

text: If the columns of the short sides were
label: Paragraph

text: extended upward, they would meet around
label: Paragraph

text: 4.8 kilometers above the roof.
label: Caption

text: While each of these refinements have
label: Paragraph

text: functional advantages—the curvature to
label: Paragraph

text: shed water, the angling to increase lateral
label: Paragraph

text: structural support during earthquakes,
label: Paragraph

text: and the corner adjustments to maintain
label: Title

text: proper column alignments with the metopes
label: Paragraph

text: above—scholars, beginning with the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: architect and historian Vitruvius, have argued
label: Paragraph

text: that the nuances were mostly for aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: effect; and indeed, in no other temple was
label: Paragraph

text: this visual tension as subtle and refined as
label: Paragraph

text: in the Parthenon. It nevertheless seems
label: Paragraph

text: astonishing that in contrast with other
label: Paragraph

text: attempts at making grand statements, where
label: Paragraph

text: architects sought height or the addition of
label: Paragraph

text: special embellishments, here the architects
label: Paragraph

text: sought a level of precision that was almost
label: Paragraph

text: imperceptible, yet could not be matched
label: Paragraph

text: anywhere else in the world at the time.
label: Paragraph

text: How these astonishing curves were made is
label: Paragraph

text: something of a mystery, since the building,
label: Paragraph

text: like all Greek temples, is made of precut
label: Paragraph

text: pieces allowing for few on-site adjustments.
label: Paragraph

text: Erechtheum
label: Title

text: Unlike Egyptians, Greeks never added new
label: Paragraph

text: elements to a ternple. New structures, of
label: Paragraph

text: course, could be added to the precinct, but
label: Paragraph

text: the temple itself was not changed unless
label: Paragraph

text: it was somehow destroyed and rebuilt.
label: Paragraph

text: It would be wrong, however, to assume
label: Paragraph

text: that Greek architects were unable to think
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the inflexibility of the temple form.
label: Paragraph

text: The Propylaea and the Erechtheum on the
label: Paragraph

text: Athenian acropolis are examples of rather
label: Paragraph

text: complex buildings whose architects had to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate a range of programmatic and
label: Paragraph

text: ritualistic purposes. The Erechtheum wraps
label: Paragraph

text: up different mythical narratives into a single
label: Paragraph

text: composition. It was built on two levels with
label: Paragraph

text: three porticoes of different designs; there
label: Paragraph

text: were four entrances besides the subterranean
label: Paragraph

text: one under the north porch. This irregularity
label: Caption

text: was due to the necessity of designing a
label: Paragraph

text: building around the spots that were essential
label: Paragraph

text: to the narrative of the founding of Athens.
label: Paragraph

text: Erechtheus, after whom the Erechtheum is
label: Paragraph

text: named, was the mythical founder of Attica
label: Paragraph

text: and the “earth-born king of Athens.” At that
label: Paragraph

text: time, it was believed that gods challenged
label: Paragraph

text: one another to be honored by cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Unfortunately, both Poseidon and Athena
label: Paragraph

text: aspired to control Athens, so Erechtheus set
label: Paragraph

text: up a contest in which each had to make a

text: of Poseidon. A door to the right leads to the

text: lonic Order
label: Title

text: Though usually discussed after the Doric,
label: Paragraph

text: the lonic should not therefore be regarded
label: Paragraph

text: as later. The development of the lonic and
label: Paragraph

text: the Doric orders paralleled each other, but
label: Paragraph

text: stylistically there are notable differences.
label: Paragraph

text: First, lonic colurins rest on molded bases
label: Paragraph

text: that stand on square plinths. These moldings
label: Paragraph

text: consist of combinations of tori, scotias,
label: Paragraph

text: and rondels, often in pairs. The capital has
label: Paragraph

text: different front and side views and is meant to
label: Paragraph

text: be seen chiefly from the front and back. At
label: Paragraph

text: the base of the capital there is a flat-topped
label: Paragraph

text: molding with a profile like that of the Doric
label: Paragraph

text: echinus, but it is usually carved with egg-
label: Paragraph

text: and-dart moldings. Above this lies the volute,
label: Paragraph

text: its loose ends winding down in dropping
label: Paragraph

text: spirals on each side of the shaft and ending
label: Paragraph

text: in buttonlike oculi (eyes). The entablature
label: Paragraph

text: usually consists of three bands of fasciae
label: Paragraph

text: of unequal height, each projecting a little
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the one below it. Above it runs a
label: Paragraph

text: band of egg-and-dart molding and over that
label: Paragraph

text: a row of dentils, superseded by a projecting
label: Caption

text: cornice often decorated with lions’ faces and
label: Paragraph

text: plant motifs.
label: Paragraph

text: The lonic capital came into its own during
label: Paragraph

text: the 7th century BCE. Unlike the Doric, the
label: Paragraph

text: lonic did not derive from a structural system,
label: Paragraph

text: but perhaps frorn symbolic headdresses or
label: Paragraph

text: from poles surrounded by bundled vegetation
label: Paragraph

text: marking sacred areas. The capital consists
label: Paragraph

text: of two large spirals that spring upward and
label: Paragraph

text: Festivals were an important part of Greek

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: in nature. The temple at Isthmia, for example,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: major athletic contest. In Athens, festivals
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: filled 120 days, or one-third of the calendar
label: Paragraph

text: year.

label: Paragraph

text: Mysteries, was the Thesmophoria, a harvest

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: purified themselves, sat on the ground, and
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Apollo at Delphi
label: Caption

text: During the three winter months, Dionysus
label: Paragraph

text: shared the temple sanctuary on the
label: Paragraph

text: Parnassos slope with Apollo, a reference
label: Paragraph

text: to some of the ancient chthonic elements
label: Paragraph

text: connected with the cult of Persephone, who,
label: Paragraph

text: according to the Orphic myth, was the mother
label: Paragraph

text: of Dionysus. Out of the ecstatic dances and
label: Paragraph

text: choruses of Dionysus, the Greek drama was
label: Paragraph

text: born, and at Delphi, above the great Temple
label: Paragraph

text: of Apollo, there lies on cross-axis to the
label: Paragraph

text: temple and facing straight down the slope a
label: Paragraph

text: brilliant example of such a theater. Filling and
label: Paragraph

text: defining a natural concavity at the base of the
label: Paragraph

text: cliff, the natural and man-made merge into
label: Paragraph

text: one majestic swath—one great hymn to the
label: Paragraph

text: creation cycle of life.
label: Paragraph

text: From just inside the wall of the temenos,
label: Paragraph

text: the viewer would see the silhouette of
label: Paragraph

text: the Temple of Apollo floating against the
label: Title

text: backdrop of the cliff. The path to the temple
label: Caption

text: was not a direct one but rather snaked its
label: Paragraph

text: way upward past the various treasuries—
label: Paragraph

text: many of distant colonies—to emerge just
label: Paragraph

text: below the broad terrace built up against the
label: Paragraph

text: slope. A supplicant, guided by an assistant
label: Paragraph

text: of the Delphian cult, would have been led to
label: Paragraph

text: the temple terrace to await his turn with the
label: Paragraph

text: oracle. He would have had the opportunity to
label: Paragraph

text: look straight down into the ancient precinct
label: Paragraph

text: of Gaia. He might have spent some time
label: Paragraph

text: regarding the ternple itself.
label: Paragraph

text: What is visible today is the last temple,
label: Paragraph

text: the site having been occupied earlier by
label: Paragraph

text: two previous Doric temples. The first one, a
label: Paragraph

text: structure from the 7th century BCE, burned
label: Caption

text: in 548 BCE and was replaced by a larger
label: Paragraph

text: one in 525 BCE, which itself was replaced
label: Paragraph

text: in the mid-4th century BCE. On the east
label: Paragraph

text: pediment facing the altar in front of the
label: Caption

text: temple, sculptures portrayed the arrival of
label: Paragraph

text: Apollo at Delphi, shown with his mother,
label: Paragraph

text: Leto; his sister Artemis; and his cornpanions,
label: Paragraph

text: the Muses. At the opposite pediment,
label: Caption

text: Dionysus, Apollo’s brother—both having
label: Paragraph

text: been fathered by Zeus—occupied the center,
label: Paragraph

text: establishing a principle of balance: Apollo
label: Title

text: representing music and poetry; Dionysus,
label: Paragraph

text: wine and ecstasy. The Dionysian and the
label: Paragraph

text: Apollonian were not perceived as opposites
label: Paragraph

text: by the Greeks but rather as complementary;
label: Paragraph

text: together they embodied the wholeness of life.
label: Paragraph

text: Below the east pediment hung the golden
label: Caption

text: shields from the spoils of the Persian War, a
label: Paragraph

text: gift to the temple by the Athenians.
label: Paragraph

text: The most important festival associated
label: Title

text: with Delphi was the change of rule that took
label: Paragraph

text: place between Apollo and Dionysus at the
label: Paragraph

text: appointed time. It was enacted in the great
label: Paragraph

text: open-air theater above the temple with its
label: Paragraph

text: thronelike overview of the sanctuary and
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding landscape. The sports events
label: Paragraph

text: that accompanied these festivals took place
label: Paragraph

text: in the heights above the temenos.
label: Paragraph

text: Once inside the ternple, the supplicant
label: Paragraph

text: would smell the meat burning on the hearth
label: Paragraph

text: and see the smoke rising toward the opening
label: Paragraph

text: in the roof, frorm which shafts of sunlight
label: Paragraph

text: 5.46 Treasury of Athens, Delphi
label: Caption

text: penetrated down into the gloom. Visitors
label: Paragraph

text: also mentioned a perfumed smell. The
label: Paragraph

text: supplicants would have seen tripods, statues,
label: Paragraph

text: pieces of armor, even entire racing chariots,
label: Paragraph

text: brought as donations from the entire world
label: Paragraph

text: of Magna Graecia, and often from foreign
label: Paragraph

text: countries as well. After depositing his own
label: Paragraph

text: offering, the supplicant would be led toward
label: Paragraph

text: the far end of the chamber, where steps
label: Paragraph

text: descend to a sunken area a meter below
label: Paragraph

text: the level of the floor. From there he made
label: Paragraph

text: his way into the adytum, at the back wall of
label: Paragraph

text: which was a bench close to the branches
label: Paragraph

text: of a laurel tree as well as a golden statue of
label: Paragraph

text: Apollo. There, the prophetess, on a tripod
label: Paragraph

text: and hidden from him by a curtain, was
label: Paragraph

text: positioned over a crack in the rocks from
label: Paragraph

text: which, according to some visitors, emanated
label: Paragraph

text: that sweetish smell. An attendant, drawing
label: Paragraph

text: back the curtain, would relay the question
label: Paragraph

text: of the petitioner, and from the depths, the
label: Paragraph

text: prophetess received a reply to the question,
label: Paragraph

text: often equivocal, which she conveyed back
label: Paragraph

text: to the petitioner. Whatever the response—
label: Paragraph

text: which often required a large amount of
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation—it probably necessitated
label: Paragraph

text: further donations. What caused the sweet
label: Paragraph

text: smell has not been determined with scientific
label: Paragraph

text: accuracy. Recent archaeological studies
label: Paragraph

text: point to the possibility that it might have been
label: Paragraph

text: ethylene, a common vapor in natural tar pits
label: Paragraph

text: that produces euphoria, which is used today
label: Paragraph

text: as an anesthetic.

text: THE HELLENISTIC AGE
label: Title

text: The legacy of Greek architecture would move
label: Paragraph

text: in two different directions, with two different
label: Paragraph

text: destinies. It would move westward when it
label: Paragraph

text: was adopted by the Romans and spread
label: Paragraph

text: into Europe, where, with the demise of the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman Empire in the 5th century CE, it would
label: Paragraph

text: slowly wither away, its ideas and ideals only
label: Paragraph

text: revitalized beginning in the 15th century
label: Paragraph

text: with the Renaissance. It would, however,
label: Paragraph

text: also move eastward with Alexander the Great
label: Paragraph

text: (356-323 BCE), son of Philip Il of Macedon,
label: Paragraph

text: and have a profound impact on Indian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and even on the architecture
label: Title

text: of the 13th-century Khmer Empire. The
label: Paragraph

text: modern-day notion that “classicism” is at the
label: Paragraph

text: core of “Western architecture” is a myth of
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th-century Romantics. It was in fact
label: Paragraph

text: in the non-European world that the legacy of
label: Paragraph

text: “classicism” would be most palpably felt.
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander assumed kingship over
label: Title

text: the newly consolidated mainland Greece
label: Title

text: after his father’s death and continued
label: Paragraph

text: his expansionary policies. He crossed
label: Paragraph

text: the Hellespont in 334 BCE, defeated the
label: Paragraph

text: Achaemenid Empire, and on his way to
label: Paragraph

text: the border of India founded many fledgling
label: Paragraph

text: cities, stocking them with some of his
label: Paragraph

text: Macedonian Greeks, who awaited—in vain,
label: Paragraph

text: as it turned out—his return with new troops
label: Paragraph

text: and settlers to sustain his eastern empire.
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander's empire fell apart after his
label: Paragraph

text: sudden and unexplained death in 323 BCE in
label: Paragraph

text: Sirkap (Taxila)

text: broke out among his potential successors,
label: Paragraph

text: but eventually three realms emerged: the
label: Paragraph

text: Antigonid Empire (Greece), the Seleucid
label: Title

text: Empire (Mesopotamia and Persia), and the
label: Paragraph

text: Ptolemaic Empire (Egypt, Palestine, and
label: Title

text: Cyrenaica). All are part of what is called the
label: Paragraph

text: Hellenistic Age. As an art form, Hellenism
label: Paragraph

text: had lost some of the discipline of its origins
label: Paragraph

text: and in temple construction tended to
label: Paragraph

text: gigantism and spatial experimentation; in
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture, it is noted for the portrayal of
label: Paragraph

text: emotions and empathy, as, for example, in
label: Paragraph

text: the Dying Gaul.
label: Paragraph

text: Old cities like Athens, which for a while
label: Paragraph

text: became part of the kingdom of Antigonus,
label: Paragraph

text: were given new buildings. Some were paid
label: Paragraph

text: for locally; some funds came from foreign
label: Paragraph

text: donations. The enormous Temple of Zeus
label: Caption

text: at Olympia in Athens, begun in 170 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: was paid for by Antiochus IV (d. 164 BCE)
label: Paragraph

text: of the Seleucids of northern Syria. A new
label: Paragraph

text: harbor, council hall, and residential quarter
label: Title

text: were added to the city of Miletus. Assos
label: Paragraph

text: redesigned its central agora with a long
label: Paragraph

text: two-story-high stoa. New cities were laid
label: Caption

text: out, some as far away as Ai Khanum on the
label: Paragraph

text: Afghan bank of the Oxus River.
label: Paragraph

text: Though planned cities go back
label: Title

text: millennia, the architecture of cities and the
label: Title

text: architecture of palaces or temples were until
label: Paragraph

text: then, generally speaking, quite distinct. In
label: Paragraph

text: Hellenistic cities, urbanism and architecture
label: Title

text: egin to overlap for the first time. Theaters,
label: Paragraph

text: temples, villas, palaces, libraries, stadia,
label: Paragraph

text: and streets are all equally important in such
label: Paragraph

text: cities as Priene, Pergamon, Alexandria, Dura-
label: Paragraph

text: Europos, Delos, and Rhodes.
label: Paragraph

text: The economic engine that drove this
label: Paragraph

text: tremendous expansion was not Athens
label: Paragraph

text: ut Hellenistic Egypt, the newly restored
label: Title

text: economic marvel of the Mediterranean.
label: Paragraph

text: By the time of Ptolemy Ill (245-221 BCE),
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian fleets controlled most of the
label: Paragraph

text: shipping lanes of the eastern Mediterranean.
label: Paragraph

text: Building on the old pharaonic tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: state control, the Ptolemaic kings updated
label: Title

text: technologies and production systems,
label: Title

text: transforming the country with its population of
label: Paragraph

text: seven million into a grain-producing machine
label: Title

text: of unprecedented proportions.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ptolemaic rulers introduced the water
label: Paragraph

text: screw of Archimedes and built machines
label: Title

text: with drums or wheels driven by humans
label: Paragraph

text: for raising water and pushing back the
label: Paragraph

text: desert. Salt production was escalated. Mines
label: Paragraph

text: and quarries, as well as the development
label: Paragraph

text: of a state-run bank, were integrated into
label: Paragraph

text: the system. It was in some respects one
label: Paragraph

text: of the first examples of state-supported
label: Paragraph

text: modernization.

text: On the eastern coast of Anatolia, Miletus,

label: Paragraph

text: Priene, founded in 334 BCE, occupies a
label: Paragraph

text: sloping ground beneath a fortifiable acropolis.
label: Paragraph

text: The streets run east-west along level ground
label: Paragraph

text: and are about 4.5 meters across. From south

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: three-block-long stoa. Up the hill a few blocks
label: Caption

text: to the west is the platform with the temple
label: Paragraph

text: of Athena, and a block higher yet but to the
label: Paragraph

text: east was a theater with spectacular views into
label: Paragraph

text: the valley below and the mountains across.

text: Farther northward yet, where the city ends
label: Paragraph

text: and the steep slope of the acropolis begins, is
label: Paragraph

text: a sanctuary dedicated to Demeter. A stadiurn
label: Caption

text: and gymnasium define the lower edge. The
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and voids and of private and public zones,
label: Paragraph

text: spread out over a difficult terrain.

text: the Gauls in 190 BCE. The Gauls had been

text: sweeping southward from western Europe,

label: Paragraph

text: harass the northern borders of Mediterranean
label: Title

text: countries for centuries, Eumenes II had
label: Paragraph

text: managed to hold them at bay, at least for
label: Paragraph

text: a while. The altar was a U-shaped, lonic,
label: Paragraph

text: stoa-like structure perched on top of a high
label: Paragraph

text: socle, with a vast flight of stairs leading up
label: Paragraph

text: its west side to the level of the colonnade.
label: Paragraph

text: On its enormous socle level was a frieze
label: Paragraph

text: representing the mythical battle between
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: symbolizing the triumphs of the Pergamon
label: Paragraph

text: kingdom over the Gauls.
label: Paragraph

text: The altar stands in a courtyard atop an
label: Paragraph

text: almost square plinth. It was surrounded by
label: Paragraph

text: a colonnade that sheltered a wall on which
label: Paragraph

text: there was another frieze celebrating the
label: Paragraph

text: legitimacy of the Pergamon kings. This altar
label: Paragraph

text: was not only the traditional end point of
label: Paragraph

text: monument and even a war memorial. These
label: Paragraph

text: are roles that had been in earlier days
label: Paragraph

text: connected with the temple—the Parthenon
label: Paragraph

text: being an excellent example. But here the
label: Paragraph

text: altar reverted to an autonomous cultural
label: Paragraph

text: object.

text: Temple of Apollo at Didyma
label: Caption

text: It is difficult to speak of the Hellenistic
label: Paragraph

text: temple as a single aesthetic form. In the
label: Paragraph

text: cosmopolitan environment of western Asia,
label: Paragraph

text: one sees different tastes in different places as
label: Paragraph

text: well as variable influences. In Egypt, buildings
label: Paragraph

text: of the Hellenistic era were designed in an
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian revival style. Such neoarchaisms
label: Paragraph

text: were not outside the aesthetic interests of
label: Paragraph

text: the Greeks. The Hellenistic aesthetic did,
label: Paragraph

text: however, draw on centuries of experience in
label: Paragraph

text: creating complex, composite relationships
label: Paragraph

text: between space, landscape, and mythical
label: Title

text: narration—organizing it, as at Priene, into
label: Paragraph

text: unified aesthetic expressions. One of the
label: Paragraph

text: most spectacular of Hellenistic temples in this
label: Paragraph

text: respect is the unfinished Temple of Apollo
label: Paragraph

text: at Didyma, 14 kilometers south of Miletus.
label: Paragraph

text: Sitting on a gentle hill and exposed on all
label: Paragraph

text: sides, it contained the unusual feature of an
label: Paragraph

text: open court, planted with bay trees, arnong
label: Caption

text: which stood a shrine-like lonic temple.
label: Paragraph

text: Though several Greek temples—possibly
label: Paragraph

text: even the Parthenon—had open interiors,
label: Paragraph

text: this was something altogether different. The
label: Paragraph

text: architects are said to have been Paeonius
label: Paragraph

text: and Demetrios of Ephesus. Though much
label: Paragraph

text: of the plan may have been laid out by them
label: Paragraph

text: around 313 BCE, the work took well over
label: Paragraph

text: three hundred years to complete and was
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned in 41 CE.
label: Paragraph

text: The temple's lonic double pteron stands on
label: Paragraph

text: a stylobate accessed by seven huge steps.
label: Paragraph

text: After ascending the steps, one enters the
label: Paragraph

text: deep porch of the pronaos, behind which is
label: Caption

text: an antechamber. The antechamber is actually
label: Paragraph

text: higher than the pronaos, with its door serving
label: Paragraph

text: as a window from which the oracles were
label: Paragraph

text: delivered. Standing arnong the pronaos's
label: Paragraph

text: treelike colurnns—the tallest of any Greek
label: Paragraph

text: temple's—the windows would have appeared
label: Paragraph

text: to be the mouth of a cave. Access to the
label: Paragraph

text: inner courtyard was by way of small doorways
label: Paragraph

text: on either side of the window, through sloping,
label: Paragraph

text: dark tunnels roofed with barrel vaults.
label: Paragraph

text: 5.61 Plan: Temple of Apollo
label: Caption

text: Penetrating through this dark “grotto,” one
label: Paragraph

text: enters the sacred grove. But this “inside”
label: Paragraph

text: was in fact an outside. The artificial grove
label: Paragraph

text: of trees, which is how the columns would
label: Paragraph

text: have appeared from the outside, gave way to
label: Paragraph

text: real trees on the inside. Furthermore, within
label: Paragraph

text: that grove was another temple, with its axis
label: Paragraph

text: oriented toward the entry; this small lonic
label: Paragraph

text: temple at the far end of the open cella faced
label: Paragraph

text: a grand staircase leading back up to the
label: Caption

text: antechamber, frorn which the priests could
label: Paragraph

text: officiate. Folding one temple compound
label: Caption

text: into another was a consummate example of
label: Paragraph

text: Hellenistic brilliance.

text: Ptolemies
label: Title

text: Alexandria was one of the principal
label: Paragraph

text: Hellenistic cities. Situated on the western
label: Paragraph

text: extremity of the Nile River delta, the city was
label: Paragraph

text: founded in 332 BCE by Alexander to serve as
label: Paragraph

text: a regional capital. It soon became the largest
label: Paragraph

text: city in the Mediterranean basin, and it was
label: Paragraph

text: unlike any other, with libraries, museums,
label: Paragraph

text: and a rich cosmopolitan culture. Though
label: Paragraph

text: little is left of the ancient city, the Ptolemaic
label: Paragraph

text: period left a vibrant record of its art and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in many parts of Egypt, including
label: Paragraph

text: the construction of about fifty medium-size
label: Paragraph

text: and large temple complexes, not to mention
label: Paragraph

text: smaller architectural works. The Ptolemies
label: Caption

text: and their queens had no misgivings about
label: Paragraph

text: following Egyptian tradition, and set up
label: Paragraph

text: statues of themselves as cult images.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, Ptolemaic architects did not
label: Paragraph

text: place windows on the top of walls, as the
label: Paragraph

text: earlier Egyptians had done: their hypostyle
label: Paragraph

text: halls are pitch black if one closes the doors.
label: Paragraph

text: Ptalernaic architects also added ambulatories
label: Paragraph

text: around the temple, making it an autonomous
label: Paragraph

text: object within the confines of the outer walls.
label: Paragraph

text: Much innovation focused on the elaborations
label: Paragraph

text: of columns and their capitals. The capital
label: Paragraph

text: could be round or single-stemmed, quatrefoil
label: Paragraph

text: or even eight-stemmed. The plant motifs are
label: Paragraph

text: palm, papyrus, lotus, and lily, even though
label: Paragraph

text: the lily was not a native Egyptian species.
label: Paragraph

text: The plants’ leaves could then appear stacked
label: Paragraph

text: variously, frorn two to five. The richness of
label: Paragraph

text: form was augmented by lively coloring.
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Horus
label: Title

text: The Temple of Horus (begun 237 BCE) is
label: Paragraph

text: an excellent example of these tendencies.
label: Paragraph

text: The building not only had to reflect the
label: Paragraph

text: needs of the cult of Horus but also had
label: Paragraph

text: to serve as a pantheon for the cumulative
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of Egyptian religion. The entrance
label: Caption

text: is marked by a grand pylon 62.6 meters
label: Paragraph

text: across and 30.5 meters high, leading to
label: Paragraph

text: a court colonnaded on three sides—a
label: Paragraph

text: very un-Egyptian motif, more Hellenistic
label: Paragraph

text: in tone. The colonnade not only frames
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance of the temple but also
label: Paragraph

text: constitutes a type of extended porch that,
label: Paragraph

text: along with the perimeter walls, forms a
label: Paragraph

text: passageway. Past the two hypostyle halls
label: Caption

text: is an inner court, in the center of which
label: Paragraph

text: is the freestanding sanctuary of Horus.
label: Paragraph

text: The court gives access to thirteen small
label: Paragraph

text: chapels for the pantheon, all windowless
label: Caption

text: and completely dark except for tiny slit
label: Paragraph

text: entries. Great care was given to align
label: Paragraph

text: the pylon with the noontime sun at the
label: Paragraph

text: midsummer solstice. At that particular
label: Paragraph

text: moment, the pylon does not cast a
label: Paragraph

text: shadow.

label: Paragraph

text: After a particularly brutal battle, Asoka lost
label: Paragraph

text: faith in the traditional Aryan order, and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: various philosophers, decided to convert to
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism. Asoka was not the first Mauryan
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the end of his life, Chandragupta Maurya,
label: Paragraph

text: founder of the Mauryan dynasty, abdicated
label: Paragraph

text: is throne and became a Jain ascetic. His
label: Paragraph

text: son, Bindusara (r. 298-272 BCE) became
label: Paragraph

text: a follower of an even more extreme ascetic
label: Paragraph

text: movement known as the ajivikas. The ascetic
label: Paragraph

text: interest of these rulers derived from the
label: Paragraph

text: fact that they were not born into the Aryan
label: Paragraph

text: Kshatriya (warrior) caste, but were low-caste
label: Paragraph

text: upstarts who became Kshatriya after seizing
label: Paragraph

text: the Magadha throne. The difference between
label: Paragraph

text: Asoka and his predecessors was that he
label: Paragraph

text: adapted Buddhist teachings into a new moral
label: Title

text: and social order for his empire that he called
label: Paragraph

text: the dhamma. In essence Buddhism became
label: Paragraph

text: a state religion.
label: Paragraph

text: Though most of Asoka’s dhamma derives
label: Paragraph

text: from Buddhism—including vegetarianism
label: Title

text: 5.68 Vajrasana (“Diamond Throne”) at Bodh Gaya, India
label: Caption

text: and belief in nonviolence—it was not identical
label: Paragraph

text: to Buddhism. In fact, Asoka rarely mentioned
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddha while describing his dhamma,
label: Paragraph

text: which, significantly, included respect for
label: Paragraph

text: all religions as a core part of its tenets. To
label: Paragraph

text: promote his dhamma, which consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: about thirty-three edicts, Asoka had them
label: Paragraph

text: etched in stone tablets, on the side of
label: Caption

text: prominent rocks, and inside cave sanctuaries,
label: Paragraph

text: all in the vernacular language of his kingdom.
label: Paragraph

text: He also carved them on the sides of pillars,
label: Paragraph

text: about twenty of which have survived. One
label: Paragraph

text: such pillar, in Lauriya Nandangarh (in
label: Paragraph

text: Bihar), made from a single piece of polished
label: Paragraph

text: sandstone, rises 12 meters above the ground
label: Paragraph

text: and extends 3 meters into the earth. Though
label: Paragraph

text: the pillar is surmounted by an ornate capital,
label: Paragraph

text: it is the shaft with the inscribed edicts that
label: Paragraph

text: is of primary significance. The Asokan pillars
label: Paragraph

text: consist of a stylized lotus base that supports
label: Paragraph

text: an ornamental drum on which there are
label: Paragraph

text: sculptures of animals ranging from the bull
label: Caption

text: to the lion signifying royal authority. Most
label: Paragraph

text: famous is the pillar found at Sarnath, the
label: Paragraph

text: site of the Buddha's first sermon, the lotus
label: Paragraph

text: ase and drum of which is topped by a
label: Paragraph

text: capital of four lions. Surmounting all this, at
label: Paragraph

text: least originally, was the Buddhist wheel of
label: Paragraph

text: jaw, which has, in turn, been adopted as the
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of the modern Indian nation.
label: Paragraph

text: To further promote the Buddhist order,
label: Paragraph

text: Asoka convened a council of all significant
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: CHINA: THE WARRING STATES PERIOD
label: Title

text: In the Warring States period (481-221 BCE),
label: Paragraph

text: the old league of cities ruled by the Zhou
label: Title

text: nobility was replaced by a systern of
label: Paragraph

text: territorial states (seven major and about
label: Title

text: seven minor ones) under the carmmand of
label: Paragraph

text: monarchs who seem to have engaged in
label: Paragraph

text: feverish construction activity. They fortified
label: Paragraph

text: existing city walls, multiplied enclosures
label: Paragraph

text: and barricades, and established satellite
label: Paragraph

text: towns, all primarily for the purpose of
label: Paragraph

text: defense. Prior to the Warring States period,
label: Paragraph

text: cities were cultic and political entities
label: Paragraph

text: inhabited by the nobility and their followers.
label: Paragraph

text: Populations were in the tens of thousands
label: Paragraph

text: at most. During the Warring States period,
label: Paragraph

text: as cities became capitals of states, their
label: Paragraph

text: nature changed, becoming divided between
label: Paragraph

text: a political center and an economic center,
label: Paragraph

text: the two holding each other in mutual
label: Paragraph

text: suspicion. This suspicion was articulated in
label: Paragraph

text: laws that attempted to control the actions
label: Paragraph

text: and influence of merchants. The result was
label: Paragraph

text: that new and sharp boundaries were drawn
label: Paragraph

text: within the city between the political district,
label: Paragraph

text: which was protected with its own wall, and
label: Paragraph

text: the merchants’ district. New architectural
label: Caption

text: elements appeared that, through height and
label: Paragraph

text: verticality, emphasized the ruler’s authority.
label: Paragraph

text: owers, pillar gates, and raised buildings
label: Title

text: were all used to demonstrate power. When
label: Paragraph

text: Shang Yang began constructing the new Qin
label: Paragraph

text: capital Xianyang, the first iterns built were the
label: Paragraph

text: gate towers.
label: Paragraph

text: 5.72 Map of Xi'an, China, through history
label: Caption

text: Stepped terraces—called fai platforms—
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded on all four sides by the wooden
label: Paragraph

text: columns and beams of the palace, could
label: Paragraph

text: give the impression of multiple-storied
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. In an age that lacked the ability
label: Paragraph

text: to construct true multistoried buildings, this
label: Paragraph

text: design allowed for structures that seemed
label: Paragraph

text: to rise above the city. The ruler was bot!
label: Paragraph

text: all-seeing and yet invisible. Furthermore, it
label: Paragraph

text: was believed that the ruler should move in
label: Paragraph

text: secret to avoid evil spirits and that he should
label: Paragraph

text: live as much as possible in towers. For this
label: Paragraph

text: reason, Shi Huangdi, the First Emperor,
label: Paragraph

text: built elevated walks to connect all 270 of his
label: Paragraph

text: palaces and towers. Anyone who revealed
label: Paragraph

text: where the emperor was visiting was put to
label: Paragraph

text: death. This withdrawal from the gaze of the
label: Paragraph

text: populace, and even from the court, became
label: Paragraph

text: an essential attribute of Qin and Han imperial
label: Paragraph

text: personages. In Rome and India, a ruler’s
label: Paragraph

text: person had to be visible. But in China, his
label: Paragraph

text: status was derived from being hidden and
label: Paragraph

text: remote.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike the enclosed and understated

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: buildings was critical for a ruler’s image.
label: Paragraph

text: For instance, a Zhou king constructed an
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: with other lords. History reveals that his
label: Paragraph

text: guests, struck with awe at the sight of this
label: Paragraph

text: The architecture of tornbs and graveyards
label: Title

text: became increasingly important at this time.
label: Paragraph

text: Texts compiled during this period distinguish
label: Paragraph

text: between rituals performed within the city
label: Title

text: in ancestral temples and others performed
label: Paragraph

text: outside the city at graveyards. The most
label: Paragraph

text: visible remnants of Zhou architecture are, in
label: Paragraph

text: fact, tombs, of which more than six thousand
label: Paragraph

text: have been discovered. The tomb of Zeng Hou
label: Paragraph

text: Yi (Marquis Yi of Zeng) attracted international
label: Paragraph

text: attention when a large collection of bronze
label: Paragraph

text: objects was found there, including a set
label: Paragraph

text: of sixty-five ritual bells weighing a total of
label: Paragraph

text: 2,500 kilograms. The tomb consisted of an
label: Paragraph

text: irregularly shaped vertical pit, 13 meters deep
label: Caption

text: and more than 200 square meters in area. It
label: Paragraph

text: was divided into four chambers by wooden
label: Paragraph

text: planks, with the principal chamber, on the
label: Paragraph

text: east, containing the marquis’s body.
label: Paragraph

text: The body was placed in a double-layered
label: Paragraph

text: coffin. The space between the coffin and the
label: Paragraph

text: chamber walls was filled with charcoal, clay,
label: Paragraph

text: and earth to seal it as completely as possible.
label: Paragraph

text: The eastern chamber also had coffins for
label: Paragraph

text: eight women—possibly musicians who were
label: Title

text: sacrificed at the time of the burial (although
label: Paragraph

text: human sacrificial internment was almost over
label: Paragraph

text: by this time in Chinese history). The western
label: Paragraph

text: chamber held skeletons of thirteen young
label: Title

text: women, who may have been the ruler’s
label: Paragraph

text: concubines. The remaining two chambers
label: Paragraph

text: Hou Yi, Sui Zhou, China
label: Caption

text: were filled with ritual objects and weapons
label: Paragraph

text: made of bronze, gold, copper, lacquer, wood,
label: Paragraph

text: jade, and other materials.
label: Paragraph

text: A curious aspect of this tomb is that
label: Paragraph

text: small window-like openings connect all four
label: Paragraph

text: chambers. Even the marquis's outer coffin
label: Paragraph

text: bears a rectangular hole, and his inner coffin
label: Paragraph

text: is painted with doors and windows with lattice
label: Paragraph

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: Eurasia was dominated by China and Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: interconnected by an increasingly vast
label: Paragraph

text: system of land and sea trade routes known
label: Title

text: in their entirety as the Silk Route. In spite
label: Paragraph

text: of its name, it wasn’t only silk that moved
label: Paragraph

text: westward; in actuality the Silk Route economy
label: Paragraph

text: was a transcontinental trade in not just silk
label: Paragraph

text: but also other luxury items such as rugs,
label: Paragraph

text: gold, silver, craft objects, gems, ivory, and
label: Paragraph

text: perfumes—all things that could be easily
label: Title

text: packed and transported on the backs of
label: Paragraph

text: camels. The term Si/k Route emphasizes
label: Paragraph

text: the trade that went from east to west, but
label: Paragraph

text: trade also went from west to east. The
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese valued horses as well as woolen
label: Paragraph

text: goods, carpets, curtains, blankets, rugs, and
label: Paragraph

text: Parthian tapestries since they were unfamiliar
label: Paragraph

text: with carpet manufacture and weaving. Also
label: Paragraph

text: imported into China were military equipment,
label: Paragraph

text: gold and silver, semiprecious stones, and
label: Paragraph

text: glass items, all of which were rare in China.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to the trade in luxury items,
label: Paragraph

text: there was bulk trade in grain, lumber, and
label: Paragraph

text: building materials. This trade belonged to a
label: Paragraph

text: different economic universe and was usually
label: Paragraph

text: transported by boat along rivers and shores;
label: Paragraph

text: here, the southern route through India and
label: Paragraph

text: along the coast around Southeast Asia was
label: Paragraph

text: preferred. That trade, along with cinnamon
label: Paragraph

text: from the Indonesian spice islands, was to
label: Paragraph

text: escalate in importance in the next centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: The Chinese, in order to get rice and other
label: Paragraph

text: bulk material, such as bricks and lumber,
label: Paragraph

text: from the rural south to the urban north,
label: Paragraph

text: built a vast network of canals, some 1,776
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers in total length, called the Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Canal. The oldest parts date back to the 5th
label: Paragraph

text: century BCE, although the various sections
label: Paragraph

text: were not connected until the Sui dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: (581-618 CE). The Romans, meanwhile, are
label: Paragraph

text: still famous for their roads today. Estimated
label: Paragraph

text: at about 400,000 kilometers in total, these
label: Paragraph

text: roads ranged from small local connectors to
label: Paragraph

text: broad, long-distance highways built to link
label: Paragraph

text: cities, towns, and military bases. The major
label: Paragraph

text: roads were stone-paved and flanked by
label: Paragraph

text: footpaths and drainage ditches.
label: Paragraph

text: The city of Rome developed from
label: Paragraph

text: a relatively small town to a sprawling
label: Paragraph

text: metropolis. Though the Romans planned
label: Paragraph

text: the layout of their military camps with great
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial precision, the city of Rome
label: Title

text: developed with little top-down planning. At
label: Paragraph

text: its center was the forum, the political core of
label: Paragraph

text: the city. It was located in a valley surrounded
label: Paragraph

text: by hills over which the city began to spread.
label: Paragraph

text: Though almost all cities in the Mediterranean
label: Paragraph

text: world were associated with deities and ritual,
label: Paragraph

text: and linked to sacred acts when they were
label: Paragraph

text: created, the Roman Forum was designed as
label: Paragraph

text: a particularly intense site, from its mythical
label: Paragraph

text: origins with Romulus and Remus to the
label: Paragraph

text: Vestal Virgins who lived in a special residence
label: Paragraph

text: and maintained the sacred fire. It was the
label: Paragraph

text: site of the umbilicus of the earth and the site
label: Caption

text: where the sacred law tablets were on display.
label: Paragraph

text: And as the ceremonial center of the republic,
label: Paragraph

text: (ending in 27 BCE with the establishment
label: Paragraph

text: of the Rornan Empire), it was politically far
label: Paragraph

text: different from almost every model of rulership
label: Paragraph

text: to date, with the exception of Athens. The
label: Paragraph

text: transition to the empire was much contested,
label: Paragraph

text: but it was more than just a grab for power
label: Paragraph

text: by certain elites. The enormous sale of the
label: Paragraph

text: territory did not match well with the still rather
label: Paragraph

text: loose mercantile ethos of the republic. The
label: Paragraph

text: shift began when Caesar invaded Gaul, not
label: Paragraph

text: just for his personal glory but to gain access
label: Paragraph

text: to some of the best farmland in Europe as
label: Paragraph

text: well as to metal. For several centuries, the
label: Paragraph

text: Romans had traded with the Gauls and
label: Paragraph

text: Celts for iron, which they needed for their
label: Paragraph

text: military. Despite early resistance to Roman
label: Paragraph

text: domination, the Celts largely accommodated
label: Paragraph

text: themselves to a Roman way of life that
label: Paragraph

text: brought protection and prosperity.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially, the economic ascendancy o
label: Paragraph

text: Rome cast a pall over western Asia, and very
label: Paragraph

text: little of consequence was built during the
label: Paragraph

text: Ist century BCE. But soon Rome was able
label: Paragraph

text: to impose a cohesive appearance over its
label: Paragraph

text: expanding domains. Roman emperors from
label: Paragraph

text: Augustus to Trajan built impressive temples,
label: Paragraph

text: forums, villas, and cities, all with the typical
label: Paragraph

text: Roman imprint. Cities, roads, theaters, baths,
label: Caption

text: markets, and military camps began to be
label: Paragraph

text: built, from Hadrian’s Wall in England (122
label: Caption

text: CE) to Timgad in Algeria (founded by Emperor
label: Paragraph

text: Trajan ca. 100 CE).
label: Paragraph

text: Between the great centers of Rome and
label: Paragraph

text: China, there stretched trackless steppe and
label: Paragraph

text: desert; to get material across this area, the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese, like the Romans, had to rely on
label: Paragraph

text: people who lived in gers, yurts, and tents,
label: Paragraph

text: and whose survival depended just as much
label: Paragraph

text: on their reliability as on their cunning and
label: Paragraph

text: prowess. These nomadic cultures, however,
label: Paragraph

text: get little credit for their efforts, as they were
label: Paragraph

text: generally seen as rootless barbarians, but
label: Paragraph

text: without them, there would have been no
label: Paragraph

text: China and no Rome. For instance, it was
label: Paragraph

text: the Xiongu khanate’s confederation of tribes
label: Title

text: north of China that fed the ravenous needs of
label: Paragraph

text: the empire. Such confederations would come
label: Paragraph

text: and go over the centuries, but they were
label: Paragraph

text: indispensable to the Eurasian economy.
label: Paragraph

text: The Romans, at their end of the Silk
label: Paragraph

text: Route, had to deal in particular with the
label: Paragraph

text: Parthians, the great horseback warriors who
label: Paragraph

text: controlled the deserts of western Asia. The
label: Paragraph

text: Romans tried to conquer them again and
label: Paragraph

text: again in a series of battles that lasted over the
label: Paragraph

text: entire period of their empire. But although the
label: Paragraph

text: 6.2 The Colosseum, Rome
label: Caption

text: history books emphasize war and conquest,
label: Paragraph

text: war or no war, it was the trade exchange
label: Paragraph

text: that linked people across the landscape. A
label: Paragraph

text: significant border city was Dura-Europos (in
label: Paragraph

text: modern-day Syria), built on a bluff 90 meters
label: Paragraph

text: above the right bank of the Euphrates River to
label: Paragraph

text: control the river crossing on the route between
label: Paragraph

text: the Mediterranean port city of Antioch
label: Title

text: and the inland caravan cities to the east.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially founded in 303 BCE, Dura-Europos
label: Paragraph

text: was redesigned in the 2nd century BCE in
label: Paragraph

text: the Greek manner, with rectangular blocks
label: Paragraph

text: around a large central agora. At the end of
label: Paragraph

text: the 2nd century BCE it came under Parthian
label: Paragraph

text: control and was known as a cosmopolitan
label: Paragraph

text: center. It contained not only a well-preserved
label: Paragraph

text: synagogue but also an early Christian church.
label: Paragraph

text: he city was captured by the Romans in 165
label: Paragraph

text: CE and all but abandoned in the middle of
label: Paragraph

text: the 3rd century CE. To enhance their trade
label: Paragraph

text: position, the Romans tried to do an end run
label: Paragraph

text: around the Parthians by making alliances
label: Paragraph

text: with the Nabataeans, a caravan-based culture
label: Paragraph

text: centered in Jordan; the Nabataeans controlled
label: Paragraph

text: the routes to the south and to India. The
label: Paragraph

text: Roman attitude toward the Nabateans was
label: Paragraph

text: different than toward the Parthians. The
label: Paragraph

text: Nabataeans were made citizens of Rome
label: Paragraph

text: and were showered with privileges. The
label: Paragraph

text: extravagant tombs the Nabataeans built for
label: Paragraph

text: themselves are showpieces of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: luxury and testaments to their important
label: Title

text: position in global trade.
label: Paragraph

text: The Roman attempt to control the eastern
label: Title

text: Mediterranean included the all-important
label: Paragraph

text: Levant, and in 70 CE they conquered the
label: Paragraph

text: city of Jerusalem and destroyed its farnous
label: Title

text: Second Temple, an act still mourned annually
label: Paragraph

text: as the Jewish fast Tisha B’Av. Back in Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: Emperor Titus built an arch celebrating
label: Paragraph

text: the sacking of Jerusalem and its temple.
label: Paragraph

text: At the center of this prosperity was Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: which underwent a profound transformation
label: Paragraph

text: between 50 CE and 150 CE. It is clear that
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in the Roman heartland in the
label: Title

text: 1st century CE was often magnificent in scale
label: Paragraph

text: and material, but in design terms it was
label: Paragraph

text: notably conventional compared to that found
label: Paragraph

text: in West Asia at the time. The architecture at
label: Paragraph

text: Petra, the Nabataean capital, parallels the
label: Paragraph

text: spatial innovation seen elsewhere, such as at
label: Paragraph

text: Herod’s Palace at Masada, which works its
label: Paragraph

text: way down a difficult slope.
label: Paragraph

text: The Romans built extensive villas,
label: Paragraph

text: including a new palace for the emperor,
label: Paragraph

text: the Palace of Domitian (also known as
label: Paragraph

text: Flavian Palace), which was completed
label: Paragraph

text: in 92 CE during the reign of Titus Flavius
label: Paragraph

text: Domitianus and attributed to his master
label: Paragraph

text: architect, Rabirius. The very word palace
label: Paragraph

text: is thought to have derived from its location
label: Paragraph

text: on the Palatine Hill. It consisted of a series
label: Paragraph

text: of open courtyards that define imperial,
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial, and private activities. The plan
label: Paragraph

text: is a master class in spatial organization.
label: Paragraph

text: This period also saw the construction of the
label: Paragraph

text: Colosseum (72-80 CE), which could hold up
label: Paragraph

text: to 80,000 spectators, and the rise of vast
label: Paragraph

text: urban-scale entertainment. Unlike earlier
label: Paragraph

text: such structures that were built into hillsides,
label: Paragraph

text: this is an entirely freestanding structure, its
label: Paragraph

text: monumental facade comprising three stories
label: Caption

text: of superimposed arcades surmounted by
label: Caption

text: a tall attic story. The building was used to
label: Paragraph

text: host gladiatorial shows and a variety of other
label: Title

text: Though there is a debate about who exactly

label: Paragraph

text: custom. This means that almost everything
label: Paragraph

text: was connected to ritual observances, at the
label: Paragraph

text: core of which was the sacrifice that served
label: Paragraph

text: as a type of consummation of deals made
label: Paragraph

text: between the supplicant and a specific god.
label: Paragraph

text: Supplicants could be an individual or an
label: Paragraph

text: entire city. Precise adherence to ritual was
label: Paragraph

text: essential, since deviations could contaminate
label: Paragraph

text: the results. Important sacrifices involved
label: Paragraph

text: animal victims. Each deity had his or
label: Paragraph

text: her own preference as to what was to be
label: Paragraph

text: sacrificed. The sex of a chosen animal was
label: Paragraph

text: also significant: male for gods, female for
label: Paragraph

text: goddesses. So was its color: white beasts were
label: Paragraph

text: offered to deities of the upper world, black
label: Paragraph

text: to those of the underworld. The sacrifice for
label: Paragraph

text: Mars was usually a combination of an ox, a
label: Paragraph

text: ram, and a boar. Sacrifices took place in front
label: Paragraph

text: of an altar and were elaborate and messy
label: Paragraph

text: routines. The head of the victim was sprinkled
label: Paragraph

text: with wine and with bits of sacred cake made
label: Paragraph

text: from flour and salt. The animal was then
label: Paragraph

text: stunned with an axe or mallet before its throat
label: Paragraph

text: was slit. It was then disemboweled, and the
label: Paragraph

text: liver and other organs were inspected. If there
label: Paragraph

text: was something wrong, this was considered
label: Paragraph

text: a bad omen and the process had to be
label: Paragraph

text: repeated with a fresh animal until it came
label: Paragraph

text: out right. The vital organs were burnt upon
label: Paragraph

text: the altar and the carcass was cut into pieces
label: Paragraph

text: and eaten on the spot, with all participants in
label: Paragraph

text: the ritual receiving a piece of the animal. For
label: Paragraph

text: large urban-scale sacrifices, this could entail
label: Paragraph

text: a large number of animals. All sacrifices and
label: Paragraph

text: to be effective. Public religious ritual had to

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: than a personal expression. The disasters of

label: Paragraph

text: Pouring large structures was a complex,

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the ancients. And though concrete workers
label: Paragraph

text: today vibrate the wet concrete after they pour
label: Paragraph

text: it to make sure it fills the formwork, Roman
label: Paragraph

text: concrete was pounded—the pounding, as
label: Paragraph

text: the engineer David Moore has discovered,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The earliest form of Roman concrete is
label: Paragraph

text: known as opus incertum. Opus is the Latin
label: Paragraph

text: word for “work,” so opus incerturm means
label: Paragraph

text: something like “worked in,” which makes
label: Paragraph

text: sense since the concrete was layered with
label: Paragraph

text: irregularly shaped uncut stones or fist-sized
label: Paragraph

text: locks of tufa. Tufa is a relatively lightweight
label: Paragraph

text: stone and is thus easy to use. Over time,
label: Paragraph

text: a more finished look was produced using
label: Paragraph

text: more regularly shaped stones. A variant is
label: Paragraph

text: nown as opus reticulatum. Reticulatum is
label: Paragraph

text: Latin for “netlike.” This form of concrete wall
label: Paragraph

text: consists of diamond-shaped bricks of tufa
label: Paragraph

text: placed around a core of cernent. The blocks
label: Paragraph

text: were placed at an angle of 45 degrees to
label: Paragraph

text: form a diagonal pattern. This construction
label: Paragraph

text: technique was used from the beginning of
label: Paragraph

text: the 1st century BCE until opus /atericium
label: Title

text: came common in the imperial age. In opus
label: Paragraph

text: fatericium, the concrete wall is surfaced with
label: Paragraph

text: rick.
label: Paragraph

text: The Romans also industrialized the
label: Paragraph

text: production of bricks. Their armies operated
label: Paragraph

text: mobile kilns so that they could build
label: Paragraph

text: structures rapidly. In this way, they introduced
label: Paragraph

text: bricks to many parts of the empire. Roman
label: Paragraph

text: bricks are often stamped with the mark of the
label: Paragraph

text: army legion that supervised their production.
label: Paragraph

text: Sizes, however, were not uniform. Shapes
label: Paragraph

text: included square, rectangular, triangular, and
label: Paragraph

text: round, with some reaching over 1 meter in
label: Paragraph

text: length.

label: Caption

text: The Roman Urban Villa
label: Title

text: Until the 2nd century BCE, Roman houses
label: Paragraph

text: followed the old Mediterranean plan,
label: Paragraph

text: with rooms grouped around a tall, dark
label: Paragraph

text: atrium. Eventually, however, with increased
label: Paragraph

text: prosperity, private houses became ever more
label: Paragraph

text: luxurious. Colonnaded gardens, inspired by
label: Caption

text: Egyptian architecture, were added behind the
label: Paragraph

text: house. Exedrae and libraries were installed,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as fountains, summer dining rooms
label: Paragraph

text: (some upstairs to allow views), and even
label: Paragraph

text: private baths. Windows became bigger, and
label: Paragraph

text: walls were ornamented with illusionistic
label: Paragraph

text: pictures. In Pompeii, some families bought
label: Paragraph

text: out their neighbors to increase their living
label: Paragraph

text: space and create a grand house. Compare
label: Paragraph

text: this with Sirkap, in present-day Pakistan,
label: Paragraph

text: founded by the Greeks in around 190 BCE;
label: Paragraph

text: while there is a similarly dense fabric
label: Paragraph

text: of houses, there is little differentiation
label: Paragraph

text: in their scale. But in Pornpeii, after the
label: Paragraph

text: abovementioned consolidation had taken
label: Paragraph

text: place, a single villa could be as large as an
label: Paragraph

text: entire city block in Sirkap. The owners of
label: Paragraph

text: these houses, based on Etruscan traditions,
label: Paragraph

text: placed great value on the social importance
label: Paragraph

text: of feasting. Meals were elaborate affairs
label: Paragraph

text: prepared by professional cooks and served
label: Paragraph

text: on silver plates, with occasional bouts of
label: Paragraph

text: drinking. In 182 BCE, the senate passed a law
label: Paragraph

text: regulating the size of parties, but this did little
label: Paragraph

text: to stem the tide. Villas grew to enormous size
label: Paragraph

text: and can be found in the Campagna, or by
label: Paragraph

text: the coast.
label: Paragraph

text: Villas were embellished with dining pavilions,
label: Paragraph

text: towers, colonnaces, fish ponds, and formal
label: Paragraph

text: parks. During this time, wealthy Romans
label: Paragraph

text: began sending their sons to Greece to learn
label: Paragraph

text: rhetoric, leading to careers in law or politics.
label: Paragraph

text: Also admired was Greek art and architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: although there was less interest in Greek
label: Paragraph

text: literature, music, and science. Sundials were
label: Paragraph

text: brought from Greek cities in Sicily, but it
label: Paragraph

text: took Romans a hundred years to learn that,
label: Paragraph

text: having moved the sundials northward, they
label: Paragraph

text: had to adjust their markings for the change
label: Paragraph

text: in latitude.

text: Republican Tombs
label: Title

text: The rise of an affluent merchant class
label: Title

text: combined with Hellenistic emotionalism led to
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of a funerary architecture that
label: Paragraph

text: became an autonomous form of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: expression. Although tomb design can
label: Paragraph

text: easily be dismissed as a minor architectural
label: Paragraph

text: typology, it played a key role in offering a field
label: Paragraph

text: of experimentation in which architects could
label: Paragraph

text: work out, in miniature, certain architectural
label: Paragraph

text: problems or themes. Roman temples in the
label: Paragraph

text: time of the republic were, by contrast, quite
label: Paragraph

text: conventional—and purposefully so, since
label: Paragraph

text: they embodied the principle of tradition. Not
label: Paragraph

text: so with tombs.
label: Paragraph

text: The tomb of Marcus Vergilius Eurysaces
label: Caption

text: (30 BCE) is a case in point. A wealthy Roman
label: Paragraph

text: baker, he asked the architect to design
label: Paragraph

text: something on the theme of a panarium
label: Title

text: (a tube for storing bread). The exterior is
label: Paragraph

text: decorated with rows of giant tubes—carved
label: Paragraph

text: in stone, of course—with a lower range of
label: Paragraph

text: standing tubes and an upper range where
label: Paragraph

text: they are horizontal. The top has been lost,
label: Paragraph

text: but it was most likely a pyramid. Grave
label: Paragraph

text: monuments of the leading class were, of
label: Paragraph

text: course, more monumental and dignified,
label: Paragraph

text: conforming to the deceased person's status
label: Paragraph

text: in life. The Monument of the Julii in St.-
label: Caption

text: Remy, France, for example, is sedate and
label: Paragraph

text: consists of three superimposed zones: a
label: Paragraph

text: socle, or foundation zone; a four-sided arch;
label: Paragraph

text: and a delicate round tempietto on top.
label: Paragraph

text: 6.18 Monument of the Julii, St.-Rémy, France

text: of which are decorated with half-columns.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: imagination. The tent indicates this might

label: Title

text: Originating from areas to the north and
label: Paragraph

text: west of the Black Sea, the Celts began to
label: Paragraph

text: spread westward across Europe around
label: Paragraph

text: 1000 BCE and soon dominated the area from
label: Paragraph

text: Switzerland and northern Italy to France
label: Title

text: and southern England. As a clan-oriented
label: Paragraph

text: society interconnected by trade, the Celts
label: Paragraph

text: were suited to the complex and disparate
label: Paragraph

text: landscapes of the region. They were also
label: Paragraph

text: excellent agriculturalists, organized around
label: Paragraph

text: networks of small settlements and farms.
label: Paragraph

text: Large cities developed during the 1st century
label: Paragraph

text: BCE. These included, from east to west, some
label: Paragraph

text: cities that are still inhabited, such as Kelheim
label: Paragraph

text: in Germany, Bern in Switzerland, and Reims
label: Paragraph

text: and Paris in France. Most others have long
label: Paragraph

text: since disappeared back into the landscape,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Hengistbury Head on the cliffs of
label: Paragraph

text: the southern coast of England and Manching
label: Title

text: Oppidum in Bavaria. These cities, the first
label: Paragraph

text: efforts at urbanization in Europe, were located
label: Paragraph

text: on flat-topped hills or along ridges that could
label: Paragraph

text: be easily defended by the addition of earthen
label: Paragraph

text: berms. The Romans used the word oppidurn
label: Paragraph

text: to describe these cities, and the term stuck.
label: Paragraph

text: In the cities of Gaul, there was a shift
label: Paragraph

text: from a largely agricultural and self-sustaining
label: Paragraph

text: local economy to one based on regional
label: Title

text: and transregional trade and industrial
label: Title

text: specialization, such as metal and cloth
label: Paragraph

text: making. The principal trading partner was,
label: Paragraph

text: of course, Rome to the south. Most maps

text: depicting Europe at the time show only the

text: Roman Empire, but viewing the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: and the Celtic areas together provides
label: Paragraph

text: a sense of the scale of Celtic territories.
label: Paragraph

text: Celtic metalworking was facilitated by the
label: Paragraph

text: presence of extensive forests, even though
label: Paragraph

text: archaeologists believe that large parts of
label: Paragraph

text: southern England, as well as locations
label: Paragraph

text: elsewhere, became deforested as a result of
label: Paragraph

text: these activities. The Celts also exported salt,
label: Paragraph

text: tin, and amber. The principal import from
label: Paragraph

text: the Greek and Roman territories was wine,
label: Paragraph

text: transported northward with great difficulty in
label: Paragraph

text: large amphorae. The Celts had a polytheistic
label: Paragraph

text: and animistic religion, with shrines situated
label: Paragraph

text: on hilltops, in groves, and on lakes. They
label: Paragraph

text: worshipped both gods and goddesses, many
label: Paragraph

text: associated with natural features like springs
label: Paragraph

text: and mountains. The oak tree was particularly
label: Paragraph

text: sacred. Their gods possessed particular
label: Paragraph

text: skills, like blacksmithing, healing, and
label: Paragraph

text: warfare. Some gods were local to a particular
label: Paragraph

text: area; others were shared. Priests were not
label: Paragraph

text: only religious officials but also judges and
label: Paragraph

text: calendar keepers, as well as guardians of the
label: Paragraph

text: communal memory.
label: Paragraph

text: Though life in these Celtic areas was
label: Paragraph

text: hardly static, with raids, expansions, and
label: Paragraph

text: contractions occurring in many places over
label: Paragraph

text: the course of time, by the 1st century BCE the
label: Paragraph

text: situation had become increasingly unstable.
label: Paragraph

text: A set of tribes from Germany and Denmark
label: Title

text: began to move southward into areas held
label: Paragraph

text: by the Helvetii. The Helvetii themselves also
label: Paragraph

text: were on the move westward, for unknown
label: Paragraph

text: reasons; to the south, the Romans had begun
label: Paragraph

text: to chip away at Celtic territory, taking Milan
label: Paragraph

text: and Marseilles. In 51 BCE, following a brutal
label: Paragraph

text: campaign, the Romans took Bibracte, one of
label: Paragraph

text: the largest Gaulic cities, and by 79 CE, most
label: Paragraph

text: of the Gaulic territory had been incorporated
label: Paragraph

text: into the Roman Empire. Bibracte stood
label: Paragraph

text: halfway on the trade route between Marseilles
label: Paragraph

text: to the south and Paris to the north; the route
label: Paragraph

text: to Paris continued across the English Channel
label: Title

text: to Hengistbury Head. Bibracte was also
label: Paragraph

text: the jumping-off point eastward to Germany.
label: Paragraph

text: The original name of the city was probably
label: Paragraph

text: Eduens, the name of the regional tribe.
label: Paragraph

text: At over a square kilometer in size and
label: Paragraph

text: straddling the ridge of one of the tallest
label: Paragraph

text: mountains in the area, Bibracte was the
label: Paragraph

text: same size as Rome, though considerably less
label: Paragraph

text: dense—it contained space for farm animals,
label: Paragraph

text: and the houses were rarely more than one or
label: Paragraph

text: two stories high. The city had a population
label: Paragraph

text: of several thousand, but there were
label: Paragraph

text: numerous smaller satellite villages. Despite its
label: Paragraph

text: mountaintop location, several artesian springs
label: Caption

text: fed the city with water year-round. The city
label: Paragraph

text: also served as a refuge for the local villagers
label: Paragraph

text: in times of warfare, which might explain the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of a second fortification ring
label: Title

text: in the Ist century BCE, about a hundred
label: Paragraph

text: years after the construction of the first ring.
label: Paragraph

text: These rings, which are log-reinforced earthen
label: Paragraph

text: AUGUSTAN ROME
label: Title

text: Rome's shift from republic to empire
label: Title

text: coincided with the trend of deifying rulers.
label: Paragraph

text: Caesar was the first to experience such an
label: Paragraph

text: apotheosis; after that, it became common
label: Paragraph

text: practice for emperors to be equated with
label: Paragraph

text: divinity. Emperor Augustus, who followed
label: Paragraph

text: Caesar, changed Rome. It is said that he
label: Paragraph

text: found Rome a city of brick, but that when
label: Paragraph

text: he died, he left it a city of marble. This is not
label: Paragraph

text: far from the truth, for in the forty years of his
label: Paragraph

text: reign, Augustus practically rebuilt the entire
label: Paragraph

text: city, and more than anything, he remodeled
label: Paragraph

text: the Roman Forum.
label: Paragraph

text: To understand the magnitude of these
label: Paragraph

text: efforts, we have to remember that before
label: Paragraph

text: Augustus’s long tenure (27 BCE-14 CE),
label: Paragraph

text: Rome was an unattractive and even unsafe
label: Paragraph

text: city. It had a population of one million; crime,
label: Paragraph

text: corruption, speculation, and misrnanagernent
label: Title

text: caused the temples to be neglected and the
label: Paragraph

text: public structures to crumble. Many parts of
label: Paragraph

text: the city were nothing better than slums. Fires
label: Paragraph

text: broke out continuously—in 16, 14, 12, and
label: Paragraph

text: 7 BCE—while floods ravaged low-lying areas.
label: Paragraph

text: Among Augustus's efforts was an attempt
label: Paragraph

text: to bring order to the core of the city. After
label: Paragraph

text: a major storm, he asked for a study of roof
label: Paragraph

text: tiles. He also created a new water system,
label: Paragraph

text: restored eighty-two temples, increase
label: Caption

text: spending on public building and street
label: Title

text: repairs, and even established a fire brigade of
label: Paragraph

text: six hundred slaves.
label: Paragraph

text: One of his first efforts was to complete
label: Paragraph

text: the Forum of Caesar, which had been left
label: Paragraph

text: unfinished at the latter's assassination in
label: Paragraph

text: 44 BcE. Rectangular in shape, it was similar
label: Paragraph

text: in scale to the old forum but enlarged to the
label: Paragraph

text: north and connected to it by a portal. The
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Caesar, built in white marble, sat
label: Caption

text: on a high podium at the narrow end of the
label: Paragraph

text: forum. The building had columns on three
label: Paragraph

text: sides, making it appear that the pferon and
label: Paragraph

text: the cella had been snapped into each other.
label: Paragraph

text: The fundamental idea of the composition was
label: Paragraph

text: Hellenistic, but its simplicity and orderliness
label: Paragraph

text: established it as a prototype. The new forum,
label: Paragraph

text: encroaching on the old Comitium, had to

label: Title

text: The Augustan Age was a boon for architects,
label: Paragraph

text: leading Marcus Vitruvius Pollio (ca.
label: Paragraph

text: 70-25 BCE) to compose a treatise entitled
label: Paragraph

text: De architectura (“On Architecture”), known
label: Paragraph

text: today as the Ten Books on Architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the book contains a vast amount of
label: Paragraph

text: useful information on construction materials,
label: Paragraph

text: choice of site, and even the education of an
label: Paragraph

text: architect, Vitruvius was generally critical of
label: Paragraph

text: the architectural developments of his age. He
label: Paragraph

text: was hesitant to accept concrete and felt that
label: Paragraph

text: many of the new buildings commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: y Augustus were built without guiding
label: Paragraph

text: principles. In attempting to reestablish
label: Paragraph

text: these principles, he argued that the three
label: Paragraph

text: orders—Doric, lonic, and Corinthian—should
label: Paragraph

text: e governed by proportions unique to
label: Paragraph

text: each. Vitruvius also differentiated between
label: Paragraph

text: firmitas, utilitas, and venustas (“durability,”
label: Paragraph

text: “usefulness,” and “beauty”). Each building,
label: Paragraph

text: e argued, needed to be designed with these
label: Paragraph

text: criteria in mind. A warehouse, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: should be built with usefulness in mind,
label: Paragraph

text: ut not be unpleasant to look at, whereas a
label: Paragraph

text: palace should be built with beauty in mind,
label: Paragraph

text: ut nonetheless designed for the ages.

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph
