text: Palace of Domitian
label: Title

text: Following a period of violence and anarchy
label: Title

text: after the death of Nero, stability returned
label: Paragraph

text: with the rule of Vespasian (r. 69-79 Ce) and
label: Paragraph

text: a century-long sequence of rulers whose
label: Paragraph

text: policies, broadly considered, brought peace
label: Paragraph

text: and unity to the ancient Mediterranean
label: Title

text: world. Peace for Romans, of course, came
label: Paragraph

text: at a price for others. In 70 CE, Vespasian
label: Paragraph

text: destroyed the Second Temple of the Jews in
label: Paragraph

text: Jerusalem and forced the Jews into slavery.
label: Paragraph

text: About ten thousand Jews were transported
label: Paragraph

text: to Rome to be used as workers to help build
label: Paragraph

text: the Colosseum. In the wake of these and
label: Paragraph

text: other victories, Vespasian’s son Domitian
label: Paragraph

text: (r. 81-96 CE) began a new imperial palace
label: Paragraph

text: (also known as the Flavian Palace or Domus
label: Paragraph

text: Augustana), which, on the eastern ridge
label: Paragraph

text: of the Palatine Hill, was to become the
label: Paragraph

text: permanent residence of the emperors. It was
label: Paragraph

text: still in use when Narses, the conqueror of the
label: Paragraph

text: Goths, died there in 571. Domitian imposed
label: Paragraph

text: his absolutist tendencies upon society to a
label: Paragraph

text: degree previously unknown. Under his rule,
label: Paragraph

text: the lingering pragmatism of Roman culture
label: Title

text: became increasingly infused with an ideology
label: Paragraph

text: of Near Eastern flavor with implications of
label: Paragraph

text: the quasi-divine nature of the ruler. The
label: Paragraph

text: new palace had to reflect the new notions of
label: Paragraph

text: power and majesty. The tight, almost chaotic
label: Paragraph

text: jumble of conflicting axial realities that made
label: Paragraph

text: Nero's palace so startling gave way to a more
label: Paragraph

text: controlled expressions when Domitian’s
label: Paragraph

text: architect, Rabirius, cut a great step into the
label: Paragraph

text: hillside to create a split-level palace.
label: Paragraph

text: The palace was in the upper part, the
label: Paragraph

text: residence in the lower. Though there is a
label: Paragraph

text: great deal of spatial innovation, everything is
label: Paragraph

text: thought through. There are no awkward or
label: Paragraph

text: surprising collisions of space, as one finds
label: Paragraph

text: in Nero's palace. The entrance is on an axis
label: Paragraph

text: that leads through two peristyle courts and
label: Paragraph

text: into a structure that is at first symmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: but, at its right and left perimeters, connects
label: Paragraph

text: fluidly into other spatial configurations.
label: Paragraph

text: Helping to negotiate the spatial transitions is
label: Paragraph

text: the ingenious use of curved and rectilinear
label: Paragraph

text: geometries. The entrance, for example, is
label: Paragraph

text: marked by a curved vestibule that leads
label: Paragraph

text: through a series of spaces that expand and
label: Paragraph

text: contract based on the theme of the vaults
label: Paragraph

text: above and on openings of different sizes and
label: Paragraph

text: qualities that lead to side rooms.
label: Paragraph

text: At the far end of the axis were two
label: Paragraph

text: summer houses, located at the top of the
label: Paragraph

text: large curve of a gallery overlooking the Circus
label: Caption

text: Maximus. On the east side of the palace one
label: Caption

text: finds another register of spaces dominated
label: Paragraph

text: by a hippodrome, the floor of which is some
label: Paragraph

text: 10 meters lower. A viewing box forms the
label: Paragraph

text: terminus of a cross-axis connecting the
label: Paragraph

text: garden fountain and the peristyle court. The
label: Paragraph

text: aula regia, or audience hall, overlooked the
label: Paragraph

text: forum.

label: Caption

text: court. To the north are three state chambers:

label: Paragraph

text: 6.43 Plan: Palace of Domitian, Palatine Hill, Rome ° ae
label: Caption

text: The building is an example of the brilliance
label: Paragraph

text: of Roman spatial practices. The designer
label: Paragraph

text: starts with the courtyard of peristyle. Since
label: Paragraph

text: the spaces attached to its four sides do not
label: Paragraph

text: need to be the same, the designer then plugs
label: Paragraph

text: in components to match the program. These
label: Paragraph

text: components are usually locally syrnmetrical,
label: Paragraph

text: but become less symmetrical the further
label: Paragraph

text: one moves from the central axis. In this way,
label: Paragraph

text: the designer creates “blocks” that can then
label: Paragraph

text: be added to each other around regulating
label: Paragraph

text: grids. The more this plan is studied, the
label: Paragraph

text: more combinations can be made of these
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, depending on whether they are read
label: Paragraph

text: as recessive or dominant. For example, the
label: Paragraph

text: southern end of the entrance peristyle hooks
label: Caption

text: directly to another peristyle, which has three
label: Paragraph

text: different suites of rooms on its three sides.
label: Paragraph

text: The loggia overlooking the hippodrome is
label: Paragraph

text: one such unit, the entrance to the palace on
label: Paragraph

text: its opposite side is another such unit, and
label: Paragraph

text: the complex set of rooms to the south yet
label: Paragraph

text: another.

text: The Colosseum
label: Title

text: The Colosseum (72-80 CE), much like the
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Fortuna, derives its structural
label: Paragraph

text: strength from its concrete vaults. If the
label: Paragraph

text: building, after earthquakes, fires, and
label: Paragraph

text: lootings, today still conveys its onetime
label: Paragraph

text: grandeur and even retains, up to a point, its
label: Paragraph

text: usability for open-air functions, we have the
label: Paragraph

text: ancients to thank for their bold use of that
label: Paragraph

text: material.
label: Paragraph

text: Though theaters were a common element
label: Paragraph

text: in Greek and Roman cities, this was the first
label: Paragraph

text: one that was designed as a freestanding
label: Paragraph

text: object. An earlier design dating from 80 BCE
label: Paragraph

text: in Pompeii and another from 56 BCE in
label: Paragraph

text: Lepcis Magna in North Africa were similar in
label: Paragraph

text: plan, but both were partially carved into the
label: Paragraph

text: rock. The Colosseum sits in a shallow valley
label: Paragraph

text: tween three hills, making it visible from
label: Paragraph

text: all directions, which gave it the status of a
label: Paragraph

text: landmark from the very beginning.
label: Paragraph

text: It is elliptical in plan and could hold fifty
label: Paragraph

text: thousand spectators, with boxes for the
label: Paragraph

text: emperor and dignitaries at the centers of the
label: Title

text: longer sides. Gladiatorial combats and the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition of wild beasts did not stop with the
label: Paragraph

text: Christianization of Rome. Romans remained
label: Paragraph

text: Romans. While gladiatorial combats were
label: Paragraph

text: abolished in 404 CE, games came to an end
label: Paragraph

text: only in the middle of the 6th century. And it
label: Paragraph

text: remained a place of public punishment well
label: Paragraph

text: into the 8th century. The masses of stone
label: Paragraph

text: that came down in earthquakes in 1231 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1349 provided Rome with building material
label: Paragraph

text: for more than four centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: If the undercroft shows once again the skill
label: Paragraph

text: of the engineers in designing and organizing
label: Title

text: a building on this scale, its facade shows
label: Paragraph

text: the architects’ confidence in their use of
label: Paragraph

text: the orders in relationship to the building's
label: Paragraph

text: solids and voids. Though ornamentation is
label: Paragraph

text: minimal, the system of attached columns
label: Paragraph

text: and arched openings allows for a balanced
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation of structure and mass. The
label: Paragraph

text: 53-meter-high wall was divided into Doric,
label: Paragraph

text: lonic, and Corinthian layers. The fourth story
label: Caption

text: had no openings, but brackets in the cornice
label: Paragraph

text: allowed large masts to be clamped against
label: Paragraph

text: the building to support awnings.
label: Paragraph

text: 6.46 Possible method for laying out the Colosseum
label: Caption

text: The capitals were stripped to their elernental
label: Paragraph

text: form. While this may have been for economy,
label: Paragraph

text: it also kept the columns from becoming
label: Paragraph

text: merely ornaments. Instead, they seem to be
label: Paragraph

text: infused with the same purposefulness as the
label: Paragraph

text: vaults, even though they belong to a different
label: Paragraph

text: structural system. Furthermore, the arches
label: Paragraph

text: have an architectural profile created by the
label: Paragraph

text: way a molding separates each arch from
label: Paragraph

text: its supporting pier at the impost blocks and
label: Paragraph

text: lightens the appearance of each arch from
label: Paragraph

text: the heavy voussoirs of which it is composed.
label: Paragraph

text: The columns look more structural than they
label: Paragraph

text: are, and the arches less so. A less skilled
label: Paragraph

text: hand could easily have tipped the balance
label: Paragraph

text: the wrong way.

text: The Imperial Forums
label: Title

text: At the beginning of the 2nd century CE, under
label: Paragraph

text: Trajan (r. 98-117 CE) and then Hadrian (r.
label: Paragraph

text: 117-138 CE), Rome was at the height of
label: Paragraph

text: its power. Trajan defeated the Dacians in
label: Paragraph

text: Romania (101-6 CE) to dispossess ther of
label: Paragraph

text: their plentiful gold mines. Other campaigns
label: Paragraph

text: led into Armenia and Mesopotamia. The
label: Paragraph

text: wealth that flowed back into the capital
label: Paragraph

text: restored the public treasury and insured
label: Title

text: vigorous implementation of architectural
label: Title

text: programs. And the rulers set a deterrnined
label: Paragraph

text: pace. Trajan rebuilt Ostia, Rorne’s harbor;
label: Caption

text: established a new public bath; and repaired
label: Paragraph

text: or extended existing streets. Above all, he
label: Paragraph

text: ordered a new forum to be built. Attributed
label: Paragraph

text: to the architect Apollodoro of Damascus, it
label: Paragraph

text: was a complex larger than any of the other
label: Paragraph

text: forums. Three hundred meters long, it
label: Paragraph

text: covered more than three times the area of
label: Paragraph

text: the Forum of Augustus. To prepare the site,
label: Paragraph

text: the engineers had to chop away a section
label: Paragraph

text: of a hill that connected the Quirinale to
label: Paragraph

text: the Campidoglio. The Forum of Trajan was
label: Paragraph

text: entered through a gateway located in a gently
label: Paragraph

text: bulging wall. At the far end was the sideways-
label: Paragraph

text: oriented Basilica Ulpia (107-13 CE), whose
label: Paragraph

text: apses on both ends echoed the ones built
label: Paragraph

text: into the colonnade of the forum that, in turn,
label: Paragraph

text: emulated the ones in the Forurn of Augustus.

text: Apart from the size of the basilica, it was designed in a traditional
label: Paragraph

text: manner. Two rows of gray granite columns lined the aisles, with
label: Paragraph

text: light filtering down, as usual, fromm a roof that covered the central
label: Paragraph

text: space. The roofs of the side aisles were covered by concrete vaults
label: Paragraph

text: rising directly from the architraves, while the roof over the central
label: Paragraph

text: aisle was probably spanned with wooden timbers. Sculptures and
label: Caption

text: relief panels show the campaigns and triumphs of the emperor.
label: Caption

text: On the main axis just behind the basilica stands Trajan’s Column,
label: Paragraph

text: with a spiral sculptural relief reading from the bottom to the top
label: Caption

text: that depicts the various important events of Trajan’s campaign
label: Paragraph

text: in Dacia. At the top was a bronze statue of Trajan himself. The
label: Paragraph

text: column contained an interior staircase. The freestanding column,
label: Paragraph

text: an unconventional feature in its own right, was also unusual for
label: Paragraph

text: Roman architecture, insofar as it interrupted the axial flow to the
label: Paragraph

text: temple. But it also highlights the central role of the forum as a war
label: Paragraph

text: memorial. The column is flanked by libraries: one for Greek scrolls,
label: Caption

text: the other for Latin. The whole cornplex ended with Trajan’s temple,
label: Paragraph

text: which was enormous, with columns measuring 2 meters across. The
label: Paragraph

text: forum’s unusual design may possibly derive from its emulation of
label: Paragraph

text: the central administrative area of a military camp: Trajan’s Column
label: Paragraph

text: and the flanking libraries seem similar to the location of the general’s
label: Paragraph

text: standard and military archives, which were set up behind the
label: Paragraph

text: basilica. Trajan was born in Spain and was raised as a soldier; the
label: Paragraph

text: military iconography has thus been suitably translated into a civic
label: Paragraph

text: monument.

text: 6.52 Plan: Imperial forums
label: Caption

text: Taken as a whole, the imperial forums constitute a remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: urban composition. There are no streets and no spatial or axial
label: Paragraph

text: connections between the spaces. The axis between the Temple
label: Paragraph

text: of Trajan and the Temple of Peace (though not exactly axial) is
label: Paragraph

text: purely planimetric. The elements are simply bonded to each other
label: Paragraph

text: to create a sequence of open, colonnaded, and enclosed spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: The words that come to mind when looking at this are montage or
label: Paragraph

text: assemblage. The Forum of Nerva, sometimes called the transitorium
label: Caption

text: (place of crossing), was the principal connection between the hill
label: Paragraph

text: and the older forums. A road led to a semicircular piazza on the
label: Paragraph

text: eastern side, the only place where the outside world infringes on the
label: Paragraph

text: space of the forums. But even that receptacle forced the foot traffic
label: Paragraph

text: to the left and around the side of the Ternple of Minerva. Traffic,
label: Paragraph

text: moving then diagonally through the space, exited at the other end
label: Paragraph

text: on the right, leading to the street that ran along the curia wall.
label: Paragraph

text: There was no attempt to make this forum into a street.

text: ROCK-CUT TOMBS
label: Title

text: The idea of making rock-cut tombs is an
label: Paragraph

text: ancient one. Hittite rock-cut sanctuaries,
label: Caption

text: for example, date back to 1250 BCE. Rock-
label: Paragraph

text: cut tombs can be even found in Italy dating
label: Paragraph

text: from the Etruscans. The custom was brought
label: Paragraph

text: eastward by Darius I, whose own tomb
label: Caption

text: (486 BCE) was carved out of the cliffs near
label: Paragraph

text: Persepolis. The rock-cut tombs in Lycia on
label: Paragraph

text: the southern coast of Turkey date from the
label: Paragraph

text: 4th century BCE; on the front of many of them
label: Paragraph

text: are temple facades in miniature. Though
label: Paragraph

text: rock-cut architecture was made in imitation of
label: Paragraph

text: traditional buildings, construction techniques
label: Title

text: were very different. Masons had to start from
label: Paragraph

text: the top so that the discarded stones did
label: Paragraph

text: not fall on the heads of their compatriots or
label: Paragraph

text: damage the new building elements. Working
label: Paragraph

text: from the top down required a different type
label: Paragraph

text: of planning and thinking; since it was not
label: Paragraph

text: possible to go back up for finishing touches,
label: Paragraph

text: one horizontal layer had to be completely
label: Paragraph

text: finished before the workers moved to the
label: Paragraph

text: segment below. This applied even for interior
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, which had to be chiseled from the
label: Paragraph

text: vault to the floor. The technique was used
label: Paragraph

text: not only for tombs but also for Buddhist and
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu temples, and later even for churches.
label: Paragraph

text: A large necropolis of rock-cut tornbs exists in
label: Paragraph

text: Cyprus near the town of Paphos. Several are
label: Paragraph

text: designed in the form of an impfuvium.

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Hellenistic areas, there was always a sense of

text: experimentation; there, Roman architecture
label: Paragraph

text: became less “Roman.” This was certainly
label: Paragraph

text: true in Petra. These were no temples,
label: Paragraph

text: however, but tombs, the most abundant of
label: Paragraph

text: which date from the early decades of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ist century CE. Their facades reveal a range

label: Paragraph

text: pilasters and topped with stepping “crow’s-
label: Caption

text: feet” ornamentation, a motif of Assyrian
label: Paragraph

text: and Babylonian origin. Others are massive,
label: Paragraph

text: largely unadorned facades with small, clearly
label: Paragraph

text: delineated entrances recalling an Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: pylon. Petra was thus a combination of
label: Paragraph

text: caravan meeting center and memorial site,

text: unique in the architectural world.
label: Paragraph

text: The beautifully preserved, deep-pinkish
label: Paragraph

text: facade of El-Deir is a showpiece of the

text: highest order. Its eight columns hold an
label: Paragraph

text: astonishing upper floor with a fhofos at the

text: center, flanked by what seem to be the
label: Paragraph

text: pieces of a broken porch front, the whole
label: Paragraph

text: then “framed” by protruding walls.
label: Paragraph

text: Khasneh al Faroun was probably built
label: Paragraph

text: for King Aretas Ill (87-65 BCE), but most
label: Paragraph

text: scholars date it to the 1st century CE.
label: Paragraph

text: Standing an astonishing 30 meters high, it
label: Paragraph

text: recalls the massing and intercolumniation
label: Paragraph

text: of Hellenistic temples. Twelve columns,
label: Caption

text: six on the lower level and six above, are
label: Paragraph

text: capped with Corinthian capitals and highly
label: Paragraph

text: ornamented moldings and friezes. The
label: Caption

text: upper colurnns are shorter than the lower,
label: Paragraph

text: but from the perspective of a viewer on
label: Paragraph

text: the ground, they seem well proportioned.
label: Paragraph

text: The spaces between the attached columns
label: Paragraph

text: contain high reliefs depicting Nabataean
label: Caption

text: deities and animals. The griffins that decorate
label: Paragraph

text: the frieze are derived from Mesopotamian
label: Paragraph

text: lore. The facade’s culminating feature is

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: they were largely tomb spaces. In 363 CE, an

label: Paragraph

text: NORTHERN PALACE AT MASADA
label: Title

text: Another striking example of Roman architecture
label: Paragraph

text: is Herod's Palace (30-20 BCE) at Masada,
label: Paragraph

text: a mountaintop fortress city rising above the
label: Paragraph

text: shores of the Dead Sea in the Judaean Desert,
label: Paragraph

text: 20 kilometers southeast of Jerusalem. This
label: Paragraph

text: palace is a synthesis of Roman and Hellenistic
label: Paragraph

text: design principles. The main residential part of
label: Paragraph

text: the palace is at the top of the acropolis, while
label: Paragraph

text: the rest of it descends down the steep northern
label: Paragraph

text: slope of the cliff in a tour de force encounter
label: Title

text: between architecture and nature. On the upper
label: Paragraph

text: terrace, rooms were grouped around a large
label: Paragraph

text: hall that opened onto a semicircular pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: or balcony, offering a fine view over the almost
label: Paragraph

text: vertical drop of the cliff. Steps led down to the
label: Paragraph

text: middle terrace, dorninated by a rotunda and
label: Paragraph

text: used, perhaps, as a dining room. Behind it,
label: Paragraph

text: carved out of the cliff face, was a library and
label: Paragraph

text: an enclosed room, possibly a treasury. Below
label: Caption

text: that was another terrace, with a hypostyle hall
label: Paragraph

text: and a bath complex. Herod built several other
label: Paragraph

text: spectacular structures. The so-called Herodion,
label: Paragraph

text: south of Jerusalem, built around 24 BCE as both
label: Paragraph

text: a palace and a fortress, lies atop an 80-meter-
label: Paragraph

text: high semi-artificial hill. Two concentric walls
label: Caption

text: contained the palace.

label: Title

text: In the period from 150 BCE to 100 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: the Gandharan region of the upper Indus
label: Title

text: Valley—now in Pakistan—was ruled by the
label: Paragraph

text: Shakas from Sogdiana and the Parthians,
label: Paragraph

text: who took over this region from Alexander's
label: Paragraph

text: governors. The Shakas and the Parthians
label: Title

text: adopted Buddhism, cultivated Hellenistic
label: Paragraph

text: workers, and brought their own Persian
label: Paragraph

text: and Central Asian backgrounds to the
label: Title

text: mix, creating an architecture that was an
label: Paragraph

text: Located on a major tributary of the Indus
label: Paragraph

text: River, the Gandharan capital city, Taxila (also
label: Paragraph

text: called Sirkap), was positioned at the meeting
label: Paragraph

text: point of three trade routes, one extending
label: Paragraph

text: east to the Indian heartland, a second west
label: Title

text: to Bactria and Persia, and a third to Central
label: Paragraph

text: Asia and the northern path of the Silk Route.
label: Paragraph

text: Taxila was rebuilt several times, until an
label: Paragraph

text: earthquake in the 1st century CE prompted a
label: Paragraph

text: complete rebuilding.
label: Paragraph

text: The urban layout of Taxila is rigidly
label: Paragraph

text: rectilinear in plan, with a 700-meter-long
label: Paragraph

text: street running through its center. The whole
label: Paragraph

text: was bounded by a high wall. Dense courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: housing of various sizes is organized in
label: Paragraph

text: blocks around a main street. A number
label: Paragraph

text: of religions seem to have commingled in
label: Paragraph

text: Taxila. The city was celebrated in the ancient
label: Paragraph

text: world as a prestigious center of learning,
label: Paragraph

text: and for the next eight hundred years or
label: Paragraph

text: more Buddhist shrines continued to be built
label: Paragraph

text: here. One of the city blocks was given over
label: Paragraph

text: to what is known as the Apsidal Temple,
label: Paragraph

text: 6.67 Plan of Taxila
label: Caption

text: which is like a caitya hall of the type that
label: Paragraph

text: was pervasive throughout South Asia at the
label: Paragraph

text: time. But this temple was constructed as
label: Paragraph

text: a freestanding object. Sitting in the middle
label: Paragraph

text: of an open courtyard and measuring about
label: Paragraph

text: 40 by 75 meters, the temple was raised on
label: Paragraph

text: a high plinth and accessed by a large axial
label: Caption

text: stair. The stair was flanked by two stupas on
label: Caption

text: square bases. (Only the bases survive.) To
label: Paragraph

text: the southeast of the city, on another plateau,
label: Paragraph

text: is the large Dnarmarajika Stupa. The mound
label: Paragraph

text: on which it sits is surrounded by a multitude
label: Paragraph

text: of monks’ cells.
label: Paragraph

text: North of the city, on a high rocky

text: outcrop, is a Jandial ternple, a Greek

label: Paragraph

text: the main walls and that the temple may have

text: QIN DYNASTY, CHINA
label: Title

text: After almost two hundred years of civil
label: Title

text: war, China was unified by the short-lived
label: Paragraph

text: but supremely despotic Qin dynasty
label: Title

text: (221-206 BCE). The first ruler of the
label: Paragraph

text: dynasty, Ying Zheng, renamed himself Shi
label: Paragraph

text: Huangdi (“First Emperor") and justified his
label: Paragraph

text: ruthless suppression of opposition on the
label: Title

text: grounds that he had a divine mandate to
label: Paragraph

text: reunify China. After victory over the last of
label: Paragraph

text: his enemies, Shi Huangdi put in place a
label: Paragraph

text: centralized bureaucracy and administration
label: Title

text: that could account for the diverse sections
label: Paragraph

text: of the empire. The systern of writing was
label: Paragraph

text: standardized, as was the language. A single
label: Paragraph

text: currency was introduced—a copper coin with
label: Paragraph

text: a hole in the middle so it could be strung
label: Paragraph

text: on a string. Shi Huangdi also connected the
label: Paragraph

text: existing defensive fortifications in the north
label: Title

text: of China to form the first Great Wall to fend
label: Paragraph

text: off invading “barbarians” from the north.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite these accomplishments, Shi Huangdi
label: Paragraph

text: was unpopular in his time; he raised taxes,
label: Paragraph

text: deprived the nobility of power, was ruthlessly
label: Paragraph

text: intolerant of those who opposed him, and
label: Paragraph

text: suppressed the writings of alternative
label: Title

text: philosophers. Although Shi Huangdi’s
label: Paragraph

text: short-lived dynasty was controversial, Qin
label: Paragraph

text: (pronounced “chin") is the origin of the
label: Paragraph

text: Western name China (“land of the Qin”). The
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese themselves referred to their domain
label: Paragraph

text: as the Middle Kingdom.

text: The ideal of a unified China, which was to
label: Paragraph

text: persist throughout Chinese history, can be
label: Paragraph

text: contrasted with the histories of South Asia
label: Paragraph

text: and Europe, where, even though emperors
label: Paragraph

text: were periodically able to conquer large
label: Paragraph

text: territories, the idea of a single, unified empire
label: Paragraph

text: was always keenly contested. It was only as
label: Paragraph

text: a consequence of European colonialism in
label: Paragraph

text: the 18th and 19th centuries that India, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, became a single nation.
label: Paragraph

text: The Qin capital, Xianyang, about 28
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers west of present-day Xi’an,
label: Paragraph

text: was built in a very unusual manner as a
label: Paragraph

text: microcosm of the Chinese empire. Each
label: Paragraph

text: time the Qin conquered a warring state, the
label: Paragraph

text: palace of the enemy was destroyed, and
label: Paragraph

text: a replica was built on the northern bank
label: Paragraph

text: of the Wei River, facing the new palace to
label: Paragraph

text: the south. These replica palaces were then
label: Paragraph

text: connected by covered walkways and filled
label: Paragraph

text: with musicians and singing women from
label: Title

text: the vanquished states. The emperor also
label: Paragraph

text: resettled over one hundred thousand people
label: Title

text: from these conquered states to Xianyang.
label: Paragraph

text: This policy was meant to reduce the
label: Paragraph

text: possibility of rebellion by placing dangerous
label: Title

text: elements within the purview of the emperor.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the Qin palaces were destroyed in
label: Paragraph

text: dynastic wars, they are described extensively
label: Paragraph

text: in the literature, and excavations in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 1970s discovered that these palaces are
label: Paragraph

text: quite similar to those descriptions. One of
label: Paragraph

text: the most impressive was the palace of Qin
label: Paragraph

text: Shi Huangdi himself. It seems to have been
label: Paragraph

text: Fas China Sea
label: Title

text: a two-level structure, with the upper level
label: Paragraph

text: imposingly raised 6 meters above the lower.
label: Paragraph

text: The upper level is L-shaped and extends 60
label: Paragraph

text: meters east to west and 45 meters north to
label: Paragraph

text: south. At its center was the principal hall,
label: Paragraph

text: with a large pillar right at its midpoint. A
label: Paragraph

text: smaller hall to the southeast is thought to
label: Paragraph

text: have been the emperor's residence. The L
label: Paragraph

text: shape suggests that another, similar complex
label: Paragraph

text: was to be syrnmetrically placed to the east.
label: Paragraph

text: According to a description:
label: Paragraph

text: [He] had palaces constructed in the Shanglin
label: Paragraph

text: Gardens, south of the Wei River. The front
label: Caption

text: palace, Epang, was built first.... The terraces
label: Paragraph

text: above could seat 10,000, and below there
label: Paragraph

text: was room for banners [20 meters] in height.
label: Paragraph

text: One causeway round the palace led to the
label: Paragraph

text: South Hill, at the top of which a gateway was
label: Paragraph

text: erected. A second led across the Wei River to
label: Paragraph

text: [the capital]*
label: Title

text: When Shi Huangdi died, his ambitious
label: Paragraph

text: building program in Xianyang had not been
label: Paragraph

text: completed. The Han dynasty then proceeded
label: Paragraph

text: to destroy it.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Tomb of the First Emperor
label: Title

text: The Tomb of the First Emperor is located in
label: Paragraph

text: Lishan, just south of Xi’an. Sited on a plain
label: Paragraph

text: with a wall of mountains framing its southern
label: Paragraph

text: view, it is probably the largest and most costly
label: Paragraph

text: tomb in history, even cornpared with the
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian pyramids. Its outer perimeter wall,
label: Paragraph

text: 6 meters thick and constructed of rammed
label: Paragraph

text: earth, encloses an area of approximately
label: Paragraph

text: 2 square kilometers. The main entrance is
label: Paragraph

text: on the east. Within the perimeter there was
label: Paragraph

text: a second walled enclosure with four more
label: Paragraph

text: gates, one on each of the four sides.
label: Paragraph

text: Outside the eastern entrance,
label: Paragraph

text: archaeologists have uncovered more than
label: Paragraph

text: 8,000 life-size terra-cotta figures, grouped
label: Caption

text: in battle order, rank by rank, some mounted
label: Paragraph

text: on horse-drawn chariots, others in infantry
label: Paragraph

text: groups armed with spears, swords, and
label: Paragraph

text: crossbows {although the spear shafts, bows,
label: Paragraph

text: and other wooden objects have decayed
label: Paragraph

text: away). Vault no. 1 is the largest, measuring
label: Paragraph

text: 60 by 210 meters. In eleven parallel trenches
label: Caption

text: there are over 3,000 terra-cotta foot soldiers
label: Paragraph

text: arranged as an infantry regiment, facing away
label: Paragraph

text: from the emperor's tomb. In the eastern
label: Caption

text: gallery are bowmen and crossbowmen in a
label: Caption

text: formation of three rows, making a total of
label: Paragraph

text: almost 200 sharpshooters. Most were armed
label: Paragraph

text: with actual crossbows with a range of 200
label: Paragraph

text: meters. Archaeologists once believed that
label: Paragraph

text: each warrior had individual traits—that they
label: Paragraph

text: were portraits of the emperor's guard of
label: Paragraph

text: honor—but it now seems that there are about
label: Paragraph

text: one hundred different types of faces.
label: Paragraph

text: Vault no. 2 contains a formation of chariots
label: Caption

text: and cavalry with supporting troops, all turned
label: Paragraph

text: toward the east. There are 1,430 warriors and
label: Paragraph

text: horses divided into four groups. Vault no. 3
label: Caption

text: seems to be the headquarters of the terra-
label: Paragraph

text: cotta army, with a commander along with 68
label: Paragraph

text: officers. This vast buried army was meant to
label: Paragraph

text: accompany the emperor in death and protect
label: Title

text: him. Other vaults contain acrobats, musicians,
label: Paragraph

text: and craftsmen.
label: Paragraph

text: The 76-meter-high mound remains
label: Paragraph

text: unexcavated but recent tests have shown that
label: Paragraph

text: it is a building of extraordinary dimension and
label: Paragraph

text: design, covered completely over by tons of
label: Paragraph

text: earth. The building consists of two bracket-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped structures of rammed earth that
label: Paragraph

text: tower over a large central room that serves
label: Paragraph

text: as the tomb chamber. The Shiji contains a
label: Paragraph

text: description of this burial monument. For a
label: Caption

text: long tire it was thought to be an exaggeration,
label: Paragraph

text: but now seems to be quite plausible:

text: 6.72 Construction of the Great Wall during the Warring States period, the Qin dynasty, and the Han dynasty
label: Caption

text: Great Wall of China
label: Title

text: The empire created by Shi Huangdi had few
label: Paragraph

text: serious enemies to its south, and to the west,
label: Paragraph

text: the enormous Taklamakan Desert served
label: Paragraph

text: as an impediment to all but the hardiest
label: Paragraph

text: of traders. But to the north, the nomadic
label: Paragraph

text: Mongol tribes were, for the Qin and Han
label: Paragraph

text: dynasties, the quintessential “barbarians.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Mongols’ skill with horses gave them a
label: Paragraph

text: military advantage that would, under Chengiz
label: Paragraph

text: (Ghengis) Khan, not only yield China to them
label: Paragraph

text: but indeed take them to the very doors of
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. The Chinese response to the Mongol
label: Paragraph

text: threat was to reach for a radical option that
label: Paragraph

text: could only be mounted by a highly organized
label: Paragraph

text: empire—the creation of a vast defensive
label: Title

text: wall, the wanti gangqeng (10,000-li-long
label: Paragraph

text: wall), popularly called the Great Wall. Small
label: Paragraph

text: segments had been constructed along the
label: Paragraph

text: northern frontier in the Warring States period
label: Title

text: under the Zhou, but Shi Huangdi conceived
label: Paragraph

text: of connecting and extending these segments,
label: Paragraph

text: a work that would be continued by the Han
label: Paragraph

text: emperors. The resulting fortification is not a
label: Paragraph

text: single continuous structure but a network of
label: Paragraph

text: walls and towers.
label: Paragraph

text: Most of the Qin and Han sections of the
label: Paragraph

text: Great Wall were made of pounded earth and
label: Paragraph

text: paved with stones. Some parts, however,
label: Paragraph

text: were made of Chinese tamarisk and reeds
label: Paragraph

text: that were arranged in a checkerboard pattern
label: Paragraph

text: and then filled in with sand and stone. While
label: Paragraph

text: much of the ancient wall of Shi Huangdi
label: Paragraph

text: has disappeared, most of what was built in
label: Paragraph

text: the Ming dynasty (1368-1644), following
label: Paragraph

text: a route different from that of Shi Huangdi’s
label: Paragraph

text: fortifications, survives today.
label: Paragraph

text: To maintain its integrity, the Great Wall was
label: Paragraph

text: constantly patrolled, and signal systems
label: Paragraph

text: were set up to transmit messages from one
label: Paragraph

text: watchtower to another. It was, however, a
label: Paragraph

text: failed enterprise. Despite being repeatedly
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced, the Great Wall was easily
label: Paragraph

text: breached by northern nomadic civilizations,
label: Paragraph

text: many of which went on to establish
label: Paragraph

text: successful ruling dynasties in China, such
label: Paragraph

text: as the Jin, the Liao, the Yuan, and the Qing.
label: Paragraph

text: These supposedly “barbarian” dynasties, of
label: Paragraph

text: course, had less interest in reinforcing the
label: Paragraph

text: wall.
label: Paragraph

text: Extending from contemporary North
label: Title

text: Korea all the way to the Jade Gate in
label: Title

text: Gansu Province, the Great Wall had several
label: Paragraph

text: architectural components:
label: Title

text: * Border towns: Of varying shapes and sizes,
label: Paragraph

text: these towns were small and defensible, af
label: Paragraph

text: complete with moats, walls, streets,
label: Paragraph

text: wellings, and watchtowers.
label: Paragraph

text: * Fortifications: Small forts, 50 to 150 square
label: Title

text: meters in area and protected by moats and
label: Paragraph

text: high walls, served as military stations.
label: Paragraph

text: * Checkpoints: Two- to three-story
label: Title

text: watchtowers were built everywhere the wall
label: Paragraph

text: encountered intersections or was open to
label: Paragraph

text: movement.
label: Paragraph

text: * Beacon towers: Watchtowers on .
label: Caption

text: platforms, frorn which lookouts could spot
label: Paragraph

text: approaching enemies and alert adjacent
label: Title

text: towers by smoke signals, were located
label: Paragraph

text: about 130 meters apart. 6.73 View of the Great Wall of China

text: DEVELOPMENT OF MAHAYANA
label: Title

text: BUDDHISM
label: Title

text: Late in the 2nd century BCE, Asoka’s
label: Paragraph

text: Mauryan Empire began to disintegrate,
label: Paragraph

text: resulting in the formation of a series of
label: Paragraph

text: smaller kingdoms: the Sunga in the west, the
label: Paragraph

text: Satavahanas to the south, and in the north,
label: Paragraph

text: the Shakas. This transformation paralleled
label: Paragraph

text: an equally significant transformation within
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism that had important implications
label: Title

text: in the field of architecture. As originally
label: Paragraph

text: conceived, Buddhist monkhood was strictly
label: Paragraph

text: mendicant. Its members lived without
label: Paragraph

text: money and survived by begging; they
label: Paragraph

text: were not allowed to erect shrines, acquire
label: Paragraph

text: property, or deify the Buddha. This form
label: Paragraph

text: of Buddhism was subsequently referred to
label: Paragraph

text: as Hinayana (or the “Lesser Vehicle”). In
label: Paragraph

text: time, as Buddhism began to receive royal
label: Paragraph

text: patronage and its practitioners became more
label: Paragraph

text: diverse, a more monastic and populist form
label: Paragraph

text: of Buddhism, known as Mahayana (or the
label: Paragraph

text: “Greater Vehicle”) emerged that required the
label: Paragraph

text: establishment of institutions where monks
label: Title

text: could live and study.
label: Paragraph

text: The transformation can be tracked
label: Paragraph

text: through the four great Buddhist councils
label: Title

text: called to reconcile differences in
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation. King Ajatsatru convened the
label: Paragraph

text: first Buddhist council in the 5th century
label: Title

text: BCE, soon after the Buddha’s death, in
label: Paragraph

text: order to record the extant sayings of the
label: Paragraph

text: Buddha (sutras) and to codify the rules of
label: Paragraph

text: mendicancy. Continuing conflicts between
label: Paragraph

text: the Hinayana and Mahayana schools of
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism prompted the convening of the
label: Paragraph

text: second Buddhist council in 383 BCE, a third
label: Paragraph

text: in 250 BCE, and a fourth around 100 CE, at
label: Paragraph

text: which time three hundred thousand verses
label: Title

text: and over nine million statements were
label: Paragraph

text: compiled and written in Sanskrit. These
label: Paragraph

text: became the basis of Mahayana Buddhism,
label: Paragraph

text: which soon began to flourish and spread into
label: Paragraph

text: Central Asia, China, Korea, and Japan.
label: Paragraph

text: Significant parts of the Mahayana
label: Title

text: credo were articulated by Nagarjuna, the
label: Paragraph

text: 2nd-century Indian philosopher and the
label: Title

text: most influential Buddhist thinker after the
label: Paragraph

text: Buddha himself. Nagarjuna promoted what
label: Paragraph

text: is known as the Middle Path, a compromise
label: Paragraph

text: between the ascetic and the worldly sects
label: Title

text: of Buddhism. He argued that Asoka, as a
label: Paragraph

text: virtuous Buddhist king, was a cakravartin
label: Paragraph

text: and should thus be considered to have
label: Paragraph

text: direct access to nirvana, or Buddhahood.
label: Paragraph

text: Nagarjuna’s definition of kingship served as
label: Paragraph

text: a model for generations of rulers throughout
label: Paragraph

text: Asia, including the 18th-century Qing dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: emperor Qianlong and today's Dalai Lama.

text: Sanchi Complex
label: Title

text: The Buddhist sanctuary known as Sanchi
label: Paragraph

text: was founded by Asoka and flourished for
label: Paragraph

text: thirteen centuries. The complex is located
label: Paragraph

text: near the ancient town of Vidisa, along the
label: Paragraph

text: fertile river valleys of the southern trade route
label: Title

text: (or dakshinapatha). It is located on a hill
label: Paragraph

text: that rises sharply above the valley, making
label: Paragraph

text: its stupas distinctly visible from afar. The
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding hills are also surmounted by
label: Paragraph

text: stupas, all of which establish the area as a
label: Paragraph

text: sacred landscape. Originally the stupas were
label: Paragraph

text: plastered and painted, and on festival days
label: Paragraph

text: gaily decorated with flowers and other ritual
label: Paragraph

text: offerings. Large groups of visiting monks and
label: Paragraph

text: laity alike came to Sanchi in processions.
label: Paragraph

text: Stupas started out as reliquary mounds, or
label: Paragraph

text: caityas, which can denote any sacred place—
label: Paragraph

text: such as where a funeral pyre or consecration
label: Paragraph

text: had occurred; they were usually marked off
label: Paragraph

text: by a wooden railing. Asoka had the Buddha’s
label: Paragraph

text: bodily remains divided into eight parts and
label: Paragraph

text: distributed throughout his empire as relics,
label: Paragraph

text: with their locations marked by ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: mounds (stupa means “piled up”).
label: Paragraph

text: 6.75 Stupa II at Sanchi, near Bhopal, India
label: Caption

text: Built by the thousands, stupas became the
label: Paragraph

text: dominant symbol of Buddhism. Conceptually,
label: Paragraph

text: a stupa is a cosmological diagrarn linking
label: Paragraph

text: the body of the Buddha to the universe.
label: Paragraph

text: The fundamental elements of a stupa are
label: Paragraph

text: present in the oldest of Sanchi’s stupas,
label: Paragraph

text: Stupa II (ca. 100 BCE). The central mass
label: Caption

text: consists of an earthen hemispherical mound
label: Paragraph

text: faced with fired bricks, with a shallow berm
label: Paragraph

text: (or medhi) ringing its base. This round
label: Paragraph

text: structure is then surrounded by a stone
label: Paragraph

text: balustrade (or vedika) that replicates a
label: Paragraph

text: construction out of wood. Both the interior
label: Caption

text: and exterior surface of the vedika are
label: Paragraph

text: carved with shallow reliefs and medallions
label: Caption

text: depicting scenes and events of Budchist
label: Paragraph

text: significance. The vedika has openings on
label: Paragraph

text: four sides, aligned to the cardinal directions.
label: Paragraph

text: These are accessed not on axis, however,
label: Paragraph

text: but at right angles, through entrances whose
label: Paragraph

text: openings face counterclockwise. The cross-
label: Paragraph

text: axis of the cardinal directions, coupled with
label: Paragraph

text: the directional openings, form a space-
label: Paragraph

text: time cosmological diagram, or mandala,
label: Paragraph

text: in the form of a svastika (or “swastika”).
label: Paragraph

text: The directions represent space, and the
label: Paragraph

text: entrances, replicating the movement of the
label: Paragraph

text: stars, represent time. The purpose of the
label: Paragraph

text: vedika is to also give spatial definition to the
label: Paragraph

text: ritual counterclockwise circumambulation of
label: Title

text: parikrama. A Buddhist monk, or a pilgrim,
label: Paragraph

text: in performing the parikrama, engages in
label: Paragraph

text: a haptic reenactment of the fundamental
label: Title

text: order of space and time, and in the process,
label: Paragraph

text: brings his or her body into harmony with that
label: Paragraph

text: larger order. In Buddhism, as in Hinduism,
label: Paragraph

text: parikrama, along with the mandala and the
label: Paragraph

text: svastika (unrelated to its Nazi appropriation),
label: Paragraph

text: are still fundamental to architectural
label: Paragraph

text: expression.
label: Paragraph

text: Stupa |, known as Mahastupa, or Great
label: Paragraph

text: Stupa, is essentially a magnification of Stupa
label: Paragraph

text: Il in plan and has a diameter of 36 meters.
label: Paragraph

text: An Asoka pillar defines its southern entrance.
label: Paragraph

text: At the top of the stupa is another vedika—
label: Paragraph

text: the harmika—that is inaccessible and serves
label: Paragraph

text: only symbolic purposes. In the middle of the
label: Paragraph

text: harmika is a finial, with three stone discs of
label: Paragraph

text: iminishing size, called chattris, balanced on
label: Paragraph

text: a columnar support. The harmika and the
label: Paragraph

text: chattris collectively denote the stupa’s vertical
label: Paragraph

text: axis, echoing Asoka’s pillar and completing
label: Paragraph

text: the casmic connections of the stupa. The
label: Paragraph

text: other innovation at the Mahastupa are the
label: Paragraph

text: monumental stone gateways called toranas.
label: Paragraph

text: he foranas, imitating wooden construction,
label: Paragraph

text: consist of two vertical pillars supporting
label: Paragraph

text: three horizontal bars that are slightly bent at
label: Paragraph

text: their center and that project well beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: posts. The beams end in volutes that connote
label: Paragraph

text: the sacred scrolls, the treasured objects of
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddhist sanghas. Like the vedikas,
label: Paragraph

text: the surfaces of the foranas are elaborately
label: Paragraph

text: lecorated, depicting Buddhist themes and
label: Paragraph

text: events, completing the classic stupa as we
label: Paragraph

text: know it.

text: Sanchi enjoyed extensive patronage and grew

label: Paragraph

text: structures where the monks lived. Over time,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: complex. The more important the person
label: Paragraph

text: whose relics were contained in a stupa, the
label: Paragraph

text: closer that stupa was to the Mahastupa.
label: Paragraph

text: (During excavation in the mid-19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: most of these relics were removed.)
label: Paragraph

text: The Hindus also recognized this site as
label: Paragraph

text: important, and one of the oldest Hindu
label: Paragraph

text: stone temples—from the 4th century CE—is
label: Paragraph

text: found there, close to the southern entrance
label: Paragraph

text: of the Mahastupa. A relief on the northern
label: Caption

text: torana of the Mahastupa depicts a large
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial procession, complete with
label: Paragraph

text: musical instruments and offerings and led by
label: Title

text: elephants, on its way to the Mahastupa. One
label: Paragraph

text: has to imagine Sanchi thus—not as a remote
label: Paragraph

text: monastery populated by mendicant Buddhist
label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: extensive contact and communication.

text: Junnar Caves
label: Title

text: Rock-cut architecture has a venerable history
label: Paragraph

text: dating back to the Egyptians and Abu Simbel
label: Paragraph

text: (1264 BCE). It was a key architectural method
label: Paragraph

text: in West Asia. The Lycians in Anatolia were
label: Paragraph

text: also its masters, as were the architects in
label: Paragraph

text: Petra. It was used for the first time in India
label: Paragraph

text: around 250 BCE, and it is quite likely that
label: Paragraph

text: the technique travelled there along the trade
label: Paragraph

text: routes. But whereas Lomas Rsi Cave in the
label: Paragraph

text: Barabar Hills (ca. 300 BCE) was an open
label: Paragraph

text: cavity, the new caves were of two types: a
label: Paragraph

text: caitya, or meditation hall, consisting of an
label: Paragraph

text: apsidal hall focused on a stupa, and a vihara,
label: Paragraph

text: or living quarter, consisting of a number of
label: Paragraph

text: cells organized around a rectilinear, columnar
label: Paragraph

text: court. By the Ist century BCE, rock-cut
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist architecture became increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate in concept and execution. Such
label: Paragraph

text: structures were excavated all over South
label: Paragraph

text: Asia, but in particular in the passes of the
label: Paragraph

text: Western Ghats, a mountain chain in western
label: Paragraph

text: India running some 45 to 90 kilometers
label: Title

text: inland from the Arabian Sea. Their purpose
label: Paragraph

text: was not remoteness, however, but rather to
label: Paragraph

text: be close to the trade routes—and indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: it was along the trade routes that a growing
label: Paragraph

text: culture of Buddhist sites arose. The largest
label: Paragraph

text: concentrations of caves are in Bhaja and
label: Paragraph

text: Pitalkhora in western India. Because they are
label: Paragraph

text: man-made, rock-cut structures, they should
label: Paragraph

text: not actually be called caves, but this is how
label: Paragraph

text: they are often referred to in India.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: or Buddhist pilgrimage site, probably with
label: Paragraph

text: some temporary wood structures for visitors.

text: At the turn of the millennium, Central
label: Paragraph

text: America was dominated by the Zapotecs,
label: Paragraph

text: who had replaced the Olmecs, now in serious
label: Paragraph

text: decline. In the Yucatan Peninsula, in the
label: Paragraph

text: meantime, the Mayan culture had begun to
label: Paragraph

text: take root, developing monumental platform-
label: Paragraph

text: and-pyramid complexes in the Mirador
label: Paragraph

text: asin and Tikal. At the edges of these great
label: Paragraph

text: civilizations, in the high lake valleys of
label: Paragraph

text: western Mexico, we find a relatively minor but
label: Paragraph

text: fascinating civilization at Teuchitlan, around
label: Paragraph

text: the slopes of the extinct volcano Tequila. The
label: Paragraph

text: remains today consist of funerary shaft tombs
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied by corresponding surface-
label: Paragraph

text: evel ritual architecture created as integral
label: Paragraph

text: parts of small chieftain settlements, the
label: Paragraph

text: largest of which probably had about twenty
label: Paragraph

text: to thirty thousand inhabitants. Though burial
label: Paragraph

text: chambers were a constant in western Mexico,
label: Paragraph

text: significant here is that no pyramids or images
label: Paragraph

text: of the usual deities have been found. The
label: Paragraph

text: origin of this particular culture and the
label: Paragraph

text: reasons for their autonomous architectural
label: Title

text: development are not well understood. Ancient
label: Paragraph

text: West Mexico (edited by Richard Townsend)
label: Caption

text: contains some of the more recent studies.

text: For the residents of Teuchitlan, funerary
label: Paragraph

text: tombs had a critical part in establishing
label: Paragraph

text: the connection between the living and their
label: Title

text: ancestors. They were used by hereditary
label: Paragraph

text: chieftains and their families and became the
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic center of the society’s communal
label: Paragraph

text: life. The earliest type of tombs (1500-
label: Paragraph

text: 800 BCE) consisted of a round opening
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by a low platform, frorn which a
label: Paragraph

text: short, stepped passage led into the mortuary
label: Caption

text: chamber. Such small tombs from all periods
label: Paragraph

text: are found everywhere in western Mexico.
label: Paragraph

text: Little is known of the tombs from the period
label: Paragraph

text: between 800 and 300 BCE, since none have
label: Paragraph

text: been scientifically excavated, although tombs
label: Paragraph

text: are found throughout the lake-basin district.

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Of the shaft tombs of the period between
label: Paragraph

text: 300 BCE and 200 CE, the largest, at El
label: Paragraph

text: Arenal, has an 18-meter shaft and three
label: Paragraph

text: burial chambers. Two other shaft tombs are
label: Paragraph

text: located within the same ceremonial area.
label: Paragraph

text: On the surface, the shaft emerged at the
label: Paragraph

text: center of a circular stepped mound that was
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by an elevated circular patio, at
label: Paragraph

text: the edge of which were eight to twelve evenly
label: Paragraph

text: spaced rectangular platforms. Made of rubble
label: Paragraph

text: and packed earth, the larger complexes of
label: Paragraph

text: the later phase (300-800 CE) range from 28
label: Paragraph

text: meters in diameter at Potrero de las Chivas
label: Caption

text: to well over 100 meters at Guachimonton,
label: Paragraph

text: the largest of the Teuchitlan ritual sites. The
label: Paragraph

text: circles were often found in groups of two or
label: Paragraph

text: three, with some of the circles overlapping.
label: Paragraph

text: Ball courts were also found in association
label: Paragraph

text: with these circles. Later, in the period from
label: Paragraph

text: 300 to 800 CE, shaft tombs became less
label: Paragraph

text: important, and huge surface circles, along
label: Paragraph

text: with ball courts, came to dominate the
label: Paragraph

text: construction, to the point that their burial
label: Paragraph

text: chambers are as yet undiscovered.

text: Clay models found with the offerings

text: testify to the self-consciousness of the

label: Title

text: The Mayan civilization, initially centered
label: Paragraph

text: on the coastlines of Guatemala and El
label: Title

text: Salvador, spread northward between 250,
label: Paragraph

text: and 900 CE into the Yucatan Peninsula.
label: Paragraph

text: At its peak, it was one of the most densely
label: Paragraph

text: populated and culturally dynamic societies
label: Title

text: in the world. Many of the pre-classical sites
label: Paragraph

text: declined by the 3rd century CE, leaving the
label: Paragraph

text: cities in northern Guatemala dominant. The
label: Paragraph

text: Mayas developed a religious philosophy
label: Paragraph

text: controlled by a professional priesthood built
label: Paragraph

text: around the importance of astronomical
label: Title

text: manifestations that were part of the eternal
label: Paragraph

text: struggle between the powers of good and
label: Title

text: evil. The benevolent gods brought thunder,
label: Paragraph

text: lightning, and rain, and insured abundance,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas the malevolent ones brought death,
label: Paragraph

text: destruction, hurricanes, and war. The religion
label: Paragraph

text: developed into a worship of time in its various
label: Paragraph

text: manifestations; it was highly esoteric in
label: Paragraph

text: nature, requiring priests, rathernaticians,
label: Paragraph

text: and prophets. Dancing was an important
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of religious ceremonies, as was the
label: Paragraph

text: giving of sacrifices. These ranged from food
label: Paragraph

text: offerings and ornaments (like feathers and
label: Paragraph

text: shells) to the practice of human sacrifice.
label: Paragraph

text: This specialized production and
label: Paragraph

text: dependency on foreign trade might have
label: Paragraph

text: been the reason for both the success and the
label: Paragraph

text: eventual demise of the Mayas. Trees were
label: Paragraph

text: felled to fuel the kilns in which limestone was
label: Paragraph

text: burned. Deforestation, it has been suggested,
label: Paragraph

text: led to a gradual erosion of both land and
label: Paragraph

text: wealth. By 350 BCE, a centralized elite was
label: Paragraph

text: able to control large labor populations whose
label: Paragraph

text: rapid rate of production was aided by the
label: Paragraph

text: development of standardized construction
label: Title

text: modules and faster stonecutting techniques.
label: Paragraph

text: It is during this period that monumental
label: Paragraph

text: Mayan architecture—at a scale never
label: Title

text: seen previously—emerged in the Yucatan
label: Paragraph

text: Peninsula. An abundance of massive
label: Paragraph

text: architectural assemblages, ranging from 40
label: Paragraph

text: to 72 meters high, are found in the Mirador
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: all the major building groups were raised on
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Located in the Petén region of Guatemala,
label: Paragraph

text: habitation at Nakbe started around 1400 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: reaching its height between 600 and
label: Paragraph

text: 350 BCE. Its central area was constructed on
label: Paragraph

text: a massive man-made platform surmounted
label: Paragraph

text: by three mounds. The mounds contained
label: Paragraph

text: clusters of temples, with the tallest structure,
label: Paragraph

text: at 50 meters, on the west platform; the one
label: Paragraph

text: on the east platform was 30 meters high.
label: Paragraph

text: Nakbe was linked by causeways made of
label: Paragraph

text: white crushed rock to adjoining settlements,
label: Paragraph

text: including the one at El Mirador, its rival to the
label: Paragraph

text: north.
label: Paragraph

text: In general, the organization of early
label: Paragraph

text: Mayan ceremonial complexes was devoted to
label: Paragraph

text: creating distinct visual hierarchies by means
label: Paragraph

text: of a system of interconnected raised platform
label: Paragraph

text: terraces surmounted by ternples. The central
label: Caption

text: ceremonial complex at Nakbe consists of
label: Paragraph

text: two major, connected, built-up platforms (the
label: Paragraph

text: eastern one 32 meters high, and the western
label: Paragraph

text: one 45 meters high), on top of which the
label: Paragraph

text: principal structures are clustered.
label: Paragraph

text: The eastern platform has two parts. One
label: Paragraph

text: is a cluster of low-platform structures on a
label: Paragraph

text: terrace, creating a court that is anchored on
label: Paragraph

text: its west side by a large freestanding pyramid.
label: Paragraph

text: The other part has a larger pyramid, which
label: Paragraph

text: is visible from the court, but whose access
label: Paragraph

text: was restricted to priestly use. Thus a complex
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial whole was forrmed—with multiple
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchically organized spatial and visual
label: Title

text: centers—that was used for a variety of
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial functions.
label: Paragraph

text: Across the causeway is the western
label: Paragraph

text: platform, which consists of three terraced
label: Paragraph

text: courtyards, the highest of which supports the
label: Paragraph

text: large pyramid; as with the others, access is
label: Paragraph

text: restricted through the small courtyard in front
label: Paragraph

text: of it. Since the function of Mayan pyramids
label: Paragraph

text: was to support the temple, they were always
label: Paragraph

text: flat-topped. The pyramid itself consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: tightly cornpressed layers of stones and clay
label: Paragraph

text: sealed by a brick casing.

text: El Mirador
label: Title

text: Just north of Nakbe, El Mirador (Spanish
label: Caption

text: or “lookout”) was an early Mayan city that
label: Paragraph

text: reached its cultural high point between
label: Paragraph

text: 150 BCE and 150 CE. Though the city
label: Paragraph

text: was spread out over an area of 16 square
label: Paragraph

text: ilometers, the center was a crowded
label: Paragraph

text: constellation of sacred and secular buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Here the platforms have been built up
label: Paragraph

text: successively over time, comprising the largest
label: Paragraph

text: set of platforrns found anywhere in the
label: Paragraph

text: Mayan world. The entire site was dominated
label: Paragraph

text: y the so-called El Tigre, a gigantic building
label: Paragraph

text: complex covering 5.6 hectares, in which the
label: Paragraph

text: emerging Mayan typology of the triple-surnmit
label: Paragraph

text: structures can be seen. These generally
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of a steep platform mountain
label: Paragraph

text: having at its summit two smaller buildings
label: Paragraph

text: facing each other in front of an axially placed
label: Paragraph

text: stepped pyramid temple. Archaeologists
label: Caption

text: believed that this arrangernent represented
label: Paragraph

text: the three stars in the constellation of Orion—
label: Title

text: known as Alnitak, Saiph, and Ligel—within
label: Paragraph

text: which was supposed to burn the fire of
label: Paragraph

text: creation.

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: In the year 200 CE, Rome, Chang'an, and
label: Paragraph

text: Teotihuacan were the world's megacities; all
label: Paragraph

text: three were the capitals of vast empires. Cities
label: Paragraph

text: at this scale impacted the world even in far-
label: Paragraph

text: off places. They required an extensive trade
label: Paragraph

text: in luxury items, with everything embedded in
label: Paragraph

text: a system of revenue production, collection,
label: Paragraph

text: and control, not to mention an army and
label: Paragraph

text: territorial mastery. Above all, there had to be
label: Paragraph

text: an imperial awe. And in this respect, the idea
label: Paragraph

text: of “tradition” in both Rome and China was
label: Paragraph

text: not a phenomenon emerging naturally over
label: Paragraph

text: time. It had to be enforced and re-enforced
label: Paragraph

text: from the top down, against the rising tide of
label: Paragraph

text: social and economic transformations.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 100 and 300 CE, the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Empire in particular grew into one of the
label: Paragraph

text: greatest and most extensive empires in
label: Title

text: the world. For centuries, it had traded with
label: Paragraph

text: the Celts to the north, mainly exchanging
label: Paragraph

text: metals for Roman wine, but once Rome had
label: Paragraph

text: conquered the Celts and Romanized them,
label: Paragraph

text: the Romans discovered that the Germanic
label: Paragraph

text: tribes to the east were much more difficult
label: Paragraph

text: to pacify. The expansion of the territory
label: Paragraph

text: paid off, however, in the short term. Wealth
label: Paragraph

text: was lavished on temples, palaces, baths,
label: Paragraph

text: aqueducts, libraries, courts, streets, theaters,
label: Paragraph

text: and amphitheaters. The development of
label: Paragraph

text: Roman architecture, the most extensive
label: Paragraph

text: urban architecture of any civilization to that
label: Paragraph

text: date, reached from England to North Africa
label: Paragraph

text: and from Spain to the Levant, and would
label: Paragraph

text: have a profound impact on subsequent
label: Paragraph

text: developments throughout Europe and beyond
label: Title

text: for centuries to come. The Han dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: in China was also building cities, palaces,
label: Paragraph

text: and tombs on a massive scale, helped by
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable advances in technology and
label: Title

text: mining. But because their architecture was
label: Paragraph

text: all built out of wood and tamped earth,
label: Paragraph

text: comparatively little has survived the ages.
label: Paragraph

text: Their western capital, Chang'an, served as
label: Paragraph

text: the Silk Route’s eastern terminus.
label: Paragraph

text: Both Rome and China, in facing the
label: Paragraph

text: rapid changes that came with expansion
label: Title

text: and cross-cultural contact, came to place
label: Paragraph

text: strong counter-emphasis on tradition, which
label: Paragraph

text: was instrumentalized as a condition of state
label: Paragraph

text: control. Traditions were promulgated and
label: Paragraph

text: enforced as a way to define the principle of
label: Paragraph

text: stability. Augustus, the first emperor, claimed
label: Paragraph

text: that he needed to create an empire precisely
label: Paragraph

text: to restore Roman tradition to its former
label: Paragraph

text: glory. And in China, tradition was imposed
label: Paragraph

text: and self-imposed on the Chinese through
label: Paragraph

text: Confucianism, which promoted security and
label: Paragraph

text: predictability for the elites.
label: Paragraph

text: Linking China and Rome were the
label: Paragraph

text: Parthians, a horse-based tribal society of
label: Paragraph

text: former nomads who established themselves
label: Title

text: as a ruling elite in Mesopotamia and Central
label: Paragraph

text: Asia. Since they were not an architecture-
label: Paragraph

text: oriented culture, they allowed local cults to
label: Paragraph

text: continue. But they were keen traders and
label: Paragraph

text: played an important part in maintaining
label: Paragraph

text: the Silk Route; their capital, Hecatompylos,
