text: became one of its prime stopping places.
label: Paragraph

text: The Parthians eventually lost control of the
label: Paragraph

text: lranian highlands to a new lineage that
label: Paragraph

text: came to be known as the Sassanians, who
label: Paragraph

text: unified their control under the heading of
label: Paragraph

text: Zoroastrianism. They built numerous cities,
label: Paragraph

text: many of them circular, presumably to give the
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants a defensive tactical advantage.
label: Paragraph

text: Among these was Firuzabad, built under
label: Paragraph

text: Ardashir | (r. 224-42 Ce). It had a diameter
label: Paragraph

text: of 2 kilometers, with two roads dividing it
label: Paragraph

text: into four districts, which in turn were divided
label: Paragraph

text: into five smaller sectors and thus ordered
label: Paragraph

text: the entire city in twenty sectors. The detailed
label: Paragraph

text: planning seems to have continued in the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding landscape. The Sassanians
label: Paragraph

text: also built enormous citadels, such as the
label: Paragraph

text: Falak-ol-Aflak Castle (226-651 CE), situated
label: Paragraph

text: on the top of a large hill within the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Khorramabad, Iran. This gigantic structure
label: Paragraph

text: measured approximately 300 by 400 meters
label: Paragraph

text: and had twelve towers and massive walls.
label: Paragraph

text: The religious innovations taking place
label: Title

text: in various parts of Eurasia, in combination
label: Paragraph

text: with the cross-Asian circulatory system
label: Paragraph

text: that was now abuzz with traffic, led to
label: Paragraph

text: important transformations in western Asia
label: Title

text: with long-term ramifications beyond its
label: Paragraph

text: immediate geographical range. The old
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamian religions with their complex
label: Title

text: pantheons were superseded by Hellenistic
label: Paragraph

text: and Iranian mystery cults, by sun cults,
label: Paragraph

text: by Zoroastrianism’s fire worship—and by
label: Paragraph

text: Christianity, itself an outgrowth of Hellenistic
label: Paragraph

text: sensibilities. Generally, these new religious
label: Paragraph

text: practices were more personal than their
label: Paragraph

text: forerunners. Another emerging religion,
label: Paragraph

text: Mithraism, was increasingly practiced
label: Paragraph

text: by the soldiery in the far-flung provinces
label: Paragraph

text: of the Roman Empire and would impact
label: Paragraph

text: Christianity. Buddhism, which has to be
label: Paragraph

text: understood as part of this search for ethical
label: Paragraph

text: self-transformation, was also developing
label: Paragraph

text: rapidly, moving deeper and deeper into China
label: Paragraph

text: and Southeast Asia in the form of monastic
label: Paragraph

text: schools located along the trade routes.
label: Paragraph

text: In Central Asia, the nomadic Yueh-chi
label: Paragraph

text: from Mongolia established the Kushan
label: Paragraph

text: Empire (1st century BCE to 3rd century CE)
label: Title

text: that stretched from parts of Afghanistan and
label: Paragraph

text: lran to Pataliputra in the central Gangetic
label: Title

text: Plains in the east and down to Sanchi in the
label: Paragraph

text: south, the location of the greatest Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuary of the time. Though nomadic,
label: Paragraph

text: they quickly adopted the typical cross-Asian
label: Paragraph

text: organization of society, where they, as the
label: Paragraph

text: aristocratic warrior class, were on top. Below
label: Paragraph

text: them were the merchants, and below the
label: Paragraph

text: merchants were the artisans and peasants.
label: Paragraph

text: The Kushans understood the uniqueness
label: Paragraph

text: of their geographical location in the former
label: Paragraph

text: Graeco-Bactrian world. They had three
label: Paragraph

text: basic agendas: to actively promote trade
label: Title

text: along the Silk Route; to promote artisanal
label: Paragraph

text: Dunhuang
label: Title

text: or
label: Title

text: MONGOLIA
label: Title

text: * Han Empire
label: Title

text: i
label: Title

text: production of luxury goods; and finally, to
label: Paragraph

text: promote the expansion of agriculture in the
label: Paragraph

text: otherwise mountainous and arid lands. India
label: Paragraph

text: exported spices like pepper, ginger, and
label: Paragraph

text: saffron, as well as sugar, dyes, perfumes,
label: Paragraph

text: and gems. Trade was a hugely lucrative
label: Paragraph

text: business for Kushans, who augmented
label: Paragraph

text: this with commodities that they produced,
label: Paragraph

text: like bronze, tin, and glassware. The new
label: Paragraph

text: rulers also developed local industries like
label: Paragraph

text: silversmithing for jewelry and ironsmithing for
label: Title

text: weapons. And finally, they made miles and
label: Paragraph

text: miles of canals to irrigate mountain slopes
label: Title

text: and valleys. One of these is the Zang Canal,
label: Paragraph

text: located in Surxondaryo, Uzbekistan, which
label: Paragraph

text: drew water from Surkhan River. There were
label: Paragraph

text: similar canals along the Amu Darya. The
label: Paragraph

text: water irrigated the vineyards the Kushans
label: Paragraph

text: planted, as wine, the drink of the Greeks,
label: Paragraph

text: was now an important luxury export to India.
label: Paragraph

text: This astonishing burst of activity, far from
label: Paragraph

text: the traditional centers of civilization, resulted
label: Paragraph

text: in an empire that was unique. It became a
label: Paragraph

text: melting pot for people and ideas from India,
label: Paragraph

text: Persia, China, and even the Roman Empire.
label: Paragraph

text: At first the Kushans absorbed the
label: Paragraph

text: remnants of the Greek culture of the
label: Title

text: Hellenistic kingdoms, becoming at least partly
label: Paragraph

text: Hellenized. They even spoke Greek. Some
label: Paragraph

text: of the elites adopted Zoroastrianism from
label: Paragraph

text: the Persians, others embraced some form of
label: Paragraph

text: Hinduism, and yet others became Buddhist.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas their first coins depict the Kushans
label: Paragraph

text: dressed in heavy coats and big felt hats
label: Title

text: appropriate to the steppe, later coins show
label: Paragraph

text: them dressed in Greek togas or lightweight
label: Paragraph

text: tunics. The first documented translation
label: Paragraph

text: efforts by foreign Buddhist monks in China
label: Title

text: were in the 2nd century CE, probably as a
label: Paragraph

text: consequence of the expansion of the Kushan
label: Paragraph

text: Empire into the Chinese territory of the Tarim
label: Title

text: Basin. Their most lasting contributions to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture were the stupas that they began
label: Paragraph

text: to erect along the trade routes. Few have
label: Paragraph

text: survived, but the Kanishka Stupa—built for
label: Paragraph

text: anishka | (ca. 127-40 Ce}—on the outskirts
label: Paragraph

text: of today’s Peshawar, Pakistan, was described
label: Paragraph

text: y Chinese pilgrims in the 7th century as
label: Paragraph

text: the tallest stupa in all of India. It rose to
label: Paragraph

text: about 200 meters and contained three bone
label: Paragraph

text: ragment relics of the Buddha, which have
label: Paragraph

text: now been transferred to Mandalay, Myanmar
label: Paragraph

text: (Burma). Only a sturip remains of the
label: Paragraph

text: original building. Hans Loeschner suggests
label: Caption

text: that it might have appeared similar to the
label: Paragraph

text: stone relief from Butkara III in Swat Valley,
label: Caption

text: which shows a stupa placed on a tall square
label: Caption

text: base. In the corners there are four pillars with
label: Paragraph

text: lions at the top, similar to many of the Ashoka
label: Paragraph

text: pillar with lion capitals, such as the one at
label: Paragraph

text: Vaisali, India.
label: Caption

text: One of the major impediments on the Silk
label: Paragraph

text: Route was the Taklamakan Desert, a vast oval
label: Paragraph

text: desert surrounded by mountains. However,
label: Paragraph

text: rivers running down from the mountains
label: Title

text: provided enough water for caravans to move
label: Paragraph

text: around the edges of the desert from one
label: Paragraph

text: oasis to another. One of these was Khotan,
label: Paragraph

text: the center of a small kingdom. The Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrim Xuanzang passed through Khotan
label: Paragraph

text: around 644 CE on his way back from India to
label: Paragraph

text: China and wrote:
label: Paragraph

text: This country is renowned for its music;
label: Paragraph

text: the men love the song and dance. Few of
label: Paragraph

text: them wear garments of skin and wool; most
label: Paragraph

text: wear taffeta and white linen. Their external
label: Paragraph

text: behavior is full of urbanity; their customs are
label: Paragraph

text: properly regulated. Their written characters
label: Paragraph

text: and their mode of forming their sentences
label: Title

text: resemble the Indian model; the forms of
label: Paragraph

text: the letters differ somewhat; the differences,
label: Paragraph

text: however, are slight.... There are about a
label: Paragraph

text: hundred sangharamas [monasteries/nunneries]
label: Title

text: with some 5000 followers, who all study the
label: Paragraph

text: doctrine of the Great Vehicle.*
label: Paragraph

text: *Styu-ki Buddhist Recards, vol. 2 (London, 1884), 309.
label: Caption

text: 7.3 A stupa from a cave mural in China
label: Caption

text: During this time, the southern maritime trade
label: Paragraph

text: routes from Egypt by way of the eastern
label: Title

text: coast of Africa to India, Indonesia, and
label: Title

text: China were beginning to develop into a trade
label: Paragraph

text: network as important as the land-based Silk
label: Paragraph

text: Route. The Romans, seeking to circumvent
label: Paragraph

text: the vicissitudes of the cross-desert trade,
label: Paragraph

text: saw places like Petra as veritable port cities
label: Paragraph

text: linking trade to India and beyond. And
label: Paragraph

text: like Petra, Aksum in modern Ethiopia had
label: Paragraph

text: become by this time a significant regional
label: Paragraph

text: force, trading with India and, northward,
label: Paragraph

text: with the Roman Empire. In summary, it
label: Paragraph

text: can be said that the 3rd century CE saw the
label: Paragraph

text: maturation of a new world order, namely
label: Paragraph

text: that of transregional, transcontinental trade
label: Paragraph

text: interdependency, especially in luxury goods.
label: Paragraph

text: It was a world order that would continue to
label: Paragraph

text: escalate with the emergence of the great
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolian Empire in the 13th century.
label: Paragraph

text: In all of this, it is important to remember
label: Paragraph

text: that the trading world that stretched
label: Paragraph

text: from Rome through India and China was
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinarily narrow. It did not yet include
label: Paragraph

text: Southeast Asia; Africa, apart from the
label: Paragraph

text: Ethiopian and Mediterranean coasts, was
label: Paragraph

text: largely on its own, as was the Siberian north.
label: Paragraph

text: In Peru, one sees regional states
label: Paragraph

text: emerging: the Moche in the north and, in
label: Paragraph

text: the south, the Nazca, who produced large
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrimage centers such as Cahuachi,
label: Paragraph

text: where mysterious patterns on the ground
label: Paragraph

text: later appeared, celebrated today as
label: Paragraph

text: the Nazca Lines. The purpose of these
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate designs—whose full impact can
label: Paragraph

text: only be appreciated from the air—remains
label: Paragraph

text: unresolved, as do questions about the
label: Paragraph

text: nature of the Nazcas’ religious practices,
label: Paragraph

text: to which they seem related. In Mexico, the
label: Paragraph

text: superpower of the region was unquestionably
label: Paragraph

text: Teotihuacan, the capital of an empire that
label: Paragraph

text: encompassed most of Central America and
label: Paragraph

text: that was the center of a trading network
label: Paragraph

text: extending from the Mississippi Delta to the
label: Paragraph

text: Peruvian coast. Teotihuacan was the largest
label: Paragraph

text: and most influential city of pre-colonial
label: Paragraph

text: America. All subsequent architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: Central America was impacted by its legacy.
label: Paragraph

text: In the Americas, the Hopewell Culture
label: Paragraph

text: came the first large-scale culture in
label: Paragraph

text: lorth America, spreading a web of cities
label: Title

text: and villages along the Ohio River. It was
label: Paragraph

text: a unique culture in that it specialized in
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonialism. The Hopewell controlled
label: Paragraph

text: jand rich in salt, flint, and pipestone, and
label: Paragraph

text: people from far away would come to gather
label: Paragraph

text: or mine these materials. But to do this, they
label: Paragraph

text: jad to bring gifts and participate in elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial exchanges. The Hopewell built
label: Caption

text: jarge enclosures, hundreds of meters across
label: Paragraph

text: and shaped in various ways. They also lined
label: Paragraph

text: the rivers and streams with ancestor mounds,
label: Paragraph

text: producing a complex, sacred landscape.

label: Title

text: The Roman Republic (509 BCE-27 BCE)
label: Title

text: focused largely on the Mediterranean,
label: Paragraph

text: especially once Rome took over Greece
label: Paragraph

text: in 146 BCE. But with the Gaulic Wars and
label: Paragraph

text: the conquest of northern territories, Rome
label: Caption

text: could combine trade over both sea and land.
label: Paragraph

text: And though this was perhaps the vision of
label: Paragraph

text: Caesar, the process of fusing everything into
label: Paragraph

text: a single imperial unit, rather than a network
label: Paragraph

text: of unequal principalities, would ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: be cornpleted by Caesar's successor, the
label: Paragraph

text: emperor Augustus. The land/sea combination
label: Title

text: was the first such empire at that scale. By the
label: Paragraph

text: 2nd century CE, the empire extended north
label: Paragraph

text: all the way to England. Under Hadrian, North
label: Caption

text: Africa was absorbed. Inroads were made
label: Paragraph

text: into western Asia in order to secure trade
label: Paragraph

text: links to the East. The eastern reaches of the
label: Paragraph

text: empire were defined by older cities like Petra,
label: Paragraph

text: Antioch, and Alexandria as well as by newly
label: Paragraph

text: expanded cities like Palmyra and Duros
label: Title

text: Europus.
label: Paragraph

text: The development of cities was now at its
label: Paragraph

text: peak, and the consequences can be seen
label: Paragraph

text: throughout Europe and the Mediterranean.
label: Paragraph

text: The list of Roman foundations includes
label: Title

text: Aosta, Bordeaux, Florence, London, Mainz,
label: Caption

text: Mantua, Paris, Milan, Silchester (Hampshire,
label: Caption

text: England), Trier, Cologne, Turin, Verona, and
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna, to name only a few. Many cities, like
label: Paragraph

text: Florence, Milan, Paris, and Trier, still carry
label: Paragraph

text: the imprint of the Roman grid to this day.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the paradigm for the city was the
label: Paragraph

text: castrum, or military camp, which was divided
label: Paragraph

text: by two intersecting main streets, the cardo
label: Paragraph

text: (north-south) and decumanus (east-west), this
label: Paragraph

text: model was used mainly in the initial phases of
label: Paragraph

text: the colonization in Europe and North Africa.
label: Paragraph

text: In Europe, though some of the Gaulic cities
label: Paragraph

text: remained in use, many, because they were
label: Paragraph

text: on hilltops, were evacuated by the Romans,
label: Paragraph

text: who preferred valleys and river towns, which
label: Paragraph

text: were easier to defend and more amenable
label: Paragraph

text: to Roman practices of camp organization.
label: Paragraph

text: Bibracte, for example, was abandoned and
label: Paragraph

text: the new city of Augustodunum, now known
label: Paragraph

text: as Autun, was built in the nearby valley. The
label: Paragraph

text: castrurm model, however, was rarely used
label: Paragraph

text: in the East, where cities were already well
label: Paragraph

text: established. There, the Romans simply added
label: Paragraph

text: to what they found. Regardless of whether the
label: Paragraph

text: castrum model was used or not, the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: method of creating cities can be compared
label: Paragraph

text: with that of the Chinese. The Chinese were
label: Paragraph

text: specialists in megacities, concentrating huge
label: Paragraph

text: populations and bringing a large spectrum
label: Paragraph

text: of activities into the confines of the city walls.
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese cities were largely composed of one-
label: Paragraph

text: or two-story houses and were thus not very
label: Paragraph

text: dense. The Romans specialized in compact,
label: Paragraph

text: small-scale cities networked across the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape. This allowed for easy expansion
label: Paragraph

text: and was a critical element in their success.
label: Paragraph

text: The Romans became experts in water
label: Paragraph

text: management, building extensive aqueducts,
label: Paragraph

text: many of which have lasted into the modern
label: Paragraph

text: world. The Pont du Gard in modern-day
label: Paragraph

text: southern France and the equally impressive
label: Title

text: Acueducto de Los Milagros in Mérida, Spain,
label: Caption

text: are testamients to the boldness of these
label: Paragraph

text: designs. The water fed not only great fountains
label: Paragraph

text: but also magnificent public baths, which were
label: Paragraph

text: among the largest public buildings in the world
label: Paragraph

text: at the time.
label: Paragraph

text: North Africa is an excellent place to study
label: Paragraph

text: Roman urban concepts; it supplied the
label: Paragraph

text: capital with staple crops and luxury goods.
label: Paragraph

text: Hadrian was eager to develop this area and
label: Paragraph

text: offered free tenancy and a period of tax
label: Paragraph

text: exemption to anyone who would agree to
label: Paragraph

text: reside permanently on marginal land and put
label: Paragraph

text: it under cultivation. It was a successful policy
label: Paragraph

text: that encouraged the establishment of rural
label: Paragraph

text: trading centers, many of which developed
label: Paragraph

text: into urban environments. In some places
label: Paragraph

text: a new town was founded, like Timgad, a
label: Paragraph

text: gridded city roughly the size of Florence; in
label: Paragraph

text: others, such as at Leptis Magna, an existing
label: Paragraph

text: Phoenician city (east of Tripoli), the planners
label: Paragraph

text: adopted a flexible and additive approach.
label: Paragraph

text: Roman cities were more differentiated
label: Paragraph

text: than Greek cities, which were usually
label: Paragraph

text: defined by a central public area and temple
label: Paragraph

text: precincts. A Roman city had streets, squares,
label: Paragraph

text: fountains, baths, gates, memorial columns,
label: Caption

text: and public buildings that formed a type
label: Paragraph

text: of armature around which the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: city grew. At the core of the city was the
label: Paragraph

text: forum, the political and economic center of
label: Title

text: the city's activities. Public ceremonies and
label: Paragraph

text: announcements took place there, and around
label: Paragraph

text: it were ranged temples, offices, jails, butcher
label: Paragraph

text: shops, and law courts.
label: Paragraph

text: At Palmyra and Ostia we can see the
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to graft this armature onto places that
label: Paragraph

text: had been founded at an earlier date, when
label: Paragraph

text: they were more towns than cities. Djemila,
label: Paragraph

text: in Algeria (96 CE), is typical; its elongated
label: Paragraph

text: shape is a result of the terrain. The first part
label: Paragraph

text: of the city to the north shows a relatively
label: Paragraph

text: systermatized layout, with the forum at the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the town along the main road. But
label: Paragraph

text: when that proved inadequate, a new forum,
label: Paragraph

text: temple, and theater were built in a southward

text: Ephesus
label: Title

text: Ephesus, a small town and religious center
label: Title

text: on the shores of the Cayster River near its
label: Paragraph

text: mouth on the Turkish coast, was settled in
label: Paragraph

text: the 9th century BCE and began to develop
label: Paragraph

text: nto an important port. Because the river
label: Paragraph

text: was silting over, the city was abandoned and
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilt at its current location 2 kilometers to
label: Paragraph

text: the east around 270 BCE. It was designed
label: Paragraph

text: not from the top down, as was Pergamon,
label: Paragraph

text: but horizontally, in a protected, curving valley
label: Paragraph

text: that opens in dramatic fashion onto the new
label: Paragraph

text: harbor. By the end of the 5th century CE, the
label: Paragraph

text: port of this city, just like that of the first one,
label: Paragraph

text: silted up and the city fell into disuse. Today
label: Paragraph

text: the harbor is 5 kilometers inland.
label: Paragraph

text: When the Romans took over the city in
label: Paragraph

text: the first century BCE, they began the process
label: Paragraph

text: of Romanization, adding temples, baths,
label: Paragraph

text: fountains, paved streets, and libraries. When
label: Paragraph

text: Augustus becarne emperor in 27 BCE, he
label: Paragraph

text: made Ephesus the capital of the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: holdings in western Asia Minor. Ephesus then
label: Paragraph

text: entered an era of prosperity, becoming both
label: Paragraph

text: the seat of the governor and a major center
label: Paragraph

text: of commerce. According to Strabo, it was
label: Paragraph

text: second in importance and size only to Rome.
label: Paragraph

text: The Library of Celsus (ca. 115 CE) was built
label: Paragraph

text: to store 12,000 scrolls and had an elegant
label: Paragraph

text: facade with four sets of marble column pairs
label: Caption

text: that framed aediculae and windows.

text: The Roman Theater
label: Title

text: Almost all Roman cities had a theater used
label: Paragraph

text: for both popular and religious purposes. In
label: Paragraph

text: the days of the republic, the Romans were
label: Paragraph

text: somewhat skeptical of theaters—which were
label: Paragraph

text: common in Greek cities—and concerned
label: Paragraph

text: about their potentially corrupting influences.
label: Paragraph

text: One decree forbade sitting at theaters, since
label: Paragraph

text: it was deemed more manly to stand. As a
label: Paragraph

text: result, theaters built during the republican
label: Paragraph

text: period were temporary structures built of
label: Paragraph

text: wood. The first permanent theater was
label: Paragraph

text: ordered by Pompey in 55 BCE. Its design was
label: Paragraph

text: what could be called transitional; it included
label: Paragraph

text: a temple of Venus at the top of the seating
label: Caption

text: area so that the rows of seats appeared to be
label: Paragraph

text: steps leading up to the temple. Gradually this
label: Paragraph

text: subterfuge fell away once theaters were built
label: Paragraph

text: in the colonies, where the emphasis was on
label: Paragraph

text: the theater as a public amenity.
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas Greek theaters were carefully
label: Paragraph

text: and strategically inserted into the natural
label: Paragraph

text: landscape and often had dramatic views, the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman theater was conceived as an urban
label: Paragraph

text: architectural element, its magnificence and
label: Paragraph

text: splendor a token of Rome's imperial status.
label: Paragraph

text: The slope of the seating was steeper than in
label: Paragraph

text: Greek theaters, possibly for acoustic reasons.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially, Roman theaters were hollowed out of
label: Paragraph

text: a hill or slope, as at the theater at Aspendos,
label: Paragraph

text: a Roman colony in Turkey. Over time,
label: Paragraph

text: however, Romans viewed their theaters as
label: Paragraph

text: regular urban structures. All of the theaters
label: Paragraph

text: built within the city of Rome were made
label: Paragraph

text: without the use of earthworks. Also unlike
label: Paragraph

text: Greek theaters, the auditorium, though not
label: Paragraph

text: roofed, was covered with awnings or velaria,
label: Paragraph

text: which could be stretched out from tall poles
label: Paragraph

text: to provide shelter from rain or sunlight. The
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were usually semicircular. The stage
label: Paragraph

text: building (scaenae frons) was usually three
label: Paragraph

text: stories high, with the theater divided into the
label: Paragraph

text: stage (orchestra) and the seating section
label: Title

text: (auditorium). In Rome, few theaters have
label: Paragraph

text: survived the centuries. Arausio, the theater
label: Caption

text: in modern-day Orange, France, is a good
label: Paragraph

text: surviving example of a classic Roman theater,
label: Paragraph

text: as is the theater at Aspendos, though of
label: Paragraph

text: course they are missing all their ornamental
label: Paragraph

text: grandeur.

text: The building was sited in an area north of
label: Paragraph

text: the old city center known as Campus Martius
label: Paragraph

text: (“Field of Mars") that, before the founding of
label: Paragraph

text: Rome, had been used for pasturing horses
label: Paragraph

text: and military exercises. During imperial
label: Paragraph

text: times, it became the site of Rome’s urban
label: Paragraph

text: expansion, with baths, theaters, and temples,
label: Paragraph

text: including a large open courtyard building
label: Paragraph

text: known as the Saepta Julia, where Romans
label: Paragraph

text: voted.
label: Paragraph

text: While the classical ce/fa had always been
label: Paragraph

text: a dark and mysterious place oriented east
label: Paragraph

text: to the rising sun, this building rejects that
label: Paragraph

text: tradition. Its bold, domed interior space was,
label: Paragraph

text: for the Romans, an innovation. It derives
label: Paragraph

text: conceptually from Greek and Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: mathematical interest in spatial geometry—
label: Title

text: concepts familiar to Hadrian, who had lived
label: Paragraph

text: in Alexandria, a city famous as a center of
label: Paragraph

text: learning. It was Archimedes, a Greek, who
label: Paragraph

text: had solved the problem of measuring the
label: Paragraph

text: volume of the sphere and cylinder in relation
label: Title

text: to each other. By way of contrast, Romans
label: Paragraph

text: contributed practically nothing to analytical
label: Paragraph

text: geometry. In that sense, the building is, one
label: Paragraph

text: might almost say, un-Roman.
label: Paragraph

text: Smaller domed oculus structures had
label: Paragraph

text: been built earlier, for bathhouses, like the
label: Paragraph

text: one that still stands at Baia, on the north
label: Paragraph

text: shore of the Bay of Naples. These places
label: Paragraph

text: might have been a good place to work out
label: Paragraph

text: technical issues, but they were certainly not
label: Paragraph

text: models in the symbolic sense. The octagonal
label: Paragraph

text: room in Nero’s palace brings us closer, in
label: Paragraph

text: that it ended in an oculus and descriptions
label: Paragraph

text: emphasize its syrnbolic purpose. Perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: seventy-five years later, with Hadrian, Rornan
label: Paragraph

text: architects had an emperor who, like Nero,
label: Paragraph

text: had a verve for architectural experimentation
label: Paragraph

text: and an interest in the Hellenistic East, where

text: The building probably had an astronomical

text: for certain.

text: Unfortunately, no Roman text has yet

text: statues, the ritual practices undertaken

text: in the building, or even the symbolism of
label: Paragraph

text: the oculus. But it is likely that the building

label: Paragraph

text: the oculus. They end, however, not at the
label: Paragraph

text: mouth of the oculus but well short of it,
label: Paragraph

text: 7.20 Dome detail: Pantheon
label: Caption

text: leaving a smooth, platelike area around the
label: Paragraph

text: opening. The concrete surface of the dome
label: Paragraph

text: visible today is not what contemporaries
label: Paragraph

text: saw, however. The edges of the oculus, and
label: Paragraph

text: the coffering as well, were probably gilded,
label: Paragraph

text: with rosettes filling the centers of the coffers
label: Paragraph

text: and creating a much more ephemeral and
label: Paragraph

text: less structural impression than what can be
label: Paragraph

text: observed today.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the Romans are often praised for
label: Paragraph

text: structural innovation, they could easily make
label: Paragraph

text: structure subservient to architectural vision.
label: Paragraph

text: The lower half of the coffering, in fact, bears
label: Paragraph

text: no relationship whatsoever to the structure
label: Title

text: behind it. In that sense, the architects were
label: Paragraph

text: willing to work with the illusion of structure,
label: Paragraph

text: or at least wanted to separate the visual
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary of a dome’s “celestial” structure
label: Title

text: from the hard reality of the structural support.
label: Paragraph

text: Even the coffering was designed from an
label: Paragraph

text: optical point of view. The steps are shallower
label: Paragraph

text: on their lower edge and steeper on the higher
label: Paragraph

text: so as to appear the same height when viewed
label: Paragraph

text: from the center of the floor.
label: Paragraph

text: The lower part of the structure is brick-
label: Paragraph

text: faced concrete, with voids serving to reduce
label: Paragraph

text: the overall weight. Massive curving vaults
label: Paragraph

text: direct the forces to the ground. For the dome,
label: Paragraph

text: only concrete was used. The pour, made
label: Paragraph

text: against a temporary wooden formwork, had
label: Paragraph

text: to be seamless, placed bottom to top without
label: Paragraph

text: pause in order to guarantee the cohesion
label: Paragraph

text: of the whole. Organizing the production of
label: Paragraph

text: the concrete, its immediate transport to the
label: Paragraph

text: level of the dome, and its distribution to the
label: Paragraph

text: right places by people carrying small batches
label: Paragraph

text: was quite a feat. The width of the wall at the
label: Paragraph

text: bottom is 6.15 meters. It thins to only 1.5
label: Paragraph

text: meters at the level of the oculus, which is 8.3
label: Paragraph

text: meters across and open to air and weather.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the powerful evocations of the
label: Paragraph

text: building, Hadrian's experiment would not
label: Paragraph

text: be repeated. Though Roman architects
label: Paragraph

text: continued to work with domed spaces, as in
label: Paragraph

text: the Baths of Caracalla, the dome-and-oculus
label: Caption

text: as imperial message was never repeated.
label: Paragraph

text: The original intermediary frieze was
label: Paragraph

text: replaced in 1747 with one far less delicate in
label: Paragraph

text: proportion. In the early 20th century, a small
label: Paragraph

text: section of the original frieze was rebuilt based
label: Paragraph

text: on Renaissance-era drawings.
label: Paragraph

text: Hadrian’s Villa
label: Title

text: Hadrian’s other major contribution to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was an extravagant villa complex,
label: Paragraph

text: a miniature world that he built for himself
label: Paragraph

text: (118-34 CE) at the top of a hill about 25
label: Caption

text: kilometers east of Rome. It is not a single
label: Paragraph

text: building, but a series of interconnected
label: Paragraph

text: structures and gardens. Unlike the Palace of
label: Paragraph

text: Domitian, with its compressed orderliness,
label: Paragraph

text: the villa returns to the more freewheeling
label: Paragraph

text: texture of Nero's palace. There are dozens of
label: Paragraph

text: distinct elements separated from each other
label: Title

text: in the landscape and yet linked in surprising
label: Paragraph

text: ways, so that the whole design unfolds only
label: Paragraph

text: gradually. Some of the parts were meant
label: Paragraph

text: to evoke memories of distant lands from
label: Paragraph

text: Hadrian’s far-flung travels. The residential
label: Paragraph

text: parts were to the north. To the south was the
label: Paragraph

text: stadium, followed by a series of baths ending
label: Paragraph

text: in the spectacular structure known as the
label: Paragraph

text: canopus, which was lined with copies of the
label: Paragraph

text: caryatids of the Erechtheum in Athens.
label: Caption

text: The whole was meant to evoke the
label: Paragraph

text: international—and particularly Greek and
label: Title

text: Egyptian—flavor of Hadrian’s trips. In that
label: Paragraph

text: sense the villa was a collection of memories
label: Paragraph

text: and allusions. The canopus, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: refers to a particularly bright star that was
label: Paragraph

text: often used in navigation by Mediterranean
label: Paragraph

text: sailors. It appears in numerous Greek
label: Paragraph

text: legends and was also the name of an
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian port near the mouth of the Nile.
label: Paragraph

text: The canopus at Hadrian’s Villa is designed
label: Caption

text: as a long lake decorated along its edges with
label: Paragraph

text: columns supporting alternating arches and
label: Paragraph

text: lintels. The Shrine of Serapis (Serapeum) on
label: Caption

text: the southern end of the complex was built
label: Paragraph

text: against a steeply sloping hillside, creating
label: Paragraph

text: the impression of a grotto or miniature gorge
label: Title

text: with a waterfall at the back. It was dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: to Serapis, the syncretic Hellenistic-Egyptian
label: Paragraph

text: god who was the protector of the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Alexandria. With water fromm an aqueduct
label: Caption

text: above flowing through the gorge and around
label: Paragraph

text: a crescent-shaped masonry reclining seat
label: Caption

text: toward the long, riverlike pool, diners on
label: Paragraph

text: the curved bench seats would have had a
label: Paragraph

text: cool and enjoyable meal, even in the heat
label: Paragraph

text: of summer. A small sernicircular pool where
label: Paragraph

text: food could be floated back and forth further
label: Paragraph

text: added to its charm. The vault’s surfaces were
label: Paragraph

text: covered with blue and green mosaics. And
label: Paragraph

text: the walls of the exedra were decorated with
label: Paragraph

text: semicircular niches that held statues.

text: The so-called Island Villa, surrounded by a moat and a colonnade, is
label: Paragraph

text: among the many astonishing elements of the villa. Access across bridges
label: Paragraph

text: leads into an intricate architectural composition of concave and convex
label: Paragraph

text: curves. The apparent symmetry at the center, typical of the spatial
label: Paragraph

text: imagination of Roman architects, feathers out toward the perimeter,
label: Paragraph

text: as if the architect had less and less control over the more marginal
label: Paragraph

text: volures—in a sense a metaphor for the Roman Empire itself. The two
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom suites were on the east side; the dining room on the south.
label: Paragraph

text: The western side was taken up by a small bathing area. At the center of
label: Paragraph

text: the compressed peristyle court was a fountain, its sound filtering its way
label: Paragraph

text: through the roorns.
label: Paragraph

text: The Piazza d’Oro, another element in the villa, was another tour de
label: Paragraph

text: force of spatial imagination. It consists of a large, nearly square peristyle
label: Paragraph

text: court, with a pool at its center. At the far end is a pavilion, or nymphaeum.
label: Paragraph

text: Its main room is composed of rounded “walls” turned concave and then
label: Paragraph

text: convex to form a flowing, four-armed space. These were not walls in the
label: Paragraph

text: strict sense, but curved colonnades that allow one to view through thern
label: Paragraph

text: to the adjoining spaces. The room was open to the sky. The four ancillary
label: Paragraph

text: spaces at the corners are all identical. The concave side leads to rooms
label: Paragraph

text: with fountains in the floors, whereas the one on the principal axis leads to
label: Paragraph

text: a curving space, the back wall of which is lined with fountains. Hadrian's
label: Paragraph

text: Villa shows the Roman spatial imagination at its best. Order is balanced
label: Paragraph

text: against complexity, as is architecture against landscape.

label: Title

text: Since the Egyptians covered their temple
label: Paragraph

text: walls with irnages or historical reliefs, there
label: Paragraph

text: was no opportunity for architects to think of
label: Paragraph

text: the wall as anything other than a definer of
label: Paragraph

text: space. In Greek architecture, walls were often
label: Paragraph

text: hidden behind columns, and even though
label: Paragraph

text: the Greeks invented the pilaster in the form
label: Paragraph

text: of columns in antis, and sometimes even
label: Paragraph

text: articulated walls with shallow panels, they
label: Paragraph

text: never saw the wall as anything other than
label: Paragraph

text: a wall. But by the tire of the Colosseum,
label: Paragraph

text: Roman architects were beginning to
label: Paragraph

text: experiment with complex articulations of the
label: Paragraph

text: vertical surface. For the first time, the wall
label: Paragraph

text: became an architectural element per se. The
label: Paragraph

text: technique of framing arches within engaged
label: Paragraph

text: half-columns supporting an entablature,
label: Paragraph

text: called the fornix system of ornamentation
label: Paragraph

text: (fornix meaning “vault” or “arched room"),
label: Paragraph

text: dates back to about 150 BCE. The Romans
label: Paragraph

text: also invented the aedicule, a combination of
label: Paragraph

text: niche with flanking columns connected by
label: Caption

text: either a pediment or arch. In addition, they
label: Paragraph

text: developed the dado, a boxlike stone under
label: Paragraph

text: the column that allows it to be elevated.
label: Paragraph

text: The amphitheater in Nimes, France,
label: Caption

text: recapitulates the there, as do numerous
label: Paragraph

text: triumphal arches, such as the Arch of Titus
label: Paragraph

text: (81 CE) in Rome. Eventually, aediculae and
label: Paragraph

text: niches were added to the vocabulary, as can

text: The so-called Palace Tomb, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: which has been variously dated to the
label: Paragraph

text: second half of the 1st century CE or early
label: Paragraph

text: 2nd century, shows a stratified design, with
label: Paragraph

text: the lower register of four doors framed by
label: Caption

text: round-headed and pedimented aediculae
label: Caption

text: with unusual, abstracted capitals. The whole
label: Paragraph

text: is tied together by an unbroken entablature
label: Paragraph

text: on which rests a row of half-columns, the
label: Paragraph

text: last ones being pilasters; above that is an
label: Paragraph

text: accordion-style entablature with the pilaster
label: Caption

text: order shadowing its way through to the
label: Paragraph

text: top. The Tomb of Sextius Florentinus is
label: Caption

text: particularly refined. Above the lower register
label: Caption

text: is a pilaster order and a second set of
label: Paragraph

text: capitals. This interpenetration of horizontals
label: Paragraph

text: and verticals shows a capacity to see in the
label: Paragraph

text: x- and y-axes simultaneously. Such a degree
label: Paragraph

text: of visual cornplexity would not recur until the
label: Paragraph

text: Italian Renaissance.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 2nd century CE, richly
label: Paragraph

text: elaborated architectural fronts that had once
label: Paragraph

text: been associated with the prosceniums in
label: Paragraph

text: theaters sprouted forth in public spaces. This
label: Paragraph

text: is true of the facade of the Library of Celsus
label: Paragraph

text: at Ephesus (115 Ce), which stands on the
label: Paragraph

text: western end of a marble courtyard and is
label: Paragraph

text: approached by a flight of nine steps. The
label: Paragraph

text: three entrances, with large windows above
label: Caption

text: them, are flanked by four niches that contain
label: Paragraph

text: statues personifying the virtues of Celsus,
label: Paragraph

text: Roman senator and proconsul of Asia. In
label: Paragraph

text: front of the facade are four double-story pairs
label: Caption

text: of columns; the capitals of the lower story
label: Caption

text: are Corinthian, and those of the upper story,
label: Paragraph

text: lonic. In a further display of design skill,
label: Paragraph

text: the architect changed the pairing between
label: Paragraph

text: top and bottom. At the top, the columns
label: Paragraph

text: are brought together with pedimental and
label: Paragraph

text: rounded arches spanning the gaps. The
label: Paragraph

text: end columns stand almost free against the
label: Paragraph

text: facade.
label: Caption

text: Such displays were more than just
label: Paragraph

text: architectural excess. They conformed to the
label: Paragraph

text: Hellenistic desire for imrnediacy and were
label: Paragraph

text: meant to express the qualities and generosity
label: Paragraph

text: of the patron.
label: Paragraph

text: At the nymphaeum of Nimes, France,
label: Caption

text: the columnar elements form an exoskeleton
label: Paragraph

text: against which presses the mass of the walls.
label: Paragraph

text: The search for complex and imaginative
label: Title

text: formations reaches a climax at the stage
label: Paragraph

text: for the South Theater in Gerasa, Jordan
label: Caption

text: (modern-day Jerash). Though the first floor
label: Paragraph

text: has been reconstructed without the second
label: Paragraph

text: floor, it shows a row of paired columns on a
label: Paragraph

text: socle forming a screen in front of pedimented
label: Paragraph

text: doorways with aedicu/ae between them. A
label: Paragraph

text: similarly well-thought-out scheme prevails at
label: Paragraph

text: the court of the Temple of Zeus at Baalbek.
label: Paragraph

text: Two Corinthian columns in antis work with
label: Caption

text: two pilasters to create the semblance of a

text: screen unit. The aediculae, roundheaded

text: at the bottom level and pedimented at the
label: Paragraph

text: top level, are squeezed in between the
label: Paragraph

text: pilasters, practically hiding the wall surface
label: Paragraph

text: behind. The theme continues in the large
label: Paragraph

text: Roman Baths
label: Title

text: Although wealthy Romans had baths in their
label: Paragraph

text: townhouses and country villas, the heating of
label: Paragraph

text: a series of rooms, or even an entire separate
label: Paragraph

text: building especially for this purpose, was
label: Paragraph

text: usually reserved for public bathhouses, which
label: Paragraph

text: were available in cities and towns throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the empire. These baths, called fhermae,
label: Paragraph

text: were owned by the state and often covered
label: Paragraph

text: several city blocks. Entrance fees were quite
label: Paragraph

text: reasonable and within the budget of most
label: Paragraph

text: free Romans. The area in these baths that
label: Paragraph

text: was actually covered with water was relatively
label: Paragraph

text: small, for the bulk of the structure was filled
label: Paragraph

text: by exercise spaces, lounges, and places to
label: Paragraph

text: stroll. Since the Roman workday began at
label: Paragraph

text: sunrise, work was usually over a little after
label: Paragraph

text: noon. At about 2 or 3 PM, men would go
label: Paragraph

text: to the baths, staying for several hours of
label: Paragraph

text: sport, bathing, and conversation, after which
label: Paragraph

text: they would be ready for a relaxing dinner.
label: Paragraph

text: Republican bathhouses often had separate
label: Paragraph

text: athing facilities for women and men, but
label: Paragraph

text: y the time of the empire, the custom was
label: Paragraph

text: to open the baths to women during the early
label: Paragraph

text: part of the day and reserve ther for men
label: Paragraph

text: rom 2 PM until closing at sundown.
label: Paragraph

text: The baths were secular spaces not
label: Paragraph

text: associated with altars or divine patronage.
label: Paragraph

text: Some of the thermal or mineral baths,
label: Paragraph

text: jowever, might be associated with local
label: Paragraph

text: river nymphs or the gods of medicine. Baths
label: Paragraph

text: offered an environment that was both sensual
label: Paragraph

text: and social. Some baths had lecture halls and
label: Paragraph

text: ibraries. The origin of these institutions goes
label: Paragraph

text: back to the beginning of classical culture and
label: Title

text: the emphasis placed on physical fitness by
label: Paragraph

text: the Greeks; bathing was viewed as a part of
label: Paragraph

text: the hygienic rituals associated with sports.
label: Paragraph

text: Gymnasiums, in which sports and education
label: Paragraph

text: were combined, were reserved primarily for
label: Paragraph

text: the sons of citizens and as a place for military
label: Title

text: training. Under Alexander the Great, however,
label: Paragraph

text: the baths of Greek gymnasiums became a
label: Paragraph

text: more social environment—and the Roman
label: Title

text: bath even more so. In fact, few citizens
label: Paragraph

text: were so poor that they could not afford
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance fee. Aware of the beneficial
label: Paragraph

text: role these institutions played in the health,
label: Paragraph

text: education, and entertainment of the people,
label: Paragraph

text: the Roman state allocated considerable
label: Paragraph

text: resources to their maintenance. Some of
label: Paragraph

text: these baths, like the Baths of Caracalla and
label: Paragraph

text: the Baths of Diocletian, were enormous
label: Paragraph

text: structures, the largest public buildings in the
label: Paragraph

text: world. Their lavish interiors were decorated
label: Paragraph

text: with trophies, inscriptions, and sculptures
label: Paragraph

text: reflecting the reach and power of the
label: Paragraph

text: emperor.
label: Paragraph

text: The Baths of Caracalla (212-16 CE) are
label: Paragraph

text: recognized as the best developed example of
label: Paragraph

text: the Roman public bath. The main building
label: Caption

text: (200 by 114 meters) was set in an enclosure
label: Paragraph

text: (328 by 400 meters) that contained cisterns,
label: Paragraph

text: running tracks, gardens, libraries, and shops.
label: Paragraph

text: The facade was relatively austere and had
label: Paragraph

text: only a few doors; by contrast, the internal
label: Paragraph

text: Spaces were open and sunny. The main
label: Paragraph

text: pool was the natatio, or swimming pool.

text: Baalbek
label: Title

text: The supreme deity of the Canaanites was El,
label: Paragraph

text: the sun god who also carried the bull as an
label: Paragraph

text: attribute. The fertility goddess Ashera was his
label: Paragraph

text: companion. Worshippers were not allowed to
label: Paragraph

text: pray directly to the couple but could use the
label: Paragraph

text: mediating influence of their son, Baal, the
label: Paragraph

text: master of rain, tempest, and thunder. This
label: Paragraph

text: was typical of the Hellenistic era, which saw
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of several sons of deities. The
label: Paragraph

text: principal site of the worship of Baal was near
label: Paragraph

text: a natural rock fissure some 15 meters deep,
label: Paragraph

text: at the bottom of which was a small rock-cut
label: Paragraph

text: altar. Since the altar was difficult to access,
label: Paragraph

text: another one was constructed above it on the
label: Paragraph

text: hill. This was then augmented with protective
label: Paragraph

text: gates and towers. Eventually a temple was
label: Paragraph

text: added, built on a high undercroft. The
label: Caption

text: Temple of Jupiter, the final temple on that
label: Paragraph

text: site, was begun during the reign of Augustus
label: Paragraph

text: (27 BCE-14 CE); it was constructed on a
label: Paragraph

text: scale unknown in Rome until then. Some
label: Paragraph

text: of the foundation stones weighed 800 tons
label: Paragraph

text: and are some of the largest stones ever used
label: Paragraph

text: in Roman times. Nonetheless, the ternple
label: Paragraph

text: was not as big as some of the enormous
label: Paragraph

text: Hellenistic temples, such as the one at
label: Paragraph

text: Dydima, which sat on a podiurn 17 meters
label: Paragraph

text: high, with columns reaching another 22
label: Paragraph

text: meters. (Large size was valued in the colonies
label: Paragraph

text: but looked down upon by the homeland as a
label: Paragraph

text: sort of barbaric excess.)
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Jupiter -
label: Title

text: Temple of Venus &..
label: Paragraph

text: 7.44 Pictorial view: Sanctuary of Jupiter Heliopolitanus
label: Caption

text: The temple's entrance was demarcated by
label: Paragraph

text: two buildings: a conventional U-shaped
label: Paragraph

text: propylaeum that was plugged into the front of
label: Paragraph

text: the temple (3rd century CE) and an unusual
label: Paragraph

text: hexagonal building (2nd century CE). The
label: Caption

text: latter had an open courtyard surrounded
label: Paragraph

text: by porticoes with rooms against the walls
label: Caption

text: that served various functions. It had a
label: Paragraph

text: showpiece facade that was a building in
label: Paragraph

text: its own right. Though symmetry was seen
label: Paragraph

text: as part of the natural order of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: architects plugged different “buildings” into
label: Paragraph

text: each other to produce creative and unusual
label: Paragraph

text: structures like this one. Trajan visited the
label: Paragraph

text: shrine around 115 Ce to consult the oracle
label: Paragraph

text: before attempting to conquer the Parthians,
label: Paragraph

text: and it may even have influenced him in the
label: Paragraph

text: design of his forum back in Rome. In 195 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: Septimus Severus (r. 193-211 CE) bestowed
label: Paragraph

text: upon Baalbek the title jus ftaficum, moving
label: Paragraph

text: it up to the most prominent class of Roman
label: Paragraph

text: cities. Construction at the site continued
label: Paragraph

text: during the rule of Caracalla (211-17 CE), a
label: Paragraph

text: member of the Syrian dynasty of emperors.
label: Paragraph

text: Nearby is the Temple of Venus (3rd
label: Paragraph

text: century CE), an extraordinary building
label: Paragraph

text: composed of a round cella with a porch.
label: Caption

text: The cella on the exterior is ornamented by
label: Caption

text: columns attached to a scalloped entablature,
label: Caption

text: creating a dynamic play between the round
label: Paragraph

text: and rectilinear geometries. The building
label: Caption

text: is a testament to the ongoing formal
label: Paragraph

text: experimentations typical in the eastern part
label: Paragraph

text: of the Roman Empire. Building activity in
label: Paragraph

text: Baalbek was still taking place when Emperor
label: Paragraph

text: Constantine declared Christianity the official
label: Title

text: religion of the Roman state in 330 CE, thus
label: Paragraph

text: putting an end to one of the largest and
label: Paragraph

text: longest building projects in the Levant.
label: Paragraph

text: Inner Asia was defined by specific
label: Paragraph

text: ecological realities. In the frozen north there
label: Paragraph

text: lived First Society people who specialized in
label: Paragraph

text: hunting and fishing. Along the vast steppe
label: Paragraph

text: region that spans thousands of kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: east to west and that in essence linked
label: Paragraph

text: China to Europe, there clustered dozens of
label: Paragraph

text: interrelated horse-centric tribes, who lived as
label: Paragraph

text: traders and raiders. The closer these people
label: Paragraph

text: got to the Silk Route, the more one tribe or
label: Paragraph

text: another wrested control of the flow of wealth.
label: Paragraph

text: Boundaries and allegiances were transitory
label: Paragraph

text: across the vast distances of deserts and
label: Paragraph

text: mountains. The Parthians and the Kushans,
label: Paragraph

text: for example, were continually fighting not
label: Paragraph

text: just an east-west battle for supremacy over
label: Paragraph

text: the trade routes but also a northern battle
label: Paragraph

text: against steppe newcomers. On the western
label: Paragraph

text: edge of this great continuum, in what is now
label: Paragraph

text: Germany and eastern Europe, there was a
label: Paragraph

text: robust pocket of the only agropastoralists in
label: Paragraph

text: the entire northern tribal belt. Once the Celts
label: Paragraph

text: in France had becorne Romanized, this group
label: Paragraph

text: of former kinsmen also came to feel the
label: Paragraph

text: pressure from the nomadic steppe people.
label: Paragraph

text: They were driven westward and finally broke
label: Paragraph

text: through the Roman defenses to settle in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe between the 4th and 6th centuries
label: Title

text: CE. From the perspective of the Romans and
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese, all of these people were barbarians,
label: Paragraph

text: living in villages instead of cities; living by
label: Paragraph

text: raiding instead of farming; and housed in
label: Paragraph

text: yurts and thatch instead of stone, brick,
label: Paragraph

text: and mud brick. A description of the Huns
label: Caption

text: by the 4th-century CE historian Ammianus
label: Paragraph

text: Marcellinus describes them as such:
label: Paragraph

text: The irony was that the great urban
label: Paragraph

text: civilizations of Eurasia were dependent on
label: Paragraph

text: this vast community of horsemen; they were
label: Paragraph

text: the oil in the Eurasian economic engine.
label: Paragraph

text: None of them plough, or even touch
label: Paragraph

text: a plough handle; for they have no
label: Paragraph

text: settled abode, but are homeless and
label: Paragraph

text: lawless, perpetually wandering with
label: Paragraph

text: their wagons, which they make their
label: Paragraph

text: homes; in fact, they seem to be people
label: Paragraph

text: always in flight. Their wives live in
label: Paragraph

text: these wagons, and there weave their
label: Paragraph

text: miserable garments; and here, too,
label: Paragraph

text: they sleep with their husbands, and
label: Paragraph

text: bring up their children ... nor, if asked,
label: Paragraph

text: can any one of them tell you where
label: Paragraph

text: he was born, as he was conceived in
label: Paragraph

text: one place, born in another at a great
label: Paragraph

text: distance, and brought up in another
label: Paragraph

text: still more remote.

text: THE PARTHIAN EMPIRE
label: Title

text: The Parthians took over the Hellenistic
label: Paragraph

text: Seleucid Empire; originally they were nomads
label: Paragraph

text: from northern Iran and Central Asia, but
label: Paragraph

text: because of their trading skills, the Parthian
label: Paragraph

text: Empire (247 BCE-224 CE) became the glue
label: Paragraph

text: that held together the vast Central Asian trade
label: Paragraph

text: networks. They brought with them, however,
label: Paragraph

text: little in the way of architectural culture, and
label: Paragraph

text: so for the most part adopted the Hellenist
label: Paragraph

text: structures before them, blending them with
label: Paragraph

text: their own particular aesthetic. As a result,
label: Paragraph

text: there is remarkably little to show for some five
label: Paragraph

text: hundred years of Parthian rule. Remaining
label: Paragraph

text: consummate and feared horsemen, they
label: Paragraph

text: governed as a military elite, leaving, by
label: Paragraph

text: and large, the local administrations intact.
label: Paragraph

text: here were, as a consequence, several
label: Paragraph

text: regional capitals. Though warfare with the
label: Paragraph

text: Romans and with nomadic invaders from
label: Title

text: the north was more ar less constant, the 2nd
label: Paragraph

text: century was a time when the caravan cities
label: Paragraph

text: of Palmyra, Hatra, and Mesene (forrnerly
label: Paragraph

text: Characene), situated at the confluence of
label: Paragraph

text: the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers, grew in
label: Paragraph

text: wealth and influence. It was also a time in
label: Paragraph

text: which, given the lack of centralized authority,
label: Paragraph

text: different religious practices began to flourish
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously. Iranian sun, fire, and mystery
label: Paragraph

text: cults took the place of ancient Mesopotamian
label: Paragraph

text: practices. Christianity, Judaism, and various
label: Paragraph

text: baptismal sects expanded into Mesopotamia.
label: Paragraph

text: Strong relations between the Parthians and
label: Paragraph

text: the Chinese resulted in envoy exchanges.
label: Paragraph

text: 7.47 Horse statuette of Parthian warrior
label: Caption

text: When the Chinese envoy arrived at the
label: Paragraph

text: Parthian border, he was greeted by an escort
label: Paragraph

text: of twenty thousand horsemen. Parthian elites,
label: Paragraph

text: on the whole, adopted Zoroastrianism (see
label: Paragraph

text: 400 CE), an emerging religious practice based
label: Paragraph

text: on fire worship. This they fused with certain
label: Paragraph

text: Hellenistic practices, creating fire sanctuaries
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to specific divinities, saints, or
label: Paragraph

text: angels. Parthian fire altars served as regional
label: Paragraph

text: and national pilgrimage sites. One such site,
label: Paragraph

text: Takht-i-Suleiman, in western Iran, around
label: Paragraph

text: the rim of an extinct volcano with a lake at
label: Paragraph

text: its core, was frequently visited by the royal
label: Paragraph

text: elites. The most important Parthian founding
label: Paragraph

text: was Ctesiphon (see 400 CE), on the east
label: Paragraph

text: bank of the Tigris at its confluence with the
label: Paragraph

text: Diyala River, 32 kilorneters south of Baghdad.
label: Caption

text: Originally a garrison city, it developed into
label: Paragraph

text: a regional capital, as it was situated on the
label: Paragraph

text: so-called Royal Road, which connected
label: Paragraph

text: Susa with Anatolia. It is not clear when
label: Paragraph

text: Ctesiphon became important, but it seems
label: Paragraph

text: that the spoils of a large campaign against
label: Paragraph

text: the Rornan Empire in 41 BCE were invested
label: Paragraph

text: in the new capital, which had become the
label: Paragraph

text: winter residence of the kings after 129 BCE.
label: Paragraph

text: The Romans sought to take the city and did
label: Paragraph

text: so in 116, 165, and 198 CE, but in 224 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: Ardashir overthrew the Parthian monarchy
label: Title

text: and established the Sassanian Empire, with
label: Paragraph

text: Ctesiphon remaining one of its capitals.
label: Paragraph

text: AKSUM
label: Title

text: By the 4th century BCE, the area of what
label: Paragraph

text: is today northern Ethiopia had come to
label: Paragraph

text: enjoy a strategic position in the developing
label: Paragraph

text: sea trade routes between Africa and
label: Title

text: points east in Arabia, India, and even
label: Paragraph

text: China. With the decline of Kush, perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: because deforestation led to the loss of
label: Paragraph

text: wood for smelting, this area, controlled
label: Paragraph

text: by the Aksumites and with its own vast
label: Paragraph

text: forest reserves (now, of course, completely
label: Paragraph

text: nonexistent), was primed to become a
label: Paragraph

text: regional powerhouse. Though Aksum was
label: Paragraph

text: an inland capital, its port cities, Adulis and
label: Paragraph

text: Matara, were cosmopolitan centers. The
label: Paragraph

text: rulers imported silver, gold, olive oil, and wine
label: Paragraph

text: while exporting luxury goods of glass crystal,
label: Paragraph

text: ivory, brass, and copper. Other important
label: Paragraph

text: exports to the Greek and Roman world were
label: Paragraph

text: frankincense, used in burials, and myrrh,
label: Paragraph

text: which had important medicinal properties.
label: Paragraph

text: Both these highly valued products were
label: Paragraph

text: obtained from the resin of particular trees
label: Paragraph

text: that grew mainly in the mountainous regions
label: Paragraph

text: of Aksum and southwest Arabia. The quality
label: Paragraph

text: of Aksumite metalwork in gold, silver, bronze,
label: Paragraph

text: and iron attests to the skill of their craftsmen.
label: Paragraph

text: The significance of Aksum in global trade
label: Title

text: should not be underestimated. With the
label: Paragraph

text: Romans eager to seek alternative trade routes
label: Title

text: to the East to get around the Parthians, they
label: Paragraph

text: had developed relationships with Petra.

label: Paragraph

text: Across the Strait of Hormuz lay the
label: Paragraph

text: Himyarite kingdom, or Himyar. It had
label: Paragraph

text: formerly traded in frankincense, but the
label: Paragraph

text: decline in demand for that product led to
label: Paragraph

text: trade in ivory exported from Africa to be sold
label: Title

text: in the Roman Empire. Ships from Himyar
label: Paragraph

text: regularly traveled the East African coast,
label: Paragraph

text: where Himyar exerted a considerable amount
label: Paragraph

text: of political control over the trading cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Himyar was independent until taken over by
label: Paragraph

text: the Aksumites in 525 Ce. Aksum remained
label: Paragraph

text: a strong empire and trading power until the
label: Paragraph

text: 6th century, when deforestation led to its
label: Paragraph

text: decline (much as it had in Kush}—a decline
label: Paragraph

text: accelerated by the rise of Islam and the
label: Paragraph

text: resulting shift in trade routes. The area's arid
label: Paragraph

text: geography today gives little indication of this
label: Paragraph

text: once lush and forested territory.

text: 7.48 Area of Aksumite influence, 200 to 500 CE
label: Caption

text: The Aksumite religion was related to
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamian and Arabic religions insofar
label: Title

text: as it was polytheistic: Deities were perceived
label: Paragraph

text: as controlling the natural forces of the
label: Paragraph

text: universe. In the 4th century CE, King Ezana
label: Paragraph

text: converted to Christianity and declared
label: Title

text: Aksum a Christian state—the first Christian
label: Title

text: state in the history of the world. The city
label: Paragraph

text: contained several large palaces that, unlike
label: Paragraph

text: the more rambling palaces of western Asia,
label: Paragraph

text: tended to be highly symmetrical. They were
label: Paragraph

text: approached by broad staircases that led to a
label: Paragraph

text: forecourt with more stairs leading to a central
label: Paragraph

text: throne or reception room. Construction
label: Paragraph

text: material was stone and brick, probably
label: Paragraph

text: covered with plaster. The roofs were wooden.

text: AMARAVATI STUPA
label: Title

text: In the 2nd and 3rd centuries CE, South Asia
label: Paragraph

text: was dominated by two major dynasties: the
label: Paragraph

text: Satavahanas, who controlled central and
label: Paragraph

text: southern India, and the Kushans, who,
label: Paragraph

text: although having recently migrated to the
label: Paragraph

text: region, ended up ruling a vast area stretching
label: Paragraph

text: from Central Asia to northern India. The
label: Paragraph

text: Kushans were Mongolians who emigrated
label: Paragraph

text: to Gandhara in response to the building of
label: Paragraph

text: the Great Wall by the Qin. It was a mutually
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcing combination since both had
label: Paragraph

text: their roots in trading communities. Both
label: Paragraph

text: were predominantly Buddhist, although
label: Paragraph

text: the Satavahanas were already witnessing
label: Paragraph

text: a re-emergent Hinduism and the Kushans
label: Title

text: continued to practice aspects of their older,
label: Paragraph

text: shamanistic beliefs. The Satavahanas called
label: Paragraph

text: themselves the dakshinapath-pati—“the
label: Paragraph

text: rulers of the southern trade route"—which
label: Paragraph

text: linked Egypt, controlled by the Romans,
label: Paragraph

text: with the Han rulers of China. The route
label: Paragraph

text: went from ports along the Indian Ocean
label: Title

text: to the west, across India in a northeasterly
label: Paragraph

text: direction, to ports on the Bay of Bengal.
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist monasteries became catalysts
label: Title

text: for this mercantile development, serving as
label: Paragraph

text: resting places and transition points for the
label: Paragraph

text: traders. The most farnous of the Satavahana
label: Paragraph

text: merchant constructions, the Amaravati
label: Title

text: Stupa (3rd century BCE), was dismantled

text: CAITYA HALL AT KARLI
label: Title

text: By the 3rd century CE, caitya halls were
label: Paragraph

text: eing built in several places in India. One of
label: Paragraph

text: the largest and most impressive was made
label: Paragraph

text: in 120 CE at Karli, on the western Deccan
label: Paragraph

text: Plateau. About 40 meters deep and 12
label: Paragraph

text: meters wide, the Karli sanctuary is fronted
label: Paragraph

text: y a recessed entrance of stone screens that
label: Paragraph

text: as holes in it, indicating that originally, a
label: Paragraph

text: larger wooden construction had been added
label: Paragraph

text: to complete the building. Just beyond the
label: Paragraph

text: screen, on the left, is a large pillar carved
label: Caption

text: rom the same matrix as the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: cave. The end wall of the entrance portico
label: Caption

text: displays a stamped-out, repeated set of
label: Paragraph

text: jorseshoe-arched building motifs that sit
label: Paragraph

text: atop a plinth composed of life-size elephants,
label: Paragraph

text: as if they were supporting the weight of the
label: Paragraph

text: superstructure. The central panel of the
label: Caption

text: cave entrance is dominated by male-female
label: Paragraph

text: couples, known as Mithuna couples, holding
label: Paragraph

text: each other affectionately with a distinctive
label: Paragraph

text: touch of sensuality. According to one source,
label: Paragraph

text: Mithuna couples represent “the notion of the
label: Paragraph

text: individual's reintegration with the universal
label: Title

text: principle.” The entrance panels also contain
label: Paragraph

text: bodhisattvas, but these were carved in the
label: Paragraph

text: late 5th century CE, when the iconography
label: Paragraph

text: was “modernized.”
label: Paragraph

text: Karli is famous for its interior, in part due to
label: Paragraph

text: its sheer size, but more so because of the
label: Paragraph

text: balanced and measured nature of the overall
label: Paragraph

text: composition of its elements through which Karli
label: Paragraph

text: brings the caitya vocabulary to one of its finest
label: Paragraph

text: resolutions. It is hard to imagine that this is a
label: Paragraph

text: rock-cut building, carved in essence frorn the
label: Paragraph

text: roof downward. The columns (fifteen on each
label: Paragraph

text: side) have fluted, bell-shaped capitals on which
label: Paragraph

text: rests a plinth that supports Mithuna couples on
label: Paragraph

text: elephants looking down into the space.
label: Paragraph

text: Compared to earlier caitya sanctuaries,
label: Paragraph

text: the width of Karli’s central space is much
label: Paragraph

text: more generous in relation to its height and
label: Paragraph

text: depth. The Karli stupa at the rear is no longer
label: Paragraph

text: the incidental center of a crowded array of
label: Paragraph

text: elements, but the focus of a hierarchical
label: Paragraph

text: composition. The stupa itself is relatively
label: Paragraph

text: simple in form. An unadorned hemisphere sits
label: Paragraph

text: atop a slightly tapered base, ornamented with
label: Caption

text: carved vedikas. At the same time, it is much
label: Paragraph

text: bolder than most earlier stupas, as its chattri,
label: Paragraph

text: rising from a rectangular base, or harmika,
label: Paragraph

text: expands into mushrooming tiers of horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: bands. But then it suddenly projects into
label: Paragraph

text: space on a high vertical stambha, upon which
label: Paragraph

text: sits the final chaftri that becomes the focus of
label: Paragraph

text: the entire composition. The chatiri catches the
label: Paragraph

text: light in the dark surroundings and appears as
label: Paragraph

text: a horizontal flash in the vertical composition.
label: Paragraph

text: (The chaittri denotes the umbrella of the
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist ideal under which the monk finds
label: Paragraph

text: shelter and faith.)

text: ANURADHAPURA
label: Title

text: Sri Lanka may have been far from the Silk Route, but
label: Paragraph

text: it nevertheless contributed to trade in an important
label: Paragraph

text: way, since it was the primary regional source of gems,
label: Paragraph

text: such as rubies, that served as lightweight and easily
label: Paragraph

text: transportable currency. The island was also a source
label: Paragraph

text: of pearls, from its western shores, and cinnamon,
label: Paragraph

text: from the wet southern regions, the latter particularly
label: Paragraph

text: important as incense in Hindu rituals. Most of
label: Paragraph

text: these luxury goods could be produced with minimal
label: Paragraph

text: governance by shore-based communities. With the
label: Paragraph

text: arrival of Buddhism in the 3rd century BCE, however,
label: Paragraph

text: the drier and more sparsely inhabited northern part
label: Title

text: of the island was turned into a rice-paddy village
label: Paragraph

text: world dominated by powerful, palace-centered elites
label: Paragraph

text: with strong mercantile interests. They transformed
label: Paragraph

text: rivers into a series of interconnected shallow lakes,
label: Paragraph

text: one feeding into the next, ending in a final, large
label: Paragraph

text: lake restrained by a massive dyke. With sluices
label: Paragraph

text: and canals, the water was then used to irrigate rice
label: Paragraph

text: paddies. The first of these systems was followed by
label: Paragraph

text: many others over subsequent centuries. Soon Sri
label: Paragraph

text: Lanka was exporting not only rice but also its hydro-
label: Paragraph

text: technological know-how throughout Southeast Asia.
label: Paragraph

text: Anuradhapura was at the center of this effort and
label: Paragraph

text: was, in fact, boldly built right below the dam of one
label: Paragraph

text: of the first of these great artificial lakes. The Malwaty
label: Paragraph

text: Oya River connected Anuradhapura to the city of
label: Paragraph

text: Mahathia (modern-day Manner), a major port, trading
label: Paragraph

text: with India, Rome, and Southeast Asia.
label: Paragraph

text: n the context of this booming economy that drew
label: Paragraph

text: in traders from all around, a sapling from the original
label: Paragraph

text: Bodhi tree frorn Boch Gaia, India, was brought and
label: Paragraph

text: planted in the palace compound at Anuradhapura,
label: Caption

text: transforming the city into a spiritual center in its own
label: Paragraph

text: right, one which has retained this status to this day.
label: Paragraph

text: Of past grand palaces of wood, only the foundations
label: Paragraph

text: and the stone columns of ground floors rernain,
label: Paragraph

text: but these are sufficient to give an indication of the
label: Paragraph

text: impressive scale of these lofty, multistoried buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: The city has at least five major stupas, each with its
label: Paragraph

text: own monastic complex: Thuparamaya (245 BCE);
label: Paragraph

text: Ruvanvelisaya (140 BCE), which stands 90 meters
label: Paragraph

text: high; Lankaram (85 BCE); Abhayagiri (final form 4th
label: Paragraph

text: century CE); and Jetavanarama (ca. 280 CE), the
label: Paragraph

text: largest stupa of them at all, at 115 meters in diameter
label: Paragraph

text: and originally 120 meters high. The stupas were
label: Paragraph

text: placed in square, walled compounds. The Sri Lankan
label: Caption

text: architects developed an unusual stupa type, which
label: Paragraph

text: was protected by a wooden domed roof supported on
label: Paragraph

text: stone columns. It is typified at the Thuparamaya. The
label: Paragraph

text: core was built in 245 BCE, but the superstructure was
label: Paragraph

text: added in the 7th century CE.
