text: HAN DYNASTY CHINA
label: Title

text: By the turn of the millennium, the Han
label: Paragraph

text: dynasty (206 BCE-220 CE) ruled an area
label: Paragraph

text: larger than the Roman Empire. The Han
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned Shi Huangdi’s absolutism for a
label: Paragraph

text: more balanced philosophy of governance,
label: Paragraph

text: even though they held on to the Qin idea of a
label: Paragraph

text: unified and centralized China. Emperor Wudi
label: Caption

text: (141-86 BCE) established new commanderies
label: Paragraph

text: in Korea, and his conquest of Ferghana and
label: Paragraph

text: neighboring regions in 101 BCE gave China
label: Paragraph

text: control of the trade routes running through
label: Title

text: the Taklamakan Desert, its gateway to the
label: Paragraph

text: west. In return for its silk and bronze, China
label: Paragraph

text: received wine, spices, woolen fabrics, grapes,
label: Paragraph

text: pomegranates, sesame, broad beans, and
label: Paragraph

text: alfalfa. Under the Han, poetry, literature, and
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy prospered, and the voluminous
label: Paragraph

text: Shiji C’ Historical Records"), written by Sima
label: Paragraph

text: Qian (145-80 BCE), set the standard for later
label: Paragraph

text: government-sponsored histories. By 100 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: trade along the Silk Route began to flourish,
label: Paragraph

text: with caravans reaching Luoyang almost every
label: Paragraph

text: month. International diplomatic exchanges
label: Title

text: became common, including those with
label: Paragraph

text: Emperor Andun (the Chinese name for the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius Antoninus)
label: Title

text: in 166 CE. By the 3rd century CE, paper was
label: Paragraph

text: widely used in China, replacing bamboo,
label: Paragraph

text: wood, and silk slips. Paper was exported
label: Paragraph

text: to Korea and Japan in the 7th century, and
label: Paragraph

text: then to Europe, most likely through Central
label: Paragraph

text: Asia and Arab intermediaries, in the 12th
label: Paragraph

text: century. The existence of water clocks,
label: Paragraph

text: sundials, astronomical instruments, and even
label: Paragraph

text: a seismograph in 132 CE attest to the Han's
label: Paragraph

text: technological and scientific sophistication.
label: Paragraph

text: To the north of Han territories were
label: Paragraph

text: the Xiongnu, who established an empire
label: Paragraph

text: (209 BCE-93 CE) that stretched beyond
label: Paragraph

text: the borders of modern-day Mongolia. The
label: Paragraph

text: Xiangnu were part of another nomadic
label: Paragraph

text: confederation known as Xianbei. By the 3rd
label: Paragraph

text: century CE, these various confederations,
label: Paragraph

text: known by the Chinese as “barbarians,” were
label: Paragraph

text: instrumental in establishing the eastern part
label: Paragraph

text: of the Silk Route. So important was this
label: Paragraph

text: to the Han worldview that they built their
label: Paragraph

text: new capital, Chang’an, at the far western
label: Paragraph

text: edge of their traditional territorial control. To
label: Paragraph

text: populate the city, around 200 BCE the Han
label: Paragraph

text: forcibly relocated thousands of clan families
label: Title

text: in the military aristocracy to this region. The
label: Paragraph

text: purpose was twofold: First, it kept all potential
label: Paragraph

text: rivals close to the new emperor; and second,
label: Paragraph

text: it allowed the emperors to focus their energy
label: Paragraph

text: on defending the capital frorn invasion by the
label: Paragraph

text: nearby Xiongnu. This astonishing break of
label: Paragraph

text: geographical ties was also the first step in the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of an artificial—one might even say
label: Paragraph

text: universal and divine—imperial culture.
label: Paragraph

text: The site was just to the south of the by
label: Paragraph

text: then destroyed Xianyang, the old palace
label: Paragraph

text: city of the Qin. The Han even used one of
label: Paragraph

text: the Qin palaces, the Xingle Palace, as its
label: Paragraph

text: core, optimistically renaming it Changle
label: Paragraph

text: (Long Joy”) Palace. The shape of the new
label: Paragraph

text: city, with its twelve gates, was irregular, this
label: Paragraph

text: having to do with its siting along the river
label: Paragraph

text: and with certain astrological imperatives.
label: Paragraph

text: About half of the city was filled in with huge
label: Paragraph

text: palaces connected by two-story passageways
label: Paragraph

text: with bridges crossing the streets. The
label: Paragraph

text: passageways that linked the palaces allowed
label: Paragraph

text: the emperor to move among the palaces
label: Title

text: unseen. As the city grew, a suburb developed
label: Paragraph

text: to the east. To the west of Changle Palace,
label: Caption

text: the Weiyang Palace was constructed, with an
label: Paragraph

text: immense audience hall. (The word weiyang
label: Paragraph

text: means “maintaining the dignity of the law.”)
label: Paragraph

text: Because the emperors lived there, this
label: Paragraph

text: building had a particular prominence. Like
label: Paragraph

text: the Qin palaces, these gigantic Han palaces
label: Paragraph

text: were built of wood around a solid earthen
label: Paragraph

text: core. The Han also constructed a major
label: Paragraph

text: palace complex west of the city at Shanglin
label: Caption

text: Park, along with an artificial lake, the
label: Paragraph

text: Kunming Chi. The lake, which symbolized the
label: Paragraph

text: world's oceans, had at its center the statue
label: Paragraph

text: of a whale. Very little survives of the vast
label: Paragraph

text: wooden constructions of the Han. However,
label: Paragraph

text: funerary objects placed in royal tombs often
label: Paragraph

text: contained models of structures for use in
label: Paragraph

text: the afterlife. These models show multistory
label: Paragraph

text: timber-frame watchtowers with corner piers
label: Caption

text: and upper levels generally smaller than the
label: Paragraph

text: lower ones, resulting in tapered profiles. At
label: Paragraph

text: each level, widely overhanging roofs and
label: Paragraph

text: balconies were supported by elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: bracket sets and braces.
label: Paragraph

text: Mingtang-Biyong Ritual Complex
label: Title

text: If the Qin capital was designed as a
label: Paragraph

text: microcosm of the Chinese empire, nearby
label: Paragraph

text: Chang’an was designed to represent nothing
label: Paragraph

text: less than the heavens themselves. For the
label: Paragraph

text: Qin, rituals tended to include disparate
label: Paragraph

text: rites from China’s far-flung geography.
label: Paragraph

text: According to the Shiji, the sacrificial rituals,
label: Paragraph

text: known as zhi, were meant to be performed
label: Paragraph

text: on high grounds in forested areas, where
label: Paragraph

text: offerings were made to the four deities of the
label: Paragraph

text: directions, represented by the colors white,
label: Paragraph

text: azure, yellow, and red. The Han multiplied
label: Paragraph

text: the Qin rituals and offered sacrifices to the
label: Paragraph

text: gods of heaven and earth, mountains and
label: Title

text: rivers, the sun and the moon, and the stars
label: Title

text: and the planets, and they built artificial
label: Paragraph

text: replicas of natural altars in the capital itself.
label: Paragraph

text: All of this coincided with the emerging
label: Paragraph

text: notion of imperial power. Unlike in Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: where absolute power was an extension of
label: Paragraph

text: aristocratic privilege and military might, the
label: Paragraph

text: emerging Chinese tradition interpreted the
label: Paragraph

text: power of the emperor as dependent on the
label: Paragraph

text: will of the divine. His actions were seen as an
label: Paragraph

text: integral part of the cosmic order. It was thus
label: Paragraph

text: incumbent upon the emperor to perform a
label: Paragraph

text: certain set of rituals in order to demonstrate
label: Paragraph

text: that he was the rightful emperor—to validate
label: Paragraph

text: his own position within the system, and at
label: Paragraph

text: the same time, to validate the system itself.

label: Caption

text: The building is a diagram of Chinese imperial
label: Paragraph

text: philosophy. The human realm was seen as
label: Paragraph

text: a land mass surrounded by water, with the
label: Paragraph

text: empire in the center, and with peripheral
label: Paragraph

text: territories occupied by barbaric people at the
label: Paragraph

text: edges. At the conceptual center of it all was
label: Paragraph

text: the emperor, who ruled by divine mandate
label: Paragraph

text: and was the Son of Heaven. Frorn this spot,
label: Paragraph

text: the calendar was regulated and its knowledge
label: Paragraph

text: disseminated.
label: Paragraph

text: Over the span of centuries, numerous
label: Paragraph

text: such complexes were built in the various
label: Paragraph

text: capital cities. Few have survived apart from
label: Paragraph

text: the Altar of Heaven at the Ternple of Heaven
label: Caption

text: Complex in present-day Beijing. It was built
label: Paragraph

text: in 1420 during the reign of the Ming dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: Emperor Yongle and is a circular platform
label: Paragraph

text: on three levels of marble stones. Twice a
label: Caption

text: year the ernperor and all his retinue would
label: Paragraph

text: leave the Forbidden City to encamp near
label: Paragraph

text: the altar. Ordinary Chinese were not allowed
label: Paragraph

text: to view this procession or the following
label: Paragraph

text: ceremony. After a highly prescribed series
label: Paragraph

text: of preparations, the emperor would pray to
label: Paragraph

text: heaven for good harvests. The ceremony had
label: Paragraph

text: to be perfectly completed; it was thought that
label: Paragraph

text: the smallest of mistakes would constitute a
label: Paragraph

text: bad omen for the whole nation in the coming
label: Title

text: year.

text: TEOTIHUACAN
label: Title

text: Teotihuacan was the largest and most
label: Paragraph

text: impressive of America’s cities until modern
label: Title

text: times. Located in the highlands of central
label: Paragraph

text: Mexico, Teotinuacan existed for a period
label: Paragraph

text: of eight hundred years, growing from a
label: Paragraph

text: large village of about 6,000 people into
label: Paragraph

text: a metropolis of 150,000 to 200,000
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants around 600 CE, with an
label: Paragraph

text: urban core extending across 20 square
label: Title

text: kilometers. It was the center of an empire
label: Paragraph

text: that dominated the culture and politics
label: Paragraph

text: of even the furthest Mayan city-states
label: Paragraph

text: and kingdoms. Third-century inscriptions
label: Caption

text: on stelae at Tikal and Copan record that
label: Paragraph

text: Teotihuacan controlled their dynasties. They
label: Paragraph

text: may have also influenced the mound cultures
label: Paragraph

text: of the Mississippi. In spite of its size an:
label: Paragraph

text: magnificence, little is known of Teotihuacan’s
label: Paragraph

text: multiethnic inhabitants. Evidence of a writing
label: Caption

text: systern is only just corning to light, most of it
label: Paragraph

text: seemingly destroyed when the city fell. The
label: Paragraph

text: city was a type of “forward capital,” insofar
label: Paragraph

text: as it was an exposed outpost on the northern
label: Paragraph

text: edge of the Mesoamerican cultural realm.
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond it to the north stretched the ari
label: Paragraph

text: wastes of the Mexican plateau. The Aztecs
label: Paragraph

text: were to eventually master that plateau with
label: Paragraph

text: their water systerns.
label: Paragraph

text: The Maya called the city Puh (“place
label: Paragraph

text: of the reeds"), but the name Teotihuacan,
label: Paragraph

text: “the place where men become gods,” was
label: Paragraph

text: given to it later by the Aztecs, who built
label: Paragraph

text: their own capital, Tenochtitlan, farther to the
label: Paragraph

text: @ Copan
label: Title

text: south a millennium later. (The original name
label: Paragraph

text: is not known.) By the time of the Aztecs,
label: Paragraph

text: Teotihuacan, by then abandoned, was already
label: Paragraph

text: a place of legend and mystery. Today, there
label: Paragraph

text: are many ongoing debates about the nature
label: Paragraph

text: of the city and the purpose of its structures.
label: Paragraph

text: Though at its height Teotihuacan was roughly
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary with the early stages of the
label: Paragraph

text: Mayan cities located to the south, there were
label: Paragraph

text: distinct differences between the cultures
label: Title

text: and, so it seems, only minor evidence of
label: Paragraph

text: interaction.
label: Paragraph

text: Archaeologists believe that a four-chambered
label: Paragraph

text: cave, discovered by local residents in the
label: Paragraph

text: early years of the 1st century BCE, marks
label: Paragraph

text: the beginning of Teotihuacan’s rapid
label: Title

text: growth. Caves played an integral role in
label: Paragraph

text: the Mesoamerican religions; they were
label: Paragraph

text: considered places connected with the origin
label: Paragraph

text: of gods and ancestors, as well as portals to

text: The initial construction phase of the

label: Paragraph

text: celestial cycle. The Temple of the Feathered

label: Paragraph

text: The surfaces were decorated with murals. All

text: and its presence at other sites is generally an

label: Paragraph

text: Mesoamerica. The balustrade and fab/eros

label: Paragraph

text: The headdresses, with their prominent
label: Paragraph

text: eyes and fangs, were integral to the military
label: Paragraph

text: throughout Mesoamerica.

text: implies a high degree of social control.

label: Paragraph

text: MOCHE AND NAZCA CIVILIZATIONS
label: Title

text: Two South American civilizations rose
label: Title

text: simultaneously in Peru during this time:
label: Paragraph

text: the Moche on the north coast, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Nazca in the south. (They are known by the
label: Paragraph

text: current names of the rivers in whose valleys
label: Title

text: their ruins are located.) Very little is known
label: Paragraph

text: about their political and social organization.
label: Paragraph

text: The Moche were, however, outstanding
label: Paragraph

text: metalworkers, and both the Moche and the
label: Paragraph

text: Nazca were potters and weavers.
label: Paragraph

text: The Moche Valley on the northern
label: Title

text: Peruvian coast had been occupied for a
label: Paragraph

text: long time. The largest of the pre-Moche
label: Paragraph

text: settlements were made by the Salinar
label: Paragraph

text: (450-200 BCE). The period was one of
label: Paragraph

text: turmoil, and for that reason large protected
label: Paragraph

text: cities developed, one of which, known as
label: Paragraph

text: Cerro Arena, sprawls for 2 kilorneters along a
label: Paragraph

text: ridge on the south side of the Moche Valley,
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking a trade route. Its two hundred
label: Paragraph

text: structures made of quarried granite range
label: Caption

text: from small one-room residences to elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-room buildings. Strangely, the Salinar
label: Paragraph

text: seem not to have built any ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: structures.
label: Paragraph

text: About 100 CE, construction began on
label: Paragraph

text: the ceremonial complexes of Huaca del Sol
label: Title

text: and, 500 meters away, Huaca de la Luna,
label: Paragraph

text: in the center of the Moche Valley. About
label: Paragraph

text: ten thousand people are believed to have
label: Paragraph

text: lived in the neighborhood of these two huge
label: Paragraph

text: platform mounds. As was the tradition in

text: In building this giant structure, the builders
label: Paragraph

text: decided not to construct a single piece, but
label: Paragraph

text: instead placed segments next to each other,
label: Paragraph

text: thus improving its resistance to seismic
label: Paragraph

text: activity. In an earthquake, the independent
label: Paragraph

text: sections might collapse, but the overall
label: Paragraph

text: structure would remain intact. The sides of
label: Paragraph

text: the stepped pyramid were decorated with
label: Paragraph

text: colorful patterns and images. The whole
label: Paragraph

text: was topped by small buildings that forrned
label: Paragraph

text: a sacred precinct. The original name of the
label: Paragraph

text: structure is not known.
label: Paragraph

text: Nearby is Huaca de la Luna, sited at the
label: Paragraph

text: northern base of a tall mountain. Built in
label: Caption

text: six stages, its extension (290 by 210 by 22
label: Paragraph

text: meters) consisted of three platforms and four
label: Paragraph

text: plazas. It is generally believed that Huaca
label: Paragraph

text: de la Luna served as the region’s paramount
label: Paragraph

text: shrine and the setting for ceremonies of
label: Title

text: human sacrifice. In an enclosure behind the
label: Paragraph

text: temple, archaeologists found the remains
label: Paragraph

text: of over forty men, their bones buried in a
label: Paragraph

text: thick layer of sediment, indicating that they
label: Paragraph

text: were sacrificed during periods of heavy
label: Paragraph

text: rain. Sacrifices in periods of drought were
label: Paragraph

text: also evident. The principal deity behind
label: Paragraph

text: this practice was a half-human, fanged god
label: Paragraph

text: often shown holding a ceremonial knife in
label: Paragraph

text: one hand and a severed human head in the
label: Title

text: other. The city’s main buildings were located
label: Paragraph

text: in the plain between the two temples.
label: Paragraph

text: Andean metalworking reached its
label: Paragraph

text: height at this time. It had developed from a
label: Paragraph

text: long-standing metallurgical tradition of the
label: Paragraph

text: Lambayeque region, with its gold, silver, and
label: Paragraph

text: copper mines. Gold had a special status,
label: Paragraph

text: not as money, but as a symbol of power.
label: Paragraph

text: Smiths developed elaborate techniques for
label: Paragraph

text: making and working the alloys, including the
label: Paragraph

text: equivalent of electrochemical replacement
label: Title

text: plating: they dissolved gold in acidic solutions
label: Paragraph

text: so that it would attach to copper surfaces,
label: Paragraph

text: thus creating stronger and longer-lasting
label: Paragraph

text: alloys with shiny golden surfaces. The metal
label: Paragraph

text: was used by priests in headdresses and as
label: Paragraph

text: ornaments, and possibly on the surfaces of
label: Paragraph

text: buildings as well.
label: Paragraph

text: By the 7th century, the site had begun to
label: Paragraph

text: be abandoned. It is thought that a thirty-year
label: Paragraph

text: drought, in combination with devastating
label: Paragraph

text: mountain floods, weakened the legitimacy of
label: Paragraph

text: the Moche rulers.

text: Nazca Lines
label: Title

text: Though the origins of the Peruvian cultures
label: Title

text: are far from clear, it seems that the Nazca
label: Paragraph

text: culture dates back to around 3000 BCE. It
label: Paragraph

text: was an oasis culture at the edge of a shore
label: Paragraph

text: desert. The oasis allowed a thriving culture
label: Paragraph

text: to develop. Citrus fruit and manioc were
label: Paragraph

text: grown on the plains; corn was grown at
label: Paragraph

text: high altitudes and stored in massive silos.
label: Paragraph

text: The Nazca traded up and down the coast,
label: Paragraph

text: as indicated by the presence in gravesites
label: Paragraph

text: of a special oyster shell that came from
label: Paragraph

text: Ecuador and was used by the elites as sacred
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation. At first the Nazca people
label: Paragraph

text: made rock art, as was common to many
label: Paragraph

text: cultures worldwide, but then, making use
label: Paragraph

text: of the terrain, they began to draw figures in
label: Paragraph

text: the desert. Though large, these images were
label: Paragraph

text: easy to make by scraping or removing the
label: Paragraph

text: dark volcanic stones from the otherwise white
label: Title

text: surface of the desert.
label: Paragraph

text: At first it was thought that the lines were
label: Paragraph

text: astronomical in nature, but more recent
label: Paragraph

text: excavations have shown that the lines were
label: Paragraph

text: made to honor the gods as part of elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: shamianistic rituals that focused on ancestral
label: Paragraph

text: memories or weather deities. Though the
label: Paragraph

text: images can famously be seen from high
label: Paragraph

text: altitude, scholars are convinced that they
label: Paragraph

text: were actually meant to be seen from the
label: Paragraph

text: west-facing slopes of the hills that served
label: Paragraph

text: as viewing areas for the rituals that certainly
label: Paragraph

text: spanned many days and were possibly even
label: Paragraph

text: performed with torches at night. The lines
label: Paragraph

text: were not empty signifiers, but paths along
label: Paragraph

text: which ritual participants would walk in the
label: Paragraph

text: context of elaborate dance ceremonies.
label: Paragraph

text: The drawings were made in various
label: Paragraph

text: phases frorn about 500 BCE to about 400 CE.
label: Paragraph

text: At first the drawings showed figures with large
label: Paragraph

text: eyes; then there was a phase when animals
label: Paragraph

text: appeared, serving as orientation points
label: Paragraph

text: for shaman “flights.” Since the monkey,
label: Paragraph

text: hummingbird, and spider were not local to
label: Paragraph

text: the region but creatures from the rain forest
label: Title

text: to the east, the images may have been meant
label: Paragraph

text: to communicate with these animals in the
label: Paragraph

text: hope of bringing rain.
label: Paragraph

text: 7.76 Nazca ground drawing of a spider
label: Caption

text: 7.77 A Nazca figure of a monkey
label: Caption

text: Beginning around 200 CE, the area was
label: Paragraph

text: drying out, and the desert began to spread
label: Paragraph

text: up the once green and fertile slopes. The
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonies that served as a struggle against
label: Paragraph

text: the drought seem to have gotten bigger and
label: Paragraph

text: bigger. Animal shapes gave way to huge
label: Paragraph

text: geometric and linear designs, the scale of
label: Paragraph

text: which indicates that all the Nazca people
label: Paragraph

text: were now involved in these efforts, not just
label: Paragraph

text: the shamans, possibly in order to add weight
label: Paragraph

text: to the ceremonies. People came to the
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrimage center of Cahuachi from far afield
label: Title

text: to participate in these elaborate rituals.
label: Paragraph

text: Cahuachi owes its significance to
label: Paragraph

text: its geographical location: because of its
label: Paragraph

text: geological path, the Nazca River goes
label: Paragraph

text: underground midvalley and emerges at a
label: Paragraph

text: point just below Cahuachi. In a water-scarce
label: Paragraph

text: region, the reappearance of the river would
label: Paragraph

text: have been viewed as miraculous. Cahuachi’s
label: Paragraph

text: adobe platform mounds are much smaller
label: Paragraph

text: than those of their Moche neighbors, and
label: Paragraph

text: they cap some forty low-lying hills overlooking
label: Paragraph

text: the Nazca River. Even after the Nazca people
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned the city in the 5th century, it
label: Paragraph

text: remained an important site for rituals and
label: Paragraph

text: burials.
label: Paragraph

text: NORTH AMAZON SOCIETIES
label: Title

text: Along the border between Brazil and Bolivia,
label: Paragraph

text: researchers have recently discovered
label: Paragraph

text: evidence of mounds, earthworks, and
label: Paragraph

text: even a ring of megaliths used for celestial
label: Paragraph

text: calculations, dating to about two thousand
label: Paragraph

text: years ago. The ring comprises 127 granite
label: Paragraph

text: blocks, each about 3 meters high. This
label: Paragraph

text: indicates that settled societies had by this
label: Paragraph

text: time penetrated the Amazon rain forest along
label: Paragraph

text: the various rivers where fertile floodplain soil
label: Paragraph

text: for agriculture was available in abundance.
label: Paragraph

text: The people who lived here seem to have
label: Paragraph

text: aN
label: Title

text: specialized in planting fruit trees, capitalizing
label: Paragraph

text: on the rich soil quality to survive during the
label: Paragraph

text: dry season and in periods of drought. An
label: Paragraph

text: extensive network of low, water-controlling
label: Paragraph

text: dams indicates the practice of fishing on a
label: Paragraph

text: large scale. In fact, experts now estimate that
label: Paragraph

text: a significant portion of lowland forests in this
label: Paragraph

text: area was organized to benefit humans. It has
label: Paragraph

text: been suggested that the diseases that came
label: Paragraph

text: with the arrival of Europeans wiped out this
label: Paragraph

text: civilization, and that the forest consumed the
label: Paragraph

text: physical traces.

label: Paragraph

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: n Eurasia, the period between 200 and
label: Paragraph

text: 400 CE was noted in particular by nomadic
label: Paragraph

text: incursions from the steppe regions of Inner
label: Title

text: Asia. What prompted this exodus is not
label: Paragraph

text: nown, but the effects were clear. The
label: Paragraph

text: Roman Empire was soon overwhelmed by
label: Paragraph

text: people the Romans called “barbarians,” but
label: Paragraph

text: who were mostly agropastoralists—Saxons,
label: Paragraph

text: Huns, Visigoths, and Franks, arnong others.
label: Paragraph

text: n 441-442 CE, Saxons from Germany
label: Caption

text: invaded Britain. The Visigoths took a more
label: Paragraph

text: southerly route, invading Italy under Alaric |
label: Paragraph

text: and sacking the fabled city of Rome in 410,
label: Paragraph

text: settling down first in southern Gaul and
label: Paragraph

text: eventually in Spain and Portugal, where they
label: Paragraph

text: founded the kingdom of the Visigoths. The
label: Paragraph

text: Franks were moving to the west, to eventually
label: Paragraph

text: set up residence in the area of modern-day
label: Paragraph

text: France. Meanwhile, the Huns who came to
label: Paragraph

text: dominate central Asia, and unified under
label: Paragraph

text: Attila, invaded the Eastern Roman Empire,
label: Paragraph

text: which was beset by internal problems such
label: Paragraph

text: as famine, plague, and earthquakes. In
label: Paragraph

text: 451 CE, Attila’s forces entered Gaul and later
label: Paragraph

text: northern Italy. Indeed, the modern world of
label: Paragraph

text: Europe was founded just as much on the
label: Paragraph

text: legacy of the Roman Empire as it was by
label: Paragraph

text: these various “barbarian” tribes who came
label: Title

text: to claim its land as their own. At first their
label: Paragraph

text: contribution to architecture was minimal, as
label: Paragraph

text: these were chieftain cultures accustomed to
label: Paragraph

text: village life and village needs. Houses were of
label: Paragraph

text: wood and thatch. In some places they took
label: Paragraph

text: over an abandoned Roman villa from which
label: Paragraph

text: in fact the word village derives.
label: Paragraph

text: To protect the empire, Emperor Constantine
label: Paragraph

text: founded a new city, Constantinople, which
label: Paragraph

text: was built around a fusion of Christian and
label: Paragraph

text: pagan motifs. Had that approach survived,
label: Paragraph

text: Europe today would feel more like India,
label: Paragraph

text: with its numerous complex hybrid religious
label: Paragraph

text: practices. But upon Constantine’s death
label: Paragraph

text: in 337 CE, Christianity became an imperial
label: Paragraph

text: religion, as effective in stabilizing the urban
label: Paragraph

text: centers as in pacifying the encroaching tribal
label: Paragraph

text: peoples, whom the Christians called “pagans,”
label: Paragraph

text: a derogatory term meaning something like
label: Paragraph

text: country bumpkins, and from the Christian
label: Title

text: perspective untouched by the grace of God.
label: Paragraph

text: A series of synods were held—from the First
label: Paragraph

text: Council of Nicaea (325 CE) to others in 381,
label: Paragraph

text: 431, 415, and 553 ce—that attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: establish the principles for a unified state
label: Title

text: church. Policy was one thing, enforcement
label: Paragraph

text: another. The Christianization of the empire
label: Paragraph

text: would turn out to be a massive undertaking
label: Paragraph

text: that would last some seven hundred years and
label: Paragraph

text: would require not just that “heathen” altars
label: Paragraph

text: and temples be meticulously destroyed, but
label: Paragraph

text: that competing perspectives on Christianity be
label: Paragraph

text: condemned as heresies and dealt with.
label: Paragraph

text: 8.2 Towers of Silence, Yazd, Iran
label: Caption

text: n this world of religious intensification,
label: Paragraph

text: Christianity injected an altogether new
label: Title

text: concept: the martyr. Since many Christians
label: Paragraph

text: ad died in Rome in the previous centuries,
label: Paragraph

text: that city became a pilgrimage site even
label: Paragraph

text: though it was by now little more than a
label: Paragraph

text: village, located in the extensive ruins of the
label: Paragraph

text: former world capital. People came from afar
label: Paragraph

text: to visit the cemeteries where the martyrs were
label: Paragraph

text: uried. To accommodate the influx, churches
label: Paragraph

text: were built, often directly over the tombs.
label: Paragraph

text: One of these was St. Peter’s. In contrast to
label: Paragraph

text: Zoroastrianism, Buddhism, and Hinduism,
label: Paragraph

text: which made structures that were more or less
label: Paragraph

text: open-air, these buildings, needing to enclose
label: Paragraph

text: throngs of pilgrims, were large indoor spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: The prototype came from the ancient Roman
label: Paragraph

text: basilicas, or law courts, which were usually
label: Paragraph

text: long walled and columnar buildings with
label: Paragraph

text: heavy timbered ceilings. The symbolism of a
label: Paragraph

text: building type dedicated to law was not lost on
label: Paragraph

text: the early designers of these churches. In a
label: Paragraph

text: world where security and lawfulness were at
label: Paragraph

text: a premium, the Church could provide both,
label: Paragraph

text: and with a message of divine deliverance
label: Paragraph

text: to boot. In Roman times, lawyers, judges,
label: Paragraph

text: and clients set up areas in the basilica’s
label: Paragraph

text: colonnades to transact business. There
label: Paragraph

text: were no separate rooms in the building, and
label: Paragraph

text: so there was a good deal of coming and
label: Paragraph

text: going. The apse at one end was often more
label: Paragraph

text: a ritual formality than a site of worship. In
label: Paragraph

text: the Christian basilica, the space was used
label: Paragraph

text: altogether differently. Though the space was
label: Paragraph

text: vast, its main purpose was to enclose the
label: Paragraph

text: devotees and focus on the apse, which was
label: Paragraph

text: now a highly charged space directly over the
label: Paragraph

text: tomb. There were not chairs or pews as there
label: Paragraph

text: are today. Furthermore, when there was no
label: Paragraph

text: service, the space would often be used by
label: Paragraph

text: merchants and traders.
label: Paragraph

text: St. Peter’s was at the time the largest
label: Paragraph

text: interior space in the world. Of all the
label: Paragraph

text: churches from that era that have survived,
label: Paragraph

text: only Santa Maria Maggiore (432-440 Ce),
label: Paragraph

text: though restored, gives us some sense of the
label: Paragraph

text: quality of the interior. The columns lining the
label: Paragraph

text: aisle were not custom made but taken from
label: Paragraph

text: Roman buildings, the art and technology
label: Title

text: of making such columns having been lost.
label: Paragraph

text: The church was built in honor of the Virgin
label: Paragraph

text: Mary, who represented both the imperial
label: Paragraph

text: ideals of classical Rome and those of the new
label: Title

text: Christian Rome.
label: Paragraph

text: In Central Asia, the story of incursions
label: Paragraph

text: from the steppe culture is not dissimilar,
label: Paragraph

text: except that here the deserts and mountains
label: Paragraph

text: belonged to various tribes of the nomadic
label: Paragraph

text: Huns, such as the Kidarites and Chionites,
label: Paragraph

text: who set up camp in Afghanistan and
label: Paragraph

text: Turkmenistan to control the mountain
label: Title

text: passes between Persia and China. They
label: Paragraph

text: encroached into Chinese territory, forcing the
label: Paragraph

text: Jin dynasty to abandon its northern areas to
label: Paragraph

text: a series of small, regional potentates. The
label: Paragraph

text: Jin moved their capital to Jiankang, about
label: Paragraph

text: 260 kilometers to the west of modern-day
label: Paragraph

text: Shanghai. The division of China into northern
label: Paragraph

text: and southern dynasties—parallel to the
label: Paragraph

text: division of the Roman Empire between east
label: Title

text: and west—would last, in fact, until 581 and
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of the Sui dynasty, which
label: Paragraph

text: for a brief time reunited China. But in the
label: Paragraph

text: meantime, during this period large nurnbers
label: Paragraph

text: of ethnic Han Chinese migrated to southern
label: Paragraph

text: China (below the Yangtze River). This
label: Paragraph

text: sinicization transformed the south from a land
label: Paragraph

text: of farming communities into an area with
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly large urban population centers.
label: Paragraph

text: In India, the Gupta Empire (320-550
label: Paragraph

text: CE) created a buffer zone for itself by
label: Paragraph

text: subjugating the Persians to the north and
label: Paragraph

text: the Kambojas to the east. But these efforts
label: Paragraph

text: did not last long. Soon northern India was
label: Paragraph

text: to be controlled by the nomadic Hephthalite
label: Paragraph

text: Empire (408-670 CE), which was centered
label: Paragraph

text: in Bactria in present-day Afghanistan and
label: Paragraph

text: for a while dorninated Central Asia. The
label: Paragraph

text: Guptas seemingly showed little predilection
label: Paragraph

text: for using horse archers, despite the fact
label: Paragraph

text: these warriors were a main component in the
label: Paragraph

text: ranks of their northern enemies. Nonetheless,
label: Paragraph

text: in the 5th century, the Gupta Empire was
label: Paragraph

text: the strongest urban civilization in Asia, its
label: Paragraph

text: prosperity producing a period of magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: accomplishments in sculpture and painting,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as in science and poetry. The Gupta
label: Paragraph

text: capital was Pataliputra, adjacent to modern-
label: Paragraph

text: day Patna; but since it was built out of wood
label: Paragraph

text: and on a river that frequently overflowed its
label: Paragraph

text: shores, practically nothing is left, even though
label: Paragraph

text: it was one of the largest cities in the world
label: Paragraph

text: during this time, dominating the riverine trade
label: Paragraph

text: of the Indo-Gangetic Plain.
label: Paragraph

text: Though shrines in India were then mostly
label: Paragraph

text: made of wood, this period includes the first
label: Paragraph

text: attempts to translate them into stone, such
label: Paragraph

text: as Temple 17 at Sanchi. Its similarities to
label: Paragraph

text: the Greek naos and porch are unmistakable.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps more important was that during
label: Paragraph

text: the Gupta period, popular worship was
label: Paragraph

text: given formal sanction; temples and images
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to the various cults began
label: Paragraph

text: springing up everywhere, releasing a new
label: Paragraph

text: generation of architectural experimentation.
label: Paragraph

text: The old Vedic world, which was not ternple
label: Paragraph

text: based, was now developing into small-scale
label: Paragraph

text: shrine cults that would eventually cohere into
label: Paragraph

text: what we today call Hinduism.
label: Paragraph

text: In Europe, the contestation between
label: Paragraph

text: monotheism (i.e., Christianity) and the
label: Paragraph

text: ancient animism of the Romans and
label: Title

text: their steppe invaders has parallels to the
label: Paragraph

text: contestation between Buddhism and Vedism
label: Title

text: in India, except in reverse. In India, Vedic
label: Paragraph

text: practices carne to dominate because they
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated the figure of the Buddha into
label: Paragraph

text: their spiritual pantheon, mostly without
label: Paragraph

text: sectarian violence. This was not the case
label: Paragraph

text: in Europe, where Christianity, though it
label: Paragraph

text: incorporated some local practices such
label: Paragraph

text: as the Christmas tree, took an aggressive
label: Paragraph

text: posture toward the tribal religions. Unlike the
label: Paragraph

text: newly Christianized Roman Empire, where
label: Paragraph

text: the political and religious elites sought to
label: Paragraph

text: unify the religious message by identifying
label: Paragraph

text: and repressing heresies, Hinduism unfolded
label: Paragraph

text: in various directions, producing a complex
label: Paragraph

text: tapestry of religious and architectural
label: Title

text: responses. Apart from Jainism and other
label: Paragraph

text: more stand-alone religions, there is Shaivism,
label: Paragraph

text: with its many different schools reflecting
label: Paragraph

text: both regional and ternporal variations
label: Title

text: and differences in philosophy, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: Vaishnavism, which is often viewed as a
label: Paragraph

text: synthesis of the worship of the gods Vishnu,
label: Paragraph

text: Narayana, Vasudeva, and Krishna. While
label: Paragraph

text: Shaivism developed mainly in the south and
label: Paragraph

text: southeast; and Shaktism in eastern India
label: Title

text: and in some parts of southwest Malabar;
label: Paragraph

text: Vaishnavism, with its emphasis on Krishna,
label: Paragraph

text: flourished mostly in the northern and central
label: Paragraph

text: parts of India.
label: Paragraph

text: This period includes the first efforts
label: Paragraph

text: to commemorate the pilgrimage site
label: Title

text: dedicated to the life of the great Buddha.
label: Paragraph

text: The Mahabodhi Temple in Bodh Gaya was,
label: Paragraph

text: however, no stupa. Though the current
label: Paragraph

text: building is a 19th-century reconstruction, the
label: Paragraph

text: basic idea of the building seems clear, even
label: Paragraph

text: though its form may confuse an uninitiated
label: Paragraph

text: observer. Unlike the stupa at Sanchi, which
label: Paragraph

text: is a large hemispherical solid, this building
label: Paragraph

text: looks like a Hindu temple. It has a tall tower,
label: Paragraph

text: a shikhara, which would normally represent
label: Paragraph

text: the geometrical model of Vishnu’s mountain
label: Title

text: residence. The enclosed fence-shrine around
label: Paragraph

text: the pipal tree, located just to the west of the
label: Paragraph

text: east-facing temple, has similarities to the
label: Paragraph

text: numerous sacred trees that are associated
label: Paragraph

text: with Hindu temples. The same goes for
label: Paragraph

text: the lotus pond, which is similar to the all-
label: Paragraph

text: important water elernent in Hindu temples
label: Paragraph

text: that represent the sacred ocean. Just as
label: Paragraph

text: Hinduism was adopting the Buddha as an
label: Paragraph

text: important deity on par with Vishnu and Shiva,
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist architecture here represents a type
label: Paragraph

text: of syncretism of its own, combining different,
label: Paragraph

text: often seemingly contradictory beliefs into a
label: Paragraph

text: 8.3 Giant Buddha, Leshan, China
label: Caption

text: new whole. The uniquely Buddhist elernent of
label: Paragraph

text: the Mahabochi Temple is the requirement for
label: Paragraph

text: circumambulation around the temple, which
label: Paragraph

text: is not a Hindu practice.
label: Paragraph

text: During this time we see the expansion of
label: Paragraph

text: Mahayana Buddhism along the trade routes
label: Title

text: between India and China. As Buddhism
label: Paragraph

text: traversed the Kushan Empire (ca. 30-375 CE)
label: Paragraph

text: and the Hephthalite Empire (408-670 CE),
label: Paragraph

text: it came into contact with Hellenism and
label: Paragraph

text: its legacy in figural sculpture. The Buddha
label: Paragraph

text: began to take on human form and was
label: Paragraph

text: represented in various ways as standing,
label: Paragraph

text: seated, or even lying down. A grand example
label: Paragraph

text: is the standing Buddhas at Bamiyan,
label: Paragraph

text: Afghanistan, located at the intersection of
label: Paragraph

text: the Eurasian trade routes. There, colossal
label: Paragraph

text: rock-cut Buddha figures were carved out of
label: Paragraph

text: the cliff face and then dressed and painted
label: Paragraph

text: to give therm a lifelike appearance. Other
label: Paragraph

text: examples can be found at Unjusa, Korea
label: Caption

text: (a Buddha in a supine position); and at
label: Paragraph

text: Leshan, China, built during the Tang dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: (618-907 CE), a seated Buddha 71 meters
label: Paragraph

text: high. The largest Buddha statue in the world
label: Paragraph

text: is the Spring Temple Buddha in Lushan
label: Paragraph

text: County, Henan, China. The statue, finished
label: Caption

text: in 2002, stands 128 meters high. Hinduism
label: Paragraph

text: also occasionally adopted the colossal form,
label: Paragraph

text: as in, for example, the large reclining figure
label: Paragraph

text: of Narayana, the Vedic supreme deity, at the
label: Paragraph

text: Udaygiri Caves, quite likely carved in the 5th
label: Paragraph

text: century CE in the Gupta period.
label: Paragraph

text: At Dunhuang (Mogao Caves), located
label: Paragraph

text: at the western end of the Great Wall—
label: Paragraph

text: where the Silk Route splits into its northern
label: Paragraph

text: and southern arms, winding around the
label: Paragraph

text: Taklamakan Desert—Buddhist monks built
label: Title

text: one of the largest cave cornplexes in the
label: Paragraph

text: world. It represents part of the movernent of
label: Paragraph

text: rock-cut technology from India into China.
label: Paragraph

text: Hundreds of caves, carved out of the sheer
label: Paragraph

text: cliff face, show Buddha, usually seated, but
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes lying down. The caves initially
label: Paragraph

text: served as a place of meditation for hermit
label: Paragraph

text: monks, but soon the priests who lived here
label: Paragraph

text: came to function as a publishing house,
label: Paragraph

text: copying sutras from India for distribution
label: Title

text: throughout China. By the 8th century CE the
label: Paragraph

text: caves had become a place of pilgrimage in
label: Paragraph

text: their own right. One could compare Mogao
label: Paragraph

text: Caves with the martyrium churches in Rome.
label: Paragraph

text: Pilgrimage had been one way in which
label: Paragraph

text: humans accessed the divine, perhaps since
label: Paragraph

text: ancient times when shamans would go to
label: Paragraph

text: mountains to speak to the ancestors. But
label: Paragraph

text: with modern religions, pilgrimages became
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly focused around specific sites
label: Paragraph

text: and were increasingly part of the popular
label: Paragraph

text: imagination. Places like Mogao and St.
label: Paragraph

text: Peter's focused on the lives of holy men and
label: Paragraph

text: the messages they embodied. The fact that
label: Paragraph

text: one person died a natural death and another
label: Title

text: did not produced different types of ethical
label: Paragraph

text: and moral stances.
label: Paragraph

text: The other major religion of the period
label: Paragraph

text: was Zoroastrianism, the state religion of
label: Paragraph

text: the Sassanians (ca. 230-650 CE), who
label: Paragraph

text: dominated the Persian heartland and
label: Paragraph

text: ruled from Ctesiphon, of which little of its
label: Paragraph

text: ancient splendor is left apart from the vast
label: Paragraph

text: central vault of a palace most likely built
label: Caption

text: around 540 CE. It is known that artisans
label: Paragraph

text: of the Roman provinces and masons frorn
label: Title

text: Byzantium helped in the building. Marble was
label: Paragraph

text: brought in from Syria. Zoroastrianism, with
label: Paragraph

text: connections to both the Hindu and Christian
label: Title

text: worldviews, stretched from West Asia to
label: Paragraph

text: western China. The architectural legacy
label: Title

text: of Zoroastrianism is less secure since the
label: Paragraph

text: religion was later repressed by both Islam and
label: Paragraph

text: Christianity. Furthermore, most Zoroastrian
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, like the Sassanian palaces, were
label: Paragraph

text: built of sun-baked mud bricks that today are
label: Paragraph

text: little more than dried-out wall stubs. Their
label: Paragraph

text: surface decoration and painting have long
label: Paragraph

text: since vanished. Nonetheless, across the
label: Paragraph

text: deserts of Inner Asia, one can still find the
label: Paragraph

text: occasional ruins of fire temples and dakhmas
label: Title

text: (“towers of silence”), where the dead are
label: Paragraph

text: left exposed to be consumed by vultures.
label: Paragraph

text: Zoroastrian tradition considers a dead body to
label: Paragraph

text: be unclean, with the corpse demon rushing
label: Paragraph

text: into the body and contaminating everything
label: Title

text: that comes into contact with it. To preclude
label: Paragraph

text: this potential pollution, the bodies of the
label: Paragraph

text: dead are placed atop a dakhma, exposing
label: Paragraph

text: them to the sun and to scavenging birds. The
label: Paragraph

text: towers are usually circular and have a flat
label: Paragraph

text: unroofed surface with raised walls all about.
label: Paragraph

text: he surface is divided into three concentric
label: Paragraph

text: rings: the bodies of men are arranged around
label: Paragraph

text: the outer ring, women in the second circle,
label: Caption

text: and children in the innermost ring. Once
label: Paragraph

text: the bones have been bleached by the sun
label: Paragraph

text: and wind, which can take as long as a year,
label: Paragraph

text: they are collected in a pit at the center of
label: Paragraph

text: the tower, where—assisted by lime—they
label: Paragraph

text: gradually disintegrate. This ritual precinct
label: Paragraph

text: may be entered only by a special class of
label: Paragraph

text: pallbearers. Of the various dakhmas that
label: Paragraph

text: still exist, the now abandoned ones in Yazd,
label: Paragraph

text: lran, are the grandest. The large circular
label: Paragraph

text: enclosures at the top of the hill are visible
label: Paragraph

text: for miles, as were the circling vultures that
label: Paragraph

text: perched on top of the walls.
label: Paragraph

text: Japan, during this time, had its first
label: Paragraph

text: encounter with centralized government,
label: Paragraph

text: following the ascent of the Yarnato clan. In
label: Paragraph

text: this period, in terms of sheer scale, nothing
label: Paragraph

text: competes with the Kofun in Japan. These are
label: Paragraph

text: tomb mounds honoring elite personages that
label: Paragraph

text: are clustered in a vast, sacred landscape. In
label: Paragraph

text: plan, they have different shapes—keyhole,
label: Paragraph

text: square-keyhole, round, and square—though
label: Paragraph

text: the reason for the differences is not known.
label: Paragraph

text: There are over 220 of these tornbs built
label: Paragraph

text: first in the Nara Basin and later in the
label: Paragraph

text: Osaka Plain. The extraordinary quantities of
label: Paragraph

text: weapons and armor discovered at Nonaka
label: Caption

text: Kofun clearly indicates the relationship of
label: Paragraph

text: the elites to military power, which makes
label: Paragraph

text: sense given the uneasy tines in China. In
label: Paragraph

text: total, these structures constitute the most
label: Paragraph

text: extensive mortuary landscape in the world,
label: Paragraph

text: rivaled perhaps only by the Ming dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: imperial tombs of the 15th and 16th
label: Title

text: centuries. Unlike the tombs of the martyrs
label: Paragraph

text: in Rome, these tombs were embedded in
label: Paragraph

text: the ancient shamanistic worldview. Perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: it might be valuable to cornpare these with
label: Paragraph

text: other earthwork mortuary constructions, like
label: Paragraph

text: the Egyptian pyramids, the great tumuli of
label: Paragraph

text: the Europeans (from the Sth millennium BCE
label: Title

text: to the time of the Romans), the kurgans of
label: Paragraph

text: the steppe people in Central Asia, and the
label: Paragraph

text: mortuary mound of China's First Emperor.
label: Paragraph

text: They all belong to the same ancestor-cult
label: Paragraph

text: ethos, though some were made by tribal
label: Paragraph

text: cultures and others by powerful elites as
label: Paragraph

text: a way to cement and demonstrate their
label: Paragraph

text: authority. The Japanese Kofun tradition and
label: Paragraph

text: the Ming dynasty imperial tombs were the
label: Paragraph

text: last great examples of this worldview in the
label: Paragraph

text: form of monumental architecture.

label: Paragraph

text: As Mahayana Buddhism became ever more
label: Paragraph

text: popular, it developed a more elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: liturgical practice that supported a richer
label: Paragraph

text: artistic program. Evidence of this can be
label: Paragraph

text: seen in Ajanta’s viharas, which served as the
label: Paragraph

text: monks’ residences. Over time, the viharas
label: Paragraph

text: at Ajanta changed from simple dwellings
label: Paragraph

text: for the monks to full-fledged ceremonial
label: Title

text: spaces, but the basic form, a rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: colonnaded hall preceded by a portico and
label: Caption

text: surrounded by cells, persisted. The Ajanta
label: Paragraph

text: viharas have a broad veranda, the roof of
label: Paragraph

text: which is supported by pillars that open into
label: Paragraph

text: a central pillared hall averaging about 6 by
label: Caption

text: 10 meters. The cells open to this hall. The
label: Paragraph

text: number of the cells vary according to the size
label: Paragraph

text: and importance of the vwihara. Some of the
label: Paragraph

text: cells associated with particularly significant
label: Paragraph

text: monks were transformed into shrines with
label: Paragraph

text: their own votive Buddha statues {as at
label: Paragraph

text: Caves No. 2, 6, and 17). Some viharas even
label: Paragraph

text: acquired multiple stories (Cave No. 6) and
label: Paragraph

text: circumambulatory routes (usually defined
label: Paragraph

text: by a colonnaded passage). As they began to
label: Paragraph

text: house more ceremonies, they also became
label: Paragraph

text: more ornamental and decorative, with images
label: Paragraph

text: depicting scenes from the life of the Buddha
label: Caption

text: and from Buddhist treatises painted onto the
label: Paragraph

text: walls. A certain nonmonastic sensuousness
label: Paragraph

text: pervades the images, which are not confined
label: Paragraph

text: 8.9 Interior of Cave No. 26 at Ajanta
label: Caption

text: to designated panels. Despite the dim light,
label: Paragraph

text: every surface of the vwiharas was painted over.
label: Paragraph

text: Art, sculpture, and architecture, in other
label: Paragraph

text: words, comingle to create a seamless, sensory
label: Paragraph

text: experience. Structural expression is denied. Like
label: Paragraph

text: the imitation-wood construction present in the
label: Paragraph

text: older caityas, the essential symbolic message of
label: Paragraph

text: the Ajanta viharas was to display the profound
label: Paragraph

text: beauty of the life and world of the Buddha and,
label: Paragraph

text: at the same time, underline its character as
label: Paragraph

text: an illusion, or maya—a fundamental doctrine
label: Paragraph

text: of Mahayana Buddhist practice on the path to
label: Title

text: nirvana.

label: Title

text: By the 6th century CE, Mahayana Buddhism
label: Paragraph

text: had made its way into China and Korea,
label: Paragraph

text: and from there crossed into Japan. Never
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied by the sword, Buddhism was
label: Paragraph

text: spread along the trade routes, benefiting
label: Paragraph

text: from the symbiotic relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: monastic monks and itinerant traders. Traffic
label: Paragraph

text: between China and South Asia in the 7th
label: Title

text: century CE was heavy. (In Chinese literature,
label: Paragraph

text: it is India—not Europe—that is referred to as
label: Paragraph

text: the “Western Kingdom.”) Besides silk, which
label: Paragraph

text: was the prime luxury commodity, South
label: Paragraph

text: Asian kingdoms imported camphor, fennel,
label: Paragraph

text: vermilion, fine leather, pears, and peaches
label: Title

text: rom China. The Chinese, who were muc
label: Paragraph

text: more self-sufficient, seemed to be interested
label: Paragraph

text: mostly in Buddhism. The Han emperor
label: Paragraph

text: Ming-di was the first to officially invite
label: Paragraph

text: ndian Buddhist monks to China to translate
label: Title

text: Budghist sutras into Chinese. In 64 CE, after
label: Paragraph

text: the long and arduous journey, Dharmaratna
label: Caption

text: and Kasyapa Matanga arrived in Luoyang,
label: Paragraph

text: the new Han capital, with a white horse laden
label: Paragraph

text: with sutras.
label: Paragraph

text: The Han emperor built a monastery for
label: Paragraph

text: them called the Baima-si (or the White Horse
label: Paragraph

text: Monastery). Although the current structure
label: Paragraph

text: dates mostly frorn the 14th century, Baima-si
label: Paragraph

text: is by reference the oldest surviving ternple
label: Paragraph

text: of China. In the millennium after the arrival
label: Paragraph

text: of Dharmaratna and Matanga, hundreds of
label: Paragraph

text: Indian monks came to live in China. Not as
label: Paragraph

text: many Chinese traveled to India, although
label: Paragraph

text: those who did were very well known,
label: Paragraph

text: even in their own time, because they kept
label: Paragraph

text: extensive records of their travels and actively
label: Paragraph

text: interpreted Buddhism for the Chinese. These
label: Paragraph

text: include Faxian in the 5th century CE and
label: Paragraph

text: Hsuan Tsang (Xuanzang) and Yi Jing in the
label: Paragraph

text: 7th century CE, both of whom made the long
label: Paragraph

text: and arduous journey to South Asia and back.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Buddhism spread rapidly across
label: Paragraph

text: East Asia, its translation into relevant Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: concepts took time.
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism, however, was only one among
label: Paragraph

text: many competitive intellectual traditions
label: Title

text: prevalent in China at the time. Not everyone
label: Paragraph

text: was convinced that Buddhism was an
label: Paragraph

text: improvement over local Confucian and
label: Title

text: Daoist principles. Confucianists, for instance,
label: Paragraph

text: challenged Buddhism’s inability to set out
label: Paragraph

text: principles of an organized social and political
label: Title

text: order—which was, of course, Confucianism’s
label: Paragraph

text: strength. (Buddhism, in contrast, is
label: Paragraph

text: introspective and personal.) Competition
label: Paragraph

text: between these two divergent philosophical
label: Paragraph

text: traditions remained a hallmark of Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: history for the next two thousand years.
label: Paragraph

text: There were several attempts at mediation—
label: Paragraph

text: most famously the Qing emperor Qianlong’s
label: Paragraph

text: creation of a Tibetan Buddhist model of
label: Paragraph

text: governance, with the emperor in a central
label: Paragraph

text: role, in the 18th century. In general, however,
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism governed the temples and
label: Paragraph

text: monasteries, while the court still operated on
label: Paragraph

text: Confucian principles. As a result, East Asian
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism has a flavor different from the
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism of South Asia and even Southeast
label: Title

text: Asia.
label: Paragraph

text: n 400 cE, Buddhism was supported
label: Paragraph

text: by the Northern Dynasties (386-581 CE).
label: Paragraph

text: In the Southern Dynasties (420-589 CE),
label: Paragraph

text: Confucianism was still dominant, even
label: Paragraph

text: though some learned monks attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: make Buddhist ideas compatible with Daoist
label: Title

text: philosophy.

text: Mogao Caves
label: Title

text: Carved out of the cliffs on the western bank
label: Caption

text: of the Dunhuang River, the five hundred or so
label: Paragraph

text: Mogao Caves document the first millennium
label: Title

text: of Buddhism in China, frorn roughly 300 to
label: Paragraph

text: 1350 CE. As one would expect, the caves
label: Paragraph

text: are located at an important junction in the
label: Paragraph

text: Silk Route, right at the western end of the
label: Paragraph

text: Great Wall. The Silk Route breaks into its
label: Paragraph

text: northern and southern paths at Dunhuang.
label: Paragraph

text: West of Dunhuang begins, or ends, one
label: Paragraph

text: of the most arduous parts of the journey,
label: Paragraph

text: through the harsh Lopnar and Taklarnakan
label: Title

text: Deserts. Abandoned in the 14th century,
label: Paragraph

text: the Mogao Caves were rediscovered in the
label: Paragraph

text: early 1900s, yielding a spectacular find of
label: Paragraph

text: fifty thousand manuscripts in just one of
label: Paragraph

text: the caves. Intentionally sealed in the 11th
label: Paragraph

text: century, this cache held thousands of copies
label: Paragraph

text: of sutras, letters, contracts, poems, prayer
label: Title

text: sheets, and various official docurnents. In
label: Paragraph

text: some cases, there were multiple copies of
label: Paragraph

text: the best-known sutras, handwritten with
label: Paragraph

text: brushes dipped in lustrous black ink on
label: Paragraph

text: paper, establishing that Mogao was a critical
label: Paragraph

text: center for the dissemination of Buddhist
label: Title

text: knowledge. Large quantities of these
label: Paragraph

text: manuscripts were distributed to Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: and European museums before the Chinese
label: Title

text: government intervened and took the rest to
label: Paragraph

text: the national museum in Beijing. The work
label: Paragraph

text: of properly translating these manuscripts
label: Paragraph

text: and understanding their significance is still
label: Paragraph

text: ongoing.

text: The architectural significance of the Mogao
label: Paragraph

text: Caves lies as much in their individual
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics as in their collective presence
label: Paragraph

text: as a marvelous city of caves. Visible from
label: Paragraph

text: a distance in the arid landscape are three
label: Paragraph

text: to five tiers of caves carved into a long cliff
label: Paragraph

text: face, all fairly close to one another. Some are
label: Paragraph

text: small niches with room enough for a single
label: Caption

text: monk to sit in meditation, whereas others
label: Paragraph

text: have lofty ceilings and are large enough for a
label: Paragraph

text: procession of a hundred or so worshippers.
label: Paragraph

text: Changes in dynasties marked new beginnings
label: Title

text: in different parts of the Dunhuang cliff. The
label: Paragraph

text: earliest caves were simple chambers with
label: Paragraph

text: niches and sculptures of the Buddha.
label: Caption

text: By the Northern Dynasties period, the
label: Paragraph

text: caves became more complex and took
label: Paragraph

text: the form of short corridors leading from
label: Paragraph

text: the entrance hall to a transverse chamber
label: Caption

text: with a simulated gabled roof. Opposite the
label: Caption

text: entrance, the principal Buddha image was
label: Paragraph

text: placed against a central pillar, allowing
label: Paragraph

text: the worshippers, as at Ajanta, to perform
label: Paragraph

text: parikrama, or circumambulation, around the
label: Paragraph

text: central image. Cave No. 285 (539 CE) has its
label: Paragraph

text: sidewalls lined with niches in which monks
label: Caption

text: could sit and meditate. Cave No. 428, the
label: Caption

text: bequest of the governor of Dunhuang, Prince
label: Caption

text: Jian Ping, (565-76 CE), is one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate of this period, with each of the four
label: Paragraph

text: niches of the central pillar featuring statues
label: Caption

text: of the Buddha and three bochisattvas. The
label: Paragraph

text: “gabled” roof is divided into panels by bands
label: Paragraph

text: painted brown that mimic the structure of a
label: Paragraph

text: wooden hut.
label: Paragraph

text: Like contemporary caves in South
label: Paragraph

text: Asia, most of the Mogao cave walls are
label: Paragraph

text: covered by paintings describing the life of
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddha and various manifestations of
label: Title

text: Buddhist doctrine. The predominant colors
label: Paragraph

text: are blue, green, red, black, white, and gold.
label: Paragraph

text: Stylistically, the art is an amalgam of Indic,
label: Paragraph

text: Central Asian, and Chinese influences,
label: Paragraph

text: although the overall style is far more South
label: Paragraph

text: Asian than is later Chinese Buddhist art and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: mountains. In their midst, separated by about

text: 1 kilometer, the Kushan emperor Kanishka
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: kind, were destroyed by the Taliban, who
label: Paragraph

text: perceived them as idols.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: valley. To the north toward China and to the

label: Paragraph

text: Bamiyan are narrow and sharp. The
label: Paragraph

text: traders coming upon Bamiyan would have
label: Paragraph

text: encountered a dramatic change in landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: The traders’ attention, however, would have
label: Paragraph

text: been focused on the imposing sandstone
label: Paragraph

text: cliff that rises sharply at the northwestern
label: Paragraph

text: edge of a wide valley. As seen from across
label: Paragraph

text: the valley, the 1.6-kilometer-long cliff,
label: Paragraph

text: pockmarked by the caves, rises to a peak in
label: Paragraph

text: the middle. Behind it, one after another, rise
label: Paragraph

text: successive layers of the Himalayas, with the
label: Paragraph

text: most distant ranges perpetually clad in snow.
label: Paragraph

text: Even from this distance, the Bamiyan statues
label: Paragraph

text: would have been clearly visible and would in
label: Paragraph

text: that sense have conversed with the distant
label: Paragraph

text: Himalayan peaks.
label: Paragraph

text: The bodies of two Bamiyans were first
label: Paragraph

text: cut directly from the stone and then molded
label: Paragraph

text: with a mixture of mud and straw to create
label: Paragraph

text: the folds of the robes, the hands, and the
label: Paragraph

text: details of the face. The drapery was made
label: Paragraph

text: by suspending ropes from the stone surface
label: Paragraph

text: of the upper body. At the base the ropes
label: Paragraph

text: were held in place by wooden pegs and then
label: Paragraph

text: covered over with mud plaster. The entire
label: Paragraph

text: surface was originally painted in gold and
label: Paragraph

text: other bright colors. The outward expression
label: Paragraph

text: of the statues, in particular the folds of
label: Paragraph

text: the garments, has a Hellenic character.
label: Paragraph

text: Precedents for colossal statues date frorn
label: Paragraph

text: pharaonic Egypt and the Roman Empire.
label: Paragraph

text: Most of the smaller caves at Bamiyan were
label: Paragraph

text: covered with paintings, very similar in style to
label: Paragraph

text: those found in the caves at Ajanta.

text: THE SASSANIAN EMPIRE
label: Title

text: With the weakening of the Parthian rulers,
label: Paragraph

text: the Sassanians asserted themselves. They
label: Paragraph

text: were led by Ardashir | (r. 226-41 CE), a
label: Paragraph

text: descendant of a line of priests serving the
label: Paragraph

text: goddess Anahita in Istakhr, Persis (Pars).
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike his predecessors, Ardashir had a
label: Paragraph

text: strong interest in architecture and urbanism,
label: Paragraph

text: and founded numerous palaces and cities.
label: Paragraph

text: The Hellenistic tradition of monumental
label: Title

text: architecture was revised and given its
label: Paragraph

text: own Persian perspective. Ardashir rebuilt
label: Caption

text: Ctesiphon, but little remains, as it was
label: Paragraph

text: constructed using traditional mud brick.
label: Paragraph

text: Elements of a palace made by Ardashir’s
label: Caption

text: successor, Shapur | (r. 241-272 Ce), imply
label: Paragraph

text: that the palace was a massive complex lying
label: Paragraph

text: about three-quarters of a kilometer from
label: Paragraph

text: the western shore of the Euphrates near a
label: Paragraph

text: large loop in the river. Facing west, the Tag-i
label: Paragraph

text: Kisra is an open vault flanked by massive
label: Paragraph

text: walls decorated bottom to top with blind
label: Caption

text: arcades, probably painted originally in vivid
label: Paragraph

text: colors. The vault, known as an iwan, was a
label: Paragraph

text: building innovation of the later Parthian era
label: Title

text: that is found in these Sassanian palaces
label: Paragraph

text: and was to remain an important typological
label: Paragraph

text: element in Persian architecture. Only parts
label: Paragraph

text: of the impressive vault remain. Spanning 28
label: Caption

text: meters, it was probably the largest vault in
label: Paragraph

text: ancient history. It is thought that the arch
label: Paragraph

text: was built without wooden supports during its
label: Paragraph

text: construction. The thin, unfired mud bricks
label: Paragraph

text: are laid on a slant, the weight transferred
label: Paragraph

text: to the massive sidewalls. Architecturally,
label: Paragraph

text: the arch is a pointed ovoid peculiar to
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamia.
label: Paragraph

text: 8.22 Central Asia, ca. 400 cE
label: Caption

text: 8.24 The only visible remains of Ctesiphon today is the great arch, Taq-i Kisra, of Khusrau’s palace.
label: Caption

text: 8.25 Firuzabad and its area, Iran
label: Caption

text: Visitors to the hall during the reign of
label: Paragraph

text: Khusrau | (r. 531-79 CE) tell that the vast
label: Paragraph

text: floor was covered with a splendid “winter
label: Paragraph

text: carpet” of heavy woven silk adorned with
label: Paragraph

text: gold and jewels. Its pattern was supposed
label: Paragraph

text: to represent a pleasure garden with running
label: Paragraph

text: brooks and interlaced paths. Though never
label: Paragraph

text: equaled, it became the model for garden
label: Paragraph

text: carpets. The carpet was confiscated by
label: Paragraph

text: Arab conquerors when they took Ctesiphon
label: Title

text: in 638 CE. Scornful of the display of royal
label: Paragraph

text: luxury, they cut it up and divided it among
label: Paragraph

text: their warriors. But the idea of a carpeted floor
label: Paragraph

text: was soon to become a permanent fixture of
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic mosques. The desolate area of these
label: Paragraph

text: ruins gives little indication of the once lush
label: Paragraph

text: orchards and rose gardens that surrounded
label: Paragraph

text: the building.
label: Paragraph

text: Ardashir's capital was Firuzabad, located
label: Paragraph

text: in an easily defensible valley. At the front of
label: Paragraph

text: Ardashir’s palace was another open iwan,
label: Paragraph

text: flanked by side chambers. To the rear were
label: Paragraph

text: three domed rooms, and behind them, a
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard and garden. The palace lay to the
label: Paragraph

text: south of Ardashir’s planned circular city, over
label: Paragraph

text: 2 kilometers in diameter, at the center of
label: Paragraph

text: which was a large tower that, so it is thought,
label: Paragraph

text: served as a Zoroastrian fire temple. The
label: Paragraph

text: Parthians established other cities as trading
label: Paragraph

text: centers, such as Hecatompylos (Sahr-e
label: Paragraph

text: Qumis) in eastern Iran, but little remains of
label: Paragraph

text: their past splendor.
label: Paragraph

text: Zoroastrian Fire Temples
label: Title

text: It is presumed that Zoroaster (Zarathustra)
label: Paragraph

text: lived around 600 BCE, but no one knows
label: Paragraph

text: exactly when or where he lived or died; there
label: Paragraph

text: remain only traditions. And there is just
label: Paragraph

text: as much ambiguity about the fire ternples
label: Paragraph

text: that were built for the faith he developed.
label: Paragraph

text: Fire was ranked according to its uses, from
label: Paragraph

text: the lesser fires of potters and goldsmiths,
label: Paragraph

text: through cooking fires and hearth fires, up
label: Paragraph

text: to the three great symbolically perceived
label: Title

text: eternal fires of the farmers, warriors, and
label: Paragraph

text: priests. Zoroastrianism was opposed to the
label: Paragraph

text: use of images, and during the Sassanian
label: Paragraph

text: period, cult statues were removed, although
label: Paragraph

text: anthropomorphized divinities remained.
label: Paragraph

text: Further, Zoroastrianism does not prescribe
label: Paragraph

text: worshipping in a temple. Traditionally,
label: Paragraph

text: Zoroastrians worship individually at home, or
label: Paragraph

text: in the open, facing a source of light. When
label: Paragraph

text: they wished to worship as a community,
label: Paragraph

text: they did so in open-air gathering areas
label: Paragraph

text: around a podium where a fire was lit. These
label: Paragraph

text: gathering areas were usually on hillsides
label: Paragraph

text: or hilltops. But as the rituals and practices
label: Paragraph

text: became canonized, the corresponding
label: Paragraph

text: religious architecture was standardized, and
label: Paragraph

text: a complex network of temples resulted. The
label: Paragraph

text: role of the fire in the religious services was
label: Paragraph

text: mainly symbolic and served the purpose of
label: Paragraph

text: consecration, much as the cross does in a
label: Paragraph

text: Christian context. Each king in the Sassanian
label: Paragraph

text: world had his own royal fire. There was a
label: Paragraph

text: prescribed ritual for reigniting the home fire
label: Title

text: from the city fire and the city fire from the
label: Title

text: 8.26 Central fire at the atash-gai in Surakhani,
label: Caption

text: Baku, Azerbaijan
label: Title

text: royal fire. Rituals, together with the rites of
label: Paragraph

text: purification, were in essence all part of state
label: Paragraph

text: bureaucracy. Some have drawn parallels to
label: Paragraph

text: the Hindu caste society and to Mandarin
label: Title

text: China.
label: Paragraph

text: It is difficult to construct a clear
label: Paragraph

text: architectural history of the fire temples since
label: Title

text: only about sixty ruinous examples remain for
label: Paragraph

text: the entire 1,200-year period from 550 BCE
label: Paragraph

text: to 650 CE. At their peak, fire temples ranged
label: Paragraph

text: from Azerbaijan to Osh, Kyrgyzstan, on the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese border. Pockets of Zoroastrian belief
label: Paragraph

text: still linger at Stakhra, 20 kilometers south of
label: Paragraph

text: Persepolis, and even as far afield as Taxila
label: Paragraph

text: in Pakistan. Some of the fire temple ruins
label: Caption

text: belong to the Sassanian era (224-642 CE),
label: Paragraph

text: during which Zoroastrianism flourished as
label: Paragraph

text: the official religion, but others date to the
label: Paragraph

text: earlier Achaemenian, Seleucid, and Parthian
label: Paragraph

text: periods. Many fire temples were built in
label: Paragraph

text: the vicinity of geothermal springs. This is
label: Paragraph

text: certainly the case in Azerbaijan, where
label: Paragraph

text: burning eruptions of gas from the numerous
label: Title

text: mud volcanoes still light up the sky today and
label: Paragraph

text: are linked to the fire temples at Nush-Dzhan-
label: Paragraph

text: Tepe, Adurgushnaep, Surakhany, Pirallahi,
label: Caption

text: Hovsany, Shakhdag, and elsewhere. An
label: Paragraph

text: important fire temple site is Takht-i-Suleiman
label: Paragraph

text: (Throne of Solomon"), near Mt. Zindan in
label: Caption

text: southern Azerbaijan. Tradition has it that it
label: Paragraph

text: was thought to be the birthplace of Zoroaster.
label: Paragraph

text: It is a spectacular site, consisting of the
label: Paragraph

text: much worn crater of a former volcano that
label: Paragraph

text: still spews out blasts of sulfuric air. Though
label: Paragraph

text: little remains today, descriptions indicate that
label: Paragraph

text: 8.27 Fire temple in modern-day Iran
label: Caption

text: the temple was in use for several hundred
label: Paragraph

text: years, beginning from around the 5th century
label: Paragraph

text: BCE. It rose to particular prominence under
label: Paragraph

text: the Sassanians.
label: Paragraph

text: An early fire temple is located near Ani,
label: Paragraph

text: Armenia. It has four massive pillars and no
label: Paragraph

text: walls. At a later period the structure was
label: Paragraph

text: converted into a Christian chapel by the
label: Paragraph

text: insertion of curved walls between its four
label: Paragraph

text: columns. The massiveness of the columns
label: Paragraph

text: suggests a stone roof, but the shape of the
label: Paragraph

text: roof in the reconstruction is speculative.
label: Caption

text: 8.28 A Zoroastrian fire ceremony
label: Caption

text: The demise of Zoroastrianism was sudden. To
label: Paragraph

text: the west, Christianity vigorously suppressed
label: Paragraph

text: it. Islam effectively chased it from the
label: Paragraph

text: realm, destroying its temples and dispersing
label: Paragraph

text: its congregations. Today, most remaining
label: Paragraph

text: believers live in Hindu areas in India, with
label: Paragraph

text: a large community, for example, living in
label: Paragraph

text: Mumbai. There are also residual communities
label: Paragraph

text: in Iran, where there are important fire
label: Paragraph

text: temples in Yazd, Kerman, and Tehran.
label: Paragraph
