text: HINDU RENAISSANCE
label: Title

text: As Buddhism was gaining new converts
label: Paragraph

text: across East Asia, India saw it gradually
label: Paragraph

text: waning. This transition took place during
label: Paragraph

text: the Gupta Empire, when Buddhist practices
label: Paragraph

text: began to fuse with the surviving Vedic
label: Paragraph

text: practices of pre-Buddhist times, creating
label: Paragraph

text: a new and well-organized religion that we
label: Paragraph

text: now call Hinduism. The Gupta revival of a
label: Paragraph

text: transformed Vedic Hinduism was a skillful
label: Paragraph

text: exercise in adaptation and invention. It
label: Paragraph

text: was not a simple revival of pre-Budchist
label: Paragraph

text: Vedic practices. Rather, Vedic institutions
label: Paragraph

text: were reinvented to serve the purposes of
label: Paragraph

text: their new champions. Old fire sacrifices
label: Paragraph

text: were transformed into courtly ritual; oral
label: Paragraph

text: Vedic literatures were rewritten to integrate
label: Paragraph

text: contemporary social and cultural norms; and
label: Paragraph

text: Vedic gods were supplanted by new, more
label: Paragraph

text: agential and personal gods—particularly
label: Paragraph

text: Shiva and Vishnu. Sanskrit became the
label: Paragraph

text: language of the court and the medium of an
label: Title

text: official high culture that revolved around the
label: Paragraph

text: reinvented institution of the temple.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the new Hinduism challenged
label: Title

text: Buddhism theologically, the latter’s
label: Paragraph

text: institutions and practices were assimilated
label: Paragraph

text: into the Hindu temple. Unlike the Mauryas
label: Paragraph

text: and the Han Chinese, the Gupta maintained
label: Paragraph

text: subject kings as vassals and did not
label: Paragraph

text: consolidate every kingdom into a single
label: Title

text: administrative unit. This enabled them
label: Paragraph

text: not only to maintain and profit from the
label: Paragraph

text: trade routes that were still controlled by
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddhists but also to exploit Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: institutions for Hindu purposes. Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: practices were not prohibited—in fact,
label: Paragraph

text: their institutions continued to thrive. The
label: Paragraph

text: interblending of Buddhist and Vedic cultures
label: Title

text: was described by Fa Hein, the famous
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese pilgrim to the Gupta state from
label: Title

text: 399 to 414 CE. He talks of a magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: procession of about twenty wheeled stupas
label: Title

text: with figures of seated Buddhas attended by
label: Caption

text: standing bodhisattvas coming to the Gupta
label: Title

text: capital of Pataliputra, where it was received
label: Paragraph

text: by the Hindu Brahmins and ushered into
label: Paragraph

text: the city with great cerernony. By this time,
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddhists were themselves routinely
label: Paragraph

text: making stone images of the Buddha. In some
label: Paragraph

text: instances, a Buddhist caitya hall would be
label: Paragraph

text: reused for Hindu gods. And in a stroke of
label: Paragraph

text: genius, the Buddha himself was deified as
label: Paragraph

text: another manifestation of Vishnu from the
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu pantheon.
label: Paragraph

text: The basic configuration of the Hindu
label: Title

text: temple can be seen at the so-called Temple
label: Paragraph

text: 17 at Sanchi and the Kankali Devi at
label: Caption

text: Tigawa, both from the early 5th century CE.
label: Paragraph

text: Both consist of a flat-roofed garbha-griha
label: Paragraph

text: and mandapa, linked by a simple stepped
label: Paragraph

text: stylobate and architrave. The garbha-griha
label: Caption

text: (literally “womb chamber”) is usually square
label: Paragraph

text: and unadorned. The mandapa is essentially a
label: Paragraph

text: place for the worshipper.
label: Paragraph

text: 8.31 Section and plan: Temple 17, Sanchi
label: Caption

text: In Hindu worship, the antarala (doorway or
label: Paragraph

text: threshold) between the garbha-griha and a
label: Paragraph

text: mandapa marks the all-important moment
label: Paragraph

text: of transition at which the worshipper and
label: Paragraph

text: the deity come into direct visual contact
label: Paragraph

text: and enact the critical transaction called
label: Paragraph

text: darsana ("beholding of an auspicious deity”).
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, the whole temple can be considered
label: Paragraph

text: a two-way portal between the worlds of the
label: Paragraph

text: worshipper and the deity. In essence, the
label: Paragraph

text: deity descends into the lingam or statue
label: Paragraph

text: while the worshipper ascends to the sacred
label: Paragraph

text: threshold. The deity is considered to be
label: Paragraph

text: a guest in the world of the worshipper. In
label: Paragraph

text: a ritual called puja, the worshipper offers
label: Paragraph

text: the deity food (and, at times, such gifts
label: Paragraph

text: as clothing and ornaments) on a tray. The
label: Paragraph

text: pandit, or priest, who stands at the threshold
label: Paragraph

text: and mediates the ritual takes the food fram
label: Paragraph

text: the tray and touches it to the mouth of the
label: Paragraph

text: deity. He keeps a portion for the ternple,
label: Paragraph

text: returning the rest, with some additional
label: Paragraph

text: special food from the temple, called prasada,
label: Paragraph

text: for the worshipper.
label: Paragraph

text: Another example of an early Gupta period
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu temple is the brick and mud-mortar
label: Paragraph

text: temple at Bhitargaon (400-50 ce). Here
label: Caption

text: the garbha-griha is surmounted by a large
label: Paragraph

text: tapering superstructure, called the shikhara.
label: Paragraph

text: The shikhara marks the vertical axis in the
label: Paragraph

text: form of the cosmic mountain. Its purpose
label: Paragraph

text: is to enable the worshipper to visualize the
label: Paragraph

text: order of the complete universe as described
label: Title

text: Garbha-griha
label: Title

text: Lingam
label: Title

text: Mandapa
label: Title

text: 8.32 Plan: Mallikarjuna Temple, Aihole, India, ca. 8th century CE
label: Caption

text: by Hindu cosmogony. A shikhara, therefore, is a three-
label: Paragraph

text: dimensional model of the Hindu cosmos. All temples
label: Paragraph

text: culminate in a finial, the conceptual center of the
label: Paragraph

text: structure. From there, the “cosmos” splays outward,
label: Paragraph

text: cascading down the building along radial lines. The
label: Paragraph

text: actual geometries of the shikhara are determined
label: Paragraph

text: by its mandala, or astrological diagram. They can
label: Paragraph

text: best be understood, as Adam Hardy has recently
label: Paragraph

text: described, as complex assemblages of mini-temples,
label: Paragraph

text: or aediculae, intended to depict the composite nature
label: Paragraph

text: of the Hindu cosmos. Shikharas are conceived of
label: Paragraph

text: as solid and are for the most part, even though for
label: Paragraph

text: structural reasons some may have internal hollows.
label: Paragraph

text: MAHABODHI TEMPLE
label: Title

text: Bodh Gaya, the garden in Gaya near Patna
label: Caption

text: where the Buddha is said to have attained
label: Paragraph

text: enlightenment while sitting under a pipal
label: Title

text: tree, is one of the most venerated pilgrimage
label: Paragraph

text: destinations of the entire Buddhist world.
label: Paragraph

text: The Mahabodhi (literally “Great Buddha”)
label: Title

text: Temple at this site was begun by Asoka,
label: Paragraph

text: who ordered the construction of a simple
label: Paragraph

text: stone platform, known as the Vajrasana
label: Paragraph

text: (Diamond Throne”), to mark the spot where
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddha supposedly sat. In accordance
label: Paragraph

text: with the nonrepresentational requirernents
label: Paragraph

text: of Hinayana Buddhism, Asoka had no other
label: Paragraph

text: representation or temple built at the site.
label: Paragraph

text: The pipal tree itself is said to have been cut
label: Paragraph

text: down by zealots, first in the 4th century BCE
label: Paragraph

text: and then again in the 7th century CE. But
label: Paragraph

text: a sapling from the original tree, taken to Sri
label: Paragraph

text: Lanka by Asoka’s daughter in the 4th century
label: Paragraph

text: BCE, still thrives. In the late Gupta period, the
label: Paragraph

text: Mahabodhi Ternple (late 5th or 6th century
label: Title

text: CE) was constructed next to the tree. The
label: Paragraph

text: temple has been renovated repeatedly over
label: Paragraph

text: time, and it is difficult to be absolutely certain
label: Paragraph

text: what part of it is original to the Gupta period.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, its contours today are not that
label: Paragraph

text: different from its description by Hsuan Tsang
label: Paragraph

text: (Xuanzang) in 637 Ce.
label: Paragraph

text: Hsuan Tsang recorded that the Bodhi Tree
label: Paragraph

text: was enclosed by a strong, high brick wall
label: Paragraph

text: (originally built by Asoka) 500 paces in
label: Paragraph

text: circumference. Rare trees offered shade,
label: Paragraph

text: while fine grasses, flowers, and strange plants
label: Paragraph

text: covered the ground. The main gate opened
label: Paragraph

text: east toward the Niranjana River, while the
label: Paragraph

text: south gate connected to a large lotus tank,
label: Paragraph

text: the sacred tank where it is believed that
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddha spent a week. The north gate
label: Paragraph

text: opened into the grounds of a large monastery.
label: Paragraph

text: Inside there were innumerable stupas and
label: Paragraph

text: shrines, built as memorials by sovereigns
label: Paragraph

text: and high officials. In the center of the Bodhi
label: Caption

text: Tree enclosure—defined by a stone vedika or
label: Paragraph

text: fence (like the one around the Great Stupa
label: Paragraph

text: at Sanchi)—-was the Vajrasana, sandwiched
label: Paragraph

text: between the Bodhi Tree to its west and, to its
label: Paragraph

text: east, the Mahabodhi Temple, 48 meters high
label: Caption

text: and 20 paces wide.
label: Paragraph

text: The temple was made of bricks coated
label: Paragraph

text: with lime. It had tiers of niches with gold
label: Paragraph

text: images, its four walls were adorned with
label: Paragraph

text: exquisite carvings of pearls, and at its top
label: Paragraph

text: was a gilt-copper stupa. Hsuan Tsang also
label: Paragraph

text: recorded separately that south of the Bodhi
label: Paragraph

text: Tree was an Asokan pillar more than 30
label: Paragraph

text: meters high. The Mahabodhi Temple is
label: Paragraph

text: today clearly similar to this description. It is
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by four subsidiary shrines at its
label: Paragraph

text: corners that were added in the 19th century.
label: Paragraph

text: The central chamber houses the image of the
label: Paragraph

text: enthroned Buddha of the temple. The brick
label: Caption

text: shikhara contains another cella at the upper
label: Paragraph

text: level with a secondary image of the Buddha.
label: Paragraph

text: Along with the Bhitargaon Temple, the
label: Paragraph

text: Mahabochi Ternple is among the oldest
label: Paragraph

text: multistory brick temples in South Asia.
label: Paragraph

text: Although they went out of fashion in India
label: Paragraph

text: once stone temples began to be constructed,
label: Paragraph

text: it is also possible that the development of
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddhist pagodas in China may have
label: Paragraph

text: in part been inspired by Hsuan Tsang’s
label: Paragraph

text: description of this temple, which was widely
label: Paragraph

text: circulated. The temple is not dissimilar to
label: Paragraph

text: the Hindu temple Bhitargaon (400-50 CE),
label: Paragraph

text: and indeed the Buddhist use of Hindu forms
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrates the experimental overlap of
label: Paragraph

text: uring this time.

text: SIGIRIYA
label: Title

text: On the island of Sri Lanka, in 477 CE,

text: EMERGENCE OF CHRISTIANITY
label: Title

text: When Constantine officially recognized
label: Title

text: Christianity in 326 CE, it did not instantly spell
label: Paragraph

text: the end of paganism, and many traditions
label: Paragraph

text: were carried over. Nonetheless, Christianity’s
label: Paragraph

text: monotheism, with its stress on ethical values,
label: Paragraph

text: imparted an authenticity to religious practice
label: Paragraph

text: that previously had been equaled only
label: Paragraph

text: by Judaism, of which it was an offspring.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially, Christianity might have appeared to
label: Paragraph

text: be just another of the numerous Hellenistic
label: Paragraph

text: religions and cults, such as the cults of Isis
label: Paragraph

text: and Dionysus, Mithraism, the Gymnosophists
label: Paragraph

text: of Upper Egypt, and the Theraputae of
label: Paragraph

text: Alexandria. Few could have predicted the
label: Paragraph

text: way Christian beliefs would sweep across the
label: Paragraph

text: Western world as it spread in the footsteps
label: Title

text: of Roman occupation and took hold in Rome
label: Paragraph

text: itself. Constantine, prodded by a dream,
label: Paragraph

text: converted on his deathbed. From then on,
label: Paragraph

text: the Roman title Pontifex Maximus signified
label: Paragraph

text: that the Roman emperor was simultaneously
label: Paragraph

text: the head of the Church and the vicar of
label: Paragraph

text: Christ. As for the Church’s competitors,
label: Paragraph

text: they were folded bit by bit into the Christian
label: Paragraph

text: world—or condemned as heresies. The
label: Paragraph

text: religious pluralism that flourished in the 5th
label: Title

text: century CE, and out of which Christianity
label: Paragraph

text: itself had emerged, ended by the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: 6th century CE. Judaism alone was given
label: Paragraph

text: some leeway, but it, too, was under pressure.
label: Paragraph

text: Christians were forbidden to marry Jews, and

text: ZAPOTECS OF OAXACA
label: Title

text: In a valley formed by the convergence of
label: Paragraph

text: three mountains 480 kilometers south of
label: Paragraph

text: Mexico City lies the dramatic and spectacular
label: Paragraph

text: Zapotec capital, Monte Alban. The entire
label: Paragraph

text: semiarid valley of Oaxaca was inhabited
label: Paragraph

text: by the Zapotec people from 1500 BCE up
label: Paragraph

text: until the Spanish invasion. By 1000 BCE, a
label: Paragraph

text: Zapotec elite had emerged, with connections
label: Paragraph

text: to the Olmecs in the north. By 500 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: the valley had an estimated twenty-five
label: Paragraph

text: thousand residents, making it one of the
label: Paragraph

text: largest population centers in America. It
label: Paragraph

text: was supported by several types of irrigation
label: Paragraph

text: projects, including artificially terraced hillsides
label: Paragraph

text: watered by canals fed from permanent
label: Paragraph

text: springs. The ubiquitous forest of today is far
label: Paragraph

text: different from the tended former landscape of
label: Paragraph

text: the Zapotecs.
label: Paragraph

text: The Zapotecs believed that the universe
label: Paragraph

text: was divided into four great quarters, each
label: Paragraph

text: associated with a color—red, black, yellow,
label: Paragraph

text: or white. The center was blue-green, which
label: Paragraph

text: they considered a single color. The east-
label: Paragraph

text: west axis of the sun was the principal axis
label: Paragraph

text: of their world. Their religion was animistic.
label: Paragraph

text: They believed that everything was alive and
label: Paragraph

text: deserving of respect. As in Hindu cosmology,
label: Paragraph

text: the Zapotecs distinguished living things from
label: Paragraph

text: inanimate matter by the possession of a vital
label: Paragraph

text: force called pee, or wind, breath, or spirit.
label: Paragraph

text: Pee made things move to show that they
label: Paragraph

text: were alive—like a bolt of lightning, clouds
label: Paragraph

text: O

label: Caption

text: moving in the sky, a tremor of the earth, the
label: Paragraph

text: wind in one’s hair, and even the foam on a
label: Paragraph

text: cup of chocolate. Inanimate things could
label: Paragraph

text: be engaged with technology, but those with
label: Paragraph

text: pee had to be approached with ritual and
label: Paragraph

text: sacrifice, especially involving something
label: Paragraph

text: living, like a beating heart. Zapotecs
label: Paragraph

text: recognized a supreme being—without
label: Paragraph

text: beginning or end—with whom no human
label: Title

text: came in contact. It was never represented.
label: Paragraph

text: Humans did, however, interact with natural
label: Paragraph

text: forces, the most powerful and sacred of
label: Paragraph

text: which were Cociyo (lightning), the angry face
label: Paragraph

text: of the sky, and Xoo (earthquake), the angry
label: Paragraph

text: face of the earth—two of the four quadrants.
label: Paragraph

text: Even time was alive and considered cyclical.
label: Paragraph

text: The Zapotecs had two calendars—a solar
label: Paragraph

text: calendar with 18 months of 20 days, plus 5
label: Paragraph

text: days to bring it to 365; and a ritual calendar,
label: Paragraph

text: or piye, composed of 20 hieroglyphs or “day
label: Paragraph

text: signs,” which combined with 13 numbers to
label: Paragraph

text: produce a cycle of 260 days.
label: Paragraph

text: Social structure was stratified into two
label: Paragraph

text: layers: the commoners and the nobility. They
label: Paragraph

text: had different origins. Commoners were born
label: Paragraph

text: of cormmoners; they lived, worked, and died.
label: Paragraph

text: Members of the nobility were descended from
label: Paragraph

text: venerated ancestors; they conducted wars,
label: Paragraph

text: brought home captives, and were buried in
label: Paragraph

text: tombs from which they ascended to the sky
label: Paragraph

text: to become “cloud people.” Men had multiple
label: Paragraph

text: wives, and under ideal circumstances,
label: Paragraph

text: primogeniture was the law.

text: ca. 400 BCE), which consists of a triple set of
label: Paragraph

text: platforms in the southeastern corner of the
label: Caption

text: site. It is decorated by a series of “dancing”
label: Paragraph

text: figures, so-called because they depict men
label: Paragraph

text: in strange, rubbery postures as if they were
label: Paragraph

text: acrobats of extraordinary ability. Despite the
label: Paragraph

text: name, they are probably not dancing. Given
label: Paragraph

text: their closed eyes and exposed, mutilated
label: Paragraph

text: genitals (a sign of ritual humiliation), these
label: Paragraph

text: figures are believed to represent the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: set of rulers subjugated by the Zapotec elite.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 100 BCE and 200 CE, Monte Alban
label: Paragraph

text: rulers expanded their control throughout the
label: Paragraph

text: Oaxaca Valley and constructed a grand plaza
label: Paragraph

text: by leveling an area of 300 by 200 meters. It
label: Paragraph

text: was oriented to the cardinal directions and
label: Paragraph

text: paved over with white stucco.
label: Paragraph

text: 8.71 Aerial view of Monte Alban
label: Caption

text: 8.70 Monte Alban, near Oaxaca, Mexico
label: Caption

text: The huge terraced platforms that are part of
label: Paragraph

text: palace enclosures are on the northern and
label: Paragraph

text: southern ends of the plaza. The northern
label: Paragraph

text: platform, which was repeatedly enlarged
label: Paragraph

text: and modified, has two sunken patios, each
label: Paragraph

text: with steps and platform mounds on axis.
label: Paragraph

text: The southern platform, which was smaller,
label: Paragraph

text: was built by incorporating older platforms
label: Paragraph

text: into its design. The period 200 to 700 CE
label: Paragraph

text: finds the Zapotecs at the height of their
label: Paragraph

text: prosperity, and this is the phase to which
label: Paragraph

text: most of the surviving structures can be dated.
label: Caption

text: In the center of the plaza is a group of three
label: Paragraph

text: conjoined buildings facing east-west; they
label: Paragraph

text: were indisputably the focal temples. While the
label: Paragraph

text: platform of the central temple has steps on
label: Paragraph

text: both sides, it actually opens only to the east
label: Paragraph

text: and consists of a double chamber separated
label: Paragraph

text: by a partial wall and columns. Later Zapotec
label: Caption

text: temples had two chambers: an outer, less
label: Paragraph

text: sacred chamber to which worshippers could
label: Paragraph

text: come, and an inner, more sacred chamber
label: Title

text: where the priests performed their rites. Those
label: Paragraph

text: rites included burning incense and both
label: Paragraph

text: animal and human sacrifice. Priests also
label: Paragraph

text: performed autosacrifice, offering their own
label: Paragraph

text: blood by piercing parts of their body. Some
label: Paragraph

text: rituals involved the use of hallucinogenic
label: Paragraph

text: mushrooms and other drugs.
label: Paragraph

text: There are three large complexes on the
label: Paragraph

text: western side of the plaza, known as L, M,
label: Paragraph

text: and IV, consisting of more platforms, ternples,
label: Paragraph

text: and enclosed forecourts. One platform
label: Caption

text: contains an internal stairway leading to the
label: Caption

text: top of the building; the stairway is reached by
label: Paragraph

text: an underground tunnel that passes beneath
label: Paragraph

text: the plaza to the central range of buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: allowing the priests to reach them unseen.

text: One structure detached from the main group,
label: Paragraph

text: Building J, is a rarity in Zapotec architecture:
label: Paragraph

text: it is set at a 45-degree angle to the site's
label: Paragraph

text: main axis. Its ground plan resembles an
label: Paragraph

text: arrowhead, with the steps forming the blunt
label: Paragraph

text: end. It opens to the northeast and may have
label: Paragraph

text: been oriented to the bright star Capella and
label: Paragraph

text: used for astronomical purposes. A vaulted
label: Paragraph

text: tunnel crosses the front part of the structure
label: Paragraph

text: and leads upward.
label: Paragraph

text: Monte Alban re-creates the Zapotec
label: Paragraph

text: conceptual order on several different scales.
label: Paragraph

text: It is primarily the place of privilege at the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the cosmological landscape. The
label: Paragraph

text: complex also replicates, on a diminished
label: Paragraph

text: scale, the very relationship of the escarpment
label: Paragraph

text: on which Monte Alban was built to the larger
label: Paragraph

text: valley of Oaxaca, with the main ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: temple in the middle surrounded by a
label: Paragraph

text: “mountainous” ring of platform mounds. The
label: Paragraph

text: sunken patios in the north platform repeat
label: Caption

text: the order of a valley surrounded by pyramids,
label: Paragraph

text: again with a central platform. Unlike the
label: Paragraph

text: artificial mountain volcanoes of the Olmecs,
label: Paragraph

text: the Zapotecs created here a miniaturized
label: Paragraph

text: landscape that is both a sacred geography
label: Paragraph

text: and its representation.
label: Paragraph

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: The economic world of 600 CE was restricted
label: Paragraph

text: in scope. India and China were prospering,
label: Paragraph

text: however, and Southeast Asia, Korea, and
label: Paragraph

text: Japan were emerging as economic forces.
label: Paragraph

text: That narrow part of the world produced
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps 90 percent of the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: innovations of the time. Europe was in a state
label: Paragraph

text: of disarray as its lands were being carved
label: Paragraph

text: up by various tribes—the Visigoths, Franks,
label: Paragraph

text: Lombards, Saxons, Avars, and Danes, among
label: Paragraph

text: others. Most of these were agropastoral
label: Paragraph

text: village societies that produced small fortified
label: Paragraph

text: settlements of wooden construction. This
label: Paragraph

text: left the eastern part of the former Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Empire, Byzantium, as a relatively isolated
label: Paragraph

text: hotspot of cosmopolitan, urban life.
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantium had a leader of extraordinary
label: Paragraph

text: charisma, Justinian (482-565), who violently
label: Paragraph

text: suppressed dissent while pursuing a policy
label: Title

text: of Mediterranean conquest. During his rule
label: Paragraph

text: a host of astonishing buildings appeared:
label: Paragraph

text: the Church of the Holy Apostles (534), SS.
label: Caption

text: Sergius and Bacchus (ca. 535), the Church
label: Paragraph

text: of Hagia Irene (ca. 530s), and a 140-meter-
label: Paragraph

text: long cistern. But nothing compared to the
label: Paragraph

text: Hagia Sophia, which was begun around 532.
label: Paragraph

text: This remarkable building, its inner finish
label: Paragraph

text: considerably diminished today, was the
label: Paragraph

text: greatest engineering marvel of the age. The
label: Paragraph

text: dome, the first to rival that of the Pantheon,
label: Paragraph

text: was completely of brick, concrete having
label: Paragraph

text: by now become a lost art. But its structural
label: Paragraph

text: sophistications were designed to be invisible
label: Paragraph

text: to observers, who marveled at its gilded inner
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces shimmering in the mottled light from
label: Paragraph

text: distant windows and suspended candelabras.
label: Caption

text: 9.2 Interior of St. Hripsime Temple, Echmiadzin, Armenia
label: Caption

text: The Byzantine Empire, however, was not on
label: Paragraph

text: sure footing. A “black death,” the Plague
label: Paragraph

text: of Justinian (541-542 ce), killed perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: 40 percent of Byzantium’s inhabitants
label: Title

text: and caused the deaths of up to a quarter
label: Paragraph

text: of the human population of the eastern
label: Title

text: Mediterranean. Vast stretches of territory
label: Paragraph

text: were left uninhabited. The long-term effects
label: Paragraph

text: were enormous. Justinian’s death in 578 CE
label: Paragraph

text: added to the problems of an empire that was
label: Paragraph

text: in more or less continuous battle with the
label: Paragraph

text: Persians and then the Arabs. The withdrawal
label: Paragraph

text: of large numbers of troops from the Balkans
label: Paragraph

text: to defend the southern borders opened the
label: Paragraph

text: door even more for the southward expansion
label: Title

text: of Slavic peoples into the Mediterranean
label: Title

text: zone. In 568 CE the Lombards invaded Italy
label: Paragraph

text: with little opposition from Byzantium, and
label: Paragraph

text: thus began the fragmentation of Italy. By
label: Paragraph

text: 650 CE Byzantium had lost all of its southern
label: Paragraph

text: provinces and could from then on only bask
label: Paragraph

text: in its former glory.
label: Paragraph

text: Throughout this period, the Armenians,
label: Paragraph

text: remote from the pestilence of the ports,
label: Paragraph

text: were pushing ahead with an amazing
label: Paragraph

text: building campaign. They alone in the world
label: Paragraph

text: were still building high-end stone masonry
label: Paragraph

text: buildings with techniques from the Greeks.
label: Paragraph

text: These buildings include the Church of Saint
label: Paragraph

text: Gayane and the Cathedral of Mren, both
label: Paragraph

text: from the 630s and both three-nave domed
label: Caption

text: basilicas with an octagonal drum resting on
label: Paragraph

text: four internal pillars. But the greatest of these
label: Paragraph

text: Armenian buildings was Zvartnots Cathedral
label: Paragraph

text: (643-652 CE), located at the edge of the city
label: Paragraph

text: of Echmiadzin. It had an extraordinary plan.
label: Paragraph

text: he core consisted of four lobes emanating
label: Paragraph

text: rom triangular-shaped piers. The whole was
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by a thirty-two-sided polygon,
label: Paragraph

text: which appears circular from a distance. Its
label: Paragraph

text: elevation is not known, but it is surmised to
label: Paragraph

text: ave risen three stories. Apart frorn copper,
label: Paragraph

text: the Armenians had little to offer economically,
label: Paragraph

text: so most of their wealth came from overland
label: Paragraph

text: trade. They were an important, stable lin
label: Paragraph

text: tween East and West. One could compare
label: Paragraph

text: them with the Srivijayan Empire in Southeast
label: Paragraph

text: Asia, which served as the link between India
label: Paragraph

text: and China.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, the Persian Sassanians in the
label: Paragraph

text: lranian heartland were no longer in a position
label: Paragraph

text: to contribute to the building arts. Their land
label: Paragraph

text: was in disarray largely because of rigid social
label: Paragraph

text: stratification, the increasing power of the
label: Paragraph

text: provincial landholders, and a rapid turnover
label: Paragraph

text: of rulers, all of which allowed the restive Arab
label: Paragraph

text: tribes to seek greater autonomy. By 640 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: the Arabs, newly united by Islam, began
label: Paragraph

text: to assert themselves and make impressive
label: Paragraph

text: territorial claims. By 651 CE, the Sassanian
label: Paragraph

text: Empire had collapsed and was replace by the
label: Paragraph

text: Rashidun Islamic caliphate (632-661 CE),
label: Paragraph

text: which soon stretched cross a vast territory
label: Paragraph

text: from Afghanistan to Morocco, and which was
label: Paragraph

text: succeeded by the even more wealthy and
label: Paragraph

text: powerful Umayyad caliphate (661-750 CE).
label: Paragraph

text: In India, the situation was altogether less
label: Paragraph

text: volatile. Despite the decline of the Gupta
label: Paragraph

text: dynasty in the 6th century CE, the newly
label: Paragraph

text: emerging small kingdoms all tried to assert
label: Paragraph

text: their regional control, leading to a period
label: Paragraph

text: of prolific temple building. One of these
label: Paragraph

text: kingdoms was the Pallavas in the south.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pallava’s wealth was generated from
label: Paragraph

text: trade to the east through their port city of
label: Paragraph

text: Mamallapuram, a sacred city and pilgrimage
label: Title

text: site. Mamallapuram came to host an amazing
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of rock-cut temples carved along
label: Caption

text: the slope of a nearby hill, connected to an
label: Paragraph

text: artificial (though now largely dry) channel that
label: Paragraph

text: represents the Ganges River. It was designed
label: Paragraph

text: as a model of the Hindu sacred landscape
label: Paragraph

text: and so was just as much a religious as an
label: Paragraph

text: economic destination, as was typical in the
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu world.
label: Paragraph

text: In 700 CE in Mamallapuram, one of
label: Paragraph

text: the first stone-built buildings in India, the
label: Paragraph

text: Shore Temple, was constructed. It is a
label: Paragraph

text: type of elaboration of Dharmaraja Ratha,
label: Paragraph

text: located about 5 kilometers away, which was
label: Paragraph

text: not stone-built but one of several rock-cut
label: Paragraph

text: experimental temples known cumulatively
label: Title

text: as Pancha Rathas (ca. 650 CE). These were
label: Paragraph

text: carved, one next to the other, to study, so it
label: Paragraph

text: seems, different potential ternple forms. The
label: Paragraph

text: Pancha Rathas experiment is unique in the
label: Paragraph

text: history of architecture. But what prompted
label: Paragraph

text: the change from rock-cut to built-up? Was
label: Paragraph

text: there some connection to the Armenians,
label: Paragraph

text: who were the best stonemasons in the world
label: Paragraph

text: at the time, and who in these times of trouble
label: Paragraph

text: were certainly leaving their homeland looking
label: Paragraph

text: for work? Or was it a more homegrown
label: Paragraph

text: transformation?
label: Title

text: 9.3 Shore Temple, Mahabalipuram, India
label: Caption

text: During this time, the process known as
label: Paragraph

text: Indianization was expanding India’s economic
label: Paragraph

text: reach into Southeast Asia, which was slowly
label: Paragraph

text: being transformed into a series of regional
label: Paragraph

text: rice-producing centers. Indianization
label: Paragraph

text: describes a process where monks, engineers,
label: Paragraph

text: and officials created temple/city communities
label: Title

text: that slowly drew converts from among the
label: Paragraph

text: locals, who eventually created nascent
label: Paragraph

text: states. In Myanmar (Burma) along the
label: Paragraph

text: Irrawaddy River, we see, for example, the
label: Paragraph

text: rise of the Sri Ksetra kingdom, which was
label: Paragraph

text: settled by adherents of Theravada Buddhism,
label: Paragraph

text: indicating a close connection to Sri Lanka,
label: Paragraph

text: one of the earliest centers of rice paddy
label: Paragraph

text: irrigation in the world. The lucrative trade
label: Paragraph

text: also led to the creation, around 500 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: of the Srivijayan Empire near present-day
label: Paragraph

text: Palembang, Sumatra, in Indonesia. The
label: Paragraph

text: Srivijayan controlled the Straits of Malacca,
label: Paragraph

text: through which all ships traveling between
label: Paragraph

text: India and China had to pass. Along with
label: Paragraph

text: the Srivijayan, other states emerged, such
label: Paragraph

text: as Dvaravanti (more or less in modern-
label: Paragraph

text: day Thailand), the Chenla (more or less in
label: Paragraph

text: modern-day Cambodia), and the Champa
label: Paragraph

text: (more or less in modern-day Vietnam),
label: Paragraph

text: each of which was beginning to develop an
label: Paragraph

text: extensive rice-producing export economy and
label: Paragraph

text: an architecture of sacred landscapes to go
label: Title

text: along with it.
label: Paragraph

text: Based on the regional strength of this
label: Paragraph

text: economy, T’ang dynasty China built one of
label: Paragraph

text: the greatest cities of the time, Daxing. The
label: Paragraph

text: first cities of China were what one might call
label: Paragraph

text: palace cities linked to a court culture and the
label: Paragraph

text: needs of the court. The development of the
label: Paragraph

text: centralized imperial government in the Han
label: Title

text: dynasty (206 BCE-220 CE) and later in the
label: Paragraph

text: T'ang dynasty (618-906 CE) gave rise to large
label: Paragraph

text: capital cities that were metropolitan in nature,
label: Paragraph

text: with population concentrations of one million
label: Paragraph

text: or more people. These megacities have to
label: Paragraph

text: be seen somewhat differently from cities in
label: Paragraph

text: other places of the world. The concentration
label: Paragraph

text: of large populations into a city was a way
label: Paragraph

text: to keep power under imperial control. This
label: Paragraph

text: is true for many large cities, but unlike the
label: Paragraph

text: ancient city of Rome—which expanded over
label: Paragraph

text: time into a dense urban labyrinth with almost
label: Paragraph

text: no planning, despite what one might assume
label: Paragraph

text: about the Romans—the Chinese capitals
label: Title

text: were designed from the outset as a spatial
label: Paragraph

text: imprint of imperial rule. They were low in
label: Paragraph

text: density, composed mainly of mud-brick and
label: Paragraph

text: thatch structures with gardens, pigsties, and
label: Paragraph

text: animal pens. In many parts the city would
label: Paragraph

text: have appeared as a compressed village.
label: Paragraph

text: For this reason, when there was a change
label: Paragraph

text: of imperial control, capitals were usually
label: Paragraph

text: destroyed and depopulated. Hundreds of
label: Paragraph

text: thousands of people were displaced and
label: Paragraph

text: resettled in new capitals. This created huge
label: Paragraph

text: temporal disruptions in Chinese history.
label: Paragraph

text: With the collapse of a single unifying
label: Paragraph

text: power, as during the Three Kingdom period
label: Paragraph

text: 220-265 CE between the Han and T'ang
label: Title

text: dynasties, three new capital cities were built.
label: Paragraph

text: This gave the Chinese a lot of experience
label: Paragraph

text: in designing cities at a great scale. The
label: Paragraph

text: history of the Daxing site is complex, for
label: Paragraph

text: Daxing is actually the third capital city on
label: Paragraph

text: that site. The first city, Xianyang, to the
label: Paragraph

text: north of the Wei River, was founded by the
label: Paragraph

text: Qin dynasty (221-206 BCE). Because the
label: Paragraph

text: city lay south of the Jiuzong Mountains and
label: Paragraph

text: north of the Wei River—both sunlight-rich
label: Paragraph

text: (yang) orientations—it was named Xianyang,
label: Paragraph

text: meaning “fully yang” or “the side that is full
label: Paragraph

text: of sun.” When the city was destroyed in a
label: Paragraph

text: flood in 202 BCE, the new capital, Chang'an
label: Paragraph

text: (“Perpetual Peace”), was built to the south of
label: Paragraph

text: the river by the Han dynasty. It was destroyed
label: Paragraph

text: in 24 BCE. Subsequent dynasties moved the
label: Paragraph

text: capital to Chengdu, Pingcheng, and Luoyang.
label: Paragraph

text: During the T’ang dynasty (618-907 CE),
label: Paragraph

text: Chang'an was made the capital again, this
label: Paragraph

text: time at a scale that was grand even for the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese. It was not sited over the ruins of the
label: Paragraph

text: old city, but just to its south. Its name was
label: Paragraph

text: Daxing (“Great Prosperity") (680-904 CE).
label: Paragraph

text: Colloquially, it was called Chang’an, leading
label: Paragraph

text: to some confusion, but it was built ex nihilo.
label: Paragraph

text: Very little is left of Daxing except for a few
label: Paragraph

text: pagodas. It is a sad fate for one of the great
label: Paragraph

text: cities of history. Today the sprawling modern
label: Paragraph

text: city of Xi'an lies over the ancient capital.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the few remnants of Daxing is the
label: Paragraph

text: Giant Wild Goose Pagoda (649-683 CE) that
label: Paragraph

text: was originally built at a height of 54 meters
label: Paragraph

text: 9.4 Sacred Grove at Futarasan Shrine, Nikko, Japan
label: Caption

text: and had a rammed earth core with a stone
label: Paragraph

text: exterior facade. After it collapsed, it was
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilt in brick (704), although an earthquake
label: Paragraph

text: in 1556 reduced its height frorn ten stories
label: Paragraph

text: to seven stories. One of the pagoda’s many
label: Paragraph

text: unctions was to hold sutras and figurines
label: Paragraph

text: of the Buddha that were brought to China
label: Paragraph

text: rom India by the Buddhist translator and
label: Title

text: traveler Hsuan Tsang (Xuanzang). To feed
label: Paragraph

text: the population, the Chinese built canals that
label: Paragraph

text: inked in the north-south direction its various
label: Paragraph

text: east-west flowing rivers. The Sui dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: (581-618 CE) made major contributions
label: Paragraph

text: to that effort. It was not just rice that was
label: Paragraph

text: rought in from the south, but also vast
label: Paragraph

text: amounts of bricks and lumber.
label: Paragraph

text: The arrival of Buddhism in Korea in the
label: Paragraph

text: 4th century and in Japan in the 6th century
label: Title

text: rought with it the arrival of the monumental
label: Paragraph

text: architectural forms that had been developed
label: Paragraph

text: in China. Monks, architects, engineers, and
label: Paragraph

text: even bureaucrats arrived hand in hand. One
label: Paragraph

text: of the earliest Buddhist structures in Japan
label: Paragraph

text: is Yakushi-ji (Healing Buddha Temple), built
label: Paragraph

text: in Fujiwara-kyo, Japan's capital in the Asuka
label: Paragraph

text: period (538-710 CE), when Japan was ruled
label: Paragraph

text: by great clans and their extended families.
label: Paragraph

text: But whereas the story often focuses
label: Paragraph

text: on Buddhism, since that left a relatively
label: Paragraph

text: permanent architectural record, the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of Japan must be viewed in
label: Paragraph

text: larger geopolitical terms. It paralleled the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of Southeast Asia as a rice
label: Title

text: producing/exporting area. In both cases,
label: Paragraph

text: rice was elevated into the status of a deity,
label: Paragraph

text: and in both cases powerful leaders emerged
label: Paragraph

text: who mastered the politics necessary to
label: Paragraph

text: control the intermixed realities of devotion,
label: Paragraph

text: production, storage, and trade, while at the
label: Paragraph

text: same time living at the behest and blessing
label: Paragraph

text: of deities whom they served. But whereas
label: Paragraph

text: by the 9th century the Khmer in Cambodia
label: Paragraph

text: would force the forest to yield to the needs
label: Paragraph

text: of a Hindu-based agricultural worldview, in
label: Paragraph

text: Japan an assimilation occurred between the
label: Paragraph

text: still-new rice-centric culture and the ancient
label: Title

text: local traditions associated with Shintoism.
label: Paragraph

text: Shintoisrn was not replaced; it simply
label: Paragraph

text: expanded to include a new and powerful
label: Paragraph

text: deity known as Inari, the rice god. Rice
label: Paragraph

text: granaries, elevated on platforms, became a
label: Paragraph

text: form of sacred architecture, and with the rise
label: Paragraph

text: of imperial clans the granary rose to the level
label: Paragraph

text: of state symbol, with no building representing
label: Paragraph

text: this better than the Ise Shrine.
label: Paragraph

text: The word Shinto, which can be translated
label: Paragraph

text: as “the way of the gods,” was coined in the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century to identify it as a religion distinct
label: Paragraph

text: from Buddhism. Prior to then Shintoism was
label: Paragraph

text: so fundamental to Japanese life and culture
label: Title

text: that it had no name apart from the names for
label: Paragraph

text: the various cultic procedures, ceremonies,
label: Paragraph

text: and shamanistic rituals. It was a belief system
label: Paragraph

text: that stretched back to early humanity and
label: Paragraph

text: was characterized by the worship in Japan of
label: Paragraph

text: kami, which can be defined as the “spirits”
label: Paragraph

text: of mountains, rivers, lightning, wind, waves,
label: Paragraph

text: trees, and even rocks. Kami and humans
label: Paragraph

text: exist in a shared continuum. Nonetheless, the
label: Paragraph

text: kami, as innate supernatural forces residing
label: Paragraph

text: in all things, are above the actions of man.
label: Paragraph

text: Certain localities, such as sacred groves,
label: Paragraph

text: or special stones are viewed as particularly
label: Paragraph

text: propitious for the meeting of humans with
label: Paragraph

text: the spirit of kami and are therefore held to
label: Paragraph

text: be sacred. There are several such groves still
label: Paragraph

text: existing in Japan, such as the 20-hectare
label: Paragraph

text: wooded area Atsuta-ku in the city of Nagoya.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike modern monotheistic religious
label: Paragraph

text: practices, Shintoism does not require those
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The time period between Constantine
label: Title

text: the Great (272-337 CE) and Justinian
label: Title

text: (483-565 CE) was one of consolidation. For
label: Paragraph

text: Justinian, the Romanum Imperium was to
label: Paragraph

text: be identified with the Christian ofkourmene
label: Paragraph

text: (the known inhabited areas of the world),
label: Paragraph

text: and the triumph of Christianity was as
label: Paragraph

text: sacred a mission as the restoration of Roman
label: Title

text: supremacy. To this end, he reintroduced
label: Paragraph

text: Roman law, but with the dogmatic primacy
label: Paragraph

text: peculiar to the Christian religion. All other
label: Paragraph

text: religions were denied legal protection. Pagan
label: Paragraph

text: temples were torn down and strict laws
label: Paragraph

text: passed to consolidate and unify the Christian
label: Paragraph

text: domination of the empire. In 529 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: Justinian closed the Academy in Athens,
label: Paragraph

text: largely to stem the multiplication of ideas and
label: Paragraph

text: theories in theological debates and to enforce
label: Title

text: a unified doctrine. Many of its scholars had
label: Paragraph

text: to seek refuge in Persia, taking with them the
label: Paragraph

text: fruits of Greek learning.
label: Paragraph

text: Justinian was able to recover Italy and
label: Paragraph

text: Africa. Bridges, fortifications, aqueducts,
label: Caption

text: churches, markets, and whole cities sprang
label: Title

text: up in the wake of his conquests. But the
label: Paragraph

text: situation was tenuous. Eastern Europe was
label: Paragraph

text: still in turmoil, with the Avars and Bulgars
label: Paragraph

text: moving into Greece and the Lombards
label: Title

text: into northern Italy. The newly Christianized
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: An excellent example of Justinian’s

text: in the church dedicated to Sergius and
label: Caption

text: Bacchus, two soldiers in the Roman
label: Title

text: army who were martyred in the early 4th
label: Title

text: century CE and became the official patrons of
label: Paragraph

text: the Byzantine armies. Certain changes to its
label: Paragraph

text: environs should, however, be kept in mind.
label: Paragraph

text: The building, now a freestanding structure,
label: Paragraph

text: was originally part of a larger complex that
label: Paragraph

text: included Justinian’s private residence and
label: Paragraph

text: palace. Furthermore, the slightly thicker walls
label: Paragraph

text: to the south belonged to another church
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to St. Peter and St. Paul, begun in
label: Caption

text: 518 CE and built by Justinian’s uncle, Justin
label: Paragraph

text: |. When Justinian became Caesar in 525 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: he appended the new construction onto that
label: Paragraph

text: one.
label: Paragraph

text: The two churches were connected at
label: Paragraph

text: ground level by means of three large arched
label: Caption

text: openings that later changed into windows
label: Paragraph

text: when the Church of SS. Peter and Paul
label: Paragraph

text: was removed. (Such church composites
label: Paragraph

text: were not uncommon in the East, though
label: Paragraph

text: they were rare in the West.) The narthex on
label: Paragraph

text: the west extended across both churches,
label: Paragraph

text: which shared a common atrium in front.
label: Paragraph

text: To the north was a monumental entrance,
label: Paragraph

text: presumably from the former palace, creating
label: Paragraph

text: a cross-axis from north to south linking
label: Paragraph

text: the two buildings. For reasons unknown,
label: Paragraph

text: the Church of SS. Peter and Paul fell into
label: Paragraph

text: disrepair and was demolished; by the 16th
label: Paragraph

text: century, it was gone, as were most of the
label: Paragraph

text: remnants of Justinian’s palace.
label: Paragraph

text: SS. Sergius and Bacchus's original context
label: Paragraph

text: is important, as it explains sorne of the
label: Paragraph

text: curious—and also sometimes overlooked—
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of its design. To provide an entrance
label: Paragraph

text: for the priests from the southwest into the
label: Paragraph

text: apse at the back of the church, the eastern
label: Caption

text: facade was tilted a bit, with the space left for
label: Paragraph

text: a porch perhaps still visible in the setback
label: Caption

text: of the facade at that corner. The resultant tilt
label: Paragraph

text: impacted the orientation of the apse and thus
label: Paragraph

text: of the central nave. To the west, the tilt was
label: Paragraph

text: not implernented because the narthex had to
label: Paragraph

text: align with the Church of SS. Peter and Paul.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan is distinguished by its extraordinary
label: Paragraph

text: openness. Unlike Western churches, whic!
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the west, here is a system that permits more
label: Paragraph

text: fluid pathways into and through the church.
label: Paragraph

text: Another remarkable feature of the plan that
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the Hagia Sophia is that there are no separate
label: Paragraph

text: rooms to the right or left of the altar—rooms
label: Caption

text: for the preparation of the sacred meal and
label: Paragraph

text: where the bishop cons his garb. Such
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: respectively, are typical in later Byzantine
label: Paragraph

text: churches, but they are not present in early
label: Paragraph

text: Justinian ones. The result in both buildings
label: Paragraph

text: is that the central structure holding the dome
label: Paragraph

text: is freed from the surrounding architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: a way that is uncharacteristic of Byzantine
label: Paragraph

text: design.

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: 9.14 Detail of capital, Hagia Sophia

text: Byzantine Capitals
label: Title

text: There are two types of capitals used at the
label: Paragraph

text: Hagia Sophia: composite and lonic. The
label: Caption

text: composite capital that emerged during the
label: Paragraph

text: late Byzantine Empire, mainly in Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: combines the Corinthian with the lonic.
label: Paragraph

text: Composite capitals line the principal space of
label: Paragraph

text: the nave. lonic capitals are used behind them
label: Paragraph

text: in the side spaces, in a minor position relative
label: Paragraph

text: to the Corinthian or composite orders (as was
label: Paragraph

text: their fate well into the 19th century, when
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were designed for the first time
label: Paragraph

text: with a monumental lonic order). At the Hagia
label: Caption

text: Sophia, though, these are not the standard
label: Paragraph

text: imperial statements. The capitals are filled
label: Paragraph

text: with foliage in all sorts of variations. In some,
label: Paragraph

text: the small, lush leaves appear to be caught
label: Paragraph

text: up in the spinning of the scrolls—clearly,
label: Paragraph

text: different, nonclassical sensibility had taken
label: Paragraph

text: over the design. At SS. Sergius and Bacchus
label: Caption

text: and other churches of the time, we see the
label: Paragraph

text: full emergence of this experimentation.
label: Paragraph

text: Post-Renaissance classicism in Europe
label: Title

text: dismissed these efforts as radically outside
label: Paragraph

text: the norm of the “classical” tradition. But
label: Paragraph

text: the classical tradition was more open to
label: Paragraph

text: experimentation than one might at first think.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, after the fall of the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Empire, in which standardized models were
label: Paragraph

text: often used, local craftsmen were invited
label: Paragraph

text: to test their skills. That many of these
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmen were using northern motives or
label: Paragraph

text: were themselves Christianized Visigoths is
label: Paragraph

text: more than obvious. The Visigoths invaded
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine territories in the 5th century, with
label: Paragraph

text: many of them staying on to be conscripted
label: Paragraph

text: into the Byzantine army. They tended to use
label: Paragraph

text: vine and plant motifs for their ornamentation,
label: Paragraph

text: as can be seen in their belt buckles. Most of
label: Paragraph

text: the Visigoths eventually went on to settle in
label: Paragraph

text: southern Spain.
label: Paragraph

text: The capitals at St. Vitale in Ravenna show
label: Caption

text: wavy and delicate floral patterns similar to
label: Paragraph

text: decorations found on belt buckles and dagger
label: Caption

text: blades. Their inverted pyrarnidal form has the
label: Paragraph

text: look of a basket. At the Basilica Eufrasiana
label: Caption

text: in Parenzo, Croatia, along the Adriatic Sea,
label: Paragraph

text: we find a double-tier design, with birds at
label: Paragraph

text: the corners and delicately carved grapevines
label: Caption

text: below. At Salonica, Greece, we encounter
label: Caption

text: capitals that also consist of abstract curved
label: Paragraph

text: patterns, in conjunction with some that
label: Paragraph

text: have leaves that look as if they are being
label: Paragraph

text: tossed around by the wind. The capitals at
label: Paragraph

text: SS. Sergius and Bacchus have a delicate
label: Paragraph

text: stenciling that allows the swirling tendrils of
label: Paragraph

text: acanthus to stand out against the blackness
label: Title

text: of a deeply cut background.

text: ARMENIAN ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: The area defined by the Caspian Sea to the
label: Paragraph

text: east and the Black Sea to the west was an
label: Paragraph

text: important geographical hub. Merchants could
label: Paragraph

text: unload goods from China on the shores of the
label: Paragraph

text: Caspian, where they would be taken through
label: Paragraph

text: Armenia to the Black Sea, from which almost
label: Paragraph

text: any destination in Europe was reachable. The
label: Paragraph

text: trip from China to Rome would have gone
label: Title

text: through fewer contested territories in the year
label: Title

text: 600 CE than it does today; the location was,
label: Paragraph

text: however, the cause for both the rise and the
label: Paragraph

text: fall of the Armenian kingdom. Descended
label: Paragraph

text: from the Urartu, the Armenians were in turn
label: Paragraph

text: controlled by the Persians, by Alexander
label: Paragraph

text: the Great, by the Romans, and then by the
label: Paragraph

text: Persians again. Despite all this, the Armenian
label: Paragraph

text: desire for autonomy was strong, and the
label: Paragraph

text: period between the 4th and 9th centuries
label: Title

text: saw Armeria at its creative best. In the 6th
label: Paragraph

text: and 7th centuries, with Arab regions to the
label: Paragraph

text: south and Viking areas to the north still in
label: Paragraph

text: disarray, Armenia was a safe link between
label: Paragraph

text: East and West. But by the 10th century,
label: Paragraph

text: with the expansion of Islam and Christianity
label: Title

text: into large, far-flung yet interconnected
label: Paragraph

text: domains, trade increased—to the detriment
label: Paragraph

text: of Armenia, which was able to survive only
label: Paragraph

text: until 1375.
label: Paragraph

text: Huns and Alans
label: Title

text: Caspian Sea
label: Title

text: Echmiadzin (Vagarshapat)
label: Title

text: Persian Empire
label: Title

text: The significance of Armenia in the history
label: Title

text: of architecture lies, once again, in the high
label: Paragraph

text: quality of its stonework. In Constantinople,
label: Paragraph

text: stone had given way to brick. (The Hagia
label: Paragraph

text: Sophia is basically a brick building.) The
label: Paragraph

text: use of concrete, furthermore, had been
label: Paragraph

text: forgotten by this time. Only the Armenians
label: Paragraph

text: had maintained the classical Hellenistic
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of clean surfaces, volumetric
label: Title

text: complexity, and a strong focus on a compact,
label: Paragraph

text: object-like effect of the building in space.
label: Paragraph

text: This would have an important impact on the
label: Paragraph

text: later development of church architecture
label: Title

text: in Europe, when Armenian masons were in
label: Paragraph

text: demand in the west, particularly in France.
label: Paragraph

text: 9.18 Typology of Armenian churches
label: Caption

text: The history of Armenia’s Christian
label: Title

text: architecture begins in 301 CE, when
label: Paragraph

text: Dertad III (the king of Armenia under Roman
label: Title

text: suzerainty) was converted to Christianity
label: Paragraph

text: by St. Gregory the Illurninator, a native
label: Caption

text: Armenian who made Christianity the state
label: Title

text: religion. In general, the Armenian liturgy
label: Paragraph

text: resembles that of the Eastern Church, except
label: Paragraph

text: that its language is classical Armenian
label: Paragraph

text: rather than Greek. The distinctive look of
label: Paragraph

text: Armenian architecture developed quite
label: Paragraph

text: rapidly. Buildings tended to have forms
label: Paragraph

text: that were simple and solid-looking. From
label: Paragraph

text: the earliest date, they were volumetric and
label: Paragraph

text: planimetric masterpieces. Furthermore, the
label: Paragraph

text: carving and placement of the stones was
label: Paragraph

text: excellent; indeed, at the time, these buildings
label: Paragraph

text: would have been far superior to other stone
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in Europe and Asia. Though
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine architecture introduced the dome
label: Paragraph

text: as an important potential element in Christian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, the Byzantine dome was not
label: Paragraph

text: visible externally. Armenian architecture, by
label: Caption

text: way of contrast, pushed the dome up over
label: Paragraph

text: the mass of the building. Though the dome
label: Paragraph

text: itself was covered with a light wooden conical
label: Paragraph

text: roof, the silhouette achieved would have a
label: Paragraph

text: profound impact on future church design.
label: Paragraph

text: he Armenian word gmbet, usually
label: Paragraph

text: translated as “dome,” means more precisely
label: Paragraph

text: “the vault of heaven.” The vision of Gregory
label: Paragraph

text: the Illuminator (b. 239 CE), the patron
label: Paragraph

text: saint of Armenia, also played a part in the
label: Paragraph

text: acceptance of the domme. He wrote that he
label: Paragraph

text: saw a figure of light descending from heaven
label: Paragraph

text: associated with a magnificent building that
label: Paragraph

text: had the form of a dome on four columns.
label: Paragraph

text: 9.19 St. Hripsime, Echmiadzin, Armenia
label: Caption

text: St. Hripsime
label: Title

text: One of the most refined examples of
label: Paragraph

text: Armenian architecture can be found in
label: Paragraph

text: Echmiadzin. St. Hripsime was the second
label: Paragraph

text: church built by St. Gregory the Illuminator
label: Caption

text: during the first quarter of the 4th century. It
label: Paragraph

text: was replaced in 395 CE by a small chapel.
label: Paragraph

text: The present edifice was built in 618 CE. The
label: Paragraph

text: building is constructed of dark, ash-colored
label: Paragraph

text: tufa bonded on the interior with concrete-like
label: Paragraph

text: mortar. The whole rests, like a Greek ternple,
label: Paragraph

text: on a stepped stylobate. The small windows
label: Caption

text: emphasize the mass and solidity of the
label: Paragraph

text: structure.
label: Paragraph

text: The interior is organized on a quatrefoil
label: Paragraph

text: plan, with niches in the cardinal directions.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition to these, there are niches on
label: Paragraph

text: the diagonal corners, creating a fluid and
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic interior space. The diagonal niches,
label: Paragraph

text: having the form of three-quarter cylinders,
label: Paragraph

text: may also have been intended to strengthen
label: Paragraph

text: the abutment of the dome. They give access
label: Paragraph

text: to four subsidiary chambers that flank
label: Paragraph

text: the eastern and western niches. Though
label: Paragraph

text: the building is biaxially symmetrical, the
label: Paragraph

text: eastern apse is emphasized by the raised
label: Paragraph

text: altar section that protrudes into the central
label: Paragraph

text: space. Barrel vaults intervene between the
label: Paragraph

text: axial niches and the central square. These
label: Paragraph

text: vaults, which are wider along the main axis,
label: Paragraph

text: accentuate the east-west direction. The
label: Paragraph

text: whole composition is bound together to form
label: Paragraph

text: 9.20 Plan: St. Hripsime
label: Caption

text: a well-proportioned rectangle with large
label: Paragraph

text: triangular recesses on the exterior that impart
label: Paragraph

text: a rhythmic impression of the composition.
label: Paragraph

text: The dome rests on a sixteen-sided windowed
label: Paragraph

text: drum that has twelve windows at its base.
label: Paragraph

text: Four of the windows are now obscured by
label: Caption

text: small cylindrical towers that were added
label: Caption

text: later as buttresses. The entrance porch on
label: Caption

text: the west is also a later addition. The beauty
label: Paragraph

text: of the St. Hripsime edifice derives from the
label: Paragraph

text: simplicity and harmony of its different parts.
label: Paragraph

text: 9.21 Interior: St. Hripsime
label: Caption

text: 9.22 Zvartnots Cathedral, Echmiadzin, Armenia
label: Caption

text: Zvartnots Cathedral
label: Title

text: Among the many inventive designs of
label: Paragraph

text: Armenian churches during this period,
label: Paragraph

text: one stands out particularly: the Church
label: Paragraph

text: of Zvartnots near Echmiadzin. Begun in
label: Caption

text: 643 CE after Armenia's recovery from an
label: Paragraph

text: Arab invasion in 640, it served for a time as
label: Paragraph

text: the seat of the Armenian church. Though
label: Paragraph

text: only the foundations and colurmns remain,
label: Paragraph

text: it can be reconstructed with reasonable
label: Paragraph

text: accuracy. From the outside it consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: three telescoped cylinders, 37 meters across
label: Caption

text: at ground level. The external walls were
label: Paragraph

text: enlivened by blind arcades. The cylindrical
label: Paragraph

text: exterior disguised a remarkable interior.
label: Paragraph

text: Four wedge-shaped piers framed four large
label: Caption

text: exedrae, three of them composed of six
label: Paragraph

text: columns and the fourth closed off to form
label: Paragraph

text: the apse. The piers rose to form arches
label: Caption

text: that supported a dome on squinches. At
label: Paragraph

text: the ground floor, the space between the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior and interior served as an ambulatory,
label: Paragraph

text: in essence producing a building within a
label: Paragraph

text: building. As with all Armenian churches, the
label: Paragraph

text: windows were small but well integrated into
label: Paragraph

text: the composition. Here, however, the interior
label: Paragraph

text: was proportionally quite tall, unlike most
label: Paragraph

text: Armenian churches, which seem to strive
label: Paragraph

text: for a balance between the horizontal and
label: Paragraph

text: vertical. The church was recognized in its day
label: Paragraph

text: as a marvel. There are clear similarities to the
label: Paragraph

text: church of SS. Sergius and Bacchus (527-
label: Caption

text: 36 CE) in Constantinople. But that building,
label: Paragraph

text: a brick structure, apart from the columns,
label: Paragraph

text: was squat and was integrated into a palace
label: Paragraph

text: compound. Zvartnots, by contrast, was not
label: Paragraph

text: only larger in footprint and built of stone,
label: Paragraph

text: but designed to be clearly visible against the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape. Furthermore, the carving of the
label: Paragraph

text: capitals and detailing of the arches was of the
label: Paragraph

text: highest order.
label: Paragraph

text: VISHNU DEOGARH AND ELEPHANTA
label: Title

text: After the collapse of the Gupta Empire,
label: Paragraph

text: the Gangetic Plains were controlled by
label: Paragraph

text: the Hephthalite Empire, which originated
label: Paragraph

text: in the area that is now Afghanistan and
label: Paragraph

text: urkmenistan, and soon dominated central
label: Paragraph

text: Asia. The power vacuum left most of India to
label: Paragraph

text: racture itself into numerous small nations,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Harshavardhana (606-47 CE)
label: Paragraph

text: in the north, and, moving southward, the
label: Paragraph

text: Chalukyas, the Pallavas, the Cholas, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Pandyas. During this period, with Buddhism
label: Paragraph

text: marginalized, Hindu architecture in South
label: Title

text: Asia entered an experimental phase, and
label: Paragraph

text: rock-cut temples competed for prominence
label: Paragraph

text: with the new structural-stone and brick
label: Paragraph

text: temples. Although an invasion of north India
label: Paragraph

text: by the Huns dispersed the Buddhist monks
label: Paragraph

text: from Kashmir, they continued to prosper in
label: Paragraph

text: major universities such as those at Nalanda,
label: Paragraph

text: Ujjain, and Sirpur. Typical for the syncretism
label: Paragraph

text: of the time, Sirpur had shrines dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: to Hindu deities such as Shiva and Vishnu
label: Paragraph

text: adjacent to compounds dedicated to the
label: Paragraph

text: Buddha. One of the oldest statues of a female
label: Paragraph

text: deity, Haritiki, has been found at Sirpur.
label: Paragraph

text: An interesting comparison can be made
label: Paragraph

text: between two 6th-century Gupta period
label: Paragraph

text: temples: the Shiva shrine on Elephanta
label: Title

text: Island, a rock-cut structure built by Shaivite
label: Paragraph

text: monks for their own use, and the Dasavatara
label: Paragraph

text: Vishnu Temple at Deogarh, a brick-and-stone
label: Caption

text: structure built for a large devotee population.
label: Paragraph

text: 9.23 A Hindu mandala
label: Caption

text: Elephanta is a Hindu shrine adapted from
label: Paragraph

text: the older Buddhist rock-cut structures,
label: Paragraph

text: while Deogarh is a new invention—a shrine
label: Paragraph

text: constructed with stones to appear as if it is
label: Paragraph

text: monolithic (i-e., rock-cut). The latter has a
label: Paragraph

text: representational mountain as its shikhara,
label: Paragraph

text: while the former has a real mountain in
label: Paragraph

text: which it is embedded. Both begin with a
label: Paragraph

text: square garbha-griha, but while Deogarh
label: Paragraph

text: would have had originally held an image of
label: Paragraph

text: Vishnu, Elephanta still has the Shiva Lingam
label: Paragraph

text: at its center. From the middle, four axes
label: Paragraph

text: radiate out, defining access paths. Deogarh,
label: Caption

text: however, is accessible only from the west (the
label: Paragraph

text: direction of Vishnu) and has three implied
label: Paragraph

text: doors (ghana-dwaras, literally “blind doors”)
label: Paragraph

text: along its remaining cardinal directions.
label: Paragraph

text: Elephanta is open on all four sides,
label: Paragraph

text: though east is its primary direction of access.
label: Paragraph

text: Deogarh’s main shrine is at the center of a
label: Paragraph

text: nine-square mandala, with four subsidiary
label: Paragraph

text: shrines interlocked at its corners. Elephanta
label: Caption

text: has a much more complex geometry, with four
label: Paragraph

text: sets of nine-square mandalas interlocking to
label: Paragraph

text: define two major axes of access, one from the
label: Paragraph

text: west and the other from the north. The north-
label: Paragraph

text: south axis, aligned with the main entrance,
label: Paragraph

text: terminates in three gigantic Shiva sculptures
label: Paragraph

text: in deeply recessed niches. This triptych,
label: Paragraph

text: much celebrated in the annals of art history,
label: Paragraph

text: occupies the entire width and height of the
label: Paragraph

text: end wall, and, compared to the rough-hewn
label: Paragraph

text: character of the rest of structure, was carved
label: Paragraph

text: with greater care.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: The cerebral exploration of interlocking
label: Title

text: geometries based on mandala diagrams
label: Title

text: was to become the defining characteristic of
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu temple form in the centuries to come.
label: Paragraph

text: Mandalas are derived from original Vedic
label: Paragraph

text: altars and are used in both the Hindu and
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist religions as diagrams to map the
label: Paragraph

text: cosmos for astrological observations. These
label: Paragraph

text: diagrams are abstract, without scale, and
label: Paragraph

text: can take any number of forms derived from
label: Paragraph

text: a combination of superimposed squares and
label: Paragraph

text: circles.

text: 9.30 Five Rathas, Mamallapuram, India
label: Caption

text: THE FIVE RATHAS
label: Title

text: Contemporary with the Chalukyas, with whom
label: Paragraph

text: they had frequent commerce, the Pallavas
label: Paragraph

text: were one of the most distinguished dynasties
label: Paragraph

text: of South Asia. The second Pallava ruler,
label: Paragraph

text: Narasimhavarman II, built at Mamallapuram,
label: Caption

text: one of India’s largest port cities of the time,
label: Paragraph

text: a series of monuments that made it one of
label: Paragraph

text: the great spiritual hubs of India. The hill
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking the shore was transformed into a
label: Paragraph

text: “model” of the Hindu universe. A channel of
label: Paragraph

text: spring-fed water, “the Ganges,” was created,
label: Paragraph

text: winding its way down the slope and passing
label: Paragraph

text: numerous finely carved rock-cut temples. At
label: Paragraph

text: the bottom of the hill, the channel opens into
label: Paragraph

text: a waterfall that spills over a large and richly
label: Paragraph

text: decorated bas-relief rock face known, fittingly,
label: Caption

text: as the Descent of the Ganges.
label: Paragraph

text: The rulers, however, were eager to
label: Paragraph

text: experiment with temples that were not rock-
label: Paragraph

text: cut, but built up from stone. For this, so it
label: Paragraph

text: seems, they held a competition, asking their
label: Paragraph

text: designers to produce models from which
label: Paragraph

text: temples could later be constructed. The
label: Paragraph

text: results are known as the Five Rathas (mid- to
label: Paragraph

text: late 7th century). They are a group of five
label: Paragraph

text: miniaturized rock-cut temples accompanied
label: Title

text: by life-size sculptures of a bull, an elephant,
label: Paragraph

text: and a lion. Every temple is a thought of as
label: Paragraph

text: a miniature, or model, of the Hindu cosmic
label: Paragraph

text: order. And the “decorative” module of a
label: Paragraph

text: temple on a shikhara is also a miniature
label: Paragraph

text: of the temple of which it is a part. In other
label: Paragraph

text: words, on every scale—from the mini-temple
label: Paragraph

text: on a shikhara, to the temple itself, to the full-
label: Paragraph

text: scale reality of the Hindu cosmos—the same
label: Paragraph

text: form repeats itself, as in fractal geometry.
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond being a symbol of cosmic order,
label: Paragraph

text: the temples also project to the worshipper a
label: Paragraph

text: sense of personal wholeness.
label: Paragraph

text: 9.31 Elevation of Dharmaraja Ratha,
label: Caption

text: Mamallapuram

text: 9.32 Shore Temple at Mamallapuram
label: Caption

text: Shore Temple at Mamallapuram
label: Title

text: The Shore Temple at Mamallapurarn
label: Title

text: (700-728 CE), so called because it
label: Paragraph

text: overlooks the Bay of Bengal, is one of the
label: Paragraph

text: oldest structural stone temples in southern
label: Caption

text: India. It is attributed to the Pallava king
label: Paragraph

text: Narasimhavarman II. Originally, it was part of
label: Paragraph

text: a series of temples that belonged to a former
label: Paragraph

text: port city that has long since disappeared
label: Title

text: into the waves, leaving the building isolated
label: Paragraph

text: on the beach. The temple is modeled on
label: Paragraph

text: the Dharmaraja Ratha, one of the Five
label: Paragraph

text: Rathas, located a few kilometers away. The
label: Paragraph

text: Dharmaraja Ratha, a rock-cut structure, is
label: Paragraph

text: in turn clearly modeled on a wooden temple,
label: Paragraph

text: suggesting that as with the ancient Greeks,
label: Paragraph

text: here a stone building replicates a wooden
label: Paragraph

text: one. The superstructure of the Dharmaraja
label: Caption

text: Ratha is a series of stacked planes, each a
label: Paragraph

text: representation of a sacred city. The Shore
label: Paragraph

text: Temple expands on that theme, with each
label: Paragraph

text: rising layer representing the intensification of
label: Paragraph

text: the divine.
label: Paragraph

text: The temple is actually an amalgam of
label: Paragraph

text: three different shrines, and in this respect is
label: Paragraph

text: quite unusual. The main shrine is dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: to Shiva and faces east. The second shrine,
label: Paragraph

text: with a smaller shikhara, is also dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: to Shiva, but faces west. Between the two,
label: Paragraph

text: attached to the back wall of the smaller Shiva
label: Caption

text: shrine and entered from the east, is a small
label: Paragraph

text: third shrine with no superstructural presence,
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to the reclining Vishnu.
label: Paragraph

text: The Vishnu shrine, probably the oldest on the
label: Paragraph

text: site, is on axis with the larger Shiva shrine,
label: Paragraph

text: although there is no direct communication
label: Paragraph

text: between the two. The Shore Temple’s
label: Paragraph

text: configuration of the two Shiva shrines,
label: Paragraph

text: which are separated and yet linked by the
label: Paragraph

text: small Vishnu shrine, represents an effort to
label: Paragraph

text: balance the multiple competing liturgical
label: Title

text: requirements. Most later Hindu temples,
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to more than one deity, are lined
label: Paragraph

text: up hierarchically or organized radially around
label: Paragraph

text: a dominant center.
label: Paragraph

text: Although most of the exterior arrangements
label: Paragraph

text: of the temple have eroded, there is ample
label: Paragraph

text: suggestion that water may have been
label: Paragraph

text: channeled into pools in the temple and may
label: Paragraph

text: indeed have also entered into the Vishnu
label: Paragraph

text: shrine—which would have been appropriate,
label: Paragraph

text: since the reclining Vishnu figure is described
label: Paragraph
