text: SOUTHEAST ASIA
label: Title

text: Between 300 and 600 CE, there was a
label: Paragraph

text: marked transformation of the Irrawaddy and
label: Paragraph

text: Mekong river hinterland in areas that are
label: Paragraph

text: today Thailand and Cambodia. River water
label: Paragraph

text: and floodwaters were brought under control,
label: Paragraph

text: and increased centralization allowed for the
label: Paragraph

text: exercise of authority. In the Mekong River
label: Paragraph

text: area, barays were created. These water pools,
label: Paragraph

text: formed by large enclosed dikes, were flooded
label: Paragraph

text: naturally by the Mekong River, and after the
label: Paragraph

text: floodwaters receded, retained water in the
label: Paragraph

text: basins for irrigation during the dry season.
label: Paragraph

text: By means of this hydroengineering, rice
label: Paragraph

text: production increased and new cities sprang
label: Title

text: up.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the larger of these new cities were
label: Paragraph

text: Nakhon Pathon and Lop Buri in Thailand,
label: Paragraph

text: and lsanapura and Shrestapura in Cambodia
label: Title

text: and Laos. All were carved out of the jungle
label: Paragraph

text: and surrounded by newly created agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: zones. It is clear that the Southeast Asian
label: Paragraph

text: hinterland was becoming interconnected with
label: Paragraph

text: trade routes that worked their way both east-
label: Paragraph

text: west and north-south, with China consequently
label: Paragraph

text: gaining in importance. Politically, the area was
label: Paragraph

text: divided between the Dvaravanti in Thailand,
label: Paragraph

text: the Chenla in Cambodia, the Charnpa along
label: Paragraph

text: the Vietnamese coast, and the emergent
label: Title

text: Srivijaya kingdom in Malaysia and Indonesia.
label: Paragraph

text: These kingdoms were heavily influenced by
label: Paragraph

text: Indian religious ideas. The Dvaravanti were
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhists, whereas the Chenla, developing

text: The idea of a sacred landscape also took

text: root in the Champa kingdom. The coast of
label: Paragraph

text: Vietnam that it controlled had for centuries
label: Paragraph

text: been developing as an important regional
label: Paragraph

text: economic zone, its numerous bays and
label: Paragraph

text: inlets accommodating trade with Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: and Indian vessels. Initially, the Champa, as
label: Paragraph

text: a set of federated cities, were closely tied
label: Paragraph

text: to Chinese cultural and religious traditions,
label: Paragraph

text: but in the 4th century CE there was a
label: Paragraph

text: strong infusion of Indian culture. Sanskrit
label: Paragraph

text: was adopted as a scholarly language, and
label: Paragraph

text: Hinduism—especially Shaivism—became the
label: Paragraph

text: state religion. Toward the end of the century,
label: Paragraph

text: in a somewhat unusual move perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: reflective of Chinese notions of kingship,
label: Paragraph

text: a valley known as My Son (69 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: southwest of Da Nang) was set aside for
label: Paragraph

text: religious purposes and as a memorial site
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to the noble achievement of the
label: Paragraph

text: royal dynasty. My Son (“Beautiful Mountain”)
label: Caption

text: is located near the Thu Bon River and to
label: Paragraph

text: the west of Indrapura, now known as Hoi
label: Paragraph

text: An, a city that at that time possessed a large
label: Paragraph

text: harbor and was an important trading center.
label: Paragraph

text: The valley, hidden from the plain and with
label: Paragraph

text: only one entrance, is surrounded by hills
label: Paragraph

text: and mountains. The site was envisioned as a
label: Paragraph

text: sacred one. The highest mountain of My Son,
label: Paragraph

text: the Rang Meo, or “Cat's Teeth Mountain”
label: Paragraph

text: (800 meters), symbolized Mt. Meru, the
label: Paragraph

text: residence of the god Shiva, the main deity
label: Paragraph

text: worshipped by the Champa.
label: Paragraph

text: The earliest temples, built from wood,
label: Paragraph

text: have not survived. Brick masonry was
label: Paragraph

text: introduced toward the end of the 7th century.
label: Paragraph

text: The temples all followed a similar Indian
label: Paragraph

text: model: a square ground plan with a platform
label: Paragraph

text: and shrine proper, and a high, stepped roof.
label: Paragraph

text: The external surface was often plastered
label: Paragraph

text: and painted. Eventually, stone was also
label: Paragraph

text: used for decorative purposes around lintels
label: Paragraph

text: and door jambs, as well as for columns and
label: Paragraph

text: pilasters. There is a blind portico facing
label: Caption

text: east, also lavishly ornamented. The interiors
label: Caption

text: are plain, with small niches for lamps. The
label: Paragraph

text: Shiva Lingam, symbolizing the divine force,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In 750 CE, Daxing (Chang’an), with a million
label: Paragraph

text: residents, was the largest city in the world.
label: Paragraph

text: A stela inscribed in 781 CE documents the
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: priests in 635 CE. The last of the Sassanian
label: Paragraph

text: princes, Firuz, found refuge there around 670
label: Paragraph

text: CE. Manichaeism arrived with the Persians
label: Paragraph

text: leeing Islam around 694 CE. However,
label: Paragraph

text: Chang'an remained predominantly a place of
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist scholarship. Thousands of Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: scholars and pilgrims, such as Faxian, came to
label: Paragraph

text: ive in Chang'an, with its hundreds of Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: monasteries. In 840 CE, the Japanese pilgrim
label: Paragraph

text: Enin found monks from southern and northern
label: Paragraph

text: called it Daxing ("Great Prosperity”). This was
label: Paragraph

text: the city that, under the T’ang, was to become
label: Paragraph

text: famous as China's urb primus of the 1st
label: Paragraph

text: millennium CE. Developing both external and
label: Paragraph

text: internal trade was a high priority under the
label: Paragraph

text: Sui, and then the T'ang linked Chang'an with
label: Paragraph

text: Luoyang, Yangzhou, Chengdu, Guangzhou,
label: Caption

text: Youzhou, Bianzhou (now Kaifeng), and
label: Paragraph

text: Mingzhou (now Ningbo). Guangzhou and
label: Paragraph

text: Mingzhou were ports that serviced Korea and
label: Paragraph

text: Southeast Asia, respectively. An ancient form
label: Paragraph

text: of bill of exchange known as feigian (“flying
label: Paragraph

text: money”) was introduced by the T'ang.
label: Paragraph

text: Merchants who sold their goods in Daxing
label: Paragraph

text: could get feiqian drafts with which they could
label: Paragraph

text: draw money in other places.

text: 9.41 Wild Goose Pagoda, Xi'an, China
label: Caption

text: Chang'an became a model for city planning,
label: Paragraph

text: not only for later Chinese capitals like Beijing
label: Paragraph

text: during the Ming and Qing dynasties but also
label: Paragraph

text: for the capital cities of Korea and Japan,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Nara, Heian-Kyo (Kyoto), and
label: Paragraph

text: Kydngju. Construction was overseen by the
label: Paragraph

text: engineer and planner Yuwen Kai (655-612
label: Title

text: CE). Kai had already engineered the Grand
label: Paragraph

text: Canal (605-6 CE) to facilitate the transport
label: Paragraph

text: of grain from the alluvial southern plains
label: Title

text: to the relatively impoverished (but militarily
label: Paragraph

text: strong) northern areas. Although overscaled,
label: Paragraph

text: Chang’an’s master plan was based on Zhou
label: Paragraph

text: period descriptions of the Wangcheng ideal
label: Title

text: city (see “800 BCE"). But whereas ancient
label: Paragraph

text: texts described the model city as surrounded
label: Paragraph

text: by a square wall, with the emperor's palace
label: Caption

text: at the center of the city, the market to
label: Paragraph

text: the north, and the temple to the imperial
label: Paragraph

text: ancestors and the shrine of the earth to the
label: Title

text: south, the planners of Chang’an placed the
label: Paragraph

text: palace—Daming Palace (“Palace of Great
label: Title

text: Brilliance”)—in an enclave outside of the
label: Paragraph

text: square, along the north wall. The Taiji Palace
label: Caption

text: (“Palace of the Supreme Ultimate"), which
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of palaces and halls for imperial
label: Paragraph

text: meetings, was located at the north end of
label: Paragraph

text: the central north-south axis, occupying no
label: Paragraph

text: less than 5 percent of the entire city. Just
label: Paragraph

text: south of it was the Imperial City (offices of
label: Paragraph

text: the government and national ceremonial
label: Title

text: halls). The Imperial City, which was the
label: Paragraph

text: administrative heart of the empire, was also
label: Paragraph

text: where the emperor conducted his ritual
label: Paragraph

text: sacrifices at the imperial ancestral temple
label: Title

text: and at the imperial heavenly altar.
label: Paragraph

text: The rest of the city was divided up on a
label: Paragraph

text: grid pattern. Enclosing an area some 8.65
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers by 9.72 kilometers in size, the
label: Paragraph

text: city’s outer walls were punctured by three
label: Paragraph

text: gates, one each on the western, southern,
label: Paragraph

text: and eastern walls. The southern gate,
label: Paragraph

text: Mingde, was the main entrance and opened
label: Paragraph

text: onto a monumental street 220 meters wide,
label: Paragraph

text: while the streets leading from the other gates
label: Paragraph

text: measured about 140 meters wide.
label: Paragraph

text: Water played an important part in the
label: Paragraph

text: design, with several streams running through
label: Paragraph

text: the city. One went through the west market
label: Paragraph

text: and another through the east market.
label: Paragraph

text: There were five transport and sanitation
label: Title

text: canals running throughout the city—which
label: Paragraph

text: had several different water sources—that
label: Paragraph

text: delivered water to city parks, the gardens
label: Paragraph

text: of the rich, and the grounds of the imperial
label: Paragraph

text: palaces. The canals were also used to
label: Paragraph

text: transport crucial goods throughout the city.
label: Paragraph

text: The residential part of the city was divided
label: Paragraph

text: by east-west and north-south avenues into
label: Paragraph

text: 108 neighborhood blocks called fangs.
label: Paragraph

text: The roads were lined with water drainage
label: Paragraph

text: channels on both sides, and shaded by rows
label: Paragraph

text: of trees. The residential areas were further
label: Paragraph

text: accessed by alleys. In spite of its population,
label: Paragraph

text: the colossal spread of the city ensured that
label: Paragraph

text: the density of the fangs was not very high,
label: Paragraph

text: especially compared to that of Teotihuacan
label: Paragraph

text: and Rome at their heights. The fangs
label: Paragraph

text: contained temples, commercial buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: public parks, and housing. Each fang was
label: Paragraph

text: a mini-city with its own inner transportation
label: Paragraph

text: network, walls, gates, and corner towers.
label: Paragraph

text: There were two major cornmercial areas in
label: Paragraph

text: the outer city, referred to as the west and
label: Paragraph

text: east markets, each occupying two fangs.
label: Paragraph

text: These markets were the subject of many
label: Paragraph

text: literary descriptions, often devoted to the
label: Paragraph

text: global range of goods available there. The
label: Paragraph

text: areas around Quijan Lake and the Xingging
label: Paragraph

text: fang were famous scenic districts. In the
label: Paragraph

text: southeastern part of the city was a ward
label: Paragraph

text: that was home to a large monastery with
label: Paragraph

text: ten courtyards and the Wild Goose Pagoda
label: Title

text: (652 CE). This same city ward also had a
label: Paragraph

text: large bathhouse, an entertainment courtyard,
label: Paragraph

text: and an additional monastery, as well as a
label: Paragraph

text: mansion that had its own bathhouse. The
label: Paragraph

text: Wild Goose Pagoda had five stories, with
label: Paragraph

text: a rammed earth core and a stone exterior
label: Paragraph

text: facade. When this collapsed, the structure
label: Paragraph

text: was rebuilt in brick in 704 CE, which with
label: Paragraph

text: renovations still stands today, one of the
label: Paragraph

text: few surviving edifices from that period. The
label: Paragraph

text: building had special significance, since it
label: Paragraph

text: held the the sutras that were brought to
label: Paragraph

text: China from India by the noted Buddhist
label: Title

text: translator and traveler Hsuan Tsang.
label: Paragraph

text: Daming Palace
label: Title

text: The authority of the emperor was represented
label: Paragraph

text: by the palace, constructed axially at the head
label: Paragraph

text: of the city. In the long reign of Gao Zong
label: Paragraph

text: (650-83 CE), the power of the emperor was
label: Paragraph

text: further magnified by the creation of another
label: Paragraph

text: palace beyond the boundaries of Chang'an.
label: Paragraph

text: The Daminggong (gong means “palace”),
label: Paragraph

text: or “Palace of Great Brilliance,” is in its
label: Paragraph

text: own special compound covering 3 square
label: Title

text: kilometers. It was organized axially in a series
label: Paragraph

text: of interconnected courts forming a four-part
label: Paragraph

text: complex:
label: Title

text: 1. Entry square, about 500 meters square
label: Caption

text: 2. Hanyuan Hall (Hanyuandian) in front
label: Caption

text: (south side) of the entry square
label: Caption

text: 3. Xuanzheng Hall at the back (north side) of
label: Caption

text: the square
label: Title

text: 4. Northern third, containing the emperor's
label: Caption

text: court, reception areas, residences,
label: Paragraph

text: gardens, and temples
label: Title

text: 9.42 Pictorial view: Hanyuan Hall, Chang’an (Xi’an), China
label: Caption

text: First in Daming Palace’s axial sequence was
label: Paragraph

text: the Hanyuan Hall, or the “Enfolding Vitality
label: Paragraph

text: 1lkm Hall,” the main gate where imperial rites
label: Caption

text: were performed. This huge, imposing gate
label: Paragraph

text: faced a gigantic square where ceremonies
label: Paragraph

text: with a large number of participants and
label: Paragraph

text: spectators were held. Fifty-eight meters
label: Paragraph

text: wide, the Hanyuan Hall, quite large in itself,
label: Paragraph

text: had a vast stair at its center, the Dragon-
label: Paragraph

text: Tail Way, that was a classic example of the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese horizontal elongation of space. The
label: Paragraph

text: Xuanzheng Hall gate's 11-by-4-bay structure supported a
label: Paragraph

text: double-hipped roof and was flanked by high
label: Paragraph

text: pavilions on either side that were raised,
label: Paragraph

text: on their own bases, higher than the main
label: Paragraph

text: hall. Three hundred meters beyond was the
label: Paragraph

text: Xuanzheng (“Political”) Hall, from whose
label: Paragraph

text: Lo. oe sides extended walls that defined the palace
label: Paragraph

text: Danfeng Gate complex. Here the emperor held court on the
label: Paragraph

text: first and fifteenth day of each lunar month.
label: Paragraph

text: Beyond its arcades lay all the main offices of
label: Paragraph

text: the imperial bureaucracy. Two gates led to
label: Paragraph

text: the internal compound of the palace, which

label: Caption

text: Songyue Temple Ta
label: Title

text: Architecturally, the Chinese translated the
label: Paragraph

text: South Asian stupa into the ta (or pagoda, a
label: Paragraph

text: Portuguese-derived word). While the stupa
label: Paragraph

text: is a round earthen mound, the fa is a tower.
label: Paragraph

text: Both the fa and the stupa serve the same
label: Paragraph

text: purpose: to house a buried relic at their core.
label: Paragraph

text: The stupa emphasizes the fullness of the
label: Paragraph

text: mound's body and focuses on the mystery
label: Paragraph

text: within its earthen core; the fa magnifies
label: Paragraph

text: the vertical axis and makes a display of the
label: Paragraph

text: many levels of heavens inhabited by many
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhas.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the forrn may have been inspired
label: Paragraph

text: yy Han Chinese watchtowers, the fa never
label: Paragraph

text: unctioned as such. Rather, it served as
label: Paragraph

text: a beacon visible from a distance. The ta
label: Paragraph

text: was no mistranslation, however; it was how
label: Paragraph

text: the Chinese chose to represent the stupa.
label: Paragraph

text: his may be because stupas began during
label: Paragraph

text: a phase of Buddhism that deemphasized
label: Paragraph

text: representation, while the fa emerged after
label: Paragraph

text: the establishment of Mahayana Buddhism,
label: Paragraph

text: which permitted representation. The ta, in
label: Paragraph

text: fact, symbolizes outright the multi-heavened
label: Paragraph

text: cosmology of Mahayana Buddhism. In the
label: Paragraph

text: stupa, this cosmology is referred to through
label: Paragraph

text: the small chatiris (umbrellas) at the summits.
label: Paragraph

text: The ta, essentially, is a chattri magnified
label: Paragraph

text: to huge proportions. Even Hsuan Tsang
label: Paragraph

text: (Xuanzang), who had seen and carefully
label: Paragraph

text: recorded innumerable stupas in India,
label: Paragraph

text: specifically chose the form of a ta when
label: Paragraph

text: building his own monastery in Chang'an, the
label: Paragraph

text: Wild Goose Pagoda (652-704 CE), a seven-
label: Paragraph

text: story, 20-meter-high structure originally made
label: Caption

text: of mud and brick.
label: Paragraph

text: The Songyue Temple Ta (523 CE), in
label: Paragraph

text: Dengfeng, Henan Province, is China's oldest
label: Paragraph

text: and largest surviving ta. Located in the
label: Paragraph

text: middle of a river valley, it is a twelve-sided,
label: Paragraph

text: 40-meter-high polygon consisting of fifteen
label: Paragraph

text: bodhisattva levels, surmounted by an obtuse
label: Paragraph

text: finial. The whole is made of brick, including
label: Paragraph

text: the corbelled overhanging eaves of the
label: Caption

text: main body. The overall form is parabolic,
label: Paragraph

text: with a slight suggestion of entasis. The
label: Paragraph

text: unornamented lower story of the base has
label: Caption

text: an entry facing south. The second story is
label: Caption

text: slightly cantilevered, with engaged columns at
label: Caption

text: the corners and lotus-bud capitals that seem
label: Paragraph

text: to be of Indian origin. The four sides face the
label: Paragraph

text: cardinal directions and have openings leading
label: Paragraph

text: to a central space; the other sides have
label: Paragraph

text: arched niches, like the Mahabodhi Temple
label: Paragraph

text: complex in India. The arches are decorated
label: Paragraph

text: with lion motifs.
label: Paragraph

text: The Songyue Temple Ta was originally
label: Paragraph

text: plastered, possibly white, and would have
label: Paragraph

text: stood out against the hills. As it is, the
label: Paragraph

text: pagoda, along with others with which it
label: Paragraph

text: forms a family, sits in dramatic relation to
label: Paragraph

text: 9.46 Plan: Songyue Temple Ta
label: Caption

text: its surroundings. Unlike most later pagodas,
label: Paragraph

text: the Songyue Temple Ta is inaccessible. The
label: Paragraph

text: individual stories—much too small to ever
label: Paragraph

text: have been intended for human occupation—
label: Paragraph

text: are entirely representational, complete with
label: Paragraph

text: a door and two windows carved into each of
label: Caption

text: the twelve sides at each story.

text: NARA PERIOD: JAPAN
label: Title

text: By the 8th century CE, the various clans of
label: Paragraph

text: Japan had cohered into a single political
label: Paragraph

text: unit under an emperor; the northern islands
label: Paragraph

text: were the last to be brought into this unity.
label: Paragraph

text: Rice was the principal commodity. Japan’s
label: Paragraph

text: native religion at the time was Shintoism, a
label: Paragraph

text: form of animism in which every aspect of
label: Paragraph

text: nature was revered. There were no creeds
label: Paragraph

text: or images of gods, but rather a host of kami,
label: Paragraph

text: or sacred spirits. Kami were both deities and
label: Paragraph

text: the numinous quality perceived in objects
label: Paragraph

text: of nature, such as trees, rocks, waters, and
label: Paragraph

text: mountains. The kami are still venerated at
label: Paragraph

text: more than one hundred thousand Shinto
label: Title

text: shrines throughout Japan and are considered
label: Paragraph

text: to be creative and harmonizing forces in
label: Paragraph

text: nature. Humans were seen not as owners of
label: Paragraph

text: nature, or above and separate from it, but as
label: Paragraph

text: integral participants in it—and indeed derived
label: Paragraph

text: from it. The Buddha was received as a “great
label: Paragraph

text: kami,” but a kami could also be attributed
label: Paragraph

text: to the spirits of deceased emperors, heroes,
label: Paragraph

text: and farnous persons. In the 6th century,
label: Paragraph

text: the emperor came to be deified as a living
label: Paragraph

text: kami, and his divinity surpassed that of other
label: Paragraph

text: kami. One honored kari in the form of food
label: Paragraph

text: offerings, music, dance, and the performance
label: Title

text: of traditional skills such as archery and sumo
label: Paragraph

text: wrestling. Ceremonial purity was strongly
label: Paragraph

text: encouraged, and bodily cleanliness was an
label: Paragraph

text: absolute necessity.

text: the kami. The earliest Shinto sanctuaries
label: Paragraph

text: were simple piles of boulders or stones that
label: Paragraph

text: marked the sacred places where the kami
label: Paragraph

text: were thought to reside. Kami could also live
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: unadorned structure before which there stood
label: Paragraph

text: a detached portal, known as a torii.

text: Ise Jingu
label: Title

text: The unification of Shinto’s animism with
label: Paragraph

text: the spirit of the emperor set the stage for a
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable building, the Ise Jingu (“Shrine”),
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to the tutelary karni of the
label: Caption

text: Japanese imperial family. It has no parallel in
label: Paragraph

text: the entire history of global architecture. Every
label: Paragraph

text: 20 years for the last 1,500 years, the shrine
label: Paragraph

text: has been rebuilt, identical to the one before,
label: Paragraph

text: but with virgin old-growth timber.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ise Jingu that stands in Japan today
label: Paragraph

text: was built in 2013. In a sense, then, it is
label: Paragraph

text: practically new. Yet, at the same time, it can
label: Paragraph

text: be dated to the year 690 CE. The sacred
label: Paragraph

text: necklace of magatama (jewels representing
label: Title

text: the soul spirit, which enter the body of the
label: Paragraph

text: possessor) is the symbol of succession from
label: Paragraph

text: the sun goddess and is the ernblem of the
label: Paragraph

text: emperors of Japan even today. This necklace
label: Paragraph

text: is kept at Ise. As such, Ise Jingu is Japan’s
label: Paragraph

text: most revered shrine.

text: Set deep in a sacred forest at the mouth
label: Paragraph

text: a river valley south of the town of Ise, the
label: Paragraph

text: shrine consists of two primary structures—the
label: Paragraph

text: Inner Shrine (Naiku) and the Outer Shrine
label: Title

text: (Geku)—as well as a wide array of lesser
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuaries distributed around a narrow,
label: Paragraph

text: verdant coastal plain on the east coast
label: Title

text: of the Kii Peninsula in southern Honshu.
label: Paragraph

text: The area, relatively warm even in winter,
label: Paragraph

text: is crossed by the fast-flowing Isuzu River.
label: Paragraph

text: Naiku is dedicated to Amaterasu Omikami
label: Paragraph

text: (“Heaven-llluminating Great Kami”), the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional ancestral deity of the imperial
label: Title

text: house, and Geku is dedicated to Touke
label: Paragraph

text: Okami (“Abundant Food Great Kami").
label: Paragraph

text: Originally unconnected, the two were joined
label: Paragraph

text: into an institutional unit in the 9th century. Of
label: Paragraph

text: the two, the Inner Shrine became the more
label: Paragraph

text: important, its complex now containing about
label: Paragraph

text: 120 separate shrines, including a number of
label: Paragraph

text: tiny sanctuaries dedicated to the spirit of a
label: Paragraph

text: single rock or the deity of a bubbling spring,
label: Paragraph

text: as is Shinto practice.
label: Paragraph

text: 9.49 Area plan: Ise Inner Shrine
label: Caption

text: The path to the Naiku is carefully scripted,
label: Paragraph

text: marked today by a series of torii (derived
label: Paragraph

text: from the Sanskrit forana, for “gate”). One
label: Paragraph

text: accesses the precinct by crossing the Uji
label: Paragraph

text: Bridge, which is constructed from fragrant
label: Paragraph

text: cypress wood, over the sacred Isuzu River.
label: Paragraph

text: From the bridge, the pilgrim proceeds to the
label: Paragraph

text: right along a broad street covered with gravel
label: Paragraph

text: and flanked by carefully tended gardens. The
label: Paragraph

text: path eventually turns east and rises up the
label: Paragraph

text: gentle slope through another torii, surrounded
label: Paragraph

text: by a forest of sacred cedars and zelkova
label: Title

text: elms. Finally, the path curves to approach the
label: Paragraph

text: Naiku from the south. The double platforms
label: Caption

text: on which the temple rests is terraced out
label: Paragraph

text: over the sloping site and supported by giant
label: Paragraph

text: stones.
label: Paragraph

text: 9.50 South gateway to the Ise Inner Shrine
label: Caption

text: The final approach is made by way of
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-one stone steps that bring one to
label: Paragraph

text: the top of the terrace and the outermost
label: Paragraph

text: fence. A fine silk curtain hanging across the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance and moving in the breeze is all
label: Paragraph

text: that marks the beginning of the prohibited
label: Paragraph

text: zone. The innermost shrines are open only
label: Paragraph

text: to the temple priests or the imperial family,
label: Paragraph

text: and even then only in a highly regulated
label: Paragraph

text: and hierarchical fashion. The ernperor has
label: Paragraph

text: access to the innermost shrine, the Shoden,
label: Paragraph

text: and the rest of the family's distance from the
label: Paragraph

text: Shoden is a measure of their distance from
label: Paragraph

text: the throne. Everyone else worships from the
label: Paragraph

text: outside. The Naiku contains three structures
label: Paragraph

text: organized axially—the central shrine, the
label: Paragraph

text: Shoden; and, behind it on either side, the two
label: Paragraph

text: treasuries. The 15-by-10-meter Shoden is
label: Paragraph

text: raised off the ground by columns set directly
label: Caption

text: into the ground (without a foundation). It
label: Paragraph

text: is a meticulously crafted and ornamented
label: Paragraph

text: wooden structure three bays wide and two
label: Caption

text: bays deep, built entirely without nails. It has
label: Paragraph

text: a deeply thatched reed roof and an entrance
label: Caption

text: on its long side accessible via an external
label: Paragraph

text: flight of stairs. The building, though empty,
label: Paragraph

text: is modeled on a granary and is the symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: residence of the rice kami.
label: Paragraph

text: Straight, squared timbers are used for
label: Paragraph

text: the rafters that descend sharply from the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: openings. At the middle of each gable end is
label: Paragraph

text: a freestanding solitary pillar that supports the
label: Paragraph

text: The elaborate ritual process of rebuilding the
label: Paragraph

text: Ise every twenty years is known as shikinen
label: Paragraph

text: sengu (“the transfer of the god-body to
label: Paragraph

text: a new shrine in a special festival year").
label: Paragraph

text: The reconstruction alternates between two
label: Paragraph

text: adjacent sites. While one site is in use, the
label: Paragraph

text: other is left empty, covered by white gravel.
label: Paragraph

text: When the floor of the previous Shoden is
label: Paragraph

text: relocated, a small wooden pillar, known
label: Paragraph

text: as the shin-no-mihashira, or “heart pillar,”
label: Paragraph

text: is left buried in the old shrine compound,
label: Paragraph

text: and a small shed, the o/-ya, is built over it
label: Paragraph

text: to protect it from the elements. The lumber
label: Paragraph

text: consists of hundreds of trees that are taken
label: Paragraph

text: from a sacred grove in the mountains and
label: Paragraph

text: transported to the site with much fanfare and
label: Paragraph

text: reverence. The old lumber, still sacred, is
label: Paragraph

text: disseminated to be used in the repair of other
label: Paragraph

text: Shinto shrines around Japan.
label: Paragraph

text: The idea of renewal might also be tied
label: Paragraph

text: to Shinto beliefs and could be described as
label: Paragraph

text: the desire to show reverence to the Great
label: Paragraph

text: Kami by revitalizing its earthly residence.
label: Paragraph

text: In a metaphysical sense, a belief in the
label: Paragraph

text: transience of material objects as opposed
label: Title

text: to the permanence of form—a metonym for
label: Paragraph

text: the nature of the kami—is ritually enacted.
label: Paragraph

text: Most fundamentally, perhaps, the rebuilding
label: Paragraph

text: renews the social contract with the imperial
label: Paragraph

text: family, the core of whose legitimacy lies in the
label: Paragraph

text: long line of its unbroken ancestry.

label: Paragraph

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: The period between 800 and 1000 CE saw
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic transformations across the African/
label: Title

text: Eurasian world. Most significant among
label: Paragraph

text: these were the expansion of Islam across
label: Paragraph

text: northern Africa and the further development
label: Title

text: of Indianization in Southeast Asia. Just
label: Paragraph

text: as Indianization tightened the maritime
label: Paragraph

text: economic connection between China and
label: Title

text: India, Islamization unified the land-based
label: Paragraph

text: connections from Baghdad in Iraq to Cordoba
label: Title

text: in Spain. The water highway and the desert
label: Title

text: highway redefined the very paradigm of
label: Paragraph

text: African and Eurasian civilization. To this must
label: Paragraph

text: be added another sweeping change, the
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhafication of northern China, Korea, and
label: Paragraph

text: Japan. Normally, these transformations are
label: Paragraph

text: viewed as separate and are treated as such.
label: Paragraph

text: From a global perspective, however, they
label: Paragraph

text: are interlocked, and together they set the
label: Paragraph

text: foundations for the modern world.
label: Paragraph

text: To put all this in architectural terms, the
label: Paragraph

text: Mosque of Cordoba in Spain (begun in 784)
label: Caption

text: is contemporaneous with Borodudur (ca.
label: Paragraph

text: 800) in Indonesia and Todai-ji (ca. 730)
label: Paragraph

text: in Japan, each the result of the respective

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: sanctuaries for the devotees of both
label: Title

text: religions. Of these Borobudur was the most

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Salvador de Valdediés and San Julian de
label: Title

text: los Prados, both in Spain, to recognize the
label: Paragraph

text: difference. These are hardly world-class
label: Paragraph

text: structures. Windows are small and unevenly
label: Paragraph

text: spaced. Most of the building is made from
label: Paragraph

text: stone rubble. Compare it to the well-formed
label: Paragraph

text: proportions and meticulous stonework of the
label: Paragraph

text: Armenian church of Saint Hripsime, or to the
label: Paragraph

text: Shore Temple in Mamallapuram, India, or the
label: Paragraph

text: Bhringesvara Shiva Termple in Bhubaneshwar,
label: Paragraph

text: India, both of which demonstrate meticulous
label: Paragraph

text: stonework and complex curving surfaces.
label: Paragraph

text: That said, one has to remark again on a
label: Paragraph

text: fundamental issue. Borobudur is a building
label: Paragraph

text: that is experienced outdoors, meaning
label: Paragraph

text: there is no inner space. It is a custom-built
label: Paragraph

text: mountain; the same can be said of the Shore
label: Paragraph

text: Temple in Mamallapuram. There is an inner
label: Paragraph

text: sanctum, but it is not a public space. Neither
label: Paragraph

text: of these buildings center on a congregational
label: Paragraph

text: ethos. The Mosque of Ibn Tulun in Cairo
label: Caption

text: certainly does, but it too is in essence an
label: Paragraph

text: outdoor building. Though there is a roof over
label: Paragraph

text: part of the structure, apart from the perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: wall there are no inner enclosures. Christians
label: Paragraph

text: alone—with an architecture that draws on its
label: Paragraph

text: sources in the Roman basilica—had by now
label: Paragraph

text: developed the idea of a completely enclosed
label: Paragraph

text: indoor space, with structures built of wood
label: Paragraph

text: and stone. These early churches were not,
label: Paragraph

text: however, for the people. Most Christians, if
label: Paragraph

text: they did worship regularly, did so in more
label: Paragraph

text: modest buildings. The early stone-built
label: Paragraph

text: churches were for the elites and the nobility,
label: Paragraph

text: for whom Christianity brought a special
label: Paragraph

text: standing in the community.
label: Paragraph

text: Think of the 9th century this way: The
label: Paragraph

text: wealth-generating horizon of rice and high-
label: Paragraph

text: end luxury goods was restricted to a narrow
label: Paragraph

text: east-west belt that curved frorn southern
label: Paragraph

text: China through Southeast Asia and India to
label: Title

text: Baghdad and Cairo, with heavy emphasis
label: Paragraph

text: on India. Adding dirnensionality to this
label: Paragraph

text: was a radical intensification of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and engineering around the production of
label: Paragraph

text: rice in Indonesia, Cambodia, Korea, and
label: Paragraph

text: Japan. The combined energy of this trade
label: Paragraph

text: produced inextricable changes at the various
label: Paragraph

text: peripheries, where the first states, Japan to
label: Paragraph

text: the east and Tibet to the north, arise. Soon
label: Paragraph

text: arrows would be pointing even further afield,
label: Paragraph

text: to Scandinavia and southward across the
label: Title

text: great Sahara Desert. Within two hundred
label: Paragraph

text: years these “peripherals” would be firmly
label: Paragraph

text: connected to the larger transcontinental world
label: Title

text: of economic wealth.
label: Paragraph

text: n all of this, one must not forget that
label: Paragraph

text: northern and Inner Asia, separated from the
label: Paragraph

text: south by vast stretches of trackless deserts,
label: Paragraph

text: forest, and tundra, were still inhabited
label: Paragraph

text: by First Society cultures. But even here
label: Paragraph

text: things were by no means static. In northern
label: Paragraph

text: Canada the Dorset hunting culture was being
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by a highly skilled, oceangoing,
label: Paragraph

text: seal-hunting culture known as the Thule
label: Paragraph

text: and later as the Inuit. They would develop
label: Paragraph

text: a unique architectural form known as the
label: Paragraph

text: igloo. An even more significant transformation
label: Paragraph

text: was taking place in the southwest of
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, where corn had been
label: Paragraph

text: introduced around 100 BCE. Beginning in
label: Paragraph

text: the 7th century, the Hohokam began to
label: Paragraph

text: build extensive irrigation networks along the
label: Paragraph

text: lower Salt and middle Gila Rivers. They were
label: Paragraph

text: the only American culture to use irrigation
label: Paragraph

text: north of Mexico. They also integrated corn
label: Paragraph

text: with the development of native plant species
label: Paragraph

text: like mesquite to develop an extensive and
label: Paragraph

text: complex agro-spiritual landscape that would
label: Paragraph

text: culminate in the construction of sacred ritual
label: Paragraph

text: cities in Chaco Canyon between 803 and
label: Paragraph

text: 1130. By this time, corn was also starting to
label: Paragraph

text: make its appearance in the eastern part of
label: Paragraph

text: North America, with dramatic implications to
label: Paragraph

text: come in the subsequent centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: In Mexico, after the collapse of
label: Paragraph

text: Teotihuacan around 600 CE, competition
label: Caption

text: ensued among several important political
label: Paragraph

text: centers in central Mexico, leading to the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of the Toltecs (ca. 800-1000).
label: Paragraph

text: They constructed a vast ceremonial center
label: Paragraph

text: with a large stepped pyramid, known
label: Paragraph

text: as Tula de Allende. To the south, in the
label: Paragraph

text: Mayan heartland, two great cities emerged:
label: Paragraph

text: Palenque in Mexico and Copan in Honduras.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile in Bolivia, of the various regional
label: Paragraph

text: powers that emerged in previous centuries,
label: Paragraph

text: Tiwanaku rose to particular importance.
label: Paragraph

text: Around 700 CE, three centuries into the
label: Paragraph

text: existence of Tiwanaku, all construction efforts
label: Paragraph

text: were suddenly concentrated on making what
label: Paragraph

text: was to become the largest structure in the
label: Paragraph

text: Andes: the Akapana, an astonishing building,
label: Caption

text: carved so precisely from stone that even
label: Paragraph

text: today it elicits a sense of wonder. It was to the
label: Paragraph

text: Americas what Borobudur was to Eurasia, the
label: Paragraph

text: most advanced stone building in the world.
label: Paragraph

text: For its construction, the earlier monuments
label: Paragraph

text: 10.5 Toltec Temple of Tlahuizcalpantecuhtli
label: Caption

text: (“Lord of the Morning Star”), Tula, Mexico
label: Caption

text: of the city were torn down and their stones
label: Paragraph

text: reused. It was a huge, multifaceted platform
label: Paragraph

text: mound or stepped pyramid of earth faced
label: Paragraph

text: with cut andesite, a hard volcanic rock, with
label: Paragraph

text: a sunken open chamber at the summit. It
label: Paragraph

text: was ultimately left unfinished when the city,
label: Paragraph

text: for unknown reasons, was abandoned.

text: RISE OF ISLAM
label: Title

text: Arabia, on account of its extreme climactic
label: Paragraph

text: and geographic conditions, was at the
label: Paragraph

text: periphery of the great cultural centers of the
label: Paragraph

text: age. It was mainly inhabited by nomadic
label: Paragraph

text: Bedouin Arabs who served as traders or
label: Paragraph

text: lived off the land’s meager resources. The
label: Paragraph

text: center of Arabian religion, which focused on
label: Paragraph

text: nature and heavenly bodies, was in Mecca.
label: Paragraph

text: Mohammed (ca. 570-632 CE) began a bitter
label: Paragraph

text: and prolonged struggle with Arab tribes and
label: Title

text: their polytheism, advocating instead a brand
label: Paragraph

text: of monotheism based on universalist and
label: Paragraph

text: egalitarian sociopolitical ideas that conflicted
label: Title

text: with traditional tribal politics.
label: Paragraph

text: Born in Mecca, Mohammed was an
label: Paragraph

text: orphan raised by his uncle. When he was
label: Paragraph

text: forty years old, he retreated into a cave
label: Paragraph

text: near Ramadan, where he received his first
label: Paragraph

text: illumination. After further revelations, he
label: Paragraph

text: began preaching monotheism. Successful in
label: Paragraph

text: attracting followers, he eventually conquered
label: Paragraph

text: Mecca and transformed it into Islam's holiest
label: Paragraph

text: city, which all adult Muslims are required to
label: Paragraph

text: visit at least once in their lives. He died in
label: Paragraph

text: 632 CE after having converted most of Arabia
label: Paragraph

text: to the new creed. Beyond being a prophet,
label: Paragraph

text: Mohammed was also a farsighted statesman,
label: Paragraph

text: a political arbitrator, and a gifted military
label: Paragraph

text: commander, setting the stage for a fusion of
label: Paragraph

text: religion and politics that was to define Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: culture for centuries to come. By 711 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: Muslim Arab armies were attacking northern
label: Paragraph

text: India to the east as well as North Africa to
label: Title

text: the west, and by the end of the 9th century,
label: Paragraph

text: Islam had grown into the largest political
label: Paragraph

text: entity west of China.
label: Paragraph

text: Since Mohammed made no arrangements
label: Title

text: for a successor, dissension arose after his
label: Paragraph

text: leath as to how to govern this vast territory,
label: Paragraph

text: and the conflict between the Abbasids
label: Title

text: and Umayyads created a divide in Islam
label: Paragraph

text: that persists to this day. The Abbasids,
label: Paragraph

text: lescendants of Mohammed's uncle,
label: Paragraph

text: al-Abbas, based their claim to the caliphate
label: Paragraph

text: on the theological aspects of their rulership.
label: Paragraph

text: he Shiites joined with the Abbasids in
label: Paragraph

text: the 8th century, as they, too, believed that
label: Paragraph

text: the caliphs ruled by divine designation
label: Title

text: and thus possessed spiritual authority. The
label: Paragraph

text: Umayyads also saw themselves as heirs to
label: Paragraph

text: the Islamic state but interpreted the caliphate
label: Paragraph

text: as a constitutional necessity working for
label: Paragraph

text: the temporal welfare and protection of
label: Title

text: the community. The conflict between the
label: Paragraph

text: theological and political interpretation of
label: Title

text: rulership continues to be contested. It was
label: Paragraph

text: initially the Umayyads who were dominant,
label: Paragraph

text: governing from their capital in Damascus.
label: Paragraph

text: Able administrators, they ruled for a brief but
label: Paragraph

text: important period over the whole of the Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: realm—the only tirne that it was so unified.
label: Paragraph

text: Muslims do not require a building, or
label: Paragraph

text: even a consecrated space, to worship;
label: Paragraph

text: rather, Islam is based on five “pillars,” the
label: Paragraph

text: most important being the five daily prayers
label: Paragraph

text: performed while facing Mecca. The month
label: Paragraph

text: of Ramadan is also important; during that
label: Paragraph

text: time, Muslims commune with themselves,
label: Paragraph

text: give thanks to God through fasting, and
label: Paragraph

text: make donations to the needy, fulfilling the
label: Paragraph

text: commandments of the third pillar.
label: Paragraph

text: The typical mosque has a courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: through which one enters and that contains
label: Paragraph

text: a well or fountain for washing the hands and
label: Paragraph

text: feet. In the first centuries of Islam, the hall
label: Paragraph

text: of worship was, in most instances, a space
label: Paragraph

text: consisting of rows of columns so that the
label: Paragraph

text: congregation could face the gibla wall—a wall
label: Paragraph

text: that stands at right angles to a line drawn to
label: Paragraph

text: Mecca. The imam, or prayer leader, stands in
label: Paragraph

text: front of a mihrab, or niche, in the middle of
label: Caption

text: the qibla wall. In some mosques, the bay just
label: Paragraph

text: in front of the mihrab is elevated and roofed
label: Paragraph

text: with a dome. To the right of the mihrab is a
label: Paragraph

text: stepped pulpit, the minbar, made of wood
label: Caption

text: or stone, from which the imam can deliver a
label: Paragraph

text: sermon (khutba), usually on Friday. Almost
label: Paragraph

text: all mosques have a minaret from which
label: Paragraph

text: the faithful are called to prayer. There is no
label: Paragraph

text: prescription as to where these should be
label: Paragraph

text: located or how many there must be.
label: Paragraph

text: Tarik Khana (ca. 760 CE) in Damghan,
label: Paragraph

text: northern Iran, is one of the oldest extant
label: Paragraph

text: mosques. Its rectangular shape encloses a
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard and prayer hall. Massive round
label: Paragraph

text: brick columns almost 2 meters in diameter
label: Caption

text: support arcades of tunnel vaults. The Aksa
label: Caption

text: Mosque in Jerusalem (702 CE) shows
label: Paragraph

text: the development of an axis and transept
label: Title

text: emphasizing the qib/a that becomes even
label: Paragraph

text: more pronounced in the El-Hakim Mosque
label: Paragraph

text: (991 CE) in Cairo.
label: Paragraph

text: Umayyad Mosque
label: Title

text: Though the Arabs were initially illiterate,
label: Paragraph

text: their conquests put them in contact with a
label: Paragraph

text: multitude of civilizations, many features of
label: Paragraph

text: which they began to assimilate, much as
label: Paragraph

text: the Romans had done with Greek and Asian
label: Paragraph

text: cultures—except that the Arabs’ transition
label: Title

text: occurred with astonishing rapidity and
label: Paragraph

text: determination. From the Indians, who at that
label: Paragraph

text: time were leaders in the field of mathematics,
label: Paragraph

text: they adopted numbering systems; from
label: Paragraph

text: the Persians, skills in construction; from
label: Paragraph

text: the Byzantines, skills in vaulting; and from
label: Paragraph

text: the Armenians, skills in stonemasonry. The
label: Paragraph

text: center of this learning was Damascus, built
label: Paragraph

text: up by al-Mansur, an Abbasid caliph, who
label: Paragraph

text: lavished the wealth and power of the new
label: Paragraph

text: empire on the city.
label: Paragraph

text: Later, Caliph al-Ma’mun ordered a library
label: Paragraph

text: to be built to house translated books from
label: Paragraph

text: Greece, Byzantium, and India, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: the growing collection of works by Arabic
label: Title

text: scholars. Known as the House of Wisdom
label: Paragraph

text: (opened 1004 CE), it became the most
label: Paragraph

text: outstanding single repository of knowledge
label: Title

text: since the Great Library of Alexandria.
label: Paragraph

text: Libraries were set up in other cities as
label: Paragraph

text: well. Soon Arab scholars were making
label: Paragraph

text: breakthroughs in everything from medicine
label: Title

text: and chemistry to optics and philosophy. In
label: Paragraph

text: 807 CE, Sultan Harun al-Rashid (766-809
label: Caption

text: CE) sent Charlemagne a brass clock with
label: Paragraph

text: a moving ball and brass horsemen who
label: Title

text: stepped out of windows on the hour. There
label: Paragraph

text: was then nothing remotely similar in all of
label: Paragraph

text: Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: The Umayyad Mosque in Damascus
label: Title

text: (709-15 CE), another monumental work of
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic architecture, was built on a religious
label: Paragraph

text: site dating back to an ancient Aramaic
label: Paragraph

text: temple dedicated to the god Hadad. The
label: Paragraph

text: Romans built a Temple of Jupiter on the
label: Paragraph

text: site, a building that was, in the 4th century,
label: Paragraph

text: transformed into a church (the Cathedral of
label: Paragraph

text: St. John) situated on the western side of the
label: Paragraph

text: temple. The church was then incorporated
label: Paragraph

text: into the design of the mosque, which consists
label: Paragraph

text: of three parallel ranges of space facing onto a
label: Paragraph

text: large, enclosed courtyard.
label: Paragraph

text: After the Islamic conquest of Damascus in
label: Paragraph

text: 661 CE during the reign of the first Urnayyad
label: Paragraph

text: caliph, Mu’awiya ibn Abi Sufiyan, Muslims at
label: Paragraph

text: first shared the church with Christians. The
label: Paragraph

text: caliph eventually negotiated with Christian
label: Paragraph

text: leaders to take over the space; in return,
label: Paragraph

text: he promised that all the other churches
label: Paragraph

text: in the city would be safe and that a new
label: Paragraph

text: church, dedicated to the Virgin Mary, could
label: Paragraph

text: be erected. Darnascus itself was completely
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilt in the shape of a rectangle bisected
label: Paragraph

text: by a Hellenistic-inspired colonnaded road
label: Paragraph

text: running north and south and crossing at the
label: Paragraph

text: center, where the principal buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: positioned.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan of the mosque is a 97-by-156-
label: Paragraph

text: meter rectangle with three gates that connect
label: Paragraph

text: the building to the city from the northern,
label: Paragraph

text: eastern, and western sides. The mosque is
label: Paragraph

text: defined by three halls, or riwaqs, that run
label: Paragraph

text: parallel to the qib/a wall. They are supported
label: Paragraph

text: by two rows of stone Corinthian columns.
label: Caption

text: Large and classically proportioned arches
label: Caption

text: support a second, smaller colonnade, on
label: Paragraph

text: which the massive wooden beams of the roof
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine church
label: Title

text: 10.7 Courtyard, Umayyad Mosque, Damascus, Syria
label: Caption

text: Court (sahr)
label: Title

text: rest. The location of the mihrab is enhanced
label: Paragraph

text: in the center by the octagonal, 36-meter-high
label: Caption

text: isr Dome (“Dome of the Eagle”). In the
label: Paragraph

text: eastern part of the mosque, a small marble
label: Caption

text: structure between the columns of the riwaq
label: Caption

text: olds the tomb of St. John the Baptist, who
label: Paragraph

text: in Islamic tradition is known as the prophet
label: Paragraph

text: Yahya. The building was richly outfitted
label: Paragraph

text: with marble paneling and mosaics. In the
label: Caption

text: eginning of the 8th century, Caliph al-Walid
label: Paragraph

text: ibn Abd al-Malik addressed the citizens of
label: Paragraph

text: Damascus thus: “Inhabitants of Damascus,
label: Paragraph

text: four things give you marked superiority over
label: Title

text: the rest of the world: your climate, your water,
label: Title

text: your fruits, and your baths. To these | wanted
label: Paragraph

text: to add a fifth: this mosque.” Originally, the
label: Paragraph

text: mosque was abutted by a palace on its
label: Paragraph

text: southern flank, with a special entrance next
label: Paragraph

text: to the mihrab.

text: Baghdad
label: Title

text: The Umayyad dynasty, which had its center
label: Paragraph

text: in Damascus, fell in the mid-8th century. The
label: Paragraph

text: new rulers, the Abbasids (r. 758-1258 CE),
label: Paragraph

text: eventually became the champions of Sunni
label: Paragraph

text: orthodoxy—a policy that helped ther to
label: Paragraph

text: unify an increasingly cosmopolitan Muslim
label: Title

text: empire. They constructed a new capital city,
label: Paragraph

text: Baghdad, to the west of Damascus and on
label: Paragraph

text: the banks of the Tigris River. Engineers from
label: Paragraph

text: the entire Islamic world were called to the site
label: Paragraph

text: to help in its planning and construction from
label: Paragraph

text: The layout, one of the most remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: examples of town planning in history, was a
label: Paragraph

text: simple circle about 3,000 meters across. The
label: Paragraph

text: walls were built of bricks and ornamented
label: Paragraph

text: with colorful tiles. Two rings of residential
label: Caption

text: zones lined the inside walls, leaving a vast
label: Paragraph

text: area open in the middle for the palace
label: Caption

text: and mosque. The walls were punctured by
label: Paragraph

text: four gates. Though there are other smaller,
label: Paragraph

text: regional examples of circular cities, this was
label: Paragraph

text: by far the most elaborate. The city prospered,
label: Paragraph

text: and with a population of about two million, it
label: Paragraph

text: became a center of science, literature, and
label: Paragraph

text: art, like Damascus. However, nothing of the
label: Paragraph

text: city remains: it perished as a consequence
label: Paragraph

text: of numerous sieges and inundations. The
label: Paragraph

text: Abbasid dynasty ended when Baghdad fell to
label: Paragraph

text: the Mongols in 1258.

text: Made possible by the wealth of the Abbasid

text: rulers, palaces of great size sprang up

label: Paragraph

text: Palace of Ukhaidir in the desert about 200
label: Caption

text: kilometers south of Baghdad. It consists of
label: Paragraph

text: a rectangular enclosure approximately 175
label: Paragraph

text: by 170 meters, with a gateway at the center
label: Paragraph

text: of each of the round towers at the corners
label: Caption

text: and semicircular towers spaced regularly
label: Paragraph

text: between them. The main entrance led to an
label: Paragraph

text: autonomous royal enclave (approximately 60
label: Title

text: by 80 meters) positioned close to the north
label: Paragraph

text: wall. It had a large courtyard and a barrel-
label: Paragraph

text: vaulted iwan throne room, behind which was
label: Paragraph

text: the royal apartment. Around that complex

text: In 836 CE, the Abbasid capital was moved
label: Paragraph

text: to Samarra, some 40 kilometers north of
label: Paragraph

text: Baghdad. Samarra soon ranked among the
label: Paragraph

text: greatest of the early Islamic cities. Though
label: Paragraph

text: it remained the capital only until 892 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: it prospered for centuries, reaching an
label: Paragraph

text: area of 50 square kilometers. The caliph’s
label: Paragraph

text: residence itself took up 173 hectares on
label: Paragraph

text: a cliff overlooking the Tigris River. Equally
label: Paragraph

text: impressive were the two mosques, the Great
label: Paragraph

text: Mosque of al-Mutawakkil (848-52 CE) and
label: Caption

text: the Mosque of Abu Dulaf (860 CE), both
label: Paragraph

text: designed to look like desert fortresses. The
label: Paragraph

text: bastioned walls of the Great Mosque of
label: Caption

text: al-Mutawakkil measured 240 by 156 meters,
label: Paragraph

text: and for centuries it was the largest mosque
label: Paragraph

text: in the world. There were sixteen doorways
label: Paragraph

text: that fed into the vast interior. On the inside,
label: Paragraph

text: four hypostyle structures (one prayer hall
label: Caption

text: and three porticoes) were arranged around
label: Paragraph

text: a large courtyard. Unlike in Damascus,
label: Paragraph

text: where the three minarets were placed in
label: Paragraph

text: the corners of the enclosing wall and one
label: Paragraph

text: in the middle of the wall, here the minaret
label: Paragraph

text: was a freestanding element placed on axis
label: Paragraph

text: in front of the principal north entrance of
label: Caption

text: the mosque. It had a helicoidal shape that
label: Paragraph

text: reached 50 meters to the summit, with an
label: Paragraph

text: external staircase.

text: Arab forces occupied Alexandria in 643 CE
label: Title

text: and crossed the Straits of Gibraltar in 711 Ce.
label: Paragraph

text: From there, they made forays over the entire
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean into Italy and France, driving
label: Paragraph

text: out the monks frorn Monte Cassino, south
label: Caption

text: of Rome, in 883 CE. By the mid-7th century,
label: Paragraph

text: however, the Muslim world had lost any real
label: Paragraph

text: political unity: the Abbasid caliphate began
label: Title

text: to disintegrate, and in the mid-10th century,
label: Paragraph

text: rival caliphates established thernselves in
label: Paragraph

text: Cairo and Cordoba. Originally, the Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: territories were administered by a provincial
label: Paragraph

text: government established in the name of the
label: Paragraph

text: Umayyad caliphate based in Damascus. But
label: Paragraph

text: when that dynasty was overthrown, its last
label: Paragraph

text: surviving member, Emir Abd al-Rahman I,
label: Paragraph

text: fled to Spain. Under him, Cordoba became
label: Paragraph

text: the quasi-autonomous capital of a vibrant
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic culture. By the end of the 10th
label: Paragraph

text: century, it had becorne the largest city in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, with a population of about one
label: Paragraph

text: hundred thousand. It was also an important
label: Paragraph

text: center of Arabic learning, making crucial
label: Paragraph

text: contributions to European civilization.
label: Paragraph

text: The first building of significance designed
label: Paragraph

text: under Abd al-Rahrman | was the Great
label: Paragraph

text: Mosque of Cérdoba (784-87 Ce). Only the
label: Paragraph

text: southwest part, the original prayer hall, still
label: Caption

text: survives more or less unaltered. The mosque,
label: Paragraph

text: modeled loosely on the Urnayyad Mosque in
label: Paragraph

text: Damascus (706-15 CE), included a walled-in
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard opening onto a hypostyle structure
label: Caption

text: consisting of twelve bays with ten columns
label: Caption

text: Mediterranean Sea
label: Title

text: 10.14 Roofscape, Great Mosque of Cordoba, Spain
label: Caption

text: each. The columns taken from Roman
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were chosen for their whitish tone.
label: Paragraph

text: The capitals are spoils taken from destroyed
label: Paragraph

text: churches and Roman civic buildings. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: the unusual siting of the mosque at the
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter of the city may be due to its being
label: Paragraph

text: built over the ruins of a Roman warehouse.
label: Paragraph

text: The principal shape of the arches above
label: Paragraph

text: the columns is, however, unique—a high
label: Paragraph

text: horseshoe arch with a nested free-spanning
label: Paragraph

text: arch below it. The voussoirs, alternately of red
label: Paragraph

text: brick and white stone, create dramatic three-
label: Paragraph

text: 10.15 Dome structure, Great Mosque of Cordoba
label: Caption

text: dimensional diagonal vistas. The building
label: Caption

text: signals that the rulers had corne to terms with
label: Paragraph

text: certain aspects of the existing architectural
label: Paragraph

text: tradition, which they incorporated with great
label: Paragraph

text: ingenuity into their design. The horseshoe-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped arches are thought to have been
label: Paragraph

text: adapted frorn the remains of local Visigoth
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The minaret, topped with a
label: Paragraph

text: domed pavilion, was one of the first tower
label: Paragraph

text: minarets in Islam. The mosque does not face
label: Paragraph

text: Mecca, but the reason is not clear.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Over time, the structure was lengthened
label: Paragraph

text: and widened, but always with reverence for
label: Paragraph

text: the initial design. The addition of al-Hakam
label: Paragraph

text: Il (964 CE) is the most elabaorate of the
label: Paragraph

text: extensions. Unlike the previous extension
label: Paragraph

text: that featured white columns, this one
label: Paragraph

text: featured black and red columns placed in
label: Caption

text: an alternating scheme. Craftsmen made
label: Paragraph

text: capitals on a simplified Corinthian model.
label: Caption

text: Al-Hakam II's addition also included a
label: Paragraph

text: new mihrab with a remarkable set of three
label: Paragraph

text: domes added to the last bay. The central
label: Caption

text: dome is spectacular. Unlike Roman domes,
label: Paragraph

text: which were primarily spatial elernents, or
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine domes, which were props for
label: Paragraph

text: spatially ambiguous mosaics, this dome
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized a combination of geometric
label: Paragraph

text: logic and decorative detail. It seems to rest
label: Paragraph

text: on the square base as an elevated building
label: Paragraph

text: supported by column bundles from which
label: Paragraph

text: spring a set of intersecting arches that in
label: Paragraph

text: plan form two intersecting squares. The result
label: Paragraph

text: is an octagonal frame that holds a petaled,
label: Paragraph

text: umbrella-shaped dome, trimmed in white
label: Paragraph

text: at its base. This is not a dome in the sense
label: Paragraph

text: of a unified object, but a series of spatial
label: Paragraph

text: layers that act horizontally and vertically. Light
label: Paragraph

text: filtering in through the screens of the lower
label: Paragraph

text: register of arches contrasts with the dark
label: Paragraph

text: niches at the corners. The mosaics, executed
label: Caption

text: by Byzantine craftsmen, complete the design
label: Paragraph

text: with plant and vine motifs.

text: 10.20 Site plan: Temple Mount, Jerusalem
label: Caption

text: Dome of the Rock
label: Title

text: With the Islamic conquest of Palestine and
label: Paragraph

text: Jerusalem in the third decade of the 7th
label: Title

text: century, Caliph Abd al-Malik brought in the
label: Paragraph

text: best masons and craftsmen available to design
label: Title

text: the Dome of the Rock, or in Arabic, the Haram
label: Paragraph

text: al-Sharif (“Noble Sanctuary”), which is today
label: Paragraph

text: the oldest Islamic building to have survived
label: Paragraph

text: intact in its original form. Completed in 691
label: Caption

text: CE, it encloses a huge rock at its center, the
label: Paragraph

text: highest point of Mt. Moriah, from which,
label: Paragraph

text: according to tradition, the prophet Mohammed
label: Paragraph

text: ascended to heaven at the end of his Isra’
label: Paragraph

text: (or Night Journey) to Jerusalem. In the older,
label: Paragraph

text: Jewish tradition, this is the Foundation Stone,
label: Paragraph

text: the symbolic underpinning upon which
label: Paragraph

text: the world was created, as well as the place
label: Paragraph

text: of Abraham's binding of Isaac. This same
label: Paragraph

text: location is also where numerous important
label: Paragraph

text: events in the life of Christ are believed to have
label: Paragraph

text: occurred. The site is therefore holy to the
label: Paragraph

text: Jewish, Christian, and Islamic religions.
label: Paragraph

text: The building, which is Byzantine in
label: Paragraph

text: conception and Sassanian in ornamentation,
label: Paragraph

text: can be entered on all four points of the
label: Paragraph

text: compass. The central space, however, is
label: Paragraph

text: inaccessible. The dome reaches 20 meters
label: Paragraph

text: across the rock and is borne on a drum
label: Paragraph

text: that rests on a double system of pillars and
label: Paragraph

text: columns, the middle one circular, the outer
label: Paragraph

text: one octagonal. The two rings, composed of
label: Paragraph

text: piers and columns, are rotated so that the
label: Paragraph

text: four piers of the inner ring face the arches of
label: Paragraph

text: the outer octagonal ring, creating a dynamic
label: Paragraph

text: interplay between square and circular
label: Title

text: geometries.
label: Paragraph

text: 10.21 Dome of the Rock, Jerusalem
label: Caption

text: The dome and drum are not of brick or stone,
label: Paragraph

text: but of wood. The dome is covered today with
label: Paragraph

text: golden copper-alloy plates, and the drum with
label: Paragraph

text: shimmering mosaic patterns of blue, red,
label: Paragraph

text: green, and gray. The interior, in the Byzantine
label: Caption

text: manner, was decorated with mosaics, with a
label: Paragraph

text: marble veneer in the lower section. Though
label: Paragraph

text: technically not a mosque, the building is
label: Paragraph

text: much more. It is not only a geometrical and
label: Paragraph

text: paradisiacal enclosure and a celebration of a
label: Title

text: spot of particular reverence but also a parallel
label: Paragraph

text: to the Ka'aba in Mecca. Unlike that building,
label: Paragraph

text: which can be circumambulated but not
label: Paragraph

text: entered, this one can indeed be entered—yet
label: Paragraph

text: because of the presence of the rock, the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the building remains inaccessible.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, one gazes not at a rock, but at
label: Paragraph

text: the peak of the mount; the architecture thus
label: Paragraph

text: creates the feeling of suspending the viewer in
label: Paragraph

text: space around that peak.
label: Paragraph

text: The history of the building site has been
label: Paragraph

text: much debated. It was first consecrated by
label: Paragraph

text: the Israelites when they built the First and
label: Paragraph

text: Second Temples. After the Second Temple
label: Paragraph

text: was razed by the Romans in 70 CE, Emperor
label: Paragraph

text: Hadrian built a temple to Jupiter there that
label: Paragraph

text: was perhaps connected to an octagonal
label: Paragraph

text: structure that served as the foundation of
label: Paragraph

text: the Dome of the Rock—but this has not yet
label: Paragraph

text: been archaeologically proven. The crusaders
label: Paragraph

text: consecrated the building as a Catholic church,
label: Paragraph

text: but with their defeat, the site reverted back to
label: Paragraph

text: Islam.
label: Paragraph

text: 10.23 Mahavihara at Nalanda, Bihar, India
label: Caption

text: MAHAVIHARAS AT NALANDA
label: Title

text: Mahavihara (literally “great vihara”)
label: Title

text: was the term used to designate the
label: Paragraph

text: huge Buddhist universities that were
label: Paragraph

text: established by the Guptas in the 5th
label: Paragraph

text: century and that flourished until the
label: Paragraph

text: 12th century. The most famous of these
label: Paragraph

text: was Nalanda. Almost every Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrim to India made a stop at Nalanda.
label: Paragraph

text: Mahaviharas like Nalanda were
label: Paragraph

text: multidisciplinary universities devoted
label: Title

text: not only to the preparation of Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: practitioners but also to the study of
label: Paragraph

text: secular disciplines. Officially established
label: Paragraph

text: by the Gupta king Kumara Gupta |
label: Caption

text: (415-55 CE), Nalanda boomed in the
label: Paragraph

text: reign of Harshavardhana. Nalanda had
label: Paragraph

text: more than two thousand senior monks
label: Title

text: and about ten thousand disciples.
label: Paragraph

text: heravada, the school of Buddhism
label: Title

text: followed mainly in Sri Lanka, Burma,
label: Paragraph

text: hailand, and Cambodia, developed
label: Paragraph

text: ere. Besides the various schools
label: Paragraph

text: of Buddhism, including Hinayana,
label: Paragraph

text: Mahayana, and Tantric, courses on the
label: Paragraph

text: ndo-Aryan Vedas, hetu vidya (“logic”),
label: Paragraph

text: shabda vidya (“grammar”), and chikitsa
label: Paragraph

text: vidya (medicine) were also taught at
label: Paragraph

text: jalanda. The Chinese pilgrim Hsuan
label: Caption

text: Tsang (Xuanzang) spent most of his time
label: Paragraph

text: at Nalanda studying law.
label: Paragraph

text: Stupas
label: Title

text: Aryabhatta, the 5th-century astronomer
label: Title

text: and mathematician (b. 476 CE in Kerala,
label: Paragraph

text: India) came to Nalanda as a boy to study
label: Paragraph

text: astronomy. He was one of the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: people to support the theory that the earth
label: Title

text: is a sphere, preceding Copernicus by a
label: Paragraph

text: millennium. His main work, known as the
label: Paragraph

text: Aryabhattiya, was translated into Latin in
label: Paragraph

text: the 13th century. It included methods of
label: Paragraph

text: calculating the area of a triangle, the volume
label: Paragraph

text: of a sphere, and square and cube roots.
label: Paragraph

text: Aryabhatta also wrote about eclipses and
label: Paragraph

text: proposed the sun as the source of moonlight.
label: Paragraph

text: Another 7th-century Indian astronomer,
label: Paragraph

text: Brahmagupta, calculated the circumference
label: Paragraph

text: of the earth as 5,000 yojanas, or about
label: Paragraph

text: 36,000 kilometers, only 4,000 short of its true
label: Paragraph

text: distance. The number zero, called sunya,
label: Paragraph

text: (meaning “void” or “empty") was invented
label: Paragraph

text: at this time. Sunya passed into the Arabic
label: Paragraph

text: as sifr, meaning “vacant.” In about 1200 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: this word was transliterated into Latin, but
label: Paragraph

text: its original meaning was lost, resulting in the
label: Paragraph

text: word zephirum (or zephyrum).
label: Paragraph

text: Nalanda consisted of ten quadrangles
label: Paragraph

text: covering 14 hectares, all lined up in a block
label: Paragraph

text: and packed next to each other. Made of
label: Paragraph

text: brick, each vihara, 50 to 60 meters long,
label: Paragraph

text: had a central courtyard (some with a shrine)
label: Paragraph

text: ringed by two or three stories of cells for the
label: Caption

text: monks, who lived about thirty to a floor. The
label: Paragraph

text: viharas faced a row of freestanding stupas
label: Paragraph

text: (sometimes described as caitya temples)
label: Paragraph

text: also made of brick, each with long central
label: Paragraph

text: stairways leading to a platform on which
label: Paragraph

text: stood the main shrine, with subsidiary shrines
label: Paragraph

text: at the corners. In its time, the street between
label: Paragraph

text: the viharas and the stupas would have been
label: Paragraph

text: packed with monks and their disciples.
label: Paragraph

text: After Harshavardhana, the Pala kings
label: Paragraph

text: of Bengal maintained Nalanda for four
label: Paragraph

text: centuries, until the 11th century. In fact, the
label: Paragraph

text: surviving ruins date frorn the Pala period. The
label: Paragraph

text: Palas were also the patrons of several other
label: Paragraph

text: monastic universities, such as at Vikramsila
label: Paragraph

text: and Somapura. So numerous were the
label: Paragraph

text: vibaras that the name of the modern state
label: Paragraph

text: in this region, Bihar, is a contraction of the
label: Paragraph

text: Sanskrit for “Land of the Viharas."
label: Paragraph

text: RAJASIMHESVARA AND VIRUPAKSHA
label: Title

text: TEMPLES
label: Title

text: While India was ruled by a series of diverse
label: Paragraph

text: kingdoms, the competition in south India
label: Title

text: between the Chalukyas and the Pallavas
label: Title

text: intensified. Victorious kings routinely carried
label: Paragraph

text: the other’s masons and temple builders back
label: Title

text: home with them. The consequence was a
label: Paragraph

text: cross-fertilization of temple design. As a temple
label: Paragraph

text: inscription notes, the Rajasimhesvara Temple
label: Caption

text: (700-730 CE)—built by the Pallava king in his
label: Paragraph

text: capital, Kanchipurarn—was the model for the
label: Paragraph

text: Virupaksha Temple (733-44 CE), built by the
label: Paragraph

text: Chalukyan queen at Pattadakal. Workmen from
label: Caption

text: Rajasimhesvara also worked on the Virupaksha;
label: Paragraph

text: the two make for an interesting comparison.
label: Paragraph

text: Basic Vocabulary of Hindu Architecture
label: Title

text: Garbha-griha: Literally, “womb chamber”;
label: Paragraph

text: innermost sanctum
label: Title

text: Lingam: Literally, “phallus,” but also “mark”
label: Paragraph

text: or “sign”; the symbol for Shiva. (Shaivite
label: Paragraph

text: temples face east; Vaishnavite temples face
label: Paragraph

text: west.)
label: Paragraph

text: Shikhara: Literally, “mountain peak”; the
label: Paragraph

text: rising tower of north Indian temples
label: Caption

text: Gopuram: A monumental tower at the
label: Caption

text: entrance of south Indian temples
label: Title

text: Pradakshina: Circumambulation
label: Title

text: Prasada: Literally, “palace”; temple precinct
label: Paragraph

text: Mandapa: A pillared hall in front of the
label: Paragraph

text: temple and sometimes connected to it; if a
label: Paragraph

text: temple has more than one mandapa, each
label: Paragraph

text: is allocated a different function and given a
label: Paragraph

text: name to reflect its use.
label: Paragraph
