label: Caption

text: The two temples’ similarities involve
label: Paragraph

text: their size and organizational type, rather
label: Paragraph

text: than their appearance and formal order.
label: Paragraph

text: Though most Hindu temples face east,
label: Paragraph

text: Virupaksha, being a Shiva temple, faces
label: Paragraph

text: west. The garbha-grihas of both temples
label: Caption

text: are surrounded by a well-defined and fully
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed parikrama path, but Rajasimhesvara
label: Paragraph

text: jas nine subsidiary shrines arrayed in
label: Paragraph

text: constellation around it, while the Virupaksha
label: Paragraph

text: establishes the presence of subsidiary
label: Paragraph

text: shrines through articulations of the outer wall.
label: Paragraph

text: Both have attached mandapas, but while
label: Paragraph

text: Rajasimhesvara’s two enclosed mandapas
label: Title

text: set up a single longitudinal axis, Virupaksha’s
label: Paragraph

text: single mandapa is fully pierced and sets
label: Paragraph

text: up a cross-axis with spatial dynamism.
label: Paragraph

text: Both temples are located with their own
label: Paragraph

text: precincts of roughly equivalent size, and
label: Paragraph

text: oth have large entrance gopurams. But
label: Paragraph

text: while Rajasimhesvara's precinct is packed
label: Paragraph

text: with a phalanx of subsidiary shrines, and in
label: Paragraph

text: act has the beginnings of a second precinct
label: Paragraph

text: enclosure also made of subsidiary shrines,
label: Paragraph

text: Virupaksha’s precinct has only an episodic
label: Paragraph

text: collection of subsidiary shrines attached to
label: Paragraph

text: it and breaks to respond to the cross-axis of
label: Paragraph

text: the mandapa. The Virupaksha, being a Shiva
label: Paragraph

text: shrine, also has the requirement of a Nandi
label: Paragraph

text: pavilion for Shiva’s bull; the pavilion sits as a
label: Paragraph

text: separate element in its forecourt.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike earlier Hindu temples in which the
label: Paragraph

text: garbha-griha is framed by its plinth and
label: Paragraph

text: precinct walls, here the outer frame and the
label: Paragraph

text: inner garbha-griha are locked into each other
label: Paragraph

text: by means of spatial intermediaries, including
label: Paragraph

text: the mandapa, that allow for both axial and
label: Paragraph

text: circumambulatory readings. Overall, the
label: Paragraph

text: geometric order of the Virupaksha is more
label: Paragraph

text: 10.29 Virupaksha Temple
label: Caption

text: articulated than that of the Rajasimhesvara,
label: Paragraph

text: as is evidenced in the ordering of the twelve
label: Paragraph

text: freestanding columns of the mandapa
label: Caption

text: that are extended into the edges, either by
label: Paragraph

text: pilasters or by columns, and arranged to
label: Paragraph

text: clear the path of the cross-axis. The inner
label: Paragraph

text: columns of the Rajasimhesvara, by contrast,
label: Paragraph

text: are laid out by a simple arithmetic geometry.
label: Paragraph

text: KAILASNATH AT ELLORA
label: Title

text: Control of the Deccan Plateau was wrested
label: Paragraph

text: from the Chalukyas around 750 CE by the
label: Paragraph

text: Rashtrakutas, who ruled for about two
label: Paragraph

text: centuries, until 973 CE. The Rashtrakutas
label: Paragraph

text: quickly established their military superiority
label: Paragraph

text: and captured the all-important trade routes
label: Paragraph

text: that connected the western region to the
label: Paragraph

text: rest of the subcontinent, in particular, the
label: Paragraph

text: dakshinapatha, or southern route. On the
label: Paragraph

text: dakshinapatha at Verul (contemporary Ellora),
label: Paragraph

text: the Rashtrakuta ruler Krishna | ordered the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of what was to become the
label: Paragraph

text: largest rock-cut temple ever. Fifty meters
label: Caption

text: wide, more than 90 meters deep, and 20
label: Paragraph

text: meters high, Kailasnath is in the middle of
label: Paragraph

text: the 3-kilometer-long wall of basalt that has
label: Paragraph

text: thirty-four caves carved out of it (twelve are
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist, seventeen Hindu, and five Jain,
label: Paragraph

text: dating from 600 to 1000 CE). Kailasnath
label: Caption

text: is conceived as a representation of the
label: Paragraph

text: mythological mountain abode of Shiva,
label: Paragraph

text: Mt. Kailash. Unlike the Buddhist rock-cut
label: Paragraph

text: structures that essentially had always been
label: Paragraph

text: elaborations of a cave, Kailasnath is an
label: Paragraph

text: independent entity, a freestanding colossal
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture revealed from the matrix. Since it is
label: Paragraph

text: still surrounded by the rock from which it was
label: Paragraph

text: hewn, there is a palpable sense of excavation
label: Paragraph

text: to Kailasnath, as if it were still a work in
label: Paragraph

text: progress.
label: Paragraph

text: ie) 50m

text: 10.31 Longitudinal section: Kailasnath, Ellora
label: Caption

text: 10.32 Plan: Kailasnath, Ellora

text: 10.33 Cross-section: Kailasnath, Ellora
label: Caption

text: Two “victory towers” have been left on either
label: Paragraph

text: side of the mass of the Nandi chamber.
label: Caption

text: They not only provide the vertical axis of
label: Paragraph

text: the composition, but their length also visibly
label: Paragraph

text: measures the mass of the rock that has
label: Paragraph

text: been excavated. From outside, the temple
label: Paragraph

text: is almost entirely obscured by its two-storied
label: Paragraph

text: entrance gopuram (flanked on either side
label: Caption

text: by Shaivite and Vaishnavite figures) on
label: Paragraph

text: the west that leads, through a vestibule,
label: Paragraph

text: into the main space. The ground floor is
label: Paragraph

text: dominated by the immense presence of
label: Paragraph

text: the excavated mass, since the body of the
label: Paragraph

text: temple at this level is mostly solid and cannot
label: Paragraph

text: be entered. Toward the back, the perimeter
label: Paragraph

text: is ringed by a colonnade of square pillars
label: Paragraph

text: whose only purpose seems to be to support
label: Paragraph

text: the overhanging rock. In the midst of an
label: Paragraph

text: elaborate sculptural program, the lower
label: Paragraph

text: rock mass of the main shrine has life-size
label: Paragraph

text: elephants carved into it, as if they were
label: Paragraph

text: supporting the temple above.
label: Caption

text: 10.34 Detail: Temple of Kailasnath, Ellora
label: Caption

text: Access to the main level of the temple is from
label: Paragraph

text: a pair of symmetrical stairs on the west that
label: Paragraph

text: emerge into the entrance vestibule of the
label: Paragraph

text: shrine. The mandapa has sixteen columns
label: Paragraph

text: clumped into groups of four, creating a
label: Paragraph

text: cruciform central space that opens into
label: Paragraph

text: smaller porches on the north and south.
label: Caption

text: The garbha-griha has no inner parikrama;
label: Paragraph

text: it is instead on the outside, defined by five
label: Paragraph

text: subsidiary shrines. Bridges connect the main
label: Paragraph

text: shrine with the Nandi chamber and the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance gopuram as well. The shikhara—or
label: Paragraph

text: tower—of the main shrine has a four-tiered
label: Caption

text: pyramidal shape resolving into an octagonal
label: Paragraph

text: finial. The subsidiary shrines use the same
label: Paragraph

text: vocabulary. Toward the north, on the cross-
label: Paragraph

text: axis with the mandapa, there is another
label: Paragraph

text: rock-cut ternple, Lankesvara, complete with a
label: Caption

text: sixteen-pillared mandapa and garbha-griha,
label: Caption

text: that almost rivals the main shrine. And to the
label: Paragraph

text: south there are two additional shrines, also
label: Paragraph

text: rock-cut, one of which extends almost 25
label: Paragraph

text: meters into the rock.
label: Paragraph

text: Most discussions of Kailasnath’s
label: Title

text: construction process assume that gigantic
label: Paragraph

text: trenches were dug into the rock to clear out
label: Paragraph

text: the main mass of the temple; this would have
label: Paragraph

text: been followed by a process of excavating
label: Paragraph

text: and sculpting. A counterintuitive possibility
label: Paragraph

text: is suggested by the subsidiary shrines—in
label: Paragraph

text: particular the one to the north—which are
label: Paragraph

text: excavated so deep into the rock; the same
label: Paragraph

text: process might have been employed for the
label: Paragraph

text: main shrine. Since Kailasnath is derived from
label: Paragraph

text: rock-cut cave ternple precedents, excavating
label: Caption

text: the sacred cave and then, in an act of
label: Paragraph

text: superseding the infinity of the mountain
label: Paragraph

text: around the traditional caves, “uncovering”
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior in the form of a complete temple,
label: Paragraph

text: makes sense conceptually as well. There
label: Paragraph

text: would have been no room for error, since
label: Paragraph

text: rock cannot be replaced. Making the temple
label: Paragraph

text: had to have been an act of skilled and
label: Paragraph

text: deliberate craftsmanship. The Rashtrakutas
label: Paragraph

text: would, of course, also have been very
label: Paragraph

text: familiar with the constructed temples of
label: Paragraph

text: the Chalukyas, their predecessors, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Pallavas and Pandyas, their contemporaries
label: Paragraph

text: to the south. The reason for their decision to
label: Paragraph

text: dedicate the full extent of their resources to
label: Paragraph

text: the creation of a gigantic rock-cut structure
label: Paragraph

text: is unknown, but it must have had to do with
label: Paragraph

text: reasserting the value of the traditional way
label: Paragraph

text: of making a monumental ritual structure in
label: Paragraph

text: the face of the imminent modernity of the
label: Paragraph

text: structural stone temple.
label: Paragraph

text: 10.35 Detail: Temple of Kailasnath, Ellora
label: Caption

text: SAMYE, TIBET
label: Title

text: A century after the introduction of Buddhism into
label: Paragraph

text: Tibet, King Trisong Detsen formally established
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism as the state religion by building the
label: Paragraph

text: Samye Monastery. Its full name is Bsam yas
label: Paragraph

text: mi ‘gyur Ihun grub gtsug lag khang, or the
label: Paragraph

text: “Temple of Unchanging Spontaneous Presence”
label: Title

text: (founded 775 CE, constructed 787-91 CE).
label: Paragraph

text: The first Tibetan monks were ordained here,
label: Paragraph

text: and it was the seat of Tibetan Buddhism until
label: Paragraph

text: the establishment of the Potala Palace by the
label: Paragraph

text: fifth Dalai Lama in the 17th century. Located
label: Caption

text: in the Chimpu Valley just south of Lhasa, the
label: Paragraph

text: monastery was laid out in the form of a mandala,
label: Paragraph

text: with a circular perimeter wall about 300
label: Paragraph

text: meters in diameter; the main ternple, the Utse,
label: Paragraph

text: representing Mt. Meru, is in the center. The wall
label: Caption

text: is topped by 1,008 tiny chortens with gates at
label: Paragraph

text: the four cardinal points. The four continents in
label: Paragraph

text: the ocean around Mt. Meru are represented by
label: Paragraph

text: temples at the cardinal points, each flanked by
label: Paragraph

text: two smaller temples to symbolize islands. The
label: Paragraph

text: Utse has three main stories, each of which was
label: Paragraph

text: designed in a different traditional architectural
label: Paragraph

text: style—Indian, Chinese, and Tibetan. The first
label: Paragraph

text: floor is dominated by the main assembly hall;
label: Paragraph

text: the second is basically an open roof area where
label: Paragraph

text: monks and locals carry out the craftwork for the
label: Paragraph

text: temple; and the third is the palace of the Dalai
label: Paragraph

text: Lama, with a small anteroom, throne room, and
label: Paragraph

text: bedroom. Four chortens at the corners of the
label: Caption

text: Utse are brightly colored black, white, red, and
label: Paragraph

text: green. Each has stairs and small chapels. There
label: Paragraph

text: is a nyima (“sun”) temple in the north and a
label: Paragraph

text: dawa (“moon") temple to the south. Though all
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist temples are modeled on an imaginary
label: Paragraph

text: mandala, this one has the mandala as its basic
label: Paragraph

text: plan, writ large in the landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: INDONESIA AT A CROSSROADS
label: Title

text: By the 9th century, the entire region of
label: Paragraph

text: Southeast Asia had begun to cohere as a
label: Paragraph

text: series of relatively stable states linked by
label: Paragraph

text: trade and religion. Guangzhou was the
label: Paragraph

text: primary entry point into China. Kunming,
label: Paragraph

text: a quasi-independent state (to become the
label: Paragraph

text: ingdom of Dali) was the primary land-based
label: Paragraph

text: entry point. Particularly important was the
label: Paragraph

text: development of trade around the Straits of
label: Title

text: Malacca. Ships no longer unloaded at Kedah
label: Paragraph

text: ior the portage across the peninsula. With the
label: Paragraph

text: sea route now becoming the norm, Sumatra
label: Paragraph

text: and Indonesia quickly became a strategically
label: Paragraph

text: important area. The rulers of the Srivijaya
label: Paragraph

text: Empire made their wealth less on export than
label: Paragraph

text: on transit tariffs, since almost all shipping
label: Paragraph

text: trade had to go through the Malacca Straits.
label: Paragraph

text: The Hindu-Budchist kings of 9th-century
label: Paragraph

text: ndonesia used their new wealth to catapult
label: Paragraph

text: their kingdom into a conceptual center of
label: Paragraph

text: the Hindu-Buddhist cosmological universe.
label: Paragraph

text: Within the short space of a hundred years,
label: Paragraph

text: they built not only one of the finest Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: stupa shrines ever, Borobudur, but also, a
label: Paragraph

text: scant 20 miles away, one of the largest and
label: Paragraph

text: most complex assemblages of Hindu temples
label: Paragraph

text: of the time, the Prambanam complex.

text: Borobudur
label: Title

text: The great “cosmic mountain” at Borobudur
label: Title

text: (ca. 760-830 CE) was started in the reign
label: Paragraph

text: of the Shailendra king Indra and completed
label: Paragraph

text: in that of Samaratunga. Though based on
label: Paragraph

text: earlier experiments, Borobudur is unique in
label: Paragraph

text: its formal organization and articulation. It is
label: Paragraph

text: approximately square in plan (122 meters
label: Paragraph

text: north to south and 116 meters east to west),
label: Paragraph

text: and it is roughly aligned to the cardinal
label: Paragraph

text: directions. The plan follows a typical Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: mandala diagram, with a biaxial symmetrical
label: Paragraph

text: order composed of a series of jagged terraces
label: Paragraph

text: giving way to round ones in the middle.
label: Paragraph

text: To make the building, the architects
label: Paragraph

text: chopped down the top of a sizable hill,
label: Paragraph

text: leaving a stepped-shape stub on a terrace.
label: Paragraph

text: On the face of the rock, the designers
label: Caption

text: basically added a layer of stone to create the
label: Paragraph

text: effect of a terraced mountain.
label: Paragraph

text: Borobudur is at one level a quintessential
label: Paragraph

text: stupa, having been built onto a solid mound;
label: Paragraph

text: at another level, it is a three-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: pedagogical diagram. The building is neither
label: Paragraph

text: a temple nor a monastery. Rather, it is
label: Paragraph

text: something of a mountain-scaled university to
label: Paragraph

text: which one goes not to invoke divine beings
label: Paragraph

text: but to participate in a didactic journey, to
label: Paragraph

text: learn—by moving through its spaces—a
label: Paragraph

text: progression of lessons by means of which the
label: Paragraph

text: successful student can attain a state of bodhi,
label: Paragraph

text: or perfected wisdom, just as the Sakyamuni
label: Paragraph

text: Buddha did 2,500 years prior. The essential
label: Paragraph

text: 10.42 Aerial view of Borobudur
label: Caption

text: 10.43 Plan: Borobudur wy
label: Caption

text: experience consists of an orchestrated
label: Paragraph

text: sequence of four galleries followed by three
label: Title

text: terraces, preceded by one large plinth, or
label: Paragraph

text: pre-terrace. The first four terraces are square,
label: Paragraph

text: and the latter three are round. The whole
label: Paragraph

text: culminates in the central stupa, which is
label: Paragraph

text: completely solid and cannot be entered.
label: Paragraph

text: As the Buddhist pilgrim approaches it, the
label: Paragraph

text: complete profile of Borobudur is clearly
label: Caption

text: visible, its levels of galleries and rounded
label: Paragraph

text: stupa terraces placed hierarchically around
label: Paragraph

text: the central stupa, forming the outline of a
label: Paragraph

text: gently swelling mountain. The destination,
label: Paragraph

text: the central stupa, seems evident. As the
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrim gets closer, however, the central
label: Paragraph

text: stupa disappears and seems to retract into
label: Paragraph

text: the monument, and it is replaced by a forest
label: Paragraph

text: of smaller stupas and sculptures on a more
label: Paragraph

text: human scale. Since nirvana is not a place or
label: Paragraph

text: a thing, it has no physical dimension that can
label: Paragraph

text: be described. Rather, it is an inner state that
label: Paragraph

text: must be achieved by the pilgrim by means
label: Paragraph

text: of a personal journey. As governed by the
label: Paragraph

text: mandala, this journey must be completed by
label: Paragraph

text: a pilgrim in sixty conceptual steps.
label: Paragraph

text: The journey begins by circumambulating the
label: Paragraph

text: four lower galleries, which have two rows of
label: Paragraph

text: sculpted panels on each side, recounting
label: Caption

text: sequentially stories from the life of the
label: Title

text: Buddha. These narrow galleries are staggered
label: Paragraph

text: to block all lines of sight, in order to focus the
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrim's attention on the panels. Only after
label: Paragraph

text: having cleared these four levels can pilgrims
label: Paragraph

text: ascend to the round upper levels, where
label: Paragraph

text: there are no enclosing walls. Instead, they
label: Paragraph

text: encounter the bell-shaped hollow stupas,
label: Paragraph

text: each one of which contains a different
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture of the seated Buddha displaying
label: Caption

text: one of the mudras, the characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic gestures of Buddhism. The
label: Paragraph

text: openings on the lower stupas are diamond-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped and large, while those on the ones
label: Paragraph

text: above are square, smaller, and fewer in
label: Paragraph

text: number. While each side of the candi
label: Paragraph

text: (“temple”) in the lower level is one step, each
label: Paragraph

text: bell-shaped stupa takes a whole step toward
label: Paragraph

text: the end. At the final stage, pilgrims arrive
label: Paragraph

text: at the stupa, whose solidity symbolizes the
label: Paragraph

text: shunyata, or “nonpresence,” aspired to by
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddhist pilgrim who seeks nirvana. The
label: Paragraph

text: lowest terrace of Borobudur, probably added
label: Caption

text: to stabilize the structure, was constructed at
label: Paragraph

text: a later date; it hides a row of friezes behind
label: Paragraph

text: it. One of the unresolved controversies
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding Borobudur is whether it was
label: Paragraph

text: originally planned with a large stupa in the
label: Paragraph

text: middle that would have dorninated the whole
label: Paragraph

text: edifice.
label: Paragraph

text: The Shailendra kingdom also constructed a
label: Paragraph

text: series of Hindu temples, the most impressive
label: Paragraph

text: of which is Candi Prambanam, known
label: Paragraph

text: popularly as Loro Jonggrang (“Slender Virgin").
label: Paragraph

text: Built around 850 CE, Loro Jonggrang's three
label: Paragraph

text: central shrines, facing east, are dedicated to
label: Paragraph

text: the Hindu trinity, Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva,
label: Paragraph

text: with Shiva at the center. Three subsidiary
label: Caption

text: shrines, for the corresponding animal
label: Paragraph

text: “vehicles,” or vahanas, of the temple deities,
label: Paragraph

text: face westward, toward the main group.)
label: Paragraph

text: The shrines sit on a platform, accessible
label: Paragraph

text: from all four sides. Around the platform, 224
label: Caption

text: small shrines are arrayed in concentric rings,
label: Paragraph

text: with extra widths for passages leading to the
label: Paragraph

text: center. A wall encloses the complex with
label: Paragraph

text: access gates on each side. Prambanam's
label: Paragraph

text: shrines are articulated as two-story structures
label: Paragraph

text: divided by a band of molding. Their profiles
label: Paragraph

text: are most like those of the Pallavas of southern
label: Paragraph

text: India, which emphasize slender verticality with
label: Paragraph

text: distinct and clear horizontal layers, as in the
label: Paragraph

text: Shore Ternple. Prambanam's two-storied base,
label: Caption

text: however, is significantly taller than its South
label: Paragraph

text: Asian precedents. The plans and tripartite
label: Paragraph

text: elevational orders of Hindu and Buddhist
label: Title

text: structures of Southeast Asia were—probably
label: Paragraph

text: quite purposefully—very similar. The two
label: Paragraph

text: cosmologies were often articulated in parallel
label: Paragraph

text: as well. As a consequence, it is not unusual to
label: Paragraph

text: mistake a Hindu temple for a Buddhist one,
label: Paragraph

text: and vice versa, especially in conternporary
label: Paragraph

text: Cambodia.
label: Paragraph

text: HINDU KINGDOMS OF CAMBODIA
label: Title

text: In 802 CE, Jayavarman II, who had united
label: Paragraph

text: the various Chola kingdoms in Cambodia
label: Title

text: and southern Vietnam, became king and
label: Paragraph

text: supreme ruler over his vast new territory.
label: Paragraph

text: The coronation ceremony took place on Mt.
label: Paragraph

text: Mahendraparvata overlooking the Angkor
label: Caption

text: Plain. It was, for the region, a new type of
label: Paragraph

text: ingdom. The traditional trade route from
label: Paragraph

text: unming had gone through Burma and
label: Paragraph

text: through cities on the Irrawaddy River, like
label: Paragraph

text: Biethano-Myo. And the shipping lanes that
label: Paragraph

text: developed around 400 CE hugged the coast
label: Paragraph

text: to the benefit of cities like Oc Eo. The Khmer
label: Paragraph

text: controlled a large inland area that they made
label: Paragraph

text: fertile with their irrigation technology. In a
label: Paragraph

text: century, it was to make them the wealthiest
label: Paragraph

text: ingdom in Southeast Asia. The rise of the
label: Paragraph

text: hmer was also spurred on by the trade
label: Paragraph

text: tween China and India. The rule of the
label: Paragraph

text: Song dynasty (960-1279 CE) conforms
label: Paragraph

text: quite closely with that of the Khmer, and
label: Paragraph

text: with the Chola in India (860-1279 CE). Both
label: Paragraph

text: China and India exerted powerful economic
label: Title

text: influences in the Southeast Asian areas,
label: Paragraph

text: although, from a cultural point of view, it
label: Paragraph

text: was India that won out, with its variants
label: Paragraph

text: of Buddhism and Hinduism spreading
label: Title

text: throughout the region. To the east, in
label: Paragraph

text: Vietnam, were the Champa, whom the Khmer
label: Paragraph

text: tried several times to conquer in order to gain
label: Paragraph

text: access to their ports. To the south was the
label: Paragraph

text: Srivijaya Empire, founded in the 8th century
label: Paragraph

text: on the island of Sumatra, which controlled
label: Paragraph

text: the Straits of Malacca. Also to be factored
label: Paragraph

text: in is the Dali kingdom in Yunnan Province
label: Paragraph

text: in southern China. From 900 until 1253 Ce,
label: Paragraph

text: when it was conquered by the Mongolians
label: Paragraph

text: and brought back into the fold of the Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: Empire, it was an autonomous state; with
label: Paragraph

text: the disruptions of the trade routes that came
label: Paragraph

text: with the Mongolian expansion into Asia, the
label: Paragraph

text: southern route, which went right through
label: Paragraph

text: the Dali heartland, proved to be a viable
label: Paragraph

text: alternative. The Khmer sold specialty iterns
label: Paragraph

text: such as spices and wood to the Chinese, in
label: Paragraph

text: exchange for metal items such as bronze
label: Title

text: pots, as well as silver and gold. Above all,
label: Paragraph

text: however, they were producers of rice, and it
label: Paragraph

text: was in fact rice as bulk exchange item that
label: Paragraph

text: drove the founding of the cities at Agkor.
label: Paragraph

text: Hariharalaya
label: Title

text: The first city that was laid out, called Hariharalaya,
label: Paragraph

text: was designed as a perfect square about 3
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers on a side. The name Hariharalaya
label: Paragraph

text: is derived from the name of the Hindu deity
label: Paragraph

text: Harihara, who was prominent in pre-Angkorian
label: Paragraph

text: Cambodia. The name Harihara, in turn, is a
label: Paragraph

text: composite of hari (meaning “the Hindu god
label: Paragraph

text: Vishnu”) and fara (meaning “the Hindu god

label: Title

text: The Nanchan and Foguang monasteries, built

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Unlike the three-bayed hall of Nanchan, with
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Foguang hall is seven-by-four bayed and has
label: Paragraph

text: a roof format known as first-class hip style.
label: Paragraph

text: The columns divide the hall into an inner and
label: Paragraph

text: outer cao (“space”). Just as they transformed
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: also transformed the monastery format;

label: Paragraph

text: palatial architecture of the time. Monasteries
label: Paragraph

text: generally consisted of a Buddha hall
label: Paragraph

text: framed by a courtyard within a colonnaded
label: Paragraph

text: enclosure, with a north and a south gate.
label: Paragraph

text: The larger ones had east and west gates as
label: Paragraph

text: well. The courtyards were named after their
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: (“land”) courtyard, and so on. The overall
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: however, are very similar, with low-pitched
label: Paragraph

text: roof slopes, deep eaves, and dominating
label: Paragraph

text: brackets.

text: Charlemagne (747-814 CE), was by all
label: Paragraph

text: accounts an unusual rman. The eldest

label: Paragraph

text: serious interest in scholarship, and promoted
label: Paragraph

text: the liberal arts at his court. With all this in

text: mind, Pope Leo III realized that in order for

text: Europe to survive, he would have to share
label: Paragraph

text: power with Charlemagne. Thus was born
label: Paragraph

text: the idea of the Holy Roman Empire. To their

text: mutual benefit, it in essence had two rulers:
label: Paragraph

text: a religious one and a secular one, the military
label: Title

label: Title

text: of the former. On Christmas day of the year
label: Paragraph

text: 800 CE, in Rome, Leo crowned Charlemagne
label: Caption

text: emperor of the Holy Roman Empire. It was a
label: Paragraph

text: unique arrangement for its age, and one that
label: Paragraph

text: would have long-term consequences. The
label: Paragraph

text: title would be handed down and fought over
label: Paragraph

text: for centuries and officially dissolved only in
label: Paragraph

text: Long before Charlemagne’s coronation,
label: Paragraph

text: the Carolingian Church had established a
label: Paragraph

text: close relationship with Rome, but it was only
label: Paragraph

text: with the coronation that the Roman liturgy
label: Title

text: became the norm. For this, Charlemagne
label: Paragraph

text: turned to the monastic rules of St. Benedict
label: Paragraph

text: (489-543 CE), who had lived three centuries
label: Paragraph

text: earlier. He had formulated his rules during
label: Paragraph

text: an age in which temporal rule had broken
label: Paragraph

text: down. As a counterbalance to the chaos,
label: Paragraph

text: Benedict envisioned the monastery as a
label: Paragraph

text: devout Christian family of men. The monks’
label: Paragraph

text: waking hours were devoted primarily to
label: Paragraph

text: worship and manual labor. But over the
label: Paragraph

text: centuries, the system was inconsistently
label: Paragraph

text: applied. Charlemagne reaffirmed the rules
label: Paragraph

text: as a way to regularize monastic life from
label: Paragraph

text: the patchwork of devotional practices it had
label: Paragraph

text: become, while simultaneously bringing the
label: Paragraph

text: Church closer to imperial policy by making it
label: Paragraph

text: the basic financial, territorial, and educational
label: Title

text: institution of the land. Christianity, which had
label: Paragraph

text: formerly lived within the limited confines of
label: Paragraph

text: what was left of the Roman Empire, was now
label: Paragraph

text: becoming a broad European phenomenon.
label: Paragraph

text: A new unified era was thus created. The
label: Paragraph

text: seat of religious power was still in Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: however, and therein lay a peculiar ambiguity
label: Paragraph

text: about the location of power that was to beset
label: Paragraph

text: European politics for centuries and would not
label: Paragraph

text: be resolved until the Enlightenment in the
label: Paragraph

text: 18th century. But at the time of Charlemagne,
label: Paragraph

text: the careful balance between the secular
label: Title

text: and the religious was still perceived as a
label: Paragraph

text: mutually beneficial cooperation. The type of
label: Paragraph

text: government Charlemagne set up developed
label: Title

text: into a feudal system, with a strict hierarchy
label: Paragraph

text: linking serf, landlord, and count to the king.
label: Paragraph

text: (It did, however, lack a firm centralized
label: Paragraph

text: administrative structure.) Charlemagne
label: Paragraph

text: moved from place to place to assert and

text: expand his authority. The result was an

text: that imprinted his rule on the landscape.

label: Title

text: In the 9th century, a series of large abbey
label: Paragraph

text: churches were built northward frorn Italy as
label: Paragraph

text: a way to spread the message and influence
label: Title

text: of the Church of Rome. These buildings
label: Paragraph

text: tended to be stark and simple volumetrically.
label: Paragraph

text: Windows were small, round-headed, sparsely
label: Paragraph

text: ornamented, and positioned high in the
label: Paragraph

text: wall. Walls were built of coarse or loosely
label: Paragraph

text: finished stone that required a good deal of
label: Paragraph

text: thickness for stability. It was an architecture
label: Paragraph

text: that did not tax the spatial imagination yet
label: Paragraph

text: one that yielded stable, solid forms and dark,
label: Paragraph

text: mysterious interiors. The transept, a minor
label: Caption

text: element in the 5th-century basilica churches
label: Paragraph

text: of Rome, became integral to the design. But
label: Paragraph

text: vaulting at the tirne was to a large extent a
label: Paragraph

text: thing of the future: most Carolingian buildings
label: Title

text: had wooden roofs supported by trusses.
label: Paragraph

text: The Abbey Church of St. Riquier in
label: Paragraph

text: northern France, not far from Amiens, though
label: Paragraph

text: it is no longer extant, can be reconstructed
label: Paragraph

text: from descriptions and old views. Completed
label: Caption

text: in 799 CE, it followed the basic plan, with
label: Paragraph

text: 10.63 Interior of the dome, Palatine Chapel, Aachen, Germany
label: Caption

text: towers soaring from cylindrical bases. The
label: Paragraph

text: external appearance was of clear geornetry,
label: Paragraph

text: solid walls, and small windows. The building
label: Paragraph

text: was accessed in the Roman manner via an
label: Paragraph

text: atrium as well as transept entrances. The
label: Paragraph

text: atrium stood in front of a massive structure
label: Paragraph

text: surmounted by a cylindrical tower. The
label: Caption

text: monastery had a population of about three
label: Paragraph

text: hundred monks and one hundred novices,
label: Paragraph

text: in addition to the servants and serfs. The
label: Paragraph

text: abbey was dedicated to the Holy Trinity and
label: Paragraph

text: was connected to two smaller sanctuaries
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated to St. Benedict and the Virgin
label: Caption

text: Mary, all connected by walls and porticoes.
label: Paragraph

text: Conforming to the new liturgy, there was a
label: Paragraph

text: processional path through the church, which
label: Paragraph

text: was designed to allow the various altars to be
label: Paragraph

text: visited in sequence. (The church contained
label: Paragraph

text: a collection of twenty-five relics.) This
label: Paragraph

text: processional movement through the church
label: Title

text: was to become a mainstay of medieval
label: Paragraph

text: religious practice. Also new was the addition
label: Paragraph

text: of an autonomous spatial zone behind the
label: Paragraph

text: altar that accommodated the monks. This
label: Paragraph

text: church-behind-a-church, or choir, was to
label: Paragraph

text: become an important element in the church
label: Paragraph

text: design of the Middle Ages. Also significant
label: Paragraph

text: was the design of the tower over the transept
label: Paragraph

text: crossing.
label: Paragraph

text: Palatine Chapel
label: Title

text: Aachen had been founded by the Romans
label: Paragraph

text: as a spa because of its thermal springs. It
label: Paragraph

text: was laid out as a square with baths, a palace,
label: Paragraph

text: and a garrison. Destroyed in the 5th century
label: Paragraph

text: during the invasions by the German tribes,
label: Paragraph

text: it was more or less abandoned as a ruin.
label: Paragraph

text: Because the Frankish kings moved their
label: Paragraph

text: court from place to place, they had no need
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: came to power in 768, he decided to settle
label: Paragraph

text: down in order to govern his kingdom from
label: Paragraph

text: one place.
label: Paragraph

text: The architect, Odo of Metz, kept the basic
label: Paragraph

text: layout of the Roman roads that divided the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: a basilica/council hall and to the south the
label: Paragraph

text: TIKAL
label: Title

text: Tikal’s recorded history begins in 292 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: when Balam Ajaw (“Decorated Jaguar”)
label: Title

text: came to power. At its peak around 700 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: Tikal was home to about eighty thousand
label: Paragraph

text: people. Surrounded by cornfields cultivated
label: Paragraph

text: with intense labor, the houses of its residents
label: Paragraph

text: were spread evenly over a 16-square-
label: Paragraph

text: kilometer area. They were clustered into
label: Paragraph

text: groups of about four to seven, all raised
label: Paragraph

text: on high platforms and organized around a
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard. A high level of civic organization
label: Paragraph

text: and hydraulic engineering was critical to
label: Paragraph

text: Tikal’s survival. The swampy land had to be
label: Paragraph

text: sectored by raised causeways that provided
label: Paragraph

text: access to the cultivable land and also allowed
label: Paragraph

text: for travel and transport. For dwellings, more
label: Paragraph

text: permanent stone platforms had to be built,
label: Paragraph

text: and for fresh water, stone-lined cisterns were
label: Paragraph

text: constructed. Tikal was built on a set of hills,
label: Paragraph

text: located on the watershed between the Gulf of
label: Paragraph

text: Mexico and the Caribbean Sea. Perched at
label: Paragraph

text: the high point of the region, therefore, Tikal’s
label: Paragraph

text: temples enjoyed a commanding view of their
label: Paragraph

text: surroundings.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the central buildings of the Mayas
label: Paragraph

text: were used for ceremonial and religious
label: Paragraph

text: functions and also sometimes as markets,
label: Paragraph

text: the city itself was spread out in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: an urban settlement. The Mayan cities were
label: Paragraph

text: Guif of Honduras
label: Title

text: organized around neighborhoods, each with
label: Paragraph

text: its own residences for the elite. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: the priestly class and ruling elite lived in the
label: Paragraph

text: palaces associated with the shrines, the rest
label: Paragraph

text: of the Mayas visited the centers sporadically
label: Paragraph

text: for distinct ritual purposes. Though temples
label: Paragraph

text: were constructed with specific orientations
label: Paragraph

text: and functions in mind, ceremonial centers
label: Paragraph

text: as a whole were not expanded according
label: Paragraph

text: to preplanned rules or geometries, giving
label: Paragraph

text: them a somewhat ad hoc appearance. There
label: Paragraph

text: may, of course, have been reasons for the
label: Paragraph

text: slightly disjointed and angular arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings and open plazas, but these have
label: Paragraph

text: been lost to time.
label: Paragraph

text: The North Acropolis, Tikal’s oldest
label: Paragraph

text: complex, was “reskinned” many times. When
label: Paragraph

text: a ruler of some significance died, he was
label: Paragraph

text: buried in the acropolis, and a new stone layer
label: Paragraph

text: was added to it. The new mass was carefully
label: Paragraph

text: set to ensure that the addition did not
label: Paragraph

text: damage the older structure. Small vaults were
label: Paragraph

text: built for the burials, each with its own shrine.
label: Paragraph

text: Stairs provided access to these chambers for
label: Paragraph

text: ancestral rites, which had to be performed by
label: Paragraph

text: later rulers. A section through the acropolis,
label: Paragraph

text: therefore, is a veritable textbook of Tikal’s
label: Paragraph

text: thousand-year history. The plaza is a flat
label: Paragraph

text: stone platform approached by climbing six
label: Caption

text: wide steps. A set of stelae describing Tikal’s

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Southeast of the Great Plaza is the so-called
label: Paragraph

text: Central Acropolis, which held the royal courts
label: Paragraph

text: and residences. It consisted of a series of
label: Paragraph

text: courts connected at the corners, with simple
label: Paragraph

text: adjoining buildings sitting on platforms. The
label: Paragraph

text: palace courts, although they adjoined the
label: Paragraph

text: central ceremonial complex, were visually
label: Paragraph

text: screened off from their surroundings. They
label: Paragraph

text: were entered at the corners. Tikal's urban
label: Paragraph

text: core is a spectacular assernbly of more
label: Paragraph

text: than a hundred stone temples. The Mayan
label: Paragraph

text: engineers constructed Tikal’s base by
label: Paragraph

text: building up the higher zones into platforms
label: Paragraph

text: with mud and stone. Three zones in the
label: Paragraph

text: middle were linked over time by causeways
label: Paragraph

text: to form a triangle. Additional causeways
label: Paragraph

text: connected to adjoining platforms and the rest
label: Paragraph

text: of the urban area.
label: Paragraph

text: The largest of these zones is focused on
label: Paragraph

text: a giant stone platform, the Great Plaza. To its
label: Paragraph

text: north is the North Acropolis, which faces the
label: Paragraph

text: Great Plaza. Its eastern and western ends are
label: Paragraph

text: anchored by the so-called Temples | and II,
label: Paragraph

text: respectively. Farther west and slightly to the
label: Paragraph

text: south is Temple III, and even farther west,
label: Paragraph

text: connected by a causeway, is Tikal’s largest
label: Paragraph

text: temple, the 70-meter-tall Temple IV.
label: Paragraph

text: Astronomy determined the location of the
label: Paragraph

text: main temples. They are linked by sightlines.
label: Paragraph

text: Standing on top of Temple | looking west,
label: Caption

text: the peak of Ternple III marks the setting of
label: Paragraph

text: the sun at the equinoxes. From the same
label: Paragraph

text: position, a sightline to Temple IV marks
label: Paragraph

text: sunset on August 13, the day the world
label: Title

text: began, according to the Mayan calendar.
label: Paragraph

text: Farther north, two adjacent platform
label: Caption

text: mounds, called the Twin Pyramid complex,
label: Paragraph

text: are oriented exactly along the cardinal
label: Paragraph

text: directions. Their collective steps add up to
label: Paragraph

text: 365, corresponding exactly to one calendar
label: Paragraph

text: year. They were constructed at the end of a
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-year period of the Mayan calendar,
label: Paragraph

text: signifying the successful cornpletion of that
label: Paragraph

text: period.

text: MAYAN CITY-STATES
label: Title

text: In the 8th and 9th centuries, the Mayan
label: Paragraph

text: city-states of the Yucatan dominated the
label: Paragraph

text: peninsula. In the period from 600 to 750 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: the city of Palenque, located in the foothills of
label: Paragraph

text: the Chiapas altipiano, began to expand under
label: Paragraph

text: the leadership of the king Pacan and his two
label: Paragraph

text: sons. Palenque is set into the hillside and laid
label: Paragraph

text: out to take advantage of the contours and
label: Paragraph

text: natural cleavage formed by the Otulum River,
label: Paragraph

text: which passes through the city; water from it
label: Paragraph

text: was diverted to the Palenque’s central palace,
label: Paragraph

text: the city's most remarkable building, via a
label: Paragraph

text: long corbel-vaulted tunnel. The Palenque
label: Caption

text: architects set corbeled vaults parallel to
label: Paragraph

text: one another, which not only created greater
label: Paragraph

text: interior spaces, unlike the solid masses of
label: Paragraph

text: most Mayan buildings, but also stabilized
label: Paragraph

text: the whole structure. This is one reason
label: Paragraph

text: Palenque’s buildings have aged so well. Their
label: Paragraph

text: rooftop ornamental superstructure was also
label: Paragraph

text: made as a roofcomb, which further reduced
label: Paragraph

text: the structure's overall weight.
label: Paragraph

text: Palenque’s palace sits on a broad platform
label: Paragraph

text: that is centrally located to visually command
label: Paragraph

text: the site. On one side, the palace dominates
label: Paragraph

text: the edge of the Otulum River; on the other,
label: Paragraph

text: its platform and profile define the edges
label: Paragraph

text: of Palenque’s central plaza. The palace
label: Caption

text: complex opens toward the hills, although
label: Paragraph

text: the monumental stairs are on the north and
label: Paragraph

text: west sides. This indicates that access to the
label: Paragraph

text: palace, as one might expect, was carefully
label: Paragraph

text: regulated. The interior is dominated by two
label: Paragraph

text: © courts that take up half the complex and are
label: Paragraph

text: . separated by a long double-vaulted building
label: Paragraph

text: Us that was the palace's original core. The
label: Paragraph

text: River on the western edge of Honduras,
label: Paragraph

text: Copan is the southernmost of the major
label: Paragraph

text: Mayan cities. One of the largest Mayan
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: between 400 and 820 CE. The site is
label: Paragraph

text: about 600 meters above sea level, above
label: Paragraph

text: the jungles and rain forests of the lowland
label: Title

text: Mayas. Although occupied for about two
label: Paragraph

text: thousand years, the main visible buildings

label: Paragraph

text: 900 CE. The excavated ruins cover about 16

label: Paragraph

text: and five plazas. Like the ancestral complex
label: Paragraph

text: of Tikal, the main structure at Copan is an
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: period of six hundred years, consisting of a

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Tiwanaku lies in a highland valley in the
label: Paragraph

text: southern Andes 3,660 meters above sea
label: Title

text: level, near the south shore of Lake Titicaca.
label: Paragraph

text: Inhabited from roughly 1000 BCE to 500 CE,
label: Paragraph

text: it was not only the capital of a network
label: Paragraph

text: of cities but also the regional ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: center, maintaining its preeminent position
label: Paragraph

text: until about 1000 CE. It was not so much
label: Paragraph

text: the city that was important but the lake,
label: Paragraph

text: which was seen as the place of origin from
label: Paragraph

text: whence the primeval couple were sent out to
label: Paragraph

text: call mankind forth from the springs, rivers,
label: Paragraph

text: rocks, and trees. Lake Titicaca was known
label: Paragraph

text: as a taypi, a zone of convergence between
label: Paragraph

text: the principles of urco (the west, high, dry,
label: Paragraph

text: pastoral, celestial, male) and uma (the east,
label: Paragraph

text: low, agricultural, underworld, female). If
label: Paragraph

text: Tiwanaku was the central representation
label: Paragraph

text: of the taypi, the elite who lived there were
label: Paragraph

text: viewed as the guardians and representatives
label: Paragraph

text: of this sacred order.
label: Paragraph

text: The ceremonial center was surrounded by
label: Paragraph

text: an immense artificial moat filled with water
label: Paragraph

text: diverted from the Tiwanaku River, which
label: Paragraph

text: evoked the image of the city’s core as an
label: Paragraph

text: Lake Titicaca
label: Title

text: island. The level of the lake itself would have
label: Paragraph

text: been higher. Now the ruins are 10 kilometers
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of the site, which featured several temples,
label: Paragraph

text: gateways of monumental scale, platforms,
label: Paragraph

text: and sunken courts. The two most important
label: Paragraph

text: structures are the Akapana (ca. 700 CE) and
label: Paragraph

text: the Puma Punku, which was built somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: later.
label: Paragraph

text: The Akapana was a low-terraced platform
label: Paragraph

text: mound with a base 200 meters square
label: Paragraph

text: and a height of 17 meters. It is an earthen
label: Paragraph

text: mound, faced with a mixture of large and
label: Paragraph

text: small stone blocks. Vertically placed stones,
label: Paragraph

text: approximately 3.5 meters on center and
label: Paragraph

text: joined with characteristic Andean precision,
label: Paragraph

text: mark the edges of the six terraces that work
label: Paragraph

text: their way up to the summit. The topmost
label: Paragraph

text: terrace was covered by a thin layer of
label: Paragraph

text: bluish-green gravel, brought in from the
label: Paragraph

text: Quimsachata mountain range just south of
label: Paragraph

text: Tiwanaku. On the summit was a sunken
label: Paragraph

text: court with a complexly engineered drainage
label: Paragraph

text: system connecting it to the Tiwanaku River
label: Paragraph

text: and ultimately to Lake Titicaca. Associated
label: Paragraph

text: with the Akapana are four temples—the
label: Paragraph

text: semi-subterranean, the Kalasasaya, the
label: Paragraph

text: Putuni, and the Kheri Kala. Like the other
label: Paragraph

text: platform mounds within Tiwanaku, it has
label: Paragraph

text: a central sunken court. The Akapana is
label: Paragraph

text: axially linked to the Kalasasaya—a large,
label: Paragraph

text: terraced platform (measuring 120 by 130
label: Caption

text: meters) with a megalithic staircase on the
label: Paragraph

text: south centered on the Portal of the Sun,
label: Paragraph

text: and a monumental stone sculpture, the
label: Paragraph

text: so-called Ponce Monolith. The Kalasasaya
label: Paragraph

text: had its own central sunken court. On the
label: Paragraph

text: morning of the spring equinox, a sunbeam
label: Caption

text: bisects the semi-subterranean temple and
label: Paragraph

text: appears in the center of the Kalasasaya’s
label: Paragraph

text: staircase. But how exactly these buildings
label: Paragraph

text: functioned as astronomical observatories is
label: Paragraph

text: unknown. In front of the northwest corner of
label: Caption

text: the Kalasasaya is a small structure known
label: Paragraph

text: as Chunchukala, which has a hole in one
label: Paragraph

text: of its walls similar to the shape of a human
label: Paragraph

text: ear, which permits one to hear sounds that
label: Paragraph

text: are made far away. This “sound amplifier”
label: Paragraph

text: must have something to do with the oracular
label: Paragraph
