text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: The difference in Africa and Eurasia between
label: Title

text: 800 and 1200 CE is huge. By 1200, a band
label: Paragraph

text: of economic wealth had spread from Japan
label: Paragraph

text: in the east to Spain in the west and from
label: Paragraph

text: Sweden in the north to Ghana and Ethiopia
label: Title

text: in the south, with even the east coast of
label: Paragraph

text: Africa as far south as Zimbabwe becoming
label: Title

text: connected to the great continuum of trade.
label: Paragraph

text: Old-wealth worlds, like those of south China,
label: Paragraph

text: India, and Constantinople, were now linked
label: Paragraph

text: to the new-wealth worlds of the Japanese,
label: Paragraph

text: the Khmer, and the Islamic caliphates.
label: Paragraph

text: Added to this were emerging-wealth worlds
label: Paragraph

text: like those associated with Ghana, central
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, and the Vikings. Even the remote
label: Paragraph

text: islands of Hawaii had now been settled by
label: Paragraph

text: intrepid oceangoing people. This vast realm
label: Paragraph

text: of connectivity would separate urban and
label: Paragraph

text: village cultures frorn the residual pockets of
label: Paragraph

text: First Society people and the haves from the
label: Title

text: have-nots for centuries, a division that would
label: Paragraph

text: be markedly transformed only in the modern
label: Paragraph

text: era.
label: Paragraph

text: The critical element in this story is the
label: Paragraph

text: competition between the traditional, land-
label: Paragraph

text: based route that went through Afghanistan
label: Title

text: and the Taklamakan Desert and the southern,
label: Paragraph

text: sea-based route, the importance of which
label: Paragraph

text: had begun to be apparent already in the 7th
label: Paragraph

text: century. On the ocean, ships could carry
label: Paragraph

text: well-calibrated loads, tariffs could be levied
label: Paragraph

text: at docks, and state bureaucracies could
label: Paragraph

text: organize labor and production. To transport
label: Paragraph

text: goods along the northern route was a riskier
label: Paragraph

text: operation. Vast stretches went through
label: Paragraph

text: unclaimed or lawless territories. Foods could
label: Paragraph

text: perish in the heat; delicate porcelain objects
label: Paragraph

text: could shatter when repeatedly loaded and
label: Paragraph

text: unloaded. Furthermore, as goods moved,
label: Paragraph

text: their price increased incrementally but
label: Paragraph

text: steadily as they passed from hand to hand.
label: Paragraph

text: Inner Asia, apart from some mined resources,
label: Paragraph

text: carpets, and leather goods, had little to offer
label: Paragraph

text: as trade. For these and other reasons, the
label: Paragraph

text: southern route, with its cargos of lumber,
label: Paragraph

text: rice, Sugar, pepper, and cinnamon, had
label: Paragraph

text: begun to take precedent over the traditional,
label: Paragraph

text: land-based route. The world was also
label: Paragraph

text: undergoing a perceptible warming period. In
label: Paragraph

text: some areas this meant long growing seasons,
label: Paragraph

text: but in Inner Asia it meant the drying out of
label: Paragraph

text: wells and streams, making cross-continental
label: Paragraph

text: travel difficult. The consequences were
label: Paragraph

text: visible at Chang'an. In 904, the T’ang dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned the once-great city and forced its
label: Paragraph

text: million or so residents to move to Luoyang,
label: Paragraph

text: the new capital on the east coast. The T'ang
label: Paragraph

text: dynasty itself would come to an end in 907.
label: Paragraph

text: The steppe region between the 6th and
label: Paragraph

text: Oth centuries was in continual flux as one
label: Paragraph

text: nomadic culture after another tried to assert
label: Paragraph

text: control over the fabled Silk Route. In the
label: Paragraph

text: Oth century, the area saw the arrival of
label: Paragraph

text: various Turkish tribes from Inner Asia, the
label: Paragraph

text: irst of which created the Ghaznavid dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: (977-1186), which was ruled by a clan of
label: Paragraph

text: urkish Sunni Islamic generals who wrested
label: Title

text: 11.2 Step well, India
label: Caption

text: control of the region from the Zoroastrian
label: Title

text: Sassanians. With their cousins now ruling in
label: Paragraph

text: Persia, the Turks to the north began to move
label: Paragraph

text: south into the region in several waves over
label: Paragraph

text: the next century, building up to the moment
label: Paragraph

text: when Seljuk converted to Islam around 985
label: Paragraph

text: and headed south to defeat the Ghaznavids
label: Paragraph

text: and take over Persia, adopting its cultural
label: Paragraph

text: perspectives. The newly formed Seljuk
label: Paragraph

text: Empire soon controlled a vast area stretching
label: Paragraph

text: from the Hindu Kush to eastern Anatolia and
label: Paragraph

text: from Central Asia to Persian Gulf. All told,
label: Paragraph

text: the impact of the various Turkish tribes was
label: Paragraph

text: profound, for they had accomplished a rather
label: Paragraph

text: important geopolitical mission, relinking the
label: Paragraph

text: economy of the Indianized world with the
label: Paragraph

text: economy of the Islamic world. In doing this,
label: Paragraph

text: they added security to the northern routes
label: Paragraph

text: across the steppe. Once this great economic
label: Paragraph

text: continuum had been established, it would
label: Paragraph

text: remain Africa's and Eurasia’s prime economic
label: Title

text: engine until the age of colonialism made it
label: Paragraph

text: obsolete.
label: Paragraph

text: More quickly than one could imagine, areas
label: Paragraph

text: peripheral to this continuum were pulled
label: Paragraph

text: into its orbit. Tibet was now an independent
label: Paragraph

text: region linking India and China. The Vikings
label: Paragraph

text: set up camp on the Caspian Sea, linking
label: Paragraph

text: the east-west trade with their networks to
label: Paragraph

text: Russia, Scandinavia, and other parts of
label: Title

text: Europe, making the Normans the envy of all
label: Paragraph

text: the Europeans. The port of Pisa was bustling
label: Paragraph

text: with trade from Cairo. For the Europeans it
label: Paragraph

text: was indeed a breakthrough moment. And
label: Paragraph

text: in Africa, trade routes manned by new
label: Paragraph

text: formations of camel-centric cultures were
label: Paragraph

text: forged across the desert to Ghana for its salt
label: Paragraph

text: and gold.
label: Paragraph

text: The Seljuks were in a way the right
label: Paragraph

text: people at the right time with Isfahan, almost
label: Paragraph

text: at the geographical center of this expanding
label: Paragraph

text: universe, rising to be one of the great
label: Paragraph

text: entrepot cities of all time. They founded the
label: Paragraph

text: Great Mosque of Isfahan, rebuilding an earlier
label: Caption

text: mosque and creating, in fact, a new typology,
label: Paragraph

text: the four-iwan mosque, so called because its
label: Paragraph

text: vast central courtyard was faced on all sides
label: Paragraph

text: on axis by a large open space, the iwan,
label: Paragraph

text: roofed by elaborate muqarna vaults with their
label: Paragraph

text: complex geometric faceting. The building's
label: Paragraph

text: columns, vaults, and walls are made almost
label: Paragraph

text: entirely of brick. When the Seljuks arrived in
label: Paragraph

text: Anatolia, however, they began to use stone,
label: Paragraph

text: following the local tradition of advanced
label: Paragraph

text: stonework. With Konya as their new capital,
label: Paragraph

text: the Seljuks built hundreds of caravanserai to
label: Paragraph

text: facilitate trade. Sultan Han, not too far from
label: Paragraph

text: Konya, was particularly elaborate. With a
label: Paragraph

text: single, richly ornamented entrance, it was a
label: Paragraph

text: place where caravans could be refurbished,
label: Paragraph

text: animals rested, and drivers afforded a good
label: Paragraph

text: rest and haircut. From the 11th to the 13th
label: Paragraph

text: centuries, hundreds of caravanserai were
label: Paragraph

text: built or refurbished, significantly improving
label: Paragraph

text: the flow of trade.
label: Paragraph

text: India in this period, prospering as it had
label: Paragraph

text: for centuries because of its trade to the
label: Paragraph

text: east, saw the rise of numerous religious
label: Paragraph

text: temple institutions, the intensification of
label: Paragraph

text: agriculture, and the expansion of commercial
label: Title

text: activities and networks. The Rajputs rose
label: Paragraph

text: to prominence in the northern part of the
label: Paragraph

text: subcontinent, and the Cholas in the south.
label: Paragraph

text: The Cholas became the first and really
label: Paragraph

text: the only Indian empire with a strong naval
label: Paragraph

text: presence, sending ships to Malaysia and
label: Paragraph

text: Indonesia to assert their regional dorninance.
label: Paragraph

text: They began to build a new capital city,
label: Paragraph

text: Gangaikonda Cholapuram, of which little
label: Paragraph

text: remains today apart from an impressively
label: Paragraph

text: scaled Shiva temple. As for the Rajputs,
label: Paragraph

text: their sumptuous palaces were often graced
label: Paragraph

text: y elaborate step wells, where the ladies of
label: Paragraph

text: the court could gather in the cool shade.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the most impressive was Rani-ni-
label: Paragraph

text: Vav (ca. 1050) at Anhilwara (modern-day
label: Paragraph

text: Patan), Gujarat, India. It was a vast, sunken,
label: Paragraph

text: paradisal retreat. To the south, the Chandela
label: Paragraph

text: Rajputs produced a remarkable set of
label: Paragraph

text: temples dedicated to the Tantric school of
label: Paragraph

text: Hinduism. The Tantric practitioner seeks
label: Paragraph

text: to use prana (energy flowing through the
label: Paragraph

text: universe, including one’s body) to attain goals
label: Paragraph

text: that may be spiritual, material, or both. This
label: Paragraph

text: rand of Hinduism had developed around
label: Paragraph

text: 300 CE. Of the over eighty-five ternples that
label: Paragraph

text: were built by the Chandelas, only about
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-five now stand in a reasonable state
label: Title

text: of preservation, scattered over an area of
label: Paragraph

text: about 20 square kilorneters. The Lakshmana
label: Caption

text: Temple and the nearby Kandariya Mahadeva
label: Title

text: Temple (1050) are the most refined. They
label: Paragraph

text: rest on a high terrace and are accessed by
label: Paragraph

text: an axial staircase that leads to an elevated
label: Paragraph

text: interior floor with balconies. Their external
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces portray tantric practice, including
label: Paragraph

text: the sex acts that were seen as a natural way
label: Paragraph

text: to access the supra-mundane through the
label: Paragraph

text: mundane.
label: Paragraph

text: Jainisrn was another important subsect
label: Paragraph

text: of Hinduism, its origins dating back to about
label: Paragraph

text: the 5th century BCE. It prescribes a path
label: Paragraph

text: of nonviolence toward all living beings and
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizes spiritual independence and
label: Paragraph

text: equality between all forms of life. Jains make
label: Paragraph

text: considerable efforts in everyday life not to
label: Paragraph

text: injure plants any more than necessary. Of
label: Paragraph

text: their numerous temples, the Vimal Vasahi
label: Paragraph

text: Ternple (1031) on Mt. Abu is a masterpiece,
label: Paragraph

text: made completely out of white marble. The
label: Paragraph

text: ceilings feature engraved designs of lotus
label: Caption

text: buds, petals, flowers, and scenes from Jain
label: Title

text: and Hindu mythology. In the sacred city of
label: Paragraph

text: Bhubaneswar, the rulers built a similarly
label: Paragraph

text: refined temple, the Lingaraj. Lingaraj means
label: Paragraph

text: “King of Lingam,” a being worshipped by
label: Paragraph

text: devotees of both Shiva and Vishnu. In Sri
label: Paragraph

text: Lanka, King Vijayabahu I, who defeated the
label: Paragraph

text: Chola invaders in 1070 and reunited the
label: Paragraph

text: country, declared Polonnaruwa the capital
label: Paragraph

text: city and began a major reworking of it. By
label: Paragraph

text: the 12th century trade and agriculture were
label: Paragraph

text: flourishing, with advanced irrigation systerns
label: Paragraph

text: being developed to provide water during the
label: Paragraph

text: dry season.
label: Paragraph

text: Farther east along the trade routes is the
label: Paragraph

text: land of the Khmer. Hariharalaya (known now
label: Paragraph

text: more colloquially as Angkor) had by this time
label: Paragraph

text: become nothing less than a boomtown—a
label: Paragraph

text: religious rice-growing industrial complex—
label: Title

text: with new city districts being built, along
label: Paragraph

text: with bold new temples, to accommodate
label: Paragraph

text: a population approaching a million. The
label: Paragraph

text: temples at the core of all this include Phnom
label: Paragraph

text: Bakheng (900), Pre Rup (960), Banteay
label: Paragraph

text: Srei (967), and Phirmeanakas (980). Each
label: Paragraph

text: represented an economic unit unto itself. The
label: Paragraph

text: Angkorites fully understood their geopolitical
label: Paragraph

text: situation. They expanded their power
label: Paragraph

text: northward to connect to China and to better
label: Paragraph

text: control access to the overland trade routes.
label: Paragraph

text: In China, given the restless expansion
label: Paragraph

text: of the northern steppe cultures, the T’ang
label: Paragraph

text: gave way to the Song dynasty (960-1279),
label: Paragraph

text: who retreated south of the Yangtze River to
label: Paragraph

text: establish a capital at Lin’an (now Hangzhou).
label: Paragraph

text: Soon, Hangzhou rose from a middling city
label: Paragraph

text: of only regional importance to become one
label: Paragraph

text: of the world’s largest and most populous
label: Paragraph

text: cities. Arab, Persian, and Korean merchants
label: Paragraph

text: lived there. The Chinese also underwent
label: Paragraph

text: a population boom, with the population
label: Paragraph

text: doubling during the 10th and 11th centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: This growth came through expanded rice
label: Paragraph

text: cultivation in central and southern China,
label: Paragraph

text: which was developed to offset imported
label: Paragraph

text: rice from Southeast Asia. With Buddhism
label: Paragraph

text: repressed, imperially sanctioned temples
label: Paragraph

text: reemerged, drawing on ancient animistic
label: Paragraph

text: belief systems; one of these was the Sage
label: Paragraph

text: Mother Hall (ca. 980-1100), built around
label: Paragraph

text: a sacred spring. Buddhist pagoda towers
label: Caption

text: continued to be built, but in the countryside
label: Paragraph

text: rather than within a city’s walls, largely to
label: Paragraph

text: avoid competition with the attempt by the
label: Paragraph

text: imperial authorities to impose their cosmic-
label: Paragraph

text: derived ideology on the city.
label: Paragraph

text: To the north, the new Mongolian-based
label: Paragraph

text: overlords did not lack architectural ambition.
label: Paragraph

text: On the contrary, the Liao dynasty (907-1125)
label: Paragraph

text: employed captured carpenters to build the
label: Paragraph

text: impressive Yingxian Timber Pagoda (1056),
label: Caption

text: also known as Mu-Ta, meaning “Timber
label: Paragraph

text: Pagoda.” Since timber buildings are so
label: Paragraph

text: vulnerable to the vicissitudes of time, this
label: Paragraph

text: building, one of the oldest surviving in China,
label: Paragraph

text: gives us valuable insight into a structure built
label: Paragraph

text: completely without nails.
label: Paragraph

text: The Mongolianization of northern
label: Title

text: China secured Buddhism in this area and
label: Paragraph

text: strengthened its position in Korea and Japan,
label: Paragraph

text: where Buddhism underwent yet another of
label: Paragraph

text: its numerous transformations. Less a religion
label: Paragraph

text: than a path to religion, Buddhism tolerates
label: Paragraph

text: and even welcomes different experiments
label: Paragraph

text: in making that path possible. One of these
label: Paragraph

text: is known as Pure Land and is based on the
label: Paragraph

text: premise that the way to let go of the worries
label: Paragraph

text: of daily life is to imagine a land of beauty that
label: Paragraph

text: surpasses all other realms. Since a devotee
label: Paragraph

text: did not need to live in meditative isolation,
label: Paragraph

text: Pure Land appealed to a more general
label: Paragraph

text: public. In China, Pure Land practices never
label: Paragraph

text: became a stand-alone sect, but in Japan,
label: Paragraph

text: Pure Land came to exist independently as
label: Paragraph

text: one of several sects. The earliest surviving
label: Paragraph

text: example of a temple dedicated to this new
label: Caption

text: sect is the Phoenix Hall (Byodo-in) in Kyoto.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike a Christian church, where images
label: Paragraph

text: of paradise might be painted on the walls,
label: Paragraph

text: or an Islamic garden, where paradise was
label: Paragraph

text: imagined through poetic inscriptions, here
label: Paragraph

text: paradise was presented in situ, with the
label: Paragraph

text: building itself, reflected in a pond, being the
label: Paragraph

text: focus of meditation. The Phoenix Hall can be
label: Paragraph

text: compared with Kandariya Mahadeva Temple:
label: Paragraph

text: Both reach out to people who are not priests
label: Paragraph

text: or ritual experts. Both are buildings that bring
label: Paragraph

text: the supplicant past the everyday into a higher
label: Paragraph

text: realm through meditation and ritual practices.
label: Paragraph

text: For both, the building serves not just as a site
label: Paragraph

text: of ritual but as a visualization for meditation.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, Constantinople had become
label: Paragraph

text: the largest city in Europe, with a population
label: Paragraph

text: of about a half a million. To its north, the
label: Paragraph

text: conversion of the Bulgarians, Serbs, and
label: Title

text: Rus to Orthodox Christianity brought some
label: Paragraph

text: stabilization to the restless area, even
label: Paragraph

text: though it did not stop a major Rus attack on
label: Paragraph

text: Constantinople in 941, probably over trading
label: Paragraph

text: rights; the Rus used a navy of ten thousand
label: Paragraph

text: 11.3 Sage Mother Hall, Jinci Temple, Taiyuan, China
label: Caption

text: vessels to devastate the Asiatic shore of the
label: Paragraph

text: Bosporus. But Islamic armies controlled
label: Paragraph

text: the Byzantine’s eastern border, and Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: navies controlled much of the Mediterranean.
label: Paragraph

text: Adding to the increased isolation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantines was the final separation of the
label: Paragraph

text: eastern and western churches in 1054.
label: Paragraph

text: From then on, the Christian church had
label: Paragraph

text: two distinctly different rules of authority,
label: Paragraph

text: one emanating from Rome and the other
label: Paragraph

text: rom Constantinople. One of the few major
label: Paragraph

text: architectural commissions of the time was
label: Paragraph

text: the church of Christ Pantokrator (“Ruler of
label: Paragraph

text: All," ca. 1120, now the Zeyrek Mosque) that
label: Paragraph

text: was commissioned by a Byzantine empress.
label: Paragraph

text: It had a library and a sixty-bed hospital, and
label: Paragraph

text: was home to over eighty monks. But if the
label: Paragraph

text: destiny of the Byzantines was on a downward
label: Paragraph

text: slope, the Russians to the north were in
label: Paragraph

text: expansion mode. Now almost completely
label: Paragraph

text: Christianized, they linked the Silk Route
label: Paragraph

text: with northern Europe and Scandinavia.
label: Paragraph

text: Kievan Rus had by now established itself as
label: Paragraph

text: an important regional powerhouse. Several
label: Paragraph

text: churches were built, such as the Cathedral
label: Paragraph

text: of St. Sophia, the Holy Wisdom of God in
label: Paragraph

text: Novgorod, and the Church of the Tithes or
label: Paragraph

text: Church of the Dormition of the Virgin (ca.
label: Caption

text: 990) in Kiev.
label: Paragraph

text: Farther south, in the Islamic world,
label: Paragraph

text: were the Fatimids, who belonged to the
label: Paragraph

text: Ismaili branch of Shi'ism and claimed to be
label: Paragraph

text: descended from Fatima bint Muhammed,
label: Paragraph

text: the daughter of the prophet Mohammed. In
label: Paragraph

text: 909, the Fatimids established the Tunisian
label: Paragraph

text: city of Mahdia as their capital, and when they
label: Paragraph

text: conquered Egypt in 969 they established
label: Paragraph

text: Cairo as the capital. They were known for
label: Paragraph

text: their exquisite arts; there are many surviving
label: Paragraph

text: traces of Fatimid architecture, the defining
label: Paragraph

text: example being the Al-Azhar Mosque (972)
label: Paragraph

text: and its associated university. It was the first
label: Paragraph

text: university in the East and perhaps the oldest
label: Paragraph

text: in history. The Fatirnids used it for official
label: Paragraph

text: pronouncements and court sessions. Initially
label: Paragraph

text: built as a prayer hall with five aisles and a
label: Paragraph

text: modest central courtyard, the mosque has
label: Paragraph

text: been expanded multiple times. Though
label: Paragraph

text: none of the original minarets or domes has
label: Paragraph

text: survived, the plan, despite the later additions,
label: Paragraph

text: is unmistakable. It was a rectangular box
label: Paragraph

text: with a doorway in each of the walls other
label: Paragraph

text: than the quibla wall. The columns were taken
label: Paragraph

text: from various Roman or Byzantine-era ruins.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan features an axial hallway that cuts
label: Paragraph

text: through the grid in front of the quib/a, thus
label: Paragraph

text: giving it special prominence in the plan.
label: Paragraph

text: To the east, along the Mediterranean, the
label: Paragraph

text: Almoravids, a Berber Sunni dynasty frorn
label: Paragraph

text: Morocco, formed an empire in the 11th
label: Paragraph

text: century, founding their capital at Marrakech
label: Paragraph

text: in 1062. The Almoravids were crucial in
label: Paragraph

text: maintaining Islamic control over southern
label: Title

text: Spain when they defeated a coalition of the
label: Paragraph

text: Christian, Castilian, and Aragonese armies
label: Title

text: at the Battle of Sagrajas. This enabled them
label: Paragraph

text: 11.4 Speyer Cathedral, Speyer, Germany
label: Caption

text: to control an empire that stretched 2,000
label: Paragraph

text: kilometers north to south. Their rule was
label: Paragraph

text: relatively short-lived. They failed to quell
label: Paragraph

text: the Masmuda-led rebellion initiated by lbn
label: Paragraph

text: Tumart that led to the rise of the Almohads.
label: Paragraph

text: The Almohads—who were also Sunni—came
label: Paragraph

text: from Tin Mal, a village that became the
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual capital and the artistic center of the
label: Paragraph

text: Almohad Empire.
label: Paragraph

text: For the first time since the fall of the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman Empire, Europe was being connected
label: Paragraph

text: to global horizons. The region was the
label: Paragraph

text: equivalent of what today would be called a
label: Paragraph

text: developing area. The Saracens had been
label: Paragraph

text: driven beyond the Pyrenees; the Slavs had
label: Paragraph

text: been forced back to the Oder River; the
label: Paragraph

text: Magyars had been expelled from Germany
label: Title

text: and Italy; Danes had become Christians. With
label: Paragraph

text: the relative relief, regional lords surfaced who
label: Paragraph

text: established themselves and claimed their
label: Paragraph

text: own sovereignty. Abbeys, usually in rernote
label: Paragraph

text: locations, were still important political sites,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Abbey of Sant’Antimo, begun
label: Paragraph

text: before 1118 just south of Siena. More than
label: Paragraph

text: just an abbey, it was an institution that had
label: Paragraph

text: authority over thirty-eight churches, from Pisa
label: Paragraph

text: to Grosseto, and controlled about a thousand
label: Paragraph

text: farm estates throughout Tuscany. Built of
label: Paragraph

text: white stone, it was sited in a field purposefully
label: Paragraph

text: planted with tarragon, an herb that is rare in
label: Paragraph

text: Italy but frequently used in French cuisine,
label: Paragraph

text: and as such an indicator of the building's
label: Paragraph

text: connections to Charlemagne. But the
label: Paragraph

text: architecture of Sant’Antimo was increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: a thing of the past. Boxy churches with
label: Paragraph

text: small windows, primitive stonemasonry, and
label: Caption

text: wooden-beamed ceilings were giving way
label: Paragraph

text: to more ambitious designs. The transition
label: Paragraph

text: began with the Ottonians in Germany. They
label: Paragraph

text: sought to define themselves as extending
label: Paragraph

text: the imperial lineage of Constantine and
label: Title

text: Justinian. They even brought in artisans
label: Paragraph

text: from Constantinople, and the results show
label: Paragraph

text: themselves at the Church of St. Michael
label: Paragraph

text: (ca. 1010) in Hildesheim, made of cleanly
label: Paragraph

text: dressed stone. The building was up the hill of
label: Paragraph

text: the nearby market town and was indicative of
label: Paragraph

text: a closer relationship between the Church and
label: Paragraph

text: daily life. The style of building, with its clearly
label: Paragraph

text: legible geometries and volumes, including
label: Paragraph

text: tube-like towers, is known as Romanesque,
label: Paragraph

text: largely because it derives consciously from
label: Paragraph

text: the Roman basilica with naves, side aisles,
label: Paragraph

text: and wood roofs.
label: Paragraph

text: In Italy, the Tuscan region, profiting
label: Paragraph

text: from the flow of goods brought to the
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean by Islamic traders, was at
label: Paragraph

text: the start of a building boom, with the port
label: Paragraph

text: city of Pisa leading the way. Pisa built a
label: Paragraph

text: cathedral (1063-1180), a large baptistery
label: Paragraph

text: (1152-1363) and a tower, the famous
label: Paragraph

text: Leaning Tower of Pisa (1173-1372), all of
label: Paragraph

text: which was rounded off with the addition of
label: Paragraph

text: the Campo Santo, also known as Camposanto
label: Paragraph

text: Monumentale (“monumental cemetery”),
label: Paragraph

text: an expansive, rectangular cloister (begun in
label: Paragraph

text: 1278) that is said to have been built on a
label: Paragraph

text: shipload of sacred soil taken from Golgotha,
label: Paragraph

text: Israel, and brought back to Pisa from the
label: Paragraph

text: Fourth Crusade. The ensemble was one
label: Paragraph

text: of the great religious sites in Europe at the
label: Paragraph

text: time. The building was paid for by the spoils
label: Paragraph

text: taken from Mahdia, a Tunisian city that was
label: Paragraph

text: the capital of a regional Islamic power. It
label: Paragraph

text: was attacked by Pisa and its allies and then
label: Paragraph

text: forced to pay a high ransom—a sign of the
label: Paragraph

text: growing dominance of Christian powers in the
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean.
label: Paragraph

text: One can compare Pisa with St Mark’s
label: Paragraph

text: Basilica in Venice that was consecrated
label: Title

text: in 1084. The latter is clearly Byzantine in
label: Paragraph

text: conception, with its great billowing vaults
label: Paragraph

text: covered with golden mosaics. The Cathedral
label: Caption

text: of Pisa is “Latin” in conception, essentially
label: Paragraph

text: copying the basilica model that came out
label: Paragraph

text: Rome with columns running down the
label: Paragraph

text: aisles. Whereas St. Mark’s was a brick
label: Paragraph

text: building and more interior than exterior, the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings at Pisa were surfaced all around
label: Paragraph

text: with shimmering white marble ornamented
label: Paragraph

text: with thin horizontal bands of black stone.
label: Paragraph

text: Such revetment has a tradition that goes
label: Paragraph

text: back to Raman times, and indeed, some of
label: Paragraph

text: the stones were scavenged from Roman-
label: Paragraph

text: era ruins. It is clear that the patrons wanted
label: Paragraph

text: a building that in its extravagant exterior
label: Paragraph

text: 11.5 Pueblo Bonito
label: Caption

text: finish would herald itself as a freestanding
label: Paragraph

text: monument of their success.
label: Paragraph

text: The Romanesque style of St. Michael
label: Paragraph

text: and the Cathedral of Pisa was, however,
label: Paragraph

text: being creatively transformed in Germany
label: Title

text: and France, as is already visible at Speyer
label: Paragraph

text: Cathedral (consecrated in 1061). There
label: Paragraph

text: we see a building that is not only taller
label: Paragraph

text: but has a whole new interior organization.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead of the nave being a wall held up as
label: Paragraph

text: a variation of columns or arches, here the
label: Paragraph

text: piers have partially melded into the wall.
label: Paragraph

text: On the surface of the pier, two columns are
label: Paragraph

text: placed on top of each other, almost as if
label: Paragraph

text: they were a single very tall column. The top
label: Paragraph

text: of the column connects directly to a rib of
label: Paragraph

text: the vaulted ceiling that then connects to a
label: Paragraph

text: vertical pier on the other side of the nave.
label: Caption

text: The eye could move up across and down in
label: Paragraph

text: a single sweep. The ancient and venerable
label: Paragraph

text: prototype of post and beam has now been
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by an aesthetic of a completely
label: Paragraph

text: different order. The idea of a column as
label: Paragraph

text: an independent architectural entity would
label: Paragraph

text: only make its return in Europe only with the
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance. The Normans in England made
label: Paragraph

text: particularly important contributions. They had
label: Paragraph

text: left northern France to conquer England and
label: Paragraph

text: then sailed around Spain to conquer southern
label: Paragraph

text: Italy and Sicily. There, they encountered
label: Paragraph

text: Arab architects and Byzantine artisans. The
label: Paragraph

text: impact is clearly evident in the difference
label: Paragraph

text: between the cathedral at Cefalu (1131)
label: Caption

text: and the later cathedral at Monreale. The
label: Paragraph

text: former is a veritable fortress with a dark and
label: Paragraph

text: gloomy interior. The Cathedral of Monreale
label: Caption

text: (1174-85), commissioned by Henry II
label: Caption

text: (r. 1154-89), has an interior with golden
label: Caption

text: mosaics that completely cover the walls of the
label: Paragraph

text: nave, aisles, transept, and apse. The mosaic
label: Caption

text: cycle is second only to the Hagia Sophia in
label: Paragraph

text: size, and much better preserved. In the apse,
label: Paragraph

text: a magnificent portrait of Christ Pantocrator
label: Caption

text: (Ruler of All”) gestures in blessing and
label: Paragraph

text: gazes serenely off to one side. The Normans
label: Paragraph

text: brought their Arab craftsmen back to
label: Paragraph

text: England, and quickly their architecture began
label: Paragraph

text: to transform, as can be seen in Durham and
label: Paragraph

text: Canterbury Cathedrals. At the piers, what
label: Paragraph

text: had been two columns placed one on top of
label: Paragraph

text: the other at Speyer now becomes a single,
label: Paragraph

text: tube-like column rising from the floor to the
label: Paragraph

text: base of the vault. The result was a revolution
label: Paragraph

text: of sensibilities that was to contribute to the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of the Gothic style.
label: Paragraph

text: In the Yucatan Peninsula the Mayan
label: Paragraph

text: civilization was at its height. In the valley
label: Paragraph

text: of Oaxaca the Zapotecs continued to build
label: Paragraph

text: new cities, moving their political center from
label: Paragraph

text: Monte Alban (ca. 700 BCE-700 Ce) to Mitla
label: Paragraph

text: (ca. 700-1400 CE), transforming the fortified
label: Paragraph

text: village into a major religious and economic
label: Paragraph

text: hub. The city was still being expanded when
label: Paragraph

text: the Spaniards arrived and destroyed it in
label: Paragraph

text: the 16th century. To the north, the Toltecs
label: Paragraph

text: were in the process of building a powerful
label: Paragraph

text: new dynasty destined to define the form
label: Title

text: and shape of the cultures that the Spanish
label: Title

text: conquistadors encountered five hundred
label: Title

text: years later. But this was not happening in
label: Paragraph

text: isolation. Trade with the Southwest Puebloans
label: Title

text: was now well established, in particular
label: Paragraph

text: because of the turquoise mines in their
label: Paragraph

text: territory. Turquoise, not readily available
label: Paragraph

text: in Mexico, was a prized commodity, as
label: Paragraph

text: it was used for sacred masks and other
label: Paragraph

text: ritual objects. The Puebloans, in the arid
label: Paragraph

text: landscapes of the Southwest, had developed
label: Paragraph

text: a thriving agricultural communal lifestyle, with
label: Paragraph

text: people living in dwellings made of stone and
label: Paragraph

text: mortar that allowed for two-story construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Settlements had round, belowground kivas
label: Paragraph

text: that were used for ceremonial purposes.
label: Paragraph

text: Some kivas were as large as 17 meters in
label: Paragraph

text: diameter. The Puebloans were not centralized
label: Paragraph

text: into kingships as the Mayans were, but
label: Paragraph

text: constituted an association of clans unified
label: Paragraph

text: around powerful cornmunal and seasonal
label: Paragraph

text: activities, at the core of which was Chaco
label: Paragraph

text: Canyon. Roughly 9 kilometers long, it
label: Paragraph

text: contained several ceremonial sites, though
label: Paragraph

text: how they functioned individually and as a
label: Paragraph

text: group is not known. The complex contained
label: Paragraph

text: the largest buildings in North America until
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th century. Meanwhile, Peruvians were
label: Paragraph

text: undergoing transition; the kingdoms of Wari
label: Title

text: and Tiwanaku had died out, to be replaced
label: Paragraph

text: by dozens of smaller regional powers, among
label: Paragraph

text: which were the Chimu, with their capital at
label: Paragraph

text: the city of Chan Chan, a large adobe city in
label: Paragraph

text: the Moche Valley. The culture arose around
label: Paragraph

text: 900 CE in roughly the same territory where
label: Paragraph

text: the Mochica had existed centuries before.
label: Paragraph

text: The city is composed of nine independently
label: Paragraph

text: walled citadels that housed the elite and their
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial rooms, burial chambers, temples,
label: Caption

text: and reservoirs. Most of the city’s population—
label: Paragraph

text: artisans and farmers—lived outside the
label: Paragraph

text: quadrangles in modest quarters of less
label: Paragraph

text: durable construction. As with most Peruvian
label: Paragraph

text: cities, it was at the center of a vast network of
label: Paragraph

text: canals that irrigated the surrounding land.

text: MAYAN UXMAL
label: Title

text: Uxmal was one of several Mayan city-states
label: Paragraph

text: competing for territory, but by 900 CE it had
label: Paragraph

text: become the regional capital and most likely
label: Paragraph

text: the largest of the Mayan cities. A network
label: Paragraph

text: of stone roadways, called sakbehoob,
label: Paragraph

text: connected Uxmal to Nohpat and Kabah.
label: Paragraph

text: Chichen Itza was a major ally. Uxmal’s elite
label: Paragraph

text: lived in a sprawling palace complex located
label: Paragraph

text: on the area's highest ground. A stone wall
label: Paragraph

text: with regularly spaced openings enclosed the
label: Paragraph

text: area. At the southern end of the complex,
label: Paragraph

text: built into a small mound, was the main
label: Paragraph

text: platform mound, wedged between a gigantic
label: Paragraph

text: platform with the so-called Governor's Palace
label: Paragraph

text: to its east and a series of rectangular courts
label: Paragraph

text: to its west. The platform mound faced north,
label: Paragraph

text: its broad stairs visible from a great distance.
label: Paragraph

text: The northern edge of the palace complex
label: Caption

text: was dominated by a huge quadrangular
label: Paragraph

text: palace, called the Nunnery (890-915 CE).
label: Paragraph

text: To its immediate east, the largest structure,
label: Paragraph

text: a steep platform mound with a rare oval-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped base, was the so-called Ternple of
label: Paragraph

text: the Magician. Scores of other buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: arranged in quadrangles of various size and
label: Paragraph

text: shape, were distributed through the complex;
label: Paragraph

text: most were residential units, and a few were
label: Paragraph

text: platform mounds. Similar structures outside
label: Paragraph

text: the wall were dispersed across a much larger
label: Paragraph

text: urban residential area. The currently used
label: Paragraph

text: names for many of the structures were
label: Paragraph

text: coined by the conquering Spanish and
label: Paragraph

text: do not indicate the actual functions of the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Chan-Chaak-K’ak’nal-Ajaw (9th
label: Caption

text: century), who ruled the city, commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: the Governor’s Palace, the Nunnery
label: Title

text: quadrangle, and very likely a rebuilding
label: Paragraph

text: of the Temple of the Magician. The latter,
label: Paragraph

text: originally built in the 6th century, was
label: Paragraph

text: reconstructed at least four times. While the
label: Paragraph

text: exact reasons for its unusual shape are still
label: Paragraph

text: uncertain, its dramatic profile dominates
label: Paragraph

text: the setting, contrasting with the orthogonal
label: Paragraph

text: geometries of the Governor's Palace and
label: Paragraph

text: the Nunnery quadrangle. Its limestone core
label: Paragraph

text: was originally covered with smooth plaster
label: Paragraph

text: and painted red with accents in blue,
label: Paragraph

text: yellow, and black.

label: Paragraph

text: vista from across a vast platform. The rising
label: Paragraph

text: sun would have brightly illuminated its
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: three compartments. Narrow passages with
label: Caption

text: steep triangular roofs separated them. Each
label: Paragraph

text: room was a set of two, one opening onto the
label: Paragraph

text: front, and the other behind it, against a blank
label: Paragraph

text: back wall. The broad frieze on the Governor's
label: Caption

text: Palace is its chief glory. Made from over

text: twenty thousand individual stones depicting
label: Title

label: Caption

text: motifs, the frieze is a kaleidoscope of Mayan
label: Paragraph

text: mythology. A gigantic stone sculpture
label: Paragraph

text: on a throne surrounded by serpents. The

label: Caption

text: quadrangle together depict the Mayan
label: Paragraph

text: cosmography, or the order of the universe

text: as conceived by the Uxmal. The southern
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Lords of Xibalba, the underworld.

label: Paragraph

text: CAHOKIA
label: Title

text: By the 11th century, Hopewell Culture cities
label: Paragraph

text: had fallen on hard times. The new power
label: Paragraph

text: centers were now farther west along the
label: Paragraph

text: Mississippi River. This change coincided
label: Paragraph

text: with the emergence of a chiefdom society
label: Paragraph

text: that adopted a comparatively large-scale,
label: Paragraph

text: intensive, maize-based agriculture. It had
label: Paragraph

text: taken about a thousand years for corn
label: Paragraph

text: cultivation to make it this far north, and
label: Paragraph

text: its impact was quite dramatic. For the first
label: Paragraph

text: time there is a clear settlement hierarchy
label: Paragraph

text: and the construction of truncated pyramid
label: Title

text: mounds, with temples or burial buildings
label: Paragraph

text: atop such mounds. Soon a network of larger
label: Paragraph

text: and smaller city cultures developed in a large
label: Paragraph

text: triangular area down the Mississippi River at
label: Paragraph

text: its western edge and eastward into Georgia am
label: Paragraph

text: along other rivers. : 2 oo
label: Caption

text: One of the most important of the new .
label: Paragraph

text: cities was Cahokia (ca. 700-1300). Its j ‘
label: Paragraph

text: residents benefited from the Mississippi's : im :
label: Paragraph

text: alluvial deposits as well as from the trade that '
label: Paragraph

text: brought copper from the upper Great Lakes, )
label: Paragraph

text: mica from the southern Appalachians, and + - vs
label: Paragraph

text: seashells from the Gulf of Mexico. Twenty , . 2
label: Caption

text: thousand people lived in Cahokia at its peak
label: Paragraph

text: in the 12th century, making it the largest city
label: Paragraph

text: north of Mexico.
label: Paragraph

text: At the center of its vast religious precinct was
label: Paragraph

text: the so-called Monks Mound. Begun around
label: Paragraph

text: 1000 CE, it was surrounded by terraces
label: Paragraph

text: and smaller mounds roughly on axis. It
label: Paragraph

text: was a huge mound—30 meters high, 291
label: Paragraph

text: meters long, and 236 meters wide—made
label: Paragraph

text: by carrying tons of earth a basketful at a
label: Paragraph

text: time. The Cahokians, who seemed to have

text: known of Central American advances in
label: Title

text: astronomy, built several calendrical circles
label: Paragraph

text: with posts of red cedar. A circle of 24 posts
label: Caption

text: was enlarged to one of 36, then to one of
label: Paragraph

text: 48, and finally to one of 60. Their last and
label: Paragraph

text: largest circle was built to an arc of only 12
label: Paragraph

text: posts, but if completed, it would have had
label: Paragraph

text: 72 posts. At the equinoxes, the post marking
label: Caption

text: sunrise, due east, aligns perfectly with the front
label: Paragraph

text: of Monks Mound. Because the city was located
label: Paragraph

text: in the Mississippi floodplain and not on the
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding bluffs, the city was designed to be
label: Paragraph

text: partially flooded during the spring flood season.
label: Paragraph

text: It is thought that elaborate ceremonies were
label: Paragraph

text: conducted at that time with people arriving from
label: Paragraph

text: up and down the Mississippi. But whether the
label: Paragraph

text: city was controlled by a single chieftain-priest
label: Paragraph

text: or was shared by several groups is not known.
label: Paragraph

text: The city was abandoned in the 15th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Overhunting, environmental degradation because
label: Paragraph

text: of the overplanting of corn, and social conflict
label: Paragraph

text: may have all played a part. Whereas Mississippi
label: Paragraph

text: cultures in Ohio faltered, they continued to thrive
label: Paragraph

text: farther south in Georgia and Alabarna until the
label: Paragraph

text: arrival of the Europeans.

text: SERPENT MOUND
label: Title

text: In Ohio, where there had once been the
label: Paragraph

text: Hopewell Culture, a new and more modest
label: Title

text: culture emerged, known by archaeologists as the
label: Paragraph

text: Fort Ancient Culture (1000-1650). Settlements
label: Paragraph

text: composed of circular and rectangular homes
label: Paragraph

text: constructed of twigs and thatch and situated
label: Paragraph

text: around an open plaza were enclosed by
label: Paragraph

text: stockades, suggesting an increase in the level
label: Paragraph

text: of conflict that perhaps accounted for the
label: Paragraph

text: breakdown of the Hopewell Culture. Settlements
label: Caption

text: were rarely permanent, usually shifting to a
label: Paragraph

text: new location after one or two generations when
label: Paragraph

text: the resources surrounding the village were
label: Paragraph

text: exhausted. The diet was composed mainly of
label: Paragraph

text: maize, squash, and beans, supplemented by
label: Paragraph

text: hunting and fishing in nearby forests and rivers.
label: Paragraph

text: Though this culture was a step down from
label: Paragraph

text: Hopewell Culture, it nonetheless managed to
label: Paragraph

text: construct sore remarkable earthworks, including
label: Paragraph

text: Serpent Mound (ca. 1060), in Adams County,
label: Caption

text: Ohio. The mound consists of a low berm made
label: Paragraph

text: of stones and compacted clay placed on a
label: Paragraph

text: promontory that rises 30 meters over a small river.
label: Paragraph

text: Measured along its coils and curves, it stretches
label: Paragraph

text: 400 meters. The head of the serpent was placed
label: Caption

text: at the crest of the bluff. Several theories have
label: Paragraph

text: been proposed as to the meaning of the mound.
label: Paragraph

text: For some American tribes, the serpent was
label: Paragraph

text: considered evil, but for others, it was thought of
label: Paragraph

text: as beneficial. In all cases, however, the snake
label: Paragraph

text: was considered a potent force. (The Hopi snake
label: Paragraph

text: dance was used principally as a prayer for rain.)
label: Paragraph

text: Astrological alignments have been proposed,
label: Paragraph

text: and indeed, the snake's head is aligned to the
label: Paragraph

text: summer solstice and the various curves to other
label: Title

text: celestial events. The village was located across
label: Paragraph

text: the river from the mound.
label: Paragraph

text: PUEBLO BONITO
label: Title

text: Modern borders encourage viewing the
label: Paragraph

text: ruins of the southwestern United States
label: Title

text: separately from those of Mesoamerica. In
label: Paragraph

text: reality, the settlements in places such as
label: Paragraph

text: Chaco Canyon and Mesa Verde made up the
label: Paragraph

text: northern frontier of the Mesoamerican world
label: Title

text: and were not separated from its influence.
label: Paragraph

text: However, because of their unique climatic
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances, the Puebloans developed
label: Paragraph

text: a very self-defined culture. By 600 CE, the
label: Paragraph

text: area came to be occupied by three distinct
label: Paragraph

text: groups: the Hisatsinom (also called Anasazi)
label: Title

text: to the north and the Mogollon and Hohokam
label: Title

text: to the south, the latter seemingly having
label: Paragraph

text: originally been Mayas. They had begun to
label: Paragraph

text: change from a migratory farming culture to
label: Title

text: a sedentary one. One of the reasons for the
label: Paragraph

text: change was the adoption of corn, not just as
label: Paragraph

text: a food but as a principal deity. The Puebloans
label: Paragraph

text: integrated corn with a range of local plants
label: Paragraph

text: that they also cultivated. The result was
label: Paragraph

text: a rapid increase in population beginning
label: Title

text: around 700 CE due to improved weather
label: Paragraph

text: conditions and more copious rainfall—the
label: Paragraph

text: dry and arid conditions of today were not
label: Paragraph

text: those of the 9th century. By 1100, there were
label: Paragraph

text: twelve major Pueblo cities and hundreds of
label: Title

text: small clutches of houses—one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: impressive urban structures north of Mexico,
label: Paragraph

text: bespeaking a high level of social organization.
label: Paragraph

text: One of these groups has traditionally
label: Paragraph

text: been known as Anasazi, but since that is
label: Paragraph

text: a Navajo word meaning “ancient enemy,”
label: Paragraph

text: the Pueblo people prefer to use the Hopi
label: Paragraph

text: word Hisatsinom, meaning “the old ones.”
label: Paragraph

text: What they called themselves is not exactly
label: Paragraph

text: nown. The largest Hisatsinom settlernent
label: Paragraph

text: was Pueblo Bonito (Spanish for “beautiful
label: Paragraph

text: town”). Located beneath a massive cliff, part
label: Paragraph

text: of which has since caved in, the city had a
label: Paragraph

text: D-shaped plan, with masses of rooms and
label: Paragraph

text: circular ceremonial structures called kivas
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding two large plazas. The rows of
label: Paragraph

text: rooms each rose one story before stepping
label: Paragraph

text: ack from the one below, giving the whole
label: Paragraph

text: an impression of a terraced amphitheater.
label: Paragraph

text: ndeed, it has been suggested that one of
label: Paragraph

text: the city’s functions was to provide a place for
label: Paragraph

text: viewing ritual dancing.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Kivas, a local building type with a very long
label: Paragraph

text: history and broad distribution, were an
label: Paragraph

text: essential part of the Hisatsinom culture and
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. They originated as circular
label: Paragraph

text: storehouses, often nothing more than deep-
label: Paragraph

text: pit houses, plastered on the inside with
label: Paragraph

text: smooth adobe. But they soon became sermi-
label: Paragraph

text: subterranean temples, serving as communal
label: Paragraph

text: spaces for the performance and viewing of
label: Title

text: ritual dances. Each kiva was the province of
label: Paragraph

text: a social unit, and there were several kivas in
label: Paragraph

text: each village. They were only for men; women
label: Paragraph

text: were allowed in only on special occasions. In
label: Paragraph

text: Pueblo Bonito, among the regular-size kivas,
label: Paragraph

text: were two that were over 18 meters across
label: Paragraph

text: and that probably served the entire city.
label: Paragraph

text: Though these kivas were built aboveground,
label: Paragraph

text: the subterranean effect was maintained by
label: Paragraph

text: constructing rooms all around and filling in any
label: Paragraph

text: empty space with earth. Kivas were equipped
label: Paragraph

text: with a central fireplace, a low masonry bench
label: Caption

text: around the wall, and four wooden posts. Some
label: Caption

text: kivas had an underfloor ventilating system and
label: Paragraph

text: a subfloor vault to the west of the fireplace.
label: Caption

text: Their flat roofs had a smoke hole in the
label: Paragraph

text: center and served as an entrance by means
label: Paragraph

text: of a ladder. The sandstone masonry walls at
label: Paragraph

text: Pueblo Bonito consisted of a loose rubble
label: Paragraph

text: center-faced on both sides with artfully placed
label: Paragraph

text: sandstone bricks.

label: Caption

text: Construction of Pueblo Bonito began in about
label: Paragraph

text: 920 CE, and the city was modified over the
label: Paragraph

text: course of three centuries. Early research
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to relate its construction directly
label: Paragraph

text: to more contemporary Pueblo architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: whose structure reflects the social order
label: Paragraph

text: of its inhabitants. The evidence, however,
label: Paragraph

text: indicates that this was not the case at Pueblo
label: Paragraph

text: Bonito. Nonetheless, its construction would
label: Paragraph

text: have required a complex coordination of
label: Paragraph

text: labor and materials. Tens of thousands of
label: Paragraph

text: pine beams, used for wall supports and roof
label: Caption

text: structures, came from a forest 90 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: away. Pueblo Bonito’s overall orientation is
label: Paragraph

text: north-south, which became typical of all
label: Paragraph

text: structures erected by the Hisatsinom, but
label: Paragraph

text: the architecture integrates the midpoint
label: Paragraph

text: and extremes of the cycles of the sun and
label: Title

text: the moon into its layout. Though the highly
label: Paragraph

text: disciplined architecture could suggest
label: Paragraph

text: a strong hierarchical social order, the
label: Paragraph

text: Hisatsinom are believed to have had a fairly
label: Paragraph

text: egalitarian society. Pubelo Bonito was one of
label: Paragraph

text: several large constructions in Chaca Canyon.
label: Paragraph

text: Its purpose is not known for sure, but it is
label: Paragraph

text: thought that the site was a ceremonial center
label: Paragraph

text: for people who travelled from far afield for
label: Paragraph

text: certain calendrical events, the canyon itself
label: Paragraph

text: being a type of sacred site.
label: Paragraph

text: The Hohokam also soon began to design
label: Paragraph

text: cities, such as Casa Grande (in Arizona,
label: Paragraph

text: ca. 1100), having developed canals to bring
label: Paragraph

text: water to their fields. Archaeologists have
label: Paragraph

text: discovered hundreds of miles of these canals
label: Paragraph

text: in the Gila River valley, as well as the Salt
label: Paragraph

text: River valley of Phoenix and elsewhere. By the
label: Paragraph

text: 13th century, long periods of drought brought
label: Paragraph

text: that culture to an end and changed the social
label: Paragraph

text: landscape of the region. They were replaced
label: Paragraph

text: by the Pima and Tohono O'odharm tribes. It
label: Paragraph

text: was the Pimas who called their predecessors
label: Paragraph

text: the Hohokam, meaning the “vanished ones.”

text: SELJUK TURKS
label: Title

text: Turks in the 10th century were a pastoral
label: Paragraph

text: people living in Central Asia east of the
label: Paragraph

text: Caspian Sea. Abandoning their homeland,
label: Paragraph

text: they moved into Afghanistan and Iran.
label: Paragraph

text: Accepting the faith of Islam along the way,
label: Paragraph

text: they created a number of Turkish-Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: states, one being the Ghaznavids, who
label: Paragraph

text: settled in what is now western Afghanistan.
label: Paragraph

text: Another tribe, the Seljuks (named after a
label: Paragraph

text: tribal leader), drove further westward, into
label: Paragraph

text: lran, Syria, and eventually the ethnically
label: Paragraph

text: diverse Anatolia, held nominally by the
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantines. The Seljuks consolidated t
label: Paragraph

text: power over eastern Anatolia in 1071; tl
label: Paragraph

text: presence was a major factor in bringing about
label: Paragraph

text: the Crusades. Despite the problems with
label: Paragraph

text: the Crusaders, the Seljuk period was one of
label: Paragraph

text: relative calm, with Persia seeing one of its
label: Paragraph

text: most prosperous periods.
label: Paragraph

text: The stability and success of the Seljuk
label: Title

text: regime was the achievement of the politically
label: Paragraph

text: skilled Vizir Nizam al-Mulk, a cultured
label: Paragraph

text: Persian, a brilliant administrator, and a
label: Paragraph

text: significant political philosopher, whose Book
label: Paragraph

text: The Seljuks distinguished themselves
label: Paragraph

text: from earlier Islamic societies by their strict
label: Paragraph

text: military hierarchy and attendant financial and
label: Title

text: landholding prerogatives, which were closed
label: Paragraph

text: to all but a few exceptional local recruits. The
label: Paragraph

text: principal elements of their political program
label: Title

text: were the mosque; the madrasa (Arabic for
label: Paragraph

text: “school”); the ribats and khanqgahs, which
label: Paragraph

text: were the Sufi lodgings; and the mausoleum,
label: Paragraph

text: which commemorated their deeds.
label: Paragraph

text: The Seljuk architecture of Iran is
label: Paragraph

text: characterized by elaborate brickwork and
label: Paragraph

text: the development of the four-iwan plan. The
label: Paragraph

text: Seljuk rulers in Anatolia used a vocabulary
label: Paragraph

text: characterized primarily by stonework. Tiles
label: Paragraph

text: were important decorative elements of Seljuk
label: Paragraph

text: architecture. The technology for tile-rnaking
label: Title

text: emerged out of a century-old tradition in
label: Paragraph

text: lran and lrag, which was brought to Anatolia
label: Paragraph

text: by the Seljuks. The tiles consisted of an
label: Paragraph

text: underlying paste with a high silicate content,
label: Paragraph

text: over which a thick mixture containing kaolin
label: Paragraph

text: and feldspar was spread. Monochromatic
label: Paragraph

text: tiles were used for fill and borders; others
label: Paragraph

text: were designed as large custom-made plaques
label: Paragraph

text: for a particular place in the composition.
label: Paragraph

text: During Seljuk times, textile and leather
label: Paragraph

text: exports were also important, as they were
label: Paragraph

text: shipped to both Europe and the East. Once a
label: Paragraph

text: year there was a vast commercial fair called
label: Paragraph

text: Yabanlu Pazan (“Bazaar of the Foreigners”)
label: Title

text: held for forty days not far from Kayseri, in the
label: Paragraph

text: center of Anatolia, at a place where several
label: Paragraph

text: caravan routes converged.
label: Paragraph

text: 11.21 Seljuk design
label: Caption

text: Representations of the human form are
label: Paragraph

text: banned in Islam, but images of birds
label: Paragraph

text: and animals as well as sphinxes and
label: Paragraph

text: centaurs—often linked to ancient totemic
label: Paragraph

text: worship still prevalent in Anatolian
label: Paragraph

text: lands—were frequently embedded in the
label: Paragraph

text: composition of Seljuk art. Calligraphic.
label: Caption

text: inscriptions of Qur’anic verses were often
label: Paragraph

text: used along the cornices or to frame portals.
label: Paragraph

text: Sultan Han
label: Title

text: Among the finest and most characteristic
label: Paragraph

text: of Seljuk buildings are the caravansaries
label: Paragraph

text: (derived from two Persian words meaning “a
label: Paragraph

text: palace for caravans"), or hans, constructed
label: Paragraph

text: during the 13th century to encourage trade
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the empire; several dozen of them
label: Paragraph

text: survive in good condition. These buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: some 119 of which are known to have been
label: Paragraph

text: erected, were made to shelter and protect
label: Paragraph

text: not only the caravan drivers but also their
label: Paragraph

text: camels, horses, and donkeys, along with their
label: Paragraph

text: cargoes, and to provide needed services.
label: Paragraph

text: Though caravan resting places had existed
label: Paragraph

text: for centuries, this was the first large-scale
label: Paragraph

text: systernatization of mercantile transport across
label: Title

text: a desert. The services offered were free of
label: Paragraph

text: charge for the first three days. One of the
label: Paragraph

text: basic rules was that travelers who came to
label: Paragraph

text: the establishment were to be treated equally,
label: Paragraph

text: without regard to race, creed, or social status.
label: Paragraph

text: Though plans of caravansaries vary,
label: Paragraph

text: they were typically square or rectangular
label: Paragraph

text: buildings with thick stone walls and a large
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard in the center surrounded by one-
label: Paragraph

text: or two-story arcades; they accommodated
label: Paragraph

text: bathing services, storage, a treasury, and
label: Paragraph

text: stables, and had rooms for physicians,
label: Paragraph

text: cooks, blacksmiths, and musicians as well
label: Paragraph

text: as drivers. Though the exterior walls were
label: Paragraph

text: plain and devoid of decoration, the portals
label: Paragraph

text: were often elaborately embellished with
label: Paragraph

text: bands of geometrical designs and Qur’anic
label: Title

text: inscriptions. At the center of the caravansary
label: Caption

text: was usually a small mosque or prayer room,
label: Paragraph

text: raised aboveground level on a stone platform.
label: Caption

text: At the far end of the courtyard, opposite the
label: Paragraph

text: main portal, was a large vaulted hall, usually
label: Paragraph

text: with several aisles. Lit by narrow windows
label: Caption

text: in the stone walls, it served as a shelter for
label: Paragraph

text: goods and men during bad winter weather.
label: Paragraph

text: The Sultan Han, the grandest caravansary
label: Title

text: of all, covering 4,500 square meters, is
label: Paragraph

text: west of Aksaray, a center in the Cappadocia
label: Paragraph

text: region on the Konya Highway. Designed by a
label: Paragraph

text: certain Muhammet of Syria, the doorway is
label: Paragraph

text: particularly spectacular. Made of marble, the
label: Paragraph

text: outer frame is covered with a delicate floral
label: Paragraph

text: pattern. The tympanum over the door, which
label: Paragraph

text: has an abstract geometrical pattern, looks
label: Paragraph

text: as if it were eaten away by the encrustations
label: Paragraph

text: of an open conically shaped stalactite vault.
label: Paragraph

text: 11.25 Development of the Great Mosque of Isfahan, Iran
label: Caption

text: Great Mosque of Isfahan
label: Title

text: The Great Mosque of Isfahan (Masjid-i Jome,
label: Paragraph

text: or Friday Mosque), in the northern part of
label: Paragraph

text: the city, was one of the most influential of
label: Paragraph

text: all early Seljuk religious structures. Though
label: Paragraph

text: the building is known as a four-iwan type
label: Paragraph

text: because the iwans face each other across
label: Paragraph

text: an open courtyard, the building is, in
label: Paragraph

text: actuality, the result of numerous architectural
label: Paragraph

text: transformations. The primary building
label: Caption

text: substance dates to a mosque built in the
label: Paragraph

text: 840s CE that stood over an even earlier
label: Paragraph

text: mosque, built in 772 CE, which in turn was
label: Paragraph

text: built over the foundations of a Christian
label: Paragraph

text: church. The mosque was a conventional
label: Paragraph

text: hypostyle-courtyard mosque, typical of early
label: Caption

text: mosques. But beginning around 870 CE, it
label: Paragraph

text: was thoroughly revised. The central space
label: Paragraph

text: was reduced somewhat by the addition of
label: Paragraph

text: a new facade running around all four sides.
label: Caption

text: An elegant qibla dome was built and, to the
label: Paragraph

text: north, an annex with a domed sacred area,
label: Paragraph

text: the original purpose of which is not precisely
label: Paragraph

text: known.
label: Paragraph

text: In the time of Sultan Sanjar (1096-1157)
label: Paragraph

text: four iwans were added to the courtyard, in
label: Caption

text: essence imposing them on top of the older
label: Paragraph

text: systern. The old columns were thickened
label: Paragraph

text: or removed, as was required; the original
label: Paragraph

text: columnar rhythms are still best visible in the
label: Paragraph

text: areas to the right and left of the northern
label: Paragraph

text: iwan. In the 1350s, buildings were joined
label: Paragraph

text: to the outer flanks of the structure, a
label: Paragraph

text: madrasa was added to the western flank,
label: Paragraph

text: and a musalla (a temporary place in which
label: Paragraph

text: worshippers congregate to perform their
label: Paragraph

text: prayers) to the eastern one, to name only
label: Paragraph

text: the most prominent changes made to the
label: Paragraph

text: building over time.
label: Paragraph

text: In its original pre-Islamic form, the iwan was
label: Paragraph

text: a type of stage for the enthroned king, but
label: Paragraph

text: the Seljuks used it for several purposes; in
label: Paragraph

text: a madrasa, for example, it was a lecture
label: Paragraph

text: room. At the Isfahan mosque, the iwans are
label: Paragraph

text: grand portals, becoming the very symbol of
label: Paragraph

text: the mosque on the other side. The Isfahan
label: Paragraph

text: iwaris are not identical. The main one, at
label: Paragraph

text: the southwest, leads to the dome in front of
label: Paragraph

text: the qibla. The side jwans have no particular
label: Paragraph

text: relationship to the spaces behind them and
label: Paragraph

text: lead nowhere except through doorways at the
label: Paragraph

text: sides.
label: Paragraph

text: 11.26 Courtyard, Great Mosque of Isfahan
label: Caption

text: To the north, the iwan with its barrel vault
label: Caption

text: points in the direction of a haram—a special
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuary where contending parties could
label: Paragraph

text: meet to settle disputes—which had originally
label: Paragraph

text: been freestanding on three sides but was
label: Paragraph

text: eventually roofed over and connected to the
label: Paragraph

text: neighboring buildings. The particular reason
label: Paragraph

text: why the mosque orientation was interrupted
label: Paragraph

text: by the use of the four iwans is not known, but
label: Paragraph

text: the building is an ideal space composed of
label: Paragraph

text: principal elements, with the iwans a symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: armature arranged in precise relationships to
label: Paragraph

text: each other.

text: Madrasas were built in almost all parts of
label: Paragraph

text: Asia Minor, but their origin is unclear. Some
label: Paragraph

text: link it with the Buddhist vihara—and given
label: Paragraph

text: that the eastern areas of Islam had been
label: Paragraph

text: saturated with Buddhism for centuries, there
label: Paragraph

text: is sore plausibility to that argument. Another
label: Paragraph

text: possibility is its association with the courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: house, a tradition that goes back to ancient
label: Paragraph

text: times. A madrasa was usually founded by a
label: Paragraph

text: sultan or nobleman, who would generously
label: Paragraph

text: endow it to meet its expenses. As with the
label: Paragraph

text: caravansaries, the Seljuk madrasa followed
label: Paragraph

text: a standard form. They were rectangular,
label: Paragraph

text: compact, and relatively windowless,
label: Paragraph

text: appearing as solid objects in the landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Portals, however, were often grandly and
label: Paragraph

text: richly carved. Most, like the Ince Minare
label: Paragraph

text: Madrasa (1260-65) in Konya, Turkey, had
label: Paragraph

text: a central courtyard lined with classrooms
label: Caption

text: around a central iwan opposite the entrance.
label: Paragraph

text: Others, like the Madrasa al-Fridus (1235-41)
label: Paragraph

text: in Aleppo, Syria, had no iwan.

text: MUGQARNAS
label: Title

text: Muqarnas, also called stalactite or
label: Paragraph

text: honeycombed vaulting, are one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: common features of Islamic architecture
label: Title

text: between the 11th and 15th centuries. They
label: Paragraph

text: appear around the Islamic world, including
label: Paragraph

text: South Asia, in a variety of materials, including
label: Paragraph

text: brick, stone, stucco, and wood. The term’s
label: Paragraph

text: origin and meaning, as well as the historical
label: Paragraph

text: development of the form, are not known
label: Paragraph

text: for certain and are much debated. They
label: Paragraph

text: originally developed out of squinches that
label: Paragraph

text: eased the transition between the square
label: Paragraph

text: and circle of a dome, but they became an
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of the fascination among Islamic
label: Title

text: artists for complex geometrical patterns,
label: Paragraph

text: which were being applied to the surfaces of
label: Paragraph

text: doors and window moldings. Though they
label: Paragraph

text: do not have an explicit symbolic value, they
label: Paragraph

text: allude to the geometry of the heavens and
label: Paragraph

text: the wonders of God's creations.
label: Paragraph

text: An early example is the Shrine of Imam
label: Paragraph

text: Dur, in Samarra, Iraq (1085). The building
label: Caption

text: consists of an elongated cube on which rests
label: Paragraph

text: a series of octagonal tiers that telescope
label: Paragraph

text: and rotate toward the final dame. Among
label: Paragraph

text: the more developed examples is the dome
label: Paragraph

text: (qubba) of al-Barubiyyin in Marrakech,
label: Caption

text: Morocco (1117), another early example
label: Paragraph

text: of a complex dome structure. Its eight-
label: Paragraph

text: pointed star seems to almost float free
label: Paragraph

text: from its enclosing frame. The four corners

text: THE FATIMIDS
label: Title

text: The Fatimids, who had established
label: Paragraph

text: themselves in Tunisia, eventually lost
label: Paragraph

text: Algeria and points to the west. But they
label: Paragraph

text: were successful in their expansion to the
label: Paragraph

text: east, sweeping through the Nile Valley,
label: Paragraph

text: across Palestine, and into southern Syria
label: Paragraph

text: to control a considerable part of the Middle
label: Paragraph

text: East for more than two hundred years.
label: Paragraph

text: Most Egyptians at that time were Sunni
label: Paragraph

text: Muslims, whom the Fatimids—Shirites of
label: Paragraph

text: the Ismma’ili sect—opposed. The Fatimid
label: Paragraph

text: caliphs, who considered themselves to
label: Paragraph

text: be divine rulers sent by God to ensure
label: Paragraph

text: the prevalence of Islamic justice, refused
label: Paragraph

text: to recognize the legitimacy of the Sunni
label: Paragraph

text: Abbasid caliphates ruling frorn Baghdad.
label: Paragraph

text: It was the Fatimid vision and mission to
label: Paragraph

text: convert the whole Muslim world to its faith
label: Title

text: and overthrow the Sunni caliphate. One of
label: Paragraph

text: its principal architectural expressions was
label: Paragraph

text: the construction of the city of al-Qahira,
label: Paragraph

text: which became the heart of the modern city
label: Paragraph

text: of Cairo, a few kilometers to the north of the
label: Paragraph

text: old early Islamic town. At the core of the
label: Paragraph

text: city, which was bisected by a main road,
label: Paragraph

text: was a palace district with an east and west
label: Paragraph

text: palace separated by a large square; nearby
label: Paragraph

text: were the office of the state bureaucracy and
label: Paragraph

text: the military. Though descriptions testify to
label: Paragraph

text: the sumptuousness of the Fatimid palaces,
label: Paragraph

text: little of that palace architecture survives,
label: Paragraph

text: but a sense of Fatimid era architectural
