text: RISE OF THE RAJPUT KINGDOMS
label: Title

text: Between 800 and 1000 Ce, the Gurjara-
label: Paragraph

text: Pratiharas from the west, the Rashtrakutas
label: Paragraph

text: from the Deccan Plateau, and the Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: Palla kings from the east were locked in
label: Paragraph

text: a battle for control of the central Gangetic
label: Title

text: Plains. Kanauj, through which all of the
label: Paragraph

text: major trade routes south, east, and north
label: Title

text: passed, was the prized possession. The three
label: Paragraph

text: contenders, by turn, had all managed to
label: Paragraph

text: capture Kanauj, but two centuries of warfare
label: Paragraph

text: weakened all three to such a degree that
label: Paragraph

text: they all eventually collapsed. The resultant
label: Paragraph

text: power vacuum in northern India led to a
label: Paragraph

text: series of new kingdoms. Some of these, like
label: Paragraph

text: the Chalukyas, were former vassal states
label: Paragraph

text: that now declared independence. More
label: Paragraph

text: significantly, a large number of semitribal and
label: Paragraph

text: tribal communities that had previously been
label: Title

text: subjugated emerged as kingdoms in their
label: Paragraph

text: own right. These are known collectively as
label: Paragraph

text: the Rajput kingdoms because of their shared
label: Paragraph

text: caste identity (raj-put means “royal son”).
label: Paragraph

text: Among these, the Solankis (western and
label: Paragraph

text: central India), the Chandellas (north-central
label: Paragraph

text: India}, and the Orissans (east and central
label: Paragraph

text: India) were eminent temple builders. The
label: Paragraph

text: capital of the Solankis, Patan, was the largest
label: Paragraph

text: city in India and the tenth-largest city in the
label: Paragraph

text: world.
label: Paragraph

text: Most of the tribal communities were of
label: Paragraph

text: the lowest caste, so their new kings had
label: Paragraph

text: to acquire the Kshatriya, or warrior caste.
label: Paragraph

text: To accomplish this, the kings laid claim to
label: Paragraph

text: a mythical lineage and, more importantly,
label: Paragraph

text: began to build and support temples as a way
label: Paragraph

text: to legitimate their rule. The result was one
label: Paragraph

text: of the largest temple-building campaigns in
label: Paragraph

text: India, with new forms coming into being.
label: Paragraph

text: Regional deities and gods were accepted into
label: Paragraph

text: the expanding Hindu pantheon, and worship
label: Paragraph

text: was conducted in regional languages. Other
label: Paragraph

text: than the introduction of Islam, which was yet
label: Paragraph

text: to come, the patchwork of regional identities
label: Paragraph

text: that is modern India was established at this
label: Paragraph

text: time. Contemporary India still has twenty-two
label: Paragraph

text: official languages (and over five hundred
label: Title

text: ialects) with clear geographical divisions.
label: Paragraph

text: It is therefore useful to think of India as one
label: Paragraph

text: joes of Europe: as an interrelated network
label: Title

text: of distinct regional areas. While the various
label: Paragraph

text: regions share certain cultural aspects,
label: Paragraph

text: their identities are as diverse as those of
label: Paragraph

text: European countries. The sare applies to
label: Paragraph

text: their architecture. To think of a unified Indian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is as useful and as useless as
label: Paragraph

text: thinking of “European architecture.”
label: Paragraph

text: Rani-ni-Vav at Patan
label: Title

text: Access to and distribution of fresh water
label: Title

text: played a critical role in all of Indian society,
label: Paragraph

text: where water had both an economic and a
label: Paragraph

text: symbolic value. But Solanki wells were no
label: Paragraph

text: simple affairs. The step well called the Rani-
label: Paragraph

text: ni-Vay, or “Queen's Step Well,” was built
label: Paragraph

text: at Anhilwara (Patan) in the 11th century,
label: Paragraph

text: in memory of Bhimdev | (1022-63) by his
label: Paragraph

text: widowed queen, Udaymati. It consists of a
label: Paragraph

text: long stairway leading down to the water table.
label: Paragraph

text: The entire excavation is lined with a multi-
label: Paragraph

text: tiered colonnaded “facade” supported by
label: Caption

text: elaborately carved stone colurnns and beams.
label: Caption

text: It was partially roofed, with light filtering even
label: Paragraph

text: into the deepest parts 28 meters below the
label: Paragraph

text: surface. The reason for such splendor was
label: Paragraph

text: that the Rani-ni-Vav (rani means “queen”;
label: Paragraph

text: vav, “well”) served as a supplementary
label: Paragraph

text: palace for the queen and her attendants. The
label: Paragraph

text: natural temperature of the earth, combined
label: Title

text: with the evaporative effects of the wind
label: Paragraph

text: passing over the water, turned the step well
label: Paragraph

text: into a subterranean world of cool repose
label: Title

text: during the blistering summer months. Since
label: Paragraph

text: the well went so far down, its walls had to
label: Paragraph

text: be buttressed against implosion. This was
label: Paragraph

text: achieved by building heavy stone buttresses
label: Paragraph

text: at the well’s mouth and bracing its interior.
label: Paragraph

text: In a more symbolic sense, the step well was
label: Paragraph

text: also another version of the ghats of Varanasi
label: Paragraph

text: or the water tank of the Sun Ternple at
label: Paragraph

text: Modhera, except that the step well was fully
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitable. Much of Solanki architecture
label: Paragraph

text: was eventually destroyed by invading Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: armies. The Rani-ni-Vav survived intact
label: Paragraph

text: because it was intentionally filled in with earth
label: Paragraph

text: by the retreating Solankis.
label: Paragraph

text: 11.46 Rani-ni-Vav, step well at Patan

text: Sun Temple at Modhera
label: Title

text: Of the various Rajput kingdoms, the Solankis,
label: Paragraph

text: who ruled in Rajasthan and Gujarat, were
label: Paragraph

text: among the most zealous temple builders.
label: Paragraph

text: They traded not only with the other kingdoms
label: Paragraph

text: of South Asia but also with Central Asia.
label: Paragraph

text: Though principally worshipers of Shiva, they
label: Paragraph

text: claimed lineage from Pandu, a mythological
label: Paragraph

text: king during ancient Vedic times. Through that
label: Paragraph

text: connection, they legitimized their tradition
label: Paragraph

text: of solar cults. The Solanki royal temple,
label: Caption

text: dedicated to Surya, or the sun, was made
label: Paragraph

text: from golden sandstone in a tripartite axial
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement. The main shrine is in the
label: Paragraph

text: west, a rectangular water tank in the east,
label: Paragraph

text: and a mandapa in between, all integrated
label: Paragraph

text: into a single composition. The mandapa is
label: Paragraph

text: connected to the steps surrounding the water
label: Paragraph

text: tank by a freestanding gateway, or forana,
label: Paragraph

text: that marks the top of a flight of steps. While
label: Paragraph

text: the aesthetic expression of all the ternple’s
label: Paragraph

text: elements is in itself quite remarkable, it
label: Paragraph

text: is the delicate richness with which all the
label: Paragraph

text: columns, brackets, cusped and wavy arches,
label: Caption

text: and roofs are carved that stands out. Their
label: Paragraph

text: distinction lies in how they function optically
label: Paragraph

text: to connect the building’s elements. Standing
label: Paragraph

text: on the western edge of the tank and looking
label: Paragraph

text: eastward toward the main ternple, the view
label: Paragraph

text: seems to be of one building composed of the
label: Paragraph

text: steps leading upward to the mandapa. But
label: Paragraph

text: the conical top belongs to the shrine in the
label: Paragraph

text: distance, and the entrance of the mandapa is
label: Paragraph

text: actually the torana in the foreground.

text: Chandellas
label: Title

text: In a brief period of about 175 years, the
label: Paragraph

text: Chandellas, who called their kingdom
label: Paragraph

text: Jejakabhukti, built more than eighty temples
label: Paragraph

text: in and around their capital of Khajuraho
label: Paragraph

text: (ancient Khajjuravahaka). The crispness
label: Paragraph

text: of their architectural forms and the close
label: Paragraph

text: continuity in their order and language
label: Title

text: 11.52 Lakshmana Temple at Khajuraho, India
label: Caption

text: indicate that there must have been a core
label: Paragraph

text: group of architects, or perhaps even a
label: Paragraph

text: single architect-in-charge. Two of the main
label: Caption

text: royal temples of the Chandellas were the
label: Paragraph

text: Lakshmana (ca. 950 CE) and the Khandariya
label: Paragraph

text: Mahadeva (1000-1025).
label: Paragraph

text: Dedicated to Shiva, the Lakshmana
label: Paragraph

text: rises on a high platform, ensuring that, like
label: Paragraph

text: all other Khajuraho temples, it is visible in
label: Paragraph

text: the surrounding flat countryside from afar.
label: Paragraph

text: Independent subsidiary shrines are located at
label: Paragraph

text: the four corners of the platform, suggesting
label: Paragraph

text: a sense of enclosure and defining a sacred
label: Title

text: precinct without the actual existence of a
label: Paragraph

text: wall. Access is highly dramatic, via an axially
label: Paragraph

text: it} 10m

text: Pore wk 4

text: placed stair to the platform and another set
label: Caption

text: of stairs to the ternple. The profile of the
label: Caption

text: temple was itself something of a “stairway
label: Paragraph

text: to heaven.” The temple consists of three
label: Paragraph

text: mandapas preceding the main shikhara. The
label: Paragraph

text: mandapas are articulated in horizontal layers,
label: Paragraph

text: while the main shikhara emphasizes the
label: Paragraph

text: vertical. One of the key architectural issues
label: Paragraph

text: is that the mandapa is no longer just a flat
label: Paragraph

text: roofed box in front of the temple: it now has
label: Paragraph

text: its own pyramidical roof that competes with
label: Paragraph

text: the shikhara of the main shrine. From this
label: Paragraph

text: time on, one of the main characteristics of
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu temples is their silhouette.
label: Paragraph

text: One distinguishing feature of the
label: Paragraph

text: ajuraho ternples is the manner in
label: Paragraph

text: hich their architects orchestrated the
label: Paragraph

text: ront elevations—not mathematically or
label: Paragraph

text: geometrically, but perspectively. The front
label: Paragraph

text: levations of the mandapas are designed
label: Paragraph

text: so that at eye level they all appear to nestle
label: Paragraph

text: nto each other perfectly. (This is similar to
label: Paragraph

text: the design of the Sun Temple at Mochera.)
label: Paragraph

text: The objective was not just aesthetic. The
label: Paragraph

text: superstructure of every Hindu temple is
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The Khandariya Mahadeva Temple
label: Title

text: (1000-1025), like the Lakshmana, sits on
label: Paragraph

text: a high platform that it shares with another,
label: Paragraph

text: smaller ternple, the Jagdambi, dedicated to
label: Paragraph

text: the goddess Parvati. There are no corner
label: Paragraph

text: shrines, so the profiles of the Khandariya
label: Paragraph

text: and its partner are silhouetted against
label: Paragraph

text: the sky without distraction. Balancing the
label: Paragraph

text: composition between the two temples is
label: Paragraph

text: a small shrine resting on its own plinth.
label: Paragraph

text: At 30 meters, including the 4-meter-high
label: Paragraph

text: platform on which it rests, the Khandariya
label: Paragraph

text: rises higher than all the other temples,
label: Paragraph

text: but its strength lies not in its size, but in
label: Paragraph

text: the quality of its architecture. Its profile
label: Paragraph

text: is designed to represent the rhythms of a
label: Paragraph

text: jagged mountain range, both in its outlines
label: Paragraph

text: and in the composition of its parts. Unlike the
label: Paragraph

text: Lakshmana, the Khandariya’s four mandapas
label: Title

text: are articulated with distinctive mini-shikharas
label: Paragraph

text: that cluster around the main shikhara. These
label: Paragraph

text: mini-shikharas produce the sense of a rising
label: Paragraph

text: wave while still being fully geometrical.
label: Paragraph

text: he slight widening at the base, the strong
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal protrusions of the porches, and the
label: Paragraph

text: tightly bound faceting at the intersection of
label: Paragraph

text: the shikhara and the mandapa make for an
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinarily powerful composition. Because
label: Paragraph

text: of their height, the porches give the visitor
label: Paragraph

text: a sense of elevation above the quotidian.
label: Paragraph

text: he interior of the sanctuary, however, is
label: Paragraph

text: appropriately deep and dark, like a cave.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike many Hindu temples, the Khandariya
label: Paragraph

text: is lit by large openings located well above eye
label: Paragraph

text: level. The effect is particularly spectacular
label: Paragraph

text: in the circumambulation route, where the
label: Paragraph

text: light coming from a high source casts dark
label: Title

text: shadows between the folds of the sculptures,
label: Paragraph

text: bringing them into sharp relief. The openings
label: Paragraph

text: are furnished with platforms and steps for
label: Paragraph

text: attendants and musicians.
label: Paragraph

text: Vastu-Shastras
label: Title

text: In the 10th and 11th centuries, a series of
label: Paragraph

text: technical manuals was published under
label: Paragraph

text: such titles as Vastu Shastra (“Construction
label: Paragraph

text: Treatise") and Shilpa Shastra (“Sculpture
label: Paragraph

text: Treatise”); they provide insight into the highly
label: Paragraph

text: codified language of termple design and
label: Paragraph

text: construction. From these texts we know that
label: Paragraph

text: a temple's overall design was handled by a
label: Paragraph

text: chief Brahmin, known as a sutradhar. He
label: Paragraph

text: based his work on an astrological diagram
label: Paragraph

text: called a mandala, a graph that mapped
label: Paragraph

text: the positions of stars, planets, deities, and
label: Paragraph

text: the sun with respect to a particular site.
label: Paragraph

text: Its design is based on the overlay of a
label: Paragraph

text: square and a circle. The sutradhar chose
label: Paragraph

text: from hundreds of mandalas, depending on
label: Paragraph

text: the deity of the temple and the religious
label: Title

text: persuasion of the community. The temple's
label: Paragraph

text: actual form was derived through a series of
label: Paragraph

text: geometrical maneuvers designed to express
label: Title

text: the potency of the various planets and
label: Paragraph

text: deities occupying the grid of the mandala.
label: Paragraph

text: Radiating lines, the weight given to the
label: Paragraph

text: primary directions, and special triangles all
label: Paragraph

text: determined the location of the building's
label: Paragraph

text: various parts. A complex system of faceting,
label: Paragraph

text: known as rathas, determined the detailed
label: Paragraph

text: articulation of the temple's surface. The
label: Paragraph

text: purpose of the rathas was to enable multiple
label: Paragraph

text: deities to share a single surface—in the
label: Paragraph

text: vertical and horizontal plane—by suggesting
label: Paragraph

text: superimposed layers. The final form was
label: Paragraph

text: inevitably a heavily faceted pyrarnid. Once
label: Paragraph

text: the design had been determined, it was
label: Paragraph

text: relayed to the master builder, whose craft
label: Paragraph

text: was handed down through oral tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: Sculpture and paintings were then finished
label: Paragraph

text: by independent shrenis (“artisans”).
label: Paragraph

text: The cosmic order expressed by a temple
label: Paragraph

text: offers a vision of a pyramidal universe
label: Paragraph

text: cascading downward in conceptual waves
label: Paragraph

text: from a single point of origin that in itself is
label: Paragraph

text: without form or substance. The objective of
label: Paragraph

text: the worshipper, in apprehending this vision,
label: Paragraph

text: was to devote himself or herself to ascending
label: Paragraph

text: to that formless center, a task assisted by
label: Paragraph

text: devotion to the temple’s resident deity.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: hundred still stand. As Hinduism matured,
label: Paragraph

text: the ruling dynasties grew in power, and their
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: elaborate, the temples of Bhubaneshwar grew
label: Paragraph

text: in size and complexity. The temples were
label: Paragraph

text: unique, as the mandapa was given its own
label: Paragraph

text: pyramidical roof that had to be harmonized
label: Paragraph

text: with the rising shikhara of the garbha-griha
label: Paragraph

text: (which the Orissans call rekha deu/). The
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of this atternpt at integration is

text: As the “king” of the Bhubaneshwar temples,
label: Paragraph

text: the Lingaraja (literally, “Phallus King,” ca.
label: Paragraph

text: 1100) was distinguished not only by its size
label: Paragraph

text: but also by the presence of a row of three
label: Paragraph

text: jagmohans. The rituals that would normally
label: Paragraph

text: have been conducted in a single hall were
label: Paragraph

text: here separated, enabling several rituals to
label: Paragraph

text: occur simultaneously and creating the sense
label: Paragraph

text: of a mini-pilgrimage in their performance.
label: Paragraph

text: These jagmohans—a primary jagmohan,
label: Paragraph

text: a nat-mandir (“dance hall”), and a bhog-
label: Paragraph

text: mandapa (“collective ritual performance
label: Title

text: hall” )}—were about the same size, though
label: Paragraph

text: each has a distinctive plan suited to its
label: Paragraph

text: function. The jagmohan has a fully articulated
label: Paragraph

text: exterior, making it a shrine in itself. The nat-
label: Paragraph

text: mandir is airy and open so that its activities
label: Paragraph

text: could be seen and heard in the surroundings.

text: The bhog-mandapa duplicates the jagmohan
label: Paragraph

text: and was probably added later to facilitate
label: Paragraph

text: rituals by larger groups that could not
label: Paragraph

text: access the innermost shrine. The Lingaraja’s
label: Paragraph

text: 37.5-meter-high rekha deul, which dominates
label: Caption

text: the silhouette, has a distinctive profile, first
label: Paragraph

text: rising almost vertically and then, only toward
label: Paragraph

text: the top, curving inward, before yielding to a
label: Paragraph

text: recessed neck that supports a wide amalaka
label: Paragraph

text: resting on the backs of lions (an indication of
label: Paragraph

text: royal patronage).
label: Paragraph

text: The Lingaraja sits in the middle of
label: Paragraph

text: a quadrangular compound dotted with
label: Paragraph

text: numerous small subsidiary shrines that
label: Paragraph

text: were added over time to the main sequence
label: Paragraph

text: in order to increase its potency. This
label: Paragraph

text: proliferation is cornmon in active Hindu
label: Paragraph

text: temples and is described as the parivar
label: Paragraph

text: (literally, the “farnily") of the main shrine,
label: Paragraph

text: which is expected to change and grow in
label: Paragraph

text: time as does a prosperous family around a
label: Paragraph

text: reigning patriarch. Though the Lingaraja is
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Temple in Puri, also built by the Gangas in
label: Paragraph

text: the 12th century, is still in use, and as a

text: Jains
label: Title

text: Many of the ministers employed in the
label: Paragraph

text: Rajput courts were neither Hindus nor
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhists but Jains, who were often
label: Paragraph

text: the best financial experts and bankers
label: Title

text: available—an unintended consequence
label: Paragraph

text: of their religion. Jainism originates in the
label: Paragraph

text: teaching of Mahavira, a conternporary of
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddha from the 6th century BCE. (Jain
label: Paragraph

text: is a corruption of the Sanskrit word jina,
label: Paragraph

text: meaning “conqueror,” the title given to
label: Paragraph

text: Mahavira in Jain texts.) Like the Buddha,
label: Paragraph

text: Mahavira preached a doctrine of asceticism
label: Paragraph

text: and meditation, but Mahavira insisted that all
label: Paragraph

text: forms of life were equivalent and that respect
label: Paragraph

text: for life was essential for the purification of
label: Paragraph

text: the human soul. Strictly ascetic Jains, known
label: Paragraph

text: as Digambaras (“sky-clad,” or naked), were
label: Paragraph

text: thus expected not only to be vegetarians
label: Paragraph

text: but also to eat only a fruit or vegetable that
label: Paragraph

text: had broken off its plant of its own accord.
label: Paragraph

text: Root vegetables like potatoes and beets
label: Title

text: that entailed killing the whole plant were
label: Paragraph

text: also prohibited. Nor could Jains be farmers,
label: Paragraph

text: since working the land inevitably harrned
label: Paragraph

text: insects and worms. As a consequence, they
label: Paragraph

text: turned to professions such as jewelry making,
label: Paragraph

text: trading, and banking and were thus highly
label: Paragraph

text: sought after by the courts. They also often
label: Paragraph

text: became great librarians and patrons of the
label: Paragraph

text: arts.
label: Paragraph

text: Like the Mahayana Buddhists of Central and
label: Paragraph

text: East Asia, the Jains built colossal monolithic
label: Paragraph

text: statues of their Tirthankars (literally, “ford
label: Paragraph

text: finders,” or “those who cross the river of
label: Paragraph

text: human misery”) and spiritual leaders. In
label: Paragraph

text: 966 CE, Chamundaray, a Jain minister of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ganga dynasty, built at Shravanabelagola,
label: Paragraph

text: Karnataka, a 17-meter-high statue of a naked
label: Paragraph

text: Gomteshwara Bahubali, the first man said
label: Paragraph

text: to have attained enlightenment through Jain
label: Title

text: practice. It sits on top of a hill visible from
label: Paragraph

text: a distance. Every twelve years the statue is
label: Paragraph

text: covered with milk, yogurt, ghee (clarified
label: Paragraph

text: butter), and saffron, as well as with gold
label: Paragraph

text: coins.
label: Paragraph

text: Like the Buddhists, the Jains challenged
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu caste hierarchy and refuted Vedic
label: Title

text: orthodoxy, particularly the Brahmin’s claim
label: Paragraph

text: to privileged access to higher knowledge.
label: Paragraph

text: So Jain ideas and institutions, like those of
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddhists, were severely attacked by
label: Paragraph

text: the Hindus in the 9th and 10th centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: Followers of the Shaivite and Vaishnite bhakti
label: Title

text: cults blamed them for negating life and
label: Paragraph

text: being too abstract and impractical for the
label: Paragraph

text: common man. But unlike the Buddhists,
label: Paragraph

text: who wilted under the critiques and eventually
label: Paragraph

text: disappeared from India, the Jains managed
label: Paragraph

text: to survive the rising tide of Hinduism (and
label: Paragraph

text: later iconoclastic Islam), in part because of
label: Paragraph

text: their economic and political clout.
label: Paragraph

text: Jain Temples at Mt. Abu
label: Caption

text: From the 10th through the 16th centuries,
label: Paragraph

text: Jain ministers employed in Rajput courts
label: Title

text: used their wealth to build a set of five temples
label: Paragraph

text: at Mt. Abu, Rajasthan, 170 kilometers north
label: Caption

text: of Ahmedabad. Known collectively as the
label: Paragraph

text: Dilwara Temples after a nearby town, they
label: Paragraph

text: are clustered on a hill located on the high
label: Paragraph

text: plateau summit of the mountain. Each ternple
label: Paragraph

text: sits high off the ground on its own terrace
label: Paragraph

text: and is accessed on its flank by steps spilling
label: Paragraph

text: out from a multitiered porch. The plans are
label: Paragraph

text: modeled on Hindu precedents, with a main
label: Paragraph

text: garbha-griha preceded by a mandapa. The
label: Paragraph

text: central deity of the site is Adinath, one of
label: Paragraph

text: the Tirthankars; shrines to all the Tirthankars
label: Paragraph

text: were added to each temple later on. As a
label: Paragraph

text: result, the individual temples came to be
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by a quadrangle composed
label: Paragraph

text: of rows of mini-shrines. The mandapas
label: Caption

text: of the mini-shrines were joined to form a
label: Paragraph

text: cloister. Into the residual space between the
label: Paragraph

text: quadrangle and the temple, the architects
label: Title

text: inserted a pavilion held up by highly ornate
label: Paragraph

text: columns of lavish sculptural detail. The
label: Paragraph

text: temples, of local white arasa marble, are
label: Paragraph

text: carved as if made of wood. The columns and
label: Paragraph

text: ceilings of the open pavilion are the climax of
label: Paragraph

text: the sculptural program.
label: Paragraph

text: 11.72 Chola and its economic sphere of influence

text: CHOLAMANDALAM
label: Title

text: India’s south came to be dominated by a
label: Paragraph

text: single power, the Cholas, who combined
label: Paragraph

text: military strength with an effective strategy of
label: Paragraph

text: wealth generation and governance to bring
label: Title

text: about a social and economic revolution of
label: Paragraph

text: their own. Building for themselves a new
label: Paragraph

text: capital at Thanjavur, they eventually came
label: Paragraph

text: to control all of peninsular India, becoming
label: Paragraph

text: the largest power on the subcontinent. They
label: Paragraph

text: lost no time in embarking on an aggressive
label: Paragraph

text: campaign of temple building, not only to
label: Paragraph

text: spread Shaivism but also to consolidate their
label: Paragraph

text: economic base. Raja Raja Chola | (r. 985-
label: Caption

text: 1004) turned his attention to the trade routes
label: Paragraph

text: and soon brought the Arabian shipping lanes
label: Paragraph

text: under his control. Sri Lanka became a vassal
label: Paragraph

text: state. His son, Rajendra | (r. 1014-44),
label: Paragraph

text: with his eye on the lucrative sea trade with
label: Paragraph

text: China, sent his fleet to conquer Malaya and
label: Paragraph

text: Shrivijaya, leaving the Cholas the controlling
label: Paragraph

text: superpower of Southeast Asia. The Cholas,
label: Paragraph

text: who called their sphere of influence the
label: Paragraph

text: Cholamandalam, the “Chola Vision-World"
label: Title

text: possessed the largest naval force India was to
label: Paragraph

text: have until modern times.
label: Paragraph

text: The Cholas chose the image of Shiva
label: Paragraph

text: Nataraj, who orders the movement of the
label: Paragraph

text: world with his dance, as their representative
label: Paragraph

text: royal deity. The temple itself was an
label: Paragraph

text: extension of the royal ordering of the world.
label: Paragraph

text: The word “temple” in Tamil is Kovil (kov
label: Paragraph

text: meaning “god-king,” # meaning “home");
label: Paragraph

text: it connotes both temple and palace and
label: Paragraph

text: thereby serves a range of functions, from the
label: Paragraph

text: religious to the judicial. For every economic
label: Paragraph

text: unit (like a village or a district), the Cholas
label: Paragraph

text: built a temple. While the temple's basic
label: Paragraph

text: endowments of agricultural land or villages
label: Title

text: were made by the king, the actual land
label: Paragraph

text: for the building was donated by the local
label: Paragraph

text: elite. Donations for building materials were
label: Paragraph

text: made by the merchants. Provisions such
label: Paragraph

text: as images, lamps, and oil were obtained
label: Paragraph

text: 11.73 A typical Chola temple town
label: Caption

text: through individual donations. Temples were
label: Paragraph

text: also run like a corporation. They had the
label: Paragraph

text: authority to make land grants and to invest
label: Title

text: their assets as they considered fit. They even
label: Paragraph

text: became banks, with major contributions and
label: Paragraph

text: investments inscribed on the walls of the
label: Caption

text: temple for all to view. In this way, the Chola
label: Paragraph

text: temples became the financial centers of the
label: Paragraph

text: community. Village assemblies were held
label: Paragraph

text: in them, and they were often responsible
label: Paragraph

text: for the education of upper-caste boys.
label: Paragraph

text: The temple’s administration, however, was
label: Paragraph

text: controlled by the king, and Brahmins were
label: Paragraph

text: the only ones allowed to conduct rituals.
label: Paragraph

text: Temples maintained a huge permanent staff
label: Paragraph

text: that included musicians, artists, artisans,
label: Paragraph

text: and dancers (including devadasis, women
label: Paragraph

text: dancers dedicated to the temple for life.) The
label: Paragraph

text: community's cultural institutions, in other
label: Paragraph

text: words, were also the preserve of the temple.
label: Paragraph

text: Dakshinameru (Rajarajeshwara Temple)
label: Caption

text: While regional temples served the more
label: Paragraph

text: quotidian purposes of governance, Rajaraja I's
label: Paragraph

text: royal ternple at Thanjavur, the Chola
label: Caption

text: capital, embodied a vision of kingship at
label: Paragraph

text: the scale of an empire. Rajaraja | projected
label: Paragraph

text: himself as a cakravartin, a king destined
label: Paragraph

text: to bring order to the world, a demigod in
label: Paragraph

text: the grace of Shiva Nataraj. He called his
label: Paragraph

text: temple Dakshinameru, the “Mt. Meru of
label: Paragraph

text: the South,” distinguishing his world from
label: Paragraph

text: that of the north. (Dakshinameru is now
label: Paragraph

text: generally known as the Rajarajeshwara or the
label: Paragraph

text: Brinadeshwara Temple). Major cerernonies
label: Caption

text: of royal initiation and legitimation were
label: Paragraph

text: held there, linking deity and king. The daily
label: Paragraph

text: rituals of the deities mirrored those of the
label: Paragraph

text: king, including his morning round of the
label: Paragraph

text: sacred enclosure and his sunset retreat to
label: Title

text: his bedroom. Dakshinameru maintained a
label: Paragraph

text: staff of six hundred devadasis, treasurers,
label: Paragraph

text: accountants, record-keepers, watchmen,
label: Title

text: musicians, readers of texts, and craftsmen of
label: Paragraph

text: every sort—in addition to scores of Brahmin
label: Paragraph

text: priests. To this day it remains the largest
label: Paragraph

text: temple in India.
label: Paragraph

text: Situated next to a river that was channeled
label: Paragraph

text: to form a moat symbolic of the cosmic ocean,
label: Paragraph

text: its outer enclosure was built like a fortress.
label: Paragraph

text: lt was entered on axis through a five-story
label: Paragraph

text: gopuram. A second, three-story freestanding
label: Caption

text: gopuram, set on a long, low platform, gave
label: Paragraph

text: access to the main quadrangle. The towering,
label: Paragraph

text: sixteen-story mass of the main shikhara
label: Caption

text: dominates the view, with pilasters, piers,
label: Paragraph

text: and attached columns articulating the entire
label: Paragraph

text: surface. In the interior, the circumambulation
label: Paragraph

text: route that goes around the massive lingam RO en,
label: Paragraph

text: in the garbha-griha is repeated on the on
label: Paragraph

text: upper story, which is inhabitable. This is a -
label: Paragraph

text: rarity in Hindu temples, an allusion to the : ~~
label: Paragraph

text: idea that Rajarajeshwara offered access _.
label: Paragraph

text: to the realm of the gods. The ground story : Y
label: Caption

text: (which symbolically corresponds to the
label: Paragraph

text: earthly realm) is articulated as two stories,
label: Paragraph

text: indicating more than one celestial dimension 7 Palace
label: Paragraph

text: of the royal temple. The main temple is
label: Paragraph

text: preceded by two cojoined, dimly lit hypostyle
label: Paragraph

text: halls: the antaraia, or vestibule, where the _ Moat."
label: Paragraph

text: priest would be, and the mandapa. In the of
label: Paragraph

text: mandapa, the columns are exquisitely and
label: Paragraph

text: intricately carved—showing the potential
label: Paragraph

text: for refinement—whereas in the antarala,
label: Paragraph

text: the columns are left as massive and plain
label: Paragraph

text: monoliths: the first manifestation of form
label: Title

text: emerging out of the formless.

text: POLONNARUWA
label: Title

text: By the end of the 12th century, the northern
label: Paragraph

text: part of Sri Lanka, with its elaborate system of
label: Paragraph

text: artificial lakes, dams, and canals, constituted
label: Paragraph

text: one of the most sophisticated hydro-
label: Paragraph

text: engineering landscapes in the world. Along
label: Paragraph

text: with exporting pearls and gems, Sri Lanka
label: Paragraph

text: had become one of the leading maritime
label: Paragraph

text: ports in South Asia. Following a period of
label: Paragraph

text: conflict with empires frorn India, eager to
label: Paragraph

text: wrest control of its markets, the old capital,
label: Paragraph

text: Anurachapura, was replaced by a new one,
label: Paragraph

text: Polonnaruma, where the king built his palace
label: Paragraph

text: compound directly to the west of a massive
label: Paragraph

text: artificial lake. An extensive pleasure garden
label: Paragraph

text: and audience hall were placed directly on top
label: Paragraph

text: of the 2-kilometer long dyke that held back
label: Paragraph

text: the water, an indication of the ruler’s supreme
label: Paragraph

text: confidence in the engineered landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the numerous shrines, pools, and
label: Paragraph

text: gardens, Vatadage (which means “circular
label: Paragraph

text: relic house") was one of the most important
label: Paragraph

text: constructions. At its core is a conventional
label: Paragraph

text: stupa, about 5 meters high and painted
label: Caption

text: white. It is located, however, within a walled
label: Paragraph

text: cylindrical chamber of brick, the whole
label: Paragraph

text: resting on a high, finely decorated stone
label: Paragraph

text: plinth, with access via four cardinally oriented
label: Paragraph

text: stairs. The circular wall, which was probably
label: Paragraph

text: stuccoed and painted, is ornamented on the
label: Paragraph

text: outside by an elegant blind, columnar stone
label: Caption

text: screen. This screen, along with a ring of tall
label: Paragraph

text: stone columns on the inside of the chamber,
label: Caption

text: has led to conjecture that the whole structure
label: Paragraph

text: was once roofed over. It is an unusual design
label: Paragraph

text: found almost exclusively in Sri Lanka. One
label: Paragraph

text: can imagine the building as a stupa that
label: Paragraph

text: has been encased in elements symbolic of a
label: Paragraph

text: palace.
label: Paragraph

text: SONG DYNASTY CHINA
label: Title

text: The Song dynasty (960-1279) reunited most
label: Paragraph

text: of China proper. The Song period divides into
label: Paragraph

text: two phases: Northern Song (960-1127), and
label: Paragraph

text: Southern Song (1127-1279). The division
label: Paragraph

text: was caused by the forced abandonment
label: Paragraph

text: of north China in 1127 by the Song court,
label: Paragraph

text: which could not push back Jin invaders. As
label: Paragraph

text: to Chang’an, the Uyghurs helped recapture
label: Paragraph

text: the fabled capital from rebels, but they
label: Paragraph

text: refused to leave until the emperor paid them
label: Paragraph

text: an enormous sum of tribute in silk. The
label: Paragraph

text: abandonment of northern China was caused
label: Paragraph

text: in part to floods in 858 along the Grand Canal
label: Paragraph

text: that inundated vast tracts of land and terrain
label: Paragraph

text: of the North China Plain; in 873 a disastrous
label: Paragraph

text: harvest shook the foundations of the empire
label: Title

text: and made it all the more dependent on
label: Paragraph

text: imported rice from Southeast Asia. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: the Northern Song capital was moved to
label: Paragraph

text: Dongjing (now Kaifeng); the southern capital
label: Paragraph

text: was established at Lin’an (now Hangzhou).
label: Paragraph

text: Though much weakened, the economy
label: Paragraph

text: was still powerful, and the use of a new
label: Paragraph

text: type of early-ripening rice from Southeast
label: Paragraph

text: and South Asia created abundant food
label: Paragraph

text: surpluses. Confucianism was reinforced, and
label: Paragraph

text: foreign relations were established with India,
label: Paragraph

text: Indonesia, and Fatimid Egypt.
label: Paragraph

text: ra

label: Paragraph

text: perhaps the largest. Unlike the cities of the
label: Paragraph

text: Tang, Song dynasty cities were more than
label: Paragraph

text: just administrative centers; they also served
label: Paragraph

text: as a locus of trade, industry, and maritime
label: Paragraph

text: commerce. Dongjing lay at the intersection

text: The architecture of the fa, or pagoda,

text: developed rapidly under the Song. Pagodas

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: as stone and brick buildings that could
label: Paragraph

text: more easily survive lightning strikes. Though
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist pagoda towers continued to be
label: Paragraph

text: built—often in the countryside instead
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: iron. It is an octagonal brick structure about
label: Paragraph

text: 57 meters high built around a solid core,
label: Paragraph

text: with a spiral staircase circulating between
label: Paragraph

text: the core and outer shell. The use of brick

label: Paragraph

text: LIAO DYNASTY

text: A tribal clan known as the Khitan created the
label: Paragraph

text: Liao dynasty (947-1125), which stretched
label: Paragraph

text: from Korea and Mongolia in the north to
label: Title

text: Beijing in the south. The Liao was the first of
label: Paragraph

text: China’s several so-called foreign dynasties. In
label: Paragraph

text: response to the dual nature of the area—with
label: Paragraph

text: nomads to the north and settled Chinese
label: Title

text: populations in the south—the Liao created a
label: Paragraph

text: double government, building a series of cities
label: Title

text: through which this duality was expressed. Its
label: Paragraph

text: capital, Shangjing (“Supreme Capital”), near
label: Paragraph

text: the modern city of Lingdong, was located at
label: Paragraph

text: the headwaters of the Shira Muren River, a
label: Paragraph

text: site hallowed by the Khitan people. It served
label: Paragraph

text: as the administrative center of the empire
label: Paragraph

text: and included a commercial district, called the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese city, made of permanent materials;
label: Paragraph

text: the ruling Liao, however, continued to live
label: Paragraph

text: in their traditional yurts in their own part of
label: Paragraph

text: the town. Eventually, more than thirty walled
label: Paragraph

text: cities were built, including four subsidiary
label: Paragraph

text: capitals for the four regions of the empire,
label: Paragraph

text: serving as centers of commerce; the southern
label: Paragraph

text: capital was a predecessor of Beijing. The
label: Paragraph

text: cities were square (or almost square), with
label: Paragraph

text: a separated walled palace city within the
label: Paragraph

text: city adjacent to the north wall. The Liao
label: Paragraph

text: embraced Buddhism with such vigor that it is
label: Paragraph

text: estimated that 10 percent of the population
label: Paragraph

text: were monks and nuns. Nonetheless, most
label: Paragraph

text: Khitan still adhered in one way or another
label: Paragraph

text: to the traditional animistic religion in which
label: Paragraph

text: the sun was worshipped. Thus, the Khitan
label: Paragraph

text: emperor faced the east, where the sun rises,
label: Paragraph

text: rather than the south, as Chinese emperors
label: Paragraph

text: did.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the Khitan accommodated
label: Title

text: themselves to the Song dynasty architectural
label: Paragraph

text: and urban traditions—as they had no such
label: Paragraph

text: traditions themselves—they transformed
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese building conventions to develop their

text: own style. The buildings they commissioned

text: were made by Chinese and Korean
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmen. Nonetheless, their buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: in many respects different, if not superior, to
label: Paragraph

text: those of the Song. Whereas the Song aspired
label: Paragraph

text: to a clarity of structure, the Liao reveled
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Pagoda, built in 1056. It is often referred to

label: Paragraph

text: A skyscraper of sorts in its day, the Mu-ta
label: Paragraph

text: was one of the most advanced structural
label: Paragraph

text: achievements of its tire. Like the Guanyin-ge
label: Paragraph

text: of Dulesi Monastery, each story of the Mu-ta
label: Paragraph

text: is a separate structural entity (none of the
label: Paragraph

text: pillars rises more than a story) tied together
label: Paragraph

text: by fifty-four different types of bracket sets.
label: Paragraph

text: On the exterior, each story of the Mu-ta is
label: Paragraph

text: represented by eaves, held up by a neat
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement of structural dou-gong. In
label: Paragraph

text: the interior, however, the structure is held
label: Paragraph

text: together by a complex mesh of posts and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: age. Trade in furs, hides, wax, honey, wheat,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and Rus converted in the 10th century to the

label: Title

text: as reported back to Russia by emissaries sent

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Novgorod prince Vladimir Yaroslavovich. The

text: set in a tight cluster around a central one.
label: Paragraph

text: The churches were bulky with small windows,
label: Paragraph

text: making the interior all the more mysterious.
label: Paragraph

text: A narthex helped negotiate the transition

text: Sanahin Complex
label: Title

text: A well-preserved monastic compound, Sanahin
label: Paragraph

text: (also known as St. Amenaprkitch), 2 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: southeast of the town of Alaverdi, is an example
label: Paragraph

text: of an Armenian monastic institution. Unlike
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine aggregates, in which buildings tend to
label: Paragraph

text: fuse into each other, the complexes in Armenia
label: Paragraph

text: maintained volumetric and functional clarity. The
label: Paragraph

text: churches (begun 934 CE) have between them
label: Paragraph

text: a barrel-vaulted corridor, or academia, where
label: Paragraph

text: pupils could sit on stone benches while the
label: Paragraph

text: teacher walked up and down the space, as was
label: Paragraph

text: the custom in peripatetic schools. Appended to
label: Paragraph

text: the front of both churches are gavits, dating from
label: Caption

text: about 1210, which came to be used around that
label: Paragraph

text: time. In these vaulted spaces, novices could assist
label: Paragraph

text: during Mass. Their principal utilization, however,
label: Paragraph

text: was as meeting halls; and laws and ordinances
label: Paragraph

text: were carved on the internal walls. They also
label: Paragraph

text: served as places to bury nobility.
label: Paragraph

text: The Church of the Holy Cross on the island
label: Caption

text: of Aght’amar (consecrated 921 CE), originally
label: Paragraph

text: unencumbered by ancillary buildings, makes its
label: Paragraph

text: impression through symmetry and equilibrium.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike Byzantine churches, which were composite
label: Paragraph

text: in nature, Armenian churches aimed to maintain
label: Paragraph

text: a tight bond between interior and exterior. The
label: Paragraph

text: sacristy and the vestry, instead of being separate
label: Paragraph

text: spaces to the right and left of the altar, are
label: Paragraph

text: therefore embedded in the mass of the wall.
label: Paragraph

text: The interior, however, was never just a reflection
label: Paragraph

text: of outer form. The church, as is also typical of
label: Paragraph

text: Armenian architecture, presents the buildings
label: Paragraph

text: in simple elernental forms: cubes, cylinders,
label: Paragraph

text: cones, and pyramids. The dome is conical on the
label: Paragraph

text: outside but hemispherical within. Walls are made
label: Paragraph

text: of an aggregate of pebbles and mortar much like
label: Paragraph

text: concrete, and dressed with blocks of closely fitting
label: Paragraph

text: pink sandstone. The plan, with its four apses,
label: Paragraph

text: is known as a tetraconch, even though the east
label: Paragraph

text: and west exedrae are deeper than those on the
label: Paragraph

text: north and south. The exterior is decorated with
label: Caption

text: bands of bas-relief sculpture depicting biblical
label: Caption

text: scenes. The lighting on the interior is indirect, and
label: Paragraph

text: the windows are small. The main light source is
label: Paragraph

text: around the drum, above which the dome seems
label: Paragraph

text: to float, as if it were on a ring of light. The wide
label: Paragraph

text: side apses swell the space outward at ground
label: Paragraph

text: level, with small concavities at the corners,
label: Paragraph

text: between the piers, adding further illumination.
label: Caption

text: The entire interior was originally painted with
label: Paragraph

text: religious scenes.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The word cathedral derives from a Greek

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: that practice was eventually abandoned.

label: Paragraph

text: architecture dates from around 800 CE. A
label: Paragraph

text: cathedral, in that etymological sense, is thus
label: Paragraph

text: an elaborate framing device for a bishop’s
label: Paragraph

text: chair. Some ancient chairs still exist, such
label: Paragraph

text: preserved in the Vatican Museums.

text: A warrior people from the northern French
label: Title

text: coast, the Normans overran England and
label: Paragraph

text: southern Italy and settled in Scotland, Wales,
label: Paragraph

text: the Byzantine Empire, and (after the First
label: Paragraph

text: Crusade) the Levant. Norman power was
label: Paragraph

text: extended by strategic marriage alliances. In
label: Paragraph

text: a series of waves, the Normans conquered
label: Paragraph

text: parts of southern Italy and Sicily (1061), and
label: Paragraph

text: then England, following the Battle of Hastings
label: Paragraph

text: (1066). The new rulers transformed the entire
label: Paragraph

text: religious, mercantile, and political geography
label: Title

text: of England. But their holdings were far-
label: Paragraph

text: flung, from England and northern France
label: Title

text: to southern Italy and Sicily; the Normans
label: Title

text: consequently became a clearinghouse of
label: Paragraph

text: different stylistic and cultural trends that
label: Paragraph

text: bridged many classic divides.

text: 11.111 Norman England
label: Caption

text: Most importantly they transformed the
label: Paragraph

text: village- and agrarian-based geography of
label: Paragraph

text: the Saxons into one based on towns in the
label: Paragraph

text: middle of large farming districts or boroughs,
label: Paragraph

text: with castles at their centers to serve as the
label: Paragraph

text: basic instrument of government. Unlike in
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, where castles were generally on
label: Paragraph

text: defensible ridges or mountains, in England,
label: Paragraph

text: where mountains are not a prominent
label: Paragraph

text: geographical feature, they were built at the
label: Paragraph

text: core of the urban layout. Town markets
label: Paragraph

text: were created and an aristocracy took shape,
label: Paragraph

text: promoting an international luxury trade in
label: Paragraph

text: commodities such as fine cloth and wine. It
label: Paragraph

text: has been estimated that about four to five
label: Paragraph

text: hundred new towns were laid out in this
label: Paragraph

text: manner, creating a pattern of urban centers
label: Paragraph

text: that was to survive virtually unchanged until
label: Paragraph

text: the Industrial Revolution and, in parts of
label: Paragraph

text: England, survives even today.
label: Paragraph

text: The Normans introduced not only a
label: Paragraph

text: strong mercantile society but also a change
label: Title

text: in the notion of kingship. Roger the Great,
label: Paragraph

text: in the chronicles of the time, is represented
label: Paragraph

text: as the royal deputy of Christ. The small
label: Paragraph

text: Saxon churches that dotted the English
label: Title

text: landscape could no longer measure up to
label: Paragraph

text: such grand claims. Most were torn down,
label: Paragraph

text: and in their stead the Normans designed a
label: Paragraph

text: religious landscape around powerful state-
label: Paragraph

text: supported bishoprics, each of which needed a
label: Paragraph

text: sumptuous cathedral. Architects and masons
label: Caption

text: were brought in from the continent, as were
label: Paragraph

text: successive waves of continental monks—
label: Title

text: Benedictines, Augustinians, Cistercians,
label: Title

text: Cluniacs, and Carthusians—who were just as
label: Paragraph

text: important from an economic point of view as
label: Paragraph

text: rom a religious one, as their well-organized
label: Paragraph

text: farms produced surpluses for the markets.
label: Paragraph

text: The Cistercians, for example, were associated
label: Paragraph

text: with irrigation and large-scale sheep farming.
label: Paragraph

text: By the end of the 12th century, six hundred
label: Paragraph

text: new monastic institutions of varying practices
label: Title

text: ad been set up.
label: Paragraph

text: Durham Cathedral
label: Title

text: Durham Cathedral is important for its
label: Paragraph

text: architectural features, specifically its rib
label: Paragraph

text: vaulting (the first of its kind in England),
label: Paragraph

text: its pointed arches, and its high standard of
label: Paragraph

text: masonry. Durham shows the specific Anglo-
label: Paragraph

text: Norman style as a blend of the English
label: Paragraph

text: decorative tradition with Norman architectural
label: Title

text: skills, and it marks the transition from a more
label: Paragraph

text: monumental and simple scheme, as is seen
label: Paragraph

text: in Gloucester Cathedral (begun 1089). The
label: Paragraph

text: choir and the nave of the three-aisled church
label: Caption

text: were built between 1093 and 1133, but the
label: Paragraph

text: west towers were not completed until 1220.
label: Paragraph

text: In comparison with the nave of Gloucester,
label: Paragraph

text: which also has heavy round columns carrying
label: Paragraph

text: the arcades, Durham, in the manner of
label: Caption

text: Speyer, introduces the idea of attached half-
label: Paragraph

text: columns that guide the eye to the ceiling.
label: Paragraph

text: The loftiness of these churches had always
label: Paragraph

text: been a feature of Romanesque architecture;
label: Paragraph

text: what is novel here is the structural openness
label: Paragraph

text: of the walls. A basic principle of Norman
label: Paragraph

text: building was the reduction of solid walls to
label: Paragraph

text: a thick but open skeleton of arches. The
label: Paragraph

text: arches were not just interruptions in the wall;
label: Paragraph

text: they were defined in a regularized way, with
label: Paragraph

text: surrounds framed by attached half-columns
label: Caption

text: and horizontal string courses. The openings
label: Paragraph

text: do not deny the weight and mass of the wall,
label: Paragraph

text: as would become the tendency later, but
label: Paragraph

text: rather, illuminated fromm behind, they seem
label: Paragraph

text: to release their load gradually as the wall
label: Paragraph

text: ascends.
label: Paragraph

text: The columns are decorated with zigzag
label: Paragraph

text: and chevron motifs and make extensive use
label: Paragraph

text: of color, specifically black and red, which was
label: Paragraph

text: an influence from Islamic architecture that
label: Paragraph

text: came to the country through the Crusades
label: Paragraph

text: and the Norman-Arab connections in Sicily
label: Title

text: and northern Africa. Geometric patterns and
label: Paragraph

text: other features of the inner decoration can
label: Paragraph

text: later be found in other cathedrals in northern
label: Paragraph

text: England, suggesting that the same masons
label: Paragraph

text: moved on to work in Scotland.
label: Paragraph

text: ia
label: Title

text: Durham Cathedral is considered a forerunner
label: Paragraph

text: of what is now called the Gothic style, largely
label: Paragraph

text: because of the fusion of the ribbed vault
label: Paragraph

text: and the pointed arch, which are considered
label: Paragraph

text: essentially Gothic features. The building
label: Paragraph

text: does not have buttresses and so appears
label: Paragraph

text: from the outside quite boxy, unlike later
label: Paragraph

text: Norman cathedrals such as Canterbury
label: Title

text: Cathedral, where buttresses contribute to
label: Paragraph

text: a vertical articulation. The so-called Galilee
label: Paragraph

text: Chapel (1153-95) in front of the west
label: Caption

text: facade is unique, with its five parallel halls
label: Paragraph

text: and longitudinal arcaded walls without any
label: Paragraph

text: subdivision into bays. This layout resembles
label: Paragraph

text: one encountered in Islamic mosques and
label: Paragraph

text: once again shows the cross-fertilization of
label: Paragraph

text: ideas introduced from the Mediterranean.

text: Canterbury Cathedral
label: Title

text: Among the new bishoprics, Canterbury was
label: Paragraph

text: the most important, as its bishop served as
label: Paragraph

text: vice-regent of the king. When Canterbury
label: Paragraph

text: Cathedral was destroyed by an accidental fire
label: Paragraph

text: in 1067, one year after William the Conqueror
label: Paragraph

text: landed on the south coast of England,
label: Paragraph

text: Lanfranc, the first Norman archbishop of
label: Paragraph

text: Canterbury, initiated a rebuilding that was
label: Paragraph

text: based on the new cathedral of St. Etienne
label: Caption

text: in France. When a fire destroyed the choir
label: Paragraph

text: in 1174, the architects, William of Sens and
label: Paragraph

text: William the Englishman, erected a new choir
label: Paragraph

text: and a presbytery that doubled the length
label: Paragraph

text: of the church. The newer part existed on a
label: Paragraph

text: higher elevation, with the stairs serving to
label: Paragraph

text: separate the more sacred areas to the east.
label: Paragraph

text: The project shows how England adopted
label: Paragraph

text: French construction techniques—specifically
label: Title

text: the flying buttress and the six-partite vault—
label: Title

text: while the nave itself remained from the time
label: Paragraph

text: of Lanfranc. (The nave was, however, rebuilt
label: Paragraph

text: in the late 14th century.) The church houses,
label: Paragraph

text: among other sacred objects, the relics of St.
label: Paragraph

text: Thomas, which were originally placed at the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the round chapel at the eastern end
label: Caption

text: of the building. The cloister and monastic
label: Paragraph

text: buildings are placed on the north—instead
label: Paragraph

text: of, as is more frequently the case, on the
label: Paragraph

text: south of the church. Compared to Durham
label: Caption

text: Cathedral, which has no buttresses, giving
label: Paragraph

text: it a resolute boxy form, the wall surface at
label: Paragraph

text: Canterbury has more vertical articulation.
label: Paragraph

text: Cefalii Cathedral
label: Title

text: When Roger d’Hauteville conquered Sicily
label: Title

text: in 1060, he found a culture that had been
label: Paragraph

text: under Arab influence since the late 9th
label: Paragraph

text: century. The Normans not only availed
label: Paragraph

text: themselves of the practical and technological
label: Paragraph

text: innovations of the Muslims but also integrated
label: Paragraph

text: Muslims into their administration and army.
label: Paragraph

text: Soon Apulia, Capua, Sicily, and finally parts
label: Paragraph

text: of northern Africa carne under Norman
label: Title

text: domination. As a consequence, the Normans
label: Paragraph

text: controlled the trade route to the Bosporus.
label: Paragraph

text: 11.121 Aerial view: Cefalii Cathedral, Sicily, Italy

text: 11.119 Site Plan: Santa Maria Nuova at Monreale, Sicily, Italy |
label: Caption

text: The first major Norman church in Sicily was
label: Paragraph

text: built at Cefalu (begun 1131); it followed a
label: Paragraph

text: typical early Norman footprint, with a nave
label: Caption

text: with side aisles, a wooden ceiling, and a
label: Paragraph

text: massive transept in the east. It is a heavy and
label: Paragraph

text: somber building that contrasts sharply with
label: Paragraph

text: Santa Maria Nuova at Monreale (from the
label: Caption

text: Latin mons regalis, “royal mountain"), south
label: Paragraph

text: of Palermo on the slopes of Monte Caputo,
label: Paragraph

text: that was started only a hundred years after
label: Paragraph

text: CefalU. Islamic influences are apparent
label: Paragraph

text: in the outside decoration of the apse,
label: Caption

text: with its intertwined arches and terra-cotta
label: Paragraph

text: ornamentation. The Great Mosque of Cordoba
label: Caption

text: (10th century) and the Bab Mardum Mosque
label: Caption

text: in Toledo (around 1000 Ce) show similar
label: Paragraph

text: interlocking arches. The cathedral also shows
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine influences, such as the exquisite
label: Paragraph

text: mosaics that cover the interior walls of the
label: Paragraph

text: cathedral and are second in quality only to
label: Paragraph

text: those in the Hagia Sofia in Istanbul.
label: Paragraph

text: This stylistic synthesis is also evident in
label: Paragraph

text: the areas of western Italy that the Normans
label: Paragraph

text: controlled. Amalfi became a seafaring
label: Paragraph

text: republic, rivaling Genoa, Venice, and Pisa,
label: Paragraph

text: from the 9th to the 11th centuries. At
label: Paragraph

text: its height it had trade representatives in
label: Paragraph

text: Mahdiya, Tunisia; Kairuan (Cairo); Alexandria;
label: Paragraph

text: Beirut; Jerusalern; Antioch, Syria; and
label: Paragraph

text: Constantinople. At the Cathedral of Amalfi, the
label: Caption

text: original Norman building underwent various
label: Paragraph

text: expansions, including the Cloister of Paradise,
label: Paragraph

text: which is clearly influenced by Islamic motifs.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: PILGRIMAGE CHURCHES
label: Title

text: The 11th and 12th centuries saw a growth
label: Paragraph

text: in the popularity of religious pilgrimages,
label: Paragraph

text: usually to sites where miracles were believed
label: Paragraph

text: to have occurred. Pilgrims sought out these
label: Paragraph

text: churches mainly for the relics they housed,
label: Paragraph

text: which were thought to emit a benevolent or
label: Paragraph

text: curative aura. Possessing relics—a finger,
label: Paragraph

text: a foot, or even a head of a saint—became
label: Paragraph

text: central to a particular church's identity, and
label: Paragraph

text: churches vied with each to collect as many
label: Paragraph

text: such relics as possible. Major ones were the
label: Paragraph

text: tomb of St. Peter in Rome, the tomb of St.
label: Caption

text: James at Santiago de Compostela, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem.
label: Caption

text: Most pilgrims traveled of their own volition,
label: Paragraph

text: but some pilgrimages were acts of penance
label: Paragraph

text: imposed for exceptional misdeeds. The trips,
label: Paragraph

text: exhausting and often dangerous, became
label: Paragraph

text: the source of stories and ballads, such
label: Paragraph

text: as Geoffrey Chaucer's Canterbury Tales.
label: Paragraph

text: Other accounts give us some of the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: descriptions of church architecture in the
label: Title

text: West.
label: Paragraph

text: The most venerated pilgrimage site
label: Title

text: was the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem. The
label: Paragraph

text: original church, constructed by Constantine,
label: Caption

text: was consecrated in 335 CE to protect a
label: Paragraph

text: tomb thought to have been that of Christ.
label: Paragraph

text: Constantine’s church was torn down by
label: Paragraph

text: the Persians. The Crusaders then began a
label: Paragraph

text: church that, with changes and additions, is
label: Paragraph

text: the basis for the church as it stands today.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: TUSCANY
label: Title

text: Charlemagne traveled to Italy only four times,
label: Paragraph

text: each trip lasting less than a year, setting
label: Paragraph

text: a precedent of absentee monarchism that
label: Paragraph

text: persisted for centuries. This allowed north
label: Paragraph

text: Italian states, seen by the kings as the
label: Paragraph

text: southern fringe of their empire, to survive
label: Paragraph

text: as neither independent nor fully integrated
label: Paragraph

text: into the empire. Nevertheless, their cities
label: Paragraph

text: were bustling places. Lucca was growing
label: Paragraph

text: so fast that houses were being built along
label: Paragraph

text: the approach roads; soon a good portion
label: Paragraph

text: of the population lived outside the walls in
label: Paragraph

text: so-called bourgs. And between the cities,
label: Paragraph

text: villages—called variously vici, foci, casatia,
label: Paragraph

text: or villae—came to be established. As a
label: Paragraph

text: result, monasteries—with some exceptions—
label: Paragraph

text: were unable to develop the hold on the
label: Paragraph

text: local population that they had in northern
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. To be sure, the cities did not look
label: Paragraph

text: very impressive. Roman civic buildings
label: Caption

text: and ternples had been left to rot, or they
label: Paragraph

text: were used as quarries. Churches built after
label: Paragraph

text: 600 CE were small. Only a limited amount
label: Paragraph

text: of farming occurred within city walls. The
label: Paragraph

text: forums had lost their civic value and become
label: Paragraph

text: marketplaces. In 1006, a series of disastrous
label: Paragraph

text: famines and plagues killed thousands of
label: Paragraph

text: people. The weak centralized power of the
label: Paragraph

text: emperors combined with the rising status
label: Paragraph

text: of the cities; consequently, more and more
label: Paragraph

text: 11.126 Modena Cathedral, Italy
label: Caption

text: power was ceded by the emperors to the city
label: Paragraph

text: bishops in order to maintain control.
label: Paragraph

text: The bishops of Modena, Reggio,
label: Caption

text: Bergamo, Cremona, and other places were
label: Paragraph

text: given unprecedented powers. In 904 CE, the
label: Paragraph

text: bishop of Bergamo, for example, was granted
label: Paragraph

text: the right to build city walls and to rebuild
label: Title

text: them with the help of the citizens. The result
label: Paragraph

text: of this transfer of authority was dangerous to
label: Paragraph

text: the imperial state, as bishops were not able to
label: Paragraph

text: maintain their hegemony over urban society.
label: Paragraph

text: Cities now began to vie with each other,
label: Paragraph

text: however, in the construction of cathedrals
label: Paragraph

text: and baptisteries that showed off the wealth
label: Paragraph

text: of the city and the status of the church. The
label: Paragraph

text: principal churches during this time were in
label: Paragraph

text: Venice (begun 832 CE), Pisa (begun 1063),
label: Paragraph

text: Modena (begun 1099), Cremona (begun
label: Paragraph

text: 1118), Verona (begun 1139), and Siena
label: Paragraph

text: (begun 1196).
label: Paragraph

text: The architect of the Modena Cathedral was
label: Paragraph

text: Lanfranco, called mirabilis artifex, mirificus
label: Paragraph

text: aedificator ("marvelous creator, wonderful
label: Paragraph

text: builder”), about whom, however, little is known
label: Paragraph

text: except that he came from Como, where a
label: Paragraph

text: school of builders had been established.
label: Paragraph

text: Compared to other Romanesque buildings
label: Paragraph

text: of the time, Modena Cathedral is lighter and
label: Paragraph

text: the lines stripped to their essentials. The
label: Paragraph

text: building was clad in white Istrian stone and
label: Paragraph

text: articulated by blind arcades. The central
label: Caption

text: division is emphasized by a rose window
label: Paragraph

text: and a baldachino-style central portal. The
label: Caption

text: rose window on the facade was added in the
label: Caption

text: 13th century. The work is ornamented with
label: Caption

text: sculptures by the stonernason Wiligelmo; it
label: Paragraph

text: depicts, among other things, Adam and Eve
label: Paragraph

text: working the land to gain redemption. The
label: Paragraph

text: portals also portray biblical and mythological
label: Paragraph

text: events, including monsters and centaurs that
label: Paragraph

text: warn not only of the diabolic threats awaiting
label: Paragraph

text: man outside the city of God but also the
label: Paragraph

text: threats that corne from outside the Christian
label: Title

text: world, a reminder that Sicily had already fallen,
label: Paragraph

text: first to Islamic troops, then to Arab colonizers.
label: Paragraph

text: The archbishop's palace and administrative
label: Title

text: center was connected to the cathedral by
label: Paragraph

text: means of a private passage. The building was
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned by Queen Matilda di Canossa
label: Caption

text: (1046-1115). One of the most powerful
label: Paragraph

text: women of the Middle Ages, she had a fortress
label: Paragraph

text: in the heart of the Emilian Apennines and was
label: Paragraph

text: a strong supporter of papal policy against the
label: Paragraph

text: emperors. Matilda ruled over Tuscany, which
label: Paragraph

text: extended from Siena and Pisa to Modena
label: Title

text: in the north. She commissioned, or had a
label: Paragraph

text: hand in the commissioning of, several other
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in the Po River valley, including the
label: Paragraph

text: Rotunda of San Lorenzo in Mantua (1083) and
label: Caption

text: the Benedictine abbey of San Benedetto in
label: Caption

text: Polirone (1077), as well as Cremona Cathedral
label: Paragraph

text: (1107-17) and Piacenza Cathedral (1122).

text: Cathedral of Pisa
label: Title

text: Construction on the Cathedral of Pisa began
label: Paragraph

text: in 1063 after the victory of the Pisan fleet
label: Paragraph

text: over the Saracens near Palermo. Pisa could
label: Paragraph

text: now atternpt to fulfill its ambition to becorne
label: Paragraph

text: the Venice of the western Mediterranean
label: Title

text: and to develop a greater visual presence.
label: Paragraph

text: The cathedral was consecrated in 1118,
label: Paragraph

text: but it was completed only after considerable
label: Paragraph

text: alterations in the 14th century. Stylistically it
label: Paragraph

text: is a variation of the Mediterranean basilica
label: Paragraph

text: plan, with influences from Armenia, Syria,
label: Paragraph

text: and Islamic architecture. The building
label: Paragraph

text: also had imperial Lombard overtones,
label: Paragraph

text: especially in its facade, with its four registers
label: Paragraph

text: of freestanding gallery work. The granite
label: Paragraph

text: columns in the nave were taken from Roman
label: Caption

text: temples on the isle of Elba; the capitals range
label: Paragraph

text: from imperial Roman to Byzantine temples.
label: Paragraph

text: The walls have marble paneling inspired
label: Caption

text: by Byzantine practice, and the shape and
label: Paragraph

text: manner of construction of the dome, rising on
label: Paragraph

text: the inside from very high and narrow pointed
label: Paragraph

text: arches, looks Islamic.
