label: Paragraph

text: that with the Viking threat now over, soldiers
label: Paragraph

text: roamed the landscape looking for “work.”
label: Paragraph

text: The Church sought to intervene in the
label: Paragraph

text: resultant conflicts by emphasizing the value
label: Paragraph

text: of peaceful activities as sanctioned by the
label: Paragraph

text: martyrs, whose spirits abided in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: relics. Thus, saintly relics became an integral
label: Paragraph

text: part of devotional practice, and the attendant
label: Paragraph

text: populism produced a whole new religious
label: Paragraph

text: architecture based around pilgrimages to
label: Title

text: visit relics. The wealth that these pilgrims
label: Paragraph

text: generated was enough to finance numerous
label: Paragraph

text: cathedrals whose prime purpose was to serve
label: Paragraph

text: as stations on the way to the Cathedral at
label: Paragraph

text: Santiago de Compostela, Spain, built over the
label: Caption

text: site where the remains of St. Jarnes were said
label: Paragraph

text: to have been found in the 9th century. These
label: Paragraph

text: churches include Vézelay, Le Puy, Arles,
label: Paragraph

text: and Saint-Gilles. In the northern countries,
label: Paragraph

text: the Hanseatic League was created as a
label: Paragraph

text: commercial and defensive confederation of
label: Title

text: merchant guilds and their market towns that
label: Paragraph

text: dominated trade along the coast of northern
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. It stretched along the Baltic Sea from
label: Paragraph

text: Novgorod to London, with its primary focus
label: Paragraph

text: being Ltlbeck and Hamburg, both of which
label: Paragraph

text: were to become important economic hubs in
label: Paragraph

text: the next centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: As a response to the new excess in
label: Paragraph

text: wealth and power, there arose a monastic
label: Paragraph

text: movement, the Cistercians, that aimed to
label: Paragraph

text: restore the principles of poverty. Cistercian
label: Paragraph

text: monks purposefully sought out unwanted
label: Title

text: areas and reinstated the principles of
label: Paragraph

text: work and devotion. Soon the Cistercians,
label: Paragraph

text: spreading all over Europe, became a political
label: Paragraph

text: force to be reckoned with by the emperors
label: Paragraph

text: and bishops. The Cistercians rejected
label: Paragraph

text: the airy Gothic spires, stained glass, and
label: Paragraph

text: sculptural elaborations for an architecture
label: Title

text: that was intentionally simple. For the first
label: Paragraph

text: time in history, we see an anti-architecture
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, the best surviving example
label: Paragraph

text: being the Abbey at Fontenay (1118), France.
label: Paragraph

text: (The Shinto Shrine, by way of comparison,
label: Paragraph

text: was designed as a building with an archaic
label: Paragraph

text: quality that was to be preserved through
label: Paragraph

text: its periodic rebuilding.) Fontenay Abbey
label: Paragraph

text: was meant to evoke simpler times and to
label: Paragraph

text: serve as an accusation against architectural
label: Paragraph

text: extravagance.
label: Paragraph

text: In Italy, during this period there are the
label: Paragraph

text: first stirrings of a political transformation
label: Title

text: that would have huge consequences as the
label: Paragraph

text: centuries progressed. The cities of Verona,
label: Paragraph

text: Padua, Vicenza, and the Republic of Venice
label: Title

text: created the Lombard League (1164) in
label: Paragraph

text: an atternpt to assert their independence
label: Paragraph

text: from imperial German control. Their efforts
label: Paragraph

text: succeeded to the extent that, in 1183,
label: Paragraph

text: the German Empire signed the Peace of
label: Paragraph

text: Constance with the Italians. The treaty
label: Paragraph

text: gave the cities local jurisdiction over their
label: Paragraph

text: territories and the freedom to elect their own
label: Title

text: councils and to enact their own legislation.
label: Paragraph

text: The cumulative result was that a new and
label: Paragraph

text: remarkable society emerged with a mix
label: Paragraph

text: of aristocrats and urban merchants. Most
label: Paragraph

text: important of all, a new designation arose
label: Paragraph

text: known as the popoio ("people"). For the first
label: Paragraph

text: time since the days of ancient Rome, Italy
label: Title

text: had a political class, which was to play an
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly large role, even conceptually,
label: Paragraph

text: in modern history. The architectural
label: Paragraph

text: consequences were immediate. Cities
label: Paragraph

text: built town halls, the first such structures in
label: Paragraph

text: modern history. They also built a new type
label: Paragraph

text: of public space called a piazza, while at the
label: Paragraph

text: same time competing to build large urban
label: Paragraph

text: cathedrals. The wealthy built increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: large private palaces. Some of the cities
label: Paragraph

text: became great military powers, particularly
label: Paragraph

text: Venice and Genoa, which built up vast naval
label: Paragraph

text: empires in the Mediterranean and Black
label: Title

text: Seas. Padua was one of these cities as well.
label: Paragraph

text: After a devastating fire in 1174, it rose to
label: Paragraph

text: particular prominence. An impressive town
label: Paragraph

text: hall, called Palazzo della Ragione (“Palace
label: Paragraph

text: of Justice”), was built at the center of town
label: Paragraph

text: with a huge assembly hall, some 81 meters
label: Paragraph

text: long and 27 meters wide. Vaulted in wood
label: Paragraph

text: like an upside-down ship's nave, it was at the
label: Paragraph

text: time the largest interior space in Europe, and
label: Paragraph

text: possibly in the world. Its long side faced the
label: Paragraph

text: town square and was lined by a two-tiered,
label: Paragraph

text: arched loggia. A university was also founded
label: Paragraph

text: (1222) in Padua, and it was to become
label: Paragraph

text: one of the leading academic institutions in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, especially in law. Town halls were
label: Paragraph

text: built in various cities across northern Italy:
label: Paragraph

text: Palazzo della Ragione in Bergamo (ca. 1190),
label: Caption

text: Broletto in Como (ca. 1215), Palazzo del
label: Caption

text: Popolo in Todi (ca. 1220), Palazzo Vecchio in
label: Caption

text: Florence (ca. 1300), and Palazzo dei Consoli
label: Paragraph

text: in Gubbio (ca. 1340). In Siena, an enormous
label: Paragraph

text: town hall, the Palazzo Pubblico (begun
label: Caption

text: 1297), was built in front of a magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: semicircular piazza. Siena is one of the best-
label: Paragraph

text: preserved Italian cities from this era, frozen in
label: Paragraph

text: time because of the Black Death that coursed
label: Paragraph

text: through Italy in the 14th century, killing off a
label: Paragraph

text: large proportion of its population.
label: Paragraph

text: If the northern Italians were slowly getting
label: Paragraph

text: out from under the feudal system, in Japan
label: Paragraph

text: feudalism was just getting started. The
label: Paragraph

text: Kamakura period (1185-1333) marks the
label: Paragraph

text: governance of the Karmakura shogunate,
label: Paragraph

text: whose first shogun, Minamoto no Yoritomo,
label: Paragraph

text: established its headquarters in Kamakura.
label: Paragraph

text: Lords required the loyal services of vassals,
label: Paragraph

text: 12.4 Town Hall, Padua, Italy
label: Caption

text: who were rewarded with fiefs of their own.
label: Paragraph

text: The fief holders exercised local military
label: Paragraph

text: rule. But their rule was not spread over
label: Paragraph

text: all of Japan: to the north, during the 12th
label: Title

text: century, the Northern Fujiwara, who ruled
label: Paragraph

text: over the Tohoku region, created a capital city,
label: Paragraph

text: Hiraizumi, to rival Kyoto to the south. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: its lack of high-quality rice-growing areas,
label: Paragraph

text: the Fujiwara derived their wealth from gold
label: Paragraph

text: mining and horse trading, and as middlemen
label: Paragraph

text: in the trade in luxury items from continental
label: Title

text: Asian states. The Northern Fujiwara also
label: Paragraph

text: developed an ambitious Buddhist temple-
label: Paragraph

text: building program on Mount Kanzan, not far
label: Caption

text: from Hiraizurni, which consisted of temples,
label: Paragraph

text: pagodas, repositories, and gardens. Known
label: Caption

text: as Chuson-ji, it featured a large pagoda at
label: Paragraph

text: the top of the mountain with small reliquaries
label: Caption

text: every 100 meters along Osho Kaido, one of
label: Paragraph

text: the main roads that connected the northern
label: Paragraph

text: provinces with Edo (modern-day Tokyo)
label: Title

text: to the south. Jodo-shu (“The Pure Land
label: Paragraph

text: School”). Though its teachings first became
label: Paragraph

text: prominent in China in the 5th century CE,
label: Paragraph

text: it was brought to Japan by a monk called
label: Paragraph

text: Honen, who gathered disciples from all walks
label: Paragraph

text: of life, developing a large following, notably
label: Paragraph

text: women, who had been excluded from serious
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist practice up to this point. One of
label: Paragraph

text: 12.5 Sanju-sangen-do, Kyoto, Japan
label: Caption

text: the buildings that has survived and that
label: Paragraph

text: best represents the Pure Land School is the
label: Paragraph

text: temple Sanju-sangen-do (“Hall of 33 Bays”)
label: Caption

text: in Kyoto (1164). A linear building a whole city
label: Paragraph

text: block long, its numerous doors could open
label: Paragraph

text: onto a large courtyard to allow devotees to
label: Paragraph

text: admire the thousand life-size statues of the
label: Paragraph

text: deity Kannon that stand on both the right and
label: Paragraph

text: left sides of the main statue, a bodhisattva of
label: Caption

text: compassion. The emergence in Buddhism of
label: Paragraph

text: a feminine deity related to compassion and
label: Paragraph

text: motherhood also has many parallels with the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence in Europe of the cult of the Virgin
label: Paragraph

text: Mary.
label: Paragraph

text: It was in this extraordinary context that
label: Paragraph

text: Asia saw perhaps the most remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: event of all, the invasion of the Mongolians.
label: Paragraph

text: In the previous century, it was the Turks
label: Paragraph

text: who had mastered Central Asia; now it
label: Paragraph

text: was their comparatively poor cousins of
label: Paragraph

text: the steppe to the east. In 1220, the unified
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolian army crossed the Syr Darya
label: Title

text: River, beginning their invasion of Central
label: Paragraph

text: Asia. The Mongolians defeated the Song
label: Paragraph

text: dynasty in 1279, allowing Kublai Khan to
label: Paragraph

text: establish his own Yuan dynasty. By 1280,
label: Paragraph

text: the Mongolians had created the largest
label: Paragraph

text: empire ever seen in history. Masters of
label: Paragraph

text: rapid equestrian attacks, the Mongolians
label: Title

text: were at first eager to confiscate goods
label: Paragraph

text: and haul them, along with thousands of
label: Paragraph

text: captive artisans, back to their camps in
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolia. But because the history of their
label: Paragraph

text: invasion was almost completely written
label: Title

text: by the conquered—there are no surviving
label: Paragraph

text: accounts from a Mongolian perspective—we
label: Paragraph

text: have to take a more balanced view. The
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolians were consummate traders and
label: Paragraph

text: basically continued what the Seljuks and
label: Paragraph

text: Turks had already begun. They also put
label: Paragraph

text: their unique stamp on the cross-continental
label: Paragraph

text: trade, not only developing Sarnarkand
label: Paragraph

text: but also purposely demoting the southern
label: Paragraph

text: route. The heady days of the Khmer and
label: Paragraph

text: Pagan were over, and indeed the entire
label: Paragraph

text: region went into steep decline. Angkor Wat
label: Paragraph

text: was soon abandoned and given over to the
label: Paragraph

text: forest, to be rediscovered only at the end
label: Paragraph

text: of the 19th century. In India, the loss of the
label: Paragraph

text: southern route to China had the effect of
label: Paragraph

text: creating infighting, with a noticeable drop
label: Paragraph

text: in architectural production in the early 14th
label: Paragraph

text: century.
label: Paragraph

text: The first Mongolian capital was
label: Paragraph

text: Karakorum, a vast city of yurts in western
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolia, but Karakorum was too far from
label: Paragraph

text: the center of political gravity in China,
label: Paragraph

text: so the khan commissioned the building
label: Paragraph

text: of a new capital city, Shangdu (meaning
label: Paragraph

text: “Supreme Capital” and also called Kaipingfu),
label: Paragraph

text: some 1,200 kilometers to the southeast
label: Paragraph

text: of Karakorum. It was designed by the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese architect Liu Bingzhong (1252)
label: Caption

text: in a profoundly Chinese manner, with an
label: Paragraph

text: outer city and an inner city, and a roughly
label: Paragraph

text: square layout. In 1264, Kublai Khan gave Liu
label: Paragraph

text: Bingzhong the task of designing yet another
label: Paragraph

text: capital city that today is more commonly
label: Paragraph

text: known as Beijing. It was broad in scale, strict
label: Paragraph

text: in planning and execution, and named Dadu.
label: Paragraph

text: It had large areas that mimicked the open
label: Paragraph

text: steppe where the Mongolians could ride their
label: Paragraph

text: horses and live in their yurts.
label: Paragraph

text: Consider all the areas just discussed, and
label: Paragraph

text: then take everything that is not included:
label: Paragraph

text: the rain forests and deserts of central and
label: Title

text: southern Africa; northern Asia and Siberia;
label: Title

text: and Australia. These regions would remain
label: Paragraph

text: more or less independent from this economic
label: Title

text: continuum until the arrival of the colonial
label: Paragraph

text: age or even later, but now that Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: the northern and eastern parts of Africa were
label: Paragraph

text: part of the global economic continuum, the
label: Paragraph

text: map began to stabilize. Within this area, the
label: Paragraph

text: historical narratives are still of war, conflict,
label: Paragraph

text: and disruption, but they are just as much
label: Paragraph

text: about power, personalities, and religion
label: Title

text: as about the need to control trade routes,
label: Paragraph

text: markets, and sites of production in a rapidly
label: Paragraph

text: changing landscape.

text: The Song dynasty (960-1279) in China
label: Paragraph

text: and the Chola in India (847-1249) exerted
label: Paragraph

text: powerful economic influences in Southeast
label: Title

text: Asia, even though it was India that won out
label: Paragraph

text: from a cultural point of view, with its variants
label: Paragraph

text: of Buddhism and Hinduism spreading
label: Title

text: throughout the region. Another factor in the
label: Paragraph

text: area’s geopolitics was the Dali kingdorn in
label: Paragraph

text: southern China's Yunnan Province. From
label: Paragraph

text: 900 CE until 1253, when it was conquered
label: Paragraph

text: by the Mongolians and brought back into
label: Paragraph

text: the fold of the Chinese empire, it was an
label: Paragraph

text: autonomous Buddhist state and served as
label: Paragraph

text: part of an overland route to southern China.
label: Paragraph

text: Its primary city, Kunming, had long been the
label: Paragraph

text: main stopping point along the route to India
label: Paragraph

text: by way of Burma. The disruptions of the Silk
label: Paragraph

text: Route that were the result of the Mongolian
label: Paragraph

text: expansion into Asia made this alternative
label: Paragraph

text: route especially important. In the 9th
label: Paragraph

text: century CE, Dali, a nearby city, took control
label: Paragraph

text: of Kunming, unified the area, and built new
label: Paragraph

text: temples and palaces.
label: Paragraph

text: A more distant development was the
label: Paragraph

text: integration of the East African coast into the
label: Title

text: circuits of Arab and Indian traders, which
label: Paragraph

text: created a continuous fabric of ocean ports
label: Paragraph

text: from Africa to China. These regional and
label: Paragraph

text: global events were highly advantageous to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: For its construction, a large part of

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and Suryavarman himself; its garbha-griha
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: as a facsimile of Suryavarman. There
label: Paragraph

text: is much that is still unknown about the
label: Paragraph

text: temple—archaeological work on the
label: Title

text: Khmer civilization is still in its infancy. The
label: Paragraph

text: building’s astrological notations (such as
label: Paragraph

text: the columns on its balustrade, which are
label: Paragraph

text: equal in number to the years in a Hindu
label: Paragraph

text: age), as well as its esoteric astronomical
label: Paragraph

text: measurements, are still being decoded.
label: Paragraph

text: It is therefore generally assumed that the
label: Paragraph

text: building is a map of cosmological space
label: Paragraph

text: and time as understood by the Khmer.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Shesha that the sleeping Vishnu dreams

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: from which the “dream” of life comes into
label: Paragraph

text: being. The Shesha Naga was one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most prominent symbols of the Khmer.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Enemies”), now known as the city of Pagan.
label: Paragraph

text: For two centuries, Pagan waged war with the
label: Paragraph

text: Cholas in peninsular India while maintaining
label: Paragraph

text: a close but carefully guarded relationship
label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: which was both Buddhist and Hindu, the
label: Paragraph

text: Pagan practiced Theravada Buddhism, a
label: Paragraph

text: traditional form that spread from Sri Lanka.
label: Paragraph

text: Between the 12th and 15th centuries, Pagan
label: Paragraph

text: ings constructed more than two thousand
label: Paragraph

text: structures, stupas, and temples. Despite
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The Song emperor Huizong (r. 1100-1125)
label: Caption

text: was an enthusiastic patron of the arts. A
label: Paragraph

text: catalog of his paintings, the Xuanhe Huapu,
label: Caption

text: published in 1123, lists over six thousand
label: Paragraph

text: works in his collection. Art academies were
label: Paragraph

text: established in his reign, which saw an
label: Paragraph

text: increased interest in ancient history and
label: Paragraph

text: culture; collecting antiques also became
label: Paragraph

text: popular. Huizong also commissioned the
label: Paragraph

text: New Yingzhao Fashi (1103), a detailed
label: Paragraph

text: manual of architecture and construction.
label: Caption

text: It was called the “new” Yingzhao Fashi
label: Paragraph

text: because the previous one, dating to the
label: Paragraph

text: T'ang, had become outdated. The manual
label: Paragraph

text: was not, however, intended as an aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: or philosophical document, but rather to help
label: Paragraph

text: the imperial administrators regulate, and
label: Paragraph

text: reign in, the construction industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Aesthetically, architecture under the Song
label: Paragraph

text: and the Jin (and later under the Yuan) had
label: Paragraph

text: become very ornamental and complicated.
label: Paragraph

text: The size of the dou-gong decreased with
label: Paragraph

text: respect to the overall column heights, but it
label: Paragraph

text: increased in complexity and showmanship.
label: Paragraph

text: The placement of columns was even
label: Paragraph

text: occasionally disrupted to accommodate
label: Paragraph

text: more ambitious spatial arrangements. While
label: Paragraph

text: all these transformations made for a much
label: Paragraph

text: richer and more expressive architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: it also resulted in a great deal of waste
label: Paragraph

text: and corruption. Because construction was
label: Paragraph

text: controlled by powerful guilds that carefully
label: Paragraph

text: guarded their knowledge, passing it on only
label: Paragraph

text: in oral verse, buildings routinely ran over
label: Paragraph

text: budget. The imperial court found that it could
label: Paragraph

text: not reasonably predict the cost to complete
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. Furthermore, the high demand
label: Paragraph

text: for timber was causing rapid deforestation
label: Paragraph

text: in the Song territories, and with the northern
label: Paragraph

text: forests in the control of “barbarians,” the
label: Paragraph

text: court feared that it would soon run out of
label: Paragraph

text: timber. The New Yingzhao Fashi aimed
label: Paragraph

text: to solve both these problems. Li Jie was
label: Paragraph

text: an intellectual, a painter, and an author of
label: Paragraph

text: books on geography, history, and philology.

text: In addition, as a superintendent for state
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in the Ministry of Works (Gong
label: Title

text: Bu), he had carried out several building
label: Paragraph

text: projects, which made him an ideal person for
label: Paragraph

text: the job. For three years Li Jie systematically
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and explanations. He finally presented his

label: Paragraph

text: that the government administrators could

label: Paragraph

text: Jie’s Yingzhao Fashi consists of thirty-four
label: Paragraph

text: chapters organized into five parts: basic
label: Title

text: data, regulations, labor work, materials,
label: Title

text: and drawings. Each part is subdivided into
label: Paragraph

text: the following fourteen sections: moats and
label: Paragraph

text: fortifications; stonework; structural carpentry;
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: staircases, etc.); wood carving; turning and
label: Paragraph

text: drilling; sawing; bamboo work; plastering,
label: Paragraph

text: painting, and decoration; brickwork; brick
label: Title

text: and tile making.
label: Paragraph

text: The Yingzhao Fashi described eight types
label: Paragraph

text: of buildings but was concerned primarily with
label: Paragraph

text: imperial and governmental buildings, and not
label: Paragraph

text: with buildings for commoners, since only the
label: Paragraph

text: former would be paid for by the administrator.
label: Paragraph

text: Most of the drawings are plans (determining
label: Paragraph

text: the basic size of a building), sections
label: Paragraph

text: (determining quantities), and wood sections
label: Paragraph

text: (instrumental in determining costs). All these
label: Paragraph

text: were regulated by a proportioning system,
label: Paragraph

text: known as the cai-fen. A cai was 10 fen, and a
label: Paragraph

text: Zu-cai was 21 fen. The standard proportions
label: Paragraph

text: were in the ratio 2:3. Thus a standard wood
label: Paragraph

text: section would be 10 by 15 fen.

label: Title

text: By 1206, Temtjin, called Genghis Khan
label: Paragraph

text: (“Mighty Ruler”) had united the dispersed
label: Paragraph

text: and infighting Mongolian tribes, sending his
label: Paragraph

text: armies south and west to create an expansive
label: Paragraph

text: empire. Following his death in 1227, his son
label: Paragraph

text: Ogedei advanced even farther west, taking
label: Paragraph

text: Kiev in 1240. Kublai Khan, another grandson
label: Caption

text: of Genghis, completed the conquest of China
label: Paragraph

text: in 1279, establishing the Yuan dynasty.
label: Paragraph

text: The result was the largest empire in history,
label: Paragraph

text: covering 20 percent of the earth’s total land
label: Paragraph

text: area and holding sway over a population
label: Paragraph

text: of more than one hundred million. Though
label: Paragraph

text: it was not to last, it had important and
label: Paragraph

text: numerous long-term effects.
label: Paragraph

text: Many accounts of the Mongolians focus
label: Paragraph

text: on their ferocious fighting style and barbarous
label: Paragraph

text: looting of cities, palaces, and libraries.
label: Paragraph

text: But most of the information that has been
label: Paragraph

text: handed down about the Mongolians was
label: Paragraph

text: written by the people who were conquered
label: Paragraph

text: and who were not inclined toward more
label: Paragraph

text: neutral assessments. One of the reasons for
label: Paragraph

text: the Mongolians’ success was their military
label: Paragraph

text: style. Most armies fought with slow masses
label: Paragraph

text: of soldiers. Many soldiers were farmhands
label: Paragraph

text: with minimal skills and training. Mongolian
label: Paragraph

text: soldiers, all excellent horsemen, had not
label: Paragraph

text: only mastered a dynamic mode of attack but
label: Paragraph

text: were also seasoned to cope with the brutal
label: Paragraph

text: conditions of the steppe. A diet of meat
label: Paragraph

text: and yogurt made them taller and stronger
label: Paragraph

text: than many of their enemies. Furthermore,
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: unlike in the West, where there were small

text: groups of elite soldiers and large masses
label: Title

text: of untrained combatants, the armies of the
label: Paragraph

text: united Mongol tribes consisted of the entire
label: Paragraph

text: adult male population under the age of sixty.
label: Paragraph

text: Living in tents designed to allow the soldiers
label: Paragraph

text: to follow the movement of their grazing
label: Paragraph

text: horses, they had no urban culture and
label: Paragraph

text: were interested primarily in the trappings of
label: Paragraph

text: movable wealth, which they distributed with
label: Paragraph

text: democratic evenhandedness to all the tribes.
label: Paragraph

text: When Genghis Khan died, he was buried in
label: Paragraph

text: a secret, unmarked location in the desert of
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolia, according to Mongolian tradition.
label: Paragraph

text: (A team of archaeologists have recently
label: Paragraph

text: located a site in Mongolia that is most likely
label: Paragraph

text: Genghis Khan's tomb.)
label: Paragraph

text: The ger (“dwelling place"), the Mongolian
label: Paragraph

text: yurt, was easily transportable and yet solid
label: Paragraph

text: enough to withstand ferocious winds. The
label: Paragraph

text: basic element is an expanding wooden lattice
label: Paragraph

text: that forms the circular walls. Poles from the
label: Paragraph

text: sides rise up to connect to a compression
label: Paragraph

text: ring, thus forming the roof structure. A
label: Paragraph

text: band of rope is drawn around the top of
label: Paragraph

text: the wall to bind it together. A fireplace was
label: Paragraph

text: set out in the center. The wood structure is
label: Paragraph

text: then covered with various amounts of felt,
label: Paragraph

text: depending on climatic conditions. (Felt was
label: Paragraph

text: made by pounding and rubbing wool—the
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolians had no weaving skills. In fact,
label: Paragraph

text: all their clothing was bartered for, bought, or
label: Paragraph

text: came from war booty.) The yurt’s entrance
label: Paragraph

text: Yuan Dynasty China
label: Title

text: When Kublai Khan (1215-94), Genghis’s
label: Paragraph

text: grandson, ascended the throne of China, he
label: Paragraph

text: chose the Chinese name Yuan (“original” or
label: Paragraph

text: “prime”) for his dynasty. By 1279, with the
label: Paragraph

text: surrender of the last of the Song territories, all
label: Paragraph

text: of China was under the Yuan. The Mongols
label: Paragraph

text: divided society into four classes, with the
label: Paragraph

text: highest reserved for thernselves and the
label: Paragraph

text: lowest for the southern Chinese from the
label: Paragraph

text: former Song regions. Outsiders enjoyed the
label: Paragraph

text: middle status in China, between the Mongols
label: Paragraph

text: and the native Chinese, to the great irritation
label: Paragraph

text: of the Song. Lamaist Buddhists—from Tibet
label: Paragraph

text: and Nepal—and Daoists found particular
label: Paragraph

text: favor with the Mongols, much as they had
label: Paragraph

text: with the Mongolian-related Jin two hundred
label: Paragraph

text: years earlier. Muslims were welcomed and
label: Paragraph

text: happily tolerated at the western border.
label: Paragraph

text: Under the Yuan, one of the oldest mosques
label: Paragraph

text: of China, the tomb of Tughlug Temur, was
label: Paragraph

text: built in 1363 in Huocheng, Xinjiang.
label: Caption

text: The Mongolian capital was Karakorum,
label: Paragraph

text: and it was from there that Genghis Khan
label: Paragraph

text: would rally his troops. Genghis’s son and
label: Paragraph

text: successor, Ogedei, erected walls around
label: Paragraph

text: the city. Though nothing remains today, we
label: Paragraph

text: know from descriptions that the city was
label: Paragraph

text: square, with gates in the cardinal directions,
label: Paragraph

text: and that it had Arab and Chinese quarters,
label: Paragraph

text: several temples and mosques, and even a
label: Paragraph

text: Nestorian church. When Kublai Khan claimed
label: Paragraph

text: the throne of the Mongol Empire in 1260,
label: Paragraph

text: he relocated his capital first to Chengdu and
label: Paragraph

text: later to Dadu (present-day Beijing). While the
label: Paragraph

text: Yuan introduced global civilization to China
label: Title

text: and modernized its military and its economy,
label: Paragraph

text: they had no architectural culture. As a result,
label: Paragraph

text: in building the new capital city, they adhered
label: Paragraph

text: to the planning principles described in the
label: Paragraph

text: Rituals of Zhou, which was a good political
label: Paragraph

text: move, as it made them appear considerate
label: Paragraph

text: of Chinese tradition. They also ordered the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of numerous altars and temples
label: Paragraph

text: throughout China dedicated to ancestors and
label: Paragraph

text: local deities.
label: Paragraph

text: Dadu (from the word fa-tu, or “Great
label: Paragraph

text: Capital”) was known to the Mongolians as
label: Paragraph

text: Khanbalig, the “City of the Great Khan.” It
label: Paragraph

text: was square with an orthogonal arrangement
label: Paragraph

text: of streets typical of earlier Chinese capitals.
label: Paragraph

text: The urban center, consisting of a palace
label: Paragraph

text: and imperial quarters, was located south
label: Paragraph

text: of the city center, with residential areas
label: Paragraph

text: predominantly occupying the northern part.
label: Paragraph

text: The name for the palace was ta-nei, or “great
label: Paragraph

text: interior.” It was surrounded by a 6-by-5
label: Paragraph

text: kilometer area reserved for the Mongolian
label: Paragraph

text: overlords, who camped there in their yurts. To
label: Paragraph

text: the south, in a separate rectangular precinct,
label: Paragraph

text: was the “outer city” for the native Chinese,
label: Paragraph

text: who lived in houses. A vast building served
label: Paragraph

text: as the official site for ceremonies. Within it,
label: Paragraph

text: Kublai Khan, like the Liao kings before him,
label: Paragraph

text: lived in resplendent tents traditional to the
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolians. Marco Polo, a visitor in his court,
label: Paragraph

text: describes Kublai Khan's palace built in the
label: Caption

text: Chinese manner:
label: Title

text: You must know that it is the greatest palace
label: Paragraph

text: that ever was. The roof is very lofty, and the
label: Paragraph

text: walls of the palace are all covered with gold
label: Paragraph

text: and silver. They are adorned with dragons,
label: Paragraph

text: beasts and birds, knights and idols, and other
label: Title

text: such things. The hall of the palace is so large
label: Paragraph

text: that six thousand people could easily dine
label: Paragraph

text: there, and it is quite a marvel to see how
label: Paragraph

text: many rooms there are besides. The building
label: Paragraph

text: is altogether so vast, so rich, and so beautiful
label: Paragraph

text: that no man on earth could design anything
label: Paragraph

text: superior to it. The outside of the roof is all
label: Paragraph

text: colored with vermilion and yellow and green
label: Paragraph

text: and blue and other hues, which are fixed with
label: Paragraph

text: a varnish so fine and exquisite that it shines
label: Paragraph

text: like crystal and lends a resplendent luster to
label: Paragraph

text: the palace as seen for a great way around.
label: Paragraph

text: Geomancy required that the palace face
label: Paragraph

text: south against the slope of a hill, but since
label: Paragraph

text: no hill was on the site, one was made—the
label: Paragraph

text: Green Hill, about 100 meters high and 2
label: Caption

text: kilometers in circumference. It was planted
label: Paragraph

text: with trees from every part of China and is
label: Paragraph

text: thus a type of map of the Chinese world.
label: Paragraph

text: Surrounding the hill was an enormous Divine
label: Paragraph

text: Menagerie—a park for deer, stags, and other
label: Paragraph

text: animals—with paved roads that led to a large
label: Paragraph

text: lake with islands and pavilions. Little apart
label: Paragraph

text: from the landscaping survives today, since
label: Paragraph

text: it became the site of the vast Forbidden
label: Paragraph

text: City, which was built after all the Mongolian
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were torn down. Two particularly
label: Paragraph

text: critical issues for the new city were water
label: Paragraph

text: and grain: for such a big city, it was located
label: Paragraph

text: far from the fertile grain regions in the south.
label: Paragraph

text: These two problems were solved by the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of a canal frorn the nearby Pei
label: Paragraph

text: Ho River to the east, which allowed grain to
label: Paragraph

text: be brought directly to the city gates.
label: Paragraph

text: The Grand Canal that wound its way
label: Paragraph

text: northward from the fertile grain-producing
label: Paragraph

text: areas of the south to the large cities of
label: Paragraph

text: the north was one of the most important
label: Paragraph

text: engineering works in the world. The goal was
label: Paragraph

text: to make the movement of goods and grain
label: Title

text: independent of ocean transport. The first
label: Paragraph

text: canal was begun in 613 BCE. In 206 BCE,
label: Paragraph

text: the Lingqu Canal, which connected the
label: Paragraph

text: Xingjiang and Lijiang Rivers, was constructed.
label: Paragraph

text: Another 200-kilormeter section, completed in
label: Paragraph

text: 589 cE, linked the newly constructed capital
label: Paragraph

text: of Luoyang (Dongdu, or Eastern Capital)
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: In the 12th century, South Asia was
label: Paragraph

text: transformed by the arrival of the Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: armies. They were led initially by Qutb-ud-Din
label: Paragraph

text: Aibak, a Ghaznavid general from Afghanistan,
label: Paragraph

text: who defeated the Rajput king and took over
label: Paragraph

text: his territories in north India in 1192. His
label: Paragraph

text: efforts were superseded in 1296 by Ala-
label: Paragraph

text: ud-Din Khilji (r. 1296-1316), who seized
label: Paragraph

text: Ranthambhor, Chittorgarh, and Jaiselmer
label: Title

text: from the Rajputs and crushed the Solankis
label: Paragraph

text: and the Pramars, going far south to conquer
label: Paragraph

text: the fortress of Devagiri from the Yadavs.
label: Paragraph

text: Historians do not all evaluate the Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: rulers’ relationship to their Hindu subjects
label: Title

text: equally. Islamic rulers often massacred
label: Paragraph

text: Hindus and systematically destroyed and
label: Paragraph

text: desecrated Hindu ternples. However, the
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu population as a whole continued to
label: Paragraph

text: thrive under Islamic rule, merging with it in
label: Paragraph

text: many ways at the level of popular culture
label: Title

text: and thus underlining the more tolerant and
label: Paragraph

text: even enlightened aspects of Islamic rule—
label: Paragraph

text: particularly that of the Moghuls. (One of the
label: Paragraph

text: eventual consequences of these underlying
label: Title

text: tensions was the partitioning of South Asia
label: Paragraph

text: into India and Pakistan in 1947 by the British
label: Paragraph

text: on the eve of their departure, an act whose
label: Paragraph

text: ramifications are still in play.)
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: in Lahore but then moved to central India,
label: Paragraph

text: taking over a Chauhan settlement called
label: Paragraph

text: Tomar to build Qila Rai Pithora, the first
label: Paragraph

text: capital on the site of modern Delhi. Delhi was
label: Paragraph

text: Ghias-ud-Din’s Tughlaq's city, Tughlaqabad
label: Title

text: (1321-25), was the largest of Delhi’s fortress
label: Paragraph

text: cities and a remarkable piece of engineering.
label: Paragraph

text: To site his city, Tughlaq picked an irregular
label: Paragraph

text: plateau that was difficult to work because
label: Paragraph

text: it was very rocky but had the advantage of
label: Paragraph

text: jutting prominently above the gentle westward
label: Paragraph

text: slope of the floodplain of the Yamuna
label: Title

text: River. Tughlaq delineated his fort, which
label: Paragraph

text: was made with local stone, in the shape
label: Paragraph

text: of an irregular parallelogram with frequent
label: Paragraph

text: circular turrets. The ground dropped quickly
label: Paragraph

text: around the fort. Within, on the southwest
label: Paragraph

text: side, he built his palace, enclosed within
label: Paragraph

text: another fortified rectangle. At the junction
label: Paragraph

text: of the palace and the rest of the fort was a
label: Paragraph

text: sub-palace, a separate defensible entity in
label: Paragraph

text: itself. One of the Yamuna River's drainage
label: Paragraph

text: canals originally went right past the southern
label: Paragraph

text: walls of Tughlaqabad; Tughlaq converted
label: Title

text: this canal into an artificial lake by building
label: Paragraph

text: a dam linking a rocky outcrop just south of
label: Paragraph

text: the city to the city itself. Tughlaqabad thus
label: Paragraph

text: had valleys on three sides, and a lake toward
label: Paragraph

text: the fourth. Within this lake Tughlaq built yet
label: Paragraph

text: another fortress, in the form of an island,
label: Paragraph

text: linked to the main fort by a 220-meter-
label: Paragraph

text: long elevated causeway. The lower level of
label: Paragraph

text: this island fortress consisted of a network
label: Paragraph

text: of arched rooms with carefully controlled
label: Paragraph

text: access. This was the treasury. On the roof
label: Paragraph

text: of the treasury, Tughlaq built his tornb,
label: Paragraph

text: a spectacular visual in the middle of the
label: Paragraph

text: lake. There were additional hidden tunnels
label: Paragraph

text: and causeways in the palace complex,
label: Paragraph

text: adding to the secretive nature of the whole
label: Paragraph

text: construction.

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Its palace is situated on the rocky promontory
label: Paragraph

text: of an island in Mso Bay. Husuni Kubwa,
label: Caption

text: which means “large fortified house” in
label: Paragraph

text: Swahili, had several courtyards for different
label: Paragraph

text: functions, with a distinct progression from
label: Paragraph

text: private to public. The king's private courtyard
label: Caption

text: had a sunken pool with an audience court
label: Paragraph

text: next to it. There was a protected harbor to
label: Paragraph

text: the west.
label: Paragraph

text: North Africa was dominated by the
label: Paragraph

text: Ayyubid sultanate in Egypt and the
label: Title

text: Almohads in Morocco and Spain. The once
label: Paragraph

text: powerful Ghana Empire was in decline. The
label: Paragraph

text: Almoravids, constituted of Saharan Berbers,
label: Paragraph

text: had taken control of the trade routes through
label: Paragraph

text: the Sahara and captured Koumbi Saleh,
label: Paragraph

text: the capital of Ghana, in 1067. By the 13th
label: Paragraph

text: century, however, a new power emerged:
label: Paragraph

text: the Mali Empire. Centered to the north of
label: Paragraph

text: Ghana, it was composed of several states that
label: Paragraph

text: took control of the gold mines. Before the
label: Paragraph

text: discovery of gold in the Americas, almost half
label: Paragraph

text: of the gold in Europe care from Mali. The
label: Paragraph

text: Mali Empire also controlled the salt trade in
label: Paragraph

text: that region.
label: Paragraph

text: AFRICA
label: Title

text: Prior to the 13th century, southern and
label: Paragraph

text: eastern Africa were remote outposts in the
label: Paragraph

text: global trade networks. But in the 1200s,
label: Paragraph

text: the East African coast developed into an
label: Paragraph

text: extensive trading zone linked to Arabian
label: Paragraph

text: and Indian port cities and thus became
label: Paragraph

text: the major distribution center for the African
label: Paragraph

text: continent. East Africans sold gold, ivory,
label: Paragraph

text: and slaves in exchange for metals, rice, and
label: Paragraph

text: other commodities. One consequence of the
label: Paragraph

text: cultural exchange was the emergence of the
label: Paragraph

text: Swahili language, which combines African
label: Paragraph

text: and Arabic linguistic elernents.
label: Paragraph

text: Preeminent among the ports at this time
label: Paragraph

text: was Kilwa, off the south coast of Tanzania.
label: Paragraph

text: It was established in the 11th century by
label: Paragraph

text: believers of Shirazi Islam, an East African
label: Title

text: variant of Middle Eastern Islam. The rulers
label: Paragraph

text: controlled the sources of gold in nearby
label: Paragraph

text: Mozambique. (In the 16th century, this
label: Paragraph

text: provoked the interest of the Portuguese,
label: Paragraph

text: whose subsequent arrival spelled the end of
label: Paragraph

text: African control of the trade routes.)

text: Mamluk Sultanate
label: Title

text: The Mamluks, who ruled Egypt from 1260
label: Paragraph

text: to 1517, were not Arabs; instead, they were
label: Paragraph

text: originally Turkish, Kurdish, and Mongolian
label: Paragraph

text: slaves who had been raised as fighters in the
label: Paragraph

text: army of the Ayyubids, who were themselves
label: Paragraph

text: Kurdish Turks from Syria. The word Mamluk
label: Paragraph

text: comes, in fact, from an Arabic word meaning
label: Paragraph

text: “the owned.” But with the collapse of Shi'ite
label: Paragraph

text: Ayyubid rule in Egypt, General Baybars
label: Paragraph

text: al-Bunduqdari (r. 1260-77) established
label: Paragraph

text: Mamluk dominance over Egypt, pushing
label: Paragraph

text: back the Mongolians as well as the Christian
label: Title

text: Crusaders in the Levant and Syria, and
label: Paragraph

text: regaining control over the holy cities of Mecca
label: Title

text: and Medina. Under the previous Ayyubids,
label: Paragraph

text: the center of power had been in Damascus,
label: Paragraph

text: but under the Mamluks, Cairo’s importance
label: Paragraph

text: was restored; indeed, from a geopolitical
label: Paragraph

text: perspective, Cairo was the prime link between
label: Paragraph

text: India and Europe. Though a military elite,
label: Paragraph

text: the Mamluks were savvy traders, establishing
label: Paragraph

text: ties with Venice and Genoa as well as
label: Paragraph

text: with Constantinople. Mamluk bureaucracy
label: Paragraph

text: consisted mostly of Coptic Christians and
label: Paragraph

text: Jews, who had filled such administrative roles
label: Paragraph

text: for centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 13th and 14th centuries
label: Title

text: at least five major madrasas were built in
label: Paragraph

text: Cairo along a street close to the sultan’s
label: Paragraph

text: palace. Each of these was associated with
label: Paragraph

text: a mausoleum. Normally, tombs, even for
label: Paragraph

text: the rich, would be located outside of the
label: Paragraph

text: city, but if the sultan gave an endowment
label: Paragraph

text: to a madrasa he was granted an exception.
label: Paragraph

text: Each madrasa is thus associated with
label: Paragraph

text: a sultan’s tornb. The buildings, sitting
label: Paragraph

text: shoulder to shoulder, constitute one of the
label: Paragraph

text: more important street environments of the
label: Paragraph

text: age. As madrasas had to face Mecca, all
label: Paragraph

text: the structures abut the street at about a
label: Paragraph

text: 10-degree angle. The architects showed great
label: Paragraph

text: adeptness at integrating the program into
label: Paragraph

text: the complex and cramped urban site. Most
label: Paragraph

text: impressive is the Tornb of Sultan Qalawun
label: Paragraph

text: (1284-85). Though the life of a sultan was
label: Paragraph

text: continually beset by the possibility of internal
label: Paragraph

text: rebellions testing his authority, he proved to
label: Paragraph

text: be a capable ruler open to trade even with
label: Paragraph

text: the Christians with whom he was fighting.
label: Paragraph

text: He made trade alliances with the Byzantine
label: Paragraph

text: Empire, Genoa, and the Kingdom of Sicily.
label: Paragraph

text: The plan echoes the octagonal plan of
label: Paragraph

text: the Dore of the Rock. The wall of the
label: Paragraph

text: mausoleum is divided into a series of pointed
label: Paragraph

text: arched recesses, the hoods supported on
label: Paragraph

text: marble columns. The portal, a remarkable
label: Caption

text: piece of Gothic marble work, is a trophy
label: Paragraph

text: seized from a church in Acre, the last
label: Paragraph

text: Crusader stronghold in Palestine. The tomb
label: Caption

text: chamber is an almost square plan, with four
label: Paragraph

text: piers and four columns arranged in the form
label: Caption

text: of an octagon supporting arches that in turn
label: Paragraph

text: raise a high drum and above that, a dome.
label: Paragraph

text: The rose granite pillars have Corinthian
label: Caption

text: capitals. The walls are richly decorated with
label: Paragraph

text: marbles and mosaics. At the mausoleum’s
label: Caption

text: rear there was a hospital. The madrasa,
label: Paragraph

text: which specialized in Sunni jurisprudence,
label: Paragraph

text: has its own courtyard with student cells.
label: Paragraph

text: Another important monument from this era
label: Paragraph

text: is the Mosque of Sultan al-Nasir Muhammad
label: Paragraph

text: (1318), built in the great citadel that protects
label: Paragraph

text: the city. Though conventional in plan, the
label: Paragraph

text: columns and capitals are mostly spoils taken
label: Paragraph

text: from other buildings, including churches and
label: Paragraph

text: even the ruins of ancient Egyptian buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: 12.46 Bieta Giorgis, Lalibela, Ethiopia
label: Caption

text: Lalibela
label: Title

text: The collapse of the Aksumite Empire around
label: Title

text: 400 CE left the Horn of Africa in the hands
label: Paragraph

text: of various regional forces, but in the 13th
label: Paragraph

text: century, the return of commerce to the
label: Paragraph

text: shores and the transformation of Ethiopia
label: Title

text: into a Christian kingdom visited by pilgrims
label: Title

text: from far afield brought prosperity back to
label: Paragraph

text: the region. The Zagwe dynasty (founded ca.
label: Paragraph

text: 1137) capitalized on this, reaching its peak
label: Paragraph

text: under King Lalibela (r. ca. 1185-1225),
label: Paragraph

text: who is credited with building a set of eleven
label: Paragraph

text: churches cut out of solid red volcanic rock
label: Caption

text: in his new capital city, Roha, now called
label: Paragraph

text: Lalibela (340 kilometers north of Addis
label: Title

text: Ababa). The city is located on a high ridge
label: Paragraph

text: above the Takkaze River. Under threat from
label: Paragraph

text: the forces of Islam from the north, the Zagwe
label: Paragraph

text: had retreated into these ridges, from which
label: Paragraph

text: they continued to control the Red Sea ports
label: Paragraph

text: that linked central and southern African trade
label: Paragraph

text: routes to the shipping lanes to India and
label: Title

text: beyond.
label: Paragraph

text: The ridge, despite its height over the valley,
label: Paragraph

text: had the added advantage of featuring several
label: Paragraph

text: artesian springs that had both agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: and symbolic value. The churches are
label: Paragraph

text: highly unusual in their overall conception.
label: Paragraph

text: Not only do they constitute a holy land unto
label: Paragraph

text: themselves, but they are also a type of map
label: Paragraph

text: of the holy city of Jerusalem, which King
label: Paragraph

text: Lalibela had never seen, but imagined from
label: Paragraph

text: descriptions in the Bible. The churches are
label: Paragraph

text: divided into northern and eastern groups by
label: Paragraph

text: a rock-cut channel called Yordannos (“River
label: Paragraph

text: Jordan”). Bieta Madhane Alam is the largest
label: Paragraph

text: and most impressive of these churches.
label: Paragraph

text: The lack of documents makes the history
label: Paragraph

text: of rock-cut architecture difficult to trace, but
label: Paragraph

text: given that it had a strong presence in India,
label: Paragraph

text: where Hindu and Buddhist sanctuaries were
label: Paragraph

text: built out of the side of cliffs from 200 CE
label: Paragraph

text: to at least 900 CE, it stands to reason that
label: Paragraph

text: the techniques and indeed perhaps even
label: Paragraph

text: some labor came from India, where the
label: Paragraph

text: tradition was dying out. There is no firm way
label: Paragraph

text: coista-micel A |
label: Title

text: Denagel
label: Title

text: 12.47 Partial plan: Rock-cut churches of Lalibela
label: Caption

text: of proving this, but the relatively sudden
label: Paragraph

text: appearance of this form of building in
label: Paragraph

text: Ethiopia lends credence to the argument.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, the narrative of Lalibela, namely
label: Paragraph

text: that it is organized around a sacred river, in
label: Paragraph

text: this case the “River Jordan,” has parallels
label: Paragraph

text: to places like Mahabalipuram in southern
label: Paragraph

text: India, where temples were organized around
label: Paragraph

text: a “River Ganges.” Each of the churches is
label: Paragraph

text: associated with a square water tank filled by
label: Paragraph

text: the pressure from an artesian spring. These
label: Paragraph

text: tanks are planted with papyrus to emulate
label: Paragraph

text: the Nile River. They are not baptismal pools
label: Paragraph

text: in the conventional sense; rather, they
label: Paragraph

text: symbolize fertility. During Easter, the site
label: Paragraph

text: attracts pilgrims from far and wide.
label: Paragraph

text: Because the churches are carved down
label: Paragraph

text: into the bedrock, the level of these pools,
label: Paragraph

text: governed by the pressure of the water in
label: Paragraph

text: the rock, had to first be determined, as that
label: Paragraph

text: then determined the height of the individual
label: Paragraph

text: church. Of the twelve churches, Bieta Giorgis
label: Caption

text: (St. George), carved into the shape of a
label: Paragraph

text: cross, is situated somewhat apart from the
label: Paragraph

text: other churches to the west. Following a deep,
label: Paragraph

text: narrow trench, visitors descend in a wide
label: Paragraph

text: arc past a sacred spring, to its ground level.
label: Paragraph

text: The building is approximately 12 meters
label: Paragraph

text: in height, length, and width and rests on a
label: Paragraph

text: triple-stepped platform. Though carved out
label: Caption

text: of the living stone, it mimics a conventionally
label: Paragraph

text: constructed building, replete with window
label: Caption

text: framing, vaults, and delicately chiseled
label: Caption

text: acanthus leaves and gargoyles. The interior
label: Caption

text: has a cruciform floor plan with a dome above
label: Caption

text: the sanctuary in the eastern arm of the
label: Paragraph

text: church.
label: Paragraph

text: Rock-cut architecture continued on as
label: Paragraph

text: a living tradition in Cappadocia, Turkey,
label: Paragraph

text: where churches and even residences were
label: Paragraph

text: carved out of the rock, probably for defensive
label: Paragraph

text: reasons. The first churches of Cappadocia
label: Paragraph

text: date to about this same period. Lalibela and
label: Paragraph

text: Cappadocia are the last great examples of
label: Paragraph

text: rock-cut architecture in the world.
label: Paragraph

text: 12.51 Great Zimbabwe, Masvingo, Zimbabwe
label: Caption

text: Great Zimbabwe
label: Title

text: The Great Zimbabwe (“Great Palace”) is
label: Paragraph

text: a fortress complex dating frorn the 10th
label: Caption

text: century; it is located on top of a granite bluff
label: Paragraph

text: as well as in adjacent valleys in Zimbabwe,
label: Paragraph

text: not far from Masvingo. The complex housed
label: Paragraph

text: a large population as well as the royal
label: Paragraph

text: court, markets, warehouses, and religious
label: Title

text: shrines. The number of ruins in its vicinity
label: Paragraph

text: is substantial, but they have yet to be
label: Paragraph

text: thoroughly studied. The kingdom acquired
label: Paragraph

text: its wealth from the abundant gold reserves
label: Paragraph

text: in the region and from the good agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: land. These drew Indian and Islarnic traders
label: Paragraph

text: down the eastern coast of Africa. The
label: Paragraph

text: traders set up ports that usually became
label: Paragraph

text: independent kingdoms. Most of the goods
label: Paragraph

text: from Zimbabwe were brought 400 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: to the east to the port town of Chibuene,
label: Paragraph

text: Mozambique, where archaeologists have
label: Paragraph

text: found the remains of structures that served
label: Paragraph

text: to smelt gold, probably obtained from
label: Paragraph

text: Zimbabwe. Other commercial settlements,
label: Paragraph

text: including Sofala, became important centers
label: Paragraph

text: for the Arab, Persian, and later Portuguese
label: Paragraph

text: trade in slaves, gold, ivory, and other
label: Paragraph

text: commodities.
label: Paragraph

text: At the heart of the Great Zimbabwe is the
label: Paragraph

text: palace itself. The Karanga ethnic group,
label: Paragraph

text: whose ancestors are now thought to have
label: Paragraph

text: built the structure, called it Mumbahuru,
label: Paragraph

text: meaning “House of the Great Woman.” The
label: Paragraph

text: building was not constructed as an isolated
label: Paragraph

text: object in space but as an extension of the
label: Paragraph

text: natural landscape. The blocks of the walls
label: Paragraph

text: that define this structure were skillfully laid
label: Paragraph

text: without mortar and ranged from 1 to 5
label: Paragraph

text: meters thick. Curved walls are stronger than
label: Paragraph

text: ones with corners, which is partially why it
label: Paragraph

text: has survived the ages. Its oval-shaped walls
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed a large area, within which were
label: Paragraph

text: other stone-wall enclosures that contained an
label: Paragraph

text: outdoor living space (kgotla), a garden, and
label: Paragraph

text: a place that was presumably used to keep
label: Paragraph

text: livestock. The kgotia is also a place where
label: Paragraph

text: descendants can establish communion with
label: Paragraph

text: one another and with their ancestors. The
label: Paragraph

text: visual focus of the building is a 6-meter-wide
label: Paragraph

text: by 10-meter-high conical tower, the original
label: Caption

text: purpose of which remains unknown. The
label: Paragraph

text: palace was sited between two rock outcrops.
label: Paragraph

text: At their summits are thick, curving stone
label: Paragraph

text: walls placed in relationship to large boulders,
label: Paragraph

text: indicating that the area was a sacred
label: Paragraph

text: landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: Mosques of Mali
label: Title

text: Timbuktu was one of Africa’s leading cities
label: Paragraph

text: as well as one of the intellectual and spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: centers for the propagation of Islam. It has
label: Paragraph

text: three great mosques—Sankoreé, Djinguereber,
label: Caption

text: and Sidi Yahya—which form part of an
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic university. By the 14th century, many
label: Paragraph

text: books were written and copied there. The city
label: Paragraph

text: lies at the intersection of the east-west and
label: Paragraph

text: north-south trans-Saharan trade routes and
label: Title

text: was (and still is today) an important market
label: Paragraph

text: for rock salt. The Djinguereber Mosque (first
label: Caption

text: built in 1327) is the oldest of the mosques.
label: Paragraph

text: Except for a small part of the northern
label: Paragraph

text: facade, which is of limestone, the building is
label: Paragraph

text: made entirely of sun-baked mud bricks called
label: Paragraph

text: ferey that are coated with a mud plaster to
label: Paragraph

text: give the building a smooth, sculpted look.
label: Paragraph

text: he thickness of the walls depends on their
label: Paragraph

text: eight. There are three inner courts, two
label: Paragraph

text: minarets, and a hypostyle hall with twenty-
label: Paragraph

text: ive rows of pillars that creates a space for
label: Paragraph

text: two thousand people.
label: Paragraph

text: Thirty-five kilometers to the southwest of
label: Paragraph

text: Timbuktu is Djenné, which was not part of
label: Paragraph

text: the Mali Empire but an independent city-
label: Paragraph

text: state. It is the horne of a large mosque that
label: Paragraph

text: was first built in the 13th century, though
label: Paragraph

text: the current structure dates from around
label: Caption

text: 907. The qibla is dominated by three large,
label: Paragraph

text: boxlike minarets jutting out from the main
label: Paragraph

text: wall, and eighteen buttresses. Each minaret
label: Caption

text: contains a spiral staircase leading to the
label: Caption

text: roof topped by a cone-shaped spire with two
label: Caption

text: ostrich eggs. The logs that protrude from the
label: Paragraph

text: uilding serve as scaffolding but have clearly
label: Paragraph

text: een integrated into the design. Half of the
label: Paragraph

text: mosque is covered by a roof, and the other
label: Paragraph

text: alf is an open-air prayer hall. The mosque’s
label: Paragraph

text: roof is supported by ninety wooden pillars.
label: Caption

text: Roof vents allow hot air to rise out of the
label: Paragraph

text: uilding. These buildings require continual
label: Paragraph

text: maintenance, in which the entire community
label: Paragraph

text: participates in preparation for the annual
label: Paragraph

text: festival.

text: 12.57 Area of Cistercian monasteries
label: Caption

text: FONTENAY ABBEY
label: Title

text: Against the backdrop of 11th-century
label: Paragraph

text: religious populism and the increasing
label: Title

text: laxity of the religious elite, especially in the
label: Paragraph

text: monasteries, a countermovement sprang
label: Paragraph

text: up, headed by St. Bernard of Clairvaux. He
label: Paragraph

text: urged a return to the austere rules of the
label: Paragraph

text: early monastic days of St. Benedict, who had
label: Paragraph

text: conceived of the church as a workshop for
label: Paragraph

text: prayer. Among the most prominent of the
label: Paragraph

text: new reform orders were the Carthusians,
label: Paragraph

text: founded in 1084, and the Cistercians,
label: Paragraph

text: founded in 1115. The Cistercians had
label: Paragraph

text: four so-called daughter houses: Clairvaux,
label: Paragraph

text: Morimond, Pontigny, and La Ferté. These in
label: Paragraph

text: turn promoted the creation of other daughter
label: Paragraph

text: houses—so many, in fact, that by the close
label: Paragraph

text: of the 12th century there were 530 Cistercian
label: Paragraph

text: abbeys in Europe, forming a powerful
label: Paragraph

text: monastic network. Though Cistercians had
label: Paragraph

text: a large number of recruits from the feudal
label: Paragraph

text: nobility, one of the reasons for their success
label: Paragraph

text: was that they conceived of manual labor
label: Paragraph

text: as a form of prayer, and therefore opened
label: Paragraph

text: their doors to artisans and peasants. The
label: Paragraph

text: workmanship in their buildings—even in
label: Paragraph

text: places that are normally not visible, like

label: Caption

text: The monasteries were organized as a farm,
label: Paragraph

text: with all the monks participating in the chores.
label: Paragraph

text: Cistercians soon became known for their
label: Paragraph

text: innovations in farming and herding. Their
label: Paragraph

text: vineyards in Burgundy and the Rhineland
label: Title

text: became legendary.
label: Paragraph

text: Under St. Bernard's influence, all the
label: Paragraph

text: details of monkish existence were rigidly
label: Paragraph

text: prescribed, and there were frequent
label: Paragraph

text: inspection visits. Cistercian monasteries
label: Caption

text: were not sited along pilgrimage routes but in
label: Paragraph

text: inhospitable, often swampy and inaccessible
label: Paragraph

text: land. They had no crypts or towers and were
label: Paragraph

text: 12.59 Monastery, Fontenay Abbey
label: Caption

text: built on rigorous geometrical principles,
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes by the monks themselves. They
label: Paragraph

text: had simple vaulted naves; lighting was dim
label: Paragraph

text: and limited by rule to only five candles. Wall
label: Caption

text: surfaces were clean and simple. Sculptural
label: Paragraph

text: embellishments were forbidden. The capitals
label: Paragraph

text: of the columns were kept as plain as
label: Paragraph

text: possible. Bold proportions and architectural
label: Paragraph

text: bravura were not tolerated; even ornamental
label: Paragraph

text: pavements were frowned upon. The plans
label: Paragraph

text: had square east ends in defiance of the
label: Paragraph

text: ambulatory design of the great cathedrals.
label: Caption

text: Even though they were slow to explore its
label: Paragraph

text: possibilities, the Cistercians’ adoption of
label: Paragraph

text: the ribbed vault around 1150 was an act of
label: Paragraph

text: major architectural importance because they
label: Paragraph

text: disseminated this feature across Europe. The
label: Paragraph

text: building that best represents the Cistercian
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic is the Fontenay Abbey near
label: Paragraph

text: Montbard, in the département of Céte-d'Or
label: Paragraph

text: in France; founded in 1119, it is the oldest
label: Paragraph

text: ensemble still in existence. Since there is no
label: Paragraph

text: clerestory, the interior gets most of its light
label: Paragraph

text: from facade windows and from windows at
label: Caption

text: the crossing and in the sanctuary. A tunnel
label: Paragraph

text: vault with transverse arches defines the
label: Paragraph

text: space of the nave. The building, though
label: Paragraph

text: its design was controlled by a proportional
label: Paragraph

text: systern, was conceived in opposition to the
label: Paragraph

text: technical virtuosity and decorative program
label: Title

text: of the great cathedrals. On account of the
label: Paragraph

text: tunnel vault, the nave possesses remarkable
label: Paragraph

text: acoustical qualities. The refectory was placed
label: Paragraph

text: in the customary Cistercian position opposite
label: Paragraph

text: the fountain house on the south side of the
label: Caption

text: cloister, with its axis perpendicular to the
label: Paragraph

text: church.
label: Paragraph

text: Several factors determined the
label: Paragraph

text: monastery’s location. Because it was remote
label: Paragraph

text: from cities, distractions were few. But the
label: Paragraph

text: Cistericans were not idle monks, and this
label: Paragraph

text: particular monastery was based around
label: Paragraph

text: metal production: it was just as much an

label: Caption

text: MEDIEVAL SCANDINAVIA
label: Title

text: The conversion of the Norse and the Swedes
label: Title

text: to Christianity was not due to missionary
label: Paragraph

text: activity, as in Ireland, but came about
label: Paragraph

text: through the efforts of the local kings. Olav
label: Paragraph

text: Trygvason, for example, who was king toward
label: Paragraph

text: the end of the 10th century, was the first to
label: Paragraph

text: build churches in Norway, probably with the
label: Paragraph

text: help of a master builder brought over from
label: Paragraph

text: the British Isles. Gradually, however, local
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmen, with their shipbuilding skills, were
label: Paragraph

text: drawn in. The churches are very distinctive.
label: Paragraph

text: A low wall of flat stones raised the building
label: Paragraph

text: above ground level. The rest of the church
label: Paragraph

text: was in wood, with columns and planks, the
label: Paragraph

text: two basic structural elements, all dovetailed,
label: Paragraph

text: pegged, and wedged—never nailed. At the
label: Paragraph

text: bottorn of the columns, a sill beam was
label: Paragraph

text: designed with a groove in it into which the
label: Paragraph

text: lower ends of the wall planks fit. To tighten
label: Paragraph

text: the structure above, a continuous belt of
label: Paragraph

text: cross-braces was sometimes added. Some
label: Paragraph

text: churches had porches on at least three sides
label: Paragraph

text: that served as a place for processions to
label: Paragraph

text: gather, or where lepers, who were otherwise
label: Paragraph

text: excluded from the sanctuary, could listen.
label: Paragraph

text: The interiors were very dark, with small strips
label: Paragraph

text: of light occasionally forcing their way from
label: Paragraph

text: openings in the west gable or from peepholes
label: Caption

text: in the walls. Religious services were intimate
label: Paragraph

text: and illuminated by candlelight. Small gold-
label: Paragraph

text: covered reliquaries, often looking like small
label: Paragraph

text: churches, held bone fragments from saints
label: Paragraph

text: and would have shimmered on the altar in
label: Paragraph

text: the dim light.
label: Paragraph

text: 12.64 Borgund Stave Church, Norway

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: vibrant shades of red and green; the visual
label: Paragraph

text: effect of the buildings would have been more
label: Paragraph

text: pronounced than today. The buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: imbued with symbolic import. The portals,
label: Paragraph

text: for example, represented the defenders of
label: Paragraph

text: the faith and were narrow so that the devil
label: Paragraph

text: could not accidentally accompany one into
label: Paragraph

text: the church. Once totaling in the hundreds, as
label: Paragraph

text: these were village churches, today there are
label: Paragraph

text: only about twenty of these unusual buildings
label: Paragraph

text: extant in various states of authenticity.

text: 12.66 Europe during the High Middle Ages
label: Caption

text: EUROPE: THE HIGH MIDDLE AGES
label: Title

text: During the 13th century, the skyline of
label: Paragraph

text: European cities underwent a profound
label: Paragraph

text: change as the spires and towers of
label: Paragraph

text: some six hundred major churches and
label: Paragraph

text: cathedrals marked the location of cities
label: Paragraph

text: in the landscape. This energetic building
label: Paragraph

text: activity was driven by a combination of
label: Paragraph

text: religious fervor and increasing wealth.
label: Paragraph

text: Income from the selling of indulgences by
label: Paragraph

text: the Roman Church was an important source
label: Paragraph

text: of financing. It was a dubious practice that
label: Paragraph

text: in the 16th century was to awaken the ire
label: Paragraph

text: of Martin Luther and eventually lead to the
label: Paragraph

text: Reformation. Another source of income
label: Paragraph

text: was sending relics on tours. The bishops of
label: Paragraph

text: Chartres, for example, sent the cathedral’s
label: Paragraph

text: relics as far away as England to solicit
label: Paragraph

text: contributions.
label: Paragraph

text: The shift in focus dates to the Synod of
label: Paragraph

text: Arras (1025), during which it was decided
label: Paragraph

text: that sculptural programs could serve to help
label: Paragraph

text: the illiterate visualize what they could not
label: Paragraph

text: understand through the written word. Statues,
label: Paragraph

text: once used only sparingly, and usually in
label: Paragraph

text: relation to aristocratic worship practices, now
label: Paragraph

text: stood row upon row along church facades.
label: Caption

text: Compared with the Norman facade of St.
label: Paragraph

text: Etienne (1067-87) in Caen, France, with its
label: Paragraph

text: small windows and imposing, solid-looking
label: Paragraph

text: wall of stone, the Basilica of St. Denis, with its
label: Paragraph

text: broad and decorated portals, seems to almost
label: Paragraph

text: float above the ground. The church was
label: Paragraph

text: begun by the Normans but was transformed
label: Paragraph

text: by Abbot Suger (1081-1155). Actively
label: Paragraph

text: engaged in France's political life, Suger
label: Paragraph

text: played a leading role in running the kingdom
label: Paragraph

text: while King Louis VI was away on a Crusade.
label: Paragraph

text: He wanted cathedrals to accommodate large
label: Paragraph

text: crowds that could then move easily past the
label: Paragraph

text: relics. He thus created for St. Denis a space
label: Paragraph

text: behind the high altar known as a chevet
label: Caption

text: (French for “headpiece”), where the church’s
label: Paragraph

text: more precious relics could be displayed.
label: Paragraph

text: It served not only to display the relics but
label: Paragraph

text: also to reinforce the spatial significance of
label: Paragraph

text: the high altar. Suger also redesigned the
label: Paragraph

text: cathedral’s facade, introducing a triple portal
label: Paragraph

text: that served as a symbol of the Trinity. The
label: Paragraph

text: Trinity had become important to theological
label: Paragraph

text: speculation in the second quarter of the
label: Paragraph

text: 12th century, and its reinstatement signified
label: Paragraph

text: support for an orthodox interpretation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Bible and for papal authority. The tyrnpanum
label: Caption

text: over the central door of St. Denis was the
label: Paragraph

text: most important element of the facade, as
label: Paragraph

text: it portrays Christ sitting in judgrnent. The
label: Paragraph

text: sculptures were once again a concession
label: Paragraph

text: to the unlettered, for few in the general
label: Paragraph

text: population at the time could read and write.
label: Paragraph

text: In this, St. Denis reflects a change in religious
label: Paragraph

text: attitudes. Whereas Romanesque cathedrals
label: Paragraph

text: were designed primarily for the elite, St.
label: Paragraph

text: Denis and later cathedrals were buildings
label: Paragraph

text: meant to appeal to the popular imagination.
label: Paragraph

text: On a more elevated plane, Abbot Suger held
label: Paragraph

text: that the religious experience was one of
label: Paragraph

text: transcendence, symbolized by disembodied
label: Paragraph

text: light. The rose window in the center of the
label: Caption

text: facade, for exarnple, was one of the first of
label: Paragraph

text: its kind—a grand wheel of light and color.
label: Paragraph

text: The function of the facade, so Suger held,
label: Paragraph

text: was to foretell the program of the interior.
label: Paragraph

text: For Suger, the use of precious materials
label: Paragraph

text: in the furnishings of the church was also
label: Paragraph

text: important, as it served as a presentiment of
label: Paragraph

text: the splendors of heaven.
label: Paragraph

text: For all these reasons, St. Denis broke new
label: Paragraph

text: ground and is thus heralded as initiating the
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic style. For the first time, features such
label: Paragraph

text: as cross-rib vaulting and flying buttresses
label: Paragraph

text: (although present in prior churches)
label: Paragraph

text: were combined into an integrated stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: statement along with sharply pointed spires,
label: Paragraph

text: a rose window, clustered columns, pointed
label: Caption

text: arches, and a stress on luminosity.
