text: 12.68 Plan: Chartres Cathedral, France
label: Caption

text: Cathedral Design
label: Title

text: In the 13th century, cathedral building was
label: Paragraph

text: by far the largest construction enterprise ever
label: Paragraph

text: attempted in Europe. Chartres Cathedral, for
label: Caption

text: example, was able to hold more than eight
label: Paragraph

text: thousand people. Technologically complex
label: Paragraph

text: and often dangerous, construction frequently
label: Paragraph

text: took many decades and sometimes hundreds
label: Paragraph

text: of years. Unlike Carolingian churches, with
label: Paragraph

text: their imposing westworks, and Ottonian
label: Paragraph

text: monastic churches, which were associated
label: Paragraph

text: with market towns and might not have had
label: Paragraph

text: a facade at all, the facades on this new
label: Paragraph

text: generation of cathedrals served as sacred
label: Paragraph

text: thresholds to a mystic interior.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the various aspects of church
label: Paragraph

text: design that changed during this period was
label: Paragraph

text: the emergence of the interior elevation of
label: Paragraph

text: the nave as an architectural unit in its own
label: Paragraph

text: right, with architects seeking to balance the
label: Paragraph

text: interplay of horizontal and vertical elements.
label: Paragraph

text: At Notre-Dame in Paris (1163-1250),
label: Paragraph

text: there are four discrete horizontal levels: the
label: Paragraph

text: ground-level arcade, over which run two
label: Caption

text: galleries—the tribune and the triforium—
label: Title

text: above which runs an upper, windowed
label: Paragraph

text: story or clerestory. The windows of these
label: Paragraph

text: cathedrals were not transparent but filled
label: Paragraph

text: with stained glass, bringing into the interior
label: Caption

text: a muted, shimmering light. To obtain the
label: Paragraph

text: soaring height that the Gothic age aspired
label: Paragraph

text: to, flying buttresses made their appearance.
label: Paragraph

text: While they achieve the desired result on the
label: Paragraph

text: inside, they tended to pose a problem on the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior. At first the flying buttresses were
label: Paragraph

text: purely structural supplements, as at St.-
label: Paragraph

text: Germain-des-Prés, where they were added as
label: Paragraph

text: reinforcements around 1180, but thereafter
label: Paragraph

text: they were integrated into the plan from the
label: Paragraph

text: start. Flying buttresses consist of a tower that
label: Paragraph

text: supplies the necessary counterweight and
label: Paragraph

text: an arch that transfers the lateral loads to the
label: Paragraph

text: tower. Because of the flying buttresses, a
label: Paragraph

text: church interior could become a spatial unit,
label: Paragraph

text: although this occurred at the expense of the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior’s legibility.
label: Paragraph

text: The epitome of the new style was Chartres
label: Paragraph

text: Cathedral (1194-1220), where on the outside
label: Paragraph

text: the nave is almost completely obscured
label: Paragraph

text: behind an intimate tangle of buttresses.
label: Paragraph

text: The interior, on the other hand, is almost
label: Paragraph

text: canyonlike. The nave elevation has only three
label: Paragraph

text: levels, permitting a strong vertical extension
label: Paragraph

text: of the bays. To compensate for the added
label: Paragraph

text: height, two flying buttresses, one over the
label: Caption

text: other, bring the load to the tower. The vaults,
label: Paragraph

text: another important Gothic element, were
label: Paragraph

text: composed of stone ribs with thin brick vaults
label: Paragraph

text: in between, stretched like taut skin. The east
label: Paragraph

text: end, with its rounded ambulatory, is modeled
label: Paragraph

text: on St. Denis but goes further, adding five
label: Paragraph

text: semicircular chapels. The piers were also
label: Caption

text: innovative. Earlier piers often were composed
label: Paragraph

text: of a cylindrical core at the level of the arcade
label: Caption

text: and thin colonettes above. Here a continual
label: Paragraph

text: line from the vault to the ground reduces
label: Paragraph

text: the visibility of the column at the arcade
label: Caption

text: level. Proportion and geometry were used
label: Paragraph

text: throughout to organize all of the elements,
label: Paragraph

text: from the small to the large. The length of the
label: Paragraph

text: church, for example, is related to the transept
label: Paragraph

text: in a ratio of 2:3; the length and width of the
label: Paragraph

text: transept is 1:2.
label: Caption

text: The town of Chartres was, at the time,
label: Paragraph

text: quite small, but among the wealthiest in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, with an important trade in textiles
label: Paragraph

text: and metalsmithing. However, financing for
label: Paragraph

text: thé cathedral came not only from the local
label: Paragraph

text: region but from nearly all sectors of France,
label: Paragraph

text: as St. Marie of Chartres had almost attained
label: Paragraph

text: the status of a national deity.
label: Paragraph

text: 12.70 Plan: Amiens Cathedral, France
label: Caption

text: Amiens and Bourges Cathedrals
label: Title

text: The development of the Gothic style was far from
label: Paragraph

text: linear. The Cathedral at Bourges (1195-1214), begun
label: Caption

text: only one year after the one at Chartres, follows a
label: Paragraph

text: slightly different model. Unlike Chartres, with its clutter
label: Paragraph

text: of buttresses, the slope of the buttresses at Bourges
label: Caption

text: corresponds to the steep slope of the roof, a rather
label: Paragraph

text: ingenious solution that, along with the absence of a
label: Paragraph

text: transept, allows the nave to be read on the outside as
label: Paragraph

text: a unified form. The chevet at the end rises in three
label: Paragraph

text: stages, with small high-peaked chapels seemingly
label: Paragraph

text: suspended between the buttresses’ piers. The interior,
label: Caption

text: with its tall arches, is not as canyonlike as Chartres
label: Paragraph

text: because the tall arches create the illusion that the wall
label: Paragraph

text: of the side aisle is the actual side of the nave.
label: Paragraph

text: At Amiens Cathedral (1220-35) the architects
label: Caption

text: were more conservative than at Bourges, following
label: Paragraph

text: the model of Chartres, with its calmer interior and
label: Paragraph

text: soaring verticality. Amiens’s impression of verticality
label: Paragraph

text: is further enhanced by the integration of the crossing
label: Paragraph

text: piers into the overall design of the nave'’s facade.
label: Paragraph

text: The division of the upper window into four segments
label: Caption

text: rather than the usual two increases the impression
label: Paragraph

text: of verticality. Its tall nave arches and high clerestory
label: Paragraph

text: windows combine elernents of Chartres and Bourges
label: Paragraph

text: while to some extent preserving the unity of the nave.
label: Paragraph

text: The calm effect of the interior combines well with the
label: Paragraph

text: luminosity of the chevet. A comparison of the sections
label: Paragraph

text: of Amiens and Bourges shows that the interior of
label: Paragraph

text: Amiens creates a greater vertical effect, which is due
label: Paragraph

text: to the lower arches along its nave and the absence
label: Paragraph

text: of a second aisle, and is aided by better illurnination.
label: Paragraph

text: The consequence is that the buttresses of Amiens
label: Paragraph

text: needed to be much higher to offset the weight, which
label: Paragraph

text: annihilates the corporeal presence of the building that
label: Paragraph

text: is still legible at Bourges.

label: Caption

text: Whereas Romanesque churches had round
label: Paragraph

text: columns in the nave, in Gothic churches from
label: Caption

text: Speyer onward, columns that were composed
label: Paragraph

text: of a columnar core with colonettes attached
label: Paragraph

text: to it began to appear. The colonettes facing
label: Paragraph

text: the nave continue upward to reach all the
label: Paragraph

text: way to the vault, whereas the colonettes on
label: Paragraph

text: the inside become part of the ribs of the
label: Paragraph

text: vaults in the side aisles. As a result, Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: supports were neither columns nor piers;
label: Paragraph

text: rather, they were columnar bundles working
label: Paragraph

text: not only in the vertical dimension but also
label: Paragraph

text: in plan, as they would seer to be squares
label: Paragraph

text: rotated 45 degrees, creating diagonals
label: Paragraph

text: through the building.

text: Notre-Dame of Reims
label: Title

text: By the second decade of the 13th century,
label: Paragraph

text: the space of the church had changed from a
label: Paragraph

text: place emphasizing the enactment of liturgical
label: Paragraph

text: processes into a more public space where
label: Paragraph

text: relics could be viewed and worshipped. On a
label: Paragraph

text: philosophical level, the discussion changed
label: Paragraph

text: from issues of liturgy to an emphasis on the
label: Paragraph

text: transcendent and dematerialized quality
label: Title

text: of light (God) and geometry (the ordered
label: Title

text: universe). Robert Grosseteste, an English
label: Paragraph

text: theologian and Bishop of Lincoln, who read
label: Paragraph

text: Greek and was familiar with Arabic scientific
label: Paragraph

text: commentaries, argued that all of human
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge stemmed from the spiritual
label: Title

text: radiance of light. Rose windows appeared in
label: Paragraph

text: almost every church, sometimes opening so
label: Paragraph

text: 12.74 West front, Amiens Cathedral
label: Caption

text: wide that they touched the frarnework of the
label: Paragraph

text: buttresses, as at France’s Auxerre Cathedral
label: Paragraph

text: (completed ca. 1234). Along with these new
label: Paragraph

text: ideas was the emergence of the cult of the
label: Paragraph

text: Virgin Mary. The mother of Christ, Mary had
label: Paragraph

text: until then played a minor role in the Christian
label: Paragraph

text: liturgy; she now captured the popular
label: Paragraph

text: imagination, and we begin to see her image
label: Paragraph

text: standing alongside those of the saints. At the
label: Caption

text: Cathedral of Notre-Dame of Reims (1211-
label: Caption

text: 90), figures of Mary were visible in every part
label: Paragraph

text: of the church, standing in not only for the
label: Paragraph

text: saints but also for the Christian church itself.
label: Paragraph

text: The building was, in comparison to Amiens,
label: Paragraph

text: more airy in its detailing. The tall windows
label: Paragraph

text: right and left of the rose window, which allow
label: Paragraph

text: a view through the building, make the upper
label: Paragraph

text: part almost seem weightless. The rosette
label: Paragraph

text: barely fits in the narrow space allocated to
label: Paragraph

text: it, and indeed the nave, though similar to
label: Paragraph

text: that of Amiens, is considerably narrower in
label: Paragraph

text: Exeter Cathedral
label: Title

text: The transition from the Romanesque to
label: Title

text: the early Gothic lies to some degree in
label: Paragraph

text: the systematization of the nave elevation
label: Title

text: and in the integration of the nave with rib
label: Paragraph

text: vaulting. By 1300, architects, increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: confident, began to explore the decorative
label: Paragraph

text: qualities inherent in structure, creating
label: Paragraph

text: styles that historians variously call
label: Paragraph

text: Decorated, Perpendicular, or Flamboyant
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic. Scholars have long wondered if the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of this new stylistic direction
label: Title

text: coincided with increased contacts with the
label: Paragraph

text: East. It is known, for example, that England's
label: Paragraph

text: Edward | (r. 1272-1307) sent an emissary
label: Paragraph

text: to Persia. At any rate, Exeter Cathedral
label: Paragraph

text: (1280-1300) shows a decorative unity and a
label: Paragraph

text: ullness that earlier cathedrals did not have.
label: Paragraph

text: he lower facade has become a veritable
label: Paragraph

text: curtain displaying the figures of the saints.
label: Caption

text: (The innumerable saints often have a special
label: Paragraph

text: day allocated to them, and a child born on a
label: Paragraph

text: specific saint’s day would often receive that
label: Paragraph

text: saint’s name.) The gallery of saints at Exeter,
label: Caption

text: with its abstract crenellations, stands as an
label: Paragraph

text: almost independent screen in front of the
label: Paragraph

text: building. On the inside, the crisply folded
label: Paragraph

text: geometries of early 13th-century vaults have
label: Paragraph

text: been replaced by the rippling shapes of fan
label: Paragraph

text: vaulting, the origin of which is not known.
label: Paragraph

text: 12.78 Tierceron vaulting, Exeter Cathedral
label: Caption

text: Buildings in this style do not represent
label: Paragraph

text: a deterioration of the Gothic style, as is
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes held; rather, they demonstrate a
label: Paragraph

text: desire to integrate decoration and structure.
label: Paragraph

text: One factor that contributed to the change was
label: Paragraph

text: the fashion for more luminous interiors and
label: Paragraph

text: more frequent use of white or clear glass,
label: Paragraph

text: which enhanced the subtleties of a building's
label: Paragraph

text: surface treatment. Furthermore, in England
label: Paragraph

text: at least, cathedral builders did not aspire to
label: Paragraph

text: the great heights that were typical of French
label: Paragraph

text: churches, preferring instead wider windows,
label: Paragraph

text: lower buildings, and taller steeples. Early
label: Paragraph

text: 14th-century English cathedrals therefore
label: Paragraph

text: tended to have more coherent and yet more
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic silhouettes. This can be seen at the
label: Paragraph

text: presbytery of Gloucester Cathedral (ca. 1350).
label: Caption

text: Unlike those parts of the building that were
label: Paragraph

text: already finished, the new extension, actually
label: Paragraph

text: a structure unto itself, has huge windows
label: Paragraph

text: that are clearly visible on the outside. The
label: Paragraph

text: buttresses are kept tight to the body of the
label: Paragraph

text: church. On the interior, facing the apse, the
label: Caption

text: lightness and paperiness of the architecture
label: Title

text: has been so deraterialized that nothing is
label: Paragraph

text: left except a thin filigree grid of supports.
label: Paragraph

text: The new direction received its grandest
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation at the Cathedral of Milan
label: Caption

text: (begun 1387), a wide building with a vast
label: Paragraph

text: orchestration of vertical elements in white
label: Caption

text: marble, reaching a crescendo in an octagonal
label: Paragraph

text: tower that rises almost magically from the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the building.

text: Italian Town Halls
label: Title

text: In Italy, in the wake of faltering imperial
label: Paragraph

text: control, a population explosion, and an
label: Paragraph

text: expansion of markets, the artisans, guild
label: Title

text: members, and merchants known collectively
label: Paragraph

text: as the popofo banded together with men of
label: Paragraph

text: rank and property to dominate the political
label: Title

text: system. The rise of the popofo was rapid. In
label: Paragraph

text: Milan, in 1190, the popofo, the main source
label: Paragraph

text: of communal revenues, were entitled to
label: Paragraph

text: only one-fifth of government positions. By
label: Paragraph

text: 1198, they were the dominant political force
label: Paragraph

text: in the city. Often the first acts of the popofo
label: Paragraph

text: were to pass tax reform, systematize the law
label: Paragraph

text: courts, and set up controls on public monies.
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning with Pisa in the 1080s, Bologna in
label: Paragraph

text: 1123, and Florence in 1138, these fledgling
label: Paragraph

text: city governments laid the groundwork for an
label: Paragraph

text: urban consciousness that was to becorne the
label: Paragraph

text: hallmark of Italian politics for the next two
label: Title

text: centuries. The formal acceptance of this new
label: Paragraph

text: arrangement came in the form of the Peace
label: Paragraph

text: of Constance (1183), a much overlooked
label: Paragraph

text: treaty that paved the way for the modern
label: Paragraph

text: notion of civic governance. With the German
label: Paragraph

text: emperors no longer in a position to assert
label: Title

text: their power, they gave the northern Italian
label: Paragraph

text: cities the right to elect their own consuls, to
label: Paragraph

text: govern their own lands, and most importantly,
label: Paragraph

text: to make their own laws.
label: Paragraph

text: Central to the new notion of governance
label: Title

text: was a town hall in front of a public piazza
label: Paragraph

text: (campo) where people could assemble. There
label: Paragraph

text: was often also a special building for the head
label: Paragraph

text: of the militia and police. For the first time
label: Paragraph

text: in centuries—perhaps since the days of the
label: Paragraph

text: 12.81 Town Hall, Gubbio
label: Caption

text: Romans—buildings were conceived and
label: Paragraph

text: constructed as an ensemble with a public
label: Paragraph

text: space. The earliest town halls date to the
label: Paragraph

text: end of the 12th century and are at Brescia,
label: Paragraph

text: Verona, Modena, Pavia, and Bergamo. These
label: Paragraph

text: were followed in the 13th century by town
label: Paragraph

text: halls at Volterra, Todi, Como, Ferrara, Siena,
label: Caption

text: and Gubbio, among others. Most of these
label: Paragraph

text: halls followed a simple prototype: a large
label: Paragraph

text: meeting hall on the upper floor, with large
label: Caption

text: windows facing the piazza and a balcony
label: Caption

text: from which proclamations could be read.
label: Paragraph

text: The ground floor was often open or had a
label: Paragraph

text: loggia where silversmiths, gold traders, or
label: Paragraph

text: other highly skilled craftsmen and merchants
label: Title

text: could work under the direct protection and
label: Paragraph

text: supervision of the city. In the urban complex
label: Paragraph

text: of Gubbio, the town hall and palace face
label: Caption

text: each other across a piazza that is raised on
label: Paragraph

text: a high undercroft looking out over the valley
label: Paragraph

text: below. The new town halls were coordinated
label: Paragraph

text: urbanistically with the cathedral buildings that
label: Paragraph

text: were begun first at Pisa in 1063, followed by
label: Paragraph

text: Modena in 1099, Verona in 1139, and Siena
label: Paragraph

text: in 1196. The situation was, however, rarely
label: Paragraph

text: peaceful. Milan, Brescia, and Piacenza were
label: Paragraph

text: often at war with each other, as were Pisa,
label: Paragraph

text: Genoa, and Lucca.
label: Paragraph

text: Siena
label: Title

text: In the 13th century, Siena, one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most important cities in Italy, controlled
label: Paragraph

text: the southern Tuscan wool industry and
label: Title

text: dominated the trade routes between France
label: Paragraph

text: and Rome. It was also home to Italy’s richest
label: Paragraph

text: banks. Siena’s power reached a zenith with
label: Paragraph

text: the defeat of a much superior Florentine
label: Title

text: army at the battle of Montaperti in 1260.
label: Paragraph

text: The city then embarked on unrivaled urban
label: Paragraph

text: redevelopment, building a cathedral, a
label: Paragraph

text: campo, and the town hall. The campo was
label: Paragraph

text: constructed more or less at the center of the
label: Paragraph

text: city, on unclaimed land that sloped steeply
label: Paragraph

text: into a ravine. A large terrace was built over
label: Paragraph

text: the ravine to form the campo. At the steep
label: Paragraph

text: end, a town hall was constructed—the
label: Paragraph

text: Palazzo Pubblico (1297-1310)—with four
label: Caption

text: stories facing the campo and elegantly
label: Paragraph

text: proportioned reception and councilor rooms,
label: Caption

text: many decorated with frescoes recounting
label: Paragraph

text: important events in the city’s history. The
label: Paragraph

text: curve of the piazza is lined with a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: row of palace fronts, most dating from the
label: Caption

text: 14th century. Opposite the town hall is
label: Caption

text: the Loggia della Mercanzia (1417), for the
label: Caption

text: merchants. The Duomo (1196-1215) a few
label: Paragraph

text: blocks away dominates the town’s silhouette.
label: Paragraph

text: As was common in Italy, areas of towns were
label: Paragraph

text: organized around mendicant churches.
label: Paragraph

text: In this case the principal ones are San
label: Paragraph

text: Domenico (1226), Sant'Agostino (1258), and
label: Paragraph

text: San Francesco (1326-1475).
label: Paragraph

text: 12.82 Aerial view: Piazza del Campo, Siena, Italy 12.83 Palazzo Pubblico, Siena
label: Caption

text: The city’s prosperity carne to an abrupt halt
label: Paragraph

text: with the arrival of the Black Plague, which
label: Paragraph

text: reached Siena in 1348; by the end of that
label: Paragraph

text: year, two-thirds of Siena’s one hundred
label: Paragraph

text: thousand citizens had succumbed. The city
label: Paragraph

text: never recovered; what we see today is a
label: Paragraph

text: snapshot of a late medieval Italian city.

text: Mendicant Orders
label: Title

text: At the beginning of the 13th century,
label: Paragraph

text: the Roman Church saw its theological
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation and hierarchical structure
label: Title

text: threatened by a series of so-called heresies,
label: Paragraph

text: several of which revolved around an
label: Paragraph

text: interpretation of the Gospels that held that
label: Paragraph

text: access to the divine was through personal
label: Paragraph

text: emulation of the deeds of Christ rather than
label: Paragraph

text: through the complex liturgical demands of
label: Paragraph

text: the church. Small wonder that this reading
label: Paragraph

text: of the Gospels displeased the church
label: Title

text: fathers, who initially felt threatened by it. St.
label: Paragraph

text: Francis of Assisi was on the verge of being
label: Paragraph

text: branded just such a heretic in 1206 when he
label: Paragraph

text: abandoned his privileged worldly life, became
label: Paragraph

text: an ascetic, and preached the gospel of
label: Paragraph

text: poverty. But Pope Innocent Ill, eager to bring
label: Paragraph

text: the poverty sects under his control, allowed
label: Paragraph

text: St. Francis to preach and informally approved
label: Paragraph

text: his efforts in 1209 (and then officially in
label: Paragraph

text: 1223), hoping to avoid a possible schism.
label: Paragraph

text: Thus was born one of several mendicant
label: Paragraph

text: orders that radically transformed church
label: Title

text: history and was to lead, some centuries
label: Paragraph

text: later, to the Reformation triggered by the
label: Paragraph

text: preachings of the German monk Martin
label: Title

text: Luther.
label: Paragraph

text: In the early Middle Ages, reclusive
label: Paragraph

text: monastics preferred their monasteries in
label: Paragraph

text: the quiet isolation of the countryside as
label: Paragraph

text: a counterweight to what they saw as the
label: Paragraph

text: decadence of Roman cities. As a result,
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants of cities and villages often had
label: Paragraph

text: to walk long distances to go to a church
label: Paragraph

text: and were thus remote from the cosmic
label: Paragraph

text: principles that united thern as members of
label: Paragraph

text: the Christian faith. The mendicant orders
label: Paragraph

text: responded by setting up their monasteries
label: Paragraph

text: in the hearts of cities or just outside their
label: Paragraph

text: gates to make themselves humbly serviceable
label: Paragraph

text: and approachable; in many places,
label: Paragraph

text: religious services were both physically and
label: Paragraph

text: conceptually within reach of the majority
label: Paragraph

text: of Christians for the first time. Mendicant
label: Paragraph

text: monasteries were not sites of calm reflection
label: Paragraph

text: as Cistercian monasteries were, but served
label: Paragraph

text: more as dormitories for the monks, who
label: Paragraph

text: would leave in the morning to perform various
label: Paragraph

text: duties. The Franciscans became specialists
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture and construction, helping to
label: Paragraph

text: build fortification walls and infrastructure. The
label: Paragraph

text: Dominicans, another mendicant order, were
label: Paragraph

text: known as doctors, lawyers, and teachers,
label: Paragraph

text: and many became well-known philosophers.
label: Paragraph

text: They were also closely associated with the
label: Paragraph

text: development of Scholasticism during the
label: Title

text: 13th century and were prominent at the
label: Paragraph

text: great universities of Europe. In a sense, the
label: Paragraph

text: 13th century can be seen as the second
label: Paragraph

text: Christianization of Europe. If the first was
label: Paragraph

text: fought in the name of (often forcible)
label: Paragraph

text: conversion and was largely dynastic in
label: Paragraph

text: structure, the second was based on broad
label: Paragraph

text: outreach and popular appeal.
label: Paragraph

text: Because mendicants had sworn an oath
label: Paragraph

text: to poverty and consequently had no money,
label: Paragraph

text: their churches were usually built for them by
label: Paragraph

text: citizens. At first many were simple structures
label: Paragraph

text: or converted barns. By 1250, there were
label: Paragraph

text: 12.86 Plan: St. Croce
label: Caption

text: Franciscan communities in alrnost every city
label: Title

text: in France, Germany, and Italy. Mendicant
label: Paragraph

text: churches were by definition simple and
label: Paragraph

text: austere. The great ebullient forms of the
label: Paragraph

text: cathedrals were spurned. The Dominican
label: Paragraph

text: Church in Toulouse (1275-92), for example,
label: Paragraph

text: had no flying buttresses and was built entirely
label: Paragraph

text: of brick. At the Franciscan church of St.
label: Caption

text: Croce (begun 1294), the architect Arnolfo di
label: Paragraph

text: Cambio spurned vaulting and re-created the
label: Paragraph

text: vast emptiness of Constantinian naves in a
label: Paragraph

text: spare Gothic idiom. In many Italian towns,
label: Paragraph

text: mendicant churches to this day are large
label: Paragraph

text: plain brick buildings.

label: Paragraph

text: Given the decline of Mohammed |’s

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Christians—the architects had to make do

label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, stone was limited to columns
label: Paragraph

text: and important ornaments, while much of the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: was in the form of intricately carved and
label: Paragraph

text: painted stucco (sadly reduced to all-white in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and a highly developed style of calligraphy
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: The original purpose of most rooms can
label: Paragraph

text: be extrapolated from the inscriptions on
label: Paragraph

text: their walls. The palace was designed as a
label: Paragraph

text: dense network of rooms, mediated by two
label: Paragraph

text: large patio-gardens placed at right angles
label: Caption

text: to each other and defining two separate
label: Paragraph

text: areas, a public/political zone and a private
label: Paragraph

text: zone. The Court of the Myrtles, with its long
label: Paragraph

text: reflecting pool, served as the center of the
label: Paragraph

text: political activities. It focused on the Hall of
label: Paragraph

text: the Ambassadors, a square room with a high
label: Paragraph

text: and richly ornamented ceiling. The Court of
label: Caption

text: the Lions, by contrast, was the private court
label: Paragraph

text: for the queen and a place for banquets. It
label: Paragraph

text: was the more elaborate of the two courts.
label: Paragraph

text: Delicate rose-white columns with subtle axial
label: Caption

text: connections set up a colonnade around the
label: Paragraph

text: entire court, which has four channels of water
label: Paragraph

text: representing the four “rivers of paradise”
label: Paragraph

text: extending cardinally within the columnar
label: Paragraph

text: portico to a fountain held up by stone lions.
label: Caption

text: Ashlar stones were used at the gates and
label: Paragraph

text: to reinforce the corners of the walls. The
label: Paragraph

text: outside walls were stuccoed and sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: painted to simulate stone or brick. The
label: Paragraph

text: marble columns are sometimes structural,
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes decorative. The whiteness and
label: Paragraph

text: thinness of the columns give them an elegant
label: Paragraph

text: quality unknown even to the ancient Romans.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the shafts of the columns were left
label: Paragraph

text: plain, the capitals were painted in bright
label: Paragraph

text: colors. The harsh, white marble flooring of
label: Paragraph

text: the Court of the Lions visible today is a recent
label: Paragraph

text: addition. Originally the court was more of a
label: Paragraph

text: garden planted with ornamental orange trees.
label: Paragraph

text: Representation of the human form is
label: Paragraph

text: forbidden in Islamic religious buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: but geometrical designs are commonplace.
label: Paragraph

text: Squares and rectangular formations produced
label: Title

text: by the rotation of a radius from the base of
label: Paragraph

text: the bisecting hypotenuse form the basis of
label: Paragraph

text: most of the Alhambra’s construction, in both
label: Paragraph

text: plan and elevation. The two-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: ornament covers the colorful tile work that
label: Paragraph

text: rises up from the bottom of the wall to about
label: Paragraph

text: 4 feet. Geometric complexity is particularly
label: Paragraph

text: evident in the ceiling of the Hall of the Two
label: Caption

text: Sisters, an intimate banqueting room.

text: TOLTEC EMPIRE
label: Title

text: From the Sth to the late 12th centuries,
label: Paragraph

text: the Toltecs, with their capital at Tula,
label: Paragraph

text: located farther north than any previous
label: Paragraph

text: pre-Columbian Central American capital,
label: Title

text: were the determining force of the region,
label: Paragraph

text: taking over the role that had once been
label: Paragraph

text: Teotihuacan’s. They adopted an aggressive
label: Paragraph

text: militaristic stance and practiced human
label: Title

text: sacrifice extensively. No subsequent dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: failed to claim Toltec ancestry. Their myth of
label: Paragraph

text: Quetzalcoatl (the “Plumed Serpent”) was the
label: Paragraph

text: likely cause of the Aztec’s acceptance of the
label: Paragraph

text: Spaniard Hernan Cortés in the 16th century,
label: Paragraph

text: when the latter’s arrival was mistaken as the
label: Paragraph

text: prophesied return of Quetzalcoatl.
label: Paragraph

text: Tula had a population of about forty
label: Paragraph

text: thousand by 1100 CE. The Toltec architects
label: Caption

text: designed within established methods, such
label: Paragraph

text: as placing buildings around large plazas,
label: Paragraph

text: using many-tiered platforms as bases,
label: Paragraph

text: building newer structures atop older ones,
label: Paragraph

text: and painting colorful motifs on building
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces. Their main sacred complex sat on
label: Paragraph

text: a high artificial terrace, with the central plaza
label: Paragraph

text: occupying an area 100 by 100 meters partly
label: Paragraph

text: enclosed by pyramids, palaces, and ball
label: Paragraph

text: courts. The substructure to Tula’s pyramid
label: Paragraph

text: was covered with thick white stucco, which
label: Paragraph

text: may have symbolized the underworld.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the temple at the top of the pyramid
label: Paragraph

text: was destroyed, the stone columns that
label: Paragraph

text: supported the roof still remain; they were
label: Paragraph

text: carved with images of Toltec warriors. Unique
label: Caption

text: to Tula was the Coatepantli, or Snake Wall—a
label: Paragraph

text: CHICHEN ITZA
label: Title

text: The architectural ideas of Tula were
label: Paragraph

text: reproduced and refined in Chichén Itza, the
label: Paragraph

text: main city-state of the Yucatan Peninsula
label: Title

text: in the 12th century. Because the city is
label: Paragraph

text: very far from Tula, the mechanics of the
label: Paragraph

text: influence between the two are still a subject
label: Paragraph

text: of discussion. The sudden efflorescence
label: Paragraph

text: of Toltec architecture in Chichén Itza has
label: Paragraph

text: led some to speculate that the exiled Toltec
label: Paragraph

text: ruler, Topiltzin Quetzalcoatl, ray have settled
label: Paragraph

text: there. Although sacrifice and a militaristic
label: Paragraph

text: stance were central to the Itza elites, their
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial complex was much more about
label: Paragraph

text: the cosmic calendar and its measurement
label: Title

text: and meaning.
label: Paragraph

text: The complex is organized around two
label: Paragraph

text: cenotés, the Mayan word for the deep,
label: Paragraph

text: water-filled sinkholes that the Itza associated
label: Paragraph

text: with the underworld. These sinkholes are
label: Paragraph

text: scattered across the Yucatan. The name
label: Paragraph

text: Chichén fiza, in fact, means “the opening
label: Paragraph

text: of the wells of the Itza.” Since the soil and
label: Paragraph

text: rock in the region is porous and does not
label: Paragraph

text: hold water well, the eerie underground
label: Title

text: pools had both a practical and a religious
label: Paragraph

text: meaning. Of the two in the city, the southern
label: Paragraph

text: one was used for drinking water, and the
label: Paragraph

text: northern one, connected to the surface by a
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial path, was used for sacrifices. The
label: Paragraph

text: main structure, however, was the caracol,
label: Paragraph

text: or observatory; it is circular, on a trapezoidal
label: Paragraph

text: base, and raised on a rectangular platform.
label: Paragraph

text: Its walls have tiny openings that allowed the
label: Paragraph

text: priests to track the movernent of various

text: The northern complex is designed around

text: mound, known as the casti/fo. It hides within

text: was accessed by a single stair. The temple,

text: chacmool, was carefully interred in the
label: Paragraph

text: reconstruction, or the symbolic “reskinning,”
label: Paragraph

text: of the platform mound.
label: Paragraph

text: Besides being a sacrificial temple, the
label: Paragraph

text: castillo also functioned as a solar calendar.
label: Paragraph

text: It has 91 steps on three sides and 92 steps
label: Paragraph

text: on the northern side, for a total of 365
label: Paragraph

text: steps, one for each day in the solar year.
label: Paragraph

text: It is almost exactly aligned to the cardinal
label: Paragraph

text: directions to enable the observation of solar
label: Paragraph

text: events on solstices and equinoxes. The
label: Paragraph

text: castillo’s best known calendar effect occurs
label: Paragraph

text: on the equinoxes, when the balustrade of
label: Paragraph

text: its northern stairway casts seven isosceles
label: Paragraph

text: triangles as shadows that link together to
label: Paragraph

text: form the body and tail of a serpent, with its
label: Paragraph

text: head sculpted at the base of the stair. This
label: Caption

text: is presumably a depiction of the ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: descent of Kukulkan, the Itza’s name for
label: Paragraph

text: Quetzalcoatl, from the sky.
label: Paragraph

text: The chacmooi was a Tula invention. These
label: Paragraph

text: post-Classical Mayan stone statues depict a
label: Paragraph

text: human figure reclining face up, its legs drawn
label: Paragraph

text: in, its elbows on the ground, with its upper
label: Paragraph

text: back raised and its head turned to a near
label: Paragraph

text: right angle. It holds a vessel, disk, or plate
label: Paragraph

text: on its stomach, where offerings may have
label: Paragraph

text: been placed or sacrifices carried out. (It is
label: Paragraph

text: presumed that the hearts of sacrificed victims
label: Paragraph

text: were placed in the vessel.) Although the
label: Paragraph

text: origins of the chacmoo/ are undetermined,
label: Paragraph

text: they proliferated during Tula times. Twelve
label: Paragraph

text: have been found at Tula, fourteen at Chichén
label: Paragraph

text: Itza, and two more in the Aztec capital,
label: Paragraph

text: Tenochtitlan. The ancient name for this type
label: Paragraph

text: of sculpture is unknown.

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: The year 1400 more or less marks the end
label: Paragraph

text: of the great migratory conquests from the
label: Title

text: Russian steppes into Europe. The arrows
label: Paragraph

text: on the maps showing the Gauls, the Huns,
label: Paragraph

text: the Turks, the Mongolians, and other tribes
label: Title

text: from the steppes are no longer there;
label: Paragraph

text: the Eurasian world for the first time in a
label: Paragraph

text: thousand years was not beset by migratory
label: Paragraph

text: invaders. Civilizations responded by building
label: Paragraph

text: walls, from the Long Wall in China to the
label: Paragraph

text: Roman Wall at Limez. Then, as now, the
label: Paragraph

text: impact of these walls was more symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: than functional—they defined limits and
label: Paragraph

text: joundaries, rather than successfully keeping
label: Paragraph

text: the “barbarians” at bay. The impact of the
label: Paragraph

text: invaders had not been all negative; within
label: Paragraph

text: a short time period, the respective tribes
label: Paragraph

text: ad adapted and started to make their own
label: Paragraph

text: contributions, from the Huns in eastern
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, who converted to Christianity; to the
label: Paragraph

text: Yuan in China, who merged their Buddhist-
label: Paragraph

text: shamanistic ways with Confucian thoughts
label: Title

text: and manners; to the Khanates in West Asia
label: Title

text: who adopted and transformed the new ways
label: Title

text: of Islam. The steppes invaders also cleaned
label: Paragraph

text: up and linked the short- and long-distance
label: Title

text: land-based trade routes, particularly along
label: Paragraph

text: the Silk Route, so that within a brief span
label: Paragraph

text: of time, renewed civilizational and aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: imperatives were underway.
label: Paragraph

text: It is perhaps a great irony of history
label: Paragraph

text: that the famous European oceangoing
label: Paragraph

text: explorations and migratory conquests
label: Title

text: also began in this century, beginning with
label: Paragraph

text: Columbus’s unexpected encounter with
label: Title

text: the Americas. The colonial age ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: decimated the commercial viability of the
label: Paragraph

text: Silk Route, but remember that the initiative
label: Paragraph

text: to search for an alternative ocean route to
label: Paragraph

text: India and the East was not initiated as a
label: Paragraph

text: great voyage of “discovery.” Rather, it was
label: Paragraph

text: the Spanish crown’s desperate effort to find
label: Title

text: an alternative to the high prices charged by
label: Paragraph

text: the new gatekeepers of the Silk Route, the
label: Paragraph

text: Ottomans. Spices from the trade route were
label: Paragraph

text: necessary not for occasional exotic fare, but
label: Paragraph

text: to preserve meat. Ferdinand and Isabella,
label: Paragraph

text: bankrupt from their long wars against the
label: Paragraph

text: Moors, financed Christopher Columbus, an
label: Paragraph

text: Italian, to counter the forces of the Ottoman
label: Paragraph

text: Empire that, in collaboration with the northern
label: Paragraph

text: Italians, had a stranglehold on Silk Route
label: Paragraph

text: trade. The Ottomans, upset over the loss of
label: Paragraph

text: Andalusia, were particularly hostile to the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish. The northern Italian city-states and
label: Paragraph

text: universities, in correspondence with those of
label: Paragraph

text: the Islamic world, had long known that the
label: Paragraph

text: world was round and thus that a sea route to
label: Paragraph

text: India from the West was a near certainty. The
label: Paragraph

text: only remaining doubt was about its distance.
label: Paragraph

text: Geometry suggested that no 15th-century
label: Paragraph

text: European ship was robust enough to
label: Paragraph

text: undertake that journey. It was only an error in
label: Paragraph

text: translation that convinced Columbus that he
label: Paragraph

text: could reach India in about the half the time
label: Paragraph

text: that it would have actually taken. While his
label: Paragraph

text: Italian compatriots, who profited significantly
label: Paragraph

text: by the Silk Route spice trade, were not
label: Paragraph

text: interested financing his missions, Columbus
label: Paragraph

text: found his backers in the Spanish, who were
label: Paragraph

text: willing to take an unlikely gamble.
label: Paragraph

text: Some scholars date from 1492 the
label: Paragraph

text: Anthropocene age, the present geological
label: Title

text: period in which human activity has come to
label: Paragraph

text: lecisively affect climate, the biosphere, and
label: Paragraph

text: geology. One marker of its onset is the titanic
label: Paragraph

text: encounter, engineered by humans, between
label: Paragraph

text: the microbes of Eurasia and the Americas
label: Title

text: that occurs at this moment. While 95 percent
label: Paragraph

text: of the 20 million or so inhabitants of the
label: Paragraph

text: Americas died from exposure to Eurasian
label: Title

text: iseases, particularly smallpox, a negligible
label: Paragraph

text: number of Europeans died from American
label: Title

text: iseases, mostly syphilis. It seems that the
label: Paragraph

text: long commerce between the distinctive
label: Title

text: communities of Eurasia and Africa, and
label: Paragraph

text: the even longer tradition of close living with
label: Paragraph

text: animals, had made Eurasians much more
label: Paragraph

text: resilient to disease than their American
label: Paragraph

text: counterparts. The Black Plague, for instance,
label: Paragraph

text: had just ravaged its way across Eurasia,
label: Paragraph

text: killing almost 10 percent of the population
label: Paragraph

text: from China to Europe, which of course
label: Paragraph

text: countered the effects of global trade—but it
label: Paragraph

text: also ultimately improved the immune systems
label: Paragraph

text: of the survivors.
label: Paragraph

text: This microbial imbalance, aided
label: Paragraph

text: of course by Spanish and Portuguese
label: Title

text: determination to exploit, perrnanently negated
label: Paragraph

text: any counterfactual possibility of a grand
label: Paragraph

text: merger of civilizations, producing instead
label: Paragraph

text: an essentially unilateral history of conquest
label: Title

text: and colonization. This was a significant loss
label: Paragraph

text: because the American civilizations, at that
label: Paragraph

text: time, were booming. By the middle of the
label: Paragraph

text: 13th century, most of North America was
label: Paragraph

text: inhabited by dozens of tribes whose villages
label: Paragraph

text: dotted the landscape. Meanwhile, in Central
label: Paragraph

text: America, the Toltecs had been displaced by a
label: Paragraph

text: new migrant group from the north, known as
label: Paragraph

text: the Mexica (from whom comes the modern
label: Paragraph

text: name Mexico), who settled into the central
label: Paragraph

text: valley of Mexico, establishing new cities.
label: Paragraph

text: After two centuries of conflict, the city of
label: Paragraph

text: enochea concluded a military alliance with
label: Paragraph

text: the Acolhua of Texcoco and the Tepanecs
label: Title

text: of Tlacopan, forming a powerful bloc linking
label: Paragraph

text: most of central Mexico. Their capital was
label: Paragraph

text: enochtitlan, the site of contemporary
label: Title

text: Mexico City, a dramatic city on an island
label: Title

text: within a lake, connected to the mainland
label: Paragraph

text: by causeways. Cortés’s descriptions of
label: Paragraph

text: enochtitlan, even as it was being decimated
label: Paragraph

text: by disease, were depicted in one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: circulated woodcuts of the time in Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: Farther south, the Chimu kingdom
label: Title

text: controlled the territories of coastal South
label: Paragraph

text: America in the 13th and 14th centuries. Here
label: Paragraph

text: they had exploited the arid climate to build
label: Paragraph

text: the largest city ever made purely from adobe,
label: Paragraph

text: an ancient type of sundried brick made of
label: Paragraph

text: clay, sand, and water with some straw mixed
label: Paragraph

text: in. In the middle of the 15th century, the
label: Paragraph

text: Chimus were displaced by upstart rulers
label: Paragraph

text: from the highlands of Peru, the Inca, with
label: Paragraph

text: their capital in Qosqo (Cuzco). In their short
label: Paragraph

text: life before they fell to the Spanish, the Inca
label: Paragraph

text: dominated the trade routes of coastal South
label: Paragraph

text: America, constructed long rope bridges, and
label: Paragraph

text: built roads and cities with some of the most
label: Paragraph

text: intricate and precise random rubble masonry
label: Paragraph

text: ever to be seen in history. The Incas did not
label: Paragraph

text: use the wheel, and the llama was their only
label: Paragraph

text: real beast of burden, and it seems a not very
label: Paragraph

text: hardy one at that. But their techniques of
label: Paragraph

text: weaving, which were also complex systems of
label: Paragraph

text: accounting and timekeeping, and their grasp
label: Title

text: of the interrelated mechanics of land and
label: Paragraph

text: water—what today might be called ecology—
label: Paragraph

text: enabled them to build cities that were not just
label: Paragraph

text: spectacularly sited but also integrated into
label: Paragraph

text: their natural context in ways that we are only
label: Paragraph

text: beginning to fully understand. Their concepts
label: Paragraph

text: of terracing, water management, and mass-
label: Title

text: based building evidence an epistemic
label: Paragraph

text: universe that is still beyond our grasp.
label: Paragraph

text: The Italian world of the 15th century,
label: Paragraph

text: retrospectively dubbed the Renaissance,
label: Paragraph

text: was transformed by the Ottoman capture
label: Paragraph

text: of Constantinople in 1453, led by Mehrned
label: Paragraph

text: Il. Propped up mostly by the Venetians
label: Paragraph

text: who benefited significantly by funneling
label: Paragraph

text: their trade through the strait of Bosphorus,
label: Paragraph

text: old Byzantium ultimately fell to the ever-
label: Paragraph

text: expanding reach of the Ottomans. After
label: Paragraph

text: dominating Silk Route trade into Europe
label: Title

text: for centuries, the loss of Constantinople
label: Paragraph

text: precipitated the decline of Venice. But that
label: Paragraph

text: also opened up opportunity for the other
label: Paragraph

text: cities of northern Italy, such as Florence
label: Paragraph

text: and Siena, which now began to actively flex
label: Paragraph

text: their economic muscle and to contemplate
label: Paragraph

text: independence and self-determination. The
label: Paragraph

text: Medici family came to dominate the banking
label: Paragraph

text: systems of Europe and controlled a major
label: Title

text: share of the Silk Route trade into Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: Numerous scholars and artisans fleeing
label: Title

text: Constantinople found new employment and
label: Paragraph

text: audiences in the houses of northern Italy.
label: Paragraph

text: With them came the old knowledge of the
label: Paragraph

text: classical world that had long been preserved
label: Paragraph

text: in the Islamic world, and which found,
label: Paragraph

text: alongside the castigation of the Church,
label: Paragraph

text: a receptive audience in the city-states of
label: Paragraph

text: northern Italy.
label: Paragraph

text: Reacquaintance with classical
label: Title

text: knowledge imported from the Islarnic world
label: Title

text: ignited the search for more—which was
label: Paragraph

text: found in the old lost libraries of Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly Switzerland. These, then,
label: Paragraph

text: were the circumstances that led to the
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual expansion and reimagining of
label: Title

text: human possibilities that we now call the
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance. This is the milieu in which
label: Paragraph

text: Brunelleschi, Alberti, Leonardo da Vinci,
label: Caption

text: and their ilk emerged as scholars and
label: Paragraph

text: original thinkers. As they reread old Greek
label: Paragraph

text: and Roman texts, they faced the standard
label: Paragraph

text: problem that all modernities face—that is,
label: Paragraph

text: how to reinvest in the past in a way that
label: Paragraph

text: suits the needs, purposes, and imaginaries
label: Paragraph

text: of the present. Theirs was a Christian
label: Paragraph

text: world that no longer knew concrete, and
label: Paragraph

text: it was perhaps fortunate for them that the
label: Paragraph

text: Italianate orthodoxy prohibited adoption of
label: Paragraph

text: the styles and structural achievements of
label: Title

text: the Gothic cathedral, so they found space
label: Paragraph

text: to test ways of adopting pagan Greek and
label: Paragraph

text: Roman intellectual, artistic, and building
label: Title

text: design concepts for new, “modern” Christian
label: Title

text: projects. Thus we get the proliferation of
label: Paragraph

text: urban cathedrals in new formal typologies,
label: Paragraph

text: some with new structural inventions to meet
label: Paragraph

text: grand ambitions, such as the gigantic dorne
label: Paragraph

text: of the Duomo in Florence. The Italians also
label: Paragraph

text: began investing in their cities, building not
label: Paragraph

text: only grand palazzi but also urban amenities,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Foundling Hospital in Florence,
label: Paragraph

text: to counter old Christian biases against cities
label: Paragraph

text: as dens of disease.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, the bounty of gold and
label: Paragraph

text: silver extracted from the Americas enabled
label: Title

text: the Spanish crown to not only consolidate
label: Paragraph

text: its hold at home but also to curry favor in
label: Paragraph

text: Rome. In competition with the northern
label: Paragraph

text: city-states, the papacy undertook a vigorous
label: Paragraph

text: new reconstruction of the Vatican building
label: Title

text: in an attempt to bridge the gap between
label: Paragraph

text: their ancient world order and the newfangled
label: Title

text: knowledge of the time. This is when artists
label: Paragraph

text: such as Bramante and Michelangelo received
label: Paragraph

text: their grand papal commissions and built their
label: Paragraph

text: formidable aesthetic reputations.
label: Paragraph

text: Competing with the authority of Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: as usual, was France, whose King Francis
label: Paragraph

text: | quickly seized the opportunity to build
label: Paragraph

text: a strategic alliance with the Ottomans to
label: Paragraph

text: create a new gateway to the Silk Route for
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. He also patronized the northern
label: Paragraph

text: Italian cognoscenti to populate his own court,
label: Paragraph

text: famously having Leonardo da Vinci move
label: Paragraph

text: to France to spend the last years of his life
label: Paragraph

text: there. Fear of disease prompted the French
label: Paragraph

text: court, unlike nobles in the Italian walled
label: Paragraph

text: cities, to live a largely rural life, building
label: Paragraph

text: country chateaux where they sought to
label: Paragraph

text: control their lands and armies via vast and
label: Paragraph

text: busy networks of communication. Later, these
label: Paragraph

text: networks and protocols of communication
label: Title

text: and governance would also prove useful in
label: Paragraph

text: organizing French colonies in the New World.
label: Paragraph

text: The Mongol invasions transferred the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the Islamic world from its original
label: Title

text: base in West Asia further to the east, in the
label: Paragraph

text: new post-Mongol kingdoms of the Ottomans
label: Title

text: in West Asia, the Safavids in Persia, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Timurids in Uzbekistan and Afghanistan.
label: Paragraph

text: The outlines of what we recognize today as
label: Paragraph

text: the complex forces at play in the West Asian
label: Paragraph

text: geopolitical sphere—from Afghanistan to
label: Title

text: Egypt—were established at this tirne.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ottomans were tribesmen who
label: Paragraph

text: negotiated the border between the Christian
label: Paragraph

text: world of Byzantium and the pre-Mongol
label: Title

text: Islamic states and who took advantage of
label: Paragraph

text: the post-Mongol chaos to unite various tribes
label: Paragraph

text: and establish a new state. “Ottoman” is the
label: Paragraph

text: anglicization of the House of Osman, which
label: Paragraph

text: is known in modern Turkish as the Osmanli
label: Paragraph

text: Empire. Osman Gazi ben Ertugrul (1258-
label: Caption

text: 1326), the founder of the Ottoman Empire,
label: Paragraph

text: was yet another of the central Asian migrants
label: Paragraph

text: who came from Turkmenistan in the middle
label: Title

text: of the 14th century to fight in local Anatolian
label: Paragraph

text: battles. Osman’s descendants captured
label: Paragraph

text: Balkan territories, united local tribesmen, and
label: Paragraph

text: put a decisive end to the Crusades.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Mehmed II firmly instituted
label: Paragraph

text: Sunni Islam in Constantinople after capturing
label: Title

text: itin 1453, he also aggressively adopted
label: Paragraph

text: Byzantine courtly life, administrative policies,
label: Title

text: and aesthetics across his empire. There was
label: Paragraph

text: broad tolerance of non-Sunnis and even
label: Paragraph

text: non-Muslims, and by the 17th century the
label: Paragraph

text: Ottomans controlled most of the Arabic Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: world along with the Balkan regions and
label: Paragraph

text: Greece. Istanbul became the largest city in
label: Paragraph

text: the world outside China. With this power, the
label: Paragraph

text: Ottomans engaged in a vigorous process of
label: Paragraph

text: building mosques along the trade routes; the
label: Paragraph

text: mosques were Byzantine by formal reference,
label: Paragraph

text: with a focus on domes and minarets.
label: Paragraph

text: To their east the Ottomans were in
label: Paragraph

text: competition with the Safavids of Persia,
label: Paragraph

text: who were also taking over from Mongol
label: Paragraph

text: regents. The Safavids established descent
label: Paragraph

text: from Safi al-Din, who was actually a mystic
label: Paragraph

text: Sufi. But the Safavids aggressively adopted
label: Paragraph

text: Shi'ite policies, including zero tolerance of
label: Paragraph

text: nonbelievers. The Safavids governed their
label: Paragraph

text: territories directly, and as a consequence,
label: Paragraph

text: unlike the Ottomans, they were unable to
label: Paragraph

text: expand their territories, but they maintained
label: Paragraph

text: a firm grip on those they did control.
label: Paragraph

text: Within their realms, the Safavids undertook
label: Paragraph

text: construction of mosques and palaces of
label: Paragraph

text: exceptional beauty.
label: Paragraph

text: To establish a counterclaim to the
label: Paragraph

text: Ottomans as the locus of the Islamic world,
label: Paragraph

text: Timur, who claimed direct descent from
label: Paragraph

text: Genghis Khan, not only launched a major
label: Paragraph

text: invasion of West Asia but also embarked on
label: Paragraph

text: a major building campaign in his capital,
label: Paragraph

text: Samarkand. With new bazaars, caravanserais,
label: Paragraph

text: and mosques, Samarkand’s location at the
label: Paragraph

text: usual crossroads of the Eurasian traffic
label: Title

text: between China, India, and West Asia made
label: Paragraph

text: it into one of the most cosmopolitan cities
label: Paragraph

text: of the time. Samarkand’s mosque achieved
label: Paragraph

text: a distinctive style by marrying the dome
label: Paragraph

text: (lifted on a high drum) with the jwan, while
label: Paragraph

text: adorning every surface with blue tile patterns
label: Paragraph

text: that reflected the sun and helped keep the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings cool.
label: Paragraph

text: The competition for influence between
label: Title

text: Samarkand and the Ottoman caliphs was
label: Paragraph

text: mirrored in the geopolitics of South Asia,
label: Paragraph

text: with the Southern “Deccan” Islamic kings
label: Title

text: working hard to establish their fidelity to the
label: Paragraph

text: distant Ottornan sultans (which is why they
label: Paragraph

text: are known as the Deccan sultanates), while
label: Paragraph

text: those further north in the Indo-Gangetic
label: Paragraph

text: Plains leaned toward Timur (who invaded
label: Paragraph

text: in 1398) and the khans. The northerners,
label: Paragraph

text: however, had to compete heavily with Hindu
label: Paragraph

text: kings and repeatedly suffered reversals
label: Title

text: in fortune, so that their architectural
label: Paragraph

text: accomplishments, though spectacular, were
label: Paragraph

text: few and far between. The Deccan sultanates,
label: Paragraph

text: on the other hand, enjoyed relatively steady
label: Paragraph

text: reigns, which, in competition with each other,
label: Paragraph

text: generated a fascinating plethora of diverse
label: Paragraph

text: architectural achievements, all of which
label: Paragraph

text: happily married imported Ottoman styles with
label: Paragraph

text: local building techniques and styles in the
label: Title

text: service of new Islamic courtly and liturgical
label: Title

text: functions. Although the Portuguese found
label: Paragraph

text: a sea route to India around South Africa in
label: Paragraph

text: 1496, just four years after Columbus's fateful
label: Paragraph

text: discovery, new European presence in India
label: Title

text: was restricted to trading and building coastal
label: Paragraph

text: seaports.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, in Southeast Asia, the Khmers
label: Paragraph

text: had gone into decline, and while their grand
label: Paragraph

text: sites were largely abandoned, the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: great ernpires was now firmly established in
label: Paragraph

text: the Southeast Asia peninsula. The Majapahit
label: Paragraph

text: and the Thai established new kingdoms that
label: Paragraph

text: continued the Khmer rereading of Hindu and
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist institutions and temples, in dialogue
label: Title

text: with those of Sri Lanka and eastern India.
label: Paragraph

text: At the eastern end of the Silk Route, the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese were undertaking a revival of their
label: Paragraph

text: own. After three centuries of “foreign” rule
label: Paragraph

text: by the Mongolian Yuan dynasty established
label: Paragraph

text: by Genghis Khan, the Han Chinese Ming
label: Caption

text: came into power in 1368. Although at first
label: Paragraph

text: the Ming sought to consolidate a rural base,
label: Paragraph

text: they quickly converted back to controlling
label: Paragraph

text: the empire from their capitals with the help
label: Paragraph

text: of their bureaucracy. The Ming actively
label: Paragraph

text: projected the Yuan as foreigner-barbarians
label: Paragraph

text: and worked hard to revive old Confucian
label: Paragraph

text: practices. And yet, as we see time and
label: Paragraph

text: again in history, the Ming did not hesitate to
label: Paragraph

text: “modernize” the past and adopt practices of
label: Paragraph

text: the Yuan that they found expedient. Thus,
label: Paragraph

text: for instance, initially the Ming built a brand-
label: Paragraph

text: new capital at Nanjing as per tradition,
label: Paragraph

text: proclaiming the establishment of a new
label: Title

text: order. But then the third Ming emperor,
label: Paragraph

text: Zhu Di (r. 1403-24), moved the main
label: Paragraph

text: capital back to Dadu, the old Yuan capital,
label: Paragraph

text: which was still flourishing, now renaming
label: Paragraph

text: it Beijing (meaning “Northern Peace”).
label: Paragraph

text: Here the Ming built the Forbidden City as
label: Paragraph

text: we know it today, incorporating a complex
label: Paragraph

text: taxonomy of sight, visibility barriers, and
label: Paragraph

text: access mediated through gates, courtyards,
label: Paragraph

text: axial pavilions, and supporting quarters.
label: Caption

text: Outside the Forbidden City, the Ming built
label: Paragraph

text: the twin Ternples of Agriculture and the
label: Title

text: Temple of Heaven Complex, which connected
label: Paragraph

text: the terrestrial realm to the celestial one.
label: Paragraph

text: While they criticized the Mongols for living
label: Paragraph

text: in “tents” in the imperial cities, the Ming
label: Paragraph

text: sought to revitalize their own old building
label: Paragraph

text: techniques, emphasizing the development of
label: Paragraph

text: the bracketing system along with techniques
label: Title

text: of glazing in construction and lacquering in
label: Paragraph

text: furniture.
label: Paragraph

text: By the middle of the 15th century, the
label: Paragraph

text: Ming had built up a stable government
label: Paragraph

text: based on renewed cultivation and trade,
label: Paragraph

text: with a population estimated at between 120
label: Paragraph

text: and 200 million people. They cultivated the
label: Paragraph

text: supportive Joseon dynasty in Korea and
label: Title

text: invested heavily in undertaking global sea
label: Paragraph

text: voyages to explore first Southeast and South
label: Title

text: Asia, and then the ports of East Africa and
label: Paragraph

text: West Asia. These seem to have been voyages
label: Paragraph

text: of arbassadorship rather than of conquest,
label: Paragraph

text: so the sense of the usual threat from
label: Paragraph

text: across the Long Wall quickly occupied the
label: Paragraph

text: government's attention at the cost of further
label: Paragraph

text: naval exploration. Later, the Ming empire was
label: Paragraph

text: to significantly benefit from the discovery of
label: Paragraph

text: the Americas, as vast quantities of gold and
label: Paragraph

text: silver were used to purchase Chinese goods
label: Paragraph

text: to be shipped back to Europe. Peppers were
label: Paragraph

text: added to Sichuan cuisine, and the mass
label: Paragraph

text: cultivation of potatoes and corn enabled large
label: Paragraph

text: populations to be fed.
label: Paragraph

text: With the development of water-powered
label: Paragraph

text: pounding mills, China had captured the
label: Paragraph

text: energy of water by the Ist or 2nd century CE.
label: Paragraph

text: This, together with the later invention of a
label: Paragraph

text: water-turned wheel for irrigation, gave China
label: Paragraph

text: an economic lead, beginning in roughly
label: Paragraph

text: 1000 CE and continuing over the next 500
label: Title

text: years. During these centuries, the Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: economy achieved levels of productivity that
label: Paragraph

text: Europe only started to attain in the 1500s. It
label: Paragraph

text: was therefore not surprising that when trade
label: Paragraph

text: began between China and Europe, fueled
label: Paragraph

text: by American silver brought to China by the
label: Paragraph

text: Europeans, the Chinese economy was more
label: Paragraph

text: productive than those of Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: But colonial contact proved to be a
label: Paragraph

text: double-edged sword; as the Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: economy became more dependent on
label: Paragraph

text: overseas currency, it also became susceptible
label: Paragraph

text: to it, and the Spanish (and Japanese) used
label: Paragraph

text: silver control policies to squeeze the Ming.
label: Paragraph

text: Considering the kind of trade taking place
label: Paragraph

text: across the world in the 1600s and 1700s
label: Title

text: and the fact that Chinese finished goods
label: Title

text: were going to Europe in return for silver, this
label: Paragraph

text: shouldn't be too great a surprise, especially
label: Paragraph

text: since the first real urban commercial
label: Title

text: dynamism within Eurasia had taken place
label: Paragraph

text: in China several centuries prior, in the Song
label: Paragraph

text: dynasty.
label: Paragraph

text: Across the East China Sea, the Japanese
label: Title

text: also sought a revival of older world orders
label: Paragraph

text: and older ties. Another unsuccessful attempt
label: Paragraph

text: by the monarchy to regain control in 1333
label: Paragraph

text: prompted the new shogun (military dictator)
label: Paragraph

text: Takauji, as a gesture of reconciliation, to
label: Paragraph

text: reinstate Kyoto as the imperial capital and
label: Paragraph

text: to reestablish connection with the Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: Song dynasty, which had been severed
label: Paragraph

text: since Kublai Khan's unsuccessful invasions
label: Title

text: of Japan in 1274 and 1281. Out of this
label: Paragraph

text: reconnection emerged the signature Zen
label: Paragraph

text: school of imperial Buddhist practice, which
label: Paragraph

text: invented the miniaturized, abstract meditation
label: Paragraph

text: gardens born from the necessity of building
label: Title

text: “nature” out of confined urban lots. Thus
label: Paragraph

text: came into being the singular beauty of sites
label: Paragraph

text: like Ginkakuji and Kinkakuji—the Golden and
label: Paragraph

text: the Silver Pavilions—built for retiring shoguns
label: Paragraph

text: in their search for the extraordinary.

text: THE AMERICAS
label: Title

text: he Americas in the 15th century were
label: Paragraph

text: far different from the Americas in the
label: Paragraph

text: 17th century after about 90 percent of
label: Paragraph

text: the continents’ population had died of
label: Paragraph

text: disease. In the 15th century, from eastern
label: Paragraph

text: Bolivia through Peru to Central America
label: Title

text: into the western United States, eastward to
label: Paragraph

text: Mississippi and Georgia, and north to what
label: Paragraph

text: is now New England, there was what the first
label: Paragraph

text: Europeans sailing down the coast of New
label: Title

text: England described as an almost continuous
label: Paragraph

text: fabric of habitation. There were major cities
label: Paragraph

text: that served as capitals of empires, like Qosqo
label: Paragraph

text: in Peru and Tenochtitlan in Mexico; there
label: Paragraph

text: were secondary cities that served as regional
label: Paragraph

text: centers, like Chan Chan in Peru; Oraibi, a
label: Paragraph

text: Hopi city in the United States; and other
label: Paragraph

text: large cities in Georgia. In between, there were
label: Paragraph

text: thousands of smaller villages. The spread
label: Paragraph

text: of diseases was so rapid that some cultures
label: Paragraph

text: disappeared even before they themselves
label: Paragraph

text: encountered the Europeans. There is
label: Paragraph

text: considerable debate about the specifics of
label: Paragraph

text: this terrible loss of life and culture, but the
label: Paragraph

text: basic parameters of the tragedy are not in
label: Paragraph

text: dispute.
label: Paragraph

text: Hopis
label: Title

text: In the 14th century, the Native Americans
label: Paragraph

text: in North America were largely seminomadic,
label: Paragraph

text: except for the major city-dwelling areas in
label: Paragraph

text: the Mississippi/Georgia region extending
label: Title

text: to the Atlantic coast, and in the Southwest
label: Paragraph

text: in areas controlled by the Hopis, who had
label: Paragraph

text: been town dwellers for many centuries. The
label: Paragraph

text: Hopi village of Old Oraibi in Arizona was
label: Paragraph

text: founded around the year 1100. Clearly, the
label: Paragraph

text: Hopis’ notion of urban culture had much
label: Paragraph

text: in common with earlier urban cultures in
label: Paragraph

text: the area dating back to the Hisatsinom and
label: Paragraph

text: Hohokam. In the period frorn 700 to 1130
label: Paragraph

text: CE there was a rapid increase in population
label: Paragraph

text: in this area due to consistent and regular
label: Paragraph

text: rainfall. In the late 13th century, however, a
label: Paragraph

text: severe drought, which seems to have put an
label: Paragraph

text: end to the nearby Hohokam culture, forced
label: Paragraph

text: the Hopis to abandon the smaller villages and
label: Paragraph

text: consolidate their population in larger urban
label: Paragraph

text: centers. When the Spanish arrived, nine
label: Paragraph

text: major towns existed: Sikyatki, Koechaptevela,
label: Paragraph

text: Kisakovi, Sichomovi, Mishongnovi, Shipaulovi,
label: Paragraph

text: Shungopavi, Oraibi, and Awatovi.

text: Hopi is a shortened form of Hopituh Shi-nu-
label: Paragraph

text: mu, “The Peaceful People” or “Peaceful Little
label: Paragraph

text: Ones.” The name reflects a concept deeply
label: Paragraph

text: rooted in the culture's religion and spirituality,
label: Paragraph

text: and even in its view of morality and ethics.
label: Paragraph

text: To be Hopi is to strive toward a state of total
label: Paragraph

text: reverence and respect for all things, to be
label: Paragraph

text: at peace with these things, and to live in
label: Paragraph

text: accordance with the instructions of Maasaw,
label: Paragraph

text: the Creator or Caretaker of Earth. The Hopis,
label: Paragraph

text: like most Native Americans, assume the
label: Paragraph

text: souls of the dead go to another part of the
label: Title

text: universe, where they have a new existence,
label: Paragraph

text: carrying on everyday activities as if they
label: Paragraph

text: were still alive. Village life revolves around
label: Paragraph

text: a series of ceremonies that are performed
label: Paragraph

text: not only for the benefit of the village but also
label: Paragraph

text: for the entire world. These ceremonies take
label: Paragraph

text: place according to the lunar calendar and
label: Paragraph

text: are observed in each of the Hopi villages.
label: Paragraph

text: As with all Pueblo cultures, most of the
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonies take place in kivas. Puebio is a
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish word derived from the Latin word
label: Paragraph

text: populus (people), and in this case means
label: Paragraph

text: “village.” Hopi cities were located at or near
label: Paragraph

text: the edges of north-south running, flat-topped
label: Paragraph

text: mountains known as mesas. The difficulty of
label: Paragraph

text: transporting water up to the towns kept their
label: Paragraph

text: populations small, but their location did allow
label: Paragraph

text: for protection, with access paths to some
label: Paragraph

text: pueblos purposely following narrow ravines.
label: Paragraph

text: Houses were made of stone and mud and
label: Paragraph

text: were often several stories high. The walls
label: Paragraph

text: were constructed of undressed stones bound
label: Paragraph

text: Inca Empire
label: Title

text: with mud plaster. Wooden beams rested on
