text: Tenochtitlan
label: Title

text: The fall of the Toltec capital of Tula (located
label: Paragraph

text: about 100 km north-northwest of Mexico
label: Paragraph

text: City) led to the founding of a number of
label: Paragraph

text: semiautonomous urban centers around
label: Title

text: Lake Texcoco. The city of Tenochtitlan (now
label: Caption

text: Mexico City) was founded by one of these
label: Paragraph

text: groups, the Mexica, on an islet in the western
label: Paragraph

text: part of the lake in the year 1325. By the
label: Paragraph

text: 14th century, war between the states had
label: Paragraph

text: become systemic, leading in 1428 to an
label: Paragraph

text: alliance between three of them that becarne
label: Paragraph

text: the basis of the Aztec Empire. (Historians
label: Paragraph

text: shy away from the term “Aztec” because it
label: Paragraph

text: only came into use in the 19th century.) At its
label: Paragraph

text: height, the empire stretched across central
label: Paragraph

text: Mexico from coast to coast. In 1521, the
label: Paragraph

text: Triple Alliance was defeated by the Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: conquistacores and their native allies under
label: Title

text: Hernan Cortés, who described the city before
label: Paragraph

text: he destroyed it; his text and drawing were
label: Paragraph

text: presented to the Spanish king and widely
label: Paragraph

text: circulated in Europe, thanks to the printing
label: Paragraph

text: press. Cortés told of a city of 200,000
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants on an island in the middle of a
label: Paragraph

text: lake, connected by causeways to the shore.
label: Paragraph

text: Gigantic stone towers dominated the city’s
label: Paragraph

text: center, at the intersection of the causeways.
label: Paragraph

text: The Mexica were originally poor and
label: Paragraph

text: peripheral to the political world of that region,
label: Paragraph

text: but under their general Tlacaélel, who
label: Paragraph

text: masterminded the Triple Alliance, the Mexica
label: Paragraph

text: altered their identity and religious worldview.
label: Paragraph

text: Politically, they modeled themselves after
label: Paragraph

text: the Toltecs and claimed descent from
label: Paragraph

text: Teotihuacan, in order to appropriate their
label: Paragraph

text: imperial claims. In terms of religion, they saw
label: Paragraph

text: the sun as engaged in a violent and perpetual
label: Paragraph

text: struggle for existence, a struggle that had to
label: Paragraph

text: be nourished by human sacrifice. Several
label: Paragraph

text: thousand were killed every year in ritual
label: Paragraph

text: sacrifices. Though later European conquerors
label: Paragraph

text: purported to be shocked at this, Europe in
label: Paragraph

text: the 17th century was in fact a significantly
label: Paragraph

text: more brutal place; tens of thousands of
label: Paragraph

text: people were hanged, quartered, burned, or
label: Paragraph

text: irmpaled—often in great public spectacles—
label: Paragraph

text: uring the various wars of religion.
label: Paragraph

text: The Mexica settled next to a swamp,
label: Paragraph

text: but were able to drain the area to create a
label: Paragraph

text: O-square-kilometer lake with an island-city
label: Paragraph

text: at the center that was linked to settlements
label: Paragraph

text: on the mainland by three raised causeways.
label: Paragraph

text: It grew to become an enormous city, much
label: Paragraph

text: larger than any European city of the time. A
label: Paragraph

text: gridded network of streets and canals teemed
label: Paragraph

text: with boats transporting goods and people to
label: Paragraph

text: its markets. Two aqueducts brought fresh
label: Paragraph

text: water into the city. The ceremonial center
label: Paragraph

text: consisted of two stepped pyramids rising
label: Paragraph

text: side by side on a huge platform painted red
label: Caption

text: and blue; nearby were palaces painted a
label: Paragraph

text: dazzling white. Not far away were schools
label: Paragraph

text: for sons of the nobility, houses for priests,
label: Paragraph

text: a ball court, an intimidating tzompantti
label: Paragraph

text: (skull rack) displaying the severed heads of
label: Paragraph

text: the sacrificed, and several other pyramids
label: Paragraph

text: and temples, all surrounded by protective
label: Paragraph

text: enclosures.
label: Paragraph

text: The main temple (Templo Mayor) had
label: Paragraph

text: large incense braziers, with serpent heads
label: Caption

text: and cauldrons on all four sides in front
label: Paragraph

text: of it to receive offerings. It rose in four
label: Paragraph

text: platforms, representative of the celestial
label: Paragraph

text: levels of the cosmos, until it reached the
label: Paragraph

text: top level with its two temples dedicated
label: Paragraph

text: to Tlaloc and Huitzilopochtli. Two parallel
label: Caption

text: stairs led separately up to the summit.
label: Paragraph

text: Huitzilopochtli, whose temple was to the
label: Paragraph

text: south, was the Mayan warrior god who fought
label: Paragraph

text: is brother Centzon Huitznahua and his sister
label: Paragraph

text: Coyolxauhqui immediately after birth. He
label: Paragraph

text: defeated them and threw their dismernbered
label: Paragraph

text: dies down the mountain, a sacrifice
label: Paragraph

text: marked by a round tablet at the foot of the
label: Caption

text: stairs. Between 1325 and 1521, Templo
label: Caption

text: Mayor was reconstructed seven times, with
label: Paragraph

text: the older temple encased intact within each
label: Paragraph

text: new larger building. Of all these, the second
label: Paragraph

text: building has survived intact, including its two
label: Paragraph

text: temples, complete with the stone to which
label: Paragraph

text: prisoners were tied before being sacrificed.
label: Paragraph

text: Like their predecessors, the Mexica were
label: Paragraph

text: dedicated observers of the sun, the stars, the
label: Paragraph

text: cycles of nature, the passing of the seasons,
label: Paragraph

text: and the death of plant and animal life. And
label: Paragraph

text: like their predecessors, their architecture
label: Paragraph

text: and rituals were intended to maintain the
label: Paragraph

text: integrity of the cosmic order. The science of
label: Paragraph

text: observation was certainly very sophisticated,
label: Paragraph

text: though today it is still incornpletely
label: Paragraph

text: understood. Templo Mayor pointed 7 degrees
label: Paragraph

text: south of east, so that on the equinoxes
label: Paragraph

text: the sun rises exactly between the temples
label: Paragraph

text: of Tlaloc and Huitzilopochtli. A monolithic
label: Paragraph

text: calendar stone 1.2 meters thick, 3.6 meters
label: Caption

text: in diarneter, and weighing over 24 tons was
label: Paragraph

text: found in 1790 under the main square. On its
label: Paragraph

text: face is a representation of the sun god.

text: Incas
label: Title

text: In the coastal valleys of northern Peru, the
label: Paragraph

text: collapse of the Wari kingdom around the year
label: Title

text: 1000 led to the emergence of the Chimu
label: Paragraph

text: (850-1470; also called the Chimor), who
label: Paragraph

text: in time came to control the entire northern
label: Paragraph

text: coast of Peru from the modern border of
label: Paragraph

text: Ecuador to Lima. Their capital, Chan Chan,
label: Paragraph

text: was spread out across a large plain of the
label: Paragraph

text: coastal desert. Because Chimu kings after
label: Paragraph

text: they died were not considered legally dead,
label: Paragraph

text: new kings built new palaces, which would
label: Paragraph

text: remain the extended family’s base after
label: Paragraph

text: that king in turn died. But Chan Chan was
label: Paragraph

text: soon subsumied into the world of the Incas.
label: Paragraph

text: Not much is known of the prehistory of the
label: Paragraph

text: Incas except that, like the Mexica, they were
label: Paragraph

text: originally a small peripheral kingdom that
label: Paragraph

text: became much more successful than those
label: Paragraph

text: around it. The Incas borrowed the Chiru
label: Paragraph

text: approach to royalty, with the exception that
label: Paragraph

text: their king, or inca, was divine. One of their
label: Paragraph

text: incas, Pachakuti, who ascended the Incan
label: Paragraph

text: throne in 1438, quickly built an empire that
label: Paragraph

text: brought the area of present-day Peru, Bolivia,
label: Paragraph

text: northern Argentina, Chile, and Ecuador under
label: Title

text: Inca control. He did this by means novel to
label: Paragraph

text: the South American political scene. In the
label: Paragraph

text: previous era, regional expansion had been
label: Paragraph

text: limited given the difficulty of marshalling
label: Paragraph

text: large armies and moving thern from place to
label: Paragraph

text: place—there were, after all, no horses. The
label: Paragraph

text: Incas expanded by more or less peacefully
label: Title

text: assimilating neighboring areas into their
label: Paragraph

text: regime, offering stability and inclusion in
label: Paragraph

text: exchange for services. Soon they were able
label: Paragraph

text: to command enormous teams of people—
label: Paragraph

text: many purposefully displaced from their
label: Paragraph

text: homelands—to build roads and palaces,
label: Paragraph

text: and work in craft industries and on farms.
label: Paragraph

text: Consolidation of the empire was more or less
label: Paragraph

text: complete by 1520. There was no money, no
label: Paragraph

text: markets, and no land ownership; all land
label: Paragraph

text: belonged to the king. It was a centralized
label: Paragraph

text: systern akin to modern socialism, except that
label: Paragraph

text: the ruling inca was a god. The result was that
label: Paragraph

text: in just over a hundred years the Incan empire
label: Paragraph

text: became the most powerful the Americas had
label: Paragraph

text: ever seen, before they were conquered by the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish and depopulated by disease.
label: Paragraph

text: 13.13 Plan: Upper temple area, Qosqo (Cuzco), Peru
label: Caption

text: Their capital was Qosqo, located in the
label: Paragraph

text: western fringe of the Peruvian highlands.
label: Paragraph

text: Four major roads of the empire terminated
label: Title

text: in its center, the Plaza of Cusipata. Under
label: Paragraph

text: Pachakuti, the first of the great Inca rulers,
label: Paragraph

text: Qosqo was transformed from a village of
label: Paragraph

text: clay and straw into a city of stone. Wedged
label: Paragraph

text: tween the Tullumayo and Huatanay Rivers,
label: Paragraph

text: the city’s plan notionally formed the body of
label: Paragraph

text: a puma or jaguar. The head was represented
label: Paragraph

text: y the fortress, the heart by the central
label: Title

text: plaza, and the tail by the confluence of the
label: Paragraph

text: two canalized rivers. The Chunchulmayo,
label: Paragraph

text: urther south, was called the “gut river,” as it
label: Paragraph

text: represented the belly of the puma. The Plaza
label: Paragraph

text: of Cusipata was surrounded by the main civic
label: Paragraph

text: structure of Qosqo, the palaces, and three
label: Caption

text: temples dedicated to the Sun (Qorikancha),
label: Paragraph

text: the Creator (Kiswarkancha), and the Thunder
label: Paragraph

text: (Pucamarka). The plaza was filled with pure
label: Paragraph

text: white sand taken from the coast, and across
label: Paragraph

text: the facades of the palaces were enormous
label: Paragraph

text: plates of polished gold, reflecting the setting
label: Paragraph

text: sun. The plaza was the center of the Inca
label: Paragraph

text: cosmos, with the four highways radiating
label: Paragraph

text: from it demarcating the four sectors of the
label: Paragraph

text: empire. Also radiating out from the city
label: Paragraph

text: was a spiderweb of forty-one crooked spirit
label: Paragraph

text: paths that connected holy features of the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape, like springs, caves, shrines, and
label: Paragraph

text: stones. The Inca calendar counted forty-one
label: Paragraph

text: weeks, each eight days long.
label: Paragraph

text: Qosqo seems to have had no defensive wall,
label: Paragraph

text: but at its “head” on the hilltop overlooking
label: Paragraph

text: the valley is an impressive structure,
label: Paragraph

text: Sacsayhuaman, presumed to have been a
label: Paragraph

text: fortress. It could also have been a ternple to
label: Paragraph

text: the sun, a water reservoir, or all of the above.
label: Paragraph

text: It has three platforms, one on top of the other,
label: Paragraph

text: followed by a triple row of toothed walls made
label: Paragraph

text: from gigantic blocks of granite. The walls
label: Paragraph

text: were precise works of engineering. Some of
label: Paragraph

text: their granite blocks weighed up to 200 tons
label: Paragraph

text: 13.15 Aerial view: Qosqo

text: Edge of mountain plateau
label: Title

text: and were shaped on site to fit exactly to their
label: Paragraph

text: neighbors. Why such precision was demanded
label: Paragraph

text: remains unknown. In many instances, the
label: Paragraph

text: massive stones simply shield the body of
label: Paragraph

text: the earth. In all cases, water was drained
label: Paragraph

text: with great care, with individual stones being
label: Paragraph

text: shaped and aligned to create a ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: series of water spouts and channels. There
label: Paragraph

text: was also a large circular meeting plaza with
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial buildings perched at the lip of the
label: Paragraph

text: cliff overlooking the city.

text: Machu Picchu
label: Title

text: Machu Picchu, 70 kilorneters northwest of
label: Caption

text: Qosqo (Cuzco), is located between two steep
label: Paragraph

text: peaks, 2,750 meters above a gorge carved
label: Caption

text: by the Urubamba River. It is the only Inca
label: Paragraph

text: settlement to have survived intact, having
label: Paragraph

text: been completely missed by the Spaniards.
label: Paragraph

text: It was probably inhabited late into the 16th
label: Paragraph

text: century, when it was gradually abandoned
label: Paragraph

text: and forgotten. There are other Inca sites
label: Paragraph

text: in this remote area, but these have yet to
label: Paragraph

text: be fully explored or understood. Some two
label: Paragraph

text: hundred buildings arranged on a series of
label: Paragraph

text: parallel terraces on both sides of a central
label: Paragraph

text: plaza constitute the core of the small
label: Paragraph

text: settlement that housed at most about a
label: Paragraph

text: thousand people.
label: Paragraph

text: Access to the site was difficult; it was a
label: Paragraph

text: long trek up the steep gorges and entry was
label: Paragraph

text: possible only from one carefully guarded
label: Paragraph

text: checkpoint. Because it was a magnificent
label: Paragraph

text: site for solar and stellar observation, some
label: Paragraph

text: have argued that the city was a royal retreat
label: Paragraph

text: or perhaps even a special temple reserved
label: Paragraph

text: for the elite. Key to the success of the site
label: Caption

text: was the artesian spring that supplied the
label: Paragraph

text: inhabitants with water year-round. The genius
label: Paragraph

text: of Machu Picchu lies in the terracing and
label: Paragraph

text: partitioning of the site, which fills a roughly
label: Paragraph

text: east-west-lying saddle between the two
label: Paragraph

text: peaks. The saddle rises sharply in the south,
label: Paragraph

text: x_Urban sector
label: Title

text: Ne
label: Title

text: and after a crest and a short flat plain slopes
label: Paragraph

text: gently down toward the north and the east.
label: Paragraph

text: It resembles a wave, with a stable spot at its
label: Paragraph

text: precarious top. To shore up the land and to
label: Paragraph

text: create spaces to build on, the Incan planners
label: Paragraph

text: constructed terraces carefully, following the
label: Paragraph

text: contours. At the eastern end, there is a sector
label: Paragraph

text: of terraces, presumably for cultivation, with a
label: Paragraph

text: complex network of irrigation channels.
label: Paragraph

text: A long central plaza, gently terracing down
label: Paragraph

text: toward the east, sets the stage. On either side
label: Paragraph

text: of this plaza, accessed by a cornplex network
label: Paragraph

text: of streets and stairs, lie the main buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: most of which are single-room dwellings,
label: Paragraph

text: clustered around courts when possible, but
label: Paragraph

text: usually arranged along narrow pathways
label: Paragraph

text: limited by the terrace widths. They are all
label: Paragraph

text: made of the characteristic finely fitted stone
label: Paragraph

text: masonry, with wedge-shaped windows and
label: Paragraph

text: monolithic lintels, and equipped with water
label: Paragraph

text: drainage and harvesting systems. The granite
label: Paragraph

text: used in the construction was quarried locally.
label: Paragraph

text: Gable ends testify to perishable roofs long
label: Paragraph

text: gone. There is, however, no evidence of any
label: Paragraph

text: adobe construction, suggesting a highly elite
label: Paragraph

text: and ceremonial function for the city. Nestled
label: Paragraph

text: within this network are some surprising
label: Paragraph

text: anomalies: a semicircular, turret-like structure
label: Paragraph

text: unexpectedly abuts the residential fabric, and
label: Paragraph

text: a series of baths line the central north-south
label: Paragraph

text: pathway.
label: Paragraph

text: 13.18 Passageway: Machu Picchu
label: Caption

text: The high southwestern edge of the saddle
label: Paragraph

text: is reserved for a temple, accessed by a long
label: Paragraph

text: stair from the east. At the foot of the stair
label: Caption

text: lies what is assumed to be a temple, with
label: Paragraph

text: three C-shaped rooms looking into a central
label: Paragraph

text: court. At the top of the stair lies the main
label: Caption

text: temple, the sacred center, dedicated to the
label: Caption

text: sun. Three steps into an antechamber lead
label: Caption

text: up to the final terrace, at the center of which
label: Paragraph

text: lies a huge granite monolith known simply as
label: Paragraph

text: the Intihuatana, or the “Hitching Post of the
label: Paragraph

text: Sun."
label: Paragraph

text: The Intihuatana stone is something of a
label: Paragraph

text: miniature Machu Picchu, with a series of
label: Paragraph

text: small “terraces” culminating in a dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: outcrop, resembling the peak just beyond.
label: Paragraph

text: Intihuatana stones are believed to have
label: Paragraph

text: once been dispersed throughout the Incan
label: Paragraph

text: world, but they were destroyed by the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish, who considered them idolatrous.
label: Paragraph

text: Their exact meaning is uncertain, but they
label: Paragraph

text: were likely miniaturized replicas of a sacred
label: Paragraph

text: peak to which the sun could be imagined to
label: Paragraph

text: be tethered by a rope, enabling its circular
label: Paragraph

text: journey through the upper and lower worlds.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps Machu Picchu's peaks were as close
label: Paragraph

text: as the Inca thought they could get to that
label: Paragraph

text: sacred peak.

label: Title

text: The Black Plague (1350-1425) carried off
label: Paragraph

text: 35 to 65 percent of the rural and urban
label: Paragraph

text: population of Italy. Only a handful of
label: Paragraph

text: European cities rebounded, among which
label: Paragraph

text: were Venice, Florence, Milan, Naples,
label: Paragraph

text: and Genoa. If one followed the Silk Route
label: Paragraph

text: westward across Asia, through the lands
label: Paragraph

text: of Timur and the Ottomans, one would
label: Paragraph

text: come to the European gateway, Venice.
label: Paragraph

text: Almost all goods traveling to Europe had
label: Paragraph

text: to pass through the port of Venice, which
label: Paragraph

text: controlled coastal trade south through the
label: Paragraph

text: Aegean Sea to Cyprus, and north into Asia
label: Title

text: via Constantinople. Taking advantage of four
label: Paragraph

text: centuries of living at the edge of papal Italy,
label: Paragraph

text: Venice had marshaled its port location to put
label: Paragraph

text: itself at the center of Mediterranean trade.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1423, the state budget of Venice was
label: Paragraph

text: equivalent to that of France and England. The
label: Paragraph

text: city, a thalassocracy, was ruled as a republic
label: Paragraph

text: 13.30 Topkapi Palace, Istanbul, Turkey
label: Caption

text: Topkapi Palace
label: Title

text: On May 29, 1453, Sultan Mehmed II captured
label: Paragraph

text: Constantinople after a fifty-three-day siege.
label: Paragraph

text: For the Europeans it was a major defeat, as
label: Paragraph

text: it brought to an end the Byzantine Empire
label: Paragraph

text: and all that it represented. For the Arab
label: Paragraph

text: armies it was a long-sought-after prize, as
label: Paragraph

text: it provided them with a major metropolis.
label: Paragraph

text: Almost immediately, work was begun on
label: Paragraph

text: the construction of mosques and other
label: Title

text: buildings, including the vast Topkapi Palace
label: Paragraph

text: (begun 1459) that served as the main royal
label: Paragraph

text: residence and seat of the imperial Ottoman
label: Title

text: administration from the second half of the
label: Title

text: 15th to the mid-19th century. The palace
label: Caption

text: was in the middle of a roughly triangular
label: Paragraph

text: shaped site that was surrounded mostly by
label: Paragraph

text: water on the north and east, while to the west
label: Paragraph

text: a high wall separated it from the rest of the
label: Paragraph

text: city. Its plan could be seen as a haphazard
label: Paragraph

text: aggregation of buildings. But this would not
label: Paragraph

text: be accurate, since it was planned according
label: Paragraph

text: to a logic related to the definition of a sultan.
label: Paragraph

text: He was seen as being beyond any relation
label: Paragraph

text: of reciprocity, and ceremonies stressed
label: Paragraph

text: the unbridgeable gap between master and
label: Paragraph

text: subject, thus the insistence in this palace
label: Paragraph

text: on the privacy of the sultan. The Moghuls,
label: Paragraph

text: elaborating on Timurid and Mongolian models,
label: Paragraph

text: had more accessible private zones, much as
label: Paragraph

text: in Europe, where the ruler could entertain
label: Paragraph

text: guests. The Topkapi Palace, however, with its
label: Paragraph

text: clearly delineated boundaries, was designed to
label: Paragraph

text: instill a sense of sanctity and respect as much
label: Paragraph

text: as fear and awe.
label: Paragraph

text: The main entrance of the palace was just
label: Paragraph

text: behind the Hagia Sophia, now converted
label: Caption

text: to a mosque. The Imperial Gate, the first of
label: Paragraph

text: three main ceremonial double gates, led to
label: Paragraph

text: the first court, which contained workshops,
label: Paragraph

text: storage areas, dormitories, kitchens, a bakery,
label: Paragraph

text: and baths. It also contained a mint and
label: Paragraph

text: various offices of the government. This court
label: Paragraph

text: served as a waiting area for dignitaries as
label: Paragraph

text: well as a staging area for processions and
label: Paragraph

text: special ceremonies. Visiting ambassadors
label: Title

text: had to walk past the thousands of richly clad
label: Paragraph

text: soldiers and courtiers standing in mandatory
label: Title

text: silence, an intimidating backdrop for
label: Paragraph

text: diplomatic negotiations. The courtyard was
label: Paragraph

text: also used for executions, which the sultan
label: Paragraph

text: could observe from a window in the Tower of
label: Paragraph

text: Justice.
label: Paragraph

text: At the second gate, the visitor would
label: Paragraph

text: have had to dismount to gain access to the
label: Paragraph

text: next court, called “the arena of justice,” and
label: Paragraph

text: the beginning of the palace proper. It was
label: Paragraph

text: uncluttered by freestanding buildings an:
label: Paragraph

text: unified by a continuous marble colonnade. It
label: Paragraph

text: housed the Tower of Justice, the Council Hall,
label: Caption

text: and the treasury clustered at the far left corner
label: Paragraph

text: of the court. A loggia, raised on a platform in
label: Caption

text: front of the Council Hall, overlooked the space.
label: Paragraph

text: On the inside of the hall, from the back, the
label: Paragraph

text: sultan could watch the proceedings frorn
label: Paragraph

text: behind a curtained window. The hall was low
label: Paragraph

text: and unassuming, because it was modele
label: Paragraph

text: on a tent known as the “consultation tent,”
label: Paragraph

text: which was used by the imperial council during
label: Paragraph

text: military campaigns.
label: Paragraph

text: The Third Gate (The Gate of Felicity) was
label: Paragraph

text: especially sacred. On particularly important
label: Paragraph

text: occasions, the sultan would greet visitors
label: Paragraph

text: under its airy canopy. Behind the gate was
label: Paragraph

text: the Chamber of Petitions, a square, one-
label: Caption

text: story structure that served as an audience
label: Paragraph

text: hall, a building technically within the private
label: Paragraph

text: precinct but still conceptually a part of the
label: Paragraph

text: second courtyard. The third court was raised
label: Paragraph

text: on high retaining walls, with the land sloping
label: Paragraph

text: down below it toward the north. The throne
label: Paragraph

text: room was located at the far left corner. The
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in this court were designed to take
label: Paragraph

text: in the vistas of the surrounding landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: The sultan, from his belvedere, could watch
label: Paragraph

text: his flourishing capital and the port. The
label: Paragraph

text: residential quarter was located to the east
label: Paragraph

text: of the second and third courts in a compact
label: Title

text: mass huddled close to the walls of the court.
label: Paragraph

text: Special areas housed pages and slaves—
label: Title

text: males, females, and eunuchs—who were
label: Paragraph

text: all part of the sultan's retinue. This quarter
label: Paragraph

text: also housed the harem. In the northernmost
label: Paragraph

text: corner were the royal apartments.
label: Paragraph

text: Topkapi Palace is not organized along
label: Paragraph

text: an axis, nor are the buildings grand in
label: Paragraph

text: the traditional sense. Rather they are
label: Paragraph

text: organized through diagonal vistas and angled
label: Paragraph

text: approaches, with the open areas of the
label: Paragraph

text: courtyards meant to contrast with the ad hoc
label: Paragraph

text: intimacy of the residential quarter.

text: ITALIAN RENAISSANCE
label: Title

text: The term Renaissance (from the French
label: Paragraph

text: renaissance, “rebirth”) was coined in the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century to describe the cultural and
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual changes that took place in Italy
label: Title

text: during the 15th century. Inspired in part by
label: Paragraph

text: the arrival of scholars fleeing Constantinople,
label: Paragraph

text: who had preserved old classical knowledge
label: Paragraph

text: in contact with the Islamic world, the Italians
label: Paragraph

text: began to uncover and study Roman and
label: Paragraph

text: Greek texts and buildings to relearn what had
label: Paragraph

text: been lost to Europe in the Middle Ages, and
label: Paragraph

text: then to find ways of applying this learning to
label: Paragraph

text: their own times. One of the most influential
label: Paragraph

text: discoveries of this process, for instance, was
label: Paragraph

text: the discovery of perspective, the appearance
label: Title

text: of which had been approximated by painters
label: Paragraph

text: like Giotto di Bondone (1267-1337), but
label: Paragraph

text: which was first described mathematically by
label: Paragraph

text: Leon Battista Alberti (1404-72) in 1435. With
label: Paragraph

text: perspective began the process of locating the
label: Paragraph

text: human eye, both literally and conceptually,
label: Paragraph

text: at the center of our epistemic universe.
label: Paragraph

text: Ultimately, one can argue, this led to the
label: Paragraph

text: European Enlightenment of the 18th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the Renaissance is linked to
label: Paragraph

text: what is called, also retrospectively, the Age
label: Paragraph

text: of Discovery, we must remember that the
label: Paragraph

text: initial voyages of discovery by the likes of
label: Paragraph

text: Christopher Columbus, Vasco da Gama, and
label: Title

text: Amerigo Vespucci were sponsored not by the
label: Paragraph

text: Italians, or the Ottomans, or the French—the
label: Paragraph

text: new centers of the Mediterranean world—but
label: Paragraph

text: by the Spanish and the Portuguese, who
label: Paragraph

text: were at the edges of the intellectual revolution
label: Paragraph

text: that was the Renaissance. For the Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: and the Portuguese, the voyages were at
label: Paragraph

text: the outset motivated singularly by economic
label: Paragraph

text: imperatives: to find cheaper routes to the
label: Title

text: spice trade with Asia, or “the Indies.”
label: Paragraph

text: Whereas in painting there is a clear
label: Paragraph

text: progression that demarcates the Renaissance
label: Paragraph

text: from the Middle Ages, the difference in
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is less obvious. Medieval
label: Paragraph

text: practices continued to intermingle with
label: Paragraph

text: classically inspired ideas for a century.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, the interior of the Pazzi Chapel,
label: Paragraph

text: begun by Brunelleschi in 1429 but finished
label: Paragraph

text: by other architects, set the tone for a type
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture that emphasized the use
label: Paragraph

text: of columns, pilasters, and entablatures,
label: Paragraph

text: all unified by a proportional system
label: Title

text: that governed the heights, widths, and
label: Paragraph

text: intercolumniations of the pilasters. Though
label: Paragraph

text: the detailing of the columns and bases was
label: Paragraph

text: inspired by Roman buildings, Brunelleschi
label: Paragraph

text: was still not using the orders in their
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive categories of Doric, lonic, and
label: Paragraph

text: Corinthian. That ernerged only somewhat later
label: Paragraph

text: and was first insisted upon by Leon Battista
label: Paragraph

text: Alberti in his treatise De re aedificatoria
label: Title

text: (1452), now known as the fen Books on
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture. Renaissance architecture is
label: Paragraph

text: thus just as much about changes in practice
label: Paragraph

text: as about the emerging theories of the
label: Paragraph

text: discipline. Key was the discovery (ca. 1415)
label: Paragraph

text: of a copy of a manuscript of Vitruvius’s 7en
label: Caption

text: Books on Architecture in the library of St.
label: Caption

text: Gallen in Switzerland. Alberti studied the
label: Paragraph

text: manuscript and used it as an inspiration
label: Paragraph

text: for his own work. Covering a wide range of
label: Paragraph

text: subjects, from choice of materials to the
label: Paragraph

text: history of architecture and from different
label: Title

text: types of buildings to the philosophy of
label: Paragraph

text: beauty, Alberti’s treatise was written not
label: Paragraph

text: only for architects but also for patrons eager
label: Paragraph

text: to understand the logic of representation
label: Title

text: through buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: 13.36 Interior of the Pazzi Chapel
label: Caption

text: There are other phenomena that are
label: Paragraph

text: part of what is understood by the words
label: Paragraph

text: “Renaissance architecture.” The difference
label: Paragraph

text: between the architect and the craftsman was
label: Paragraph

text: now accepted, and architectural drawings
label: Paragraph

text: were now more common. Sebastiano Serlio
label: Paragraph

text: (1475-1554) wrote a treatise, of which
label: Paragraph

text: five books were finished, that was more
label: Paragraph

text: visual than Alberti’s treatise, which had
label: Paragraph

text: no illustrations. Serlio's book had dozens
label: Paragraph

text: of drawings, showing a variety of built and
label: Paragraph

text: unbuilt projects. It was enormously popular
label: Paragraph

text: among the many patrons and architects
label: Paragraph

text: eager to emulate the splendors of antiquity.
label: Paragraph

text: Questions about the nature of ancient
label: Title

text: Roman architecture and about the
label: Title

text: proportional systems that the Romans used
label: Title

text: were not easy to resolve and led to a wide
label: Paragraph

text: range of interpretations. Some architects, like
label: Paragraph

text: Brunelleschi, were less Roman than others,
label: Paragraph

text: and, in fact, it was only with Neoclassicism
label: Paragraph

text: in the 18th and 19th centuries that rigorous
label: Paragraph

text: adherence to antique models was seen as
label: Paragraph

text: a virtue. Nonetheless, the Renaissance did
label: Paragraph

text: require a rigorous attention to proportion,
label: Paragraph

text: and as a result, facades become flatter
label: Paragraph

text: and volumes more regularized. The vertical
label: Paragraph

text: dimension began to be articulated by
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal layers of columns, entablatures, and
label: Paragraph

text: cornices. Niches and aediculae now entered
label: Caption

text: the architect's vocabulary as secondary
label: Title

text: elements to be placed between pilasters.
label: Paragraph

text: Windows were framed and often pedimented.

label: Paragraph

text: dried substance held in a vial, is located in
label: Paragraph

text: the crypt beneath the church and is retrieved
label: Paragraph

text: during the ceremony through an opening
label: Title

text: in the floor. If the contents of the vial turns
label: Paragraph

text: to liquid, it is seen as a good omen. The

label: Caption

text: of the Renaissance, faces onto a small piazza

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: carried into the interior elevations of the nave.

text: made no attempt to compromise the two
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: an arched opening that shields the upper-
label: Paragraph

text: level window. The barrel vault on the interior
label: Caption

text: was another Albertian novelty. Since there
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Medici
label: Title

text: Though urban palaces were the norm for
label: Paragraph

text: the elite, the Medici were among the first
label: Paragraph

text: to create a villa that was not just a fortified
label: Paragraph

text: stronghold. As ubiquitous as this building
label: Paragraph

text: type became over time, in the 15th century
label: Paragraph

text: it was quite unusual. One of the important
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of villas are the gardens, and their
label: Paragraph

text: inclusion into the design was something of
label: Paragraph

text: a novelty. During the Middle Ages, gardens
label: Paragraph

text: as places of pleasure were rare; in the tight
label: Paragraph

text: maze of medieval cities space was restricted
label: Title

text: by city walls, leaving little room for pleasure
label: Paragraph

text: gardens. Furthermore, because of their
label: Paragraph

text: association with pleasure, gardens were
label: Paragraph

text: frowned upon. No doubt, visitors telling of
label: Paragraph

text: the great gardens at the Alhambra in Spain
label: Caption

text: played a part in establishing their legitimacy.
label: Paragraph

text: At any rate, by the middle of the 15th
label: Paragraph

text: century, the idea of having a place outside of
label: Paragraph

text: town, perhaps in the hills where it was cooler
label: Paragraph

text: in the summer and where the family could
label: Paragraph

text: gather, became the norm for the elite. The
label: Paragraph

text: word villa to describe these places came into
label: Paragraph

text: use only in the late 16th century, when the
label: Paragraph

text: villas themselves became more elaborate.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 15th century, they were still—at least
label: Paragraph

text: partially—working farms that supplied the
label: Paragraph

text: family, but that were also outfitted with a
label: Paragraph

text: manor house and garden.
label: Paragraph

text: Impacting this development was the revival
label: Paragraph

text: of the old Rornan notion of the bucolic
label: Paragraph

text: country retreat as a place where one could
label: Paragraph

text: enjoy music, poetry, and good company
label: Title

text: and play the gentleman farmer away from
label: Paragraph

text: the mercantile world of the cities. A treatise
label: Paragraph

text: that Alberti wrote entitled Villa helped define
label: Paragraph

text: the parameters of this lifestyle. For the new
label: Paragraph

text: elite, the villa served more practical goals as
label: Paragraph

text: well: the artworks, sculptures, gardens, and
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were all very much part of a system
label: Paragraph

text: of wealth and prestige.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the several villas used by the
label: Paragraph

text: Medici family, the Villa Medici at Poggio a
label: Title

text: Caiano was among the most important of
label: Paragraph

text: that period. Standing on the top of a small
label: Paragraph

text: hill a few kilometers west of Florence, it had
label: Paragraph

text: a wide view over the plain between Florence
label: Caption

text: and Pistoia. Originally a fortress, it was
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilt, beginning around 1485, into a villa
label: Paragraph

text: by Giuliano da Sangallo. It also seers to be
label: Paragraph

text: the earliest attempt to re-create a classical
label: Paragraph

text: vila suburbana as described in texts by
label: Paragraph

text: Pliny and Vitruvius. The villa rests on a large
label: Paragraph

text: vaulted platform containing the service rooms
label: Caption

text: and spaces needed for the farm. It is a two-
label: Paragraph

text: story building with an H-shaped plan, set
label: Caption

text: sideways to the axis. The whole, including its
label: Paragraph

text: gardens, was frarned by an enclosing wall.
label: Paragraph

text: The curved double staircase replaced the
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: was rarely expressed as such and instead
label: Paragraph

text: was usually hidden underneath a conical
label: Paragraph

text: external form. Similarly, the dome of the
label: Paragraph

text: Pantheon was impressive from the inside,
label: Paragraph

text: but had no exterior legibility. The dornes
label: Paragraph

text: of Islamic mosques and tombs were often
label: Paragraph

text: hidden behind frontispieces.
label: Paragraph

text: By contrast, the dorne of San Pietro in
label: Paragraph

text: Montorio is not only the culmination of the
label: Paragraph

text: composition, it was also designed to be seen
label: Paragraph

text: and comprehended from both the outside
label: Paragraph

text: and the inside. Later domes, like the one
label: Paragraph

text: over St. Peter's Basilica in Rorne designed
label: Caption

text: by Michelangelo Buonarroti (1475-1564),
label: Caption

text: were derivatives of this idea, even though for
label: Paragraph

text: structural—and aesthetic—reasons, the outer
label: Paragraph

text: and inner domes were rarely built as a single
label: Paragraph

text: unit, but instead as two domes.

text: FRENCH CHATEAUX
label: Title

text: In France, the 15th century and the first
label: Paragraph

text: half of the 16th century was a period of
label: Paragraph

text: relative economic weakness compared to
label: Paragraph

text: the situation in Italy. The Black Plague had
label: Paragraph

text: killed thousands, and due to the Hundred
label: Paragraph

text: Years’ War large tracts of farmland were left
label: Paragraph

text: fallow. Furthermore, the struggle between the
label: Paragraph

text: aristocratic classes had left the royal finances
label: Paragraph

text: in disarray. High taxes fed a spirit of revolt.
label: Paragraph

text: A turning point in France's fortunes came
label: Paragraph

text: with the ascension of Francis | (r. 1515-47),
label: Paragraph

text: who, though not a particularly astute military
label: Paragraph

text: planner, did capture tracts of land in northern
label: Paragraph

text: Italy, and in the process became a great
label: Paragraph

text: admirer of Italian art and learning. In 1516
label: Paragraph

text: he invited the renowned Leonardo da Vinci to
label: Paragraph

text: spend the rest of his life in his court, offering
label: Paragraph

text: him his own little palazzo, Clos Luce, near
label: Paragraph

text: the royal castle at Amboise, to which it was
label: Paragraph

text: connected by an underground tunnel.
label: Paragraph

text: 13.55 Chateau of Chambord
label: Caption

text: An urban culture such as was familiar
label: Paragraph

text: to Italians did not exist in France. The
label: Paragraph

text: kings did not even live in Paris, which was
label: Paragraph

text: not to become the capital until the 17th
label: Paragraph

text: century. Instead, in a tradition dating back
label: Paragraph

text: to Charlernagne, they moved from place to
label: Paragraph

text: place, living in an assortment of chateaux,
label: Paragraph

text: usually close to hunting grounds. Whereas
label: Paragraph

text: a villa is primarily a summer residence, a
label: Paragraph

text: chateau is the residence of the lord of the
label: Paragraph

text: manor—a country house for nobility and
label: Paragraph

text: gentry. It is also often associated with a forest
label: Paragraph

text: preserve used for hunting, an activity that
label: Paragraph

text: only nobility were permitted to engage in.
label: Paragraph

text: Between 1527 and 1547, Francis | built no
label: Paragraph

text: fewer than seven chateaux near Paris. Some
label: Paragraph

text: were hunting lodges; others were places of
label: Paragraph

text: residence. Chambord (1519-47) was the
label: Paragraph

text: largest and most elaborate chateau of its age;
label: Paragraph

text: it was so huge that it was uncomfortable to
label: Paragraph

text: live in, and Francis himself inhabited it for
label: Paragraph

text: only a few weeks. It is believed that Leonardo
label: Paragraph

text: da Vinci had a hand in its design, but since
label: Paragraph

text: Leonardo died in 1519, in the year it was
label: Paragraph

text: begun, he could only have been involved in
label: Paragraph

text: its planning stages. Construction went on
label: Paragraph

text: even though the royal treasury was empty.
label: Paragraph

text: The building consists of a square castle, or
label: Paragraph

text: donjon, with round towers at the corners,
label: Paragraph

text: the whole structure framed by a larger,
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular building, still partially unfinished.
label: Caption

text: The donjen is not in the center but on the
label: Paragraph

text: inside of the square court, clamped against
label: Paragraph

text: the northeastern side of the larger structure.
label: Paragraph

text: The double helical staircase that rises
label: Caption

text: through the center of the building, and which
label: Paragraph

text: is attributed to Leonardo, leads to the roof
label: Paragraph

text: of the building, a world unto itself. With its
label: Paragraph

text: complex coves and turrets and views of the
label: Paragraph

text: hunting grounds, it was used as a place for
label: Paragraph

text: social events and outdoor entertainment.
label: Paragraph

text: In a layout that was unique to the French,
label: Paragraph

text: the central residential structure had four
label: Paragraph

text: apartments, one in each quadrant.
label: Paragraph

text: MAMLUK SULTANATE
label: Title

text: The Mamluks of Egypt (to be distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: from the Mamluks of Delhi; mamiuk means
label: Paragraph

text: “slave” or “owned,” so these are kingdoms
label: Paragraph

text: created by former slaves) maintained a
label: Paragraph

text: turbulent rule from Cairo—battling the
label: Title

text: Mongols, trying to conquer Cyprus, and
label: Paragraph

text: balancing a peace with the Ottomans. With
label: Paragraph

text: a ready supply of well-trained masons,
label: Paragraph

text: the Mamluks extended and enhanced the
label: Paragraph

text: tradition of Fatimid palace architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: establishing a series of important religious
label: Paragraph

text: institutions along the main road leading to
label: Paragraph

text: the citadel of Cairo. The greatest example
label: Paragraph

text: is the Complex of Sultan Hassan, a colossal
label: Paragraph

text: project begun in 1356. It contains a
label: Paragraph

text: cruciform congregational mosque with four
label: Caption

text: madrasas and a mausoleum of an imperial
label: Title

text: scale, as well as an orphanage, a hospital, a
label: Paragraph

text: bazaar, a water tower, baths, and kitchens.
label: Paragraph

text: It was meant to house some four hundred
label: Paragraph

text: students. The religious spaces are organized
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrically to fit into the awkward site,
label: Paragraph

text: which is defined by two major streets. The
label: Paragraph

text: portal of the complex, rising 37 meters high,
label: Paragraph

text: is crowned by a mugarnas cornice. The
label: Paragraph

text: decorations include such Chinese motifs as
label: Paragraph

text: chrysanthemums and lotus flowers. The open
label: Paragraph

text: central court was paved and has a fountain
label: Paragraph

text: at the center. The four madrasas are located
label: Paragraph

text: in the corners between the arms of the
label: Caption

text: iwans; each has its own small courtyard. The
label: Paragraph

text: southeast iwan, the largest of the four, was
label: Paragraph

text: spanned by an enormous vault, considered
label: Paragraph

text: at the time one of the wonders of the world.
label: Paragraph

text: The mihrab and surrounding qib/a wall
label: Title

text: are paneled in marble slabs of contrasting
label: Caption

text: colors. Doors flanking the mihrab lead to the
label: Paragraph

text: tomb beyond. In it, the walls are paneled
label: Paragraph

text: with marble and the muqarnas of the dome
label: Caption

text: are gilded, and the whole is illuminated by
label: Paragraph

text: hundreds of specially designed glass lamps.
label: Paragraph

text: The building not only makes maximum use of
label: Paragraph

text: the site but redefines the Central Asian four-
label: Paragraph

text: iwan mosque, making it more intimate yet
label: Paragraph

text: also more monumental.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The capacity of the designers to impose
label: Paragraph

text: order onto complex urban sites was a unique
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of Mamluk architecture in Cairo.
label: Paragraph

text: No two buildings are alike, testifying to the
label: Paragraph

text: fluid irnagination of the architects. But the
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetry of these buildings was not always
label: Paragraph

text: a matter of necessity, as one can see at
label: Paragraph

text: the Mausoleurn Complex of Sultan Qaitbay
label: Caption

text: (1472-74). Sultan al Ashraf Qaitbay (r. 1468-
label: Caption

text: 96) was known for the efficient manner in
label: Paragraph

text: which he ran the country and the stability
label: Paragraph

text: he created. He was particularly interested
label: Paragraph

text: in architecture, promoting more than sixty
label: Paragraph

text: projects, not only in Cairo but also in Mecca,
label: Paragraph

text: Medina, Damascus, and Jerusalem. The
label: Paragraph

text: mausoleum complex, with no other buildings
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding it, houses a madrasa and the
label: Paragraph

text: burial qubba of the sultan. Architecturally,
label: Caption

text: it balances the minaret tower on the right
label: Paragraph

text: with an open loggia on the left. The dome
label: Caption

text: is made up of three separate elements: the
label: Paragraph

text: square-planned building at the bottom; an
label: Paragraph

text: intermediate volume with vigorously shaped
label: Title

text: scrolls at the corners that make the transition
label: Paragraph

text: to an octagonal platform; and finally the
label: Paragraph

text: dome, resting on a drum on that platform.
label: Paragraph

text: Compared to the simple windows on the body
label: Paragraph

text: of the building, some designed to look like
label: Paragraph

text: they were carved out of the wall, the dome
label: Paragraph

text: was given a particularly refined and elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: decoration in which two patterns, an
label: Paragraph

text: interlaced geometric star pattern and a floral
label: Caption

text: arabesque, are combined. On the interior
label: Paragraph

text: is found pietra serena paneling, a surface
label: Paragraph

text: treatment similar to those found in northern
label: Paragraph

text: TIMURID DYNASTY
label: Title

text: The occupation of Persia by the Mongolians
label: Title

text: and the fall of Baghdad in 1258 unleashed
label: Title

text: a period of disarray and confusion. One of
label: Paragraph

text: the earliest post-Mongolian states to ernerge
label: Paragraph

text: was created by the Turkish-speaking Timur
label: Paragraph

text: (1336-1405), who proudly claimed descent
label: Paragraph

text: from Genghis Khan. An ambitious and
label: Paragraph

text: notably cruel commander, Timur defeated the
label: Paragraph

text: Mamluks of Egypt, the early Ottomans, and
label: Paragraph

text: the Delhi sultanates to create an empire that
label: Paragraph

text: unified Persia, lraq, Transoxiana, and parts of
label: Paragraph

text: South Asia. While not themselves heterodox
label: Paragraph

text: or Shi'ite, the Timurid rulers accorded
label: Paragraph

text: respect to the Shi'ite figure of Ali, the
label: Paragraph

text: prophet Mohammed's son-in-law, whom they
label: Paragraph

text: considered the founder of their civilization’s
label: Paragraph

text: mystic brotherhoods. Furthermore, with a
label: Paragraph

text: generosity unthinkable in later generations,
label: Paragraph

text: Empress Gohar Shad built her Shi'ite subjects
label: Paragraph

text: a splendid shrine in the city of Mashhad, still
label: Paragraph

text: now a major pilgrimage center in modern
label: Paragraph

text: lran. Timur set up Samarkand, already a
label: Paragraph

text: major metropolis along the Silk Route, as his
label: Paragraph

text: capital. It soon possessed large suburbs with
label: Paragraph

text: fountains and canals. In the factories, the
label: Paragraph

text: citizens wove silk and cotton, worked leather,
label: Paragraph

text: and decorated copper; Chinese craftsmen
label: Title

text: produced here the first paper outside of
label: Paragraph

text: China itself. The 13th-century population
label: Paragraph

text: exceeded half a million.
label: Paragraph

text: Consistent with Timur’s passion for grand
label: Paragraph

text: structures, imposing appearances became
label: Paragraph

text: the main priority of his architectural program,
label: Paragraph

text: with the facade developing into a virtual
label: Paragraph

text: freestanding architectural form. High drums
label: Caption

text: and external domes stabilized by brick ribs
label: Caption

text: were often placed over the structural inner
label: Paragraph

text: domes. The combination of portal and dome
label: Paragraph

text: produced buildings of great spatial drama,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Samarkand’s biggest mosque, known
label: Paragraph

text: as Bibi Khanum Friday Mosque (1339-1404)
label: Caption

text: which was entered through a high portal with
label: Paragraph

text: round corner towers, its arches spanning
label: Paragraph

text: nearly 19 meters. The principal elements of
label: Paragraph

text: the plan—the entrance portal, the mosque,
label: Paragraph

text: and the lecture halls—are all enlarged into
label: Paragraph

text: monumental forms and then framed by
label: Paragraph

text: the repetitive elements of the mosque. The
label: Paragraph

text: colossal entrance portal protrudes from the
label: Caption

text: exterior wall, with two minarets projecting
label: Caption

text: out even further. The cylindrical shafts of the
label: Paragraph

text: minarets, rising from the ground rather than
label: Paragraph

text: emerging from the top of the iwan, and sitting
label: Paragraph

text: on decagonal socles, provide the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: surviving example of minarets flanking a
label: Caption

text: in the air. The basic plan is the four-iwan type
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: this building was a unit frorn the very start, and

text: its hypostyle hall forms the connective tissue
label: Paragraph

text: olding together the monumental elements.
label: Paragraph

text: Of a similarly grand scale is the Ulugh Beg
label: Paragraph

text: Madrasa in Samarkand (1417-20), which
label: Paragraph

text: opens up to the main square on axis to the Bibi
label: Paragraph

text: hanum Friday Mosque. It is one of the largest
label: Paragraph

text: madrasas in Central Asia, with an enormous
label: Paragraph

text: entrance portal flanked left and right by dome-
label: Caption

text: covered lecture halls with four axial niches.
label: Caption

text: Slender round minarets mark the corners. The
label: Paragraph

text: square courtyard has four jwans and a large
label: Paragraph

text: mosque at the rear, with additional lecture halls
label: Caption

text: to the right and left. The building became the
label: Paragraph

text: prototype of many later madrasas. The domed
label: Paragraph

text: corner rooms served as classrooms, while the
label: Paragraph

text: court was enclosed by two stories of individual
label: Paragraph

text: cells. The four colonnaded fwan porches,
label: Caption

text: axially disposed and deeply recessed, served as
label: Paragraph

text: meeting and discussion areas. The walls were
label: Paragraph

text: decorated with marble panels and blue and
label: Paragraph

text: purple bricks.
label: Paragraph

text: The Timurids developed a new type of
label: Paragraph

text: dome support. Instead of the square hall and
label: Caption

text: octagonal squinch, which had been developed in
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic architecture over the previous centuries,
label: Paragraph

text: the dome was set on two pairs of overlapping
label: Paragraph

text: arches. The dome was thus smaller than in
label: Paragraph

text: the older system, but the whole now had a
label: Paragraph

text: dynamic plasticity, both outside and inside. This
label: Paragraph

text: technique had originated in Armenia, where it
label: Paragraph

text: had been known since the 12th century. From
label: Paragraph

text: there it spread to Russia, and it is quite possible
label: Paragraph

text: that captured Russian or Armenian building
label: Title

text: masters might have been responsible for this
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of Timurid architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Though decorative tiles were use
label: Paragraph

text: Islamic architecture from early on and had
label: Paragraph

text: n

text: also been developed by the Seljuks, the
label: Paragraph

text: complete sheathing of buildings in colored tiles,
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of Persian architecture today, dates
label: Paragraph

text: only from this period. Prior to the 13th century,
label: Paragraph

text: most monumental decorations were made of
label: Paragraph

text: stucco that was painted or gilded. Only under
label: Paragraph

text: the House of Timur in the late 14th century
label: Title

text: did the various ornamental motifs appear,
label: Paragraph

text: fired in cerarnic tiles, that utterly blanketed the
label: Paragraph

text: structures. Though the color blue predominates,
label: Paragraph

text: the range of possible colors was quite wide,
label: Paragraph

text: including turquoise, white, yellow, green, brown,
label: Paragraph

text: aubergine, and black.

text: DECCAN SULTANATES
label: Title

text: In 1400 central India was controlled by
label: Paragraph

text: a familiar patchwork of diverse regional
label: Paragraph

text: kingdoms, but this is the first time that most
label: Paragraph

text: of these were ruled by Islamic kings, known
label: Paragraph

text: as the Deccan (Southern) Sultanates. Most
label: Paragraph

text: of the Deccan sultans were affiliated with
label: Paragraph

text: the Ottomans in Turkey for political reasons.
label: Paragraph

text: Qutb-ud-Din Aibak’s Mamluk dynasty
label: Title

text: (1206-90) had controlled the entire Indo-
label: Paragraph

text: Gangetic Plain of northern India from their
label: Title

text: capital in Delhi. Their successors, the Khilji
label: Paragraph

text: dynasty (1290-1320), did spectacularly
label: Paragraph

text: better and brought central India—that is, the
label: Paragraph

text: entire Deccan Plateau, from Gujarat in the
label: Paragraph

text: west to Pandua in the east and Gulbarga in
label: Paragraph

text: the south—under their control. The Khilji’s
label: Paragraph

text: successors, the Tughlaqs (1320-1413),
label: Paragraph

text: however, were unable to manage this vast
label: Paragraph

text: empire and bungled a series of ill-conceived
label: Paragraph

text: administrative projects. Timur, the Mongol
label: Caption

text: sultan of Samarkand opposed to the
label: Paragraph

text: Ottomans, took the opportunity to launch
label: Paragraph

text: an invasion in 1398, and decimated the
label: Paragraph

text: sultanates. He did not stay to rule, however,
label: Paragraph

text: and in the ensuing chaos, the governors and
label: Paragraph

text: regents of the Deccan Plateau, many of them
label: Paragraph

text: Khilji appointees, declared independence,
label: Paragraph

text: establishing the Deccan Sultanates. The
label: Paragraph

text: sultans took pains to distinguish themselves
label: Paragraph

text: from the weak court in Delhi and instead
label: Paragraph

text: turned to West Asia, not only for trade but
label: Paragraph

text: also for occasional help in shaping their
label: Paragraph

text: material culture and architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Shamsuddin Ilyas Shah (r. 1342-1358) was
label: Paragraph

text: one of the regents of the Deccan Sultanes
label: Paragraph

text: who declared independence in the area of
label: Paragraph

text: Bengal and established his own dynasty. The
label: Paragraph

text: llyas Shah dynasty constructed a new capital
label: Paragraph

text: in Pandua, where it built a set of unique
label: Paragraph

text: mosques and mausolea.
label: Paragraph

text: The Shah dynasty sultans started out
label: Paragraph

text: building fairly conventional stone-clad
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. But stone is scarce in Bengal, and
label: Paragraph

text: it rains incessantly. Brick had always been
label: Paragraph

text: the local material of choice, as can be seen in
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddhist monasteries of the Pala kings.
label: Paragraph

text: Even mosques such as the Adina Mosque in
label: Paragraph

text: Pandua (1364) were made of brick and then
label: Paragraph

text: clad in stone. So in 1425, when the Sultan
label: Paragraph

text: Jalal al-Din Muhammad Shah (r. 1414-32)
label: Caption

text: began construction on his mausoleum, he
label: Paragraph

text: decided to make it out of brick. This square
label: Paragraph

text: building with corner turrets and an octagonal
label: Caption

text: room surmounted by a hemispherical dome
label: Caption

text: has an unusual twist to it. Inspired by the
label: Paragraph

text: curved roof of local vernacular bamboo-and-
label: Paragraph

text: hay structures, Muhammad Shah's architects
label: Title

text: incorporated a curved cornice into the profile
label: Paragraph

text: that not only helps shed water but also gives
label: Paragraph

text: the mausoleum a unique shape. The Pandua
label: Paragraph

text: curved roof became iconic; from this time
label: Paragraph

text: onward all significant Bengal buildings began
label: Title

text: incorporating the curved cornice, creating
label: Paragraph

text: a uniquely Bengali style that was imitated
label: Paragraph

text: around South Asia in later centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: Jami Masjid of Ahmedabad
label: Title

text: In 1398, Ahmed Shah (r. 1411-42), a former
label: Paragraph

text: governor of Gujarat, declared independence
label: Title

text: from the Tughlaqs, and in 1410, he founded
label: Paragraph

text: Ahmedabad on the Sabarmati River as his
label: Paragraph

text: new capital. Anrnedabad went on to become
label: Paragraph

text: prosperous, particularly under Fath Kahn
label: Paragraph

text: Mahmud (1459-1511), who expanded the
label: Paragraph

text: kingdom in all directions. Under the Delhi
label: Paragraph

text: sultanate and the Tughlaqs, it had been
label: Paragraph

text: standard practice to dernean demolished
label: Title

text: Hindu temples by reusing their columns,
label: Paragraph

text: upside down or in pieces, to hold up a
label: Paragraph

text: new mosque. The curious characteristic of
label: Paragraph

text: Ahmed Shah's architecture is the manner in
label: Paragraph

text: which this mark of repression became the
label: Paragraph

text: expressive language of the new architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: For his new Jami Masjid (Friday Mosque),
label: Paragraph

text: built in 1423 in Ahmedabad, Ahmed Shah
label: Caption

text: embraced the new aesthetic created by the
label: Paragraph

text: demeaned Hindu columns and authorized
label: Paragraph

text: the construction of new colurins not
label: Paragraph

text: unlike the ones that were pillaged, thereby
label: Paragraph

text: legitimizing this new architectural hybrid.

label: Paragraph

text: MING DYNASTY CHINA
label: Title

text: In 1368, Zhu Yuanzhang defeated the last
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolian Yuan emperor and established
label: Title

text: the Ming (“bright” in Chinese) dynasty. The
label: Paragraph

text: Ming (1368-1644) were Han Chinese and
label: Paragraph

text: projected the Mongolian Yuan as foreign
label: Paragraph

text: barbarians, reviving the “insider-outsider”
label: Paragraph

text: conflict signified by the Long Wall. And yet,
label: Paragraph

text: even as they tightened controls over the
label: Paragraph

text: citizens and reinforced Confucian practices,
label: Paragraph

text: they also continued the modernization
label: Paragraph

text: programs of the Yuan and expanded their
label: Paragraph

text: urban centers. Initially, the Ming established
label: Paragraph

text: a new capital at Nanjing, in accordance with
label: Paragraph

text: tradition; but then the third Ming emperor,
label: Paragraph

text: Zhu Di (r. 1403-24), known by his royal
label: Paragraph

text: name as the Yongle Emperor, broke with
label: Paragraph

text: tradition and moved the capital back to
label: Paragraph

text: the city of Yuan Dadu, renaming it Beijing
label: Paragraph

text: (meaning “Northern Peace”).
label: Paragraph

text: Zhu Di was a controversial emperor.
label: Paragraph

text: Relentlessly ambitious, he exterrninated his
label: Paragraph

text: rivals ruthlessly and often doled out cruel
label: Paragraph

text: punishments to criminals and detractors. At
label: Paragraph

text: the same time, he consolidated Ming rule
label: Paragraph

text: and undertook massive building projects.
label: Paragraph

text: To revive Confucianism he ordered the
label: Paragraph

text: transcription of all known classical texts
label: Title

text: into a single volume, sometimes referred to
label: Paragraph

text: as the Chinese encyclopedia. He repaired
label: Paragraph

text: and reopened the Grand Canal, the
label: Paragraph

text: 1800-kilometer-long 6th-century CE canal
label: Title

text: connecting Beijing to Hangzhou. Running
label: Paragraph

text: north-south, against the predominant east-
label: Paragraph

text: west direction of the rivers of China, the
label: Paragraph

text: Grand Canal was a critical transportation
label: Paragraph

text: highway and had been neglected by the
label: Paragraph

text: Yuan. Beijing, the capital, was located in
label: Paragraph

text: northern China, in an area that was not
label: Paragraph

text: nearly as fertile or as irrigated as the lands of
label: Paragraph

text: the south. But the army and emperor were
label: Paragraph

text: situated here to defend against invaders
label: Paragraph

text: from the north, the primary direction from
label: Paragraph

text: which they came. Thus, while the demand
label: Paragraph

text: for grain was great in the north and
label: Paragraph

text: particularly in Beijing, grain production was
label: Paragraph

text: more than 1,500 kilometers away. But while
label: Paragraph

text: the south produced a significant surplus
label: Paragraph

text: of grain, until modern times grain was
label: Paragraph

text: always very expensive to transport because
label: Paragraph

text: it has great bulk and degrades easily. The
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese solution was to create a water-
label: Paragraph

text: based transportation highway, the Grand
label: Title

text: Canal, which served all kinds of commercial
label: Paragraph

text: traffic. Zhu Di vociferously denigrated the
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolians. At the same, he was protective
label: Paragraph

text: of all non-Confucian religions and was most
label: Paragraph

text: likely himself a Buddhist. Muslims enjoyed
label: Paragraph

text: significant freedom in his time, and after the
label: Paragraph

text: death of Timur (who had sworn to invade
label: Title

text: China) he maintained diplornatic missions
label: Paragraph

text: with the rulers of Samarkand and the
label: Paragraph

text: Safavids of Persia.
label: Paragraph

text: Forbidden City
label: Title

text: The Forbidden City, the enormous palace
label: Title

text: complex built by Emperor Zhu Di in Beijing,
label: Paragraph

text: is still one of the most celebrated icons of
label: Paragraph

text: imperial China. Consisting essentially of one
label: Paragraph

text: long south-to-north axis, this palace-cum—
label: Paragraph

text: governmental cornplex functioned through
label: Paragraph

text: a series of thresholds, each of which gave
label: Paragraph

text: access to different levels of government.
label: Paragraph

text: At its center were the diptych of the Hall of
label: Paragraph

text: Supreme Harmony and the Hall of Preserving
label: Title

text: Harmony, with the diminutive Hall of Central
label: Paragraph

text: Harmony in the middle. Beyond these, at
label: Paragraph

text: the core of the imperial compound, was the
label: Paragraph

text: Palace of Heavenly Purity—the residence
label: Title

text: of the Son of Heaven and the conceptual
label: Title

text: center of the empire. Since the emperor
label: Paragraph

text: embodied both the authority of government
label: Paragraph

text: and its justice system, access to him had to
label: Paragraph

text: be both carefully circumscribed and, at the
label: Paragraph

text: same time, projected well beyond his actual
label: Paragraph

text: physical presence. This, in essence, was the
label: Paragraph

text: dual purpose of the Forbidden City.
label: Paragraph

text: 13.74 Meridian Gate, Forbidden City, Beijing, China
label: Caption

text: The Palace of Heavenly Purity consists of
label: Paragraph

text: three pavilions on axis, on an I-shaped,
label: Paragraph

text: single-stepped marble platform, preceded by
label: Caption

text: a terrace facing south. It is surrounded by
label: Paragraph

text: a wall. Sixteen pavilions, housing the royal
label: Caption

text: concubines, extended beyond this innermost
label: Paragraph

text: sanctum to the east and west. Imperial
label: Caption

text: gardens and additional palaces for members
label: Title

text: of the royal family make up much of the
label: Paragraph

text: remaining structures. South of the palace,
label: Caption

text: a set of three halls perched on a three-step,
label: Paragraph

text: |-shaped marble platform repeated the order
label: Paragraph

text: of the innermost palace. This second set of
label: Paragraph

text: buildings is the terminus and focus of the
label: Paragraph

text: public sequence of the Forbidden City, and
label: Paragraph

text: the conceptual center of the empire.
label: Paragraph

text: 13.76 Section: Hall of Supreme Harmony, Forbidden City
label: Caption

text: The emperor met daily with his officials in
label: Paragraph

text: the Hall of Supreme Harmony. Only the
label: Paragraph

text: highest officers had access to this hall, which
label: Paragraph

text: was also the emperor's throne room. The
label: Paragraph

text: halls behind it, the Hall of Central Harmony
label: Paragraph

text: and the Hall of Preserving Harmony, only
label: Paragraph

text: served supporting functions. Although the
label: Paragraph

text: height, spans, and ornamentation of the Hall
label: Caption

text: of Supreme Harmony are magnificent, the
label: Paragraph

text: impact of the hall comes from the manner
label: Paragraph

text: in which the deep overhang of the roof
label: Paragraph

text: projects its presence into the vast space of
label: Paragraph

text: the courtyard that precedes it. Here grand
label: Paragraph

text: spectacles and marches could be staged.
label: Paragraph

text: In front of the emperor all supplicants had
label: Paragraph

text: to kowtow—that is, they had to prostrate
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: for action when necessary. The offices of the

text: either side of the Hall of Supreme Harmony.

text: Five marble bridges symmetrically straddle

label: Paragraph
