text: The U-shaped form (with five entrances
label: Paragraph

text: and a tall platform with high pavilions) of
label: Paragraph

text: the Meridian Gate connected the Forbidden
label: Paragraph

text: City to the palaces beyond. The Gate of
label: Paragraph

text: Uprightness, or Duanmen, was followed by
label: Paragraph

text: Chengtian, from where the emperor issued
label: Paragraph

text: imperial edicts, and then finally by the Great
label: Paragraph

text: Ming Gate, or Da Mingmen, the main entry
label: Paragraph

text: into the imperial city. As a visitor travels along
label: Paragraph

text: the main axis of the Forbidden City toward its
label: Paragraph

text: center, the elevation increases, each increase
label: Paragraph

text: being an indication of the power of the
label: Paragraph

text: emperor. The first three gates rise high above
label: Caption

text: the ground on imposing blank walls, giving
label: Paragraph

text: the viewer the impression of being far below
label: Paragraph

text: the zone of privilege. Beyond the Gate of
label: Paragraph

text: Supreme Harmony, where the view opens up,
label: Paragraph

text: with the Hall of Suprerne Harmony is raised
label: Paragraph

text: handsomely as an object in space on its
label: Paragraph

text: three stately terraces, and the highest point
label: Paragraph

text: in the Forbidden City is attained. The south
label: Paragraph

text: view from the top of the third terrace was the
label: Paragraph

text: emperor’s privileged view, enabling him to see
label: Paragraph

text: over the walls. From here all the gates and
label: Paragraph

text: the length of the city could be apprehended
label: Paragraph

text: in a single glance. Color played an important
label: Paragraph

text: role. The podiums on which the buildings
label: Paragraph

text: stood are a brilliant white; the wooden pillars
label: Paragraph

text: are a dull red (whose coloring agent also
label: Paragraph

text: serves as a preservative); finally, the roofs are
label: Paragraph

text: tiled in imperial sun yellow.
label: Paragraph

text: That these palaces survive is itself of
label: Paragraph

text: historical significance, as it was ancient
label: Paragraph

text: practice in China for new dynasties to burn
label: Title

text: the capital of the former dynasty. This is one
label: Paragraph

text: of the reasons there are so few historical
label: Paragraph

text: structures, apart from temples, in China
label: Paragraph

text: today. But in 1616, when the Manchu set
label: Paragraph

text: up their dynasty on the ruins of the defeated
label: Paragraph

text: Ming, they did not destroy the capital. For
label: Paragraph

text: five centuries, therefore, from about 1420
label: Paragraph

text: to 1908, the city was the hallowed seat of
label: Paragraph

text: twenty-four emperors. The buildings that
label: Paragraph

text: we see today are not the original Ming-era
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, but most are relatively accurate
label: Paragraph

text: reconstructions made by the Qing dynasty in
label: Paragraph

text: the 17th and 18th centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: Mt. Wudang
label: Title

text: Zhu Di, the Yongle Emperor, believing that
label: Paragraph

text: his ascent to the throne had been aided by
label: Paragraph

text: Zhenwu, a mythical Daoist warrior, in 1412
label: Paragraph

text: dispatched some 300,000 workers to Mt.
label: Paragraph

text: Wudang, Hubei, where the Daoists believe
label: Paragraph

text: Zhenwu attained immortality. Mt. Wudang is
label: Paragraph

text: in an area of precipitous cliffs and dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: views, often covered in mist. Its thick forest
label: Paragraph

text: s filled with caves, springs, and grottoes.
label: Paragraph

text: Zhu Di’s workers built a 60-kilometer-long
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrimage path made of stone that winds
label: Title

text: its way up to the peak, aided by thirty-nine
label: Paragraph

text: delicately constructed bridges. Along the way
label: Paragraph

text: are nine temple complexes, two monasteries,
label: Paragraph

text: and thirty-six hermitages, sore perched over
label: Paragraph

text: and along cliffs. The Purple Heaven Hall,
label: Paragraph

text: Mt. Wudang’s largest monastery, is farther
label: Paragraph

text: up the slope. Two terraces (only one short
label: Paragraph

text: of the Forbidden City’s Hall of Supreme
label: Title

text: Harmony) elevate the elegant double-eaved,
label: Paragraph

text: hip-and-gable, five-bay hall. One of the
label: Caption

text: main martial arts schools of China, Wudang
label: Caption

text: kung fu, is associated with this area. Five
label: Paragraph

text: hundred meters higher, the route culminates
label: Paragraph

text: at Tianzhufeng (“Heavenly Pillar Peak”), on
label: Paragraph

text: the top of Mt. Wudang. Here sits the small
label: Paragraph

text: Golden Hall (1416) with its roof and the
label: Paragraph

text: prominent parts of its three-bay structure
label: Caption

text: executed in bronze. Within is the statue of the
label: Caption

text: barefoot, long-haired Zhenwu, surrounded
label: Paragraph

text: by his Daoist retinue. Above them, a bracket
label: Paragraph

text: set more complicated than any found in
label: Paragraph

text: the Yingzhao Fashi was built to signify their
label: Paragraph

text: stature and royal favor.
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Heaven
label: Title

text: Periodically, determined by a set calendar,
label: Paragraph

text: the emperor was required to travel out of
label: Paragraph

text: the Forbidden City to altars located at the
label: Caption

text: southern edge of the city. Thus a balance was
label: Paragraph

text: etween the imperial authority of
label: Title

text: the Forbidden City and the celestial authority
label: Title

text: maintained
label: Title

text: of heaven. The Imperial Ancestral Temple
label: Paragraph

text: and the Altar of Soil and Grain, located just
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the Meridian Gate, to the east and
label: Paragraph

text: west of the major axis, were the oldest of the
label: Paragraph

text: structures. The Altars of the Sun and Moon
label: Caption

text: were located to the east and west of Beijing,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Altar of Earth to the north.
label: Paragraph

text: The sout
label: Title

text: important altars of all, in the Temple of
label: Caption

text: Heaven complex: the Altar of Agriculture,
label: Caption

text: intended to ensure the timely cycle of
label: Paragraph

text: production, and the Circular Mound Altar,
label: Paragraph

text: the enabler of the Emperors’ mandate. The
label: Paragraph

text: Circular Mound Altar, also called the Altar
label: Paragraph

text: of Heaven (Yuan Qiu Tan) is a three-tiered
label: Paragraph

text: circular platform (the circle representing
label: Title

text: the shape of heaven) located in a square
label: Paragraph

text: enclosure (the square symbolizing the
label: Paragraph

text: earth). The altar, basically a type of ritual
label: Paragraph

text: platform, was illuminated by hundreds of
label: Paragraph

text: lanterns, and incense burned everywhere.
label: Paragraph

text: In the middle, facing south, was a tablet
label: Paragraph

text: representing heaven, moved there especially
label: Paragraph

text: for the emperor's visits from its resting place
label: Paragraph

text: in the Imperial Vault of Heaven just beyond
label: Caption

text: to the north. Before it, the emperor prostrated
label: Paragraph

text: himself and kowtowed to the heavens more
label: Paragraph

text: than fifty times in a carefully scripted ritual,
label: Paragraph

text: was reserved for the most
label: Paragraph

text: witnessed by all present, that only he could
label: Paragraph

text: perform. Heaven's displeasure with the
label: Paragraph

text: emperor, manifested by bad omens and
label: Paragraph

text: natural or political catastrophes, was always
label: Paragraph

text: considered a sign of the withdrawal of his
label: Paragraph

text: mandate to rule.
label: Paragraph

text: Just north of the Mound Altar is the
label: Paragraph

text: Imperial Vault of Heaven, and farther north is
label: Paragraph

text: the Hall of Prayer for Good Harvests (Qinian
label: Caption

text: Dian). Elevated on three terraces of white
label: Paragraph

text: marble, this temple has a triple set of conical
label: Paragraph

text: roofs over a round space that is unique in
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese architecture. The sacrifice there
label: Paragraph

text: occurred on the winter equinox, and the
label: Paragraph

text: emperor prepared for the event by fasting
label: Paragraph

text: for three days, living in the Abstinence
label: Paragraph

text: Palace located at the western edge of the
label: Paragraph

text: complex. At three in the morning on the day
label: Paragraph

text: of the equinox, the emperor traveled to the
label: Paragraph

text: Circular Mound Altar, approaching it from the
label: Paragraph

text: south—that is, facing north, in the position of
label: Paragraph

text: a supplicant. The Abstinence Palace is one
label: Paragraph

text: of the few Ming buildings made with stone
label: Paragraph

text: vaults. Only the buildings for the dead (the
label: Paragraph

text: Ming tombs) and this one were considered
label: Paragraph

text: “unworthy” of a wooden roof, yet they were
label: Paragraph

text: built with extraordinary care, showing that
label: Paragraph

text: though stone architecture was not a tradition
label: Paragraph

text: in China, it could be produced very skillfully.

text: Dabao-en Temple, or the Porcelain Tower of
label: Paragraph

text: Nanjing
label: Title

text: The Porcelain Tower of Nanjing (Dabao-en
label: Caption

text: Temple) was designed during the reign of
label: Paragraph

text: Zhu Di, the Yongle Emperor (r. 1402-24),
label: Paragraph

text: shortly before its construction in the early
label: Paragraph

text: 15th century. The Yongle Emperor followed
label: Paragraph

text: traditional rituals closely and held many
label: Paragraph

text: popular beliefs. He did not overindulge in the
label: Paragraph

text: luxuries of palace life, and used Buddhism
label: Paragraph

text: and Buddhist festivals to help calm civil
label: Title

text: unrest. He stopped the warring between the
label: Paragraph

text: various Chinese tribes and reorganized the
label: Paragraph

text: provinces to best provide peace within his
label: Paragraph

text: kingdom. Yongle was said by Ernst Faber to
label: Paragraph

text: be an “ardent Buddhist.”
label: Paragraph

text: In 1403 the Yongle Emperor, after
label: Paragraph

text: experiencing a vision of the Avalokiteshvara
label: Paragraph

text: Buddha, invited Deshin Shekpa, the fifth
label: Paragraph

text: Gyalwa Karmapa of the Kagyu school of
label: Paragraph

text: Tibetan Buddhism, to Nanjing. The visit of
label: Paragraph

text: the Buddhist Karmapa revalidated Buddhism
label: Title

text: in Ming China and helped the Yongle
label: Paragraph

text: Emperor secure a popular base for his
label: Paragraph

text: rule. To mark this visit, the Yongle Emperor
label: Paragraph

text: ordered the construction of the Dabao-En
label: Paragraph

text: Temple, or the Temple of Giving Thanks,
label: Paragraph

text: which was made of wood and covered in
label: Paragraph

text: brightly colored porcelain. The tower—30
label: Caption

text: meters in diameter, rising 79 meters in 9
label: Paragraph

text: stories—was part of a massive Buddhist
label: Paragraph

text: monastery on the banks of the Qinhuai River
label: Caption

text: in Nanjing. One of the tallest structures in
label: Paragraph

text: China, the tower was illuminated at night
label: Paragraph

text: by larmps, which, reflected by the porcelain,
label: Paragraph

text: gave it a luminescent quality that earned
label: Paragraph

text: the building an international reputation.
label: Paragraph

text: Extensively described by Western emissaries,
label: Paragraph

text: the Porcelain Tower, as it came to be known
label: Paragraph

text: in the West, inspired the blue-tiled roof of
label: Paragraph

text: the Trianon de Porcelain built by Louis XIV
label: Caption

text: in 1675. The tower was destroyed during the
label: Paragraph

text: Taiping rebellion in the mid-19th century.
label: Paragraph

text: JOSEON DYNASTY
label: Title

text: n 1392 Yi Songgye, with the aid of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ming dynasty, seized the Korean throne
label: Title

text: and established the Joseon dynasty (also
label: Paragraph

text: nown as the Chosun dynasty), which
label: Paragraph

text: jasted until 1910. Korea was known under
label: Paragraph

text: the Joseon as Daejoseonguk (the “Great
label: Paragraph

text: Joseon Nation”). Though the Mongolians
label: Paragraph

text: were defeated, aspects of Mongolian culture,
label: Paragraph

text: ere as elsewhere, remained embedded in
label: Paragraph

text: ‘orean society. As in China, Confucianism
label: Paragraph

text: was reestablished as the state religion. A
label: Paragraph

text: new capital, Seoul, was built, situated not far
label: Paragraph

text: rom the peninsula's largest river and at the
label: Paragraph

text: focal point of overland transportation routes.
label: Paragraph

text: Several palaces were built in Seoul, the most
label: Paragraph

text: important being Gyeongbokgung (“Palace
label: Paragraph

text: Greatly Blessed by Heaven"—gung meaning
label: Paragraph

text: “palace”—in 1394) and, a kilometer to the
label: Paragraph

text: east, Changdeokgung (“Palace of Prospering
label: Paragraph

text: Virtue,” begun 1405, rebuilt 1592). For
label: Paragraph

text: the siting of the palaces, the surrounding
label: Paragraph

text: topography was carefully studied from the
label: Paragraph

text: standpoint of both Confucian ideology and
label: Paragraph

text: feng shui. Feng shui was also very much
label: Paragraph

text: respected in the making of the principal
label: Paragraph

text: roads connecting the main gates of the
label: Paragraph

text: city by way of the four cardinal directions.
label: Paragraph

text: Straight lines were not always the rule, as
label: Paragraph

text: can be seen in the east-west and north-south
label: Paragraph

text: thoroughfares, which are slightly curved.

text: According to feng shui, a building should
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: on the left and right, symbolizing an azure
label: Paragraph

text: dragon and a white tiger, respectively.
label: Paragraph

text: Changdeokgung was thus situated in the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of Paekak Mountain, facing south to the
label: Paragraph

text: northern mountain peak called Nam
label: Title

text: Mountain. The deity on Paekak Mountain was
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: was male. Paekak, which symbolized royal
label: Paragraph

text: authority and was the most highly valued
label: Paragraph

text: in terms of feng shui, was closed to the
label: Paragraph

text: common people and protected from any
label: Title

text: private use. Nam Mountain, however, was
label: Paragraph

text: open to the common people. Because
label: Paragraph

text: there was no natural mountain to the east
label: Paragraph

text: of the palace, an artificial hill was created
label: Paragraph

text: to compensate for the shortcoming in
label: Paragraph

text: topography. In its original form, the palace
label: Paragraph

text: had about five hundred buildings. They were
label: Paragraph

text: burned during the Japanese invasions of
label: Paragraph

text: 1592. About ten 19th-century reconstructions
label: Caption

text: exist. Changdeokgung had a public portion
label: Paragraph

text: (toward the south) and a more private part
label: Paragraph

text: (toward the north) consisting of several
label: Paragraph

text: stroll gardens strung together by a series of
label: Paragraph

text: carefully composed follies for repose. One
label: Paragraph

text: of these is particularly farnous. Organized
label: Paragraph

text: around a shallow quadrangular water tank,
label: Paragraph

text: with a high ridge on one side and several
label: Paragraph

text: The throne hall (injongjon), facing east and
label: Paragraph

text: of a series of low stone platforms that seem

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The throne sat on a high platform at the back

text: of the middle bay. It was connected in the

text: MUROMACHI JAPAN
label: Title

text: After two centuries of domination by
label: Paragraph

text: aristocratic regents and military rulers,
label: Paragraph

text: Emperor Godaigo (r. 1318-39) enlisted
label: Paragraph

text: the help of Ashikaga Takauji (1305-58) to
label: Paragraph

text: reclaim the court in 1333. But when Godaigo
label: Paragraph

text: refused to name Takauji as shogun after his
label: Paragraph

text: victory, the latter forced the emperor into exile
label: Paragraph

text: (1335) and placed his own representative
label: Paragraph

text: on the throne. As shogun, Takauji made
label: Paragraph

text: two decisions that changed the course of
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese history: he reinstated Kyoto as
label: Title

text: the capital and reestablished links with the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese Song dynasty, links that had been
label: Paragraph

text: broken since Kublai Khan’s failed attempt
label: Paragraph

text: to invade Japan in the 13th century. Profits
label: Paragraph

text: from the China trade were important to the
label: Paragraph

text: shogun’s power. Song culture infused itself
label: Paragraph

text: into Japanese society and with that came a
label: Paragraph

text: blending of cultural elements that laid the
label: Paragraph

text: foundation for a form of Buddhism known
label: Title

text: as Zen, the Japanese pronunciation of the
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese kanji for chan. Chan, in turn, was
label: Paragraph

text: a transformation of the Sanskrit dhyan,
label: Paragraph

text: or meditation. Zen emphasizes sustained
label: Paragraph

text: meditation rather than visualization as the
label: Paragraph

text: way to nirvana. The Zen monasteries were
label: Paragraph

text: built in the traditional Karayo style.

label: Title

text: Ginkakuji (“Silver Pavilion”) was built as a
label: Paragraph

text: retirement villa by Yoshimitsu’s grandson,
label: Paragraph

text: the shogun Yoshimasa, in 1482. Yoshimasa
label: Caption

text: intended to cover two stories of his pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: with silver, but this intention was never
label: Paragraph

text: realized. In Yoshimasa’s original design,
label: Paragraph

text: the two-story pavilion stood at the edge of
label: Paragraph

text: a pond set off against small bridges, tiny
label: Paragraph

text: islands, and exactingly planted and pruned
label: Paragraph

text: shrubs, all designed to generate carefully
label: Paragraph

text: framed views that recalled descriptions from
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese literature. Ginkakuji’s fame lies in
label: Paragraph

text: the additions made by Zen Budchist monks
label: Title

text: during the Edo period in the 17th century,
label: Paragraph

text: the palace having been turned over to Zen
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhists after its patron’s death. Since
label: Paragraph

text: sand had to be stored on site to maintain
label: Paragraph

text: the gardens, the Zen monks decided to
label: Paragraph

text: use it to build two sculpted mounds next to
label: Paragraph

text: the pond and in stark contrast to it. One is
label: Paragraph

text: low and carefully raked to form a plateau,
label: Paragraph

text: and it is called the Sea of Silver Sand, so
label: Paragraph

text: named for its appearance in moonlight. The
label: Paragraph

text: other mound rises as a perfectly shaped,
label: Paragraph

text: truncated cone, arresting at first glance
label: Paragraph

text: if only for its sheer size. The cone evokes
label: Paragraph

text: the profile of Mt. Fuji, but may also refer
label: Paragraph

text: to the sacred mountain in the middle of a
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist mandala. From different points of
label: Paragraph

text: view around Ginkakuji, the cone, uniform in
label: Caption

text: color and outline from all directions, functions
label: Title

text: as an object of constancy in the changing
label: Paragraph

text: panorama. The two mounds set in play a
label: Paragraph

text: drama of visual tension, the exact meaning
label: Paragraph

text: remaining open to interpretation This type
label: Paragraph

text: of meditational paradox is typical for Zen
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhism.
label: Paragraph

text: In a sense, Ginkakuji is more successful
label: Paragraph

text: as a Zen garden than Kinkakuji. The
label: Paragraph

text: assembly of its views is more restrained and
label: Paragraph

text: subtle, and since they are bound by a much
label: Paragraph

text: smaller space their experience is far more
label: Paragraph

text: intimate and irmmediate. Together, however,
label: Paragraph

text: they define the aspirations of the Muromachi
label: Paragraph

text: warrior aristocracy as it changed under the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of the Song and Zen.

text: AYUTTHAYA
label: Title

text: The collapse of the Knmer Empire, combined
label: Paragraph

text: with the related unraveling of the Srivijayan
label: Paragraph

text: Empire in Malaysia, reduced the importance
label: Paragraph

text: of Southeast Asia in the global economy.
label: Paragraph

text: The Majapahit Kingdom, which ruled frorn
label: Paragraph

text: Java, and the Thai kingdom, with its capital
label: Paragraph

text: in Ayutthaya, were the two dominant forces,
label: Paragraph

text: both maintaining strong trade links with India
label: Paragraph

text: and China.
label: Paragraph

text: The Thai kingdom was not a single,
label: Paragraph

text: unified state, but rather composed of
label: Paragraph

text: self-governing principalities and tributary
label: Title

text: provinces owing allegiance to the king.
label: Paragraph

text: The name of the capital city derives from
label: Paragraph

text: the Hindu holy city Ayodhya in northern
label: Title

text: India, which is said to be the birth place of
label: Paragraph

text: the Hindu god Rama. King Ramathibodi,
label: Paragraph

text: who established Ayutthaya, was Buddhist,
label: Paragraph

text: however, and made Theravada Buddhism
label: Paragraph

text: the official religion of the state, indicating the
label: Paragraph

text: close continuity between Hindu and Buddhist
label: Title

text: practices at the time.
label: Paragraph

text: The kingdom’s wealth derived not only
label: Paragraph

text: from its control of trade routes but also from
label: Paragraph

text: its introduction of a new strain of rice. Thai
label: Paragraph

text: farmers had traditionally planted the glutinous
label: Paragraph

text: rice that is still the staple in the north and
label: Paragraph

text: northeast regions of the country. But in the
label: Paragraph

text: floodplain of the Chao Phraya River, farmers
label: Caption

text: turned to a variety of rice—so-called floating
label: Paragraph

text: rice—a nonglutinous grain introduced from
label: Paragraph

text: Bengal. It grew faster and more easily,
label: Paragraph

text: producing a surplus that was sold abroad,
label: Paragraph

text: Champa

label: Caption

text: even to China. An extensive set of canals
label: Paragraph

text: was dug to bring the rice from the fields.
label: Paragraph

text: Though inland, Ayutthaya was essentially a
label: Paragraph

text: port located on an island of the Chao Phraya
label: Paragraph

text: River at the intersection of the Lopbur and
label: Paragraph

text: Pasak Rivers. The island was crisscrossed
label: Paragraph

text: by a network of canals that ran alongside
label: Paragraph

text: a rectilinear road system. Over time, five
label: Paragraph

text: hundred temples, stupas, and palaces were
label: Paragraph

text: built on this island by successive generations
label: Paragraph

text: of kings. Initially, Ayutthaya’s temples derived
label: Paragraph

text: their form from the architecture of the
label: Paragraph

text: Khmers, but at a smaller scale and with a
label: Paragraph

text: more deliberate staging of ancillary parts.
label: Paragraph

text: The central stupa of Wat Rat Burana (1424)
label: Caption

text: was not only surrounded by a geometrically
label: Paragraph

text: configured cosmos of stupas, but also had
label: Paragraph

text: colonnaded arrival halls to its east and west.
label: Paragraph

text: Ramathibodi II (r. 1491-1529), immediately
label: Paragraph

text: after his coronation in 1491, initiated the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of a spectacular triple-stupa
label: Caption

text: funerary structure, Wat Si Sanpet, to contain
label: Paragraph

text: the remains of his father and brother; the
label: Paragraph

text: third structure, built by his son after his
label: Caption

text: death, contained his own remains. These
label: Paragraph

text: three stupas, with their tall spirals on bell-
label: Paragraph

text: shaped bodies, copied the Pagan prototype.
label: Paragraph

text: An arrival hall to the east and a cruciform
label: Caption

text: temple to the west frarned the centerpiece
label: Caption

text: of this unique compound, which was also
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by numerous small stupas,
label: Paragraph

text: each with its own small funeral temple
label: Paragraph

text: for the extended families of the kings. As
label: Paragraph

text: such, Wat Si Sanpet was a singularly royal
label: Paragraph

text: precinct, and, atypically, had no residential or
label: Paragraph

text: meditation halls for Buddhist monks.

text: In the 17th century, the Eurasian world, from
label: Paragraph

text: Japan to western Europe, was a contiguous
label: Paragraph

text: economic power bloc connected by well-
label: Paragraph

text: established cross-country and coastal trade.
label: Paragraph

text: From one end to the other, wealth and ideas
label: Title

text: traveled in the baggage or minds of traders,
label: Paragraph

text: migrants, and armies. This was the Old World
label: Paragraph

text: order that was now increasingly undermined
label: Paragraph

text: by the newly arising, more efficient ocean
label: Paragraph

text: trade. Eventually, sometime in the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century, the efficiencies of the ocean routes,
label: Paragraph

text: the unprecedented advantage of untrammeled
label: Paragraph

text: access to the American continents, and
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization would make colonial Europe
label: Title

text: the unrivaled power of the world. Until then—
label: Paragraph

text: until the complete collapse of the Silk Route—
label: Paragraph

text: the power centers of Eurasia still dominated
label: Paragraph

text: the old economies of the world.

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: tea ceremony. Crossing into Korea, he visits
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: state. Traveling into the heart of Manchuria

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the castle compound, which consists of a
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: terrace. Resting on the top of a sloping stone
label: Caption

text: base some 14 meters high, the main tower
label: Caption

text: (known as the Great Tenshu) rises seven
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: he entire structure is held together, from
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and lock together each level of the building.

label: Paragraph

text: silver fir 28.4 meters tall, while the second is
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: So efficient was the Ming bureaucracy that
label: Paragraph

text: the fact that the reportedly indolent and
label: Paragraph

text: pleasure-seeking seventh Ming emperor,
label: Title

text: Wanli (1573-1620), seems not to have
label: Paragraph

text: affected the prosperity of his empire. Official
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonies and presentations were simply
label: Paragraph

text: made to an empty throne in his stead. A
label: Paragraph

text: large proportion of Wanli’s time, along with
label: Paragraph

text: an estimated eight million fae/s of silver, was
label: Paragraph

text: spent in the design and construction of his
label: Paragraph

text: tomb, which began in 1585, when he was
label: Paragraph

text: only twenty-two years old. Much more than
label: Paragraph

text: personalized egocentric attempts to guarantee
label: Title

text: an afterlife, tombs, and in particular royal
label: Paragraph

text: tombs, were an integral part of the Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: cosmology. Spirits of dead ancestors of even
label: Paragraph

text: the common people had to be fed and cared
label: Paragraph

text: for, or else they were liable to visit misfortune
label: Paragraph

text: upon future generations. The emperor's
label: Paragraph

text: death, however, was particularly special, as he
label: Paragraph

text: became part of heaven itself, and his tomb’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture represented that transition. Many
label: Paragraph

text: of China’s royal tombs, going back to that of
label: Paragraph

text: the First Emperor, Shi Huangdi, have still not
label: Paragraph

text: been excavated.
label: Paragraph

text: The thirteen Ming tombs, of which only
label: Paragraph

text: Wanli's has been excavated, are among
label: Paragraph

text: the most famous and best preserved. They
label: Paragraph

text: are clustered in the valley of the Tianshou
label: Paragraph

text: Mountains, about 80 kilometers northwest of
label: Paragraph

text: Beijing.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Buddhism was introduced into Tibet by
label: Paragraph

text: Mahayana monks travelling from India and
label: Title

text: Nepal in the 8th century CE. By the 10th
label: Paragraph

text: century, Nepal had begun to thrive as a
label: Paragraph

text: regional power, capturing significant territories
label: Paragraph

text: in Mongolia and China. The growth of Tibet
label: Paragraph

text: was, however, checked by the Chinese well
label: Paragraph

text: into the 15th century. Although China's non-
label: Paragraph

text: Han dynasties—the Liao and, in particular,
label: Paragraph

text: the Mongol Yuan—supported Tibetan
label: Title

text: Buddhism, they made sure the Tibetans
label: Paragraph

text: were politically subservient. The Ming paid
label: Paragraph

text: only lip service to Tibetan Buddhism since
label: Paragraph

text: their focus was on the revival of a Confucian
label: Paragraph

text: and Daoist state. As a consequence, Tibetan
label: Paragraph

text: Buddhists split into a number of competing
label: Paragraph

text: sects, variously identified by the color of their
label: Paragraph

text: habit as the red, white, and yellow sects. But
label: Paragraph

text: when the Ming dynasty began to lose power,
label: Paragraph

text: the Uigher Mongols under Altan Khan, the
label: Paragraph

text: descendants of the erstwhile Yuan dynasty,
label: Paragraph

text: converted to the Tibetan yellow sect; after
label: Paragraph

text: that, Tibetan Buddhism or Lamaism spread
label: Paragraph

text: quickly among the Mongols of Central Asia. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1641, Altan Khan's grandson, Gushri Khan,
label: Paragraph

text: defeated all the other Tibetan sects and
label: Paragraph

text: proclaimed Ngawang Losang Gyatso (1617-
label: Paragraph

text: 82), the fifth Dalai Lama, not only the spiritual
label: Paragraph

text: head of Tibetan Buddhism but also, for the &
label: Paragraph

text: first time in Tibetan history, the political head /“ ’

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The Potala Palace is
label: Paragraph

text: the sacred center
label: Title

text: of Tibetan worship. It signifies Mount
label: Paragraph

text: Meru, the conceptual organizing center
label: Title

text: of the Buddhist cosmos. As such, the
label: Paragraph

text: palace is just as much a pilgrimage site
label: Paragraph

text: as a royal residence.
label: Paragraph

text: Since it was meant to be defensible, the
label: Paragraph

text: palace’s primary massing is that of a fort.
label: Paragraph

text: Thick, battered brick walls, painted white,
label: Paragraph

text: rise steeply from the rock surface in a series
label: Paragraph

text: of terraces that take over the entire summit of
label: Paragraph

text: the Red Hill. The walls step back and forth to
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate the changing contours and to
label: Paragraph

text: generate openings for the access paths.
label: Paragraph

text: Solid and impenetrable at the bottom,
label: Paragraph

text: the walls’ higher reaches are punctuated by
label: Paragraph

text: dark windows, which are few and simple at
label: Paragraph

text: first but, at higher elevations, become larger
label: Paragraph

text: and more richly embellished. The walls are
label: Paragraph

text: topped by a prominent red coping. The
label: Paragraph

text: visual terminus is a series of small, golden,
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese-style roofs that are not so large as to
label: Paragraph

text: be the solitary focus but prominent enough
label: Paragraph

text: to ensure that the eye comes to rest on them,
label: Paragraph

text: providing a speck of metallic brilliance in
label: Paragraph

text: a landscape dominated by gray rock. Long
label: Paragraph

text: ramps, visible frorn the distance, wind their
label: Paragraph

text: way up the side of the hill. Their slow ascents
label: Paragraph

text: mark ther as self-conscious processional
label: Paragraph

text: paths, leading to a place of pilgrimage.

text: 14.35 South elevation: Potala Palace

text: The current palace was built in two major

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: as the White Palace, were built. This was
label: Paragraph

text: partially rebuilt and a Red Palace was
label: Paragraph

text: constructed that became the primary
label: Paragraph

text: residence of the Dalai Lamas.
label: Paragraph

text: The White Palace houses large ceremonial
label: Paragraph

text: halls for prayers, rooms for visiting dignitaries,
label: Paragraph

text: and offices, while the Red Palace houses the
label: Paragraph

text: audience hall as well as burial stupas for the
label: Paragraph

text: dalai lamas. The roof of the palace opens
label: Caption

text: onto a flat terrace where there are Chinese-
label: Paragraph

text: style pavilions, gilded in copper, one for each
label: Caption

text: dalai lama. At the foot of the Potala Palace, a
label: Caption

text: square walled enclosure contains a network
label: Paragraph

text: of governmental buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Access to the Potala Palace begins at the
label: Paragraph

text: end of the lower quadrangle, at a column
label: Caption

text: erected to mark the completion of the Red
label: Caption

text: Palace. The first ramp
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: leads to subsidiary

text: ut then it switches
label: Title

text: back and heads up toward the White Palace.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: have been hidden until now, suddenly reveal
label: Paragraph

text: themselves, nestled between the staggers
label: Paragraph

text: of the walls. A stair to the east leads to the
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and for the pilgrim this is the first arrival
label: Paragraph

text: VOYAGES OF ZHENG HE
label: Title

text: The first Ming emperor, Taizu, also called
label: Paragraph

text: the Hongwu Emperor, sponsored a series
label: Paragraph

text: of naval voyages between 1405 and 1433,
label: Paragraph

text: with at least seven of those traversing the
label: Paragraph

text: “western ocean,” which could be either the
label: Paragraph

text: Indian or Pacific Ocean. The voyages were
label: Paragraph

text: commanded by Zheng He (1371-1435),
label: Paragraph

text: a Muslim eunuch from China's Yunnan
label: Title

text: Province whose father and grandfather had
label: Paragraph

text: made the hajj to Mecca and who, therefore,
label: Paragraph

text: knew of Islamic cartographic advances.
label: Paragraph

text: Zheng He's mission was not economic but
label: Paragraph

text: diplomatic, seeking to establish ties with other
label: Paragraph

text: nations. Some of the voyages had as many
label: Paragraph

text: as three hundred ships and 27,000 sailors
label: Paragraph

text: in all, and they reached as far as Mombasa
label: Paragraph

text: in Africa. Fantastic descriptions of the fleet
label: Caption

text: are still evident in temples in Ayutthaya in
label: Paragraph

text: Thaland.

text: The Chinese economy was integrally tied

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and Portuguese. It is estimated that as much
label: Paragraph

text: as one-third of all the silver extracted from
label: Paragraph

text: South America was brought to China to pay
label: Paragraph

text: for porcelain, silk, and other luxury goods.
label: Paragraph

text: To feed this export economy, huge kilns
label: Paragraph

text: were built at Jingdezhen in Jiangxi Province,
label: Paragraph

text: which produced an estimated 100,000 small
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: annually. Still preserved as ceiling decorations

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: emperor. Stability returned only in 1457 when
label: Paragraph

text: Zhengdong recovered the throne. The Mongol
label: Paragraph

text: threat, yet once again, shook the Ming court.
label: Paragraph

text: They resolved to disband the expensive
label: Paragraph

text: explorative sea voyages and to concentrate
label: Title

text: instead on fortifying against the Mongolians.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1474 the Ming general Wang Yueh insisted
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: rebuild the Great Wall. Almost forty thousand
label: Paragraph

text: troops were set to work to build not only
label: Paragraph

text: vast segments of the wall but also its
label: Paragraph

text: accompanying fortifications, signal towers,
label: Caption

text: and stockades. The Ming Great Wall occupies
label: Paragraph

text: the rest of the last range of hills before the
label: Paragraph

text: mountains level off in the northern deserts of
label: Paragraph

text: Mongolia. And so the long-term possibilities
label: Paragraph

text: of Zheng He's naval expeditions were traded
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Great Wall system.

label: Caption

text: MUGHALS
label: Title

text: The Delhi sultanates, with their various
label: Paragraph

text: competing interests, fell prey to an outside
label: Paragraph

text: conqueror, Babur, a descendant of the Timur
label: Paragraph

text: ine. He established the Mughal dynasty
label: Paragraph

text: which, by the time of his death in 1530,
label: Paragraph

text: stretched from the Deccan to Turkestan.
label: Paragraph

text: Babur’s oldest son, Humanyun, lost the
label: Paragraph

text: throne in 1540 to Sher Shah Sur, an Afghan
label: Paragraph

text: and former ally who, though he ruled for only
label: Paragraph

text: ifteen years, established a centralized system
label: Paragraph

text: of administration on the foundations of which
label: Paragraph

text: jater Mughals expanded. Humanyun regained
label: Paragraph

text: the Delhi throne by 1555 but died a year
label: Paragraph

text: later. He was succeeded by the eighteen-year
label: Paragraph

text: old Jalal-ud-Din Akbar (1556-1605), who laid
label: Paragraph

text: the foundation of—and consolidated—the
label: Paragraph

text: Mughal Empire. His grandson Khurram Shah
label: Paragraph

text: Jahan (1628-57) was the beneficiary. The
label: Paragraph

text: former was an uneducated and idiosyncratic
label: Paragraph

text: idealist, the latter an indolent and cultured
label: Paragraph

text: aesthete; both used their vast wealth for two
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The Buland Darwaza (1573) is an ingenious

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: courtyard, with gates on three sides and, to
label: Paragraph

text: the west, the qib/a wall, centered on an iwan
label: Paragraph

text: with a central dome flanked by two smaller
label: Caption

text: side domes. The mihrab and the western wall
label: Caption

text: are elaborately decorated with inlay work of
label: Paragraph

text: stone mosaic and glazed tiles with azure blue
label: Caption

text: and gold inscriptions. Except for the qibla

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Diwan-i-Khas
label: Title

text: Akbar’s Diwan-i-Khas is a singular building in
label: Paragraph

text: the history of architecture. It was conceived
label: Paragraph

text: by Akbar, who was an exceptional and,
label: Paragraph

text: in many senses, a very modern thinker.
label: Paragraph

text: Although he was illiterate, he was very
label: Paragraph

text: curious about the empire he had just created.
label: Paragraph

text: He surrounded himself with philosophers
label: Paragraph

text: and aestheticians, and searched for a
label: Paragraph

text: philosophical and religious practice that
label: Paragraph

text: could, to his mind, resolve the multiplicity
label: Paragraph

text: of and contradictions among beliefs in his
label: Paragraph

text: world. Akbar constructed a new syncretic and
label: Paragraph

text: pluralistic cult, or religious practice, called
label: Paragraph

text: the Din-i-llahi, or Divine Religion, with a fairly
label: Paragraph

text: generic creed of abstinence, meditation,
label: Paragraph

text: beneficence, politeness, and mystical
label: Title

text: monotheism. In 1582, at Fatehpur Sikri,
label: Paragraph

text: Akbar officially proclaimed the birth of Din-
label: Paragraph

text: i-llahi and called a general council meeting
label: Paragraph

text: of members of all faiths to resolve all their
label: Paragraph

text: religious differences. The core of Din-i-llahi
label: Paragraph

text: was Sulh-i-kul, or tolerance of all thoughts
label: Paragraph

text: that benefit mankind. Akbar proposed
label: Paragraph

text: himself, as a unique ambassador of God, as
label: Paragraph

text: the central institution for resolving religious
label: Title

text: differences.
label: Paragraph

text: The concepts of Din-i-llahi are manifested
label: Paragraph

text: in the Diwan-i-Khas, the royal audience hall.
label: Caption

text: It is the solitary object-in-space building in
label: Paragraph

text: the main court, a two-story square box with
label: Paragraph

text: four chattris at the corners, made entirely out
label: Caption

text: of red sandstone. A deep overhanging chajja
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Rauza-i-Munavvara (Taj Mahal)
label: Caption

text: Having inherited a vast and prosperous
label: Paragraph

text: empire, Shah Jahan (1628-58) enjoyed
label: Paragraph

text: the dividends of peace. He was dedicate
label: Paragraph

text: to poetry, art, literature, and most of all to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, expending vast resources to
label: Paragraph

text: build palaces, mosques, and tombs all across
label: Paragraph

text: his empire, especially in Delhi, where he built
label: Paragraph

text: a brand-new city called Shahjahanabad. In
label: Paragraph

text: the latter half of his reign, however, the bu
label: Paragraph

text: of Shah Jahan's energies were devoted to
label: Paragraph

text: the creation of the funerary tornb for Mumtaz
label: Paragraph

text: Mahal, his favorite queen and granddaughter
label: Title

text: of the fabled Nur Jehan. The tomb was
label: Paragraph

text: nown to the Moghuls as the Rauza-I-
label: Paragraph

text: Munawara {or the Illumined Tomb), because
label: Paragraph

text: of the luster and transparency of its marb!
label: Paragraph

text: Later it was also referred to as Rauza-|-
label: Paragraph

text: Mumtaj-Mahal, which the English contracted
label: Paragraph

text: to Taj Mahal in the 19th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Mumtaz Mahal died unexpectedly in
label: Paragraph

text: 631 while giving birth to her fourteenth
label: Title

text: child. Twenty-thousand workmen labored for
label: Paragraph

text: ifteen years on her tomb. On every death
label: Paragraph

text: anniversary of Mumtaz, Shah Jahan staged
label: Title

text: the Urs celebration at the Taj Mahal. (Urs
label: Paragraph

text: celebrations involve prayers and song in
label: Paragraph

text: praise of the deceased, usually a saint.) The
label: Paragraph

text: k
label: Title

text: first Urs occurred on June 22, 1632, even
label: Paragraph

text: before the tomb was completed. Shah Jahan
label: Caption

text: was also buried on Mumtaz’s right, feet facing
label: Paragraph

text: south, and closer to the Ka’aba, as required
label: Paragraph

text: by Islam. The Taj Mahal thus is truly the tornb
label: Paragraph

text: of both Mumtaz Mahal and Shah Jahan.
label: Paragraph

text: Controversy surrounds the question of
label: Paragraph

text: who was the architect of the Taj Mahal.
label: Paragraph

text: The historical records list several people
label: Paragraph

text: responsible for the tomb, or parts of it. Ismail
label: Paragraph

text: Khan from Turkey may have designed the
label: Paragraph

text: dome. Qazim Khan frorn Lahore cast its gold
label: Caption

text: finial. Chiranjilal, a local lapidary from Delhi,
label: Paragraph

text: was the chief sculptor and mosaicist. Amanat
label: Paragraph

text: Khan from Shiraz was the chief calligrapher.
label: Paragraph

text: Other specialists included sculptors from
label: Paragraph

text: Bukhara, calligraphers from Syria and Persia,
label: Paragraph

text: inlayers from southern India, stonecutters
label: Paragraph

text: from Baluchistan, and so on. Thirty-seven
label: Caption

text: men can be counted in the creative nucleus.
label: Paragraph

text: In this sense, the Taj Mahal was a global
label: Paragraph

text: project. Yet given that Shah Jahan personally
label: Paragraph

text: supervised the design and approved every
label: Paragraph

text: aspect of the project, he must be recognized
label: Paragraph

text: as its chief architect.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The section reveals that the outer bulbous dome

label: Paragraph

text: the inner dome, so that the volume contained
label: Paragraph

text: in the upper dome is actually equivalent to
label: Paragraph

text: the volume below. Because of the high drum,
label: Paragraph

text: the outer dome rises well above the central
label: Paragraph

text: iwan of the elevation, making it the undisputed
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: compete with the central dome, making the
label: Paragraph

text: overall structure more squat than tall). The side
label: Paragraph

text: iwans are considerably lower; they are faceted
label: Paragraph

text: only on the outer side, and not on the inner as
label: Paragraph

text: at Humanyun's Tomb; and the articulation of all
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal elements has been decidedly subdued
label: Paragraph

text: in favor of the vertical. Indeed, a distinguishing
label: Paragraph

text: characteristic of the Taj Mahal's massing is that
label: Paragraph

text: in elevation, all the elements are clustered and
label: Paragraph

text: hierarchically arranged to ensure that they do
label: Paragraph

text: not compete with each other and instead build
label: Paragraph

text: up the centrality of the main dome. Even the

text: ISFAHAN
label: Title

text: In Persia, throughout the 16th century
label: Paragraph

text: various dynasties vied for control, with the
label: Paragraph

text: Safavids (who originated in Azerbaijan), led
label: Paragraph

text: by Shah Ismail | (1501-24), finally winning
label: Paragraph

text: out in 1501. The population of Persia until
label: Paragraph

text: that time had been chiefly Sunni, but Ismail
label: Paragraph

text: enforced adherence to the Shi'ite sect
label: Title

text: and began a campaign of conversion and
label: Paragraph

text: unification. He also sought to retake what
label: Paragraph

text: had been lost between 1501 and 1587 to
label: Paragraph

text: the Ottornans. Close ties with China and
label: Paragraph

text: Europe were characteristic of the period. Iraq
label: Paragraph

text: remained united with Persia until 1653, with
label: Paragraph

text: the Shiite pilgrimage centers prospering.
label: Paragraph

text: Under Shah Abbas (r. 1587-1629),
label: Paragraph

text: Isfahan—located almost in the center of Iran,
label: Paragraph

text: between Tehran and Fars—was made the
label: Paragraph

text: capital in 1598. It was rebuilt into one of the
label: Paragraph

text: largest cities of the world and the focus for all
label: Title

text: the artistic energy in the country. Transferring
label: Paragraph

text: the capital away from the insecure borderland
label: Title

text: to the center of the country was part of
label: Paragraph

text: Abbas's policy of state consolidation. Isfahan,
label: Paragraph

text: with a population of about half a million,
label: Paragraph

text: soon became a grand cosmopolitan center
label: Paragraph

text: visited by English and Dutch merchants and
label: Paragraph

text: European artists and diplomats—the latter
label: Title

text: hoping to secure alliances with the Safavid

text: named it Naqsh-e Jahan (“Design of the

text: World”). It consisted of a vast, rectangular

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: pools, promenades, and pavilions. The
label: Paragraph

text: central element in the composition—and the
label: Paragraph

text: 14.73 Main square of Isfahan, Iran

text: ink between the commercial district and the
label: Paragraph

text: avenue—was the Imperial Palace in its own
label: Paragraph

text: walled precinct, the Naqsh-e Jahan garden.
label: Caption

text: The new square—still today one of the
label: Paragraph

text: jargest in the world (512 by 159 meters)—
label: Paragraph

text: was the symbolic center of the Safavid
label: Paragraph

text: dynasty and its empire. It was used for
label: Paragraph

text: festivals, markets, and games of polo. At
label: Paragraph

text: night, fifty thousand earthenware lamps
label: Title

text: ung from poles in front of the buildings to
label: Paragraph

text: illurninate the square. It was designed with
label: Paragraph

text: two stories of shops around its perimeter.
label: Paragraph

text: The long, modular facades decorated with

text: the monumental entrances to four buildings:
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: as to face in the direction of Mecca. Its main
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the north. The mosque uses the four-iwan
label: Paragraph

text: scheme, with a central courtyard 70 meters
label: Paragraph

text: square and surrounded by two-story arcades
label: Paragraph

text: noted for a calm balance between volumetric
label: Paragraph

text: organization, decorative detail, and unifying
label: Paragraph

text: symmetry. The plan is, in fact, distinguished
label: Paragraph

text: from many other such buildings by its
label: Paragraph

text: unusual concern for such symmetry.
label: Paragraph

text: The domed sanctuary is flanked by
label: Paragraph

text: domes that serve as winter prayer halls.
label: Paragraph

text: These halls lead to rectangular courts
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by arcades that also serve as
label: Paragraph

text: madrasas. The entrance portal is a tour de
label: Caption

text: force of tile decoration, executed in a full
label: Paragraph

text: palette of six colors (dark blue, light blue,
label: Paragraph

text: white, black, yellow, and green). Glittering
label: Paragraph

text: tiers of muqarnas fill the half-dome, some
label: Paragraph

text: panels of which are decorated with stars and
label: Paragraph

text: SULEYMANIYE COMPLEX
label: Title

text: The Ottoman sultan Suleyman | (r. 1520-66),
label: Paragraph

text: also known as Suleyman the Magnificent,
label: Paragraph

text: not only expanded the reach of the Islamic
label: Paragraph

text: armies but also sought to turn Constantinople
label: Paragraph

text: into the center of Islamic civilization through a
label: Paragraph

text: series of building projects, including bridges,
label: Paragraph

text: mosques, palaces, and various charitable
label: Title

text: and social establishments. He had the
label: Paragraph

text: benefit of an extraordinarily gifted architect,
label: Paragraph

text: Mimar Sinan (1491-1588), a contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: of both Michelangelo and Andrea Palladio,
label: Paragraph

text: with whom he is often compared. Sinan
label: Paragraph

text: constructed nearly two hundred buildings
label: Paragraph

text: in Constantinople alone, changing the face
label: Paragraph

text: of the city and thereby creating its unique
label: Paragraph

text: silhouette of mighty domes and slender
label: Paragraph

text: minarets. As an officer in the military and
label: Paragraph

text: a trained engineer, Sinan assisted in the
label: Paragraph

text: building of defense works and bridges, and
label: Paragraph

text: converted churches into mosques. With the
label: Paragraph

text: capture of Cairo, he was promoted to chief
label: Paragraph

text: architect and assigned the task of putting an
label: Paragraph

text: Ottoman stamp on that city.
label: Paragraph

text: Though Sinan was consumed by the
label: Paragraph

text: ambition to create a domed building modeled
label: Paragraph

text: on the style of the Hagia Sophia, his signature
label: Paragraph

text: achievement was to fuse Seljuk features,
label: Paragraph

text: with their emphasis on portals, with the stone
label: Paragraph

text: mastery of Anatolia and the structural logic
label: Title

text: of the Byzantine domes into a seamless and
label: Paragraph

text: novel unity. This is nowhere better expressed
label: Paragraph

text: than in Sinan’s masterwork, the Suleymaniye
label: Paragraph

text: Complex, begun in 1559, commissioned by
label: Paragraph

text: Suleyman the Magnificent in the wake of his
label: Paragraph

text: military successes in Iraq and the Balkans.
label: Paragraph

text: The walled complex (216 by 144 meters)
label: Caption

text: was terraced up a hill to take advantage of
label: Paragraph

text: the view overlooking the Golden Horn to the
label: Paragraph

text: north, and it contains, among other things,
label: Paragraph

text: four madrasas, a medical madrasa and a
label: Paragraph

text: hospice, a caravansary, a bath, and a bazaar.
label: Paragraph

text: The spatial composition of the mosque is
label: Paragraph

text: obviously modeled on the Hagia Sophia,
label: Paragraph

text: and in this it was similar to a trend already
label: Paragraph

text: epitomized by the designer of the Beyazit
label: Paragraph

text: Mosque (1501-6), except that with Sinan as
label: Paragraph

text: the architect, the composition is considerably
label: Paragraph

text: tighter.
label: Paragraph

text: 14.80 Elevation and section: Suleymaniye Mosque, Istanbul
label: Caption

text: The building is also, in many respects,
label: Paragraph

text: very different from its Justinian model. It is
label: Paragraph

text: dominated by a dome 48 meters high, with
label: Paragraph

text: two flanking half-domes on the principal east-
label: Caption

text: west axis and arches on the cross-axis. The
label: Paragraph

text: weight descends to the ground by means
label: Paragraph

text: of four massive columns of granite. On the
label: Caption

text: exterior, the forecourt has a colossal portal
label: Paragraph

text: with a tympanum framed by half-columns
label: Caption

text: and minarets at the corners. Construction
label: Caption

text: was organized by a court management
label: Paragraph

text: office that, in consultation with the sultan,
label: Paragraph

text: planned and oversaw the building project.
label: Paragraph

text: Workers were Muslims as well as Christians
label: Paragraph

text: and were organized according to their
label: Paragraph

text: skills. The decorative tiles were made in
label: Paragraph

text: Iznik, the carpets in Anatolia and Egypt,
label: Paragraph

text: and the colored and clear glass (the latter
label: Paragraph

text: a technological innovation of the time) in
label: Paragraph

text: Venice; the limestone and granite came fromm
label: Paragraph

text: the quarries on the Sea of Marmara, and the
label: Paragraph

text: lead for the window grilles and doors from the
label: Caption

text: Balkans.
label: Paragraph

text: While the Hagia Sophia was dark on the
label: Paragraph

text: inside and designed to have a mysterious
label: Paragraph

text: effect, Sinan's building is lit from floor to
label: Paragraph

text: dome in equal measure and pervaded by a
label: Paragraph

text: sense of clarity and discipline. The windows
label: Caption

text: are numerous and wide, and since the
label: Paragraph

text: galleries are pushed back, sunlight entering
label: Paragraph

text: through the windows of the sidewalls
label: Paragraph

text: reaches directly into the central space. The
label: Paragraph

text: architectural volumes are clearly legible and
label: Paragraph

text: enhanced by a corbelled gallery at the level
label: Paragraph

text: of the springing of the arches (sornewhat
label: Caption

text: similar in effect to the arch style at Santa
label: Paragraph

text: Maria del Fiore in Florence), thereby unifying
label: Paragraph

text: the central unit underneath the domes. By
label: Paragraph

text: comparison, at the Hagia Sophia, the surface
label: Paragraph

text: mosaics and gilding tend to blanket the form.
label: Paragraph

text: Sinan’s mosques served as models for Sultan
label: Paragraph

text: Ahmed’s mosque, built by Mehmet Agha,
label: Paragraph

text: a student of Sinan; it is known as the Blue
label: Paragraph

text: KREMLIN’S NEW CHURCHES
label: Title

text: The Byzantine Church, in a desperate move
label: Paragraph

text: to relieve Turkish pressure on Constantinople,
label: Paragraph

text: agreed to reunite with the Roman Catholic
label: Paragraph

text: Church (Union of Florence, 1439). The
label: Paragraph

text: Russian Church, a delegate of which was
label: Paragraph

text: present at the signing in Florence, chose,
label: Paragraph

text: jowever, to repudiate the treaty and to
label: Paragraph

text: maintain the Russian Church as defenders
label: Title

text: of the Orthodox faith. This sense of renewal,
label: Paragraph

text: along with the consolidation of central
label: Paragraph

text: Russian lands in the face of the disintegrating
label: Title

text: Mongol Empire, spurred an unprecedented
label: Paragraph

text: uilding campaign, especially under Ivan III
label: Paragraph

text: (r. 1462-1505). Despite the Russian
label: Paragraph

text: insistence on a decoupled relationship with
label: Paragraph

text: the West on matters of church doctrine,
label: Paragraph

text: van Ill sent an envoy to Italy in 1475
label: Paragraph

text: to seek out Italian architects who could
label: Paragraph

text: assist in the planning and execution of his
label: Paragraph

text: various construction projects. None was
label: Paragraph

text: more important than the redesigning of the
label: Paragraph

text: Kremlin, the hilltop fortification compound at
label: Paragraph

text: the center of Moscow that the city rulers had
label: Paragraph

text: used as their place of residence since the
label: Paragraph

text: 12th century.
label: Paragraph

text: The most important Italian architect to
label: Paragraph

text: arrive was Aristotile Fioravanti (1420-85),
label: Paragraph

text: who had worked in the service of Francesco
label: Paragraph

text: Sforza in Milan. He designed the Cathedral
label: Paragraph

text: of the Assumption or Repose of the Virgin
label: Title

text: (Uspenskii Sobor), a church that became the
label: Paragraph

text: location for the crowning of Russian rulers
label: Caption

text: and the investiture of the patriarchs of the
label: Title

text: Russian Orthodox Church. Though the design
label: Paragraph

text: rhedral of the Assumption fy +
label: Title

text: fe
label: Title

text: 14.84 Cathedral of the Assumption, Moscow
label: Caption

text: was Closely monitored by the Russian clergy,
label: Paragraph

text: ever on guard against any possible heresy *
label: Title

text: or the slightest sign of “Latinity,” the church
label: Paragraph

text: brilliantly fuses Italian and Russian motifs.
label: Paragraph

text: The cathedral was designed as an open
label: Paragraph

text: nine-square grid added to the front of the
label: Caption

text: iconostasis, which was incorporated into the
label: Paragraph

text: gridded system. Pilasters thicken the walls to
label: Paragraph

text: give the volume a typical Italian flavor. The
label: Paragraph

text: strict lines of the cornices darnpen the profile
label: Caption

text: of the semicircular zakomary gables. The
label: Paragraph

text: groin vaults support tall drums and gilded
label: Caption

text: domes. The typically Russian pentacupolar
label: Paragraph

text: silhouette brings the Italian and Russian
label: Title

text: elements together. Fioravanti’s technical
label: Paragraph

text: expertise allowed him to provide better-
label: Paragraph

text: finished limestone walls and better bricks and
label: Paragraph

text: mortar, yielding a thinner but more durable
label: Paragraph

text: structure.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the final churches begun by
label: Paragraph

text: Ivan Ill was the Cathedral of the Archangel
label: Paragraph

text: Michael (begun 1505) on a site 100
label: Paragraph

text: meters to the south of the Cathedral of the
label: Caption

text: Assumption. It was to be used as the burial
label: Paragraph

text: site for Russian rulers. The architect, Aleviz
label: Caption

text: Novyi, had arrived in Moscow in 1504
label: Paragraph

text: after completing a palace for the Crimean
label: Paragraph

text: khan, Mengli-Girei, at Bakhchisarai. He was
label: Paragraph

text: possibly Alvise Lamberti da Montagnana, a
label: Caption

text: student of Mauro Codussi, the noted Venetian
label: Paragraph

text: architect. The architecture clearly reflects a
label: Paragraph

text: Venetian style, as opposed to the Lombard
label: Paragraph

text: style of Fioravanti. The facade is of a
label: Caption

text: standard tripartite division, whereas the side
label: Paragraph

text: facade has an ababa rhythm.
label: Paragraph

text: 14.85 Plan and section: Cathedral
label: Caption

text: of the Assumption
label: Title

text: Instead of unadorned piers, as at the
label: Paragraph

text: Cathedral of the Assumption (in the city of
label: Caption

text: Vladimir, 1158-60), there are two registers
label: Paragraph

text: of pilasters, some of the earliest examples of
label: Paragraph

text: the neoclassical style in Russian architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Much like the Cathedral of the Assumption,
label: Paragraph

text: there is a fusion of khanate and classical
label: Paragraph

text: motifs, especially in the series of shell arches
label: Paragraph

text: that form the crown of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: Indeed, it was the intent of Ivan’s
label: Paragraph

text: architects to remain firmly rooted in the
label: Paragraph

text: Russian tradition, and classicism was
label: Paragraph

text: therefore sublimated into regional idioms to
label: Paragraph

text: maintain, for political purposes, a continuity
label: Paragraph

text: with the past. Thus, here were the beginnings
label: Paragraph

text: of the dialogue between classicism as a kind
label: Title

text: of universal idiom and regional expression—a
label: Paragraph

text: dialogue that persists into the present in
label: Paragraph

text: various forms.
label: Paragraph

text: Church of the Ascension
label: Title

text: Following lvan IV's conquest in 1554-6 of
label: Paragraph

text: the Khanate of Astrakhan at the mouth of the
label: Paragraph

text: Volga on the Caspian Sea, one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: important Eurasian trading arteries came into
label: Paragraph

text: Muscovite possession. Just as importantly, 8 oo. See -
label: Caption

text: the conquest gave a boost to the Russian 14.86 Church of the Archangel Michael, Moscow
label: Caption

text: Orthodox Church, which had been facing
label: Paragraph

text: challenges to its wealth, institutions, and even
label: Paragraph

text: to its doctrines from various religious groups.
label: Paragraph

text: The new churches being built at the time are
label: Paragraph

text: known as tower churches and have become
label: Paragraph

text: some of the more distinctive examples of
label: Paragraph

text: Russian architecture. One of the most noted
label: Paragraph

text: examples is the Church of the Purification
label: Paragraph

text: (latter half of the 17th century), which
label: Paragraph

text: was built in Aleksandrova Sloboda, in the
label: Paragraph

text: compound from which lvan himself ruled.
label: Paragraph

text: Built over an earlier structure, it consists
label: Paragraph

text: of a two-story polygonal arcade supporting
label: Caption

text: tiers of kokoshniki (a decorative form), an
label: Paragraph

text: open octagon, and on top, a tent roof with
label: Paragraph

text: cupola, soaring to a height of 56 meters. The
label: Caption

text: uilding thus moves away from the religious
label: Paragraph

text: traditions embedded in the pentacupolar
label: Title

text: motif toward a dynastic message, reaching its
label: Paragraph

text: apotheosis at the Church of the Ascension at
label: Caption

text: olomenskoe (1529-32) some 10 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: southeast of the Kremlin in Moscow. This
label: Paragraph

text: was a two-tier arcaded church reached
label: Paragraph

text: y external staircases, on top of which
label: Caption

text: rose an astonishing structure consisting
label: Paragraph

text: of the body of the church, three tiers of
label: Paragraph

text: lattened kokoshniki, and an octagonal drum
label: Paragraph

text: supported by a tent tower on top.

text: DOGON OF MALI
label: Title

text: nthe 17th century, the African continent
label: Title

text: elow the Islamic north consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: a complex web of social and political
label: Title

text: organizations. Some societies, like the
label: Paragraph

text: Asante, Yoruba, and Tutsi, maintained
label: Paragraph

text: large states; others, like the Mbuti and Efe
label: Paragraph

text: of central Africa and the Kalahari Desert,
label: Paragraph

text: continued a life of hunting and gathering.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the tendency to see African society
label: Paragraph

text: as a collection of self-contained and self-
label: Paragraph

text: supporting tribes, in reality, various groups
label: Paragraph

text: ad long and extensive contacts with one
label: Paragraph

text: another through trade. Neighboring societies
label: Paragraph

text: may in fact have borrowed elements of each
label: Paragraph

text: other's rituals over the centuries, making
label: Paragraph

text: it impossible to trace the precise origin
label: Paragraph

text: of particular rituals. During the 1700s,
label: Paragraph

text: aggressive Islamization from the north deeply
label: Title

text: impacted and changed West African nations,
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Bambara, but full Islamization,
label: Paragraph

text: still a matter of political friction to this day,
label: Paragraph

text: was never achieved; often, a hybrid religious
label: Paragraph

text: culture wasa created instead.
label: Paragraph

text: Western Africa was for a while dominated
label: Paragraph

text: y the Mali Empire and then the Songhai,
label: Paragraph

text: oth of which had strong trade connections
label: Paragraph

text: to the north. But when the latter were
label: Paragraph

text: defeated by Moroccan forces, the area was
label: Paragraph

text: eft to various regional powers, and the center
label: Paragraph

text: of political and economic gravity moved to the
label: Paragraph

text: coast (to the Asante kingdom in Ghana and,
label: Paragraph

text: farther east, to Benin, in the modern state of
label: Paragraph

text: igeria) and eastward to the Bornu Empire in
label: Paragraph

text: iger. The Mossi retained control of the Mali
label: Paragraph

text: eartland in central Burkina Faso.

text: 14.89 Dogon communal structure, Mali
label: Caption

text: Between the 12th and 17th centuries,
label: Paragraph

text: difficulties with the Mossi and with Islamic
label: Title

text: slave raiders forced several groups in Mali
label: Paragraph

text: to move east, to more defensible positions
label: Paragraph

text: along and below the Bandiagara Cliffs, a
label: Paragraph

text: 150-kiloreter-long sandstone escarpment
label: Caption

text: in south-central Mali. The name Dogon was
label: Paragraph

text: given to these people by the French in the
label: Paragraph

text: early 20th century, even though they are
label: Paragraph

text: not a homogeneous group but a mosaic
label: Title

text: of different cultures, as is clear from their
label: Paragraph

text: language, which consists of numerous
label: Paragraph

text: dialects. In their new homes, the Dogon
label: Paragraph

text: encountered a preexisting culture, the Tellem,
label: Paragraph

text: whom they accepted into their society.
label: Paragraph

text: Even today, the Teller are the smithies for
label: Paragraph

text: the Dogon, and they are responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: making the important ancestor statues that
label: Paragraph

text: are commissioned by Dogon elders for their
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonies. The Tellem are held in awe
label: Paragraph

text: because of their magical powers, but they are
label: Paragraph

text: seen as lesser in the highly stratified society
label: Paragraph

text: of the Dogon. Despite differences, the various
label: Paragraph

text: groups have lived in rernarkable peace over
label: Paragraph

text: the centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: In Dogon society, an individual's status is
label: Paragraph

text: determined by position within family groups
label: Title

text: and by hierarchies based on age and rules
label: Paragraph

text: 14.90 Dogon houses, Mali
label: Caption

text: of descent. Religion involves the worship
label: Paragraph

text: of ancestors as well as spirits. The Dogon
label: Paragraph

text: believe, however, in one god, Amma, who is
label: Paragraph

text: all-knowing and all-powerful and who upholds
label: Paragraph

text: the balance between the living and the dead.
label: Paragraph

text: Each clan has its own altar (taba) to Amma.
label: Paragraph

text: The Léwé cult, dedicated to agricultural
label: Paragraph

text: renewal, is the principal cult that reenacts
label: Paragraph

text: the departure from the ancestral homeland.
label: Paragraph

text: Its main symbol is the snake that comes
label: Paragraph

text: out of the earth of the ancestors and that
label: Paragraph

text: accompanies the tribes on their journey.
label: Paragraph

text: These and other ceremonies are overseen by
label: Paragraph

text: priests. All the rites and ceremonies involved
label: Paragraph

text: masking, performed by males personifying
label: Paragraph

text: supernatural beings and speaking their
label: Title

text: special language.
label: Paragraph

text: Dogon society is spread out over a vast
label: Paragraph

text: area of cities, villages, and clan compounds.
label: Paragraph

text: Some of the larger cities have more than
label: Paragraph

text: 5000 inhabitants and are composed

text: Venice’s opposition to the Ottomans,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: by the Spanish, replaced the Venetian
label: Paragraph

text: galleys; Antwerp had become Europe's
label: Paragraph

text: most important port, and Portugal, using
label: Paragraph

text: its new shipping lanes around the Cape of
label: Paragraph

text: Good Hope, had brought the cost of pepper
label: Paragraph

text: down considerably. In 1505, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: pepper imported frorn Venice over the old
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: while Portuguese pepper cost only about 16
label: Paragraph

text: groats. For a while, Venice managed to hold
label: Paragraph

text: on to its economic position largely because
label: Paragraph

text: of its mainland farms. {It has been estimated
label: Paragraph

text: that by 1630 about 35 percent of patrician
label: Paragraph

text: income came from Venice’s mainland
label: Paragraph

text: estates.) But eventually, the long-maturing
label: Paragraph

text: crisis approached a climax, and by 1670
label: Paragraph

text: Venice was a shell of its former self.
label: Paragraph

text: In the interim brief window of opportunity,
label: Paragraph

text: Andrea Palladio (1508-80) rose to
label: Paragraph

text: prominence, designing most of his buildings
label: Paragraph

text: not in Venice where trade was in decline, but
label: Paragraph

text: on the farming mainland, in Vicenza. Palladio
label: Caption

text: was trained as a mason, but under the
label: Paragraph

text: influence of the humanist poet Giangiorgio
label: Paragraph

text: Trissino, who became his first patron,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: extensive studies of the ancient buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: publishing his findings in 1554 in the treatise
label: Paragraph

text: Le antichita di Roma. In 1545, he was given
label: Paragraph

text: his first major commission, the rebuilding of
label: Paragraph

text: the Basilica in Vicenza.
label: Caption

text: The villas Palladio designed for the great
label: Caption

text: Venetian farming families were far different
label: Paragraph

text: from those of the popes in Rome or the
label: Paragraph

text: Medici in Florence, which were designed
label: Paragraph

text: for urban grandness and privacy. Palladio's
label: Paragraph

text: villas were working farms that had to
label: Paragraph

text: simultaneously be both functional and
label: Paragraph

text: dignified by access to the orders of antiquity.
label: Paragraph

text: This made Palladio a protomodernist, in
label: Paragraph

text: that he created buildings for cormmon use.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the numerous villas he designed, the
label: Paragraph

text: most distinguished are Villa Barbaro (1549),
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Foscari {La Malcontenta, 1560), and
label: Paragraph

text: have splendid, elevated temple-front facades

text: giving access to a great hall. Their layouts
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the rooms, too, are governed by simple
label: Paragraph

text: proportions (1 by 1, 2 by 3, 3 by 4, etc.).
label: Paragraph

text: Windows and internal doorways are often
label: Paragraph

text: aligned, adding even more cohesion to
label: Paragraph

text: the interiors. Villa Foscari became a model
label: Paragraph

text: for palaces, villas, and houses throughout
label: Paragraph

text: Europe and the Americas. The inner planning
label: Title

text: was based on a large cruciform hall that
label: Paragraph

text: reaches from front to back. Its dramatic
label: Paragraph

text: temple front, very three-dimensional,
label: Paragraph

text: faces the Brenta River. Being so intimately
label: Paragraph

text: connected with this gentle river imparts a
label: Paragraph

text: special atmosphere of practicality to the villa.
label: Paragraph

text: Not only could its owners easily cormmute to
label: Paragraph

text: the Venetian lagoon, but its farm products
label: Paragraph

text: could be transported to market. The villa was
label: Paragraph

text: commissioned in 1550 and has in modern
label: Paragraph

text: times again returned to members of the
label: Paragraph

text: Foscari family, who have carefully restored it.
