text: BAROQUE ITALY
label: Title

text: The Baroque style emerged in Rome
label: Paragraph

text: essentially as a counterstatement to the
label: Paragraph

text: Reformation; the architects who had
label: Paragraph

text: contributed most to bring it to its ripe
label: Paragraph

text: and full-fledged characteristics were
label: Paragraph

text: Giovanni Lorenzo Bernini (1598-1680) and
label: Paragraph

text: Francesco Castelli Borromini (1599-1667).
label: Paragraph

text: t is important here to differentiate Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque from European Baroque. Baroque
label: Paragraph

text: Rome waned after 1648 under Pope
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander VII. From that time forward the
label: Paragraph

text: papacy was no longer a major power in
label: Paragraph

text: European politics. With the ascendancy of
label: Paragraph

text: France and Austria, the Baroque style began
label: Paragraph

text: to change, assuming a more urban form and,
label: Paragraph

text: insofar as it was now also applied to chateaux
label: Paragraph

text: and princes’ castles, acquiring elements
label: Paragraph

text: such as public parks and waterworks.
label: Paragraph

text: Approaches often extended far into the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape with elongated perspectives.
label: Paragraph

text: In France it is exernplified by the Place
label: Paragraph

text: Venddme in Paris and the Chateau de Vaux-
label: Paragraph

text: le-Vicomte (1656-61) by André Le Nétre; in
label: Caption

text: Austria, by the castle of Schénbrunn Palace
label: Caption

text: (1695). Eventually the Baroque became
label: Paragraph

text: an architecture of the late 17th-century
label: Title

text: European capitals—Rome, Paris, London,
label: Caption

text: and Vienna—giving to these cities a profile
label: Title

text: that remains very much part of their identities
label: Paragraph

text: today. On the negative side, many venerable
label: Paragraph

text: old buildings of the Middle Ages were
label: Paragraph

text: given new Baroque facades or makeovers,
label: Paragraph

text: their interiors upgraded to conform to the
label: Paragraph

text: “modernizing” trend of the Baroque.
label: Paragraph

text: The decade of the 1620s was a
label: Paragraph

text: particularly promising moment in church
label: Paragraph

text: politics. The heroes of the Counter-
label: Title

text: Reformation (many of them Spanish) were
label: Paragraph

text: canonized—Charles Borromeo in 1610;
label: Paragraph

text: ignatius de Loyola, Francis Xavier, Filippo
label: Title

text: eri, and Teresa of Avila, all in 1622; and
label: Paragraph

text: Gaetano da Thiene in 1629. This, in itself,
label: Paragraph

text: was a signal for new churches and chapels to
label: Paragraph

text: e built, in honor of the new saints.
label: Paragraph

text: In church architecture, the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: cross, which was sometimes favored in the
label: Paragraph

text: Renaissance because of its syrnmetry, was
label: Paragraph

text: rejected for the conventions of the Latin
label: Paragraph

text: cross, which was liturgically more satisfying
label: Paragraph

text: for Counter-Reformation purposes, as it
label: Paragraph

text: allowed for a clear separation between clergy
label: Paragraph

text: 14.99 Palace of the Senators, Campidoglio, Rome
label: Caption

text: and laity, this being one of the distinctions
label: Paragraph

text: between Catholic and Protestant churches
label: Title

text: of the time. The preference, as established
label: Paragraph

text: at Il Gesu, was for a longitudinal nave
label: Paragraph

text: unencumbered as much as possible by
label: Paragraph

text: side aisles. Transepts were minimized or
label: Caption

text: nonexistent, allowing the use of rectangles
label: Paragraph

text: and ovals, which also helped to create a
label: Paragraph

text: sense of community that these churches
label: Title

text: were to inculcate. Baroque architects
label: Paragraph

text: preferred curves to straight lines, deploying
label: Paragraph

text: niches, walls, pilasters, and attached
label: Caption

text: columns in a seamless way that made
label: Paragraph

text: architecture seem pliant and rubbery—not
label: Paragraph

text: framing the liturgical but part of it. They also
label: Paragraph

text: had an appreciation of rhythmic movement
label: Paragraph

text: through space, and intensified visual
label: Paragraph

text: dynamics with the use of painting as well
label: Paragraph

text: as sculptural putti (winged babies), which
label: Paragraph

text: often inhabit the higher reaches of the space,
label: Paragraph

text: sitting on ledges and entablatures. While in
label: Paragraph

text: medieval cathedrals stained glass modulated
label: Title

text: the light, Baroque churches had plain glass
label: Paragraph

text: devoid of tracery and the windows were often
label: Paragraph

text: unseen, designed to create a mysterious
label: Paragraph

text: and diffuse light. One often finds a Baroque
label: Paragraph

text: church quite luminous upon entering—
label: Paragraph

text: without first noticing any windows at all.

text: The European 16th century was marked in
label: Paragraph

text: the main by the Reformation and Counter-
label: Title

text: Reformation triggered by a recalcitrant
label: Title

text: monk in Germany. When Martin Luther
label: Paragraph

text: (1483-1546) nailed his Ninety-Five Theses
label: Paragraph

text: to the church door in Wittenberg in 1517,
label: Caption

text: he only wanted to reform corruption in the
label: Paragraph

text: Catholic Church. He had no idea that he was
label: Paragraph

text: about to change the course of history. The
label: Paragraph

text: rebellion against the church spread and soon
label: Paragraph

text: embroiled Europe in terrible wars for most
label: Paragraph

text: of the next two centuries. Additional reform
label: Paragraph

text: movements emerged—such as the Calvinists,
label: Paragraph

text: who believed in a form of predestination—but
label: Paragraph

text: the various versions of counter-movements
label: Title

text: are for the most part surmmed up as
label: Paragraph

text: “Protestant,” a word derived from “protest.”
label: Paragraph

text: The response of the Catholic Church was
label: Paragraph

text: called the Counter-Reformation, in which
label: Paragraph

text: architecture played an important role, with
label: Paragraph

text: great emphasis put on representation.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: century, after the Renaissance, the pope

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ongoing even into the 20th century.

label: Paragraph

text: of which still survive, allowing a close look
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: sides. Each arm of the Greek cross ended
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The major institution set up by the Church
label: Paragraph

text: to fight the Reformation was the Society
label: Paragraph

text: of Jesus, also known as the Jesuits. It was
label: Paragraph

text: formed in 1534 by Ignatius Loyola (1491-
label: Paragraph

text: 1556), a Basque, and six of his followers, all
label: Paragraph

text: students at the University of Paris in France.
label: Paragraph

text: Loyola, a major force behind the Counter-
label: Paragraph

text: Reformation, founded the Society of Jesus
label: Paragraph

text: “to enter upon hospital and missionary work
label: Title

text: in Jerusalem and to go without questioning
label: Title

text: wherever the pope might direct.” The
label: Paragraph

text: principal difference between the Jesuits and
label: Paragraph

text: other orders that had traditionally emphasized
label: Paragraph

text: communal religious devotion was Loyola's
label: Paragraph

text: relaxation of a prescribed monastic life and
label: Title

text: an emphasis on a more active apostolic
label: Paragraph

text: mission. Prayer and meditation had to be
label: Paragraph

text: balanced with service and teaching. The
label: Paragraph

text: Jesuits hoped to unify religious teaching with
label: Paragraph

text: academic learning. Classical learning with
label: Paragraph

text: bible studies was required. By 1575 they had
label: Paragraph

text: established fourteen educational institutions
label: Title

text: in France with about one thousand members
label: Paragraph

text: and with some of the colleges having a
label: Paragraph

text: student population of more than eight
label: Title

text: hundred. The Jesuits also set up colleges
label: Paragraph

text: in India, Africa, and the Americas. In 1592,

text: Spain ruthlessly exploited its new

label: Paragraph

text: hand in hand with the forced introduction

text: of Christianity. At the center of Spain's
label: Paragraph

text: colonial system was a form of feudalism,
label: Paragraph

text: in which Spanish settlers (encomiendos)
label: Paragraph

text: were entrusted with large tracts of land,
label: Paragraph

text: the encomienda, along with a population
label: Paragraph

text: of not more than three hundred Indians.
label: Paragraph

text: The natives retained possession of the land,
label: Paragraph

text: which, however, officially belonged to the
label: Paragraph

text: crown of Castile. The encomiendos were
label: Paragraph

text: given the right of taxation and were allowed to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: According to a papal bull of 1493, the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: order and convert the Indians under their
label: Title

text: care to Catholicism. This, at least, was the
label: Paragraph

text: theory; in practice, the system soon became
label: Paragraph

text: corrupt and a tool for oppression and slavery.
label: Paragraph

text: The encomiendos introduced European
label: Paragraph

text: beasts of burden, farming techniques,
label: Title

text: and manufacturing processes, along with
label: Paragraph

text: extensive mining facilitated by an unlimited
label: Paragraph

text: supply of forced labor. New towns were
label: Paragraph

text: created to support the encomienda economy
label: Paragraph

text: and to connect it to the ports. A Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: colonial town was laid out on a regular
label: Paragraph

text: grid with a plaza in the center. Church and
label: Paragraph

text: administrative buildings usually faced onto
label: Paragraph

text: the plaza.
label: Paragraph

text: Hard on the heels of the conquistadores

label: Paragraph

text: assignment to claim the natives for Christ.
label: Paragraph

text: They built churches, and in an effort to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of church liturgy with local pre-Columbian
label: Title

text: practices. The friars were also the first to

label: Paragraph

text: as children of God. Central to that effort
label: Paragraph

text: encomienda turned Dominican friar who
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: cruel and harsh treatment of the natives to
label: Paragraph

text: Atrios
label: Title

text: The Spanish-American churches built by the
label: Paragraph

text: friars emphasized simplicity and directness.
label: Paragraph

text: Straighforward boxes with thick walls, often
label: Paragraph

text: buttressed on the exterior, provided a sturdy
label: Paragraph

text: frame for the Franciscan house of God.
label: Caption

text: Windows were few and usually very high. The
label: Paragraph

text: walls were unsegmented and left bare, or
label: Paragraph

text: were at best painted with simple illustrations
label: Paragraph

text: in a style not unlike that of the pre-Columbian
label: Paragraph

text: platform mounds. A simple stone table,
label: Paragraph

text: raised up by a few steps, served as an
label: Paragraph

text: altar, behind which might be a reredos—an
label: Paragraph

text: ornamental screen—often painted with
label: Paragraph

text: pictures illustrating Christ’s trials.
label: Caption

text: The real innovations were on the
label: Paragraph

text: exterior. To accommodate large groups of
label: Paragraph

text: worshippers, the friars developed the concept
label: Paragraph

text: of the atrio, a large open court, walled along
label: Paragraph

text: the edges, that used the facade of the
label: Paragraph

text: church as a backdrop; there was an outdoor
label: Paragraph

text: chapel to conduct Mass at the west end.
label: Caption

text: In its entirety, the atrio was reminiscent of
label: Paragraph

text: the plazas that fronted the pre-Columbian
label: Paragraph

text: pyramids which were familiar to the native
label: Paragraph

text: population. Within, the friars devised
label: Paragraph

text: processions, complete with stopping places
label: Paragraph

text: for the Stations of the Cross that began at the
label: Paragraph

text: church and rotated counterclockwise around
label: Paragraph

text: the atrio. The so-called stations were altars
label: Paragraph

text: that represented the events that occurred
label: Paragraph

text: as Jesus was brought to his crucifixion in
label: Paragraph

text: Jerusalem. Worshipers would stop at each,
label: Paragraph

text: thereby reenacting the way stations of
label: Paragraph

text: Jesus's suffering in a form of spatial prayer
label: Paragraph

text: that had also become common in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: uring this time. Hundreds of such atrio
label: Paragraph

text: churches were built by the Franciscans in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1560s and 1570s, with some of the
label: Paragraph

text: classic examples at Cuernavaca, Cholula,
label: Caption

text: and spices were initially the Spanish and
label: Paragraph

text: century it was the English who had risen to
label: Paragraph

text: naval preeminence.

text: Early in the 17th century, with the formation
label: Paragraph

text: of the British and the Dutch East India
label: Title

text: companies and the establishment of French
label: Title

text: Port Royal in Nova Scotia, newer powers
label: Title

text: entered the global colonial fray to compete
label: Paragraph

text: with the Spanish and the Portuguese. For the
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch, recently liberated from Spain, their
label: Paragraph

text: colonial efforts began with the fur trade, but
label: Paragraph

text: quickly gained a mercantile, banking focus.
label: Paragraph

text: tt was not gold that the Dutch were to extract
label: Paragraph

text: rom the colonies but cocoa, tobacco, and
label: Paragraph

text: sugar—addictive cash crops that could be
label: Paragraph

text: grown in vast quantities and transported
label: Paragraph

text: overseas with few losses, and which would
label: Paragraph

text: ring more profit than all the bullion of
label: Paragraph

text: the Americas combined. In this way the
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch, with the French, were responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: transforming the Americas into a cash-crop
label: Paragraph

text: economy that exploited the unique advantage
label: Paragraph

text: of the vast stores of “empty” land that fell
label: Paragraph

text: into European hands. In the long run, it
label: Paragraph

text: was this mercantile economy that flooded
label: Paragraph

text: European markets with vast amounts of
label: Paragraph

text: cheap consumable products and transformed
label: Title

text: modern European culture, putting it on the
label: Paragraph

text: path to rationalization, industrialization, and
label: Title

text: the Enlightenment.

label: Caption

text: In Amsterdam—the new center of the
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch world and a city dedicated to making
label: Title

text: money—palaces, monasteries, and castles
label: Title

text: were not part of the cultural fabric. Instead,
label: Paragraph

text: rows and rows of townhouses faced onto
label: Paragraph

text: a relatively straight arrangement of parallel
label: Paragraph

text: streets and canals. By the end of the 17th
label: Paragraph

text: century, the city’s population had grown
label: Paragraph

text: from 20,000 to 200,000 in the span of just
label: Paragraph

text: over one hundred years. The city’s exchange
label: Paragraph

text: bank, Wiselbank, founded in 1609, was for a
label: Paragraph

text: long time the largest public bank in northern
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. By the end of the 17th century, over
label: Paragraph

text: 16 million Dutch florins were on deposit
label: Paragraph

text: in its vaults—including the florins of other
label: Paragraph

text: European governments. The bank was on the
label: Paragraph

text: first floor of the new town hall (begun 1648),
label: Caption

text: designed by Jacob van Campen. On the
label: Caption

text: facade of the building, a statue of Atlas lifts
label: Caption

text: the globe on his shoulders above a pediment
label: Caption

text: in which the nations of the world offered
label: Paragraph

text: up their goods to an allegorical Amsterdam.
label: Paragraph

text: Inside, the marble floor of the huge barrel-
label: Paragraph

text: vaulted town hall, or Burgerzaal, lit from the
label: Paragraph

text: sides by two courtyards, was inscribed with
label: Paragraph

text: maps of both the heavenly and the terrestrial
label: Title

text: worlds. Though the building is almost 100
label: Paragraph

text: meters long, its facade looks like two palaces
label: Paragraph

text: stacked on top of one another.
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam's town hall was as an expression
label: Paragraph

text: of the city’s ascension in world politics, and
label: Paragraph

text: it presaged the role civic architecture was to
label: Paragraph

text: have in future European urban profiles. The
label: Paragraph

text: town hall was one of the first applications of
label: Paragraph

text: Italian Renaissance style to a monumental
label: Title

text: civic structure, and it was in many respects
label: Paragraph

text: to remain the model for town halls well into
label: Paragraph

text: the modern era. The building faced onto
label: Paragraph

text: one of the few public squares of the city,
label: Paragraph

text: called the Dam, which had as its focus a
label: Paragraph

text: tall square building known as the Wage
label: Paragraph

text: (or the public weigh-house). Here and in
label: Paragraph

text: the nearby markets, as a description put it
label: Paragraph

text: in 1664, almost the whole world seemed
label: Paragraph

text: to be assembled to buy and sell—Poles,
label: Paragraph

text: Hungarians, Frenchmen, Spaniards,
label: Paragraph

text: Muscovites, Persians, and Turks.

text: PLACE ROYALE
label: Title

text: When Henry IV came into power in France
label: Title

text: in 1589, Paris was hardly the city that it
label: Paragraph

text: is today. Despite the nominal authority of
label: Paragraph

text: the crown, France essentially functioned
label: Paragraph

text: as a highly decentralized confederacy of
label: Paragraph

text: autonomous provinces. Paris had suffered
label: Paragraph

text: several setbacks, such as the absence of
label: Paragraph

text: the kings, who preferred to live in their
label: Paragraph

text: countryside chateaux, and the general
label: Title

text: downturn of the economy in the 16th century.
label: Paragraph

text: In Paris, there was not even a royal palace.
label: Paragraph

text: With an estimated population of 20 million in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1600s, France was, however, the most
label: Paragraph

text: populous country in Europe and the third
label: Title

text: most populous country in the world—only
label: Paragraph

text: China and India had greater populations.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite a massive increase in urban
label: Paragraph

text: population, France remained a profoundly
label: Paragraph

text: rural country. Economically, the glut of gold
label: Paragraph

text: and silver from the Americas had led to
label: Paragraph

text: inflation and a vast underclass that would
label: Paragraph

text: haunt French politics for another century.
label: Paragraph

text: In deciding to make Paris a capital city
label: Paragraph

text: and the seat of a newly forming centralized
label: Title

text: nation-state, Henry IV initiated a series of
label: Paragraph

text: urban projects that were also intended to
label: Paragraph

text: boost the city's economic condition. One
label: Paragraph

text: such project was the triangular-shaped Place
label: Paragraph

text: Dauphine (1609-14), designed to provide
label: Paragraph

text: accommodations for bankers and merchants.
label: Paragraph

text: To make its importance highly visible, it
label: Paragraph

text: was located at the westernmost tip of the
label: Paragraph

text: lle de la Cité; its narrow entrance formed,
label: Paragraph

text: however, a tranquil and enclosed precinct
label: Paragraph

text: within. Another experiment in urban design
label: Paragraph

text: 14.142 Plan: 17th-century Paris
label: Caption

text: and mercantile enhancement was the Place
label: Paragraph

text: Royale (today the Place des Vosges), begun
label: Paragraph

text: around 1605 on open land at the edge of the
label: Paragraph

text: city. It was originally planned with three sides
label: Paragraph

text: for shops and apartments and the fourth for
label: Paragraph

text: a range of workshops for the manufacture of
label: Paragraph

text: silk. Though some silk was still imported from
label: Paragraph

text: China, much of it now came from Vigevano,
label: Paragraph

text: Italy, where silk production was mastered in
label: Paragraph

text: the late 15th century. Henry IV was eager
label: Paragraph

text: to reduce France's dependence on foreign
label: Paragraph

text: production, but French silk production
label: Paragraph

text: never succeeded because of the climate,
label: Paragraph

text: and eventually the whole square became a
label: Paragraph

text: residential address attracting the cream of
label: Paragraph

text: Parisian society. Presiding over the square at
label: Paragraph

text: both ends were special pavilions for the king
label: Paragraph

text: and queen, as the square was intended as a
label: Paragraph

text: setting for royal pageants. It was inaugurated
label: Paragraph

text: in 1611 when a masque and a tournament
label: Paragraph

text: were held there in celebration of the marriage
label: Paragraph

text: of Louis XIII to Anne of Austria. As a setting
label: Paragraph

text: it was well suited to the nobility and the rich
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeois who had taken up the fashion of
label: Paragraph

text: strolling and riding in carriages. Originally,
label: Paragraph

text: therefore, the square was not paved but
label: Paragraph

text: covered with a lawn and fenced in, an idea
label: Paragraph

text: unknown to the Italian Renaissance.

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: policies. Its maritime economy consisted
label: Paragraph

text: mainly of fishing, smuggling, and plundering.
label: Paragraph

text: It was at best a regional force. This began to
label: Paragraph

text: change during the reign of Queen Elizabeth |
label: Title

text: (1558-1603). She adopted modern notions
label: Paragraph

text: of management, transforming feudal
label: Title

text: magnates into officeholders. Overseas foreign on
label: Paragraph

text: investments resulted in a growing propertied
label: Paragraph

text: class, with wool and textiles becoming an
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly large part of the economy, along
label: Paragraph

text: with the production of lead, salt, and soap.
label: Paragraph

text: The population increased from 3 to 4 million
label: Paragraph

text: between 1530 and 1600, providing a large
label: Paragraph

text: reservoir of potential indentured labor. The
label: Paragraph

text: English destruction of the Spanish Armada in
label: Title

text: 1588 established the country as a sea power
label: Paragraph

text: and opened up an opportunity for the English
label: Paragraph

text: to pursue Atlantic trade, putting them on a 6
label: Paragraph

text: path to becoming the colonial superpower of
label: Title

text: the world.

text: Wollaton Hall (near Nottingham, 1580-88),
label: Caption

text: the home of an important coal magnate,
label: Paragraph

text: was already a splendid showcase for the
label: Paragraph

text: new industry. It sported at the top a special
label: Paragraph

text: “prospect room” that had no particular
label: Paragraph

text: purpose other than to show off its towering
label: Paragraph

text: fenestration. This type of fenestration can
label: Paragraph

text: be contrasted with that of Titchfield Priory
label: Paragraph

text: (Hampshire, 1537-40), which still has Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: medieval windows in the surviving gatehouse.
label: Caption

text: 14.146 Wollaton Hall, near Nottingham, England
label: Caption

text: English architecture, however, had a long
label: Paragraph

text: way to go. Houses were relatively plain and
label: Paragraph

text: rugged, and showed no fine paintings, apart
label: Paragraph

text: from portraits. Nonetheless, the change in
label: Paragraph

text: English culture was rapid and profound.
label: Paragraph

text: Old houses were set out with chimneys,
label: Paragraph

text: walls were paneled, windows glazed, and
label: Paragraph

text: old timber-framed buildings were faced with
label: Paragraph

text: stone. A particularly important innovation
label: Paragraph

text: at the time and one that affected the
label: Paragraph

text: development of Elizabethan-era architecture
label: Title

text: was the use of coal in glass firing. And
label: Paragraph

text: here, once again, immigrants played an
label: Paragraph

text: important role. Jean Carré, who was from
label: Paragraph

text: the highly contested area of Lorraine and
label: Paragraph

text: whose patent for plate glass was granted
label: Paragraph

text: in 1567, was attracted to England along
label: Paragraph

text: with other glassmakers from Lorraine. Soon
label: Paragraph

text: furnaces were being built in scattered parts
label: Paragraph

text: of the country, and prices began to fall
label: Paragraph

text: almost at once. The market responded with
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiasm.
label: Paragraph

text: 14.147 Interior, Banqueting House, London
label: Caption

text: Freee ew

text: I:
label: Title

text: Yo nmeand
label: Title

text: 14.148 Plan and elevation: Banqueting House
label: Caption

text: Banqueting House
label: Title

text: nigo Jones’s second visit to Italy from
label: Title

text: 613 to 1614, during which he studied the
label: Paragraph

text: buildings of Andrea Palladio in particular,
label: Paragraph

text: prepared the young architect for his most
label: Paragraph

text: ambitious project, the Banqueting House.
label: Paragraph

text: he first Banqueting House, appendaged
label: Paragraph

text: to the Royal Palace in London, was built in
label: Paragraph

text: 581 and served for dining and theatrical
label: Caption

text: entertainment. A second one was built in
label: Paragraph

text: 606 but was destroyed by fire in 1619.
label: Paragraph

text: he Banqueting House designed by Jones
label: Caption

text: in 1619 was less a place for banquets than
label: Paragraph

text: a royal audience hall, reflecting a greater
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on royal authority. This was the first
label: Paragraph

text: public structure in the mature Palladian style
label: Caption

text: in England. At the ground floor, the windows
label: Paragraph

text: between the pilasters are an alternating
label: Caption

text: sequence of triangulated and segmental
label: Title

text: pediments, while at the upper floor the
label: Paragraph

text: windows are all unpedimented, yielding an
label: Paragraph

text: intricate yet calm design. The central three
label: Paragraph

text: bays are emphasized by the use of attached
label: Paragraph

text: columns, and the corners by pilaster pairs.
label: Caption

text: 14.149 Church of Santo Domingo, San Cristobal de Las Casas, Mexico
label: Caption

text: The whole is raised on a low rusticated
label: Paragraph

text: basement that matches in height the
label: Paragraph

text: balustraded frieze on top. The building's
label: Paragraph

text: importance lies in the symbolic significance
label: Paragraph

text: of its Italian motifs—an attempt to extend the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural language born during Europe's
label: Title

text: mercantile revolution in the 15th century.
label: Paragraph

text: But whereas Italian architecture developed
label: Paragraph

text: in a culture of regional princes and rich
label: Paragraph

text: merchants, it was now being associated with
label: Paragraph

text: the centralization of the state. European
label: Paragraph

text: sensibility was slowly transforming from more
label: Paragraph

text: regional to more global.
label: Paragraph

text: CHURCH OF SANTO DOMINGO
label: Title

text: One of the largest Spanish churches from this
label: Paragraph

text: era is the Church of Santo Domingo in San
label: Paragraph

text: Cristobal de Las Casas, Mexico. Built between
label: Caption

text: 1547 and 1560 on the orders of Bishop
label: Title

text: Francisco de Marroquin of Guatemala, its
label: Paragraph

text: present 17th-century facade is typical of the
label: Paragraph

text: Mexican Baroque. The imperial double eagle,
label: Caption

text: the coat of arms of the Emperor Charles V,
label: Paragraph

text: can still be seen above the central portal and
label: Caption

text: on the sides. The interior is lavishly decorated
label: Caption

text: and contains a number of sculptures and
label: Paragraph

text: wooden altars covered with gold leaf.
label: Caption

text: The city San Cristébal de Las Casas was
label: Paragraph

text: laid out on a grid according to the principles
label: Paragraph

text: of the Law of the Indies, a series of laws that
label: Paragraph

text: regulated social, political, and economic
label: Title

text: life in conquered areas. The grid facilitated
label: Paragraph

text: land exploitation. A commons was always
label: Paragraph

text: established in a city’s center, in front of a
label: Paragraph

text: church or cathedral. (The Church of Santo
label: Paragraph

text: Domingo, however, was founded separately,
label: Paragraph

text: to the north of the city center.)
label: Paragraph

text: 14.150 Plan: Dry garden at Ryoanji, Kyoto, Japan
label: Caption

text: RYOANII
label: Title

text: The Zen monks invented the dry meditation
label: Paragraph

text: garden as a practical necessity. Earlier
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese garden design had been based on
label: Paragraph

text: Song Chinese examples, which were built on
label: Paragraph

text: large estates with long stroll paths that had
label: Paragraph

text: views created from the natural landscape
label: Title

text: and constructed ponds, islands, mountains,
label: Paragraph

text: and even rivers, complete with waterfalls.
label: Paragraph

text: While the miniaturization of natural elements
label: Paragraph

text: was a part of the design strategy, these
label: Paragraph

text: gardens relied on size for their effect. In the
label: Paragraph

text: 15th century, however, when the shoguns
label: Paragraph

text: began to reduce plot sizes to accommodate
label: Paragraph

text: larger populations in their cities, such
label: Paragraph

text: full-fledged gardens were impossible. The
label: Paragraph

text: newer generation of gardens, made by Zen
label: Paragraph

text: masters, were designed around the principle
label: Paragraph

text: of carefully staged views. In the process, they
label: Paragraph

text: created dry gardens, so called because they
label: Paragraph

text: employed abstract means of representation—
label: Paragraph

text: using, for example, white pebbles and moss
label: Paragraph

text: to signify large bodies of water. The Zen
label: Paragraph

text: monks particularly enjoyed creating visual
label: Paragraph

text: koans, or quizzical conundrums, that could
label: Paragraph

text: be meditated upon.
label: Paragraph

text: 14.151 Dry garden at Ryoanji
label: Caption

text: Ryoanji, the Temple of the Peaceful Dragon,
label: Title

text: contains the most famous of Japan’s dry
label: Paragraph

text: gardens, created around 1480 by an
label: Paragraph

text: unknown designer on the estate of Hosokawa
label: Caption

text: Masamoto, located in the northwestern
label: Paragraph

text: foothills of Kyoto. The southern half of the
label: Paragraph

text: estate contains a pond with an island and a
label: Paragraph

text: circumambulatory stroll path, to which was
label: Paragraph

text: added a rectangular dry garden with a bed of
label: Paragraph

text: white gravel, carefully raked to form east-west
label: Caption

text: running bands. Within it were placed fifteen
label: Paragraph

text: natural stones, clustered in five groups. The
label: Paragraph

text: gravel around therm is raked in the manner
label: Paragraph

text: of ripples in a pond. The precise meaning
label: Paragraph

text: of this koan is left open to interpretation.
label: Paragraph

text: Perhaps the white field is an ocean and the
label: Paragraph

text: rocks islands. The rocks could also stand
label: Paragraph

text: for a tigress leading her cubs across a river.
label: Paragraph

text: Ultimately, the garden is not meant to convey
label: Paragraph

text: a singular interpretation but to serve as an aid
label: Paragraph

text: to meditation, with the empty space between
label: Paragraph

text: the stones just as important as the stones
label: Paragraph

text: themselves—perhaps even more so.
label: Paragraph

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: By the early 18th century, cities like
label: Paragraph

text: Samarkand, Bukhara, Aleppo, Istanbul,
label: Caption

text: Venice, and Florence, once at the heart of
label: Paragraph

text: Eurasian trade, were becoming increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: marginal to the new world economy centered
label: Title

text: on the maritime ports established by the
label: Paragraph

text: European colonial powers. This phenomenon
label: Paragraph

text: was global, spawning major new metropolises
label: Paragraph

text: such as Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore,
label: Paragraph

text: Bombay (now Mumbai), Calcutta (now
label: Paragraph

text: Kolkata), Madras (now Chennai), Cape
label: Paragraph

text: Town, St.-Louis (Senegal), Rio de Janeiro,
label: Caption

text: Buenos Aires, Boston, and New York. It is
label: Paragraph

text: not surprising, then, that the architectural
label: Paragraph

text: survey of this time shows a world in which
label: Paragraph

text: some areas were rapidly transforming under
label: Paragraph

text: the modernizing sway of colonization, while
label: Paragraph

text: others, in spite of the colonial frenzy, still
label: Paragraph

text: clung to the old ways as long as possible.
label: Paragraph

text: This tumult of transformation centered on
label: Paragraph

text: the Americas. Two hundred years after their
label: Paragraph

text: conquest by the Europeans, the indigenous
label: Paragraph

text: civilizations of the American continents
label: Title

text: had been almost completely destroyed. In
label: Paragraph

text: their stead, a brand-new and revolutionary
label: Paragraph

text: system of wealth generation was invented—
label: Paragraph

text: the hacienda, or plantation, where vast
label: Paragraph

text: tracts of land were used to grow a single
label: Paragraph

text: or a few crops that could be shipped back
label: Paragraph

text: to Europe for profit. Plantation culture not
label: Paragraph

text: only transformed America; it also drastically
label: Paragraph

text: impacted Africa, where an infrastructure was
label: Paragraph

text: built to support the slave trade—including the
label: Paragraph

text: development of internal exploitative cultures
label: Title

text: to facilitate the capture of slaves. Slavery
label: Paragraph

text: put in place the hard divisions of racism in
label: Paragraph

text: America, particularly after it was legalized into
label: Paragraph

text: a race-based, hereditary institution in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 17th century.
label: Paragraph

text: The plantation economies had the most
label: Paragraph

text: transformative effect on Europe, where the
label: Paragraph

text: massive influx of colonial wealth and goods
label: Title

text: radically remade urban culture. As colonial
label: Paragraph

text: merchants plied European streets with coffee,
label: Paragraph

text: sugar, tobacco, and tea, they created new
label: Paragraph

text: urban institutions, such as coffeehouses,
label: Paragraph

text: along with new building types, such as
label: Paragraph

text: bourgeois apartments (or Adte/s), parks, and
label: Paragraph

text: theaters. This urban culture, which in so
label: Paragraph

text: many ways still exists today, was instrumental
label: Paragraph

text: in the rise of the bourgeoisie and preliminary
label: Title

text: to the discourses and ferment that led to
label: Paragraph

text: the European Enlightenment in the late 18th
label: Title

text: century. If today the coffeehouse is essentially
label: Paragraph

text: a place of recreation and quiet study—
label: Title

text: perhaps the new library of our times—it is
label: Paragraph

text: interesting to look back and see that it started
label: Paragraph

text: as a site of novelty and exploration, a place to
label: Paragraph

text: experience the new products of the colonial
label: Title

text: world.
label: Paragraph

text: The massive size of the colonial
label: Paragraph

text: plantations, and the correspondingly
label: Paragraph

text: massive volume of products that were
label: Paragraph

text: grown, processed, shipped, distributed, and
label: Paragraph

text: consumed—along with all the economic side
label: Paragraph

text: eddies that this system generated—created
label: Paragraph

text: an economic engine of unprecedented scale
label: Paragraph

text: for Europe. It required a reimagining of
label: Paragraph

text: governance and management that resulted
label: Title

text: in a new administrative culture focused on
label: Paragraph

text: rationalization and efficiency. Although the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish were first in this reorganization, the
label: Paragraph

text: French soon took the lead. Jean Baptiste
label: Paragraph

text: Colbert, a renowned workaholic who served
label: Paragraph

text: as the minister of finances from 1665 to
label: Paragraph

text: 1683 under Louis XIV, took upon himself
label: Paragraph

text: the task of overhauling and rationalizing the
label: Paragraph

text: French government and bureaucracy. His
label: Paragraph

text: administrative machinery gave the French,
label: Paragraph

text: and subsequently the Dutch and English,
label: Paragraph

text: who followed suit, a decisive advantage over
label: Paragraph

text: the Spanish and Portuguese in the colonial
label: Title

text: competition.
label: Paragraph

text: Rationalization and efficiency, as the new
label: Paragraph

text: administrative mantras of the times, also
label: Paragraph

text: affected the culture. In architecture, the
label: Paragraph

text: ongoing adaptation of the styles of antiquity
label: Title

text: for modern purposes was subjected to
label: Paragraph

text: rationalization. The culture of science began
label: Paragraph

text: to assert itself, particularly the questions of
label: Paragraph

text: astronomy necessary for naval navigation.
label: Paragraph

text: Although reason—beyond rationalization—
label: Title

text: had yet to become the dominant discourse
label: Paragraph

text: of philosophy, its ideas were already being
label: Paragraph

text: addressed in works such as those of
label: Paragraph

text: Galileo and Copernicus. The push toward
label: Paragraph

text: science was furthered in particular by the
label: Paragraph

text: innumerable nautical and territorial maps
label: Title

text: that had to constantly be made and updated;
label: Paragraph

text: the success of the colonial missions relied
label: Paragraph

text: on their accuracy. As countries carefully
label: Paragraph

text: guarded their knowledge of new cartographic
label: Paragraph

text: information, it is no surprise that the French,
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch, and English disputed the location of
label: Paragraph

text: the prime meridian.
label: Paragraph

text: The European upper classes largely
label: Title

text: expended their new wealth building
label: Title

text: fantastic new palaces and the like, the
label: Paragraph

text: most celebrated example being Louis XIV's
label: Paragraph

text: extravaganza at Versailles. The fusses and
label: Paragraph

text: frills of the Baroque continued to hold court
label: Paragraph

text: in these palaces, as they did in the numerous
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque churches and abbeys that were built
label: Title

text: across Europe. The Russians, under Czar
label: Paragraph

text: Alexander, forced their way to the Baltic Sea
label: Paragraph

text: in search of a viable port. Here, instead of
label: Paragraph

text: launching a massive colonial campaign to
label: Paragraph

text: compete with the British and French, they
label: Paragraph

text: built a massive new capital city called St.
label: Paragraph

text: Petersburg, founded in 1703 and modeled
label: Paragraph

text: after French and Italian Baroque precedents.
label: Paragraph

text: St. Petersburg was a project both heroic
label: Paragraph

text: and extravagant, a self-conscious attempt
label: Paragraph

text: to “catch up” with other countries that
label: Paragraph

text: were considered more advanced by simply
label: Paragraph

text: importing their culture and knowledge via a
label: Paragraph

text: massive systematic transfer—thus mistaking
label: Paragraph

text: symptom for cause. Such efforts would be
label: Paragraph

text: repeated many times over in years to come,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly by nations that were late to the
label: Paragraph

text: colonial enterprise.
label: Paragraph

text: In England, the revolution wrought by the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of the Church of England continued
label: Title

text: to play itself out with the radical Puritan
label: Paragraph

text: call for de-Catholicization, which for a short
label: Paragraph

text: while starting in 1688 even resulted in the
label: Paragraph

text: overthrow of the monarchy. Its subsequent
label: Paragraph

text: restoration resulted in the prosecution of the
label: Paragraph

text: Puritans, many of whom then left for New
label: Paragraph

text: England to join descendants of the Mayflower
label: Title

text: passengers. In the new world they sought to
label: Paragraph

text: build their Puritan churches with renewed
label: Paragraph

text: vigor, but their congregations included
label: Paragraph

text: dissenters, such as Roger Williams, who
label: Paragraph

text: left to found his own colony in Providence,
label: Paragraph

text: Rhode Island, with religious toleration as
label: Paragraph

text: one of its cornerstones. In keeping with
label: Paragraph

text: their larger ethic, the Puritans, like the
label: Paragraph

text: adherents of the Church of England, followed
label: Paragraph

text: the austere renderings of a neo-Palladian
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that relied on proportion and
label: Paragraph

text: order for effect, rather than on style and
label: Paragraph

text: gesture as in the Baroque style.
label: Paragraph

text: By the early 18th century, the Whigs had
label: Paragraph

text: emerged as a force in English politics; they
label: Paragraph

text: were strong supporters of English mercantile
label: Paragraph

text: expansion (with protections in place) and
label: Paragraph

text: advocates of constitutional monarchy. It was
label: Paragraph

text: under the Whigs, and in their wake, that Sir
label: Paragraph

text: Christopher Wren built his neo-Palladian
label: Paragraph

text: churches in the aftermath of a great fire. The
label: Paragraph

text: English picturesque garden now emerged—
label: Paragraph

text: influenced though it was by descriptions of
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese gardens—as an irregular landscape
label: Paragraph

text: with distributed follies that sought to unite
label: Paragraph

text: the experience of the peripatetic visitor with
label: Paragraph

text: surrounding nature. These gardens, along
label: Paragraph

text: with philosophical propositions such as cogito
label: Paragraph

text: ergo sum (| think, therefore | arm), were at the
label: Paragraph

text: genesis of the Enlightenment’s autonomous
label: Title

text: subject.
label: Paragraph

text: The African slave trade was going full
label: Paragraph

text: steam in the 1700s. Most of the slaves came
label: Paragraph

text: from West Africa, and as a consequence,
label: Paragraph

text: social structures in the region were
label: Paragraph

text: devastated.
label: Paragraph

text: Meanwhile, the mineral wealth extracted
label: Paragraph

text: from America continued to find its way
label: Title

text: across the Pacific to China, where it was
label: Paragraph

text: exchanged by the Chinese for luxury goods
label: Title

text: such as porcelain and lacquerware. In the
label: Paragraph

text: 17th century, China was in transition from
label: Paragraph

text: the rule of the Ming to the Qing dynasty.
label: Paragraph

text: The Ming, unable to capitalize on their early
label: Paragraph

text: gains, had overprinted the Middle Kingdom's
label: Paragraph

text: paper currency (the world’s first), which led
label: Paragraph

text: to serious inflation. In consequence, silver
label: Paragraph

text: began to circulate as the de facto currency of
label: Paragraph

text: the realm, which promoted coastal piracy.
label: Paragraph

text: Into the gap stepped the Manchu,
label: Paragraph

text: Jurchen Mongolians from the northeastern
label: Title

text: frontier of China, who took over Ming China
label: Paragraph

text: without a major battle and formed the Qing
label: Paragraph

text: dynasty. Although theirs was still the largest
label: Paragraph

text: economy in the world by far, the Qing quickly
label: Paragraph

text: realized that they desperately needed silver
label: Paragraph

text: to stabilize the currency. They also had to
label: Paragraph

text: legitimize themselves as rulers, since they
label: Paragraph

text: were a small and foreign minority. Not only
label: Paragraph

text: did they manage to stabilize the currency,
label: Paragraph

text: but they were also able to establish—first
label: Paragraph

text: under the rule of the Kangxi Emperor and
label: Paragraph

text: then under his grandson, the Qianlong
label: Paragraph

text: Emperor—an administrative order that
label: Paragraph

text: merged Confucian and Han Chinese systems
label: Title

text: with a transnational Manchu perspective that
label: Paragraph

text: was keenly aware of the wider world beyond
label: Paragraph

text: the Middle Kingdom. With their wealth, the
label: Paragraph

text: Qing vastly expanded their borders, built vast
label: Paragraph

text: and lavish palaces and gardens, established
label: Paragraph

text: new cities, and, most importantly, renewed
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructure. They also produced a new
label: Paragraph

text: and comprehensive manual on building
label: Title

text: construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Even though a great quantity of Qing
label: Paragraph

text: architecture still stands, it is not best served
label: Paragraph

text: by a detailed analysis of its formal properties.
label: Paragraph

text: Formal orders and the quest for their
label: Title

text: perfection were an obsession in Europe at
label: Paragraph

text: that time, but in China these things had been
label: Paragraph

text: settled for some time and were no longer the
label: Paragraph

text: defining question. Rather, the focus was on
label: Paragraph

text: standardization, efficiency, and integration
label: Title

text: with the larger administrative machinery of
label: Paragraph

text: the empire.
label: Paragraph

text: Qing China functioned as an efficient
label: Paragraph

text: pre-modern empire and quickly became the
label: Paragraph

text: cynosure of European intellectuals. Colonial
label: Paragraph

text: ships carried missionaries to China, who
label: Paragraph

text: settled there and subsequently produced
label: Paragraph

text: detailed accounts of life and order under
label: Title

text: the Qing. These illustrated accounts made
label: Paragraph

text: their way to Europe, where they were
label: Paragraph

text: avidly read and citied by Enlightenment
label: Paragraph

text: thinkers, particularly those who were keen to
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrate nonreligious moral and political
label: Paragraph

text: orders. It is in this sense that European stroll
label: Paragraph

text: gardens such as Stowe in England, which
label: Paragraph

text: were trying to establish the new human
label: Paragraph

text: subject who was comfortable in nature rather
label: Paragraph

text: than differentiated from it, can be seen as a
label: Paragraph

text: reading of Chinese garden precedents. The
label: Paragraph

text: Qing bureaucracy, or jinshi system, based on
label: Paragraph

text: open competitive exams, was the role model
label: Paragraph

text: of the European civil services. On the Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: side, the Qing invited the Jesuits to court to
label: Paragraph

text: learn from them and even built one of their
label: Paragraph

text: palaces in European Baroque style.
label: Paragraph

text: The Koreans, strong supporters of the
label: Paragraph

text: Ming, were forced to recognize the Qing
label: Paragraph

text: authority in China; but once they did, they
label: Paragraph

text: quickly adopted to it.
label: Paragraph

text: In Japan, the Tokugawa shoguns were
label: Paragraph

text: also in the midst of redefining their culture
label: Paragraph

text: at this time, creating a world that followed
label: Paragraph

text: a strict code of behavior. The Bakafu code,
label: Paragraph

text: as it was known, was in many respects
label: Paragraph

text: astonishingly modern, as the rising middle
label: Paragraph

text: class sought ways to articulate institutions
label: Paragraph

text: suitable to its needs despite the restrictions
label: Paragraph

text: placed on it by the shoguns.
label: Paragraph

text: The original colonial project to find an
label: Paragraph

text: ocean route to the Indies for the spice trade
label: Title

text: continued to be pursued by several European
label: Paragraph

text: powers—the Portuguese in particular, but
label: Paragraph

text: also by the Dutch and the French—via
label: Paragraph

text: private companies with monopolistic charters.
label: Paragraph

text: The Portuguese built forts across the Amazon
label: Paragraph

text: delta, and then across South and East Asia.
label: Paragraph

text: In this way, the Portuguese colonial port
label: Paragraph

text: network established the first infrastructure of
label: Paragraph

text: today's global cities of Asia. The Dutch did
label: Paragraph

text: the same, but their focus was on the fertile
label: Paragraph

text: spice islands of modern-day Indonesia. The
label: Paragraph

text: French, too, built trading posts worldwide,
label: Paragraph

text: but their main interest, in competition with
label: Paragraph

text: England, was in New England, Canada, and
label: Paragraph

text: along the Mississippi. In these areas the
label: Paragraph

text: French traded in fur, a commodity with a vast
label: Paragraph

text: market in the frigid lands of northern Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: where there were few forests left.
label: Paragraph

text: In India, European colonial cornpanies
label: Paragraph

text: traded and built ports with the consent of the
label: Paragraph

text: Mughals, who remained formidable through
label: Paragraph

text: the 17th century. Aurangzeb (r. 1658-1707)
label: Caption

text: vastly expanded the Mughal Empire, bringing
label: Paragraph

text: erstwhile vassal states directly under Mughal
label: Title

text: control. But unlike his predecessors and his
label: Paragraph

text: Qing contemporaries in China, Aurangzeb
label: Title

text: adopted a much less tolerant attitude toward
label: Paragraph

text: the diversity of India's peoples and cultures,
label: Paragraph

text: and consequently his death in 1707 initiated
label: Paragraph

text: a series of revolts. Shuja-ud-Daula in northern
label: Paragraph

text: India, the Nawab of Oudh in Bengal, the
label: Paragraph

text: Sikhs in Punjab, the Rajputs in Rajasthan,
label: Paragraph

text: and the Marathas in the Deccan wrestled
label: Title

text: for power. At the same time, European
label: Paragraph

text: colonizers began to build on their coastal
label: Paragraph

text: footholds and start to acquire hinterlands. As
label: Paragraph

text: a result, though this was a turbulent period
label: Paragraph

text: in India, from a cultural and architectural
label: Paragraph

text: perspective it was also a time of tremendous
label: Paragraph

text: exploration. Jaipur, a beautiful new city, was
label: Paragraph

text: laid out by Sawai Jai Singh, a former Mughal
label: Paragraph

text: general, along an important trade highway.
label: Paragraph

text: The Sikhs, a reformist movement, took
label: Paragraph

text: root in northwestern India and established
label: Paragraph

text: a formidable kingdom. Darbar Sahib
label: Paragraph

text: (“Golden Temple”) in Amritsar was their
label: Paragraph

text: most important shrine. The Mallas of Nepal,
label: Paragraph

text: meanwhile, enjoyed relative immunity from
label: Paragraph

text: these global events next door, but their royal
label: Paragraph

text: square in Patan embodied its own global
label: Paragraph

text: history.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast to the energy on both sides of
label: Paragraph

text: the Atlantic, in China, and in India, building
label: Paragraph

text: activity in West and Central Asia slowed
label: Title

text: down. The Ottomans held strong throughout
label: Paragraph

text: the 17th century and in 1683 laid siege to
label: Paragraph

text: Vienna again (after the first unsuccessful
label: Title

text: siege of 1529) but were conclusively
label: Paragraph

text: defeated. In 1722, the Safavids of Persia
label: Paragraph

text: were overrun by the Afghans. During the 18th
label: Paragraph

text: century, the Ottorman Empire continued to
label: Paragraph

text: reign from Istanbul, but it was now buffeted
label: Paragraph

text: by the new wealth of the Atlantic trade. As

text: COLONIALISM
label: Title

text: By the end of the 17th century, what had
label: Paragraph

text: begun as risky sojourns to distant lands in
label: Paragraph

text: search of less expensive spices developed
label: Title

text: into a struggle among the various European
label: Title

text: nations for control of coastal trading posts
label: Title

text: across the globe and with them, wherever
label: Paragraph

text: possible, the hinterland that supplied those
label: Paragraph

text: ports. The principal competitors were
label: Paragraph

text: Portugal, Spain, Holland, France, and Britain.
label: Paragraph

text: For the first two centuries of its history
label: Paragraph

text: (roughly the 16th-18th centuries), the
label: Paragraph

text: colonial project was focused on the
label: Paragraph

text: competition to exploit and develop the
label: Paragraph

text: Americas. Spain, Portugal, and then
label: Paragraph

text: France, England, and Holland all competed
label: Paragraph

text: aggressively for a piece of the American pie—
label: Title

text: first for its mineral wealth and then, more
label: Paragraph

text: profitably and impacttfully, for its land. At the
label: Paragraph

text: same time, all these European powers except
label: Paragraph

text: Spain also developed trading ports around
label: Paragraph

text: the rest of the rest of the globe, particularly
label: Paragraph

text: along the coasts of South, Southeast, and
label: Paragraph

text: East Asia. But at this time, these ports had
label: Paragraph

text: only a fraction of the value of the American
label: Paragraph

text: territories. It would not be until the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century—as most of the colonies in the
label: Paragraph

text: Americas became independent and European
label: Title

text: wealth, particularly that of England, increased
label: Paragraph

text: exponentially with industrialization—that the
label: Paragraph

text: Buenos Aires
label: Title

text: colonial enterprise became fully global.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially, the Portuguese focused on
label: Paragraph

text: developing the Amazon coast, and the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish conquistadores maintained their
label: Paragraph

text: aggressive focus on annexing the territories of
label: Paragraph

text: Central America and Andean South America.
label: Paragraph

text: But then, as the gold and silver began to
label: Paragraph

text: run out, they invented the plantation and its
label: Paragraph

text: hacienda culture focused on the large-scale
label: Paragraph

text: production of sugar, coffee, and cocoa using
label: Paragraph

text: indentured labor. Most of the mineral wealth
label: Paragraph

text: was gone or tightly controlled by the time the
label: Paragraph

text: French, Dutch, and British got into the game,
label: Paragraph

text: so they too ultimately focused on exploiting
label: Paragraph

text: the plantation economies. At first the British,
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch, and French developed footholds in
label: Paragraph

text: the New England area, far from Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: territories, and competed mostly for fur trade
label: Paragraph

text: with the indigenous people. But as these
label: Paragraph

text: footholds evolved into full-fledged colonies,
label: Paragraph

text: they gained economic strength with the
label: Paragraph

text: establishment of tobacco plantations, most of
label: Paragraph

text: them British, in Virginia and territories farther
label: Paragraph

text: south.
label: Paragraph

text: Before colonial plantations, in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: sugar was a highly luxurious commodity
label: Paragraph

text: accessible only to the upper classes, coffee
label: Paragraph

text: was an exotic Arabic drink, and cocoa was
label: Paragraph

text: mostly unknown. The plantations enabled
label: Paragraph

text: sugar to be sold on the streets. Together with
label: Paragraph

text: coffee, cocoa, and tobacco, this chartered
label: Paragraph

text: an urban addictive culture that is still with
label: Paragraph

text: us. The plantations powered mercantile
label: Paragraph

text: capitalism, the core of which was the large-
label: Paragraph

text: scale, cheap production of a single crop
label: Paragraph

text: destined for mass consumption. Racial
label: Paragraph

text: slavery was its by-product.
label: Paragraph

text: The plantations were massive, as land was
label: Paragraph

text: essentially “free.” Large tracts of land under
label: Paragraph

text: single control meant that large amounts of
label: Paragraph

text: cash crops could be produced efficiently.
label: Paragraph

text: The principal problem was the availability
label: Paragraph

text: and supply of labor. At first European settlers
label: Paragraph

text: worked the land themselves, encouraging
label: Paragraph

text: locals to migrate. But this quickly became a
label: Paragraph

text: poor economic proposition, although there
label: Paragraph

text: was a massive migration of Irish populations
label: Paragraph

text: (forced frorn Ireland by the policies of
label: Paragraph

text: James II} to the Caribbean and Virginia. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1619 the Dutch brought slaves from Africa to
label: Paragraph

text: North America to work on the plantations. The
label: Paragraph

text: native American populations had already been
label: Paragraph

text: decimated, and native slaves often escaped,
label: Paragraph

text: disappearing back to their tribes. But African
label: Paragraph

text: slaves, in a completely foreign land with
label: Paragraph

text: no hope of ever making it back to their
label: Title

text: homelands, were both more reliable and more
label: Paragraph

text: easily obtained, with a steady stream of ships
label: Paragraph

text: bringing new slaves to American shores. This
label: Paragraph

text: is what led to the African slave “solution.”
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Initially, policies of the Spanish crown
label: Paragraph

text: identified the locals as heathens and sought
label: Paragraph

text: to destroy or convert them. By this system
label: Paragraph

text: conversion was a process of acceptance;
label: Paragraph

text: however exploitative it was, it provided
label: Paragraph

text: potential paths to freedom. When the first
label: Paragraph

text: Africans were brought to the Caribbean in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1520s, they too were given the option
label: Paragraph

text: of conversion. Racial slavery—the idea
label: Paragraph

text: that African labor could be owned, and
label: Paragraph

text: that children of African women inherited
label: Paragraph

text: the slave identity of their mother and were
label: Paragraph

text: slaves regardless of their father—was only
label: Paragraph

text: developed as an institution on the British
label: Paragraph

text: tobacco plantations of Virginia around
label: Title

text: landmark court cases in the middle of the
label: Paragraph

text: 16th century. After that, the African slave
label: Paragraph

text: trade increased significantly.
label: Paragraph

text: Slavery had existed across Eurasia and
label: Paragraph

text: Africa since the beginning of history. The
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian pharaohs, the Greeks, Romans,
label: Title

text: Phoenicians, Persians, Seljuks, Indians, and
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese all practiced slavery in various forms,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly as it concerned subjugated and
label: Paragraph

text: conquered peoples. In Africa, too, slavery
label: Paragraph

text: preexisted colonial trade. But the new
label: Paragraph

text: colonial model, dependent on cheap labor,
label: Paragraph

text: magnified it to such a degree that the history
label: Paragraph

text: of Europe, Africa, and the Americas was
label: Paragraph

text: irrevocably altered. It is estimated that more
label: Paragraph

text: than 20 million people, and possibly as many
label: Paragraph

text: as 40 million, were forcibly removed from
label: Paragraph

text: Africa; all the colonizing powers participated.
label: Paragraph

text: The legacy of the plantation system
label: Title

text: was unambiguously negative and had
label: Paragraph

text: consequences that are still playing out today.
label: Paragraph

text: In Mexico, even by 1910, 70 percent of
label: Paragraph

text: all arable land was held by just 1 percent
label: Paragraph

text: of the population, and similar situations
label: Paragraph

text: existed in South American countries. Almost
label: Paragraph

text: every country or region that was colonized
label: Title

text: by the plantation system had to struggle
label: Paragraph

text: later to create secular, scientific, and
label: Paragraph

text: cultural institutions on par with those of the
label: Paragraph

text: Europeans.
label: Paragraph

text: While critics of the slave trade could be
label: Paragraph

text: found everywhere—particularly in England—.
label: Paragraph

text: from its earliest days, all European powers
label: Paragraph

text: exploited the plantation and its system of
label: Paragraph

text: slave labor. The situation in New England
label: Title

text: was arguably somewhat better: There
label: Paragraph

text: were no large chiefdoms, as there were in
label: Paragraph

text: Louisiana and Georgia, to stand up to the
label: Paragraph

text: invaders, and this allowed settlers to nourish
label: Paragraph

text: the illusion that they were occupying virgin
label: Paragraph

text: territory. In addition, the influx of Europeans
label: Paragraph

text: was extraordinarily diverse. By 1700, from
label: Paragraph

text: Maine to Virginia, villages and towns had
label: Paragraph

text: a mixture of Dutch and English Puritans,
label: Paragraph

text: French Calvinists, Catholics, Swedes,
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish Jews, and English Anglicans. By
label: Paragraph

text: the early 1700s, a traveler would have found
label: Paragraph

text: courthouses, schools, churches, roads, and
label: Paragraph

text: two universities—Harvard, founded in 1636,
label: Paragraph

text: and Yale, founded in 1701. Although New
label: Paragraph

text: England ships participated and profited
label: Title

text: extensively in the slave trade, slave ownership
label: Paragraph

text: itself was relatively unusual. This New
label: Paragraph

text: England exceptionalism in colonial America
label: Title

text: set the stage for conflict with the southern
label: Paragraph

text: British settlements.
label: Paragraph

text: While the colonial project in the Americas
label: Title

text: quickly became a settler project, in most
label: Paragraph

text: of the rest of the world the Europeans were
label: Paragraph

text: primarily interested in setting up trading
label: Paragraph

text: outposts. The Portuguese expanded from
label: Paragraph

text: their ports along the Amazon coast by quickly
label: Paragraph

text: establishing ports on the coasts of India,
label: Paragraph

text: China, and points between in Southeast Asia.
label: Paragraph

text: The English, French, and Dutch followed
label: Paragraph

text: the Portuguese lead, developing competing
label: Paragraph

text: ports on the Bay of Bengal coast of India, in
label: Paragraph

text: southern China, and at intervals along the
label: Paragraph

text: route through the Straits of Malacca. The
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch focused their interests in Indonesia,
label: Paragraph

text: and the English exploited their superior naval
label: Paragraph

text: navigation skills to claim the territories of
label: Paragraph

text: Australia and New Zealand, although it was
label: Paragraph

text: the Dutch who first discovered them.
label: Paragraph

text: Outside of Australia and America, European
label: Paragraph

text: colonial enterprise at this time focused on
label: Paragraph

text: trade with local powers. Colonial forts, with
label: Paragraph

text: their backs to their hinterlands—where
label: Paragraph

text: they depended on treaties for their safety—
label: Paragraph

text: faced their guns toward the sea to ward off
label: Paragraph

text: attacks from competing European ships.
label: Paragraph

text: Old European rivalries and alliances were
label: Paragraph

text: replayed on these distant shores, and it
label: Paragraph

text: was not unusual for European war treaties
label: Paragraph

text: to dictate the loss or gain of distant colonial
label: Paragraph

text: forts. The Asian powers, particularly the
label: Paragraph

text: Mughals in India and the Ming and Qing
label: Title

text: dynasties in China, quietly tolerated and
label: Paragraph

text: profited from these coastal activities, as long
label: Paragraph

text: as the Europeans stayed within the terms of
label: Paragraph

text: their treaties. It was the old Eurasian world as
label: Paragraph

text: usual, but now along ocean-faring seaways.
label: Paragraph

text: Ultimately, this seemingly small change would
label: Paragraph

text: tilt the balance decisively in favor of the
label: Paragraph

text: European colonists.
label: Paragraph

text: The largely Arabic and Islamic countries
label: Title

text: of West and Central Asia were of limited
label: Paragraph

text: interest to the colonial powers. The Ottoman
label: Paragraph

text: Empire was seen primarily as a convenient
label: Paragraph

text: ulwark against czarist Russia. Persia was of
label: Paragraph

text: even less consequence to the Europeans and
label: Paragraph

text: slowly shrank under Russian pressure. The
label: Paragraph

text: area did not receive any strong interest from
label: Paragraph

text: Europeans until the discovery of oil in the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century.

text: 15.2 Hacienda Tabi, Mexico
label: Caption

text: It is no accident that just as the colonial
label: Paragraph

text: project was unfolding and flooding Europe
label: Paragraph

text: with great wealth, the 18th century saw
label: Paragraph

text: a philosophical movement emerge that
label: Paragraph

text: challenged the arbitrariness of power and
label: Paragraph

text: attitudes toward “primitive cultures.” Known
label: Paragraph

text: as the Enlightenment, it tried to imagine
label: Paragraph

text: alternative civil and institutional models in
label: Title

text: tune with new thinking about the rule of law,
label: Paragraph

text: even though it did not reject colonialism
label: Paragraph

text: as such. Its successes and failures in
label: Paragraph

text: that respect are still being debated. The
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment ideals were widely discussed
label: Paragraph

text: in the cities of France, England, an
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, though they were also tested,
label: Paragraph

text: contested, and remade in the colonies.
label: Paragraph

text: Though usually described as “European,” the
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment can in fact be considered a
label: Paragraph

text: global colonial construct.

text: Haciendas
label: Title

text: The hacienda system is thought to date to
label: Paragraph

text: 1529, when the Spanish crown granted
label: Paragraph

text: Hernan Cortés the title of Marquis of the
label: Paragraph

text: Valley of Oaxaca, in the present-day state
label: Paragraph

text: of Morelos, Mexico. The grant included all
label: Paragraph

text: the Native Americans then living on the
label: Paragraph

text: land and the power of life and death over
label: Title

text: them. The Native Americans, like the slaves
label: Paragraph

text: who soon arrived from Africa, were bound
label: Paragraph

text: to a particular hacienda for life, as were
label: Paragraph

text: their descendants. By the 18th century, the
label: Paragraph

text: system, stretching from Mexico to Argentina,
label: Paragraph

text: was the primary means of export production
label: Paragraph

text: and in some cases the core of urban
label: Paragraph

text: developments. The hacienda was developed
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the Americas, and later other
label: Paragraph

text: parts of the colonial world developed the
label: Paragraph

text: plantation system.
label: Paragraph

text: Haciendas came in various sizes, and
label: Paragraph

text: some were gigantic. Peotillos, 55 kilometers
label: Paragraph

text: from San Luis Potosi in Mexico, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: controlled an area of 193,000 hectares. The
label: Paragraph

text: word hacienda comes from an Old Spanish
label: Paragraph

text: term (facienda) derived from the Latin focere,
label: Paragraph

text: which means “to make something,” and most
label: Paragraph

text: haciendas specialized in one or two products,
label: Paragraph

text: always an export-based cash crop. In areas
label: Paragraph

text: where water was abundant, sugarcane was
label: Paragraph

text: grown, which gave rise to rum and liquor
label: Paragraph

text: production. Other haciendas focused on
label: Paragraph

text: livestock, cacao, coffee, tobacco, cotton,
label: Paragraph

text: rubber, and a variety of woods. Since the
label: Paragraph

text: hacienda was often remote from metropolitan
label: Paragraph

text: centers, it had to accommodate a wide range
label: Paragraph

text: of functions. It had its own marketplace,
label: Paragraph

text: cemetery, and jail. Layout followed a common
label: Paragraph

text: scheme involving courtyards for different
label: Paragraph

text: purposes: for the workers and their families,
label: Paragraph

text: for workshops, and for warehouses. The
label: Paragraph

text: main residential building fronted onto a
label: Paragraph

text: plaza, known as a patio de campo. The link
label: Paragraph

text: between the patio de campo and the more
label: Paragraph

text: restricted private areas of the master was
label: Paragraph

text: through a corridor known as a zaguan.
label: Paragraph

text: New European Colonial Urban Culture
label: Title

text: The expanding middle class, with its
label: Paragraph

text: ravenous taste for novelty food items and
label: Paragraph

text: luxuries supplied by the colonies, rapidly
label: Paragraph

text: reshaped European culture. The diet
label: Paragraph

text: changed considerably, with tomatoes,
label: Paragraph

text: potatoes, and corn becoming the new
label: Paragraph

text: staples; chocolate, imported from the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish Americas, became a luxury item;
label: Paragraph

text: and sugar from the Caribbean became an
label: Paragraph

text: indispensable consumer good in a very
label: Paragraph

text: short time. Coffee, however, came to Europe
label: Paragraph

text: first from Africa by way of Arab traders. It
label: Paragraph

text: is thought to have been first produced in
label: Paragraph

text: Ethiopia and Yemen. The drink caused a
label: Paragraph

text: great deal of controversy in the Islamic world,
label: Paragraph

text: because some authorities thought coffee
label: Paragraph

text: was intoxicating and therefore should be
label: Paragraph

text: forbidden. As a result, its consumption was
label: Paragraph

text: initially associated with subversive political
label: Paragraph

text: activity, perhaps because it was drunk in the
label: Paragraph

text: new all-male coffeehouses, where intrigue
label: Paragraph

text: might be brewed along with the beverage.
label: Paragraph

text: From the beginning, then, the social
label: Paragraph

text: significance of drinking coffee derived from
label: Paragraph

text: the fact that it was consumed in public by
label: Paragraph

text: an exclusively male clientele in this new kind
label: Paragraph

text: of establishment, the coffeehouse, usually
label: Paragraph

text: located on major commercial arteries. The
label: Paragraph

text: coffeehouse of Ipshir Pasha in Aleppo (1653)
label: Caption

text: is a rare early coffeehouse to have survived to
label: Paragraph

text: present times. It consists of a courtyard and
label: Paragraph

text: a covered hall, with windows overlooking the
label: Paragraph

text: street to the south. Domes of varying shapes
label: Caption

text: cover the hall.

label: Title

text: stems from this era, when mass-produced
label: Paragraph

text: colonial products transformed European
label: Title

text: culture. Sugar in particular starred in the
label: Paragraph

text: newly emerging rituals of consumption. It was
label: Paragraph

text: put into tea and coffee (first in France, so it

text: ST. PETERSBURG
label: Title

text: Of the many Baroque projects of the period,
label: Paragraph

text: none rivaled that of St. Petersburg in scale
label: Paragraph

text: and complexity. At the start of the 17th
label: Paragraph

text: century, Russia was a backward country,
label: Paragraph

text: at the mercy of conflicting forces. There
label: Paragraph

text: were urban riots in 1648, a revolt in 1662,
label: Paragraph

text: a rebellion in 1669, and an uprising in
label: Paragraph

text: 1668. Czar Peter Alexeyevich Romanov |
label: Caption

text: (1672-1725), known as Peter the Great,
label: Paragraph

text: reestablished order, modernized Russia,
label: Paragraph

text: and pulled the country out of its isolation.
label: Paragraph

text: Singlehandedly, he turned the Orthodox
label: Paragraph

text: Muscovite state into a secular, Westernized
label: Paragraph

text: empire—against considerable opposition
label: Title

text: from many levels of society. This was realized
label: Paragraph

text: through massive forced-labor enterprises
label: Title

text: as well as a series of wars that consumed
label: Paragraph

text: as much as 90 percent of the state budget.
label: Paragraph

text: The result, however, was an empire that
label: Paragraph

text: stretched from the Baltic to the Caspian
label: Paragraph

text: Sea. After his victory over Sweden in a war
label: Paragraph

text: that lasted twenty-one years, Russia could
label: Paragraph

text: again sail down the Neva River to the Gulf
label: Title

text: of Finland. To safeguard his access to the
label: Paragraph

text: Baltic Sea, Russia built the Peter and Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Fortress, the cornerstone of which was laid
label: Paragraph

text: in 1703. The project eventually grew into one
label: Paragraph

text: of the biggest building sites in Europe. Forty
label: Paragraph

text: thousand peasants were conscripted, along
label: Paragraph

text: with Swedish prisoners of war.
label: Paragraph

text: Work had progressed far enough by 1712
label: Paragraph

text: for relics from the Vladimir-Suzdal Monastery
label: Caption

text: to be sent to the St. Alexander Nevsky
label: Paragraph

text: Monastery, named after the 13th-century
label: Paragraph

text: national hero St. Alexander Nevsky who
label: Paragraph

text: received his name after beating the Swedes
label: Paragraph

text: on the Neva River. St. Petersburg now had its
label: Paragraph

text: founding myth and was an instant religious
label: Paragraph

text: as well as secular center. To speed things
label: Paragraph

text: along, Peter, in 1714, even forbade masonry
label: Paragraph

text: construction throughout the rest of Russia
label: Title

text: to ensure a supply of qualified workers and
label: Paragraph

text: materials for St. Petersburg.
