label: Title

text: REASON
label: Title

text: While the Spanish thought that stockpiling
label: Paragraph

text: gold and silver was the way to build wealth,
label: Paragraph

text: the French, Dutch, and English, focused
label: Paragraph

text: on economic efficiency as a means of
label: Title

text: wealth generation. Their success lay in
label: Paragraph

text: combining absolutism with highly rationalized
label: Paragraph

text: governmental processes and investment in a
label: Title

text: national knowledge base. The rationalization
label: Title

text: of the national economy was the undertaking
label: Paragraph

text: of Jean-Baptiste Colbert (1619-83), one of
label: Paragraph

text: Louis XIV’s chief advisors. He was responsible
label: Paragraph

text: for many of the bureaucratic innovations
label: Paragraph

text: that, though cumbersome, created the
label: Paragraph

text: base for France’s economic prosperity and
label: Paragraph

text: particularly its ordering of colonial territories
label: Paragraph

text: and extraction processes. Thanks to Colbert,
label: Paragraph

text: there was a new understanding that there
label: Paragraph

text: was a nexus between global trade and the
label: Paragraph

text: national economy. Colbert also appreciated
label: Paragraph

text: that economic power was dependent on
label: Paragraph

text: knowledge. He therefore commissioned
label: Paragraph

text: extensive studies of, for exarnple,
label: Paragraph

text: shipbuilding, navigation, and armaments to
label: Title

text: ensure that the French fleet remained the
label: Paragraph

text: strongest in the world. He also founded the
label: Paragraph

text: Royal Academy of Science (1666) and the
label: Paragraph

text: Academy of Architecture (1671), among
label: Paragraph

text: other institutions, to serve and advise
label: Paragraph

text: government administrators and ministers.
label: Paragraph

text: In economics, rationalization is defined
label: Paragraph

text: as the act of bringing order to ad hoc
label: Paragraph

text: workflows by defining appropriate rules
label: Paragraph

text: or processes. It is thus not surprising that
label: Paragraph

text: Netherlands

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: of Reason, for the scientific work of early
label: Paragraph

text: scientists and philosophers of this age was
label: Paragraph

text: also the search for the underlying processes
label: Paragraph

text: and rules that defined the apparent ad hoc

text: phenomenon of the world. Galileo and Tycho
label: Caption

text: Brache were both looking for mathematical

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: half of the 17th century. Generally speaking,

label: Paragraph

text: detail that was to become an essential aspect

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: antiquity, resisting the temptation, prevalent
label: Paragraph

text: at his time, to dwell on ornamentation and
label: Paragraph

text: decoration. A particularly heated debate
label: Paragraph

text: revolved around the question of whether
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: argued that beauty was not a fixed property

label: Paragraph

text: The Observatoire was quite austere by
label: Paragraph

text: the standards of the day. There were no
label: Paragraph

text: orders, no columns, and no pilasters. Simple
label: Paragraph

text: string courses demarcating the stories and
label: Paragraph

text: openings are either slightly recessed from
label: Paragraph

text: the smooth wall surface or surrounded by
label: Paragraph

text: barely projecting moldings. Each side of
label: Paragraph

text: the octagonal corner towers was aligned
label: Paragraph

text: with the sun's position at solstices and
label: Paragraph

text: equinoxes, and the eastern one was unroofed
label: Paragraph

text: for the use of a telescope within. The
label: Paragraph

text: building was put together with the greatest
label: Paragraph

text: skill, and the staircase, with its complex
label: Paragraph

text: three-dimensional curving surfaces—all in
label: Paragraph

text: stone—still astonishes today. The roof was
label: Paragraph

text: used as a platform from which astronomical
label: Paragraph

text: measurements could be made. A hole in the
label: Paragraph

text: center of the floors of the main chambers
label: Caption

text: Hétel des Invalides
label: Title

text: Hospitals had first appeared in Europe
label: Paragraph

text: as a by-product of pilgrimages and of the
label: Paragraph

text: Crusades. There were several important
label: Paragraph

text: hospitals in Italy. The Knights of St. John
label: Caption

text: were well known for their hospitals on
label: Paragraph

text: Rhodes and elsewhere. By the 18th century,
label: Paragraph

text: however, hospitals were flooded not only
label: Paragraph

text: with the thousands of soldiers who fought in
label: Paragraph

text: the alrnost endless cycle of battles, but also
label: Paragraph

text: by the poor and the indigent, who formed
label: Paragraph

text: an increasingly large lower class. Plagues
label: Paragraph

text: and epidemics added to the problem. In
label: Paragraph

text: Paris, a cholera epidemic in 1519 and the
label: Paragraph

text: struck down thousands. But because
label: Paragraph

text: hospitals remained associated with religious
label: Paragraph

text: orders and charitable institutions, there
label: Paragraph

text: was practically no distinction between a
label: Paragraph

text: hospital, a pesthouse, and a poorhouse.
label: Paragraph

text: Conditions were so terrible that the sick were
label: Paragraph

text: often unwilling to leave their houses for a
label: Paragraph

text: hospital, concerned that while they were
label: Paragraph

text: sequestered, their property would be pillaged
label: Paragraph

text: or their income threatened. To combat these
label: Paragraph

text: conditions, Henry IV decreed the construction
label: Paragraph

text: of the Hépital St.-Louis (begun 1607). It was
label: Paragraph

text: outside the city walls and easily accessible
label: Paragraph

text: from major roads. The wards consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: wide, open corridors with patients’ beds
label: Paragraph

text: placed against the walls. Four of these
label: Paragraph

text: corridor buildings were linked to form a large
label: Paragraph

text: courtyard.
label: Paragraph

text: At the end of the Thirty Years’ War in
label: Paragraph

text: 1648, much of Europe was flooded with
label: Paragraph

text: former soldiers, many of whom had lived
label: Paragraph

text: their entire adult lives in the military and
label: Paragraph

text: had difficulty adjusting to civilian life,
label: Paragraph

text: suffering from a form of PTSD. The Hotel
label: Paragraph

text: des Invalides (1671-76) aimed to address
label: Paragraph

text: this problem in that it served as a military
label: Paragraph

text: retirement dormitory. Behind its moat and
label: Paragraph

text: expansive entrance lies a large court, while
label: Paragraph

text: ranges of buildings to the right and left are
label: Paragraph

text: grouped around smaller courts. The north
label: Paragraph

text: 15.27 Plan: Hotel des Invalides
label: Caption

text: facade is articulated in typical French fashion
label: Paragraph

text: by central and end pavilions that project
label: Paragraph

text: forward. Apart from the entrance porches,
label: Paragraph

text: there are no columns or pilasters on the main
label: Caption

text: facade. The court has two stories of arches
label: Paragraph

text: on piers relieved only by the pedimented
label: Caption

text: pavilions at the center along the axis. There
label: Paragraph

text: were special areas for sick and wounded
label: Paragraph

text: soldiers, for pauper soldiers, and a barracks
label: Paragraph

text: for older veterans. There were surgery areas
label: Paragraph

text: and large mess halls where soldiers ate, with
label: Paragraph

text: their officers at the head table.
label: Paragraph

text: Hospitals in England, built from public
label: Paragraph

text: funds, tended to be simpler and less
label: Paragraph

text: generous by comparison. There was
label: Paragraph

text: considerable ambivalence among the English
label: Paragraph

text: upper classes and Tories about spending
label: Title

text: money in a way that many thought would
label: Paragraph

text: seem to reward poverty. Chelsea Hospital
label: Caption

text: (begun 1682) shows, however, the first
label: Paragraph

text: awareness of French innovation regarding
label: Title

text: the problems of former soldiers. Designed
label: Paragraph

text: yy Sir Christopher Wren, the cells were
label: Paragraph

text: placed in ranges, back to back. At the end
label: Paragraph

text: of the range, a larger room was set out
label: Paragraph

text: for the sergeants. Instead of an enclosed
label: Paragraph

text: quadrangle, the wards faced each other
label: Paragraph

text: across a courtyard open to the Thames
label: Caption

text: River, with a great hall and chapel linking the
label: Paragraph

text: wards at the far end. The hospital's governor
label: Paragraph

text: and lieutenant governor lived in detached
label: Paragraph

text: pavilions at the corners. The differences
label: Paragraph

text: tween the two hospitals speaks volurnes
label: Title

text: about the English and French attitudes about
label: Title

text: society and hierarchy at the time.

text: Neresheim
label: Title

text: Largely rural and possessing only three towns
label: Paragraph

text: with a population over 100,000, Catholic
label: Paragraph

text: Bavaria in southern Germany had not only
label: Paragraph

text: withstood the Reformation but was also
label: Paragraph

text: resistant to the aristocratic urban Catholicism
label: Title

text: of nearby Austria. Here a few architects
label: Paragraph

text: assisted by painters, stucco workers, and
label: Paragraph

text: sculptors created a unique style of church
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, without a dome. Johann
label: Caption

text: Michael Fischer (1692-1766) and Johann
label: Title

text: Balthasar Neumann (1687-1753) were the
label: Paragraph

text: most prolific architects. Neumann's most
label: Paragraph

text: extraordinary work is perhaps the Church of
label: Paragraph

text: Vierzehnheiligen (1743-72) at a Franciscan
label: Paragraph

text: monastery near the town of Bamberg,
label: Paragraph

text: Germany. It had become a pilgrimage church
label: Paragraph

text: in the mid-15th century, following what was
label: Paragraph

text: said to be a miraculous apparition.
label: Paragraph

text: Neumann's last and most
label: Title

text: comprehensively conceived major project
label: Title

text: was the church of Neresheim (1747-92).
label: Paragraph

text: It was integrated into the fabric of a
label: Paragraph

text: Benedictine monastery and includes at
label: Title

text: its choir end an old tower from an earlier
label: Caption

text: Romanesque church. Oval and circular vaults
label: Caption

text: are supported on an undulating frame of
label: Paragraph

text: columns, pilasters, arches, and piers. Though
label: Paragraph

text: the space may read as decorative and plastic,
label: Paragraph

text: Neumann was an officer in the engineering
label: Paragraph

text: corps, and his buildings were just as much a
label: Paragraph

text: testament to his engineering as to his design
label: Paragraph

text: skills. He used wall piers or short sections
label: Paragraph

text: of wall turned at right angles to the nave as
label: Paragraph

text: primary load-bearing elernents, eliminating
label: Paragraph

text: the necessity for a solid continuous outer
label: Title

text: surface. Notwithstanding the cheerful
label: Paragraph

text: interior, the exterior shell of the church was
label: Paragraph

text: relatively plain. The oval at the crossing is
label: Paragraph

text: placed lengthwise to the longitudinal interior,
label: Paragraph

text: stretching between the part of the church
label: Paragraph

text: that was used by the community and the
label: Paragraph

text: choir at the rear reserved for the monks. The
label: Caption

text: oval is counterbalanced by smaller ovals that
label: Paragraph

text: evoke the tradition of the transept without
label: Paragraph

text: interfering in the spatial liturgical rituals,
label: Paragraph

text: which did not require such spaces. The ovals
label: Paragraph

text: are connected by curving vaults that leave
label: Paragraph

text: one in doubt as to how they work structurally,
label: Paragraph

text: with light from the large windows visually
label: Paragraph

text: dissolving the borders of the different spatial
label: Paragraph

text: elements.

text: CHINA AND THE EUROPEAN
label: Title

text: ENLIGHTENMENT
label: Title

text: The Jesuits, with their emphasis on
label: Paragraph

text: education, were at the forefront of bridging
label: Paragraph

text: the Chinese and European worlds. In 1601,
label: Paragraph

text: the Italian Jesuit Matteo Ricci (1552-1610)
label: Title

text: arrived in Beijing and established a Catholic
label: Paragraph

text: mission. For the next two centuries the
label: Paragraph

text: Jesuits, as well as members of other Catholic
label: Paragraph

text: orders, built close links to the Qing court
label: Paragraph

text: while converting approximately 250,000
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese to Christianity. Because of their
label: Paragraph

text: strong interest in education and their own
label: Paragraph

text: high levels of education, many Jesuits
label: Paragraph

text: became trusted members of the Qing court
label: Paragraph

text: and were given important positions, such as
label: Paragraph

text: control of the Board of Astronomy.
label: Paragraph

text: These Europeans wrote home detailed
label: Paragraph

text: accounts of what they saw, which were
label: Paragraph

text: published as books, usually in French or
label: Paragraph

text: Latin, in Paris, the European center of
label: Paragraph

text: Jesuit activities. These included Confucius,
label: Paragraph

text: the Philosopher of the Chinese (1687);
label: Paragraph

text: Description of China (1735), in 4 volumes;
label: Caption

text: the long series Fdifying and Curious Letters,
label: Paragraph

text: in 34 volumes (1702-76); General History
label: Paragraph

text: of China, in 13 volumes (1777-85); and
label: Paragraph

text: Memoirs on the History, Sciences, Arts, etc.,
label: Paragraph

text: of the Chinese, in 16 volumes (1776-1814).
label: Paragraph

text: The Chinese political system was studied
label: Paragraph

text: and cited by many European thinkers,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Voltaire (1694-1778), Francis
label: Paragraph

text: Quesnay (1694-1774), and Gottfried Leibniz
label: Paragraph

text: (1646-1716), at a time when Europeans
label: Paragraph

text: were beginning to develop alternatives
label: Paragraph

text: to monarchic and church procedures in
label: Paragraph

text: their own political systerns. The German
label: Paragraph

text: philosopher Leibniz, who was considered
label: Paragraph

text: an “expert” on things Chinese, argued that
label: Paragraph

text: a truly universal new civilization could be
label: Paragraph

text: achieved by merging the best elements
label: Paragraph

text: in Chinese and Western culture. He
label: Paragraph

text: published this argument in a little book of
label: Paragraph

text: 1697, Novissima Sinica (Latest News from
label: Caption

text: China). Of particular interest to European
label: Paragraph

text: philosophers was the concept of the
label: Paragraph

text: mandate—the idea that the emperor ruled
label: Title

text: only by divine mandate, and that when things
label: Paragraph

text: went wrong, it was a signal that the mandate
label: Paragraph

text: had been revoked. As Derk Bodde has
label: Paragraph

text: argued, the European Enlightenment thinkers
label: Paragraph

text: particularly admired China as a land where
label: Paragraph

text: governmental power was negotiated not
label: Paragraph

text: through the traditions of a feudal aristocracy,
label: Paragraph

text: as in Europe, but by the mandarins, a group
label: Paragraph

text: of highly educated scholars, who gained their
label: Paragraph

text: official positions only after proving their worth
label: Paragraph

text: by passing a series of state-administered
label: Paragraph

text: examinations. It became their aim to create
label: Paragraph

text: an “enlightened despotism” that would rule
label: Paragraph

text: for the benefit of the people as a whole,
label: Paragraph

text: rather than merely for a small, privileged
label: Paragraph

text: group. They argued this concept, particularly
label: Paragraph

text: in the work of the economists known as the
label: Paragraph

text: Physiocrats, whose leader, Francis Quesnay,
label: Paragraph

text: wrote The Despotism of China (1767) as an
label: Paragraph

text: example of a truly enlightened despotism.
label: Paragraph

text: Quesnay influenced the ideas of Adarn Smith
label: Paragraph

text: (1723-90), the seminal thinker of modern
label: Paragraph

text: economics.
label: Paragraph

text: The most famous of the Enlightenment
label: Title

text: thinkers to learn from Qing China was
label: Title

text: Voltaire, for whom China was the one country
label: Paragraph

text: where the ruler was also a philosopher
label: Paragraph

text: (Plato’s “philosopher-king”). He was
label: Paragraph

text: impressed by the idea that the Chinese were
label: Paragraph

text: not forcing their own religious ideas upon
label: Paragraph

text: other people. “One need not be obsessed
label: Paragraph

text: with the merits of the Chinese,” he wrote in
label: Paragraph

text: 1764, “to recognize ... that their empire is in
label: Paragraph

text: truth the best that the world has ever seen.”
label: Paragraph

text: In 1755, Voltaire wrote the play The Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: Orphan, adapted from an old Chinese play,
label: Paragraph

text: as a rebuttal to Rousseau's (1712-78) “back-
label: Paragraph

text: to-nature” theories that decried history, the
label: Paragraph

text: arts, and other cultural constructs on the
label: Paragraph

text: grounds that they corrupted the natural
label: Paragraph

text: goodness of human nature. By contrast,
label: Paragraph

text: Voltaire argued that superior civilizations can
label: Paragraph

text: overcome barbarism, citing the example of
label: Paragraph

text: the Chinese civilization's triumph over the
label: Title

text: invading Mongols.
label: Paragraph

text: The Gongyuan and the Jinshi
label: Title

text: Of particular importance amongst the
label: Paragraph

text: administrative buildings distributed around
label: Title

text: the Forbidden City was the Gongyuan, or the
label: Paragraph

text: Examination Yard, where the highest exams
label: Paragraph

text: for entering the imperial bureaucracy were
label: Paragraph

text: held. Admittance to the Mandarin cadres
label: Paragraph

text: required three levels of examinations: first
label: Paragraph

text: in local counties, second in the provincial
label: Paragraph

text: capitals, and the final in the national capital,
label: Paragraph

text: held only once every three years. Those who
label: Paragraph

text: passed this final weeklong exam earned the
label: Paragraph

text: title jinshi (known in English as Mandarin).
label: Paragraph

text: The Gongyuan was a huge walled enclosure,
label: Paragraph

text: inside of which were thousands of small brick
label: Paragraph

text: cells laid out in straight rows. This eliminated
label: Paragraph

text: cheating. Still, candidates were searched,
label: Paragraph

text: carefully supervised, and not permitted to
label: Paragraph

text: leave until the exam ended. The exams
label: Paragraph

text: demanded high standards of literary style and
label: Paragraph

text: calligraphy, as well as detailed knowledge of
label: Paragraph

text: the Chinese classics.
label: Paragraph

text: From the Gongyuan, the lucky few who
label: Paragraph

text: passed were allowed into the Forbidden
label: Paragraph

text: City, where they participated in a daylong
label: Paragraph

text: exam in the first of the great halls, which
label: Paragraph

text: was attended by a large assembly of civil
label: Paragraph

text: and military officials in full regalia. Of these
label: Paragraph

text: examinees, the top three finalists were
label: Paragraph

text: presented directly to the emperor and allowed
label: Paragraph

text: to exit from the central gate first, followed
label: Paragraph

text: by all the others who had passed the tests.
label: Paragraph

text: The jinshi, who might have started out as a
label: Paragraph

text: peasant's son, was quickly were incorporated
label: Paragraph

text: into the imperial administration.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 18th century, as the European
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment thinkers were looking for more
label: Paragraph

text: egalitarian, merit-based models to replace
label: Paragraph

text: the orders of the Church and the court, they
label: Paragraph

text: turned to the Chinese jinshi system. The idea
label: Paragraph

text: of a civil service that would be selected via
label: Paragraph

text: competitive exams open to anyone derived
label: Title

text: from studies of this Chinese bureaucracy.
label: Paragraph

text: The first written civil service exams were
label: Paragraph

text: held in European universities in 1702. The
label: Paragraph

text: French established their civil service in 1791,
label: Paragraph

text: after the French Revolution. The British
label: Paragraph

text: established their civil service exams in 1806,
label: Paragraph

text: initially only for recruitment to the British East
label: Paragraph

text: India Company. The United States began
label: Paragraph

text: to require exams for some administrative
label: Paragraph

text: positions after 1885. Contemporary licensing
label: Paragraph

text: exams, such as those required to be
label: Paragraph

text: registered as an architect, structural engineer,
label: Paragraph

text: lawyer, or chartered accountant are also a
label: Paragraph

text: legacy of the original Chinese system.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Stowe Gardens and the Temple of British
label: Title

text: Worthies
label: Title

text: Along with lacquered tables and teaware,
label: Paragraph

text: European merchant ships brought home
label: Title

text: folios and travel accounts of Chinese gardens.
label: Caption

text: Sir William Temple, an aristocratic British
label: Title

text: essayist writing on the gardens of Epicurus
label: Title

text: in 1685, extoled what he called the Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: concept of sharawadgi, or irregular landscape
label: Paragraph

text: scenery carefully arranged, in critique of
label: Paragraph

text: the axial symmetries and carefully pruned
label: Paragraph

text: formal orders that characterized European
label: Paragraph

text: gardens at that time. Temple is credited
label: Paragraph

text: with originating the concept of the British
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque stroll garden of the 18th century,
label: Paragraph

text: which, like the Chinese garden, relied on
label: Paragraph

text: irregular movement, artfully placed follies
label: Paragraph

text: and pavilions, borrowed scenery, and studied
label: Paragraph

text: asymmetry for effect.
label: Paragraph

text: William Kent’s “Elysian Field" of 1738
label: Caption

text: at Stowe House exemplifies this trend.
label: Paragraph

text: Elysium, a Homeric description of the garden
label: Caption

text: where worthy souls found eternal life, was
label: Paragraph

text: transformed into an instrument of nationalist
label: Paragraph

text: consciousness in the form of the stroll
label: Title

text: garden at Stowe. In combination with neo-
label: Caption

text: Palladian follies, and with the invention of the
label: Paragraph

text: ha-ha trench that enabled seamless visual
label: Paragraph

text: continuity between the designed garden and
label: Paragraph

text: its larger surrounding environment, Stowe
label: Paragraph

text: Gardens offered a new vision of nature and of
label: Paragraph

text: man’s place in it—an alternative to that of the
label: Paragraph

text: Bible, in which earth was naturally barbaric.
label: Paragraph

text: It also projected a vision of harmony between
label: Paragraph

text: nature and the “natural” proportions of the
label: Title

text: classical orders.
label: Paragraph

text: The English nationalist garden emerged
label: Title

text: with the early 18th-century rise of the
label: Paragraph

text: Whigs, trenchant critics of the Tories and
label: Paragraph

text: strong believers in constitutional monarchy.
label: Paragraph

text: No clergymen or saints were arnong those
label: Paragraph

text: chosen to be represented in the Temple of
label: Paragraph

text: British Worthies at Stowe. Rather, the Elysian
label: Paragraph

text: Field honored poets such as Shakespeare,
label: Paragraph

text: John Milton, and Alexander Pope; architects
label: Paragraph

text: such as Inigo Jones; and explorers such
label: Paragraph

text: as Thomas Cook, among others. Over the
label: Paragraph

text: next two centuries a large number of follies
label: Paragraph

text: were added and destroyed, including a Shell
label: Paragraph

text: Bridge, a Grotto, a Season's Fountain, a
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Friendship, a Chinese House, and
label: Title

text: others.

label: Caption

text: Key to the success of Stowe and gardens
label: Title

text: like it, such as that at Chiswick, was that
label: Paragraph

text: they could be experienced not only by their
label: Paragraph

text: owners and friends but also by a wide range
label: Paragraph

text: of personages drawn from the upper and
label: Paragraph

text: middle classes. At the time, garden tourism
label: Paragraph

text: was on the increase and already an important
label: Paragraph

text: part of upper-class social life.
label: Paragraph

text: Stowe conceptualized a new, secularist
label: Paragraph

text: vision of English nationalism. This idea of
label: Paragraph

text: a harmonic natural landscape, however
label: Paragraph

text: artificially contrived, designed around a
label: Paragraph

text: dignified, civilizational armature, arguably
label: Paragraph

text: also parallels the English colonial experience
label: Paragraph

text: in the Americas. The French initially
label: Paragraph

text: encountered strong resistance from the
label: Paragraph

text: Indians and never had enough colonists to
label: Paragraph

text: suppress them, so they began to study and
label: Paragraph

text: analyze their habits to gain their cooperation
label: Paragraph

text: in trade and then lead ther into conversion.
label: Paragraph

text: The British experience was different. Except
label: Paragraph

text: in the Carolinas, they faced little organized
label: Paragraph

text: resistance among the Indians, who were
label: Paragraph

text: less socially unified than those in the
label: Paragraph

text: French settlements in Canada and along the
label: Title

text: Mississippi River. Whereas contact with the
label: Paragraph

text: Indians led the French to study and question
label: Paragraph

text: the origins of civilization, the English, at least
label: Paragraph

text: those back home in their gardens, began to
label: Paragraph

text: muse on the mythological underpinnings of
label: Paragraph

text: European identity and its role in the larger
label: Title

text: global theater that was only just beginning
label: Title

text: to fit within a single frame. It may have
label: Paragraph

text: been in the English gardens, with their often
label: Paragraph

text: pedagogical and ideological emphasis, that
label: Paragraph

text: the first traces of what later was termed
label: Paragraph

text: Eurocentrism began to appear.

text: The Ming dynasty’s rule in China came

text: tender age of nine, proved to be disastrous,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and complex administrative machinery that
label: Paragraph

text: managed the empire. The consequence was
label: Paragraph

text: inevitable; power brokers and local lords
label: Title

text: used the opportunity to carve out competitive
label: Paragraph

text: mini-empires for themselves as the emperor
label: Paragraph

text: became increasingly reclusive. Lawlessness
label: Paragraph

text: increased, and Japanese and even Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: pirates frequently raided coastal towns. At
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: was arriving from the Americas by coastal
label: Paragraph

text: routes. Indeed, the Chinese demand for silver
label: Paragraph

text: was at the core of the growth of mining in
label: Paragraph

text: South America. Silver became the alternative
label: Paragraph

text: to Ming printed currency, which resulted in
label: Paragraph

text: drastic inflation. The price of grain rose, and
label: Paragraph

text: the poor went hungry and were unable to pay
label: Paragraph

text: taxes. Vigilante bandit groups began to roam
label: Paragraph

text: the countryside. Finally, a farnous bandit,
label: Paragraph

text: Li Zicheng, or the “dashing prince,” made
label: Paragraph

text: camp outside Beijing in 1644. In response,
label: Paragraph

text: the Ming army commander, who had been

label: Paragraph

text: the Manchu were assembling to attack,

label: Paragraph

text: The Manchu, who ruled under the title
label: Paragraph

text: of the Qing, were Jurchen descendants who
label: Paragraph

text: took on the Mongol title “khan.” Although
label: Paragraph

text: only a million strong in a kingdom of 250
label: Paragraph

text: million native Chinese, the Manchu proved
label: Paragraph

text: equal to the task of governance, and
label: Paragraph

text: quickly established stability. One of their
label: Paragraph

text: first acts was to establish a strong regulatory
label: Paragraph

text: framework for coastal trade. With that in
label: Paragraph

text: place, they moved to establish internal order.
label: Paragraph

text: The core of Manchu administrative policy
label: Title

text: was to simultaneously adopt established
label: Paragraph

text: Confucian and Ming courtly practices
label: Title

text: while accommodating regional differences.
label: Paragraph

text: They maintained a strong grip on central
label: Paragraph

text: administrative control, but like the Mongols
label: Paragraph

text: and the Yuan before them, they tolerated
label: Paragraph

text: multiple religious and cultural practices. They
label: Paragraph

text: settled into the Ming capitals, built similar
label: Paragraph

text: tombs, restored and expanded the palaces
label: Paragraph

text: and administrative wings, and, in Beijing,
label: Paragraph

text: undertook a reorganization of the inhabitants,
label: Paragraph

text: pushing the old Han Chinese to the south
label: Title

text: to make room for their own bannermen.
label: Paragraph

text: The Qing also built scores of new towns and
label: Paragraph

text: administrative centers around the Middle
label: Title

text: Kingdom, making sure to distribute their own
label: Paragraph

text: clansmen in these areas. The Dalai Lama was
label: Paragraph

text: invited back, and stupas were built to mark
label: Paragraph

text: his visit.
label: Paragraph

text: The Qing had a strong appetite for
label: Paragraph

text: silver, which they used to mint currency.
label: Paragraph

text: For geographical reasons, China was poor
label: Paragraph

text: in minerals. They had some gold, very little
label: Paragraph

text: silver, and some copper. And yet at the same
label: Paragraph

text: time they had a vibrant economy that was
label: Paragraph

text: very commercial in that it relied on active
label: Paragraph

text: exchange of goods. Centuries before anyone
label: Paragraph

text: else, during the Song period, the old Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: solution had been to print money. Printed
label: Paragraph

text: currency worked very well until the Yuan
label: Paragraph

text: and particularly the Ming did what many
label: Paragraph

text: governments in trouble do—they overprinted
label: Paragraph

text: their currency, which resulted in loss of
label: Paragraph

text: public confidence in the printed currency.
label: Paragraph

text: The Qing solution to this was to mint
label: Paragraph

text: currency in silver. After they exhausted the
label: Paragraph

text: silver supply in Japan, South America’s silver
label: Title

text: became the main source. It was transported
label: Paragraph

text: to China on European vessels. Between 1500
label: Paragraph

text: and 1800, South America produced about 85
label: Paragraph

text: percent of the world’s silver; about 40 percent
label: Paragraph

text: of it went straight to China.

text: The Qing also embarked on a remarkably
label: Paragraph

text: successful military campaign that resulted
label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: (1683), Inner and Outer Mongolia (1697),
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 80 percent were killed on orders by Qing
label: Paragraph

text: and Mongolian soldiers, and more by a
label: Paragraph

text: subsequent outbreak of smallpox.

text: To accommodate the vast diversity that
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the English after they became a major world
label: Paragraph

text: power. Confucians, Buddhists, Muslims, and
label: Paragraph

text: even Christian visitors were accepted and
label: Paragraph

text: accommodated, and at the same time kept
label: Paragraph

text: in check and abeyance. All decrees were
label: Paragraph

text: issued in multiple languages. Underlying
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Buddhist ideology, with its long history of
label: Paragraph

text: accommodating multiple Asian peoples and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Emperor Asoka.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Qianlong Emperor (r. 1736-95). Their reigns
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: modern period of China.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: NAYAKS OF MADURAI
label: Title

text: The Nayaks, though nominally under the rule
label: Paragraph

text: of Delhi, continued the Chola and Vijayanagar
label: Paragraph

text: practice of treating ternples as surrogate courts.
label: Paragraph

text: In fact, the temples of Madurai and Tanjore
label: Paragraph

text: became veritable cities unto themselves.
label: Paragraph

text: Their gates were rarely closed, and urban
label: Paragraph

text: life moved in and out at will. The Meenakshi
label: Paragraph

text: Sunderesvara Temple (1623-59) has two main
label: Paragraph

text: shrines, the larger one dedicated to Shiva in the
label: Paragraph

text: manifestation of Sunderesvara (“the beautiful
label: Title

text: one”) and the smaller to his wife Meenakshi
label: Paragraph

text: (“the fish-eyed one”). Nonetheless, the temple’s
label: Paragraph

text: main deity is Meenakshi, a local regional
label: Paragraph

text: goddess who is important to the Tamils. Though
label: Paragraph

text: she was married to Shiva after the rise of the
label: Paragraph

text: bhakti cults, she maintained her dominance over
label: Paragraph

text: the populace. Spatially this duality is represented
label: Paragraph

text: in procession. Although Sunderesvara’s shrine
label: Paragraph

text: has a well-defined axis leading to it, it is
label: Paragraph

text: Meenakshi’s more informally defined access
label: Title

text: path that has the important historical locations
label: Paragraph

text: along it, most importantly the Lotus Tank—the
label: Paragraph

text: mythical origin of the ternple—and a corridor
label: Title

text: with painted panels depicting stories from
label: Caption

text: Meenakshi's life.
label: Paragraph

text: As it grew, the ternple became a series
label: Paragraph

text: of enclosures that nestle a diverse array of
label: Paragraph

text: functional and ceremonial spaces, such as
label: Paragraph

text: pillared halls, open courts, inhabitable corridors,
label: Paragraph

text: and shrines, all designed to accormmodate the
label: Paragraph

text: temple's diverse civic and religious functions.
label: Paragraph

text: In addition, it has markets, private shrines,
label: Paragraph

text: places for resting, dwellings for priests, and
label: Paragraph

text: ceremonial sites; a museum was added recently.
label: Paragraph

text: Chief among the rituals is an elaborate annual
label: Paragraph

text: procession meant to be visible to all, particularly
label: Paragraph

text: the lowest castes, who were not allowed into
label: Paragraph

text: 15.60 Plan: Urban core of Madurai, India
label: Caption

text: the temple. This procession celebrated
label: Paragraph

text: Meenakshi’s divine wedding to Sunderesvara
label: Title

text: (Shiva). Over a nineteen-day period in
label: Paragraph

text: April and May, Meenakshi is taken out in
label: Paragraph

text: procession in a mobile structure, into the
label: Paragraph

text: crowded city streets, where she ceremonially
label: Paragraph

text: defeats all the gods and earthly kings in one
label: Paragraph

text: battle after another until she finally meets
label: Paragraph

text: Sunderesvara, whom she almost defeats
label: Paragraph

text: before suddenly realizing she is prophesied to
label: Paragraph

text: marry him.
label: Paragraph

text: Seen from a distance, the Meenakshi
label: Paragraph

text: Sunderesvara Ternple’s silhouette is defined
label: Paragraph

text: by its gopurams, or gateways, the highest
label: Paragraph

text: ones reaching 50 meters. Made of brick,
label: Paragraph

text: they are largely solid and are ornamented
label: Paragraph

text: with a myriad of vividly painted mythical
label: Paragraph

text: deities and creatures. The gopurams
label: Paragraph

text: dis
label: Title

text: 15.61 Gopuram of Meenakshi Sunderesvara Temple at Madurai
label: Caption

text: increase in height the farther they are from
label: Paragraph

text: the center. The gold-covered shikharas
label: Paragraph

text: over the shrines are actually the temple's
label: Paragraph

text: smallest superstructures. In part, the
label: Paragraph

text: gopurams' function is to announce the
label: Paragraph

text: temple's presence to the city, and when seen
label: Paragraph

text: from a distance, they create a visual wave
label: Paragraph

text: radiating out into the landscape. In other
label: Paragraph

text: words, the mandalic universe that is usually
label: Paragraph

text: condensed into the figurative representation
label: Paragraph

text: of a Hindu temple's shikhara was, under
label: Paragraph

text: the Nayaks, expanded so far outward that
label: Paragraph

text: it encornpasses the geography of the entire
label: Paragraph

text: city itself. And because Madurai sits in a
label: Paragraph

text: river valley surrounded by a ring of low-lying
label: Paragraph

text: hills, the hills can be imagined as the next
label: Paragraph

text: layer of gopurams, implying mythical unseen
label: Paragraph

text: mountains beyond.

text: JAIPUR
label: Title

text: The Mughal emperor Akbar’s policy to
label: Paragraph

text: subjugate the Rajputs was to offer them
label: Paragraph

text: conciliatory alliances, preserving their cultural
label: Paragraph

text: and political independence, subject to a
label: Paragraph

text: military tax; and to invade only if they rejected
label: Paragraph

text: that offer. The Rajput king Raja Bharmal of
label: Paragraph

text: Amer was the first to accept this alliance,
label: Paragraph

text: which enabled his state to prosper during the
label: Paragraph

text: Mughal tenure. Amer was one of the critical
label: Paragraph

text: ports on the highway from Agra to the Kutch
label: Title

text: coast, so its defense and the taxes that it
label: Paragraph

text: generated were important for the Mughals.
label: Paragraph

text: For their loyalty, Amer maharajas were often
label: Paragraph

text: appointed viceroys to Mughal territories such
label: Paragraph

text: as Malwa in peninsular India.
label: Paragraph

text: After Aurangzeb’s death in 1707, the then
label: Paragraph

text: maharaja of Amer, Sawai Jai Singh, realized
label: Paragraph

text: that the Mughal Empire was beginning to
label: Paragraph

text: break down, and went on an aggressive
label: Paragraph

text: campaign to modernize and weaponize
label: Title

text: his own state. In particular, he modernized
label: Paragraph

text: his forts’ defenses to better withstand
label: Paragraph

text: artillery and invested in large ammount of
label: Paragraph

text: artillery as well, with a massive reserve of
label: Paragraph

text: ammunition—at the cost of cavalry, which
label: Paragraph

text: was the traditional strength of the Rajputs.
label: Paragraph

text: Because of this militarization, Amer quickly
label: Paragraph

text: emerged as a strong and stable regional
label: Paragraph

text: power, highly protective of trade routes and
label: Paragraph

text: commercial activity, and in the waning days
label: Paragraph

text: of the Mughals attracted a large amount of
label: Paragraph

text: migration from Mughal cities.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1727, Sawai Jai Singh felt sufficiently
label: Paragraph

text: secure that he moved his palace out of the
label: Paragraph

text: big fort at Amer and down the hill onto an
label: Paragraph

text: open field, where he already had a built a
label: Paragraph

text: large garden. This was quite a risk, for the
label: Paragraph

text: location of the new city made it vulnerable
label: Paragraph

text: not only to artillery but even to a strong
label: Paragraph

text: cavalry attack. Jai Singh’s solution was to
label: Paragraph

text: build a fort on the hillock immediately behind
label: Paragraph

text: the new city, called Nahargarh, to which the
label: Paragraph

text: royal farnily at least could retreat in case of a
label: Paragraph

text: sudden attack. Nahargarh had the particular
label: Paragraph

text: advantage of an artesian spring, around
label: Paragraph

text: which a fantastic asymmetrical tank was
label: Paragraph

text: built. But as it happened, Nahargarh never
label: Paragraph

text: had to be used.
label: Paragraph

text: Jai Singh called his new city Jaipur, and
label: Paragraph

text: he put the architect Vidyadhar, the head of
label: Paragraph

text: his imarat, or building department, in charge
label: Paragraph

text: of building it. Vidhyachar is the first recorded
label: Paragraph

text: L
label: Title

text: 15.63 Plan of Jaipur, India
label: Caption

text: individual town planner in South Asian
label: Title

text: history in charge of building a brand-new
label: Title

text: city (although Mughal court names are also
label: Paragraph

text: documented as being in charge of various
label: Paragraph

text: projects, such as Fatehpur Sikri).
label: Paragraph

text: Fortunately, Vidyadhar proved equal to
label: Paragraph

text: the task. He first built a master plan for the

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: hill butted into the garden in one corner.
label: Paragraph

text: To compensate, Vidyadhar added another
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhood square, called a chokri, at the
label: Paragraph

text: other end of the city. Around the boundary
label: Paragraph

text: of the new city he built a wall—not strong
label: Paragraph

text: enough to hold back artillery fire, but high
label: Paragraph

text: enough to designate the urban boundary
label: Paragraph

text: and to control access through designated
label: Title

text: gates. Since the city stood on an important
label: Paragraph

text: trade route, controlling access was vital to
label: Paragraph

text: collecting octroj (taxes).
label: Paragraph

text: Within the city walls, Vidyadhar invested
label: Paragraph

text: heavily in building the drainage infrastructure
label: Paragraph

text: of the city and, more importantly, in
label: Paragraph

text: constructing rows of markets along the main
label: Paragraph

text: arteries of the city. By building up the street
label: Paragraph

text: nea ae
label: Title

text: edges of the main avenues, Vidyadhar was
label: Paragraph

text: not only able to construct a unified street
label: Paragraph

text: picture, he also immediately had a large
label: Paragraph

text: amount of commercial street-front property
label: Paragraph

text: available for sale, which attracted merchants
label: Paragraph

text: fleeing the declining Mughal cities. Behind
label: Paragraph

text: the main streets, the interiors were built up
label: Paragraph

text: around the settling populations, who largely
label: Paragraph

text: clustered around trades. Street intersections
label: Paragraph

text: were cut at the corners to create chokris. The
label: Paragraph

text: street section of the shopswas set up such
label: Paragraph

text: that people could gather on shop rooftops
label: Paragraph

text: and view the street processions that were
label: Paragraph

text: commonpace then as today on festival days.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 19th century, all of Jaipur’s main
label: Paragraph

text: streets were painted a uniform color—a pink
label: Paragraph

text: pigment derived from the local sandstone—to
label: Paragraph

text: welcome a visiting colonial prince. This added
label: Paragraph

text: significantly to the strong urban street picture
label: Paragraph

text: of the city. Sawai Jai Singh patronized Jesuit
label: Paragraph

text: priests alongside Islamic scientists and Hindu
label: Title

text: and Jain scholars in his court. He had an
label: Paragraph

text: extensive library, and is famous for building

text: the most accurate observatories in the world
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: as an early modern architecture in which
label: Paragraph

text: Sinan’s “classicism” was hybridized with
label: Paragraph

text: European—and particularly French—Baroque
label: Title

text: architectural sensibilities and then mixed
label: Title

text: together with Persian and Indian precedents,
label: Paragraph

text: THE ANGLICAN CHURCH
label: Title

text: In 1536, in order to annul his marriage to his
label: Paragraph

text: Catholic Spanish queen, Catherine of Aragon,
label: Title

text: the English king Henry VIII dissolved the
label: Paragraph

text: Catholic monasteries and abbeys and created
label: Title

text: the Church of England, or Anglican Church,
label: Paragraph

text: with himself as its head. However, this new
label: Paragraph

text: church maintained many liturgical similarities
label: Paragraph

text: to the Catholic Church, a fact that came to
label: Paragraph

text: be vociferously opposed by the Puritans,
label: Paragraph

text: who, influenced by Protestants such as the
label: Paragraph

text: Calvinists, wanted a purer form of worship
label: Paragraph

text: freed of all Catholic influence. The Puritan
label: Paragraph

text: influence in Parliament became so strong
label: Paragraph

text: that during the English Civil War (1642-51)
label: Paragraph

text: they executed Charles | in 1649 and set up
label: Paragraph

text: the Puritan Oliver Cromwell (1599-1658)
label: Title

text: as ruler of a self-proclaimed Protestant
label: Paragraph

text: Republic. This was, however, a short-lived
label: Paragraph

text: revolution, and in 1660 the monarchy was
label: Paragraph

text: able to reinstate itself. The Puritans found
label: Paragraph

text: themselves marginalized in English society,
label: Paragraph

text: and many left to join their cornpatriots already
label: Paragraph

text: settled on the shores of New England.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1665 a great fire destroyed most of
label: Paragraph

text: central London, including eighty churches.
label: Paragraph

text: The rebuilding of the churches became
label: Paragraph

text: an opportunity to place a strong Anglican
label: Paragraph

text: imprint on the city. Dominated by the landed
label: Paragraph

text: gentry, the Anglican Church effectively
label: Paragraph

text: functioned as an extension of the interests
label: Paragraph

text: of the ruling class. Sir Christopher Wren, an
label: Paragraph

text: English nobleman trained as an astronomer,
label: Paragraph

text: was asked to design almost all of these
label: Paragraph

text: churches. Wren studied contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: French architecture but seemed to have been
label: Paragraph

text: more impressed with Italianate examples and
label: Paragraph

text: literature, particularly Palladian simplicity.
label: Paragraph

text: Anglicanism placed considerable emphasis
label: Paragraph

text: on the dignity of the service as prescribed
label: Title

text: in the Book of Common Prayer, but unlike
label: Paragraph

text: Italian Counter-Reformation churches, which
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized the spectacle of devotion, Wren’s
label: Paragraph

text: churches possess some of the simplicity
label: Paragraph

text: and openness of Protestant churches. The
label: Paragraph

text: color palette of their interiors was restrained;
label: Paragraph

text: almost everything was white, with a few
label: Paragraph

text: accents like gilded column capitals, string
label: Paragraph

text: courses, and rosettes set against the dark
label: Paragraph

text: wood of the altarpiece and furniture. Large
label: Caption

text: windows brought in ample light.
label: Paragraph

text: After the destruction of St. Paul’s Cathedral
label: Paragraph

text: in the Great Fire of London, many wanted
label: Paragraph

text: to rebuild it in the old Gothic style. Wren,
label: Paragraph

text: however, envisioned a building up to date
label: Paragraph

text: with European neoclassical sensibilities.
label: Paragraph

text: Several plans and revisions were made,
label: Paragraph

text: including one known as the “great model,”
label: Paragraph

text: which had highly original, large concave
label: Paragraph

text: exteriors. It was rejected for a more
label: Paragraph

text: conventional plan. The church fathers
label: Paragraph

text: accepted the modern exterior but insisted on
label: Paragraph

text: a medieval-style section, with low side aisles
label: Caption

text: and a tall nave.
label: Paragraph

text: The building (1675-1709) is in the
label: Paragraph

text: shape of a cross, with the dome, one of the
label: Paragraph

text: largest in the world, over the crossing. It is
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by three galleries on different
label: Paragraph

text: levels. To disguise the low side aisles, Wren
label: Paragraph

text: created a blind second story that also
label: Paragraph

text: concealed the buttresses holding up the
label: Paragraph

text: vaults. Without the false second story, the
label: Paragraph

text: dome would have looked astonishingly out
label: Paragraph

text: of scale. Even so, it looms large, resting on a
label: Paragraph

text: ring of columns with eight cleverly disguised
label: Caption

text: buttresses. On the interior is a giant pilaster
label: Caption

text: order for the nave and a lower order for the
label: Paragraph

text: secondary spaces, modeled loosely on St.
label: Paragraph

text: Peter's Basilica in Rome.

label: Paragraph

text: The most imaginative of the English architects
label: Paragraph

text: of the early 18th century was undoubtedly
label: Paragraph

text: Nicholas Hawksmoor (1661-1736), Wren's
label: Paragraph

text: apprentice. Wren shared with his apprentice
label: Paragraph

text: an interest in the architecture of Asia Minor
label: Paragraph

text: and in the then still barely known architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of Greece and Egypt. But if Wren had an
label: Paragraph

text: eye for compositional unity, Hawksmoor
label: Caption

text: aimed to bring the elements of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: composition into dynamic interrelationship.
label: Paragraph

text: He pried features out of their expected
label: Paragraph

text: contexts.
label: Paragraph

text: The strangeness of Hawksmoor’s
label: Title

text: buildings is a result of a design process
label: Paragraph

text: that emphasized esoteric historical and
label: Paragraph

text: philosophical meanings. In that sense,
label: Paragraph

text: Hawksmoor spoke to a generation of
label: Paragraph

text: designers that attempted to distance itself
label: Title

text: from amateur architects and questioned
label: Title

text: the normative production of aesthetic ideals
label: Title

text: as public spectacle. His St. Mary Woolnoth
label: Paragraph

text: (1716-24) is an astonishing building when
label: Paragraph

text: compared with the stiff linearity of the English
label: Paragraph

text: Palladian style that was starting to make its
label: Paragraph

text: presence felt. The double-tower front facade
label: Paragraph

text: appears to be two buildings stacked on top
label: Paragraph

text: of each other, the entirety surmounted by two
label: Paragraph

text: symmetrically placed small bell housings.
label: Caption

text: In the lower zone, the voussoirs around
label: Paragraph

text: the openings are connected to horizontally
label: Paragraph

text: 15.70 St. Mary Woolnoth, London
label: Caption

text: banded rustication grooves that continue
label: Paragraph

text: even around the corner columns. Over this
label: Paragraph

text: structure, Hawksmoor placed a “base” on
label: Paragraph

text: which rests an entablatured blind portico.
label: Caption

text: It would be wrong to read Hawksmoor’s
label: Paragraph

text: architecture as simply playful or baroque,
label: Paragraph

text: however. He was not just playing with formal
label: Paragraph

text: composition but also citing less well-known
label: Paragraph

text: references from antiquity. Not adhering
label: Paragraph

text: to the limited Palladian interpretation of
label: Paragraph

text: the antique, Hawksmoor studied buildings
label: Paragraph

text: such as the Roman tomb of the Julii at St.-
label: Paragraph

text: Rémy, France. The two columns flanking
label: Caption

text: the entrance are esoteric references to the
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Solomon, the reconstruction of
label: Title

text: which preoccupied many architects of the
label: Paragraph

text: time, including Wren. Anglican theologians
label: Paragraph

text: of the day were also interested in the Second
label: Paragraph

text: Temple of Solomon as a way to reconnect
label: Title

text: to both biblical authenticity and the ethos of
label: Paragraph

text: early Christianity. The upper portico was a
label: Paragraph

text: reference to the Mausoleum of Halicarnassus,
label: Paragraph

text: one of the seven ancient wonders of the
label: Paragraph

text: world, which had been destroyed but for
label: Paragraph

text: which Hawksmoor made a sketch based on
label: Paragraph

text: descriptions by Pliny and Vitruvius. In this
label: Paragraph

text: way, Hawksmoor opened a brief window to
label: Paragraph

text: the possibility that antiquity could be a source
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural heterogeneity—contrary to the
label: Paragraph

text: rush to exemplify, as with the spread of the
label: Paragraph

text: Baroque style throughout colonial Europe.

text: WHIGS AND THE PALLADIAN REVIVAL
label: Title

text: By the early 18th century, the older
label: Paragraph

text: puritanical interests of England had been
label: Paragraph

text: channeled into the rise of the Whig party,
label: Paragraph

text: which, with Robert Walpole as prime minister
label: Paragraph

text: under kings George | and George II, pursued
label: Paragraph

text: a policy of aggressive mercantile capitalism
label: Title

text: focused on protecting British interests in
label: Paragraph

text: the colonies, accompanied by anti-Catholic
label: Paragraph

text: and anti-slavery policies, and a strong
label: Paragraph

text: anti-Tory push for constitutional monarchy.
label: Paragraph

text: Continuing the Whigs’ puritanical leaning,
label: Paragraph

text: the Georgian architecture of this time was
label: Paragraph

text: overtly simple and understated. Walls were
label: Paragraph

text: usually of unadorned brick, and windows and
label: Paragraph

text: doorways were framed in wood painted white.
label: Paragraph

text: Facades were symmetrically arranged around
label: Paragraph

text: the ground-level entrance or, on occasion,
label: Paragraph

text: accessed by a short flight of steps. Grander
label: Caption

text: houses might have a portico, pilasters, or
label: Paragraph

text: corner quoins.
label: Paragraph

text: The Georgian style was England's
label: Paragraph

text: first truly national style; it was unique to
label: Paragraph

text: England and its colonies and arose out of
label: Paragraph

text: the Protestant ethic of nondemonstrative
label: Title

text: simplicity. Functional and serviceable, it was
label: Paragraph

text: adopted by the newly emerging mercantile
label: Paragraph

text: class, which was heavily involved in coal and
label: Paragraph

text: agricultural ventures, not only in England but
label: Paragraph

text: also abroad. Unlike the French aristocracy,
label: Paragraph

text: the English upper classes actively invested in
label: Paragraph

text: the colonies. Stratford Hall Plantation (1738)
label: Caption

text: in Virginia, at the head of a large estate that
label: Paragraph

text: grew tobacco for export to England, was
label: Paragraph

text: designed for Thomas Lee, a businessman
label: Caption

text: in the Virginia colonies and for a time acting
label: Paragraph

text: governor of the state.
label: Paragraph

text: Palladian Revival architecture blossomed
label: Title

text: after the 1715 publication of Vitruvius
label: Paragraph

text: Britannicus, written by the Scottish lawyer
label: Paragraph

text: and architect Colen Campbell, who
label: Paragraph

text: proclaimed the superiority of antiquity over
label: Paragraph

text: what he argued were the affected and
label: Paragraph

text: licentious forms of the Baroque. The work
label: Paragraph

text: of Inigo Jones, in his eyes, should have
label: Paragraph

text: been held in just as high an esteem as that
label: Paragraph

text: of Palladio. Vitruvius Britannicus, together
label: Caption

text: with the publication of the three volumes
label: Paragraph

text: of The Architecture of A. Pailadio (1715,
label: Caption

text: 1717, and 1725) by the Venetian Giacomo
label: Paragraph

text: Leoni, sparked a movement that invested
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: lea of the primacy of the natural law of
label: Paragraph

text: proportion, still a rather novel idea in English
label: Paragraph

text: design practice. Facade, plan, and volume
label: Paragraph

text: had to be unified into a formal whole. Yet
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Palladio’s own works—thus the frequent
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: The start of the 19th century was a watershed
label: Paragraph

text: moment in the advent of modernity. In 1800,
label: Paragraph

text: the world’s wealth was about the same it had
label: Paragraph

text: been a millennium before; China's wealth
label: Paragraph

text: was greater than that of the entire Western
label: Paragraph

text: world; and less than 2 percent of the world’s
label: Paragraph

text: population lived in cities. Today, a little over
label: Paragraph

text: two centuries later, the world's wealth has
label: Paragraph

text: increased more than sixteenfold; the West's
label: Paragraph

text: share of that wealth is almost 75 percent; and
label: Paragraph

text: about 50 percent of the world’s population
label: Paragraph

text: lives in cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Momentous events around 1800
label: Title

text: unleashed this radical transformation. The
label: Paragraph

text: European Enlightenment, particularly its
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on nature, science, reason, and
label: Title

text: egalitarianism, circulated in the colonial
label: Paragraph

text: world and eventually captured the global
label: Paragraph

text: imagination. Two major social revolutions—
label: Paragraph

text: the American and the French—translated
label: Title

text: the Enlightenment into political form, creating
label: Paragraph

text: new democracies that charted the path,
label: Paragraph

text: however circuitous and fitful, that led to the
label: Paragraph

text: decline of the monarchic institution, which
label: Paragraph

text: was replaced by that of the nation-state.
label: Paragraph

text: And at the center of it all, the Industrial
label: Paragraph

text: Revolution, particularly the invention of the
label: Paragraph

text: cotton gin, transformed a global mercantile
label: Paragraph

text: economy into a mass-manufacturing
label: Title

text: industrial economy, which made consumer
label: Paragraph

text: goods the new focus of the global economic
label: Title

text: system. One of its lesser consequences was
label: Paragraph

text: a global building boom, and with it the steady
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of a new sensibility regarding the
label: Paragraph

text: purposes and forms of architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: But that was still in the future; in its time
label: Paragraph

text: this entire transformation was more gradual
label: Paragraph

text: and fraught with contradictions. Europe was
label: Paragraph

text: still oriented primarily toward accumulating
label: Paragraph

text: wealth from far-flung global territories; its own
label: Paragraph

text: historical identity was as yet episodic, and its
label: Paragraph

text: sense of manifest destiny only just beginning
label: Title

text: to emerge. Thus the call for egalitarianism,
label: Paragraph

text: for instance, cohabited with the defense of
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The Mughal Empire was at its largest under
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: all the Deccan Sultanates. After his death in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: crumble. Taking advantage of the situation,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the Rajput ones, either moved toward
label: Paragraph

text: independence or declared independence
label: Title

text: outright. The prosperity of South Asia
label: Paragraph

text: actually increased at this time with growth in
label: Paragraph

text: trade, including from the newly established
label: Paragraph

text: European trading ports. If modernity can
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: transformation and as the production and
label: Title

text: exploration of the possibilities of the new in
label: Title

text: negotiation with the values of the status quo,
label: Paragraph

text: then this was indeed a period of modernity.
label: Paragraph

text: There is a theory that Jaipur was based on a

text: observations could be cross-referenced for
label: Paragraph

text: greater accuracy. Named Jantar Mantar, they
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of yantra, which means “instrument.”)
label: Paragraph

text: In 1799, Sawai Jai Singh's grandson,
label: Paragraph

text: Sawai Pratap Singh, built the Hawa Mahall,
label: Paragraph

text: considered to be one of Jaipur's signature
label: Paragraph

text: monuments. The Hawa Mahall (“Wind

label: Paragraph

text: palace complex, facing the street, it was built

text: while remaining unobserved themselves.

text: and mosques that often contained screened

text: In the 18th century, the Sikhs, under
label: Paragraph

text: Maharaja Ranjit Singh (r. 1801-1839),
label: Paragraph

text: expanded into an empire encompassing the
label: Paragraph

text: region of the five tributaries of the Indus, or
label: Paragraph

text: the Punjab (literally, “five rivers”). Founded
label: Paragraph

text: by Guru Nanak in the 15th century, Sikhism
label: Paragraph

text: was a mix of Islamic Sufi concepts and
label: Paragraph

text: Hindu bhakti ideas. Critical of some Hindu
label: Paragraph

text: practices, it eliminated idol worship and caste
label: Paragraph

text: distinction and emphasized the unity of God
label: Paragraph

text: and the necessity of an intimate experience
label: Title

text: with the divine. The Sikhs offered themselves
label: Paragraph

text: as an alternative to both Islam and Hinduism
label: Paragraph

text: and accepted converts from both. Sikh
label: Paragraph

text: involvement in the political affairs of the
label: Paragraph

text: Mughals was complex; they fell in and out of
label: Paragraph

text: favor with the Mughal court at various times.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1699, Guru Gobind Singh (1675-1708),
label: Paragraph

text: the last of their gurus, formalized the Sikh
label: Paragraph

text: religion, enjoining the faithful to defend it by
label: Paragraph

text: arms if necessary.
label: Paragraph

text: Darbar Sahib, or Golden Temple, built in
label: Paragraph

text: Amritsar in 1764 during the reign of Maharaja
label: Paragraph

text: Ranjit Singh, had long been an important
label: Paragraph

text: place of Sikh pilgrimage and learning. It was
label: Paragraph

text: here that, in 1604, Guru Arjan Das installed
label: Paragraph

text: the Granth Sahib, the Sikh holy book after its
label: Paragraph

text: compilation. It sits in the center of a square
label: Paragraph

text: sacred pool, 150 meters on each side, that
label: Paragraph

text: is surrounded by a marble walkway (for
label: Paragraph

text: ritual circumambulation), which in turn is
label: Paragraph

text: separated from the outside world by buildings
label: Paragraph

text: that house the various functions of the
label: Paragraph

text: institution, such as its administrative offices,
label: Paragraph

text: galleries, and dining halls. A causeway leads
label: Paragraph

text: from the Darbar Sahib to the edge, where
label: Paragraph

text: one finds a three-story structure with a single
label: Paragraph

text: ome, the Akal Takht, where the highest
label: Paragraph

text: priests have their offices. Every morning the
label: Paragraph

text: Granth Sahib is cerernoniously carried from
label: Paragraph

text: the Akal Takh to the Darbar Sahib to be
label: Paragraph

text: installed; it is returned in the evening. Among
label: Paragraph

text: the several affiliated structures that lie outside
label: Paragraph

text: the compound is the Guru-ka-langar, a three-
label: Paragraph

text: storied building where 35,000 people are fed
label: Paragraph

text: jaily at no charge.
label: Paragraph

text: The Darbar Sahib itself has doorless
label: Paragraph

text: entrances on all four sides as an indication
label: Paragraph

text: of the building's accessibility to all. No formal
label: Paragraph

text: rituals are conducted here, but hymns are
label: Paragraph

text: sung day and night. The lower story of the
label: Paragraph

text: main structure is made of marble, whereas
label: Paragraph

text: the upper story and domes are covered with
label: Paragraph

text: plates of gilded copper. An off-center low
label: Paragraph

text: fluted dome is partially obscured by a high
label: Paragraph

text: parapet with four chattris at the four corners.
label: Caption

text: Its ornamentation and formal outlines are
label: Paragraph

text: based on Mughal precedents, though the
label: Paragraph

text: easy informality of their orchestration gives
label: Paragraph

text: the Darbar Sahib a fluidity of expression
label: Title

text: associated more with complex Hindu and
label: Paragraph

text: Jain temples than with the stately tornbs
label: Paragraph

text: and mosques of the Mughals. It is a unique
label: Paragraph

text: structure, a product of one of the most
label: Paragraph

text: determined attempts to bridge the differences
label: Title

text: between Islamic and Hindu thought to create
label: Title

text: a new synthesis.

text: NEOCLASSICISM VS. ROMANTICISM
label: Title

text: The term Neoclassicism, in wide use today,
label: Paragraph

text: was actually invented in the mid-19th
label: Paragraph

text: century. Until then, critics, theorists, and
label: Paragraph

text: artists called it simply the “true style” that
label: Paragraph

text: challenged the fluctuations of taste and,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly, the extravagances of Baroque
label: Paragraph

text: space. The heady mercantile era of the
label: Paragraph

text: preceding century gave way to a desire
label: Paragraph

text: for something perceived as authentic and
label: Paragraph

text: stable. At its best, Neoclassicism shared the
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment's spirit of reform, whether it
label: Paragraph

text: was scientific advancement in the Age of
label: Paragraph

text: Reason or the new political philosophy that
label: Title

text: stressed the principles of a socially regulated
label: Paragraph

text: uman action. But Neoclassicism was
label: Paragraph

text: also connected to Eurocentrism, the idea
label: Paragraph

text: that European heritage conferred special
label: Paragraph

text: standing in the history of civilization. Although
label: Paragraph

text: leoclassicism was originally a broad
label: Paragraph

text: movement encompassing all the arts and the
label: Paragraph

text: umanities, by the middle of the 19th century
label: Paragraph

text: it had mostly died out except in architecture,

text: the time, but Piranesi elevated the art into an

text: iorn all its own. Scouring the often malaria-
label: Paragraph

text: infested Roman campagna for pictorial
label: Title

text: possibilities, Piranesi created etchings
label: Paragraph

text: of haunting intensity, bringing into view

text: unexpected and revealing angles, with broken
label: Paragraph

text: stones, crumbling bricks, collapsed vaults,

text: and overgrown facades. This was a Rome far

label: Paragraph

text: Adam and Piranesi represented the two
label: Paragraph

text: sides of the Romantic movement. Both
label: Paragraph

text: admired the heroic, but from different
label: Paragraph

text: political perspectives. Adam saw the Roman
label: Paragraph

text: past as the legitimization of European—and
label: Paragraph

text: particularly English—civilizational supremacy
label: Title

text: in a diverse global world, while Piranesi
label: Paragraph

text: rendered it as a meditative reflection on the
label: Paragraph

text: short-sightedness of the powers currently in
label: Paragraph

text: charge. Whereas Adam privileged a sustained
label: Paragraph

text: investment in the “eternal principles” of the
label: Paragraph

text: “true style"—that is, classicism—Piranesi
label: Paragraph

text: pointed toward a more conflicted reading of
label: Paragraph

text: history, one less sure of its certainties and
label: Paragraph

text: more mindful of its losses.
label: Paragraph

text: In the European colonial environment,
label: Paragraph

text: where global realities had increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: become part of upper-class life,
label: Paragraph

text: Neoclassicism, as the work of Adam
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrates, provided a language of
label: Paragraph

text: stability and order that also reinforced the
label: Paragraph

text: search for European self-understanding in
label: Title

text: the wake of the colonial experience. But
label: Paragraph

text: Neoclassicism, as a language of self-mastery,
label: Paragraph

text: was also a language of the master over
label: Paragraph

text: the production of others. Neoclassicism
label: Paragraph

text: Walpole (1717-97), builder of Strawberry
label: Paragraph

text: Hill (1749-77), used the term Gothic

text: picturesque to define this style. Walpole was

text: in many respects a counterculturalist. His

label: Paragraph

text: such as The Castle of Otranto. He also

label: Paragraph

text: as an essay entitled “History of the Modern

text: Taste in Gardening” (1771). Upon the
label: Paragraph

text: death of his farnous father in 1745, Walpole
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 16 hectares at Twickenham, southwest
label: Caption

text: of London, set among fashionable villas
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking the Thames River and near the
label: Paragraph

text: residence of his friend, the poet and garden
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiast Alexander Pope. Rather than
label: Paragraph

text: delve deep into classicism, Walpole was
label: Paragraph

text: among the first English intellectuals to amass
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: world, building in essence one of the first
label: Paragraph

text: museums. To hold and display his collection
label: Paragraph

text: he expanded the existing house and built a
label: Paragraph

text: library, an armory, a gallery, a “star chamber,”
label: Paragraph

text: a “tribune,” a sort of shrine, a china closet,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 16.20 Interior: Strawberry Hill
label: Caption

text: The structure itself was made in a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: an experimental Gothic idiom, searching not
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the collaging of forms. There were towers,
label: Paragraph

text: battlements, and stained glass rescued from
label: Caption

text: demolished buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: While Robert Adam was an ideologue and
label: Paragraph

text: consummate tasternaker for the metropolitan
label: Title

text: gentry, Walpole created a willful aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: environment reflecting his personal choices.
label: Paragraph

text: Strawberry Hill became celebrated in its
label: Paragraph

text: time; after 1763 Walpole even began selling
label: Paragraph

text: entrance tickets. The house became a
label: Paragraph

text: showpiece, while Adam's work represented
label: Paragraph

text: the profession of an ideal. Adam and
label: Paragraph

text: Walpole represent the paradoxes associated
label: Paragraph

text: with emerging modernism: in the former,
label: Paragraph

text: professionalism, or at least the beginnings of
label: Paragraph

text: what might be called a professional practice;
label: Paragraph

text: and in the latter, the deliberate and self-
label: Paragraph

text: conscious search for personal expression in a
label: Title

text: diverse world.
