text: Laugier, Rousseau, and the Noble Savage
label: Title

text: Whereas in England, Neoclassicism was
label: Paragraph

text: generally seen as the proper environment
label: Paragraph

text: for the elite, the tone in France was
label: Paragraph

text: more strident, assuming a subtext of
label: Paragraph

text: antimonarchism driven in part by an
label: Paragraph

text: emerging interest in rationalism and legalism
label: Title

text: and a desire to rethink the role of civic
label: Title

text: institutions. In architectural circles, all this
label: Paragraph

text: came into the open with the publication
label: Paragraph

text: in 1753 of Marc-Antoine Laugier’s Essai
label: Paragraph

text: sur architecture. Translated into English
label: Caption

text: in 1775, it was a flashpoint of discussion
label: Paragraph

text: about the nature of architectural production.
label: Paragraph

text: Unlike Leon Battista Alberti's 7en Books on
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, Andrea Palladio’s Four Books
label: Title

text: on Architecture, and Claude Perrault's French
label: Paragraph

text: translation of Vitruvius, Laugier's work pointed
label: Paragraph

text: not to a classical past, but rather to an earlier,
label: Paragraph

text: “rustic” past.
label: Paragraph

text: Here we have the beginnings of
label: Paragraph

text: primitivism in modern art and architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: Laugier wrote neither as an architect nor as
label: Paragraph

text: a gentleman connoisseur. He was a Jesuit
label: Paragraph

text: priest and impassioned crator, in a clirnate of
label: Paragraph

text: approaching revolt. Unlike previous writers,
label: Paragraph

text: Laugier frowned on the use of pilasters
label: Paragraph

text: as “fakes” that did not contribute to the
label: Paragraph

text: actual solidity of the object. Even though his
label: Paragraph

text: image of the ideal building was not based
label: Paragraph

text: on Roman models, Laugier admired the
label: Paragraph

text: Maison Carrée at Nimes, France, as the most
label: Paragraph

text: perfect building of antiquity: “Thirty columns
label: Paragraph

text: support an entablature and a roof which is
label: Paragraph

text: closed at both ends by a pediment—that is
label: Paragraph

text: all; the combination is of a simplicity and
label: Paragraph

text: a nobility which strikes everybody.” But
label: Paragraph

text: critically for Laugier, unlike Adam and the
label: Paragraph

text: other Neoclassicists, it was not the classical
label: Paragraph

text: temple as such that needed to be imitated,
label: Paragraph

text: but that which lay behind its design, the
label: Paragraph

text: original “rustic hut,” or cabane rustique, as
label: Paragraph

text: he called it (widely mistranslated into English
label: Paragraph

text: as “primitive hut"). This hut, according
label: Paragraph

text: to Laugier, consisted only of columns,
label: Paragraph

text: entablatures, and pediments. Vaults, arches,
label: Caption

text: pedestals, and pilasters were not part of that
label: Paragraph

text: system and, he argued, should therefore not
label: Paragraph

text: be used. Even arcades, another important
label: Paragraph

text: element in classical architecture, were listed
label: Paragraph

text: by Laugier as “abuses.”
label: Paragraph

text: Laugier's book was highly controversial.
label: Paragraph

text: He argued that architecture should not be
label: Paragraph

text: seen as representing a magical transition
label: Paragraph

text: from the worldly to the heavenly, as had been
label: Paragraph

text: implied by the Baroque style, or a search for
label: Paragraph

text: classical truths in the architecture of Greece
label: Title

text: and Rome, but rather as a medium that told
label: Paragraph

text: nothing less than the story of the “origins” of
label: Paragraph

text: mankind—all mankind. This is why Laugier
label: Paragraph

text: is often cited as one of the key precursors
label: Paragraph

text: of the discourses of modern architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: still more than a century away. These origins
label: Paragraph

text: had to remain embedded in architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: They were similar to the notion of grace—a
label: Paragraph

text: sign of divine approval that for Catholics is
label: Paragraph

text: embedded in the human soul.
label: Paragraph

text: n this sense, Laugier’s argument echoed
label: Paragraph

text: the 15th-century debate between Bartolomé
label: Paragraph

text: de las Casas and Juan Ginés de Sepulveda in
label: Paragraph

text: Madrid on the question of the status of Native

text: Americans. The Jesuits had studied and

label: Paragraph

text: Americans and had lived more with ther in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: any other colonists. While Walpole collected
label: Paragraph

text: objects from around the world to glean in
label: Paragraph

text: them meaning from the world's civilizations,
label: Paragraph

text: Laugier's hut sought to bring home to Europe
label: Paragraph

text: what the Jesuits had learned from people,
label: Paragraph

text: who in their eyes were not “primitive” as in
label: Paragraph

text: barbarians, but “noble” primitives. It was this,
label: Paragraph

text: the Jesuits argued, that prepared them for
label: Paragraph

text: Christ.

text: Claude Nicholas Ledoux and Etienne-
label: Title

text: Louis Boullée are often called revolutionary
label: Paragraph

text: architects, but this is based on their
label: Paragraph

text: architecture rather than their politics. Both
label: Paragraph

text: architects straddled the fence in the French
label: Paragraph

text: Revolution, even though they set in motion
label: Paragraph

text: much of the aesthetic that for a short
label: Paragraph

text: while governed the sensibilities of the age.
label: Paragraph

text: Boullée probably made the transition to the
label: Paragraph

text: postrevolutionary world better than Ledoux.
label: Paragraph

text: He built little after the Revolution, but his
label: Paragraph

text: place was more secure, and it was his vision
label: Paragraph

text: that young architects in the Academy of
label: Paragraph

text: Architecture, where Boullée taught, aspired
label: Paragraph

text: to emulate. After the French Revolution, the
label: Paragraph

text: history of Neoclassicism took many turns,
label: Paragraph

text: fusing with the Greek Revival in Germany and
label: Paragraph

text: Scotland and blending in with the eclectic
label: Title

text: stylistic preferences of the Victorians. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: all this, traces of a vigorous and austere
label: Paragraph

text: Neoclassicism as pursued by Ledoux and
label: Paragraph

text: Boullée could be found throughout Europe
label: Paragraph

text: from 1800 onward.

text: Napoleonic Cemeteries
label: Title

text: After the French Revolution, Napoleon sought
label: Paragraph

text: to rebuild not only France but all of Europe
label: Title

text: along Enlightenment lines. He eventually
label: Paragraph

text: succumbed to his overreaching ambition,
label: Paragraph

text: making enemies of the Austrians, Russians,
label: Paragraph

text: and English, who were all eager to keep
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleonic ideas as far as possible from
label: Paragraph

text: their domains. The impact of the Napoleonic
label: Paragraph

text: era was, however, profound, bringing into
label: Paragraph

text: parlance concepts like liberty and justice,
label: Paragraph

text: abstractions that were presumed universal
label: Paragraph

text: and strong enough to replace the defunct
label: Paragraph

text: and self-serving regimes of the aristocracy.
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleon proved that nations could function
label: Paragraph

text: without the paternalism of kings and princes.
label: Paragraph

text: Socially, he introduced many Enlightenment-
label: Paragraph

text: influenced notions—the Napoleonic Code
label: Title

text: of 1804, for example, brought about the
label: Paragraph

text: emancipation of the Jews in many of the
label: Title

text: lands under his control; it also modernized
label: Paragraph

text: the school system.
label: Paragraph

text: One of his important contributions to
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was in cemeteries. Prior to
label: Paragraph

text: then Napoleon, the well-to-do were buried
label: Paragraph

text: in or near a parish church. The poor were
label: Paragraph

text: buried in paupers’ graves. As for soldiers,
label: Paragraph

text: they were easily dispensable figures, often
label: Paragraph

text: fighting as conscripts or mercenaries. They
label: Paragraph

text: were buried in unmarked graves on the
label: Paragraph

text: battlefield. But in Napoleon's army, death
label: Paragraph

text: in battle took on a new dignity, a notion that
label: Paragraph

text: would gain in importance in the Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: period to come. Consequently, military death
label: Paragraph

text: achieved an honorable connotation that it
label: Paragraph

text: had not had since antiquity. As a result of
label: Paragraph

text: these changes, the cemetery known as
label: Paragraph

text: Pére Lachaise, which was laid out in 1804
label: Paragraph

text: outside of Paris, was open to all citizens.
label: Paragraph

text: Graves, however, were to last for only
label: Paragraph

text: five years unless the plot was bought by
label: Paragraph

text: the deceased's relatives, who were also
label: Paragraph

text: required to endow certain architectural
label: Title

text: features of the cemetery. The cemetery
label: Caption

text: was among the first examples of a “garden
label: Paragraph

text: cemetery,” laid out with trees, bushes, and
label: Paragraph

text: winding paths; it had a central esplanade
label: Paragraph

text: ending in a funerary monument. Pére
label: Caption

text: Lachaise became the model for cemeteries
label: Paragraph

text: all over the world: the Glasgow Necropolis
label: Title

text: (1820), the South Metropolitan Cemetery
label: Caption

text: at Norwood in London (1830s), and the
label: Paragraph

text: Mt. Auburn Cemetery in Cambridge,
label: Caption

text: Massachusetts (1831), are just a few
label: Paragraph

text: examples.

text: Jean-Nicolas-Louis Durand
label: Title

text: In France, the Romantic movement had
label: Paragraph

text: many representatives among painters.
label: Paragraph

text: Théodore Géricault (1791-1824), for
label: Paragraph

text: example, used dramatic compositional
label: Paragraph

text: techniques to bring out the themes of
label: Paragraph

text: heroism, suffering, and endurance. In
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, Romanticism was slower
label: Paragraph

text: to develop. This was largely because
label: Paragraph

text: architecture in France, unlike in England and
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, remained under state sponsorship.
label: Paragraph

text: For that reason, post-Napoleonic French
label: Paragraph

text: architecture maintained the course of
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment rationalism. The most
label: Paragraph

text: important proponent of this tendency was
label: Paragraph

text: Jean-Nicolas-Louis Durand (1760-1834),
label: Paragraph

text: a pupil of Etienne-Louis Boullée and a
label: Paragraph

text: professor at the Ecole Polytechnique
label: Paragraph

text: (founded in 1794) whose work set the tone
label: Paragraph

text: for more than a generation. The purpose
label: Paragraph

text: of the Ecole Polytechnique was to graduate
label: Paragraph

text: engineers capable of meeting the needs of
label: Paragraph

text: the revolutionary armies as well as providing
label: Paragraph

text: plans for civilian public works in the remote
label: Title

text: corners of the new republic. No such school
label: Paragraph

text: existed in England, where the evolution of
label: Paragraph

text: taste, remaining in the hands of the elite,
label: Paragraph

text: was decentralized and thus often eclectic.
label: Paragraph

text: Durand's book Précis, first published in
label: Paragraph

text: 1802, became a reference book used
label: Paragraph

text: throughout Europe for half a century. In
label: Paragraph

text: it, he rejected the standard Neoclassical
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on historical relationship between
label: Title

text: contemporary architecture and classical
label: Title

text: antiquity, and instead argued that even
label: Paragraph

text: classical antiquity needed to be regularized
label: Paragraph

text: according to the eternal principles of
label: Paragraph

text: geometry. Durand was opposed to historical
label: Paragraph

text: classicism that only copied surface classical
label: Title

text: elements but that in plan was anything
label: Paragraph

text: but rationalClike the Capitol Building in
label: Paragraph

text: Washington, DC, for example. He wanted
label: Paragraph

text: the plan to be laid out on a grid and the
label: Paragraph

text: function clearly expressed. “To please,”
label: Paragraph

text: he wrote, “has never been the purpose of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture.” Instead, the architect should
label: Paragraph

text: provide “public and private utility,” while
label: Paragraph

text: aiming to serve “the well-being and the
label: Paragraph

text: maintenance of individuals and of society.”
label: Paragraph

text: Durand’s designs for walls, following Laugier,
label: Paragraph

text: were freed from pilasters, moldings, quoins,
label: Paragraph

text: and rustications. This was not stripped-down
label: Paragraph

text: Jeffersonian Neoclassicism
label: Title

text: When the sons, daughters, and grandchildren of
label: Paragraph

text: the European settlers revolted against English rule,
label: Paragraph

text: what had started as a search for economic freedom
label: Paragraph

text: became one of the Enlightenment's greatest moments.
label: Paragraph

text: Historically, in their search for antecedents, the
label: Paragraph

text: American taste-setters saw themselves as paralleling
label: Paragraph

text: the early Roman Republic rather than the Roman
label: Title

text: Empire. It was a subtle but important distinction,
label: Paragraph

text: based more on fantasy than historical accuracy. The
label: Paragraph

text: style of French postrevolutionary Neoclassicism was
label: Paragraph

text: picked up in particular by Thomas Jefferson (1743-
label: Paragraph

text: 1826), the drafter of the Declaration of Independence
label: Paragraph

text: and the third president of the United States, who
label: Paragraph

text: left a lasting imprint on American architecture
label: Paragraph

text: of the period. Having lived in Paris for five years
label: Paragraph

text: (1784-89) as ambassador to France, he came to
label: Paragraph

text: admire philosophical developments in Europe, which
label: Paragraph

text: instilled in him the idea that architecture was directly
label: Paragraph

text: related to social reform. He was also the consummate
label: Paragraph

text: gentleman architect, amassing a library of 130 books
label: Paragraph

text: on the fine arts—certainly the largest in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States at the time. As an amateur architect, Jefferson,
label: Paragraph

text: together with Charles-Louis Clérisseau, fused the
label: Paragraph

text: styles of Laugier and Adam in the design of the
label: Paragraph

text: Virginia State Capitol (1785-92). It was modeled on
label: Paragraph

text: the Maison Carrée of Nimes, one of the few Roman
label: Paragraph

text: buildings that was accepted by Laugier as true to the
label: Paragraph

text: standards of the “rustic hut.”
label: Paragraph

text: Monticello
label: Title

text: Thomas Jefferson designed most of Monticello,
label: Paragraph

text: his plantation and primary residence, himself. He
label: Paragraph

text: designed the house along neo-Palladian lines,
label: Paragraph

text: with a prominent pedimented portico fronting an
label: Paragraph

text: octagonal rotunda dome as the centerpiece. Within,
label: Caption

text: Jefferson devoted most of his attention to his library
label: Paragraph

text: and living room, reserving the central space as a
label: Paragraph

text: kind of a museum for the waiting guests, where they
label: Paragraph

text: were regaled with displays of Jefferson's scientific
label: Paragraph

text: experiments and re-creations of objects from Lewis
label: Title

text: and Clark’s expedition through the Western territories
label: Title

text: that had been acquired from Napoleon in 1805
label: Paragraph

text: during Jefferson's presidency.
label: Paragraph

text: Tobacco was the primary product of the Monticello
label: Paragraph

text: plantation. Jefferson was a slave-owner, and, unlike
label: Paragraph

text: George Washington, did not free his slaves on his
label: Paragraph

text: death—except the children of Sally Hemings, his
label: Paragraph

text: domestic help slave, with whom he almost certainly
label: Paragraph

text: had six children. Hemings’s family lived under the
label: Paragraph

text: kitchen at Monticello, and the rest of the slaves lived
label: Paragraph

text: in cabins along a prominent lane called Mulberry Row.
label: Paragraph

text: Jefferson died about $130,000 in debt; his daughter
label: Paragraph

text: sold Monticello and the slaves to settle his estate.

text: WASHINGTON, DC
label: Title

text: The design of Washington, DC, was the first
label: Paragraph

text: attempt to spatialize a new capital city as
label: Paragraph

text: an embodiment of the nation-state. Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Pierre U'Enfant, a French engineer who
label: Paragraph

text: served in the American Revolutionary War,
label: Paragraph

text: worked at the direction of George Washington
label: Paragraph

text: to prepare the plan. While Jefferson had
label: Paragraph

text: a more modest vision for the capital,
label: Paragraph

text: L'Enfant, presumably reflecting Washington's
label: Paragraph

text: conception, designed something more
label: Paragraph

text: grandiose—a city for the ages.
label: Paragraph

text: Over the base pattern of the urban grid,
label: Paragraph

text: L'Enfant imposed a Baroque-style web of
label: Paragraph

text: avenues that is surprisingly idiosyncratic
label: Paragraph

text: and that adjusts to the landscape and to the
label: Paragraph

text: turns of the Potomac River. Together they
label: Paragraph

text: form fifteen squares, intended to be divided
label: Paragraph

text: among the states. Over this, he imposed a
label: Paragraph

text: third order, with the Capitol Building and the
label: Paragraph

text: White House not facing each other across
label: Title

text: an open mall but placed at the ends of an
label: Paragraph

text: L, with the capitol at the longer arm of the
label: Paragraph

text: east-west-facing L. The intersection of the
label: Paragraph

text: two arms lies along the Potomac so that the
label: Paragraph

text: two buildings, backing their way into the urban
label: Paragraph

text: fabric from the river's edge, achieve a sense of
label: Paragraph

text: parallel prominence when approached from the
label: Paragraph

text: riverside—one of the major ways by which the
label: Paragraph

text: city would have been accessed at the time.
label: Paragraph

text: LEnfant's design calls to mind the
label: Paragraph

text: gardens of Versailles because the grand
label: Title

text: avenues of the former are like the allées
label: Paragraph

text: of the latter. However, the Capitol and the
label: Paragraph

text: White House are also connected by one of
label: Paragraph

text: several diagonals—Pennsylvania Avenue is
label: Paragraph

text: a Baroque device first articulated for Rome
label: Paragraph

text: under Sixtus V in his atternpt to link the great
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrimage sites of that city. In that sense the
label: Paragraph

text: city blends aspects of Versailles and Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: bringing the Counter-Reformation ideal of
label: Paragraph

text: the freestanding monumental building into
label: Paragraph

text: line with the notion of a city as a landscape
label: Paragraph

text: traversed by grand ceremonial approaches.
label: Paragraph

text: The siting of both the Capitol and the
label: Paragraph

text: White House away fromm the river’s edge
label: Title

text: and fronted by lawns derives from English
label: Paragraph

text: country house prototypes. It might also point
label: Paragraph

text: to the Hétel des Invalides (begun 1671) in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris, which, unlike the Louvre, was set at
label: Paragraph

text: 90 degrees to the Seine River at the end of
label: Paragraph

text: a park, connecting building and river. (At
label: Paragraph

text: St. Petersburg, the Winter Palace, which is
label: Paragraph

text: modeled on the Louvre, sits alongside the
label: Paragraph

text: Neva River.)
label: Paragraph

text: Uenfant was dismissed from service
label: Title

text: in 1792, and he left for Paris with all his
label: Paragraph

text: drawings. The plan as executed was based
label: Paragraph

text: on the drawings of Benjamin Banneker, a
label: Paragraph

text: former slave and self-taught astronomer.
label: Paragraph

text: The U.S. Capitol Building, begun in 1793,
label: Caption

text: went through several stages involving the
label: Paragraph

text: architects William Thornton, Henry Latrobe,
label: Caption

text: and Charles Bulfinch, in that order. It was a
label: Paragraph

text: difficult building to design, since there was
label: Paragraph

text: no clear prototype for a building with such a
label: Paragraph

text: complex program. In the Thornton plan, the
label: Paragraph

text: House chambers and the Senate chambers
label: Title

text: were placed right and left of a great rotunda
label: Paragraph

text: that was envisioned as a museum, with
label: Paragraph

text: niches sheltering statues of revolutionary
label: Caption

text: heroes. The building seamlessly integrated
label: Paragraph

text: allusions to a mythical Roman Republic, to
label: Paragraph

text: universal geometries, and to great historical
label: Paragraph

text: events. The entrance was defined by a
label: Paragraph

text: temple front with eight columns, modeled on
label: Caption

text: the Pantheon, flanked somewhat unusually
label: Paragraph

text: by columnar porches. Though the building
label: Caption

text: was symmetrical on the exterior, it was not on
label: Paragraph

text: the interior, where there was no attempt to
label: Paragraph

text: balance the two chambers. This went against
label: Paragraph

text: the Neoclassical tendencies of the time. The
label: Paragraph

text: building, set on a high ground-floor plinth,
label: Paragraph

text: was topped by a Pantheonesque dome
label: Paragraph

text: resting on an octagonal drum—higher than
label: Paragraph

text: that of its Roman model, so it would be easily
label: Paragraph

text: visible from the surroundings. Beginning
label: Paragraph

text: in 1855, the west front of the Capitol was
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilt and a new dome, held up by a steel
label: Paragraph

text: frame, was designed to rest on a high drum.
label: Paragraph

text: Compared to the conventions established by
label: Paragraph

text: Michelangelo's dome for St. Peter’s in Vatican
label: Caption

text: City, the dome is far out of proportion to the
label: Paragraph

text: building below. Perhaps it is this strangeness
label: Paragraph

text: that keeps the building from looking like a
label: Paragraph

text: cathedral and imparts to it an unmistakable
label: Paragraph

text: uniqueness.
label: Paragraph

text: Bulfinch, when left to his own devices, as
label: Paragraph

text: at the Massachusetts State House (1795-98),
label: Caption

text: was closer to the tradition of Palladio and
label: Paragraph

text: Inigo Jones. Sited prominently on a hill, the
label: Caption

text: state house is a brick structure with white
label: Paragraph

text: woodwork and trim in the Georgian manner,
label: Paragraph

text: but modeled loosely on Palladio's Pallazo
label: Paragraph

text: Thiene and Robert Adam's Shelburne House.
label: Paragraph

text: The upper floor is accessed by parallel stairs
label: Paragraph

text: that flank the central space. A broad loggia
label: Paragraph

text: with paired pilasters provide vistas down
label: Paragraph

text: to the city and harbor. The wooden dome,
label: Paragraph

text: originally painted gray to make it look like
label: Paragraph

text: stone, was gilded in the 1890s. The style of
label: Paragraph

text: the building is known as Federal, referring to
label: Paragraph

text: buildings designed between 1780 and 1830
label: Caption

text: in the United States.

text: NATIONALISM
label: Title

text: Nationalism is presently such a ubiquitous
label: Paragraph

text: concept that one forgets that it is actually
label: Paragraph

text: a modern concept, springing from the
label: Paragraph

text: end of the Napoleonic wars. As important
label: Paragraph

text: as Napoleon Bonaparte was in spreading
label: Paragraph

text: the ideas of liberty and justice throughout
label: Title

text: Europe, the consequences of decades of
label: Title

text: war left Europeans in desperate need of
label: Paragraph

text: stability. In 1813, Europe's diplomats met
label: Paragraph

text: in Vienna to discuss the political future of
label: Paragraph

text: Europe in the hope that the borders could be
label: Paragraph

text: stabilized. The Vienna Congress stipulated
label: Paragraph

text: that countries were to create constitutions,
label: Paragraph

text: if they had not already done so—a promise
label: Paragraph

text: some rulers broke to create stronger bonds
label: Paragraph

text: between the aristocracy and the bourgeoisie.
label: Paragraph

text: Prior to the Vienna Congress, that bond was
label: Paragraph

text: achieved mainly through the antiquated
label: Paragraph

text: custom of marriage, which only tended to
label: Paragraph

text: splinter and fragment the political landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: It was hoped that countries with fixed
label: Paragraph

text: national boundaries and with a working legal
label: Title

text: infrastructure would avoid war or have the
label: Paragraph

text: means and recourse to avoid it. Though the
label: Paragraph

text: ideals proved to be elusive, there is no doubt
label: Paragraph

text: that the Vienna Congress helped create the
label: Paragraph

text: modern notion of a nation-state, and it was
label: Paragraph

text: certainly successful in determining the future
label: Paragraph

text: national boundaries in Europe—boundaries
label: Title

text: that drive European politics to this day.
label: Paragraph

text: 16.49 Church of the Savior on Blood,
label: Caption

text: St. Petersburg, Russia
label: Caption

text: The new spirit of nationalism found an
label: Paragraph

text: easy alliance with Romanticism. For the
label: Paragraph

text: nationalists, history was more than just a
label: Paragraph

text: gentleman’s pastime. State boundaries had
label: Paragraph

text: to make sense historically, linguistically,
label: Paragraph

text: geographically, and now ethnically, and this
label: Paragraph

text: led to an interest in local history and the
label: Paragraph

text: development of regional antiquarianism.
label: Paragraph

text: Russia experienced a revival of the Russian
label: Paragraph

text: language (until the defeat of Napoleon, the
label: Paragraph

text: Russian aristocracy had spoken mainly
label: Paragraph

text: French). In Germany, there was a fascination
label: Paragraph

text: with the medieval and with the imagery
label: Paragraph

text: of the forest, as well as with the ancient
label: Paragraph

text: Greeks, with whom many Romantics felt
label: Paragraph

text: an affinity. Romantic nationalism also
label: Paragraph

text: emerged in Scandinavia as a protest against
label: Paragraph

text: Russian occupation and took the form of a
label: Paragraph

text: revival of Nordic mythology. Apart from the
label: Paragraph

text: development of national languages, Romantic
label: Title

text: nationalists were interested in folklore and
label: Paragraph

text: local customs, even if these had to be
label: Paragraph

text: enhanced. A case in point is the “discovery”
label: Paragraph

text: of Beowulf in a single manuscript, first
label: Paragraph

text: transcribed in 1818, after the manuscript
label: Paragraph

text: had lain as an ignored curiosity in scholars’
label: Paragraph

text: collections for two centuries. Beowulf quickly
label: Paragraph

text: came to be seen as an English national epic.
label: Paragraph

text: In architecture, Romantic nationalism was
label: Paragraph

text: slower to take hold due to the entrenched
label: Paragraph

text: dominance of Neoclassicism, but as the
label: Paragraph

text: century progressed, more and more examples
label: Paragraph

text: could be found. One such, the Church of
label: Paragraph

text: the Savior on Blood in St. Petersburg (1883-
label: Caption

text: 1907), was clearly meant to give impetus to a
label: Paragraph

text: revival of Byzantine forms.
label: Paragraph

text: In recent decades, with the post-Cold
label: Paragraph

text: War multiplication of new countries,
label: Title

text: Romantic nationalism has become a global
label: Paragraph

text: phenomenon. Though it heralds the farmer
label: Paragraph

text: and the workers, it often develops into an
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic that appeals to upper-class tastes.
label: Paragraph

text: As a result, Romantic nationalism is generally
label: Paragraph

text: a conservative response in the context of
label: Paragraph

text: the lower classes and a seemingly liberal
label: Title

text: response in the context of the upper classes.
label: Paragraph

text: The traits are clearly identifiable: passion for
label: Paragraph

text: one's country combined with a feeling—fact-
label: Paragraph

text: based or not—of past injustices at the hands
label: Title

text: of others. The past that Romantics point to is
label: Paragraph

text: often bucolic and pre-modern—a cleaned-up
label: Paragraph

text: fiction more than a reality.
label: Paragraph

text: During the 17th century, the electors of
label: Paragraph

text: Brandenburg expanded their territory so that
label: Paragraph

text: by the end of the century Prussia had grown
label: Paragraph

text: from a regional principality to a major state.
label: Paragraph

text: And with the defeat of Napoleon at Leipzig
label: Title

text: in 1813, it became an important European
label: Paragraph

text: power. Despite the difficulties with France,
label: Paragraph

text: infatuation with Napoleonic ideas led to a
label: Paragraph

text: generation of German thinkers who hoped
label: Title

text: to retool the Enlightenment to fit the German
label: Paragraph

text: context.
label: Paragraph

text: Energetic reformers, including the noted
label: Paragraph

text: scientist Wilhelm von Humboldt, head of
label: Title

text: Prussia’s department of education and arts,
label: Paragraph

text: helped transform Prussia into a progressive
label: Paragraph

text: state by abolishing serfdom and curtailing
label: Paragraph

text: the privileges of the nobility, introducing
label: Paragraph

text: agrarian and other social and economic
label: Title

text: reforms, and creating an exernplary systern
label: Paragraph

text: of universal education. Among the leading
label: Paragraph

text: literary figures in Germany at the tirne were
label: Paragraph

text: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749-1832)
label: Title

text: and Friedrich von Schiller (1759-1805),
label: Paragraph

text: who wanted to link German nationalism to
label: Paragraph

text: the ideals of ancient Greece. This gave the
label: Paragraph

text: German movement a different tenor than the
label: Paragraph

text: nationalism in France, which emphasized the
label: Paragraph

text: idealization of political institutions and social
label: Title

text: arrangements.
label: Paragraph

text: The person who gave architectural
label: Title

text: shape to Romantic neo-Greek ideals was
label: Paragraph

text: Karl Friedrich Schinkel (1781-1841). He
label: Paragraph

text: completed his training as an architect in
label: Paragraph

text: 1803 in Rome, where he met Wilhelm von
label: Paragraph

text: Humboldt, with whom he became friends. It
label: Paragraph

text: was Humboldt who helped secure Schinkel’s
label: Paragraph

text: position in the Prussian bureaucracy; one
label: Paragraph

text: of his first public projects was the design
label: Paragraph

text: of the Neue Wache, or New Guardhouse
label: Paragraph

text: (1816-18), a monument to the new citizen's
label: Caption

text: army of Prussia. Until then, the only
label: Paragraph

text: significant Neoclassical building in Berlin
label: Caption

text: was the Brandenburg Gate, inspired by the
label: Paragraph

text: Athenian Propylaea. The Neue Wache is an
label: Paragraph

text: austere building with a Doric porch flanked
label: Caption

text: by two tower bases (rather than towers) that
label: Paragraph

text: make the building appear to be a temple-
label: Paragraph

text: gate combination. The tympanum shows the
label: Paragraph

text: Goddess of Victory controlling and deciding
label: Title

text: a battle. The interior is a simple square room
label: Paragraph

text: without a dome but with a round skylight at
label: Paragraph

text: the center.
label: Paragraph

text: A few of Schinkel's other prominent works
label: Paragraph

text: included a theater, the Schauspielhaus
label: Paragraph

text: (1818-21); the Altes Museum at Berlin
label: Caption

text: (1823-30); Schloss Glienicke (completed
label: Caption

text: 1827); and the Bauakademie (1831-36).
label: Paragraph

text: No other architect in Europe, with perhaps
label: Paragraph

text: the exception of John Nash, wielded so
label: Paragraph

text: much influence. Schinkel’s most visible
label: Paragraph

text: commission was for a public art museum
label: Paragraph

text: (1822-30) sited very prominently opposite
label: Paragraph

text: the Schloss, or Royal Palace, in the very
label: Paragraph

text: heart of Berlin. Now called the Altes
label: Paragraph

text: Museum, it embodies Schinkel’s commitment
label: Paragraph

text: to monumental civic architecture as a vehicle
label: Title

text: of the Enlightenment’s cultural irnperative.
label: Paragraph

text: Though museums were beginning to appear,
label: Paragraph

text: most were refurbished palaces; the building
label: Paragraph

text: type, as an institutional element in the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: until this period art collecting had largely
label: Paragraph

text: been an aristocratic privilege. Schinkel
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: COLONIAL CALCUTTA: THE
label: Title

text: ESPLANADE
label: Title

text: While the Americans were building
label: Paragraph

text: Washington, DC, as their new federal capital,
label: Paragraph

text: and while Napoleon's armies were bringing
label: Paragraph

text: France's revolution to the rest of Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: the English began their counterproposition
label: Paragraph

text: to these movements by beginning the large-
label: Paragraph

text: scale construction of what effectively became
label: Paragraph

text: their capital in colonial India.
label: Paragraph

text: The early days of the English colonists
label: Title

text: in India were far from idyllic. Calcutta (now
label: Paragraph

text: Kolkata) was awarded to the British by
label: Paragraph

text: the Mughals because it sat on one of the
label: Paragraph

text: least desirable pieces of land—a marshy
label: Title

text: swampland. Cholera, typhoid, malaria, and
label: Paragraph

text: tuberculosis were endemic. Particularly
label: Paragraph

text: feared were the monsoons, when flooding
label: Paragraph

text: increased health risks exponentially. But the
label: Paragraph

text: deep waters of the river Hooghly enabled
label: Title

text: ocean-faring ships to travel 96 miles inland,
label: Paragraph

text: and Calcutta developed into a busy port. By
label: Paragraph

text: the 1780s the British East India Company
label: Title

text: army had become so large that only military
label: Paragraph

text: personnel were allowed to reside within the
label: Paragraph

text: fort, and new public buildings had to be
label: Paragraph

text: constructed outside the fort. A huge open
label: Paragraph

text: space was created all around the fort to
label: Paragraph

text: maintain defensive sightlines. This made the
label: Paragraph

text: avenues lining the edge of the Maidan, as
label: Paragraph

text: the open space was called, into prime sites
label: Paragraph

text: for new mercantile and civic establishments.
label: Paragraph

text: As Calcutta grew in prestige and wealth,
label: Paragraph

text: two-, three-, and even four-story mercantile
label: Paragraph

text: establishments quickly filled in the avenue’s
label: Paragraph

text: edges, creating a continuous facade around
label: Paragraph

text: the Maidan. Very visible and meant to be
label: Paragraph

text: seen, monumental loggia, pilasters, and
label: Caption

text: the occasional pedimented portico rubbed
label: Paragraph

text: shoulders with one another, as crisp, white,
label: Paragraph

text: Italianate and Neoclassical buildings lined
label: Paragraph

text: up to announce the English presence,
label: Paragraph

text: forming what was called the Esplanade.
label: Paragraph

text: Little of the Esplanade was made from
label: Paragraph

text: stone, however. Most of it was brick-based
label: Paragraph

text: indigenous construction with a generous
label: Paragraph

text: Although today the Parthenon is one of the
label: Paragraph

text: most revered ancient buildings in Europe,
label: Paragraph

text: its artistic prominence only slowly came
label: Paragraph

text: into focus during the 19th century. In 1805,
label: Paragraph

text: when Thomas Bruce, 7th Earl of Elgin,
label: Paragraph

text: who had purchased the Parthenon frieze
label: Paragraph

text: rom the Ottomans, first approached the
label: Paragraph

text: British Museum about buying the pieces,
label: Paragraph

text: @ encountered hesitation on the part of the
label: Paragraph

text: authorities. A few years later, when Charles
label: Paragraph

text: Robert Cockerell took the sculptures from
label: Paragraph

text: the temple of Aegina, the English showed
label: Paragraph

text: no interest in their purchase, and he sold
label: Paragraph

text: them to Ludwig | of Bavaria, where they now
label: Paragraph

text: form the kernel of the Glyptothek Museum in
label: Paragraph

text: Munich.
label: Paragraph

text: The fascination with Greece received
label: Title

text: a boost when hostilities ended between
label: Paragraph

text: England and France in 1814, allowing
label: Paragraph

text: Europeans to flock to Greece in
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented numbers. The country
label: Paragraph

text: came all the more alluring in the 1830s,
label: Paragraph

text: following the liberation of Greece from Turkish
label: Title

text: occupation. In 1830, England, Germany,
label: Paragraph

text: and Russia signed the London Protocol,
label: Paragraph

text: which recognized the independence of
label: Paragraph

text: Greece. The Germans and the Bavarians
label: Title

text: placed themselves in charge of the military
label: Paragraph

text: operation that eventually freed Greece from
label: Title

text: the Ottoman Empire in 1833, putting Otto
label: Paragraph

text: von Wittelsbach on the throne, his reign
label: Title

text: guaranteed by the European powers. The
label: Paragraph

text: impact of the liberation of Greece on the
label: Title

text: European consciousness was profound.
label: Paragraph

text: It breathed new life into the Neoclassical
label: Paragraph

text: movement and into Enlightenment notions
label: Title

text: about freedom and progress. As a result,
label: Paragraph

text: Neoclassicism, once associated with the
label: Paragraph

text: heavy-handed world of imperial institutions,
label: Paragraph

text: was now linked to the optimistic and
label: Paragraph

text: progressive world of bourgeois industry.
label: Paragraph

text: Neo-Greek architecture took on a more
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: trusts. As corruption again grew, the critics

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION
label: Title

text: By the second decade of the 19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization in England began to have
label: Paragraph

text: global implications. A whole new society was
label: Paragraph

text: being created, taking shape in a new type
label: Paragraph

text: of city and new types of political and power
label: Title

text: relations. Unlike the great metropolises of
label: Paragraph

text: old, factory towns like Manchester, Leeds,
label: Paragraph

text: and Liverpool were not urban to begin with.
label: Paragraph

text: There was no core of elegance—no great
label: Paragraph

text: boulevards, no parks, churches, palaces,
label: Paragraph

text: or cultural institutions. And yet these were
label: Paragraph

text: cities competing in size and population with
label: Paragraph

text: the likes of London and Paris. Manchester,
label: Caption

text: nicknamed Cottonopolis because of all its
label: Paragraph

text: cotton mills, became the second-largest
label: Paragraph

text: city in England after London. The industrial
label: Paragraph

text: city was a novel urban landscape of people,
label: Paragraph

text: traffic, and commerce—with a level of
label: Paragraph

text: squalor never witnessed before. There was no
label: Paragraph

text: urban planning; there was no sewage system;
label: Paragraph

text: and water delivery was haphazard. Typhoid
label: Paragraph

text: and tuberculosis outbreaks were common.
label: Paragraph

text: Air pollution from the foul smells of factories,
label: Paragraph

text: sewage, and slaughterhouses was a given. (In
label: Paragraph

text: London, the stench fram the Thames River
label: Title

text: was so severe that work in the Parliament
label: Paragraph

text: building, which is located right next to the
label: Paragraph

text: river, was often impossible.) The cramped
label: Paragraph

text: conditions of the workers were startling; life
label: Paragraph

text: expectancy was twenty-eight years. During
label: Paragraph

text: the Napoleonic wars, the government paid
label: Paragraph

text: little attention to these problems, and even
label: Paragraph

text: after the war, despite growing unrest, the
label: Paragraph

text: conservative Tory Party was resistant to
label: Paragraph

text: change.
label: Paragraph

text: 16.68 View of Manchester factories depicted in a painting by William Wylde in 1857
label: Caption

text: When the Whig Party gained a majority in the
label: Paragraph

text: 830 elections, things began slowly to change.
label: Paragraph

text: The Reform Bill of 1832 reapportioned city
label: Title

text: istricts to reflect changes in the population;
label: Paragraph

text: it also liberalized voting qualifications and
label: Paragraph

text: lefined the idea of democracy as we
label: Paragraph

text: understand it today, even though voting rights
label: Paragraph

text: were, for a long time, still reserved for men
label: Paragraph

text: only. The Factory Acts of the 1830s reduced
label: Paragraph

text: the hours of child labor; the Mines Act of 1842
label: Title

text: prohibited underground work for all women
label: Title

text: and for boys under the age of ten; and the
label: Paragraph

text: en Hours Act of 1847 limited the workday
label: Paragraph

text: for women and young people to ten hours.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite these improvements, factory life
label: Paragraph

text: remained dire and a major point of contention
label: Paragraph

text: and political strife. Efforts were made to control
label: Paragraph

text: sanitation. In the 1860s, Joseph Bazalgette,
label: Paragraph

text: chief engineer of the Metropolitan Board
label: Title

text: of Works, designed an extensive series of
label: Paragraph

text: underground sewerage pipes to that diverted
label: Title

text: waste downstream of the population center.
label: Paragraph

text: The modern notion of infrastructure was
label: Paragraph

text: therewith born, and the system was soon
label: Paragraph

text: expanded to include electricity and water.
label: Paragraph

text: The most important change to the
label: Paragraph

text: landscape was the emergence of the factory—
label: Paragraph

text: in particular cotton and clothing factories
label: Title

text: located near streams used drive waterwheels.

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: From the main shaft on each floor, power was
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: shafts drove the individual machines. The
label: Paragraph

text: longer the shaft, the more vulnerable it was to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: meters, which limited the overall length of the
label: Paragraph

text: mills. The problem of mechanically distributing
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 1850. The developrnent of electrically powered
label: Caption

text: machines at the end of the century allowed
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and they no longer had to be placed next to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The English ports of London and Liverpool
label: Title

text: constituted cities unto themselves. The
label: Paragraph

text: London docks at midcentury, which were
label: Paragraph

text: continually being improved and expanded,
label: Paragraph

text: employed 30,000 people. Liverpool witnessed
label: Paragraph

text: a series of expansions cementing its status
label: Paragraph

text: as a global commercial power. By the 1890s,
label: Paragraph

text: it had become the second-largest port in
label: Paragraph

text: England, after London. It now became
label: Paragraph

text: England's main slave port. Cotton, tea, rice
label: Paragraph

text: tobacco, sugar, and grain passed through
label: Paragraph

text: this port—as did immigrants. Specialized
label: Paragraph

text: docks were built to house different types
label: Paragraph

text: of merchandise, from palm oil, cocoa, and
label: Paragraph

text: cotton to ivory and timber.
label: Paragraph

text: The Albert Dock (1846) in Liverpool, built of
label: Paragraph

text: cast iron, brick, and stone with no structural
label: Paragraph

text: wood, was the first fireproof warehousing
label: Paragraph

text: system in the world. It also had the world’s
label: Paragraph

text: first hydraulic warehouse hoist system. Sited
label: Caption

text: around a rectangular basin, the inner side
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: cast-iron columns filled with masonry, with
label: Caption

text: warehouses on the floors above. Tall windows
label: Caption

text: allowed cranes to load and unload from
label: Paragraph

text: and to the floors. To make the building fully
label: Paragraph

text: fireproof, the cast-iron columns and beams
label: Paragraph

text: supported shallow brick-arched floors. At
label: Caption

text: a cost of £700,000, the Albert Dock was
label: Paragraph

text: probably the most expensive structure
label: Paragraph

text: in the world of that time. But within two
label: Paragraph

text: decades, the entrance was too small for the
label: Paragraph

text: ships, which had kept getting larger, so it

text: Panoptic Prisons
label: Title

text: As the ideas of the Enlightenment were
label: Paragraph

text: adopted in the new industrial cities of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century, the definition of criminality
label: Paragraph

text: changed considerably. In the 18th century,
label: Paragraph

text: criminals, the insane, the poor, and the
label: Title

text: indigent—all the “unwanteds”—were
label: Paragraph

text: thrown together in large halls and corridors.
label: Paragraph

text: The Lunatics Tower in Vienna (1784) was
label: Paragraph

text: nothing more than a cylindrical fortress.
label: Paragraph

text: Overcrowding, filth, and brutal conditions
label: Title

text: made them into exceptionally terrifying
label: Paragraph

text: places. In England around 1819, there were
label: Paragraph

text: 220 capital offenses, ranging from murder
label: Title

text: to stealing bread. With the Enlightenment
label: Paragraph

text: came the atternpt to refine the law, but it was
label: Paragraph

text: not so much the terror of the prisons that
label: Paragraph

text: so appalled the early 19th-century moralists
label: Paragraph

text: as the fact that humanity could, in essence,
label: Paragraph

text: be placed outside the reach of the moral
label: Paragraph

text: life. A connection had to be made between
label: Paragraph

text: the reform of the body and mind of the
label: Title

text: prisoner and the legitimacy of the state. This
label: Paragraph

text: engendered the first modern jails, such as
label: Paragraph

text: the Virginia Penitentiary (1798) by Benjamin
label: Caption

text: Latrobe and the Suffolk House of Correction
label: Title

text: in Bury St. Edmunds, England (1803), where
label: Paragraph

text: the governor's house was at the prison’s
label: Paragraph

text: center to demonstrate the new force of law
label: Title

text: that now ostensibly protected the prisoners
label: Paragraph

text: from abuse while enforcing its own code of
label: Paragraph

text: behavior.
label: Paragraph

text: 16.73 Suffolk House of Correction, Bury St. Edmunds, England
label: Caption

text: These new prisons were designed with
label: Paragraph

text: isolated cells for the inmates grouped along
label: Paragraph

text: open corridors of buildings that were like the
label: Paragraph

text: spokes of a wheel, giving rise to the name
label: Paragraph

text: panoptic prison. An exemplar of the panoptic
label: Paragraph

text: system can be found at the Eastern State
label: Paragraph

text: Penitentiary in Philadelphia (begun 1821),
label: Paragraph

text: organized according to a philosophy set out
label: Paragraph

text: by the Pennsylvania Quakers that presumed
label: Paragraph

text: that isolation would promote monastic self-
label: Paragraph

text: reflection. Prisoners lived in a cell and could
label: Paragraph

text: go outside into a small private courtyard.
label: Paragraph

text: They were allowed out only for infrequent
label: Paragraph

text: baths or medical emergencies. Visits were
label: Paragraph

text: permitted only from officials. Masks and the
label: Paragraph

text: use of numbers rather than names ensured
label: Title

text: anonymity if inmates had to be removed
label: Paragraph

text: from their cells. Even the sewer pipes were
label: Paragraph

text: arranged to prevent communication frorn
label: Paragraph

text: wn
label: Title

text: cell to cell. All the while, the prisoner's every
label: Paragraph

text: movement was observed, either through
label: Paragraph

text: the corridor or from the towers during
label: Paragraph

text: exercises. Prisoners who were able were
label: Paragraph

text: allowed to choose to perfect a few skills,
label: Paragraph

text: such as shoemaking, basket-weaving, and
label: Paragraph

text: broom-making; it was thought that these
label: Paragraph

text: humble activities would reconnect them
label: Paragraph

text: with the principle that service to society
label: Paragraph

text: was the primary reason for existence. This
label: Paragraph

text: systern was much admired despite the fact
label: Paragraph

text: that it soon became obvious that quite a few
label: Paragraph

text: inmates went insane. Its English equivalent,
label: Paragraph

text: the Pentonville Prison in London (1844),
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Jeremy Bentham, had five
label: Paragraph

text: radiating arms extending from a central hall,
label: Paragraph

text: from which the prisoners could be observed.
label: Paragraph

text: Pentonville became the most copied prison in
label: Paragraph

text: the world.

text: The growing dissatisfaction with the grand
label: Title

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: and scientists who would tame the forces
label: Paragraph

text: of industrialization by means of a rational
label: Title

text: Christian humanism. Though Saint-Simon
label: Paragraph

text: had adherents in Europe and even influenced
label: Paragraph

text: the thinking of Karl Marx, his rmovement to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: reaching its height around 1840. Why? Many
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: England, France, Germany, and Scandinavia.
label: Paragraph

text: For most, the ideal was a small tidy village
label: Paragraph

text: with a range of craft industries.

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: ENGLISH PARLIAMENT BUILDING
label: Title

text: It is perhaps not coincidental that the two
label: Paragraph

text: most important architectural theoretical works
label: Title

text: of the time came not from secularists but
label: Paragraph

text: from secularism's—and industrialism’s—
label: Title

text: critics: Marc-Antoine Laugier and August
label: Title

text: Welby Pugin (1812-52). Pugin’s father,
label: Paragraph

text: August Charles, Comte de Pugin, fled France
label: Title

text: during the revolution and, as an authority on
label: Paragraph

text: the Gothic style, took up work in the office
label: Paragraph

text: of John Nash, who had to accommodate the
label: Paragraph

text: growing demand for Gothic-style architecture
label: Title

text: even though he personally found it
label: Paragraph

text: troublesome. The younger Pugin was already
label: Paragraph

text: saturated in Gothic architecture and had even
label: Paragraph

text: converted to Catholicism as the only true
label: Paragraph

text: religion. With little hope for a cornmission,
label: Paragraph

text: he set about writing Contrasts, which he
label: Paragraph

text: published in 1836 at his own expense
label: Paragraph

text: because no publisher would agree to put
label: Paragraph

text: out such an explosive work. The book made
label: Paragraph

text: his reputation, and soon commissions for
label: Paragraph

text: chapels, churches, and even private houses
label: Paragraph

text: came his way. “The history of architecture
label: Paragraph

text: is the history of the world,” he wrote, and,
label: Paragraph

text: turning to the work of his own day, he asked
label: Paragraph

text: whether “the architecture of our times, even
label: Paragraph

text: supposing it solid enough to last, handl[s.
label: Paragraph

text: down to posterity any certain clue or guide
label: Title

text: to the system under which it was erected?
label: Paragraph

text: Surely not.... It is a confused jumble of
label: Paragraph

text: styles and symbols borrowed from all nations
label: Title

text: and periods.” At stake was not just a style,
label: Paragraph

text: he believed, but the history of civilization.
label: Paragraph

text: Industrialism, greed, and secularism hai
label: Title

text: isolated man from his fellow man.
label: Paragraph

text: Contrasts set the tone for a critique o
label: Paragraph

text: industrialism that focused not on repairing
label: Paragraph

text: the inequities that it precipitated by means
label: Paragraph

text: of law and politics, but by proposing a
label: Paragraph

text: quasi-utopian alternative—one harkening
label: Title

text: back to the Middle Ages, for Pugin a time
label: Paragraph

text: during which a vibrant social conscience had
label: Paragraph

text: existed that he felt had since been lost. The
label: Paragraph

text: architect, he argued, should therefore not just
label: Paragraph

text: adopt any style the client wanted. That would
label: Paragraph

text: be equivalent to encorsing the arbitrariness
label: Paragraph

text: of the modern world. Contrasts has a plate
label: Paragraph

text: showing a town as Pugin imagined it in 1440,
label: Paragraph

text: and another one showing it again in 1840.
label: Paragraph

text: The former portrays a coherent city with
label: Paragraph

text: intact walls and a church in the foreground;
label: Caption

label: Caption

label: Caption

text: the latter shows a cluttered river, a jumble
label: Paragraph

text: of church spires and smokestacks, and
label: Paragraph

text: in the foreground a prison; the church
label: Caption

text: is still there but now overgrown and
label: Paragraph

text: neglected. It was an accusation against
label: Paragraph

text: rationalism that remains embedded in
label: Paragraph

text: the image of modernity to this day, easily
label: Paragraph

text: retrieved by those who see modern life as
label: Paragraph

text: a downward spiral into ethical and moral
label: Title

text: decline. Architecture had to be based on
label: Paragraph

text: principles (and in this he was the child of
label: Paragraph

text: the Enlightenment), including the use of
label: Paragraph

text: local materials in accordance with local
label: Paragraph

text: traditions. This was what made “true”
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic different from what he saw as the
label: Paragraph

text: shallow Gothic of Horace Walpole or, worse,
label: Paragraph

text: the cald rationalism of the Neoclassicists.
label: Paragraph

text: Only Gothic, he argued, could provide the
label: Paragraph

text: moral compass that one should expect from
label: Paragraph

text: a Christian society.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite Pugin’s conservatism, he should
label: Paragraph

text: not be seen as naively antimodern. His
label: Paragraph

text: convictions in respect to regional traditions
label: Title

text: and local climate, as well as his belief in
label: Paragraph

text: “honest” construction, were all taken up
label: Paragraph

text: by modernists once the Gothic imperative
label: Paragraph

text: had played itself out. One of his arguments
label: Paragraph

text: against Italianate architecture was that it did
label: Paragraph

text: not suit England. A building, he maintained,
label: Paragraph

text: had to show its various purposes, and this led
label: Paragraph

text: to an appreciation for asymmetry and to an
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on articulating the differing parts
label: Title

text: of a building, an argument that modernists
label: Paragraph

text: would later take up as well.
label: Paragraph

text: It was because of this growing confidence
label: Paragraph

text: in the legitimacy of the neo-Gothic as a
label: Paragraph

text: genuinely English format that, after the old
label: Paragraph

text: palace at Westminster burned in 1834, a
label: Paragraph

text: parliamentary committee decided to rebuild
label: Title

text: in the Gothic style. Two hundred years earlier,
label: Paragraph

text: a similar body had decided to rebuild old St.
label: Paragraph

text: Paul’s in the Neoclassical style.
label: Paragraph

text: A competition for the commission for the
label: Title

text: new Parliament building was announced; it
label: Paragraph

text: was eventually given to Charles Barry, who
label: Paragraph

text: worked closely with Pugin. Few can deny the
label: Paragraph

text: brilliance of the plan, with its lucid hierarchies
label: Paragraph

text: that differentiate between public and private

text: areas and the grandeur of the approaches
label: Title

text: to the great octagonal hall that separates

text: the House of Lords to the north from the
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: building, was buffered by a number of open-
label: Paragraph

text: air courts that allowed light into the various
label: Paragraph

text: rooms. Offices, libraries, and meeting rooms
label: Paragraph

text: were lined up along the principal facade
label: Paragraph

text: toward the river. The exterior-—done almost
label: Paragraph

text: uniformly in a soft, yellowish limestone—
label: Paragraph

text: was designed in a Perpendicular Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: style that replicated the taste of the 15th
label: Paragraph

text: century. Despite the monotone treatment of
label: Paragraph

text: the building's external mass, Barry was able
label: Paragraph

text: to introduce picturesque elements to the
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: of the vertical elements—the Victoria Tower,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the spectacular Big Ben, Parliament’s now-
label: Paragraph

text: jamous clock tower. The debates that swirled
label: Paragraph

text: around this building concerning the role and
label: Paragraph

text: purpose of architecture were remarkable. The
label: Paragraph

text: istory of modern architecture is intertwined
label: Paragraph

text: with the history of polemics, beginning with
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Perrault's attack on beauty, carried
label: Paragraph

text: forth by Marc-Antoine Laugier’s attack on the
label: Paragraph

text: classical orders, and extended into the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century by Pugin, the greatest defender of
label: Paragraph

text: the Gothic at the time, who envisioned the
label: Paragraph

text: uilding as a showcase of the Gothic style, a
label: Paragraph

text: moral and aesthetic exemplar. Neoclassicism,
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The mid-19th century saw the rapid
label: Paragraph

text: expansion of the middle class, the fitful
label: Title

text: demise of the influence of the landed gentry,
label: Paragraph

text: and the rise of a professional class. The
label: Paragraph

text: Geological Society upgraded its membership
label: Title

text: from the “interested” gentry to one based
label: Title

text: on merit and scholarly accomplishment.
label: Paragraph

text: Arguments that fossils were planted in the
label: Paragraph

text: ground by God, still a viable theory in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1830s, were no longer accepted in 1850.
label: Paragraph

text: In architecture a similar revolution was
label: Paragraph

text: taking place, led by a generation of theorists
label: Paragraph

text: that included Eugene-Emmanuel Viollet-le-
label: Paragraph

text: Duc (1814-79) in France, Gottfried Semper
label: Paragraph

text: (1803-79) in Germany, and John Ruskin
label: Paragraph

text: (1819-1900) in England. Though different
label: Paragraph

text: in many respects, each tried to rethink the
label: Paragraph

text: principles of rationalism and technology, and
label: Paragraph

text: all were writing at the same time. Ruskin's
label: Paragraph

text: Stones of Venice appeared first in 1851, on
label: Paragraph

text: the same date as Semper’s Die vier Elemente
label: Paragraph

text: der Baukunst. Viollet-le-Duc’s Dictionnaire
label: Caption

text: raisonné de larchitecture francaise du Xle au
label: Title

text: XVe siécle, which was published in several
label: Paragraph

text: editions, first appeared in 1854. Without
label: Paragraph

text: doubt, the period represented a turning point
label: Paragraph

text: in architectural discourse. Viollet-le-Duc was
label: Paragraph

text: a strong advocate of the modern material
label: Paragraph

text: of iron. Unlike other architects of his time,
label: Paragraph

text: who were giving cast iron a Gothic flavor to
label: Paragraph

text: appease the demands of the followers of
label: Paragraph

text: 16.83 Oriel Chambers, Liverpool, England
label: Caption

text: August Welby Pugin, Viollet-le-Duc made no
label: Caption

text: such demand.
label: Paragraph

text: Neither was he advocating the
label: Paragraph

text: technological rationalism of Sir Joseph
label: Title

text: Paxton in the Crystal Palace in London. Cast
label: Caption

text: iron, and then iron, had emerged relatively
label: Paragraph

text: quickly on the architectural scene, but
label: Paragraph

text: the application proper to its aesthetic was
label: Paragraph

text: not yet obvious to mid-century architects.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 17th and 18th centuries, Baroque
label: Paragraph

text: architects, because of the large domes
label: Paragraph

text: and complex lighting effects, operated in a
label: Paragraph

text: realm between architecture and technology.
label: Paragraph

text: Neoclassicism, with its emphasis on image,
label: Paragraph

text: made significantly fewer technical demands
label: Paragraph

text: on the architect. But with the introduction
label: Paragraph

text: of cast iron, that changed rapidly. The
label: Paragraph

text: catalogues of architectural components
label: Title

text: published by the design offices of British
label: Caption

text: foundries began to grow thicker, and it was
label: Paragraph

text: a short step from adding cast-iron balconies
label: Paragraph

text: (excellent examples of which abound in the
label: Paragraph

text: French Quarter of New Orleans, Louisiana) to
label: Paragraph

text: designing entire houses and structures out of
label: Paragraph

text: cast iron.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1850 some were arguing for a
label: Paragraph

text: congruence between material and form,
label: Paragraph

text: as can be seen in the remarkable Oriel
label: Paragraph

text: Chambers (1864) in Liverpool, England, by
label: Caption

text: the architect Peter Ellis. The thin cast-iron
label: Caption

text: frame holds glazed bay windows with no
label: Caption

text: concession to ornamentation. At the time, it
label: Paragraph

text: was not well received; architects preferred to
label: Paragraph

text: use cast iron mainly for floor supports. In that
label: Paragraph

text: sense, the general approach of Quatremére
label: Paragraph

text: de Quincy, who taught at the Ecole des
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts, still prevailed. He critiqued the
label: Paragraph

text: use of exposed iron in anything other than
label: Paragraph

text: industrial buildings, setting a tone with long-
label: Paragraph

text: lasting consequences. Iron received strong
label: Paragraph

text: support, however, from the Romantics,
label: Paragraph

text: who saw it as an opportunity to escape
label: Paragraph

text: the strictures of the classical orders and
label: Paragraph

text: to introduce a more local or regional flavor
label: Paragraph

text: to architecture. Viollet-le-Duc tried to hold
label: Paragraph

text: a middle ground, arguing against both the
label: Paragraph

text: academy, with its Neoclassical allegiances,
label: Paragraph

text: and the autonomy of rational engineering.
label: Paragraph

text: For him, rationalism was a question not of
label: Paragraph

text: numbers and efficiency but of style—a style
label: Title

text: that emerged from a thorough familiarity with
label: Paragraph

text: the history of architecture and with the visual
label: Title

text: and functional needs of the program.
label: Paragraph

text: Viollet-le-Duc's approach is best
label: Paragraph

text: exemplified in his design for an iron armature
label: Paragraph

text: for a concert hall (1886), which even today
label: Paragraph

text: strikes one as astonishing. Using the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: a buttress but inverting it and placing it on
label: Paragraph

text: the inside instead of the outside, he holds
label: Paragraph

text: up a steel frame that in turn supports a thin
label: Paragraph

text: masonry roof.

text: ARCHITECTURAL PRESERVATION
label: Title

text: Today, architectural preservation is a major
label: Paragraph

text: part of the architectural profession, but
label: Paragraph

text: that was not always the case. Medievalists
label: Paragraph

text: were especially concerned about the bad
label: Paragraph

text: conditions many cathedrals were in, and the
label: Paragraph

text: first preservation efforts were concerned with
label: Paragraph

text: medieval buildings. Viollet-le-Duc played a
label: Paragraph

text: large part in this movement, having been
label: Paragraph

text: asked in 1835 to restore the Romanesque
label: Paragraph

text: Abbey of Vézelay in France. This led to
label: Paragraph

text: restorations at Notre-Dame in Paris, Mont
label: Caption

text: St.-Michel in Normandy, and the town of
label: Paragraph

text: Carcassone in Provence. Whereas John
label: Paragraph

text: Ruskin advocated a restoration that preserved
label: Paragraph

text: only the building's status quo, Viollet-le-
label: Paragraph

text: Duc advocated a more aggressive form of
label: Paragraph

text: preservation that included the possibility of
label: Paragraph

text: rebuilding and even extending a building in
label: Paragraph

text: the same stylistic manner. At Carcassone,
label: Paragraph

text: the high-pitched roofs and the Cathedral of
label: Paragraph

text: Vézelay are basically his designs. In France,
label: Paragraph

text: many cathedrals had been damaged during
label: Paragraph

text: the French Revolution or had fallen into
label: Paragraph

text: disrepair. On some buildings, Baroque and
label: Paragraph

text: Neoclassical additions had been added.
label: Paragraph

text: In dealing with such complex situations—
label: Paragraph

text: and given that a medieval church might
label: Paragraph

text: have taken centuries to complete and thus
label: Paragraph

text: exhibited numerous styles—his approach
label: Paragraph

text: was not to pick a particular time and restore
label: Paragraph

text: it to that moment, but rather to synthesize
label: Paragraph

text: the building and make the restoration a
label: Paragraph

text: completion. This put a lot of power in the
label: Paragraph

text: hands of the designer; the final result might
label: Paragraph

text: have been a building that could never have
label: Paragraph

text: existed prior to that moment. To advance his
label: Paragraph

text: cause, Viollet-le-Duc made extensive studies
label: Paragraph

text: of medieval building practices—not only
label: Paragraph

text: so that the restoration could be accurate,
label: Paragraph

text: but also to show how this knowledge could
label: Paragraph

text: ensure the conceptual and perceived
label: Paragraph

text: authenticity of the new parts of the building.

text: Among those who argued in favor of the

text: (designed 1843, built 1845-51), with its

text: slender columns and billowing domes,
label: Paragraph

text: coexists with stone walls, themselves without
label: Paragraph

text: any trace of classical columns and pilasters.
label: Paragraph

text: The distinction between the two floors is
label: Paragraph

text: made on the outside by a thin entablature,
label: Paragraph

text: with a continuous row of garlands suspended
label: Paragraph

text: beneath it. Below, the wall is punctuated by
label: Paragraph

text: relatively small, Romanesque-style round-
label: Paragraph

text: headed windows. Above, from end to end,
label: Caption

text: runs an arcade, with pilasters forming a
label: Paragraph

text: regular rhythm across the facade; it is
label: Paragraph

text: distinctly Roman in flavor. The lower two
label: Paragraph

text: thirds of the arcade are filled in to allow for
label: Paragraph

text: a window in each bay. The whole is topped
label: Paragraph

text: by a stripped-down cornice, lightly decorated
label: Caption

text: in a neo-Greek manner. The building thus
label: Paragraph

text: makes numerous historical references, but is
label: Paragraph

text: in no way historicist. Labrouste attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: create an idiom that, through its reductivist
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic, could demonstrate a fluid
label: Paragraph

text: connection between the old and the modern.

label: Paragraph

text: the end bolts of the tie rods with round

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: shelves within.

label: Caption

text: QIANLONG’S UNIVERSAL VISION
label: Title

text: Though China increased its export of tea
label: Paragraph

text: by more than 50 percent in the first third
label: Paragraph

text: of the 19th century and quadrupled its
label: Paragraph

text: silk exports, Chinese traders showed little
label: Paragraph

text: interest in European merchandise. Indeed,
label: Paragraph

text: they demanded hard currency payment in
label: Paragraph

text: silver. The result of this asyrnmetrical trade
label: Paragraph

text: relationship was that by 1800, almost half of
label: Paragraph

text: the Spanish silver mined in America ended
label: Paragraph

text: up in Chinese coffers. England, meanwhile,
label: Paragraph

text: was having serious financial problems and
label: Paragraph

text: began to force Chinese traders to accept
label: Paragraph

text: opium in exchange for tea, a policy they
label: Paragraph

text: pursued so relentlessly that by the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century, the Chinese economy went into
label: Paragraph

text: a long-lasting tailspin. This is arguably one
label: Paragraph

text: of the great civilizational tragedies created by
label: Paragraph

text: European colonialism.
label: Paragraph

text: Back in the 18th century, the eventual
label: Paragraph

text: reversal of China's fate would not have been
label: Paragraph

text: conceivable. At that time, China under the
label: Paragraph

text: Qianlong Emperor (r. 1736-96) was the
label: Paragraph

text: largest and richest empire in the world, and
label: Paragraph

text: from the Chinese perspective, trade with the
label: Paragraph

text: new European mercantile world had to be
label: Title

text: severely regulated to minimize disruption.
label: Paragraph

text: Qianlong saw himself as a pan-Asian
label: Paragraph

text: emperor, not dissimilar to his contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleon Bonaparte, who pursued a pan-
label: Paragraph

text: Canton (Guangzhou)
label: Title

text: European ideal. And like Napoleon, he
label: Paragraph

text: was a military cormmander of great skill. In
label: Paragraph

text: Qingyi Garden
label: Title

text: One of Qianlong's additions was a new
label: Paragraph

text: garden, originally called Qingyi Garden
label: Paragraph

text: (1750-64) and now known as the Summer
label: Paragraph

text: Palace. It was designed as a series of palaces
label: Paragraph

text: and pavilions around a large oval lake that
label: Paragraph

text: is separated from two smaller lakes by long
label: Paragraph

text: narrow islands. A stroll path goes around the
label: Paragraph

text: lake and across all the small islands. In the
label: Paragraph

text: middle of the main lake is a small artificial
label: Paragraph

text: island, connected to the edge on the east by a
label: Paragraph

text: long, arched, graceful bridge. The north edge
label: Paragraph

text: of the lake is dominated by a huge palace and
label: Paragraph

text: a Buddhist shrine complex, raised high on a
label: Paragraph

text: solid stone platform, on axis with the central
label: Caption

text: island. In the west, the horizon is filled with a
label: Paragraph

text: series of long mountains with distinct peaks. A
label: Paragraph

text: pagoda and several pavilions were built on the
label: Paragraph

text: crests of the peaks.
label: Paragraph

text: Chinese gardens were intended to evoke
label: Paragraph

text: the order of nature distilled to its essence. The
label: Paragraph

text: design skill lay in ensuring that every element
label: Paragraph

text: functioned in a way that was harmonious
label: Paragraph

text: with the whole from the perspective of
label: Paragraph

text: viewing sites along the strolling paths. A
label: Paragraph

text: garden's quality was described as a function
label: Paragraph

text: of its scenic spots, which were thought of
label: Paragraph

text: as embodied poems and three-dimensional
label: Title

text: paintings. Symmetry was abhorred.
label: Paragraph

text: At the same time, all the expectations
label: Paragraph

text: and conveniences of a royal palace and
label: Paragraph

text: seat of government were to be fulfilled.
label: Paragraph

text: There are three palpable visual foci at the
label: Paragraph

text: Summer Palace: the island in the middle of
label: Title

text: the lake, the Buddhist shrine at the northern
label: Paragraph

text: edge, and the tall pagoda on the hills in the
label: Paragraph

text: west. Although the Buddhist shrine is the
label: Paragraph

text: largest element, the island is in the middle
label: Paragraph

text: and constantly attracts the eye. Yet while
label: Paragraph

text: walking around, the pagoda in the distance
label: Paragraph

text: always remains in view, becoming the best-
label: Paragraph

text: remembered part of the garden.
label: Paragraph

text: The compositional ideas were derived
label: Paragraph

text: from principles described in texts such as
label: Paragraph

text: the Ji Cheng’s Yuan Zhi (“Gardening”),
label: Paragraph

text: written in the early 17th century. Ji Cheng
label: Caption

text: invoked design concepts such as “suitability,”
label: Paragraph

text: “refinement,” “simplicity,” and “changeability
label: Paragraph

text: or unexpectedness,” which were to be used
label: Paragraph

text: to create places that have qualities such as
label: Paragraph

text: “the real and the false,” “assembling and
label: Paragraph

text: spreading,” “unevenness and neatness,”
label: Paragraph

text: “connecting and separating,” “open and
label: Paragraph

text: closed,” and “level and solid.”
