text: SYNAGOGUES
label: Title

text: Until the end of the 15th century, most Jews
label: Paragraph

text: lived within the footprint of the old Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Empire, whether in Trastevere in Rome, in
label: Paragraph

text: Spain, or in Thessalonica in Greece. This
label: Paragraph

text: was the result of the great diaspora imposed
label: Paragraph

text: on the Jews by the Ronan emperor Titus,
label: Paragraph

text: after his victory over the Jews and the
label: Paragraph

text: destruction of the Second Temple in 70 CE.
label: Paragraph

text: Beginning with the Christian era, restrictions
label: Paragraph

text: were imposed on Jews wherever they lived.
label: Paragraph

text: hey were not allowed to own land and were
label: Paragraph

text: excluded from affairs of the military, thus
label: Paragraph

text: denying them access to aristocratic privileges.
label: Paragraph

text: Since banking was one of the few trades
label: Paragraph

text: they were permitted to engage in, Jews were
label: Paragraph

text: able to create a network that transcended
label: Paragraph

text: local rivalries, and in that capacity were often
label: Paragraph

text: protected by kings and princes, who used
label: Paragraph

text: them as private bankers. In Venice, Jews
label: Paragraph

text: were allowed to come to the city principally
label: Paragraph

text: because of their banking associations. They
label: Paragraph

text: were assigned to live in an area known as
label: Paragraph

text: the ghetto, a term from then on used to
label: Paragraph

text: designate where Jews were required to live.
label: Paragraph

text: An exception was in Lithuania, where, frorn
label: Paragraph

text: 316 onward, Jews had a surprising amount
label: Paragraph

text: of freedom.
label: Paragraph

text: With their expulsion by the Spanish in
label: Paragraph

text: 1492 and by the Portuguese in 1496,
label: Paragraph

text: the Sephardic Jews were forced to seek
label: Paragraph

text: sanctuary in Poland, Amsterdam, Venice,
label: Caption

text: Greece, Istanbul, and even Rome. In
label: Paragraph

text: Amsterdam, a Sephardic synagogue was
label: Paragraph

text: built in 1675 that has remained largely
label: Paragraph

text: unchanged, and is today one of the few
label: Paragraph

text: tangible remnants of Amsterdam's once-
label: Paragraph

text: thriving Jewish community. It is a large
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular brick building, with large round-
label: Paragraph

text: headed windows on all sides that emphasize
label: Paragraph

text: its vast interior space. It became the model
label: Paragraph

text: for several later synagogues, including
label: Paragraph

text: the Bevis-Marks Synagogue in London
label: Caption

text: {1700) and the smaller Touro Synagogue
label: Title

text: in Newport, Rhode Island, the oldest
label: Paragraph

text: synagogue in the United States. Jewish life
label: Title

text: in Germany improved slightly in the 18th
label: Paragraph

text: century when courts invited Jews to come
label: Title

text: and serve as financial agents. In 1714, King
label: Paragraph

text: Frederick William | of Prussia permitted the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of a synagogue in Berlin.
label: Paragraph

text: The fate of Jews significantly improved
label: Paragraph

text: under Napoleon, who passed a number of
label: Paragraph

text: measures supporting the position of Jews in
label: Paragraph

text: the French Empire and Austria—and, just
label: Paragraph

text: as importantly, in conquered countries. He
label: Paragraph

text: abolished laws restricting Jews to ghettos
label: Title

text: or to certain professions. In 1797 when he
label: Paragraph

text: invaded Italy, he threw open the gates to the
label: Paragraph

text: ghettos. In 1807, like his conternporary Qing
label: Paragraph

text: emperors of China, he sanctioned several
label: Paragraph

text: religions as “official”—a first for a European
label: Paragraph

text: ruler; these included Judaism, Roman
label: Paragraph

text: Catholicism, Lutheranism, and Calvinism.
label: Paragraph

text: As a result of Napoleon's initiatives, Jews in
label: Paragraph

text: other lands sought and eventually received
label: Paragraph

text: emancipation in Germany in 1848, in Great
label: Paragraph

text: Britain in 1890, in Russia in 1917, and finally
label: Paragraph

text: in Spain in 1930.
label: Paragraph

text: The response by Jews to German
label: Title

text: emancipation was a building boom of
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented proportion. During the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century, more than two hundred
label: Paragraph

text: large synagogues were built. It would be
label: Paragraph

text: shortsighted to see synagogue architecture
label: Title

text: as part of the general European trend
label: Paragraph

text: toward eclecticism. Synagogue eclecticism
label: Title

text: was a direct response to the new freedom
label: Paragraph

text: from restrictions on what could be built.
label: Paragraph

text: Furthermore, most of the architects were
label: Paragraph

text: non-Jews who brought their own, often
label: Paragraph

text: romanticized, expectations of what a Jewish
label: Paragraph

text: space should look like. Gottfried Semper
label: Paragraph

text: (1803-79) designed a synagogue in Dresden
label: Paragraph

text: (1840) that was on its exterior Carolingian-
label: Paragraph

text: Romanesque, presumably to emphasize the
label: Paragraph

text: aspirations of assimilation, but on the inside
label: Paragraph

text: there was an order of columns with deep
label: Paragraph

text: impost blocks copied from the Alhambra at
label: Paragraph

text: Granada.
label: Paragraph

text: The emergence of the Reform Judaism,
label: Paragraph

text: intended to appeal to urban Jews, had
label: Paragraph

text: a major influence on synagogue design.
label: Paragraph

text: Reform Jews stressed the universal teachings
label: Paragraph

text: of Judaism but also sought to modernize
label: Paragraph

text: rituals that were difficult to maintain in a
label: Paragraph

text: modern world. Reform Jews held that Jewish
label: Paragraph

text: people were not in a state of permanent
label: Paragraph

text: exile but were contributing members of their
label: Paragraph

text: community and nation. They considered
label: Paragraph

text: every house of worship a temple, as holy
label: Paragraph

text: as the original temple in Jerusalem. Pews
label: Caption

text: were permitted, and prayer was in German.
label: Paragraph

text: The organ was introduced. The first Reform
label: Paragraph

text: synagogue was opened in Seesen in central
label: Paragraph

text: Germany in 1810 and was called a “temple,”
label: Paragraph

text: in keeping with Enlightenment ideals. Some
label: Paragraph

text: synagogues took up the classical theme and
label: Paragraph

text: were designed almost literally as temples,
label: Paragraph

text: as in the Seitenstettengasse Synagogue
label: Paragraph

text: in Vienna (1826) and the Beth Elohim
label: Paragraph

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: As the 198th century wore on, the forms,
label: Paragraph

text: institutions, and modes of representation that
label: Paragraph

text: can be retrospectively identified as being
label: Paragraph

text: modern or modernist eventually started to
label: Paragraph

text: coalesce. But that was a long time coming.
label: Paragraph

text: By the middle of the 19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: the new nation-states of Europe and the
label: Title

text: Americas were jockeying with each other
label: Paragraph

text: to envision and establish the institutions
label: Paragraph

text: and the accompanying social, political,
label: Paragraph

text: and economic practices of modernity. The
label: Paragraph

text: burgeoning colonial industrial economy
label: Title

text: fueled slow but steady growth. British
label: Paragraph

text: supremacy on the sea continued to flourish,
label: Paragraph

text: and by the end of the century England was
label: Paragraph

text: the dominant global force, controlling land
label: Paragraph

text: all around the world. As other European
label: Paragraph

text: nations scrambled to compete with the
label: Paragraph

text: English, the rest of the world began to adapt
label: Paragraph

text: to, and challenge, the new global imperatives
label: Paragraph

text: of the colonial world. At the same time,
label: Paragraph

text: the social costs of industrial concentration
label: Title

text: became more apparent—devastation of old
label: Paragraph

text: rural economies; development of massive,
label: Paragraph

text: subsistence-level working classes; and rapid
label: Paragraph

text: growth in urban populations—creating cities
label: Title

text: that were woefully underprepared to deliver
label: Paragraph

text: the services that were suddenly expected
label: Paragraph

text: of them. The consequent urban upheavals,
label: Paragraph

text: accompanied by a chorus of criticism from
label: Paragraph

text: the likes of as Ruskin, Morris, Marx, and
label: Paragraph

text: Engels, were met with the establishment of
label: Paragraph

text: a series of new urban institutions designed
label: Paragraph

text: to cope with the new city. For the first time,
label: Paragraph

text: what we now recognize as public-sector
label: Paragraph

text: works—such as hospitals, fire stations,
label: Paragraph

text: law courts, and the like—were undertaken
label: Paragraph

text: by European municipal bodies. Soon,
label: Paragraph

text: these bodies began also to take pride in
label: Paragraph

text: their work and in their cities and began
label: Paragraph

text: to build larger public works that sought to
label: Paragraph

text: establish the identity of the city as a civic
label: Paragraph

text: space. Particularly celebrated were railroad
label: Paragraph

text: stations that moved the people and goods
label: Title

text: necessary to the new economy; law courts
label: Title

text: that signified the new, more public-minded
label: Paragraph

text: jurisprudence of the city; and museums that
label: Paragraph

text: catered to new conceptions of an educated
label: Paragraph

text: citizenry. New public societies that debated
label: Paragraph

text: the meaning of the public, such as libraries
label: Paragraph

text: and athenaeums, began to be established;
label: Paragraph

text: and as the ultimate democratic civic space
label: Title

text: accessible to all, the large urban park in the
label: Paragraph

text: midst of the city became a central part of the
label: Paragraph

text: urban experience. This was especially true
label: Paragraph

text: in the United States, spearheaded by the
label: Paragraph

text: creation of Central Park in Manhattan in the
label: Paragraph

text: 1850s, designed by the landscape architect
label: Paragraph

text: Frederick Law Olmsted in collaboration with
label: Paragraph

text: Calvert Vaux, a European-trained architect.
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park, former site of immigrant slums
label: Caption

text: and squatter settlements, soon came to
label: Paragraph

text: embody the idea of massive public works as
label: Paragraph

text: the signature mark of a prosperous city, even
label: Paragraph

text: though it would still take more than half a
label: Paragraph

text: century before the park was fully established
label: Paragraph

text: as the heart of the city.
label: Paragraph

text: In terms of architectural expression, the
label: Paragraph

text: 18th-century Enlightenment ideal—which
label: Paragraph

text: held up a restatement of the Greco-Roman
label: Paragraph

text: classical ideal as the specific European
label: Title

text: heritage that best expressed the new
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: The Victorian era on the whole was still tied
label: Paragraph

text: to the Picturesque ideal that architecture had
label: Paragraph

text: to be linked creatively to the past in order
label: Paragraph

text: to dignify the present. But the Victorians
label: Paragraph

text: tended to be less attached to the purity
label: Paragraph

text: of Roman or Greek prototypes than the
label: Paragraph

text: generation of Robert Adam and John Nash.
label: Paragraph

text: They experimented with historical styles that
label: Paragraph

text: resonated with the increased archaeological
label: Paragraph

text: erudition of the time and with the diverse
label: Title

text: philosophical persuasions of their clientele.
label: Paragraph

text: George Edmund Street (1824-81), who
label: Paragraph

text: designed the London Law Courts (1870-81),
label: Paragraph

text: for example, used an early medieval style,
label: Paragraph

text: not August Welby Pugin’s high Gothic.
label: Paragraph

text: Street chose this style for its more stern and
label: Paragraph

text: primitive associations. He and many of the
label: Paragraph

text: young architects of the time were enthralled
label: Paragraph

text: with the ideals of Gallic toughness. What
label: Paragraph

text: today might be seen as medieval, they saw
label: Paragraph

text: as Saxon. The Saxons were not known
label: Paragraph

text: for their architectural accomplishments,
label: Paragraph

text: however, and here the added problem is that
label: Paragraph

text: the precedents are more Franco-Norman
label: Paragraph

text: than English.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and mirrored the new and expanded horizons
label: Title

text: of law. It had eighteen courtrooms, two of
label: Paragraph

text: them larger than the others for the more
label: Paragraph

text: prominent trials. A private corridor for the
label: Paragraph

text: bar circled the building between the courts
label: Paragraph

text: and the central hall. Judges were provided

text: For most people in England and Europe,

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: and exchange, these buildings were not

text: only marvels of engineering but also new
label: Title

text: and imposing additions to the urban
label: Paragraph

text: environment. Civil engineers began to
label: Paragraph

text: compete with architects as arbiters of taste.
label: Paragraph

text: St. Pancras Station in London (1863-76),
label: Paragraph

text: for example, contained a volume of space
label: Paragraph

text: within its 80-meter span that defied anything
label: Paragraph

text: architecture could have striven for previously.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: France, the United States, and even in

text: the colonies, such as Victoria Terminus in
label: Paragraph

text: Mumbai (1888), had becorne the symbol of

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: steam engines. Many of these peripheral

label: Title

text: into urban hubs in their own right, with
label: Paragraph

text: boulevards and rectangular urban blocks.

text: THE ATHENAEUM
label: Title

text: By the turn of the century, the idea of
label: Paragraph

text: associations—citizens coming together
label: Title

text: around a particular set of common
label: Paragraph

text: interests—had become a social movement
label: Paragraph

text: unto itself, reaching into the middle class.
label: Paragraph

text: The theoretical underpinnings of this
label: Paragraph

text: development can be found in the writing of
label: Paragraph

text: Alexis de Tocqueville (1805-59), the French
label: Paragraph

text: philosopher and social scientist. He argued
label: Paragraph

text: that associations were an important part of
label: Paragraph

text: a healthy civil society. Given the contrary
label: Paragraph

text: propensity for isolation in the modern world,
label: Paragraph

text: society needed to be bound together, he
label: Paragraph

text: argued, not through the abstract authority of
label: Paragraph

text: the state but through voluntary associations,
label: Paragraph

text: educational institutions, newspapers,
label: Title

text: and even commercial and manufacturing
label: Title

text: associations.
label: Paragraph

text: Building on the older mercantile culture
label: Title

text: of coffeehouses, the new associations of
label: Paragraph

text: the 19th century tended to be pro-urban,
label: Paragraph

text: seeing the city, despite its faults and ugliness,
label: Paragraph

text: as the symbol of civilization and the place
label: Paragraph

text: where the virtues of polity, politeness, and
label: Paragraph

text: urbanity could be exercised and maintained.
label: Paragraph

text: Associations took many forms: some were
label: Paragraph

text: social, others political; some secular, others
label: Paragraph

text: religious. Among them were the Natural
label: Paragraph

text: History Society, the Mechanic's Institute, the
label: Title

text: Architectural Association, the Royal Victoria
label: Title

text: Gallery for the Encouragement of Practical
label: Title

text: Science, and a rich array of musical groups,
label: Paragraph

text: library societies, and philosophical and
label: Title

text: charitable organizations.
label: Paragraph

text: Before the public library came the
label: Paragraph

text: athenaeum. Inspired by Hadrian's
label: Paragraph

text: Athenaeum in Rome, which was meant to
label: Paragraph

text: emulate the culture of learning associated
label: Paragraph

text: with ternples dedicated to Athena,
label: Paragraph

text: 19th-century athenaeum societies sought to
label: Paragraph

text: promote a culture of literary and scientific
label: Paragraph

text: learning focused on books, poetry, criticism,
label: Paragraph

text: and the like. Their roots were in the
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment, probably in the 1798 literary
label: Paragraph

text: magazine called the Afhenaeum that was
label: Paragraph

text: started by the brothers August and Karl
label: Paragraph

text: Friedrich Schlegel, pioneers of Indo-European
label: Title

text: studies and active advocates of the German
label: Title

text: Romantic movement.
label: Paragraph

text: A wide diversity of athenaeums sprang
label: Paragraph

text: up all over Europe and the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: Rather than stick to a specific visual heritage,
label: Paragraph

text: athenaeums sought to be very current and
label: Paragraph

text: in tune with extant intellectual cultures.
label: Paragraph

text: They were modern-day temples of Athena.
label: Paragraph

text: Many were designed in the Italianate
label: Paragraph

text: manner, while others were Greek Revival.
label: Paragraph

text: Some were a mix, such as those in London
label: Paragraph

text: and Boston. The Wadsworth Atheneum in
label: Caption

text: Hartford, Connecticut, is the oldest in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States and exhibits a fascinating
label: Paragraph

text: blend of diverse architectural idioms. Its
label: Paragraph

text: original building, designed by Alexander
label: Caption

text: Jackson Davis and Ithiel Town in 1842, was
label: Paragraph

text: a neo-Gothic building complete with turrets
label: Caption

text: and a crenelated roofline. Besides a large
label: Paragraph

text: fine arts collection, this building housed
label: Paragraph

text: the beginnings of what later became the
label: Paragraph

text: Hartford Public Library and the Connecticut
label: Title

text: Historical Society. In 1910 and 1915, two
label: Paragraph

text: new wings were added to house the growing
label: Paragraph

text: art collection, one in Tudor Revival style and
label: Paragraph

text: the other in a more Italianate Renaissance
label: Paragraph

text: mode, both designed by Benjamin Wistar
label: Paragraph

text: Morris. In 1934, the museum chose a strong
label: Paragraph

text: modernist idiom for its new wing—the first
label: Paragraph

text: museum in the United States to adopt
label: Title

text: modernism—making the entire structure an
label: Paragraph

text: eclectic assemblage.
label: Paragraph

text: The athenaeum was an international
label: Paragraph

text: movement, with institutions appearing in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, in England, and in other
label: Paragraph

text: parts of Europe. The Finnish Athenaeum
label: Caption

text: (1887) in Helsinki, designed by Theodor
label: Caption

text: Héjer, demonstrates the emerging scale and
label: Paragraph

text: importance of these institutions. The facade
label: Paragraph

text: is decorated with statues and reliefs along
label: Paragraph

text: with busts of the architect Bramante, the
label: Paragraph

text: painter Raphael, and the sculptor Phidias.
label: Paragraph

text: On the third floor, the caryatids that support
label: Paragraph

text: the pediment symbolize the four classical art
label: Paragraph

text: forms: architecture, painting, sculpting, and
label: Paragraph

text: music. Between the second-floor windows
label: Caption

text: are reliefs that represent Finnish and
label: Paragraph

text: international artists.
label: Paragraph

text: NATIONAL MUSEUMS
label: Title

text: Before the European Enlightenment, history
label: Title

text: was more often than not explained as
label: Paragraph

text: mythical genealogies, and as a sequence
label: Paragraph

text: of great kings, queens, and military events.
label: Paragraph

text: But beginning in the Enlightenment,
label: Paragraph

text: history began to be perceived in terms
label: Paragraph

text: of a civilizational dynamic and verifiable
label: Paragraph

text: data. The original fixation on Rome and
label: Paragraph

text: Greece expanded into a fascination with
label: Paragraph

text: global history—particularly that of Egypt,
label: Paragraph

text: Mesopotamia, China, and India—with nations
label: Title

text: such as England, France, and Germany
label: Paragraph

text: seeing themselves as the protectors and heirs
label: Paragraph

text: of antique values. With William Jones’s 1786
label: Paragraph

text: discovery of the linguistic continuity between
label: Title

text: Sanskrit and Greek and Latin, comparative
label: Title

text: histories, along with theories of “originary”
label: Paragraph

text: nations, also began to circulate.
label: Paragraph

text: The national museums that now came
label: Title

text: into being exemplified the Victorian’s desire—
label: Paragraph

text: and capacity—to master the logic of the
label: Paragraph

text: expanding concept of history. The Louvre
label: Caption

text: was among the first of these new museums,
label: Paragraph

text: aving been transformed in 1793 from
label: Paragraph

text: a private royal collection into a public art
label: Title

text: museum open to all citizens free of charge.
label: Paragraph

text: Subsequently, Napoleon transformed the
label: Paragraph

text: Louvre into an instrument of the state to
label: Paragraph

text: strengthen the link between national identity
label: Title

text: and the history of civilization. The idea of
label: Paragraph

text: the national museum was taken up by the
label: Paragraph

text: Prussian king Friedrich Wilhelm II, who built
label: Paragraph

text: the Altes Museum in Berlin in 1829. By
label: Caption

text: the end of the 19th century, the European
label: Paragraph

text: Enlightenment conception of nation and
label: Title

text: empire was inextricably intertwined with
label: Paragraph

text: museum displays and exhibitions.
label: Paragraph

text: 17.15 French-Egyptian Museum, Cairo
label: Caption

text: The discovery of dazzling, forgotten ruins,
label: Paragraph

text: such as those found at Angkor Wat by
label: Paragraph

text: the French in the 1860s, became almost
label: Paragraph

text: a competitive sport arnong nations. The
label: Paragraph

text: principle of these discoveries was “finders
label: Paragraph

text: keepers,” with the finders becoming more
label: Paragraph

text: famous than their discoveries: the Elgin
label: Title

text: Marbles, from the frieze of the Parthenon,
label: Caption

text: were named not after the temple but after
label: Paragraph

text: the man who had dismantled them and sold
label: Paragraph

text: them to the British Museum—Thomas Bruce,
label: Caption

text: the 7th Earl of Elgin.
label: Paragraph

text: The span of time encompassing the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of the National Gallery in London
label: Caption

text: (1861), the Kyoto National Museum (1898),
label: Paragraph

text: the Estonian National Museum (1909), and
label: Paragraph

text: the National Gallery of Art in Washington,
label: Caption

text: DC (1931), demonstrates the expanding
label: Paragraph

text: role of history in the construction of national
label: Title

text: ideologies. At the same time, museums were
label: Paragraph

text: built in the colonies to stress the legitimacy
label: Paragraph

text: of the colonizer’s presumed civilizing mission
label: Title

text: and to enable native peoples to recognize
label: Paragraph

text: themselves as differentiated subjects under
label: Paragraph

text: the overarching and unifying umbrella of
label: Paragraph

text: empire. India’s Government Museum of
label: Caption

text: Chennai (1851) and Prince of Wales Museum
label: Title

text: in Mumbai (1914), as well as the French-
label: Paragraph

text: Egyptian Museum in Cairo (1858), are but a
label: Paragraph

text: few examples of the complex aspects of the
label: Paragraph

text: history of colonialism.
label: Paragraph

text: In most cases, these museums were
label: Paragraph

text: conceived as Neoclassical structures,
label: Paragraph

text: because the claim to classicism and its
label: Paragraph

text: associated principles of order and system
label: Title

text: were so central to the concept of nationalism
label: Paragraph

text: in the 19th century. The National Gallery
label: Caption

text: of England had an octastyle ternple front.
label: Paragraph

text: The imprint of Neoclassicism was so strong
label: Paragraph

text: that even in the 20th century, modernism—
label: Paragraph

text: apart from a few exceptions—could do little
label: Paragraph

text: to challenge it, at least in Europe and the
label: Paragraph

text: Americas. In Europe, until the advent of
label: Paragraph

text: postmodernism there were few examples of
label: Paragraph

text: museums not built in a Neoclassical style.
label: Paragraph

text: WORLD’S FAIRS
label: Title

text: The first industrial exhibition was held in
label: Paragraph

text: France in 1801 to search for buyers of
label: Paragraph

text: products during an economic depression
label: Title

text: that followed the French Revolution. The
label: Paragraph

text: English also had such fairs, but on a smaller
label: Paragraph

text: scale. The success of these fairs led Henry
label: Paragraph

text: Cole (1808-82), a leading advocate of the
label: Paragraph

text: necessity for improvement in industrial design
label: Title

text: and well-known through his Journal of Design
label: Paragraph

text: and Manufactures (1849-52), to argue
label: Paragraph

text: that what was needed was not a national
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition but a large international one that
label: Paragraph

text: could assemble the best goods from the
label: Paragraph

text: world over and, at the same time, showcase
label: Paragraph

text: England's unique influence in the global
label: Paragraph

text: economy. The fair he organized was held in
label: Paragraph

text: 1851 and took place in a building that came
label: Paragraph

text: to be called the Crystal Palace.
label: Paragraph

text: he Crystal Palace was designed
label: Paragraph

text: and engineered by Sir Joseph Paxton,
label: Paragraph

text: an innovative designer of steel and glass
label: Paragraph

text: greenhouses. Unlike Henri Labrouste’s
label: Paragraph

text: Bibliothéque St.-Genevieve with its custom-
label: Paragraph

text: detailed iron elements, or St. Pancras Station
label: Caption

text: with its massive beams, the Crystal Palace
label: Paragraph

text: was composed of thin, lightweight elements
label: Paragraph

text: that were mass-produced and assembled
label: Paragraph

text: on-site. Tension wires kept the structure from
label: Paragraph

text: falling over. The effect was of a building that
label: Paragraph

text: seemed almost to be woven; compression
label: Paragraph

text: and tension forces were brought into the
label: Paragraph

text: open as no other building had ever done
label: Paragraph

text: before. Paxton also understood that the
label: Paragraph

text: 17.18 Plan: Crystal Palace
label: Caption

text: structure had to be inspiring and so designed
label: Paragraph

text: its central element in the form of a long nave
label: Paragraph

text: filled with exhibits, trees, and gardens. On
label: Paragraph

text: display were the first English mass-produced
label: Paragraph

text: machines and products, alongside intricate
label: Paragraph

text: handcrafted products from the colonies. The
label: Paragraph

text: contradiction between the two reflected the
label: Paragraph

text: intellectual mindset of the time. The industrial
label: Paragraph

text: bosses marveled at the engineering and mass
label: Paragraph

text: production; the Arts and Crafts enthusiasts
label: Title

text: pointed to the colonial products as evidence
label: Paragraph

text: of what was lost to England. John Ruskin
label: Paragraph

text: and Qwen Jones decried the building and
label: Paragraph

text: its industrial contents as representing the
label: Paragraph

text: superficiality of modern culture, while
label: Paragraph

text: extolling the colonial products for their
label: Paragraph

text: beauty.
label: Paragraph

text: No one had ever seen such a spectacle.
label: Paragraph

text: The fair was a phenomenal success:
label: Paragraph

text: 6 million people visited in the six short
label: Title

text: months the exhibition was open. The fair’s
label: Paragraph

text: unprecedented triurmph set the stage for
label: Paragraph

text: a seemingly endless series of repeats:
label: Paragraph

text: the Great Industrial Exhibition of Dublin
label: Title

text: (1853), the New York Crystal Palace (1853),
label: Paragraph

text: the International Exhibition of London
label: Title

text: (1862), the Dublin International Exhibition
label: Caption

text: (1865), and London's Colonial and Indian
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition (1886). There were still others:
label: Paragraph

text: the international exhibitions in Paris in 1855,
label: Paragraph

text: 1867, 1878, 1889, and 1900; the Centennial
label: Title

text: Exhibition in Philadelphia (1876); the World’s
label: Paragraph

text: Columbian Exposition in Chicago (1893),
label: Paragraph

text: and the World's Exposition at Melbourne,
label: Paragraph

text: Australia (1880). And then there were
label: Paragraph

text: countless exhibitions held in the colonies and
label: Paragraph

text: in non-European countries: in Calcutta and
label: Paragraph

text: No Victorian-era theorist was as widely read
label: Paragraph

text: and discussed as John Ruskin. Ruskin
label: Paragraph

text: preferred the simpler Italian medieval
label: Paragraph

text: style to the more complicated northern
label: Title

text: Gothic, because form, he argued, should
label: Paragraph

text: be determined by the material of which
label: Paragraph

text: it consists and of the way in which it is
label: Paragraph

text: constructed. The early medieval period,
label: Paragraph

text: he felt, embodied this ethos. Unlike Pugin,
label: Paragraph

text: Ruskin was not opposed to the use of
label: Paragraph

text: iron, but he much preferred conventional
label: Paragraph

text: materials. Disturbed by the rawness of
label: Paragraph

text: industrialism, he wanted to bring a new
label: Paragraph

text: awareness to the aesthetic intensity of the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural surface. The fact that a wall is a
label: Paragraph

text: series of layers, he argued, should be shown
label: Paragraph

text: as distinctly as possible on the surface. He
label: Paragraph

text: was not opposed to thin walls, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: but wanted the thinness to be expressed in
label: Paragraph

text: the paneling or in the use of a checkered
label: Paragraph

text: pattern. Ruskin also asked his readers to
label: Paragraph

text: rethink their attitude to the past, looking not
label: Paragraph

text: at the question of proportion and order in
label: Paragraph

text: the neoclassical sense, nor at the question of
label: Paragraph

text: Roman versus nen-Roman motifs, but rather
label: Paragraph

text: at the physical and material rationale that
label: Paragraph

text: underlies architectural reasoning.
label: Paragraph

text: Ruskin's concern for the visual led him to
label: Paragraph

text: prefer monolithic columns. He rejected the
label: Paragraph

text: use of piers and buttresses, as they interfered
label: Paragraph

text: with the visual impact of a form. Mass was
label: Paragraph

text: not to be constricted by cold geometry;
label: Paragraph

text: rather, it was something to be molded freely
label: Paragraph

text: with simple and grand outlines. He very rarely
label: Paragraph

text: dealt with interiors and thus rarely asked
label: Paragraph

text: questions about program and function. For
label: Paragraph

text: Ruskin, the shape of a building—as would
label: Paragraph

text: have been significant for Durand—was less
label: Paragraph

text: important than the architect's attitude toward
label: Paragraph

text: designing it; and a building's tactile surface
label: Paragraph

text: and detail were just as important as the plan.
label: Paragraph

text: After Ruskin, a generation of architects
label: Paragraph

text: began to design in a way that they thought
label: Paragraph

text: conformed to his vision of the constructed
label: Paragraph

text: world. This entailed a shift away from the
label: Paragraph

text: enforced medievalism of Pugin to a more
label: Title

text: inventive style for which there is no particular
label: Paragraph

text: name apart from the term Ruskinian Gothic.
label: Paragraph

text: Among those who worked in this direction
label: Paragraph

text: was the firm of Deane and Woodward,
label: Paragraph

text: which designed the interior of the Museum
label: Paragraph

text: of Natural History at Oxford University
label: Title

text: (1853) using exposed Gothic-styled iron,
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrating its expressive qualities down
label: Paragraph

text: to the rivets holding the elernents together.
label: Paragraph

text: The industrial feel is offset by individually
label: Paragraph

text: designed capitals with inventive floral motifs
label: Caption

text: and the use of column clusters to create a
label: Paragraph

text: light, transparent appearance. In the United
label: Paragraph

text: States, one of the best examples of Ruskinian
label: Paragraph

text: Gothic is Memorial Hall (1865-68) at Harvard
label: Paragraph

text: University in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
label: Paragraph

text: Housing a theater and dining hall, it was
label: Paragraph

text: designed by William Robert Ware and Henry
label: Caption

text: Van Brunt. Most of the building is in red brick
label: Caption

text: accented in a lively manner with yellowish
label: Paragraph

text: 17.21 Museum of Natural History, Oxford, England
label: Caption

text: limestone. The roof is stripped in grays,
label: Paragraph

text: over the ensemble.
label: Paragraph

text: In this context, a movement sprang
label: Paragraph

text: up that defined a middle ground between
label: Paragraph

text: socialism and capitalism. Known as the
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts movement, it appealed to
label: Paragraph

text: individuality, novelty, and good taste; but it
label: Paragraph

text: refined these tendencies into a social and
label: Paragraph

text: philosophical position that revolved around
label: Paragraph

text: the critique of what many saw as the ethical
label: Paragraph

text: vacuum at the center of England’s mercantile
label: Title

text: culture. The concern of the Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: was not with the end product of design, and
label: Paragraph

text: certainly not with efficiency, but with the
label: Paragraph

text: processes shaping the design—there had to
label: Paragraph

text: be an intimate connection between design
label: Paragraph

text: and production. This position was to have
label: Paragraph

text: significant influence on later modernists,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Henry Van de Velde, Hermann
label: Paragraph

text: Muthesius, Adolf Loos, and Walter Gropius.
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts artists were, for the most
label: Paragraph

text: part, resistant to making connections to
label: Paragraph

text: industry, as they were frustrated by what they
label: Paragraph

text: perceived as the drift toward mechanization.
label: Paragraph

text: Perfection of finish, symmetry, and precision
label: Title

text: were suspect, since they represented the
label: Paragraph

text: denial of the human element. But just
label: Paragraph

text: ecause the movement critiqued capitalism
label: Title

text: and industrialismn did not mean it was a
label: Paragraph

text: riend of the socialists, who for their part
label: Paragraph

text: paid little regard to the Arts and Crafts
label: Paragraph

text: movement; the socialists’ weapons were the
label: Paragraph

text: trade unions, not guilds of bookbinders and
label: Paragraph

text: urniture makers. In reality, the Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts appealed more to the disenfranchised
label: Paragraph

text: ourgecisie, social utopians, and upper-class
label: Title

text: aesthetes than to members of the working
label: Paragraph

text: class. In this it was, in essence, an extension
label: Paragraph

text: of Victorian ideals that tried to educate the
label: Paragraph

text: middle class on the question of taste. Ruskin,
label: Paragraph

text: for example, created a museum in Sheffield
label: Paragraph

text: that contained carefully assembled objects
label: Paragraph

text: intended for the edification of local laborers
label: Paragraph

text: and schoolchildren; it displayed paintings,
label: Paragraph

text: sculptures, prints, and casts.

text: Arts and Crafts in India: Indo-Saracenic Style
label: Title

text: The Arts and Crafts movement became quite
label: Paragraph

text: widespread, reaching Belgium, France,
label: Paragraph

text: Germany, the United States, and even some
label: Paragraph

text: of the English colonies, particularly India. in
label: Paragraph

text: fact, some Arts and Crafts enthusiasts, like
label: Paragraph

text: John Lockwood Kipling (father of the author
label: Title

text: Rudyard Kipling), moved to India to dedicate
label: Paragraph

text: themselves to the cause of preserving and
label: Paragraph

text: promoting Indian crafts. Kipling promoted a
label: Paragraph

text: new journal on Indian crafts and even started
label: Title

text: a school to train young craftsmen.
label: Paragraph

text: Late in the 198th century, Gothic Revival
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, with its overt message of English
label: Paragraph

text: nationalism, seemed increasingly out of place
label: Paragraph

text: in India. It was now clear to the English that
label: Paragraph

text: India had an architectural history that was
label: Paragraph

text: as deep as it was complicated. With scholars
label: Paragraph

text: now studying Indian art and architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: a new generation of architects began to
label: Paragraph

text: experiment with a style that came to be
label: Paragraph

text: known as Indo-Saracenic, which adapted
label: Paragraph

text: the architectural vocabulary of Islamic or
label: Title

text: “Saracenic” architecture to create buildings
label: Paragraph

text: such as town halls, libraries, and schools.
label: Paragraph

text: The Indo-Saracenic paralleled the attempt in
label: Paragraph

text: Egypt to create a neo-Mamluk style. Part of
label: Paragraph

text: the Indo-Saracenic ideal was lodged in the
label: Paragraph

text: colonial stereotype of the putative “decline”
label: Title

text: of Indian civilization. The English claimed
label: Paragraph

text: that they had succeeded in conquering India
label: Paragraph

text: because Indian civilization in general had
label: Paragraph

text: Vt
label: Title

text: gone into decay. One of the chief proponents
label: Paragraph

text: of this idea was James Fergusson, the first
label: Paragraph

text: historian of Indian architecture. Without any
label: Paragraph

text: understanding of the functional or conceptual
label: Title

text: basis of Indian architecture, Fergusson
label: Caption

text: classified and evaluated Indian buildings
label: Title

text: based on their formal properties and
label: Paragraph

text: proposed that Indian architecture periodically
label: Paragraph

text: went into decline and that it had thus to be
label: Paragraph

text: revived by contact with foreigners.
label: Paragraph

text: For John Ruskin, the crucial index of
label: Paragraph

text: decline could be mapped by differentiating
label: Paragraph

text: between Indian craft and Indian art.
label: Paragraph

text: While craftsmen, working in their native
label: Paragraph

text: “innocence,” were seen as a positive example
label: Paragraph

text: for the English, the Indian arts had, in his
label: Paragraph

text: opinion, gone into a decline accompanied
label: Paragraph

text: by a downslide in morality. Fearing that
label: Paragraph

text: this decline might be due to the corrupting
label: Paragraph

text: influence of Europeans, his prescription was
label: Paragraph

text: to educate Indian craftsmen in European
label: Title

text: aesthetics while preserving and reviving their
label: Paragraph

text: craft traditions. European art with Indian craft
label: Paragraph

text: in the service of modern colonial buildings
label: Title

text: was, therefore, the 19th-century recipe for a
label: Paragraph

text: “modern” Indian architecture.

text: Arts and Crafts in California
label: Title

text: In California, Arts and Crafts underwent its
label: Paragraph

text: most vigorous transformation and its longest
label: Title

text: period of vibrancy, fusing with Spanish-
label: Paragraph

text: Mexican motifs as well as elements from
label: Paragraph

text: the Italian Mediterranean and the Far East.
label: Paragraph

text: Linked to its development was a public
label: Paragraph

text: school system strongly committed to manual-
label: Paragraph

text: arts education and in particular to the belief
label: Title

text: that the union of head and heart through
label: Paragraph

text: handicraft yielded therapeutic benefits. Local
label: Paragraph

text: libraries organized sketch clubs and hosted
label: Paragraph

text: exhibitions of local craft production.
label: Paragraph

text: Elements from the local landscape and
label: Paragraph

text: flora were also quite strong in the California
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts. Whether depicting golden
label: Paragraph

text: poppies, the Torrey pines, the redwoods, or
label: Paragraph

text: the sublime majesty of the Yosemite Valley,
label: Paragraph

text: California’s Arts and Crafts artists extolled
label: Title

text: the state’s natural beauty and were much
label: Paragraph

text: more intimately associated with the outdoors
label: Paragraph

text: than their counterparts in England and the
label: Paragraph

text: northeastern United States. Many of their
label: Paragraph

text: houses exploited the fine views and outdoor
label: Paragraph

text: living afforded by the natural settings. These
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts houses featured deliberate
label: Title

text: blurring of interior and exterior space through
label: Paragraph

text: the use of decks, pergolas, porches, and
label: Paragraph

text: terraces. The English-style medievalism in
label: Paragraph

text: these houses gave way to an aesthetic of
label: Paragraph

text: primitivism embodied, for example, in the
label: Paragraph

text: writings of Jack London, author of The Cait
label: Title

text: of the Wifd (1903). London's own house
label: Caption

text: in Sonoma’s Valley of the Moon was a
label: Paragraph

text: prime example of Arts and Crafts domestic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture: redwood, timber with bark left
label: Paragraph

text: on, huge halls, and giant fireplaces. The
label: Paragraph

text: Gamble House by Charles Sumner Greene
label: Caption

text: and Henry Mather Greene (Pasadena,
label: Caption

text: California, 1908-9) is an excellent example
label: Paragraph

text: of the use of Japanese motifs. The stepping-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: are all inspired by Japanese precedents. The
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the space of the living rooms outward toward
label: Paragraph

text: the gardens and lawns. The house also
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: majestic eucalyptus trees. Inside, from lamps
label: Caption

text: to furniture to carpets, not a single detail

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Building on the Romantic associations with
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Plan of 1811, New York City’s Central Park
label: Caption

text: (1853-83) was not only the nation’s first
label: Paragraph

text: and largest urban park, but it also became
label: Paragraph

text: the model of American landscape design.
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: (1822-1903). Olmsted began his career
label: Paragraph

text: as a journalist and was influenced first by
label: Paragraph

text: his dispatches from Europe, where he was
label: Paragraph

text: particularly impressed by the new urban
label: Paragraph

text: parks, such as Birkenhead Park in England
label: Paragraph

text: by Joseph Paxton of Crystal Palace fare,
label: Caption

text: and subsequently by his travels in the
label: Paragraph

text: South, where he carefully documented and
label: Paragraph

text: commented on the adverse effects of the
label: Paragraph

text: slave economy.
label: Paragraph

text: Central Park was championed by Andrew
label: Paragraph

text: Jackson Downing, an advocate of landscape
label: Paragraph

text: design and a famous critic of industrialization
label: Title

text: and urbanization, as well as a mentor to
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted. Downing (1815-52), influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by Picturesque ideas as well as the growing
label: Paragraph

text: moralism of the early Victorian era, saw
label: Paragraph

text: in landscapes more than just beauty. He
label: Paragraph

text: saw the garden as something more than a
label: Paragraph

text: convenient stage for setting up monuments
label: Paragraph

text: to heroes, as it was at Stowe Gardens in
label: Paragraph

text: Buckinghamshire, England. Landscape, so
label: Caption

text: Downing held, strengthened character and
label: Paragraph

text: supported the integrity of the farnily. The
label: Paragraph

text: intimate house garden, he argued, served
label: Paragraph

text: as a civilizing and protective veil around the
label: Paragraph

text: house and helped it to blend as naturally as
label: Paragraph

text: possible into the landscape. At the time, the
label: Paragraph

text: area around most large cities in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States had been radically deforested to make
label: Paragraph

text: way for farms. In 1845, when Henry David
label: Paragraph

text: Thoreau lived for two years in solitude next to
label: Paragraph

text: Walden Pond in Massachusetts in an attempt
label: Title

text: to immerse himself in nature, the pond was
label: Paragraph

text: one of the few areas for many miles around
label: Paragraph

text: surrounded by trees. Downing believed that
label: Paragraph

text: one could bring nature to the city in the form
label: Paragraph

text: of parks, but only if they were big enough to
label: Paragraph

text: simulate a landscape—albeit one that had
label: Paragraph

text: been tamed and brought into balance with
label: Paragraph

text: human needs.
label: Paragraph

text: When Downing was killed in a stearnboat
label: Paragraph

text: explosion on the Hudson River in 1852,
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted joined with Calvert Vaux to submit
label: Paragraph

text: the competition entry for the park. Vaux was
label: Paragraph

text: an English architect who had come to the
label: Paragraph

text: United States to work with Downing. The
label: Paragraph

text: 3.4-square-kilometer park, in the heart of
label: Caption

text: Manhattan, was built on land occupied by
label: Paragraph

text: free slaves and Irish immigrants, who were
label: Paragraph

text: forcibly evicted. The park was not raw nature,
label: Paragraph

text: but a carefully constructed vision of it. This
label: Paragraph

text: involved vast amounts of cut and fill work, the
label: Paragraph

text: planting of millions of trees, the construction
label: Paragraph

text: of thirty-six bridges, and the creation of
label: Paragraph

text: meadows, forests, hilltop lookouts, castles,
label: Paragraph

text: sheep farms, skating rinks, and eateries.
label: Paragraph

text: In keeping with the Romantic Picturesque
label: Paragraph

text: tradition, a flock of pedigreed Dorset sheep
label: Paragraph

text: were maintained in a specially designated
label: Paragraph

text: meadow. Two major reservoirs stored water
label: Paragraph

text: for the city. Underneath was an elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: drainage system.
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted and Vaux were at constant
label: Paragraph

text: loggerheads with the park’s commissioners
label: Title

text: to ensure that the park was maintained as a
label: Paragraph

text: democratic space accessible to all. Although
label: Paragraph

text: first years, it went into severe decline around
label: Paragraph

text: the turn of the century. In 1934, Robert
label: Paragraph

text: Moses cleaned up and restored the park as
label: Paragraph

text: part of his drive to transform New York City.
label: Paragraph

text: Olmsted, Vaux and Company, founded
label: Paragraph

text: in 1861, also designed parks in Milwaukee,
label: Paragraph

text: Wisconsin; Buffalo, New York; and other
label: Paragraph

text: cities. The firm was inherited by Olmsted's
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: and Frederick Law Olmsted Jr. (1870-1957),
label: Paragraph

text: who developed it into one of the largest and
label: Paragraph

text: most influential landscape firms of the time.
label: Paragraph

text: They designed numerous well-known projects
label: Paragraph

text: such as Acadia National Park, Yosemite
label: Paragraph

text: National Park, and Atlanta’s Piedmont Park,
label: Paragraph

text: as well as the complete park systems of cities
label: Paragraph

text: such as Portland and Seattle.

text: PARIS AND HAUSSMANN
label: Title

text: After Napoleon's defeat in 1815, the
label: Paragraph

text: monarchy was restored in France and
label: Paragraph

text: lasted in various forms until 1848, when
label: Paragraph

text: another major popular revolt in the streets of
label: Paragraph

text: Paris—immortalized by Victor Hugo in Les
label: Paragraph

text: Miserables—led to the establishment of the
label: Paragraph

text: Second Republic. Louis-Napoleon Bonaparte
label: Caption

text: was elected president of the Second
label: Paragraph

text: Republic, and in 1852 a plebiscite was held
label: Paragraph

text: that gave him supreme power, with the title
label: Paragraph

text: of emperor, as Napoleon III (1808-73). He
label: Paragraph

text: promptly canceled the independence of
label: Paragraph

text: parliament and rolled back advancements
label: Title

text: that had been made in the name of universal
label: Paragraph

text: suffrage, free press, and education. Public
label: Paragraph

text: institutions were strictly supervised, the
label: Paragraph

text: teaching of philosophy in the high schools
label: Title

text: was suppressed, and the power of the
label: Paragraph

text: government was increased.
label: Paragraph

text: Initially, the fortunes of France seemed
label: Paragraph

text: restored. The country emerged victorious
label: Paragraph

text: in the Crimean War (1854-56) and then
label: Paragraph

text: went on to build the Suez Canal (1854-69).
label: Paragraph

text: Napoleon II| was eager to translate these
label: Paragraph

text: successes into architectural form and, even
label: Paragraph

text: more, to make Paris into the “capital of the
label: Paragraph

text: 19th century.” His agent of change was
label: Paragraph

text: Georges-Eugéne Haussmann (1809-91),
label: Paragraph

text: whose vision for Paris, like Napoleon Ill’s, was
label: Paragraph

text: unmistakably big. Unlike earlier urban design
label: Paragraph

text: approaches—as in Rome under Sixtus V,
label: Paragraph

text: and in Washington, DC—that used straight
label: Paragraph

text: boulevards in relationship to major buildings
label: Paragraph

text: such as palaces and churches, Haussmann’s
label: Paragraph

text: new streets were laid out according to
label: Paragraph

text: pragmatic and economic considerations.
label: Paragraph

text: They had to be built, however, by destroying
label: Paragraph

text: large parts of medieval Paris and displacing
label: Title

text: thousands of inhabitants, mainly from the
label: Paragraph

text: lower classes.
label: Paragraph

text: 17.37 Paris Opera House, France
label: Caption

text: Though there was some atternpt to integrate
label: Paragraph

text: the new streets with the old, little was spared
label: Paragraph

text: and entire neighborhoods were wiped out.
label: Paragraph

text: The new streets were lined with apartments
label: Paragraph

text: and provided with sewage pipes and gas
label: Paragraph

text: lines. To forestall conflagrations, the use of
label: Paragraph

text: stone for buildings, once the privilege of the
label: Paragraph

text: rich, was now common throughout the new
label: Paragraph

text: parts of the city. Haussmann’s Paris would
label: Paragraph

text: become the model for cities around the
label: Paragraph

text: world, such as Buenos Aires, Cairo, Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: and Saigon. “Haussmannization,” which
label: Paragraph

text: impeded effective blockading of streets, is
label: Paragraph

text: sometimes blamed for the suppression of the
label: Paragraph

text: Paris Commune in the street revolts of 1871.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the centerpieces of the new Paris
label: Caption

text: was the Opera House (1861-75), set at the
label: Paragraph

text: intersection of several radiating streets. It
label: Paragraph

text: was designed by Charles Garnier (1825-98),
label: Paragraph

text: a young architect who was only thirty-six
label: Paragraph

text: years old when he won the competition.
label: Paragraph

text: Earlier, he had won the Prix de Rome,
label: Paragraph

text: demonstrating that even a workingman’s son
label: Paragraph

text: could gain access to the new professional
label: Paragraph

text: class. Garnier’s design combines the double
label: Paragraph

text: columnar colonnade from the Louvre with
label: Caption

text: elements from Michelangelo's facade on the
label: Caption

text: Campidoglio, blending the royal symbolism
label: Paragraph

text: that would have appealed to Napoleon III with
label: Paragraph

text: the republican symbolism of Michelangelo's
label: Title

text: work. The front, when taken as a whole,
label: Paragraph

text: could also be seen as a very wide triurnphal
label: Paragraph

text: arch. In this way, the building successfully
label: Paragraph

text: negotiated the complex political situation of
label: Paragraph

text: its times without referring to Rome or Greece
label: Title

text: in any direct way. Like the London Law
label: Paragraph

text: Courts, this building had multiple programs
label: Paragraph

text: and circulation systems. The impressive
label: Paragraph

text: front entrance was for the public arriving on
label: Paragraph

text: foot. Those arriving by coach entered on the
label: Paragraph

text: right-hand side. Performers and members
label: Paragraph

text: of the opera administration entered at the
label: Paragraph

text: rear. There was a special side entrance for
label: Paragraph

text: 17.38 Grand Staircase: Paris Opera House
label: Caption

text: the emperor, to which he could roll up in his
label: Paragraph

text: coach and go directly indoors. Structurally the
label: Paragraph

text: building is of steel, but the steel is rendered
label: Paragraph

text: invisible by stone and brick. The staircase
label: Caption

text: that lies between the entrance narthex and
label: Paragraph

text: the theater is itself a three-dimensional
label: Paragraph

text: theater intended to allow opera goers to see
label: Paragraph

text: and be seen, the encounters themselves
label: Paragraph

text: constituting an elaborate social ritual.

text: THE PASSAGE
label: Title

text: Besides train stations and industrial fairs, the
label: Paragraph

text: building type that perhaps best epitomized
label: Paragraph

text: the Industrial Revolution and its new culture
label: Title

text: of mass consumption was the shopping
label: Paragraph

text: gallery. These buildings were places where
label: Paragraph

text: one could see firsthand not only the wealth
label: Paragraph

text: of the global marketplace but also the use
label: Paragraph

text: of new building materials, metal and glass.
label: Paragraph

text: At the beginning of the 19th century, most
label: Paragraph

text: shops differed very little from those of
label: Paragraph

text: medieval times—a window or counter faced
label: Paragraph

text: the street, and there was a small enclosure
label: Paragraph

text: where business could be transacted. The
label: Paragraph

text: fall in the price of glass made large shop
label: Title

text: windows possible, and they appeared at
label: Paragraph

text: the end of the 1820s in Landon, Paris, and
label: Paragraph

text: lew York. In Paris, shopping streets—called
label: Paragraph

text: galeries or passages—were soon designed
label: Paragraph

text: with rows of shops under a single glazed roof.
label: Paragraph

text: By the end of the 19th century, passages
label: Paragraph

text: or their equivalents could be found in most
label: Paragraph

text: European cities. At first they were on a single
label: Paragraph

text: loor, but soon they were built on two or
label: Paragraph

text: more levels. They provided security for shop
label: Paragraph

text: owners as well as convenience for shoppers:
label: Paragraph

text: most 19th-century cities were noisy and
label: Paragraph

text: chaotic, and the streets unpaved. Passages
label: Paragraph

text: offered protected enclaves for bourgeois
label: Paragraph

text: patrons.
label: Paragraph

text: Marking the zenith of this building type
label: Paragraph

text: was the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II in
label: Paragraph

text: Milan, a building that became a symbol of
label: Paragraph

text: the young nation. Its entrance was located
label: Paragraph

text: facing the piazza in front of the Duomo,
label: Paragraph

text: the facade of which had only been finished
label: Paragraph

text: in 1806. The planning of the piazza had
label: Paragraph

text: Stalled for decades, but it was revived with
label: Paragraph

text: the unification of Italy in 1859. Almost
label: Paragraph

text: irmmediately the designing of the galleria was
label: Paragraph

text: put into motion, and when it was opened
label: Paragraph

text: in 1867, it was seen as an engineering and
label: Paragraph

text: urban marvel.
label: Paragraph

text: The building, whose four wings meet at
label: Paragraph

text: a great, glasse
label: Title

text: on the interior,
label: Paragraph

text: existing structures around it. There are seven
label: Paragraph

text: floors, not including the cellar, with a network
label: Paragraph

text: of concealed intersecting supports that
label: Paragraph

text: dome, is completely regular
label: Paragraph

text: ut it dovetails with the older
label: Paragraph

text: allow for a flexible use of space. Staircases
label: Paragraph

text: are located at the rear and are accessible
label: Paragraph

text: through courtyards so as not to disturb
label: Paragraph

text: the visual unity of the facades. The main
label: Paragraph

text: staircases are located at the reentrant angles
label: Paragraph

text: of the crossings. The third floor is reserved
label: Paragraph

text: for club rooms, offices, and studios, while the

text: ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS
label: Title

text: Throughout the 19th century, Europe's
label: Paragraph

text: prime school for the study of architecture
label: Title

text: was the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris.
label: Paragraph

text: Though intended for French citizens, it was
label: Paragraph

text: by the end of the 19th century visited by
label: Paragraph

text: students from around the world, creating a
label: Paragraph

text: cadre of devotees who spread the school's
label: Paragraph

text: pedagogical system and architectural style to
label: Title

text: places around the globe. Its influence could
label: Paragraph

text: still be felt in American architectural schools
label: Paragraph

text: well into the 1940s. The Beaux-Arts was
label: Paragraph

text: originally founded as the Académie Royale
label: Paragraph

text: d’Architecture in Paris in 1671 by Jean-
label: Caption

text: Baptiste Colbert, minister of Louis XIV, who
label: Paragraph

text: envisioned it as a place that would create
label: Paragraph

text: the talent necessary for the king’s cornplex
label: Title

text: building program. The French Revolution
label: Title

text: ended the royal acadernies, but in 1803,
label: Paragraph

text: architectural education resumed, mainly
label: Paragraph

text: to prepare students for state-sponsored
label: Paragraph

text: architectural competitions. The founding
label: Paragraph

text: of the Société Centrale des Architects in
label: Paragraph

text: 1840 made architecture into an academic
label: Paragraph

text: profession similar to law and medicine. The
label: Paragraph

text: Société ended the aristocratic system of
label: Paragraph

text: patronage. It was also the death knell of the
label: Paragraph

text: gentleman architect (though that tradition
label: Paragraph

text: had always been stronger in England than in
label: Paragraph

text: France). This is important to note, because
label: Paragraph

text: even though the academic style of the French
label: Paragraph

text: was much criticized by the moderns of the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century, the Ecole elevated architecture
label: Title

text: to an autonomous and structured discipline.
label: Paragraph

text: With that autonomy came new and
label: Paragraph

text: complex theoretical questions about the
label: Title

text: nature of architectural production. Should
label: Paragraph

text: one use new materials like steel and glass?
label: Paragraph

text: And if so, how? What is the relationship
label: Paragraph

text: between the identity of a nation, its history,
label: Paragraph

text: and its architecture? By mid-century these
label: Paragraph

text: issues became quite divisive. On the one
label: Paragraph

text: side stood defenders of idealized classicism
label: Title

text: such as Quatremére de Quincy; on the other
label: Paragraph

text: were the Romantics such as Henri Labrouste,
label: Paragraph

text: with their flexible understanding of history.
label: Paragraph

text: The conflict broke into the open with the
label: Paragraph

text: appointment of Eugene-Emmanuel Viollet-le-
label: Caption

text: Duc in 1863 as professor of the history of art
label: Paragraph

text: and aesthetics. He supported the use of iron
label: Paragraph

text: in buildings, which many French architects
label: Paragraph

text: resisted.

text: Beaux-Arts plans have a set of unique
label: Paragraph

text: characteristics:
label: Title

text: 1. Symmetry is stressed, and where there
label: Paragraph

text: is asymmetry, it must be worked into the
label: Paragraph

text: larger whole.
label: Paragraph

text: 2. Axiality is important; the most important
label: Paragraph

text: spaces must be on axis and clearly
label: Paragraph

text: emphasized in space and proportion.
label: Paragraph

text: 3. Cross-axes are used to distribute and
label: Paragraph

text: organize the program.
label: Paragraph

text: 4. There should be a clear hierarchy of the
label: Title

text: major and minor parts of the program.
label: Paragraph

text: There should be no hidden spaces, but a
label: Paragraph

text: gradation of importance.
label: Paragraph

text: 5. At the center of the composition should be
label: Caption

text: a great hall, the dimensions of which relate
label: Paragraph

text: to the building's overall proportions.
label: Paragraph

text: 6. Repeating elements should be unified to
label: Caption

text: support the overall planning.
label: Paragraph

text: 7. The relationships between open and closed
label: Title

text: spaces and among buildings, courtyards,
label: Paragraph

text: and surrounding gardens should be
label: Paragraph

text: resolved into an integrated whole.
label: Paragraph

text: 8. The decorative elements should be in
label: Caption

text: accordance with the programm. Civic
label: Paragraph

text: buildings should show restraint; opera
label: Paragraph

text: houses, ebullience.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: This was true for Egypt, one of the

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Sa‘id Pasha (r. 1854-63), Muhammad ‘Ali's
label: Paragraph

text: son and third successor, and especially
label: Paragraph

text: Isma‘il Pasha (r. 1863-79), his grandson,
label: Paragraph

text: were the architects of Egypt's freedom
label: Paragraph

text: from the Ottomans. Isma‘il was fascinated
label: Paragraph

text: by French culture, so much so that he
label: Paragraph

text: adopted French manners in his personal
label: Paragraph

text: life and encouraged his entourage to follow
label: Paragraph

text: suit. He also was an impatient modernizer
label: Paragraph

text: who wanted to turn Egypt into an extension
label: Title

text: of Europe, despite adverse economic
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances. The country’s foreign debt,
label: Paragraph

text: however, spun out of control. Bankruptcy was
label: Paragraph

text: declared in 1879, leading to its occupation by
label: Paragraph

text: the British in 1882.
label: Paragraph

text: Isma‘il's passion for Europeanization can
label: Paragraph

text: be understood as mimicry or as local
label: Paragraph

text: modernism, as in any other part of the
label: Paragraph

text: world. Inspired by his visit to the Exposition
label: Paragraph

text: Universelle in Paris in 1867, he tried to turn
label: Paragraph

text: his own capital into another Paris, complete
label: Paragraph

text: with wide, straight avenues planted with
label: Paragraph

text: trees, planned gardens, pavilions, and all
label: Paragraph

text: the amenities of modern city life, such as
label: Paragraph

text: theaters, cafés, and even an opera house.
label: Paragraph

text: He commissioned his minister of public
label: Paragraph

text: works, Ali Pasha Mubarak, a member of the

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: master plan.

label: Paragraph

text: HENRY HOBSON RICHARDSON
label: Title

text: By the late 1830s, the Greek Revival had
label: Paragraph

text: become without question the adopted style
label: Title

text: of the United States, and it remained so up
label: Paragraph

text: to the Civil War. The simplicity, ideological
label: Paragraph

text: coherence, and the ease with which its forms
label: Paragraph

text: could be copied in brick and wood by local
label: Paragraph

text: carpenters contributed greatly to its success.
label: Paragraph

text: It had little competition from the Gothic
label: Paragraph

text: style, which in the United States, unlike in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe, had few major representatives. The
label: Paragraph

text: result was a fluid movement from the Greek
label: Paragraph

text: Revival to a French-derived style known
label: Paragraph

text: as Second Empire. With its compositional
label: Paragraph

text: emphasis on vertical pavilions and classically
label: Paragraph

text: derived ornamentation, the Second Empire
label: Paragraph

text: remained an important subcurrent until well
label: Paragraph

text: into the advent of modernism. In the 1880s
label: Paragraph

text: and 1890s, a group of architects began to
label: Paragraph

text: chart their own way, however, bringing out
label: Paragraph

text: latent ideas of the Picturesque while trying
label: Title

text: to match this aesthetic with the needs of
label: Paragraph

text: rising the mercantile class. These architects
label: Paragraph

text: were Frank Furness in Philadelphia, Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan in Chicago, and Henry Hobson
label: Title

text: Richardson in Boston. All developed very
label: Paragraph

text: distinctive approaches. Furness brought to
label: Paragraph

text: the United States many of Viollet-le-Duc’s
label: Paragraph

text: ideas about integrating iron into design.
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan stressed bold simplicity combined
label: Title

text: with rich ornamentation in his buildings. And
label: Paragraph

text: Richardson's work from the late 1870s to the
label: Paragraph

text: mid 1890s came to be seen by many as a
label: Paragraph

text: style unto itself.
label: Paragraph

text: When Richardson (1838-86) was young he
label: Paragraph

text: had intended to become a civil engineer,
label: Paragraph

text: but he switched to architecture while
label: Paragraph

text: studying at Harvard. In 1859, he began
label: Paragraph

text: to study at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: remained in Paris for five years. Because
label: Paragraph

text: of his Parisian training, Richardson was
label: Paragraph

text: well suited to serve the needs of the rising
label: Paragraph

text: Class of new businessmen who wanted to
label: Paragraph

text: see their success endorsed by the currently
label: Paragraph

text: fashionable style of cosmopolitan Paris. But
label: Paragraph

text: by the 1870s, Richardson was increasingly
label: Paragraph

text: drawn to the English medieval style and to
label: Paragraph

text: the Picturesque, attempting to synthesize
label: Paragraph

text: their disparate and even contradictory
label: Paragraph

text: aspects. Richardson's plans, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: maintain the clarity typical of the Beaux-
label: Paragraph

text: Arts, while his attention to the tactility and
label: Paragraph

text: color of the building’s stone surface evoke
label: Paragraph

text: a tactility more in line with Queen Anne
label: Paragraph

text: style and Ruskinian Gothic. Richardson
label: Caption

text: closely collaborated with landscape architect
label: Paragraph

text: Frederick Law Olmsted on many of his
label: Paragraph

text: projects.

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: compared to the small windows of the
label: Paragraph

text: tower, make the composition seem both

text: THE GLOBAL BUNGALOW
label: Title

text: One of the most visible manifestations of the
label: Paragraph

text: global colonial economy was the development
label: Title

text: and spread of the bungalow. The bungalow
label: Paragraph

text: (the word derives from the Bengali word
label: Paragraph

text: bangla) was first used by the English
label: Paragraph

text: colonists in India as a type of garden and
label: Paragraph

text: plantation house. Most had a single ridge roof
label: Paragraph

text: that overhung the house, creating a porch
label: Paragraph

text: called the verandah (originally a Hindi word).
label: Paragraph

text: The verandah served as an intermediate
label: Paragraph

text: space where colonizer and colonized could
label: Paragraph

text: interact. In tropical climates it was also the
label: Paragraph

text: most comfortable space of the house. In
label: Paragraph

text: time, bungalows added an entrance porch,
label: Paragraph

text: which had to be large enough to receive a
label: Paragraph

text: carriage. The interior space was designed
label: Paragraph

text: around a central room with bedrooms directly
label: Caption

text: off to the sides, and toilets and kitchens in
label: Paragraph

text: the back so that they could be serviced by
label: Paragraph

text: the local staff. Servant quarters were built
label: Paragraph

text: at a distance in the back of the garden.
label: Paragraph

text: The colonial bungalow spread as a type
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the tropical colonies in the late
label: Paragraph

text: 18th and early 19th centuries.
label: Paragraph

text: As a symbol of the good life, the bungalow
label: Paragraph

text: was exported back to England and soon
label: Paragraph

text: could be found in the United States as well,
label: Paragraph

text: in the form of the detached, single-family
label: Paragraph

text: residential dwelling that could be easily
label: Paragraph

text: built on small parcels. Climate and lifestyle
label: Paragraph

text: dictates did not allow the core properties of
label: Paragraph

text: the colonial bungalow to be exported, but its
label: Paragraph

text: 17.58 Typical block of bungalows
label: Caption

text: image was variously translated as it spread.
label: Paragraph

text: The noncolonial bungalow was usually a
label: Paragraph

text: single-story house (though sometime it
label: Paragraph

text: had two floors) of modest scale, with a low
label: Paragraph

text: overhanging roof and a porch running along
label: Caption

text: its front. Many subcategories evolved. The
label: Paragraph

text: California bungalows—which were among
label: Paragraph

text: the earliest in the United States, dating from
label: Paragraph

text: about the 1880s onward—cormmonly have
label: Paragraph

text: wood shingles, horizontal siding, or stucco
label: Paragraph

text: exteriors, as well as brick chirmneys. The
label: Paragraph

text: so-called Chicago bungalow, which was
label: Paragraph

text: popular between 1910 and 1940, was often
label: Paragraph

text: made of brick. In many cases, the bungalow
label: Paragraph

text: was inexpensive to build and did not need
label: Paragraph

text: an architect. Furthermore, with its space-
label: Paragraph

text: saving layout, it appealed to middle-class
label: Paragraph

text: owners who could not afford live-in servants.
label: Paragraph

text: The kitchen was compact and located next
label: Paragraph

text: to the dining room. The walls were usually
label: Paragraph

text: wallpapered, whereas the trim for the doors
label: Paragraph

text: and windows was dark-stained oak.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1880s, the bungalow became
label: Paragraph

text: associated with the Arts and Crafts
label: Title

text: movement, and indeed many bungalows
label: Paragraph

text: were built in the so-called American
label: Paragraph

text: Craftsman style, which was a reaction against
label: Paragraph

text: the overdecorated aesthetic of the Victorian
label: Paragraph

text: era. Though the Arts and Crafts emphasized
label: Paragraph

text: the handmade over the mass-produced,
label: Paragraph

text: and some early bungalows followed in this
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic, the bungalow was soon nothing
label: Paragraph

text: less than an industrialized product. In fact,
label: Paragraph

text: by the turn of the 20th century, an entire
label: Paragraph

text: house could be ordered through catalogues;
label: Paragraph

text: the bungalow was then shipped by rail
label: Paragraph

text: or boat to be assembled on-site. Doors,
label: Paragraph

text: windows, and built-in furnishings such
label: Paragraph

text: as bookcases, desks, and folding beds
label: Paragraph

text: could also be purchased from mail-order
label: Paragraph

text: catalogues. The bungalow was spread as part
label: Paragraph

text: of the suburbanization of the American city,
label: Paragraph

text: with whole bungalow districts appearing in
label: Paragraph

text: many U.S. cities.
label: Paragraph

text: SHINGLE STYLE
label: Title

text: Unique to the United States, and parallel
label: Paragraph

text: to the Arts and Crafts movement, but more
label: Paragraph

text: closely allied with the Queen Anne style,
label: Paragraph

text: was the development of what is now called
label: Paragraph

text: the Shingle Style. Houses designed in this
label: Paragraph

text: manner—often as summer homes for the
label: Paragraph

text: New England elite—show an inventiveness in
label: Paragraph

text: plan, with elements not merely touching each
label: Paragraph

text: other but seeming to pass through or overlap
label: Paragraph

text: with each other. The firm that developed this
label: Paragraph

text: style more than any other was McKim, Mead
label: Paragraph

text: & White (founded 1879), which eventually
label: Paragraph

text: became one of the leading design firms in
label: Paragraph

text: the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: William Rutherford Mead (1846-1928),
label: Paragraph

text: who had an affinity for the Renaissance,
label: Paragraph

text: and Stanford White (1853-1906) had little
label: Paragraph

text: formal training, but they worked their way
label: Paragraph

text: up as apprentices. Charles Follen McKim
label: Caption

text: (1847-1909), by contrast, had studied at the
label: Paragraph

text: a SS
