label: Caption

text: Ecole des Beaux-Arts. Between the three they
label: Paragraph

text: produced a style of architecture that brought
label: Paragraph

text: out the best in each of them. One of their
label: Paragraph

text: innovations in their Shingle Style homes was
label: Paragraph

text: to take the rooms of the servants’ quarters
label: Paragraph

text: out from under the attic and place thern
label: Paragraph

text: in a compact block or wing, against which
label: Paragraph

text: the more openly designed living rooms of
label: Paragraph

text: the first floor were contrasted. This can be
label: Paragraph

text: seen in the Isaac Bell House (1882-83) in
label: Caption

text: Newport, Rhode Island, where the staircase
label: Caption

text: was situated in a large room that served as a
label: Paragraph

text: circulation center and as a spatial extension
label: Title

text: of the neighboring study and drawing
label: Title

text: rooms. This makes it different from the more
label: Paragraph

text: controlled and boxy spaces of Arts and
label: Title

text: Crafts houses. Even though it was common
label: Paragraph

text: to raise the first floor above the level of the
label: Paragraph

text: ground, the use of porches made the house
label: Paragraph

text: appear as if were resting on an elevated
label: Paragraph

text: terrace, protected from the sun and rain by
label: Paragraph

text: generously proportioned overhangs and roofs.
label: Paragraph

text: The vertical surfaces of the houses were
label: Paragraph

text: completely clad in wooden shingles, using
label: Paragraph

text: a variety of possible patterns to differentiate
label: Paragraph

text: certain elements like the gable front. The
label: Paragraph

text: interior surfaces were usually covered with
label: Paragraph

text: dark wooden paneling in combination with
label: Caption

text: stucco, usually wallpapered but sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: left plain.
label: Paragraph

text: In contrast, the Watts Sherman House (1874)
label: Paragraph

text: in Newport, Rhode Island, by Henry Hobson
label: Caption

text: Richardson, is closer to the Queen Anne and
label: Paragraph

text: the Arts and Crafts styles. The rooms are
label: Paragraph

text: arranged in a more formal way and less open
label: Paragraph

text: to the hall, and the servants lived in the attic.
label: Paragraph

text: The overall massing is much more complex
label: Paragraph

text: than the more volumetrically simple Isaac
label: Paragraph

text: Bell House.

text: by President Abraham Lincoln, had a major
label: Paragraph

text: impact on the history of U.S. education. It
label: Paragraph

text: stipulated that each state was to have its own
label: Paragraph

text: university, paid for by the sale of government
label: Paragraph

text: land. No such educational policy had ever
label: Paragraph

text: been atternpted before, and no one could
label: Paragraph

text: have foreseen its consequences in shaping
label: Paragraph

text: advanced education in the United States.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite differences from state to state, the
label: Paragraph

text: early schools (known as land-grant schools)
label: Title

text: shared certain basic goals, including the
label: Paragraph

text: promotion of practical education, the right
label: Title

text: of education for all social classes, and the
label: Paragraph

text: reedom of students to choose their course
label: Title

text: of study. By the 1870s almost every state
label: Paragraph

text: ad one such university. Among the earliest
label: Paragraph

text: were Cornell University in Ithaca, New York,
label: Paragraph

text: and the University of California, Berkeley.
label: Paragraph

text: By the turn of the century, dozens of
label: Paragraph

text: private universities had also been built, and
label: Paragraph

text: ecause of the rapid professionalization of
label: Paragraph

text: the sciences in the 1880s, a new generation
label: Paragraph

text: of technical institutions emerged. The
label: Paragraph

text: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT),
label: Paragraph

text: founded in 1863, was among the first, but
label: Paragraph

text: soon there were also the Illinois Institute of
label: Paragraph

text: echnology (1890); the Carnegie Technical
label: Paragraph

text: nstitute (1900), which later became
label: Paragraph

text: Carnegie Mellon University; and the California
label: Title

text: Polytechnic State University (1901). The net
label: Paragraph

text: result of this combination of public, private,
label: Paragraph

text: and technical universities was a university
label: Paragraph

text: system unique in the world.
label: Paragraph

text: 17.62 View of Ithaca, New York, in 1882, showing the early campus of Cornell University
label: Caption

text: In terms of architecture, many U.S.
label: Paragraph

text: universities looked to English precedents,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Cambridge and Oxford, but toward
label: Paragraph

text: the end of the 19th century, the upper
label: Paragraph

text: classes began to see higher education in a
label: Paragraph

text: broader context as a maturing experience.
label: Paragraph

text: This led to the design of campuses with
label: Paragraph

text: sports facilities, dormitories, and a parklike
label: Paragraph

text: atmosphere such as the rural environs
label: Paragraph

text: Jefferson specifically chose for the University
label: Paragraph

text: of Virginia.
label: Paragraph

text: Universities built in this period by the
label: Paragraph

text: top firms in the country are still today some
label: Paragraph

text: of the most impressive accomplishments of
label: Paragraph

text: that era. Designs came in three basic styles:
label: Paragraph

text: Georgian, neo-Gothic, and Neoclassical. The
label: Paragraph

text: Georgian style, leaning on the tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: Harvard University, had individual buildings,
label: Paragraph

text: usually raised in brick, arranged around a
label: Paragraph

text: quad or “green,” as at Cornell University.
label: Paragraph

text: Differing from that was the neo-Gothic style
label: Paragraph

text: that offered an integration of life, study,
label: Paragraph

text: and sports; examples can be found at
label: Paragraph

text: Princeton University in New Jersey and at
label: Title

text: the University of Chicago, where there was
label: Paragraph

text: no central quad but a loose arrangement of
label: Paragraph

text: buildings in the landscape. The Neoclassical
label: Paragraph

text: was also frequently used—as for example
label: Paragraph

text: at Columbia University in New York City,
label: Paragraph

text: with its centerpiece, Low Memorial Library,
label: Paragraph

text: designed by McKim, Mead & White (1903);
label: Paragraph

text: the University of Michigan (1904-36) by
label: Paragraph

text: Albert Kahn; and MIT (1913-16), designed
label: Paragraph

text: by William Bosworth, with buildings arranged
label: Caption

text: around a central axis, and a domed library
label: Paragraph

text: modeled on the Pantheon at the symbolic
label: Paragraph

text: head of the composition.

text: ART NOUVEAU’S MAISON TASSEL
label: Title

text: Though Westerners had purchased Chinese
label: Paragraph

text: and Japanese tea sets, plates, and bowls
label: Title

text: for well over a hundred years and had tried
label: Paragraph

text: to imitate certain Chinese building types
label: Paragraph

text: like the garden pavilion, Art Nouveau artists
label: Paragraph

text: were stimulated by Japanese art, with its
label: Paragraph

text: sinuous ornamental patterns. Indeed, the
label: Paragraph

text: movement is named after d'Art Nouveau, the
label: Paragraph

text: shop of Siegfried Bing, a Parisian importer
label: Title

text: of Japanese art and himself the owner of
label: Paragraph

text: one of the important private collections of
label: Paragraph

text: japonaiserie. In London, James Whistler
label: Caption

text: was a brilliant promoter and adaptor of the
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese style. He and others admired, in
label: Paragraph

text: particular, the work of Kitagawa Utamaro,
label: Paragraph

text: whose woodcuts were known for their curving
label: Paragraph

text: lines, asymmetrical distribution of masses,
label: Paragraph

text: and boldness of composition. Furthermore,
label: Paragraph

text: the idea of coordinating a painting, its frame,
label: Paragraph

text: its artistic effect on the room, and even the
label: Paragraph

text: shape and proportion of the whole room,
label: Paragraph

text: already put forward by William Morris, was
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced by the perceived coordinated unity
label: Paragraph

text: of Japanese architecture. For Art Nouveau,
label: Paragraph

text: exclusive purity of style was not important.
label: Paragraph

text: Japanese themes could be fused with
label: Paragraph

text: Greek, Celtic, and—after Knossos had been
label: Paragraph

text: excavated in 1900—Minoan motifs.
label: Paragraph

text: Though Art Nouveau expressed itself in
label: Paragraph

text: the surface, it was far from superficial. In its
label: Paragraph

text: rejection of depth and perspective and its
label: Title

text: insistence on flatness, it foreshadowed future
label: Paragraph

text: dialogues on the validity of the representation
label: Title

text: of illusionary depth. Nature was no longer a
label: Paragraph

text: remote system of regulating realities, as it was
label: Paragraph

text: for the Enlightenment, but a sensuous play
label: Paragraph

text: of living forms. Biological forms were eagerly
label: Paragraph

text: embraced. Ornamentation was no longer a
label: Paragraph

text: sin but the means by which one could reach
label: Paragraph

text: behind the static world of appearances. A
label: Paragraph

text: door handle by Victor Horta (1861-1947)
label: Caption

text: loops in and around itself like a piece of soft
label: Paragraph

text: candy, one strand of which springs out into
label: Paragraph

text: space to almost accidentally form a handle.
label: Paragraph

text: Art Nouveau had parallels with the Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts movement in England, but there
label: Paragraph

text: were important differences. Whereas the
label: Paragraph

text: Arts and Crafts movement aimed to heal
label: Title

text: the alienation that had arisen between
label: Paragraph

text: man and his products as a consequence
label: Title

text: of industrialization, Art Nouveau stressed
label: Paragraph

text: creativity. While the products promoted
label: Paragraph

text: by Arts and Crafts were by no means
label: Paragraph

text: inexpensive, the movement carried with it
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual and therapeutic connotations and
label: Title

text: a back-to-the-land naturalness that was
label: Paragraph

text: ostensibly accessible to all; Art Nouveau
label: Paragraph

text: appealed mainly to the wealthy.
label: Paragraph

text: Victor Horta, active in Belgiurn, was
label: Paragraph

text: probably the greatest of the Art Nouveau
label: Paragraph

text: architects. In Maison Tassel (1893), Horta
label: Caption

text: brought out the expressive quality of iron,
label: Paragraph

text: which he used both inside and outside of
label: Paragraph

text: the house in the form of ribbons that appear
label: Paragraph

text: weightless, spiraling and twisting into space.
label: Paragraph

text: Since the floors were supported for the most
label: Paragraph

text: part by iron columns, rooms could open into
label: Paragraph

text: one another and be distributed in a novel
label: Paragraph

text: manner. Horta rejected the standard Brussels
label: Paragraph

text: building type, with the staircase to one side of
label: Paragraph

text: the building. Instead, the staircase, combined
label: Paragraph

text: with a lightwell, is placed at the center. This
label: Paragraph

text: allowed hirn to vary the elevations of the
label: Paragraph

text: floors in the front and back, with four floors
label: Paragraph

text: in the front along the street and three in the
label: Paragraph

text: 17.65 Section: Maison Tassel
label: Caption

text: back, and the main roams oriented in the
label: Paragraph

text: center. Interpenetrating space, as well as
label: Paragraph

text: the use of mirrors to enhance the feeling of
label: Paragraph

text: space, make the interior seem a world unto
label: Paragraph

text: itsel-—a sanctuary from outside life.

text: RISE OF PROFESSIONALISM
label: Title

text: Medicine and law were among the first
label: Paragraph

text: fields to be professionalized, starting around
label: Paragraph

text: 1860. Architecture lagged behind, long
label: Caption

text: considered to be more of a gentleman’s
label: Paragraph

text: occupation. By the middle of the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century, the professionalization of the field
label: Title

text: was gradually winning converts, especially
label: Paragraph

text: since the Beaux-Arts system was so
label: Paragraph

text: successful. In England, The Royal Institute
label: Paragraph

text: of British Architects (RIBA) was founded in
label: Paragraph

text: 1834, and with it came increased attention
label: Paragraph

text: on the education of the architect, with the
label: Paragraph

text: RIBA sponsoring lectures and publications
label: Title

text: on a variety of subjects. Professionalism
label: Paragraph

text: discouraged ad hoc, on-the-spot solutions
label: Paragraph

text: in favor of precise architectural drawings.
label: Paragraph

text: This is clearly demonstrated in the case of
label: Paragraph

text: William Butterfield (1814-1900), who is
label: Paragraph

text: often associated with the aesthetics of John
label: Paragraph

text: Ruskin. The first church he built required
label: Paragraph

text: only nine drawings; but for the chancel of St.
label: Caption

text: Mark’s Dundela in Belfast (completed 1891),
label: Paragraph

text: the contract was accompanied by about
label: Paragraph

text: forty drawings, including working details and
label: Paragraph

text: fittings down to the boot scrapers. The new
label: Paragraph

text: prerequisite for explicitness such as detailed
label: Paragraph

text: specifications and drawings had its effect on
label: Paragraph

text: the contractual relationship between client,
label: Paragraph

text: architect, and craftsmen. By the middle of
label: Paragraph

text: the 20th century, a building of any magnitude
label: Paragraph

text: would require perhaps one thousand
label: Paragraph

text: drawings, accompanied by a detailed
label: Paragraph

text: specifications.
label: Paragraph

text: In the United States, the American
label: Paragraph

text: Institute of Architects (AIA) had already
label: Paragraph

text: been formed in 1836. But, interrupted
label: Paragraph

text: by the Civil War and handicapped by the
label: Paragraph

text: very immensity of the far-flung continent
label: Paragraph

text: and the commensurate communications
label: Title

text: difficulties, architectural professionalism did
label: Paragraph

text: not really blossom until after the World's
label: Paragraph

text: Columbian Exposition of 1893 (also known
label: Title

text: as the Chicago World's Fair). The exposition
label: Paragraph

text: buildings, designed on a monumental scale
label: Paragraph

text: and integrated into a master plan, served
label: Paragraph

text: to demonstrate what professional architects
label: Paragraph

text: could accomplish. These architects included
label: Paragraph

text: AIA leaders Daniel Burnham, Richard M.
label: Caption

text: Hunt, Henry van Brunt, and Charles F.
label: Paragraph

text: McKim.
label: Paragraph

text: 00k of
label: Title

text: 17.67 View of an architect's office
label: Caption

text: The Tarsney Act passed by Congress that
label: Paragraph

text: year established the requirement for limited
label: Paragraph

text: competitions for federal commissions, with
label: Paragraph

text: institute members advising the treasury
label: Title

text: secretary, the federal official responsible for
label: Paragraph

text: governmental building appropriations. Though
label: Paragraph

text: the Tarsney Act was never fully implemented,
label: Paragraph

text: the status of the professional—as opposed to
label: Paragraph

text: an architect working as an employee of the
label: Paragraph

text: government—was increasingly secure. By
label: Paragraph

text: 1895, the AIA had more than seven hundred
label: Paragraph

text: members. In the first decade of the 20th
label: Paragraph

text: century, Daniel Burnham's architectural firm
label: Title

text: was the world’s largest and had become,
label: Paragraph

text: as discussed by the historian Mary Woods,
label: Paragraph

text: the model for countless later firms that
label: Paragraph

text: utilized global business techniques. This new
label: Paragraph

text: professional class had little patience with the
label: Paragraph

text: mid-century battle between classical and
label: Title

text: medieval revival styles. That does not mean
label: Paragraph

text: that Hunt, for example, who was schooled at
label: Paragraph

text: the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris and who
label: Paragraph

text: was a major advocate of architecture as a
label: Paragraph

text: profession, was indifferent to style; rather,
label: Paragraph

text: he had left the sectarian debates for a more
label: Paragraph

text: fluid and individualist appropriation of the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural vocabulary of the time.
label: Paragraph

text: INTERNATIONAL CITY BEAUTIFUL
label: Title

text: PLANS
label: Title

text: The exceptional success of the Crystal Palace
label: Title

text: exposition in London of 1851, attended by
label: Paragraph

text: an estimated 6 million visitors, triggered a
label: Paragraph

text: series of imitation events around the world
label: Title

text: designed to showcase their global reach. The
label: Paragraph

text: Exposition Universelle of 1867 and 1878
label: Title

text: in Paris boasted 15 million and 16 million
label: Paragraph

text: visitors, respectively, while the Centennial
label: Paragraph

text: Exhibition in Philadelphia in 1876 had 10
label: Paragraph

text: million. Finally, at Paris's 1889 Exposition
label: Paragraph

text: Universelle, the Eiffel Tower reported 32
label: Caption

text: million visitors—and in response, the United
label: Paragraph

text: States launched the Columbian Exposition of
label: Paragraph

text: 1893 in Chicago, ostensibly to celebrate the
label: Paragraph

text: four hundredth anniversary of Christopher
label: Title

text: Columbus's arrival in America.
label: Paragraph

text: Designed by Daniel Burnham, the
label: Caption

text: Columbian expo ushered in the golden era of
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts design and planning in the United
label: Title

text: States, with carefully detailed Neoclassical
label: Paragraph

text: buildings orchestrated along long and
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic axial lines, all designed to generate
label: Paragraph

text: a spectacular sense of the civic.
label: Paragraph

text: Inspired by the exhibition, city fathers
label: Paragraph

text: around the country began to draw up
label: Paragraph

text: plans following some of its principles in a
label: Paragraph

text: movement that came to be known as City
label: Paragraph

text: Beautiful. These cities included Cleveland,
label: Paragraph

text: San Francisco, Chicago, Detroit, Baltirnore,
label: Caption

text: and St. Louis. Although few plans were
label: Paragraph

text: 17.68 Boston Public Library
label: Caption

text: actually implemented in their totality, those
label: Paragraph

text: that were completed were very influential. In
label: Paragraph

text: 1900, Congress formed a special committee
label: Paragraph

text: to redesign Washington, DC. Committee
label: Caption

text: members included Daniel Burnham,
label: Paragraph

text: Frederick Law Olmsted Jr., and Charles F.
label: Paragraph

text: McKim of McKirn, Mead & White. Their plan
label: Paragraph

text: created the National Mall as we know it now,
label: Paragraph

text: with the Lincoln and Grant Memorials, along
label: Paragraph

text: with Union Station, which was designed by
label: Paragraph

text: Daniel Burnham. The plan also cleared slums
label: Paragraph

text: and established a new citywide park.
label: Paragraph

text: Pennsylvania Station in New York City
label: Title

text: (1904-10) featured a block-long Doric
label: Paragraph

text: columnar screen, a drive-in unloading
label: Paragraph

text: street, a central waiting room modeled on
label: Paragraph

text: Diocletian’s baths in Rome, and a steel-
label: Paragraph

text: and-glass hall and circulation platform
label: Title

text: leading down to the various levels. The
label: Paragraph

text: building was designed by McKim, Mead
label: Caption

text: & White, one of the leading champions of
label: Paragraph

text: the Beaux-Arts. Another example of their
label: Paragraph

text: work is the Boston Public Library (1895),
label: Paragraph

text: which faces Richardson’s Trinity Church
label: Caption

text: across Copley Square. Drawing on Henri
label: Caption

text: Labrouste’s Bibliotheque St.-Geneviéve in
label: Caption

text: Paris, its arcade, set up on a high base, has
label: Paragraph

text: the names of famous authors etched into the
label: Paragraph

text: spandrels. With its use of exquisite marbles
label: Paragraph

text: and mosaics, it was one of the finest U.S.
label: Paragraph

text: public buildings at that time. Its monumental
label: Paragraph

text: entrance leads up to the main barrel-vaulted
label: Caption

text: reading room, which spans the entire length
label: Paragraph

text: of the building, and its central courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: is surrounded by an arcaded gallery in the
label: Paragraph

text: manner of a Renaissance cloister. The library
label: Caption

text: also features thin tile vaults by the Catalan
label: Caption

text: master builder Rafael Guastavino.
label: Caption

text: In 1898, the Philippines was acquired by
label: Paragraph

text: the United States following its victory over the
label: Paragraph

text: Spanish forces in the Pacific. This gave Daniel
label: Paragraph

text: Burnham an opportunity to internationalize his
label: Paragraph

text: urban vision in the form of plans he made for
label: Paragraph

text: Manila and Baguio, though these were also
label: Paragraph

text: not fully implemented. Nonetheless, Burnham
label: Paragraph

text: acquired a formidable reputation in the
label: Paragraph

text: Philippines and around the world.

text: Newly united in 1901, Australians, under
label: Paragraph

text: Prime Minister Edmund Barton, were looking
label: Paragraph

text: for a style suitable to express their national
label: Paragraph

text: aspirations. Some atternpts at transforming
label: Paragraph

text: an Arts and Crafts— and Art Nouveau—
label: Title

text: derived interpretation of Australian flora
label: Title

text: and a Richardsonian-derived idea of civic
label: Paragraph

text: buildings (such as Edward Raht’s Equitable
label: Paragraph

text: Life Assurance Society Building in Sydney,
label: Caption

text: 1895) were finally rejected in favor of a
label: Paragraph

text: more progressive modernism, as can be
label: Paragraph

text: seen in the design of Canberra, Australia’s
label: Paragraph

text: new national capital. The winning entry
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1912 competition was by a young,
label: Paragraph

text: little-known architect from Chicago, Walter
label: Paragraph

text: Burley Griffin. Strongly influenced by Frank
label: Paragraph

text: Lloyd Wright's houses and Daniel Burnham's
label: Title

text: master plans, Griffin called himself a
label: Paragraph

text: landscape architect to emphasize what he
label: Paragraph

text: claimed was the organic derivation of his
label: Paragraph

text: design. His proposal also drew on the City
label: Paragraph

text: Beautiful Movement insofar as it featured a
label: Paragraph

text: picturesque ordering of the landscape with
label: Paragraph

text: intersecting axial geometries. He proposed
label: Paragraph

text: to use the irregular basin from the site to
label: Paragraph

text: create a series of interconnected water
label: Paragraph

text: tanks and even a lake, showcasing the
label: Paragraph

text: main government center and capital. The
label: Paragraph

text: rest of the city was spread out axially, with
label: Paragraph

text: star-shaped intersections forming the highly
label: Paragraph

text: visible civic centers and nodes of residential
label: Title

text: suburbs.
label: Paragraph

text: Although Canberra was not developed
label: Paragraph

text: until after World War II, Griffin created a
label: Paragraph

text: 17.71 Lucknow University Library, India
label: Caption

text: successful practice in Australia, designing
label: Paragraph

text: several houses and institutional buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: His architecture was derived largely from
label: Paragraph

text: Wrightian sources, particularly the latter's
label: Paragraph

text: California houses. Griffin's Creswick
label: Caption

text: Residence in Castlecrag (1926), his ten-story
label: Paragraph

text: office building in Melbourne, and the Keith
label: Paragraph

text: Arcade (1927), also drew on the decorative
label: Paragraph

text: motifs of local flora.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1935, Griffin took an opportunity to design
label: Paragraph

text: a library in India and left Australia. His last
label: Paragraph

text: set of buildings, therefore, are in Lucknow,
label: Paragraph

text: India, where he unexpectedly died in 1937.
label: Paragraph

text: As in Australia, Griffin tried to invent a new
label: Paragraph

text: architectural vocabulary—this time suitable
label: Paragraph

text: for modern India. He did not try to copy
label: Paragraph

text: Wright so much as to translate Wright into a
label: Paragraph

text: new national style and an alternative to both
label: Paragraph

text: the Beaux-Arts and European modernism.

text: THE GARDEN CITY MOVEMENT
label: Title

text: By the late 19th century, the great new
label: Paragraph

text: industrial Victorian cities of the world like New
label: Title

text: York had, despite their significant financial
label: Paragraph

text: success and clout, become overcrowded,
label: Paragraph

text: dirty, and violent. Many in the middle and
label: Paragraph

text: upper classes preferred to turn their backs
label: Paragraph

text: on the city for the comfort and security of the
label: Title

text: suburbs, with their socially and economically
label: Paragraph

text: stratified neighborhoods. The results shaped
label: Paragraph

text: the debate about the nature of a city. On one
label: Paragraph

text: hand, there was the uncomfortable density
label: Paragraph

text: of life, the cagey interaction between the
label: Paragraph

text: classes, and the persistence of poverty and
label: Title

text: grime; but side by side with these negatives
label: Paragraph

text: were the benefits of urbanity: the centers of
label: Paragraph

text: learning, the theaters, the libraries, and the
label: Title

text: concert halls. For every theory that decried
label: Paragraph

text: the city as an uncontrollable behemoth, there
label: Paragraph

text: were those who were deplored the blandness
label: Paragraph

text: and false security of the suburbs.
label: Paragraph

text: It was in an attempt to solve this
label: Paragraph

text: controversy that Ebenezer Howard wrote his
label: Paragraph

text: book Tomorrow: A Peaceful Path to Real
label: Title

text: Reform (1892), republished as Garden Cities
label: Paragraph

text: of To-morrow (1902). The city suggested
label: Paragraph

text: therein was to have the virtues of both
label: Paragraph

text: the city and the suburbs, but in a highly
label: Paragraph

text: controlled way that controlled or abolished
label: Title

text: the contested extremes and made for
label: Paragraph

text: pleasant surroundings. Howard's garden city
label: Caption

text: was not a suburb but a type of mini-city with
label: Paragraph

text: a core and a perimeter. It was not meant
label: Paragraph

text: to be fully dependent on a nearby great
label: Paragraph

text: metropolis as a suburb would be, but it was

text: Howard's vision did not arise in a vacuum.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: not far frorn Liverpool, was founded by the
label: Paragraph

text: owners of a soap manufacturing business;
label: Paragraph

text: in addition to factory-owned stores and
label: Paragraph

text: businesses, the town had schools, churches,
label: Paragraph

text: and training centers.

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: INTERNATIONAL BEAUX-ARTS
label: Title

text: Between 1870 and 1910 the global economic
label: Title

text: situation changed considerably. England
label: Paragraph

text: was at such heights that its slide was not
label: Paragraph

text: immediately noticeable, but by 1900,
label: Paragraph

text: England had to share its economic power
label: Paragraph

text: with the United States and, increasingly, with
label: Paragraph

text: the economic might of Germany. The rise of
label: Paragraph

text: Germany was not accidental. Its educational
label: Paragraph

text: system was first rate: by the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: century, Germany possessed a literacy rate
label: Paragraph

text: of 99.9 percent, an educational level that
label: Paragraph

text: provided Germany with engineers, chemists,
label: Paragraph

text: opticians, skilled workers for its factories,
label: Paragraph

text: skilled managers, knowledgeable farmers,
label: Paragraph

text: and skilled military personnel. In comparison,
label: Paragraph

text: literacy in Britain, France, Norway, Sweden,
label: Paragraph

text: and Australia was 30 to 50 percent. France
label: Paragraph

text: was certainly the world’s cultural leader, but
label: Paragraph

text: by 1880 it produced only 7.8 percent of
label: Paragraph

text: world manufacturing output, and by 1900.
label: Paragraph

text: this had dropped to 6.8 percent; that year,
label: Paragraph

text: Italy had only a 2.5 percent share of the
label: Paragraph

text: global market. Meanwhile, Germany’s output
label: Paragraph

text: had risen to 13.2 percent due to its greatly
label: Paragraph

text: expanded heavy industry; this, ominously,
label: Paragraph

text: gave it military capabilities that in time led to
label: Paragraph

text: World War |.
label: Paragraph

text: The most important rising economy of the
label: Paragraph

text: time, however, was that of the United States,
label: Paragraph

text: which grew considerably beginning in the
label: Paragraph

text: last decade of the 19th century. Following
label: Paragraph

text: the Civil War, the United States had already
label: Paragraph

text: begun to industrialize on a massive scale.
label: Paragraph

text: Raw materials were plentiful. Coal was

label: Paragraph

text: With the global economy centered on
label: Paragraph

text: England and the United States, formerly
label: Title

text: peripheral countries underwent an economic
label: Paragraph

text: upturn of their own, as materials and
label: Paragraph

text: products could now be advantageously
label: Paragraph

text: exported. This modernization at the global

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the underclasses. In South America, the
label: Paragraph

text: new upper class may have had factories
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the material culture, they more often than
label: Paragraph

text: not flaunted the latest of French fashions;
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: as a visible substantiation of their policies.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the consequences was that Beaux-
label: Paragraph

text: Arts eclecticism, with its associations with
label: Paragraph

text: the professional class, developed into an
label: Paragraph

text: international movement. There were few
label: Paragraph

text: major metropolises that were not touched by
label: Paragraph

text: this phenomenon.
label: Paragraph

text: These global realities left their most
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic imprint in Argentina and Brazil,
label: Paragraph

text: with most of its exports of beef, wool, and
label: Paragraph

text: wheat supported by heavy investments
label: Title

text: from England. Rio de Janeiro, during its
label: Paragraph

text: Republican phase from the 1880s to 1910s,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 1940), who was greatly influenced by Beaux-
label: Paragraph

text: Arts academicism. The Municipal Theater

text: Passos was designed to be reminiscent of the
label: Paragraph

text: Paris Opera.
label: Paragraph

text: The building of these structures coincided
label: Paragraph

text: with the development of pubic hygiene
label: Paragraph

text: and the introduction of electrical and gas
label: Title

text: services. As in Egypt, where debate still
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: of the neo-Mamluk style, in Rio de Janeiro,
label: Paragraph

text: a camp developed in 1910 that argued that
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: 19th-century Portuguese colonial architecture

text: because those structures were built by local

text: Today some ascribe Rio’s urban difficulties

text: SKYSCRAPERS
label: Title

text: If there is one building type that represents
label: Paragraph

text: the confluence of new materials, new
label: Title

text: strategies of construction, and new attitudes
label: Title

text: to capital and representation in the early
label: Title

text: 20th century, particularly in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States, it is the skyscraper. It did not appear
label: Paragraph

text: suddenly, for it took considerable time for
label: Paragraph

text: its function, production, design, and even
label: Paragraph

text: its purpose to be synthesized. The most
label: Paragraph

text: significant contributing factor was the
label: Paragraph

text: improved quality of steel, which allowed
label: Paragraph

text: prefabricated elements to be brought to the
label: Paragraph

text: construction site and erected with relative
label: Paragraph

text: rapidity. The technology of steel framing was
label: Paragraph

text: well established by 1890; in fact, during
label: Paragraph

text: construction, many buildings of that time
label: Paragraph

text: would look as modern as buildings of today.
label: Paragraph

text: Questions about how to design the steel
label: Title

text: frame were, however, the least problematic
label: Paragraph

text: part of the building. Elevators needed to be
label: Paragraph

text: improved and their operation guaranteed. The
label: Paragraph

text: same was true of the plumbing, electrical,
label: Paragraph

text: and heating systerns and the integration of
label: Title

text: all these systems with each other. At the
label: Paragraph

text: 1900 Paris Exposition, the designers of the
label: Caption

text: U.S. exhibition chose to emphasize just this,
label: Paragraph

text: using as an example the recently erected
label: Paragraph

text: eighteen-story Broadway Chambers Building
label: Caption

text: in New York City. The exhibition presented a
label: Paragraph

text: 4-meter-high model of the building with an
label: Caption

text: exterior skin in plaster that could be removed
label: Paragraph

text: to show the underlying steel frame, complete
label: Paragraph

text: with mechanical systems, boilers, pipes, and
label: Paragraph

text: furnaces. It was an eye-opening lesson in an
label: Paragraph

text: emerging architectural ideal.
label: Paragraph

text: From a financial standpoint, the idea was
label: Paragraph

text: relatively straightforward. An investor, typically
label: Paragraph

text: a bank, insurance agency, or newspaper,
label: Paragraph

text: would finance the building and use it as
label: Paragraph

text: home office, occupying the lower, walk-in
label: Paragraph

text: floor while renting out the rest to business
label: Paragraph

text: tenants. Besides having a stately home
label: Paragraph

text: office, the owner would have made a good
label: Paragraph

text: investment in a booming rental market hungry
label: Paragraph

text: for representative office space. The owner
label: Paragraph

text: company’s logo would be affixed to the top of
label: Paragraph

text: the building and beam forth its message.
label: Paragraph

text: The Woolworth Building (1911-13) in
label: Caption

text: New York City, designed by Cass Gilbert
label: Caption

text: in a Gothic style, was at the time of its
label: Paragraph

text: construction the world’s tallest building. It
label: Paragraph

text: was built for Frank W. Woolworth, owner
label: Paragraph

text: of the famous five-and-dime chain. The
label: Paragraph

text: whole was sheathed in elaborate terra-cotta
label: Paragraph

text: tiles with equally elaborate Gothic-inspired
label: Paragraph

text: detailing. The interior lobby had mosaic-
label: Paragraph

text: covered vaults.
label: Paragraph

text: This commercialization of styles
label: Title

text: resulted in an increased need to outdo the
label: Paragraph

text: competitor. Many early designers assumed
label: Paragraph

text: that a classical or Gothic front was still the
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate response, but in Chicago, which
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1890s had more tall buildings than any
label: Paragraph

text: other city in the world, a group of designers
label: Paragraph

text: were beginning to challenge that notion.
label: Paragraph

text: Among the most innovative was the firm of
label: Paragraph

text: Daniel Burnham & Company, which designed
label: Paragraph

text: the fifteen-story steel-and-glass Reliance
label: Caption

text: Building in 1894, with the principal design
label: Paragraph

text: credits going to John Root and Charles B.
label: Caption

text: Atwood.
label: Paragraph

text: Instead of the heavy cornice that is seen
label: Paragraph

text: in buildings like Dankmar Adler and Louis
label: Paragraph

text: Sullivan's Wainwright Building in St. Louis,
label: Caption

text: Missouri (1890), the Reliance Building is
label: Paragraph

text: topped with a thin square lid, and the top
label: Paragraph

text: floor, which houses machinery for heating
label: Paragraph

text: and other utilities, converts into a type of
label: Paragraph

text: frieze. Bay windows reach out into space,
label: Paragraph

text: giving the building an inner dynamic. The
label: Paragraph

text: insistent verticality of the Wainwright Building
label: Caption

text: has been replaced by a layered look; but
label: Paragraph

text: instead of appearing heavy, one floor almost
label: Paragraph

text: seems to float over the next, assisted in this
label: Paragraph

text: effect by the building’s spandrels, which are
label: Paragraph

text: lined with delicately ornamented white terra-
label: Paragraph

text: cotta tiles that give it an ethereal presence.
label: Paragraph

text: Wrigley Building
label: Title

text: The Reliance Building was more the
label: Paragraph

text: exception than the rule. A look of modernity
label: Paragraph

text: in tall buildings was not insisted upon and,
label: Paragraph

text: in fact, went counter to the idea that these
label: Paragraph

text: buildings were meant to advertise old wealth
label: Paragraph

text: and culture. For that very reason, most
label: Paragraph

text: tall buildings after the World’s Columbian
label: Title

text: Exposition were clad in historical styles. A
label: Paragraph

text: typical example is the headquarters building
label: Paragraph

text: of AT&T, the largest and most innovative
label: Paragraph

text: 17.81 Reliance Building, Chicago
label: Caption

text: corporation in the United States, in New York
label: Paragraph

text: (1912). It was designed by the Beaux-Arts—
label: Paragraph

text: trained architect William Welles Bosworth, an
label: Paragraph

text: American who had also studied at MIT, one
label: Paragraph

text: of the first institutions in the United States
label: Paragraph

text: to model itself on the Beaux-Arts system of
label: Paragraph

text: education. Corporate representation at the
label: Paragraph

text: turn of the century was a form of modernity
label: Paragraph

text: in its own right. In that sense, the skyscraper
label: Paragraph

text: was similar to the train stations of the 1860s,
label: Paragraph

text: and much like the train stations of the period,
label: Paragraph

text: skyscrapers competed against each other in
label: Paragraph

text: size and lavishness.
label: Paragraph

text: It is often argued that Beaux-Arts
label: Paragraph

text: modernism survived so long in the United
label: Paragraph

text: States because of the hold that the system
label: Paragraph

text: had on acaderne—but that is not the
label: Paragraph

text: only reason. Beaux-Arts modernism had
label: Paragraph

text: become the language par excellence of
label: Paragraph

text: corporations eager to promote themselves.
label: Paragraph

text: Historical awareness and reference to great
label: Title

text: architectural accomplishments of the past
label: Title

text: were an integral part of this ambition. That
label: Paragraph

text: was the reason Bosworth chose to model his
label: Paragraph

text: columns in the lobby of the AT&T building
label: Caption

text: on those of the Parthenon and also why, at
label: Paragraph

text: 17.82 Wrigley Building, Chicago
label: Caption

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: well-known manufacturer of chewing gum,
label: Paragraph

text: the architects placed a reconstruction of
label: Paragraph

text: CASA BATLLO
label: Title

text: Antonio Gaudi (1852-1926), despite his
label: Paragraph

text: obvious talent, was not a particularly good
label: Paragraph

text: student at the school of architecture at
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona. The Beaux-Arts academic
label: Paragraph

text: styles and rationalization of construction
label: Title

text: did not appeal to him; he preferred history
label: Paragraph

text: and economy. After a period in which he
label: Paragraph

text: apprenticed with various local architects, he
label: Paragraph

text: set out on his own. One of the characteristics
label: Paragraph

text: of his work was his use of color. His
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, more than any produced in the
label: Paragraph

text: 20th century, must be experienced in person
label: Paragraph

text: in order to be fully understood. Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: and Frank Lloyd Wright were consummate
label: Paragraph

text: colorists, but for Wright, color was a question
label: Paragraph

text: of patina, and for Le Corbusier, color served
label: Paragraph

text: spatial articulation. For Gaudi, color was
label: Paragraph

text: a tactile experience and sprang, as César
label: Paragraph

text: Martinell has pointed out in his research,
label: Paragraph

text: from the immediacy of folk sensibilities,
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean mosaic art, and Spain’s
label: Title

text: Islamic past. Gaudi experimented with
label: Paragraph

text: colored stone and glass, polychrome glazes,
label: Paragraph

text: and broken tiles and plates, and exploited the
label: Paragraph

text: shadings of stone and brick.
label: Paragraph

text: Despite the seemingly impromptu character
label: Paragraph

text: of his buildings, Gaudi was very much a
label: Paragraph

text: perfectionist, working out every project
label: Title

text: in great detail. The facade of Palau GUell
label: Caption

text: (1886-90) was completely redrawn twenty-
label: Paragraph

text: eight times, and some of its details changed
label: Paragraph

text: completely. This explains why it took him four
label: Paragraph

text: years to perfect the columns of the nave of
label: Paragraph

text: Sagrada Familia (1882-1926). The richness
label: Paragraph

text: of Gaudi’s forms might make his work seem
label: Paragraph

text: preeminently sculptural, but according to
label: Paragraph

text: him, his priorities were situation, measure,
label: Paragraph

text: material—and only then form. Already in his
label: Paragraph

text: first works, he was creating hyperbolic and
label: Paragraph

text: trumpet-shaped helical forms, but always
label: Paragraph

text: in combination with his refined sense of
label: Paragraph

text: construction. As a young architect, he could
label: Paragraph

text: imagine structural possibilities that seemed to
label: Paragraph

text: defy conventional wisdom. One worker once
label: Paragraph

text: waited hours after a particularly precarious-
label: Paragraph

text: appearing corbel had been constructed to
label: Paragraph

text: see if it would fall. It still stands today.
label: Paragraph

text: n the late 19th century, Barcelona had become one of the leading
label: Paragraph

text: Mediterranean ports, specializing in the trade of cotton and metal. The
label: Paragraph

text: wealth of the local bourgeoisie resulted in commissions such as the one
label: Paragraph

text: for the Casa Batll6 (1904-6) for Josep Batll6, a textile manufacturer,
label: Paragraph

text: which involved renovating an existing building. Gaudi modified the
label: Paragraph

text: inner court, introducing a staircase with a tautly undulating outline. The
label: Paragraph

text: facade shows wavy forms surfaced with ceramics in shades of blue. The
label: Caption

text: enigmatic, mask-like balconies and the stained-glass windows evoke
label: Paragraph

text: loral, animal, and geological motifs. The roof of glazed brick looks
label: Paragraph

text: ike the scales of a dragon pierced by the tower, which has at its top a
label: Paragraph

text: ead of garlic that morphs into a three-dimensional cross—perhaps an
label: Paragraph

text: allusion to St. George and the killing of the dragon, a story with much
label: Paragraph

text: local resonance. At the level of the piano nobife, the malleable forms
label: Paragraph

text: that seem to be made more of mud than of stone are held up by thin,
label: Paragraph

text: ony colonnettes “deforrned” in the middle and ornamented by vines.

text: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT
label: Title

text: The long and complex career of Frank Lloyd
label: Title

text: Wright (1867-1959) can be divided into
label: Paragraph

text: several phases: from the time he opened
label: Paragraph

text: his office in 1893 to the Robie House
label: Paragraph

text: (1908-10); the Taliesin phase (1911-14); the
label: Paragraph

text: period from the design of the Imperial Hotel
label: Caption

text: to Falling Water (1934) and Taliesin West
label: Title

text: (1938); and the period from the Johnson
label: Paragraph

text: Wax Administration Building (1936) to the
label: Caption

text: Marin County Civic Center (1957) and the
label: Paragraph

text: end of his life in 1959. His production was
label: Paragraph

text: vast and includes about four hundred houses
label: Paragraph

text: and a dozen or so other major buildings. By
label: Paragraph

text: the time Wright designed the Robie House in
label: Paragraph

text: Chicago, his style had become quite distinct
label: Paragraph

text: when compared to the Victorian mansions
label: Paragraph

text: that were then in vogue. Furthermore, unlike
label: Paragraph

text: other architects who changed style slowly or
label: Paragraph

text: at the behest of a client, Wright's break with
label: Paragraph

text: tradition was driven by a personal stylistic
label: Paragraph

text: development in search for ever greater
label: Title

text: abstraction. At the Robie House, its Shingle
label: Paragraph

text: Style origins can still be seen in the service
label: Paragraph

text: rooms, which are packed into a massive
label: Paragraph

text: block against which the building rests. The
label: Paragraph

text: hip roofs have been flattened so that they
label: Paragraph

text: practically disappear. The fireplace has now
label: Paragraph

text: become the spatial and visual hub of the
label: Paragraph

text: building, freed from encroaching walls and
label: Paragraph

text: linked only to a staircase.
label: Paragraph

text: The house is screened against the street
label: Paragraph

text: and no staircase is visible; it seems almost
label: Paragraph

text: defensive while, at the same tirne the design
label: Paragraph

text: emphasizes the linearity of the street. The
label: Paragraph

text: bands of white stone parapets form a series
label: Paragraph

text: of striations that rise to meet the dark-
label: Paragraph

text: edged roof lines, with the bands of windows
label: Paragraph

text: recessive in the shadows. The main floor
label: Caption

text: opens onto a balcony that runs along the
label: Paragraph

text: entire southern exposure. And in good Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts fashion, every aspect of the house
label: Paragraph

text: was designed by Wright himself, from the
label: Paragraph

text: carpets to the light fixtures.
label: Caption

text: A comparison of the Robie House with
label: Paragraph

text: the Steiner House by Adolf Loos yields more
label: Paragraph

text: similarities than are obvious at first glance.
label: Paragraph

text: Both give the client an interior environment
label: Paragraph

text: that is intimate, richly detailed, and crafted
label: Paragraph

text: down to the last detail. Both are also abstract
label: Paragraph

text: 17.87 Robie House, Chicago

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: While colonization had already introduced
label: Paragraph

text: many parts of Asia to Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: modernization, Japan was the first country
label: Paragraph

text: to embark on a self-initiated process of
label: Paragraph

text: modernization and Westernization. This was
label: Paragraph

text: done under the Meiji Restoration (1868),
label: Paragraph

text: which reinstated the monarchy following
label: Paragraph

text: the demise of the last shogunate. Anxious
label: Paragraph

text: about possible invasion and conscious of
label: Title

text: the weakness of the shogunate that had
label: Paragraph

text: aggressively worked to keep the colonists at
label: Paragraph

text: bay, the Japanese upper class forced the
label: Paragraph

text: return of power to the emperor and embarked
label: Title

text: on a course of aggressive industrialization
label: Title

text: and militarization. Delegations from Japan
label: Paragraph

text: were sent to European world exhibitions to
label: Paragraph

text: learn the latest technological developments.
label: Paragraph

text: Japan particularly cultivated a relationship
label: Paragraph

text: with Germany under Bismarck. The Japanese
label: Paragraph

text: also studied the Egyptian modernization
label: Paragraph

text: program under Isma‘il Pasha. Japan invaded
label: Paragraph

text: China and Taiwan in 1895, then parts of
label: Paragraph

text: Russia, and then annexed Korea in 1910.
label: Paragraph

text: The Kyoto National Museum (1897),
label: Paragraph

text: built in a French Baroque style, was meant
label: Paragraph

text: to mark the emergence of Japan onto
label: Paragraph

text: the world stage. This rapid introduction
label: Paragraph

text: of Western styles—even though it was
label: Paragraph

text: made as a way to compete in the rapidly
label: Paragraph

text: expanding global economy—engendered
label: Title

text: a backlash from traditionalists. Nationalists
label: Paragraph

text: denounced Western customs and by World
label: Title

text: War Il had forced the government to return
label: Paragraph

text: to a more traditional modality, at least in
label: Paragraph

text: outer appearance, for underneath the call
label: Paragraph

text: for tradition was a policy that continued the
label: Paragraph

text: modernization of Japan's military machine.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: ADOLF LOOS
label: Title

text: A stonemason’s son, Adolf Loos (1870-1933)
label: Paragraph

text: was born in rural Moravia, 100 kilorneters
label: Paragraph

text: north of Vienna. When he was nine, his father
label: Paragraph

text: whom he idolized, died. Loos’s relationship
label: Paragraph

text: with his mother, Maria Hertl, was strained
label: Paragraph

text: at best, and when he was twenty-three she
label: Paragraph

text: cut him off from the family, with just enough
label: Paragraph

text: money for a passage to the United States. In
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, Loos was enraptured by
label: Paragraph

text: the Chicago exposition, American industrial
label: Title

text: infrastructure, and the writings of Louis
label: Title

text: Sullivan. After returning to Austria, he settled
label: Paragraph

text: in Vienna, where at first he evinced much
label: Paragraph

text: enthusiasm for the Secessionists. But then
label: Paragraph

text: he began to denounce Secessionist art
label: Paragraph

text: and architecture, along with other modern
label: Paragraph

text: decorators such as the Deutsche Werkbund,
label: Paragraph

text: for their moral degeneration. In 1908
label: Paragraph

text: Loos wrote a now-famous article entitled
label: Paragraph

text: “Architecture and Ornament” in which,
label: Paragraph

text: relying on Jean-Jacques Rousseau's critique
label: Paragraph

text: of civilization, he railed against the use of
label: Paragraph

text: ornament as a degenerate form of art not
label: Paragraph

text: suitable for advanced European cultures.
label: Paragraph

text: For Loos, ornament was appropriate in tribal
label: Paragraph

text: societies, where it played an important part
label: Paragraph

text: in social interaction, but for an advanced
label: Paragraph

text: civilization, ornament was no longer a
label: Paragraph

text: relevant form of communication. Loos was
label: Paragraph

text: not opposed to using the color and texture of
label: Paragraph

text: natural materials for their ornamental quality,
label: Paragraph

text: however. His opinions put a damper on his
label: Paragraph

text: career, but he did secure a number of jobs
label: Paragraph

text: leading up to the design for a commercial
label: Paragraph

text: building in Vienna in a style now called the
label: Paragraph

text: Wiener Moderne; popularly, the building is
label: Paragraph

text: called the Loos Haus (1909-10).
label: Paragraph

text: By the time Loos designed the Steiner
label: Paragraph

text: House (1910), even the residual classical
label: Paragraph

text: motifs of his earlier work were gone, leaving
label: Paragraph

text: only a pure white exterior. The building
label: Paragraph

text: certainly anticipates—and indeed was highly
label: Paragraph

text: influential in—the modernist aesthetic that
label: Paragraph

text: would become the norm from the 1930s
label: Paragraph

text: onward, although it differed markedly from
label: Paragraph

text: later functionalist buildings. Here the stark
label: Paragraph

text: exterior was meant to contrast with the lush
label: Paragraph

text: and almost sensual interior. “On the outside,
label: Paragraph

text: the building must remain dumb and reveal
label: Paragraph

text: all its richness only on the inside,” Loos wrote
label: Paragraph

text: The Moller House (1927-8) is
label: Paragraph

text: paradigmatic of Loos’s approach. Its facade
label: Paragraph

text: is simple and rather forbidding, with the
label: Paragraph

text: entrance, balcony, and windows bound
label: Caption

text: together into a tight compositional unit. Since
label: Paragraph

text: the windows on the top floor face the rear,
label: Paragraph

text: the number of windows on the facade is
label: Paragraph

text: limited. Despite the external symmetry, the
label: Paragraph

text: interior is labyrinthine. The living and family
label: Paragraph

text: rooms on the second floor are separated by
label: Paragraph

text: steps and framed openings to create a range
label: Paragraph

text: of areas, some more private than others.
label: Paragraph

text: The interiors of the principal rooms are richly
label: Paragraph

text: outfitted with light-colored wood veneers on
label: Paragraph

text: the walls and oriental carpets on the floors,
label: Paragraph

text: creating a sense of sumptuous elegance.
label: Paragraph

text: In this respect, though Loos is seen as the
label: Paragraph

text: harbinger of the modern movement, his work
label: Paragraph

text: maintained a strong allegiance to the Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and Crafts ideal of interiority and intimacy.

text: THE FACTORY AESTHETIC
label: Title

text: By the early 20th century, factory design
label: Paragraph

text: had changed considerably over the previous
label: Paragraph

text: century. The introduction of electricity in
label: Paragraph

text: the 1880s freed the factory floor from the
label: Paragraph

text: cumbersome system of pipes, gears and
label: Paragraph

text: belts that had driven the coal and steam
label: Paragraph

text: powered machines during most of the 19th
label: Paragraph

text: century. Advances in steel engineering
label: Title

text: allowed factory buildings to become larger
label: Paragraph

text: and spaces wider. Glass was used extensively
label: Paragraph

text: to permit illumination. Skylights were
label: Paragraph

text: common, sometimes in saw tooth form or
label: Paragraph

text: as part of a Pratt truss. Flat roofs were also
label: Paragraph

text: adopted, since it was easy for fire to develop
label: Paragraph

text: in the old gable roof system, with its complex
label: Paragraph

text: wood supports. The development of concrete
label: Paragraph

text: provided a fireproof—although expensive—
label: Paragraph

text: alternative to buildings that were of brick,
label: Paragraph

text: stone, or terra-cotta. Standardized building
label: Caption

text: types became widely available in the form of
label: Paragraph

text: iron- and steel-frarned structures.
label: Paragraph

text: The late 19th century also saw the
label: Paragraph

text: emergence of a search for a factory aesthetic
label: Title

text: once it became clear that the building
label: Paragraph

text: was—or could be—used for advertising.
label: Paragraph

text: Some factories had main buildings that were
label: Paragraph

text: in a type of Gothic or Romanesque—and
label: Paragraph

text: occasionally classical—style. The Yenidze
label: Paragraph

text: Tabakfabrik (1907-9) in Dresden, Germany,
label: Paragraph

text: bloomed forth in an Oriental style, even
label: Paragraph

text: using simulated minarets and a glazed
label: Paragraph

text: dome to conform to the branding of its
label: Paragraph

text: cigarettes. Usually, such buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: designed without an architect. But even
label: Paragraph

text: when an architect was involved, there was
label: Paragraph

text: a noticeable difference between the image
label: Paragraph

text: of the building that the architect designed
label: Paragraph

text: and the factory itself, designed by engineers.

label: Caption

text: The latter was seen—at least until the advent
label: Paragraph

text: of modernism—as not really part of the
label: Paragraph

text: architect’s concern. The freedom engineers
label: Paragraph

text: achieved had resulted in a type of building
label: Paragraph

text: that was designed around the concepts
label: Paragraph

text: of function and utility. Decoration was
label: Paragraph

text: eschewed, but there was a desire to express
label: Paragraph

text: strength and stability. There was also a
label: Paragraph

text: contradictory desire for light, and the creation
label: Title

text: of long steel and glass walls paved the way
label: Paragraph

text: for what later came to be known as the
label: Paragraph

text: curtain wall, used extensively in skyscrapers
label: Paragraph

text: in the 1950s.

text: DEUTSCHE WERKBUND
label: Title

text: The transformation of Germany from an
label: Title

text: agricultural society into an industrial one
label: Title

text: and from a country with limited national
label: Title

text: and military goals to a world power on par
label: Title

text: with England occurred at an astonishing
label: Paragraph

text: pace. Between 1894 and 1904, the value
label: Paragraph

text: of Germany's foreign trade doubled, and
label: Paragraph

text: by 1913 Germany overtook Great Britain in
label: Paragraph

text: percentage of world industrial production—
label: Title

text: and did all this without a colonial empire.
label: Paragraph

text: Large companies like Friedrich Krupp Werke
label: Paragraph

text: (munitions, cannons, steel, and ships),
label: Paragraph

text: the Allgemeine Elektrikitats-Gesellschaft,
label: Paragraph

text: or AEG (turbines, electric railroads, and
label: Paragraph

text: equipment for the new German navy), and
label: Paragraph

text: Siemens-Schuckert Werke (railroad and
label: Title

text: electrical equiprnent) were supported by
label: Paragraph

text: the government through lucrative military
label: Title

text: contracts and protected from international
label: Title

text: competition by tariffs. Beginning in the mid-
label: Paragraph

text: 1890s and continuing until the outbreak
label: Title

text: of World War |, urban officials, functioning
label: Caption

text: under the tight control of the imperial
label: Paragraph

text: government and learning, belatedly, the
label: Paragraph

text: lessons of England and France, organized
label: Title

text: special exhibitions to promote and glorify
label: Title

text: German production.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the architecture and architectural
label: Title

text: quality of these exhibitions varied, they were,
label: Paragraph

text: for those who noticed, a bold showcase
label: Paragraph

text: for innovation. German architects were not
label: Paragraph

text: hampered by the Beaux-Arts system, which
label: Paragraph

text: was never implemented in Germany. For
label: Paragraph

text: the Nordwestdeutsche Kunstausstellung in
label: Title

text: Oldenburg in 1905, Peter Behrens designed
label: Paragraph

text: a highly abstracted and formal exhibition
label: Paragraph

text: layout with square structures, their surfaces
label: Paragraph

text: incised with simple geometrical forms; an
label: Paragraph

text: octagonal, domed garden pavilion; and a
label: Caption

text: rigorously symmetrical exhibition hall with a
label: Paragraph

text: central cubical space to which four smaller
label: Paragraph

text: skylight boxes were attached at the corners.
label: Paragraph

text: At the German Shipbuilding Exhibition
label: Title

text: of 1908, Behrens built an octagonal,
label: Paragraph

text: baptistery-like structure for the AEG. The
label: Paragraph

text: high altar was actually a ship’s deck on
label: Paragraph

text: which stood a great searchlight, the most
label: Paragraph

text: advanced of its kind in the world and the
label: Paragraph

text: pride and joy of the German navy. At a
label: Paragraph

text: 1910 exhibition of concrete manufacturers,
label: Caption

text: visitors saw Behrens’s all-concrete pavilion
label: Paragraph

text: for Zementwahrenfabrikanten Deutschlands
label: Title

text: (German Concrete Manufacturing
label: Title

text: Association).
label: Paragraph

text: At the 1914 Werkbund Exhibition in
label: Paragraph

text: Cologne, the dramatic Glass House by Bruno
label: Caption

text: Taut, who had a quasi-mystical fascination
label: Paragraph

text: with glass, was on display. It consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: two spaces: a type of crypt below, set within
label: Paragraph

text: a cylindrical concrete plinth, and a domed
label: Paragraph

text: space above. The crypt contained a pool at
label: Paragraph

text: its center, with water cascading down small
label: Paragraph

text: terraces decorated with pale yellow glass.
label: Paragraph

text: Access to the dome above was by means
label: Paragraph

text: of curving stairs at the top of the plinth, on
label: Caption

text: which rested a fourteen-sided structure of
label: Paragraph

text: concrete beams. On top of that structure,
label: Paragraph

text: Taut set the prismatic dome with a double
label: Paragraph

text: skin of glass—an outer protective layer of
label: Paragraph

text: reflective glass, and an inner layer of colored
label: Paragraph

text: glass—as if in a three-dimensional explosion
label: Paragraph

text: of light, color, and geometry. Apart frorn
label: Paragraph

text: the structure itself, all its surfaces were
label: Paragraph

text: made of glass, in keeping with the pavilion’s
label: Paragraph

text: purpose as an advertisement for the glass
label: Paragraph

text: industry. Walls were made of shiny glass tiles,
label: Paragraph

text: transparent glass bricks, and translucent
label: Paragraph

text: colored glass. Even the steps were made of
label: Paragraph

text: glass.
label: Paragraph

text: GERMAN CONCRETE
label: Title

text: Even though Ford's factories brought to the fore the
label: Paragraph

text: radical modernity of reinforced concrete from the
label: Title

text: point of view of civil engineering, the architectural
label: Title

text: question still remained open. While the expressive
label: Paragraph

text: potential in concrete's ability to take any form
label: Paragraph

text: languished in England—suffering in part under
label: Paragraph

text: Ruskinian proscriptions—it flourished in France and
label: Paragraph

text: Germany. If the French contribution consisted of
label: Paragraph

text: attempting to integrate concrete into the conventions
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural practices, the Germans contributed
label: Paragraph

text: toward its engineering. One of the earliest uses of
label: Paragraph

text: concrete in a major public building in Germany was
label: Paragraph

text: the Garnisonskirche in Ulm (1906-8), a Protestant
label: Paragraph

text: church that, as its name implies, was made for
label: Paragraph

text: and by a military base. It was designed by Theodor
label: Paragraph

text: Fischer (1862-1938), a prolific architect and noted
label: Paragraph

text: educator, and one of the founders of the Deutsche
label: Paragraph

text: Werkbund. He argued for a contextual modernity,
label: Paragraph

text: and his work therefore seems more neo-medieval
label: Paragraph

text: than modern today. Nonetheless, the building is
label: Paragraph

text: a landmark in the history of modern architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: The body of the church consisted of a reinforced-
label: Paragraph

text: concrete skeleton with brick infill. The towers
label: Caption

text: are huge empty silos 55 meters high, with a bell
label: Paragraph

text: chamber suspended between them.
label: Paragraph

text: A second important building was the Breslau
label: Paragraph

text: Jahrhunderthalle (1913), which showed off
label: Paragraph

text: the virtuosity and elegance of concrete. Part of
label: Paragraph

text: a campaign by the city to define itself as the
label: Paragraph

text: “Metropolis of the East,” it was designed by Max
label: Paragraph

text: Berg, Frankfurt am Main's building department
label: Caption

text: director, to serve as both an exhibition hall and
label: Paragraph

text: assembly hall. The Jahrhunderthalle (literally
label: Paragraph

text: “Centennial Hall”) was an enormous building, with
label: Paragraph

text: an enclosed floor space of over 5,600 square meters
label: Paragraph

text: that could hold ten thousand people. Due to the
label: Paragraph

text: fires that had broken out at a building of the 1910
label: Paragraph

text: world's fair in Brussels, the builders decided to use
label: Paragraph

text: concrete—the first attempt ever to use the material
label: Paragraph

text: for a building on that scale. The structure consisted
label: Paragraph

text: of four large curved arches that formed a continuous
label: Paragraph

text: ring on which rested the dome. To provide a more
label: Paragraph

text: secure environment against weather, the glazing was
label: Paragraph

text: not laid in the interstices of the ribs. Instead, Berg
label: Paragraph

text: designed a system of stepped glazing applied to the
label: Paragraph

text: outside of the dome in the form of vertical windows
label: Caption

text: and horizontal roofs. From the inside, the small
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal roof planes disappear in the light that
label: Paragraph

text: streams through the vertical apertures of glass.
label: Paragraph

text: EXPRESSIONISM
label: Title

text: Architecture before and after World War | was
label: Paragraph

text: surprisingly imaginative and experimental.
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism, as it soon came to be known,
label: Paragraph

text: had begun to develop before World War |
label: Paragraph

text: in the work of Bruno Taut and a few others.
label: Paragraph

text: Particularly influential were the writings of
label: Paragraph

text: Paul Scheerbart, who in 1914 published
label: Paragraph

text: Glass Architecture, a book describing a
label: Title

text: utopian architecture of colored glass in
label: Title

text: combination with sparkling jewels and
label: Paragraph

text: enamel. The Expressionists, despite their
label: Paragraph

text: differences, all envisioned an architecture
label: Paragraph

text: as far removed from classicism as could
label: Paragraph

text: be imagined at that time. The old notion
label: Paragraph

text: that architecture reembodied the power of
label: Paragraph

text: the past gave way to a desire to create an
label: Paragraph

text: architecture that spoke to the irmmediacy
label: Paragraph

text: of perception and the psychology of the
label: Title

text: beholder. As one commentator, Heinrich de
label: Paragraph

text: Fries, explained, “Buildings are in the highest
label: Paragraph

text: degree alive.... We can only guess at the
label: Paragraph

text: extent to which the art of spatial articulation
label: Paragraph

text: will one day transcend the art of pictorial
label: Title

text: creation.” Expressionism rejected the duality
label: Paragraph

text: of interior and exterior, and of building and
label: Paragraph

text: landscape. It also opened architecture to
label: Paragraph

text: influences from the other arts—in opposition
label: Title

text: to the Arts and Crafts movement, which had
label: Paragraph

text: hoped to integrate the artistic conception
label: Paragraph

text: within the framework of craftmaking.
label: Paragraph

text: The movement was particularly strong
label: Paragraph

text: in Prague between 1910 and 1914. In the
label: Paragraph

text: 1880s, Czech artists, dissatisfied with the
label: Paragraph

text: poor standards of the Prague Academy of
label: Paragraph

text: Painting, departed en masse for Munich,
label: Paragraph

text: a leading center for the German Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts movement. Many others went to Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: where they encountered the work of Auguste
label: Paragraph

text: Rodin, whom many Czechs admired for the
label: Paragraph

text: spontaneity and expressiveness of his work.
label: Paragraph

text: Other sources of inspiration were found in
label: Paragraph

text: French Cubism, which began to be exhibited
label: Paragraph

text: in 1908. But despite the pictorial innovations
label: Paragraph

text: of Pablo Picasso and Georges Braque, the
label: Paragraph

text: possibility of a Cubist architecture was not
label: Paragraph

text: pursued in France until the arrival of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier in the 1920s—and certainly not
label: Paragraph

text: in Germany, where French developments
label: Paragraph

text: were generally viewed with suspicion. The
label: Paragraph

text: introduction of Cubism into architecture in
label: Title

text: Prague was, therefore, path-breaking.
label: Paragraph

text: 17.112 Pavilion of Commerce, 1908 Jubilee Exhibition, Prague
label: Caption

text: One of the leading architects among the
label: Paragraph

text: Czech Cubists was Jan Kotera (1871-
label: Paragraph

text: 1923), a professor at the Prague School of
label: Paragraph

text: Decorative Arts, who actively collaborated
label: Paragraph

text: with Czech sculptors like Jan Stursa and
label: Paragraph

text: Stanislav Sucharda on his architectural
label: Title

text: designs. He saw prismatic shapes as
label: Paragraph

text: appropriate to the intellectual vitality of the
label: Paragraph

text: modern age. For him, structure had to give
label: Paragraph

text: way to the logic of visual dynamics. This
label: Paragraph

text: was also true for Pavel Janak (1882-1956),
label: Paragraph

text: whose idiosyncratic interpretation of
label: Paragraph

text: Cubism led him to shift toward tapered,
label: Paragraph

text: slanted, and triangular forms. He argued
label: Paragraph

text: that the orthogonal architecture reflected
label: Paragraph

text: its dependency on matter and weight,
label: Paragraph

text: whereas the new Cubist style, with its angles,
label: Paragraph

text: expressed the active nature of the human
label: Paragraph

text: spirit and its ability to prevail over matter.
label: Paragraph

text: After World War I, with the downfall of the
label: Paragraph

text: aristocratic regime in Germany, Expressionist
label: Title

text: architecture found one of its more realistic
label: Paragraph

text: voices in Hans Poelzig (1869-1936),
label: Paragraph

text: whose first major cormmission, the Grosse
label: Paragraph

text: Schauspielhaus (“Large Performance Hall”)
label: Title

text: in Berlin, had a plaster ceiling, hung from
label: Paragraph

text: the rafters, that looked like cave stalactites.
label: Paragraph

text: Thousands of light bulbs, variously colored
label: Paragraph

text: in shades of yellow, green, and red, were
label: Paragraph

text: embedded in the vault so that the whole
label: Paragraph

text: thing resembled both a cave and, when the
label: Paragraph

text: lights were dimmed, a starry night sky. The
label: Paragraph

text: foyer was supported by a single column that,
label: Paragraph

text: like a fusion between a fountain and a plant,
label: Paragraph

text: spread successive rings of colored petals
label: Paragraph

text: —also illuminated by recessed colored light
label: Paragraph

text: bulbs—until it reached the vault above.
label: Paragraph

text: 17.113 Pavel Janak’s study for a facade
label: Caption

text: 17.114 Interior: Grosse Schauspielhaus, Berlin
label: Caption

text: Another important figure in the Expressionist
label: Paragraph

text: camp was Hans Bernhard Scharoun (1893-
label: Paragraph

text: 1972), who rejected the crystalline shapes
label: Paragraph

text: of some of the other Expressionists in favor
label: Paragraph

text: of soft, rubbery forms. In his design for a
label: Paragraph

text: stock exchange building (1922), he warped
label: Caption

text: and bent space around the central lobby,
label: Paragraph

text: giving the appearance of a building that had
label: Paragraph

text: ingested the various aspects of the program.
label: Paragraph

text: In Italy, Expressionism took an even
label: Paragraph

text: stronger form under the name of Futurism,
label: Paragraph

text: initially a literary movement created by
label: Paragraph

text: Filippo Tommaso Marinetti in 1909—it was
label: Paragraph

text: his manifesto, Le futurisme, published in
label: Paragraph

text: Paris, that coined the name of the movement.
label: Paragraph

text: Marinetti was a keen follower of the Cubist
label: Paragraph

text: movement and even took a group of Italian
label: Paragraph

text: painters to Paris to show them recent work.
label: Paragraph

text: Soon, however, the Italians developed their
label: Paragraph

text: own distinctive style, significantly more
label: Paragraph

text: aggressive in tone in comparison to the quiet
label: Paragraph

text: utopianism of Scheerbart. The Futurists
label: Paragraph

text: were particularly enamored of technology,
label: Paragraph

text: speed, and machinery and expressed
label: Title

text: this in their painting and poetry. They saw
label: Paragraph

text: the outbreak of World War | as a positive
label: Title

text: development for the Italians and hoped it
label: Paragraph

text: would propel the young country into the
label: Paragraph

text: modern age. “Art,” so Marinetti stated,
label: Paragraph

text: “can be nothing but violence, cruelty, and
label: Paragraph

text: injustice.” The movement eventually came
label: Paragraph

text: to include architecture, and in a 1914
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto, Umberto Boccioni proclaimed the
label: Paragraph

text: movement's antipathy to the classical styles.
label: Paragraph

text: Ris
label: Title

text: 17.115 A drawing for a futurist Citta Nuova (“New City”) by
label: Caption

text: Antonio Sant’Elia
label: Title

text: Boccioni argued instead for an architecture of
label: Paragraph

text: “dynamic awareness.” The leading architect
label: Paragraph

text: among the group was Antonio Sant'Elia
label: Paragraph

text: (1888-1916), who built little but who made
label: Paragraph

text: influential visionary drawings of massive
label: Title

text: buildings with soaring heights.
label: Paragraph

text: In Germany, the Expressionists formed
label: Paragraph

text: several groups, such as the Arbeitsrat fur
label: Paragraph

text: Kunst (“Worker’s Council for Art”) and the
label: Title

text: Novembergruppe (“November Group,”
label: Title

text: named after the 1917 Russian Revolution).
label: Paragraph

text: In 1918, the November Group, in its first
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto, called upon Cubists, Futurists,
label: Paragraph

text: and Expressionists to join together in the
label: Paragraph

text: regeneration of Germany after its defeat in
label: Title

text: World War |.
label: Paragraph

text: The architect most associated with
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionism was Eric Mendelsohn (1887-
label: Paragraph

text: 1953 }, as famous for his drawings as for his
label: Paragraph

text: buildings. His sketches, many unrelated to
label: Paragraph

text: any commission, emphasized the building's
label: Paragraph

text: flowing silhouette. There are no pictorial
label: Paragraph

text: enhancements, no landscape features—just
label: Paragraph

text: the building without context, drawn in dark
label: Paragraph

text: lines on a white sheet of paper. Despite
label: Paragraph

text: his seemingly impossible and grandiose
label: Title

text: ambitions for the field of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn was an extremely successful
label: Paragraph

text: architect, even during the 1920s, and was
label: Paragraph

text: one of the first professionally successful
label: Paragraph

text: modernist architects, employing as many as
label: Paragraph

text: forty people in his office.
label: Paragraph
