text: 17.117 Einstein Tower, Potsdam, Germany
label: Caption

text: Mendelsohn was naturally drawn to concrete,
label: Paragraph

text: but the technology at that time was still rather
label: Paragraph

text: limited, and even though he first conceived
label: Paragraph

text: of the Einstein Tower in Potsdam, Germany
label: Caption

text: (1917-21), as a concrete building, it was in
label: Paragraph

text: actuality a brick structure with a concrete-
label: Paragraph

text: stucco exterior. The tower, his first major
label: Caption

text: commission, was built for the Astrophysical
label: Paragraph

text: Institute in Potsdam and is still in use today.
label: Paragraph

text: The building, surrounded by a forest, was
label: Paragraph

text: sited in a clearing on a plateau at the edge
label: Paragraph

text: of a drop-off. (The site is now somewhat
label: Paragraph

text: altered.)
label: Paragraph

text: The form of the building’s exterior in some
label: Paragraph

text: places seems to have been carved out; in
label: Paragraph

text: other places, it seems to have been molded.
label: Paragraph

text: In the vicinity of the windows, it seems to be
label: Paragraph

text: a soft encasement of a mysterious, angular
label: Paragraph

text: metallic structure within. In the approach
label: Paragraph

text: to the building, a set of steps leads to an
label: Paragraph

text: elevated deck that opens to the entrance
label: Paragraph

text: lobby, with one stair leading down and
label: Caption

text: another leading up the tower. The telescope
label: Caption

text: at the top of the tower transmits light to
label: Paragraph

text: instruments in the basernent laboratory.
label: Paragraph

text: Between the shaft and the base, to the
label: Paragraph

text: rear of the building, are study and sleeping
label: Paragraph

text: quarters for the scientists.

text: NEW DELHI
label: Title

text: In 1911, at a coronation darbar (“court”)
label: Paragraph

text: in Delhi, India, George V announced his
label: Paragraph

text: decision to build a new capital for imperial
label: Title

text: India, one that could unfalteringly display the
label: Paragraph

text: English determination to maintain British rule
label: Title

text: in India in perpetuity. Calcutta had always
label: Paragraph

text: been the seat of the colonial government, but
label: Paragraph

text: this was an accident of history. The English
label: Paragraph

text: chose Delhi to ensure the identification of
label: Paragraph

text: the new capital with the onetime Mughal
label: Paragraph

text: seat of power. A debate immediately raged
label: Paragraph

text: over whether the architecture should
label: Paragraph

text: acknowledge an indigenous idiom or reflect
label: Paragraph

text: the conventions of colonial neoclassicism.
label: Paragraph

text: After intense lobbying by advocates of both
label: Paragraph

text: sides, Viceroy Lord Charles Hardinge decided
label: Paragraph

text: that a design that was “plain classic” with
label: Paragraph

text: a “touch of Orientalism" would be best. His
label: Paragraph

text: solution was not much different from that
label: Paragraph

text: of a century earlier, when a classical revival
label: Paragraph

text: had been advocated based on the eternal
label: Paragraph

text: principles of classical architecture. With that,
label: Paragraph

text: the colonial ideologues were back to where
label: Paragraph

text: they had started—except for the “touch of
label: Paragraph

text: Orientalism.”
label: Paragraph

text: New Delhi’s master plan and the design
label: Title

text: of its principal building, the Viceroy’s Palace
label: Paragraph

text: (1921-27), was executed by Sir Edwin
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyens. The Secretariat buildings were
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Herbert Baker, who had just
label: Paragraph

text: completed the Union Buildings in Pretoria
label: Caption

text: to great success. The master plan reflected
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts academicism; a series of radial
label: Paragraph

text: spokes were elegantly stitched together over
label: Paragraph

text: 85 square kilometers to create an expansive
label: Paragraph

text: vision of a capital city. Different classes of
label: Paragraph

text: bungalows appropriate for various levels of
label: Paragraph

text: officers were distributed around its expanse.
label: Paragraph

text: At its center was the grand east-west path,
label: Paragraph

text: King’s Way, with the Viceroy’s Palace and
label: Paragraph

text: Secretariat raised on a hill at its western
label: Paragraph

text: terminus. The other end of King’s Way was
label: Paragraph

text: marked by a diminutive memorial to the
label: Caption

text: unknown soldier, designed by Lutyens.
label: Caption

text: tr
label: Title

text: 17.122 Viceroy’s Palace, New Delhi
label: Caption

text: Although they had a personal falling out,
label: Paragraph

text: Lutyens’s and Baker's designs harmonized
label: Title

text: well. Finished in red and yellow Rajasthan
label: Paragraph

text: sandstone, both sets of designs stress the
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal, utilizing the Indian chajja, or
label: Paragraph

text: overhang, to cast long, continuous shadows
label: Paragraph

text: that contrast sharply with the bright Indian
label: Paragraph

text: sun. Small chattris, campaniles, and domes
label: Caption

text: provide the vertical counterpoints. Baker,
label: Paragraph

text: ever more the imperialist than Lutyens, did
label: Paragraph

text: not hesitate to incorporate some elephants
label: Paragraph

text: and sandstone screens to make his designs
label: Paragraph

text: more “Oriental” in tone. But the general
label: Paragraph

text: impression of the entire viceroyal complex
label: Caption

text: displays the restrained and accomplished use
label: Paragraph

text: of a stripped-down neoclassical vocabulary,
label: Paragraph

text: arguably some of Lutyens’s and Baker’s best
label: Paragraph

text: work. Indeed, the greatest impact is from the
label: Paragraph

text: distance at the terminus of King's Way (now
label: Paragraph

text: called Raj Path), where the broad horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: sweeps off the complex effectively emphasize
label: Paragraph

text: the three domes and two campaniles.

text: With the exception of a few countries such

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: facilities, and urban layouts that separated
label: Paragraph

text: whites from blacks. Mombasa is an excellent
label: Paragraph

text: example. It had long been a busy port with a
label: Paragraph

text: complex multiethnic character. Its harbor, on
label: Paragraph

text: the eastern side of the island, had a narrow
label: Paragraph

text: entrance and afforded good protection. In the
label: Paragraph

text: 16th century, the Portuguese had hoped to
label: Paragraph

text: control the city but were never able to assert
label: Paragraph

text: their domination over the sultan of Mombasa,
label: Paragraph

text: who reigned over the relatively independent
label: Paragraph

text: city until the middle of the 19th century,
label: Paragraph

text: when it became a British protectorate.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1887, the city’s administration was
label: Paragraph

text: relinquished to the British East Africa
label: Title

text: Association, which envisioned it as the sea
label: Paragraph

text: terminal of the Uganda Railway (started in
label: Paragraph

text: 1896). The aim was to connect the city with
label: Paragraph

text: Buganda (part of present-day Uganda), a
label: Paragraph

text: wealthy kingdom on the north shore of Lake
label: Title

text: Victoria that the colonial powers were eager to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: hoped to set up cotton farms.
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Indian traders set up corporations alongside
label: Paragraph

text: the British, dealing in rice and coffee in
label: Paragraph

text: particular. In the 1920s, Mombasa became
label: Paragraph

text: Africa’s leading harbor for kerosene and
label: Paragraph

text: gasoline. Because the old city was compact
label: Paragraph

text: and not very large, the rest of the island was

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: the old town. To the north and south of
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: according to race and class, with separate
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and sports areas.

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: architecture, and it suddenly emerged in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: wing causes. The basic diagram of the house

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: slope. At the head of the U is the living room,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: DUTCH KAMPUNG
label: Title

text: While the English controlled India and most
label: Paragraph

text: of the China trade, the Dutch retained their
label: Paragraph

text: hold on Indonesia, in spite of several English
label: Paragraph

text: and French attempts to dislodge them.
label: Paragraph

text: However, late 19th-century wars with the
label: Paragraph

text: French, the Acehnese, and the Javanese put
label: Paragraph

text: the Dutch colonial government deeply into
label: Title

text: debt. In response, the Dutch set production
label: Paragraph

text: quotas, fixed prices, restricted travel, and
label: Paragraph

text: raised taxes. These policies were a disaster
label: Paragraph

text: and led to massive starvation in the midst
label: Paragraph

text: of burnper crops of export commodities. A
label: Paragraph

text: disgruntled young Dutch colonial officer,
label: Paragraph

text: Eduard Douwes Dekker, captured the
label: Paragraph

text: hardships of these years for the Dutch public
label: Title

text: in the 1859 novel Max Havalaar. The ensuing
label: Paragraph

text: outrage back in the Netherlands forced the
label: Paragraph

text: hand of the colonial authorities, and in a
label: Paragraph

text: series of legislative changes starting in 1870,
label: Paragraph

text: the so-called Liberal Policy dismantled the
label: Paragraph

text: forced cultivation of export commodities
label: Title

text: and opened the colonial economy to Dutch
label: Paragraph

text: private enterprise. The policy sparked a large
label: Paragraph

text: migration of Dutch to the East Indies, leading
label: Paragraph

text: to a forceful spatial assertion of European
label: Paragraph

text: identity against Indonesian and immigrant
label: Title

text: Asian societies. Using the Garden City model,
label: Paragraph

text: the Dutch carved their colonial space out of
label: Paragraph

text: what they saw as the congestion and filth of
label: Paragraph

text: neighborhoods in the colonial towns across
label: Title

text: Java and Sumatra, building Indian-style
label: Caption

text: bungalows set in spacious gardens with
label: Paragraph

text: outbuildings for kitchens and servants.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1901, the Dutch queen, Wilhelmina,
label: Paragraph

text: announced that the Netherlands would from
label: Paragraph

text: then on accept an ethical responsibility for
label: Paragraph

text: the welfare of its Indonesian subjects. This
label: Paragraph

text: announcement was a sharp contrast with
label: Paragraph

text: the former doctrine of profit-making. The
label: Paragraph

text: result, architecturally, was a search for hybrid
label: Paragraph

text: styles. In fact, the Indies-born but ethnically
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch architect Henri Maclaine Pont was
label: Paragraph

text: one of the progenitors of the Indische style,
label: Paragraph

text: an architecture dedicated to the fusion of
label: Paragraph

text: Dutch and indigenous approaches. Hendrik
label: Caption

text: Petrus Berlage, the noted Dutch architect,
label: Paragraph

text: characterized the challenge as one of pulling
label: Paragraph

text: together the universal qualities of Western
label: Title

text: modernism with “the local spiritual aesthetic
label: Title

text: 17.132 Site plan: Bandung Institute of Technology
label: Caption

text: elements of the East,” an early interpretation
label: Paragraph

text: of what later came to be characterized as
label: Paragraph

text: “critical regionalism.”
label: Paragraph

text: An exemplar of this approach was
label: Paragraph

text: Pont's design for the Bandoeng Technische
label: Caption

text: Hoogeschool {Bandung Institute of
label: Title

text: Technology, 1920). The twenty buildings
label: Paragraph

text: were laid out crossways to the site’s principal
label: Paragraph

text: axis in a Beaux-Arts manner. The wood
label: Paragraph

text: trusses of the buildings were left exposed on
label: Paragraph

text: the interiors of the halls in keeping with the
label: Paragraph

text: strictures of the Arts and Crafts movement,
label: Paragraph

text: while the roof form is a free interpretation of
label: Paragraph

text: the traditional Sumatran minangkabau roof
label: Title

text: systern found in many regions of Southeast

text: DE STIL MOVEMENT
label: Title

text: After World War |, Expressionism in Holland
label: Paragraph

text: gave way to a vibrant avant-garde culture that
label: Paragraph

text: focused on issues of abstraction and color; at
label: Paragraph

text: the center of it were Piet Mondrian and Theo
label: Paragraph

text: van Doesburg. The latter still had ties to the
label: Paragraph

text: Expressionist cause insofar as he advocated a
label: Paragraph

text: form of three-dimensional color environment.
label: Paragraph

text: As Van Doesburg explained in several essays
label: Paragraph

text: published in de Sti! between 1926 and 1928,
label: Paragraph

text: the essence of the countercomposition was
label: Paragraph

text: its opposition to the orthogonal character
label: Paragraph

text: of architecture and nature. Art, he argued,
label: Paragraph

text: in aspiring to the spiritual, must provide for
label: Paragraph

text: architecture an additional dimension—the
label: Paragraph

text: obligue—that architecture by itself was
label: Paragraph

text: not capable of creating, given that it was
label: Paragraph

text: shackled to weight and gravity. In that sense,
label: Paragraph

text: art, for him, was opposed to functionality as
label: Paragraph

text: well as to construction.
label: Paragraph

text: Van Doesburg was deeply influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by the work of painter Piet Mondrian. His
label: Paragraph

text: designs for a cinerna/dance hall, the Café
label: Caption

text: Aubette in Strasbourg (1926-28), which
label: Paragraph

text: involved broad compositions of colored
label: Paragraph

text: rectangles in relief, oriented at 45-degree
label: Paragraph

text: angles. Mirrors were placed between the
label: Paragraph

text: windows to reflect the ceiling and the three
label: Paragraph

text: other walls, all treated in a manner that
label: Paragraph

text: turned the architectural surface into a kind of
label: Paragraph

text: plastic relief sculpture.
label: Paragraph

text: One of the few examples of de Stijl
label: Paragraph

text: architecture is the Schroder House (1924),
label: Paragraph

text: designed by Dutch architect Gerrit Thornas
label: Caption

text: Rietveld, who lived and worked in Utrecht.
label: Paragraph

text: The client, Truus Schrader-Schrader, the wife
label: Paragraph

text: of a noted lawyer, wanted a house with as few
label: Paragraph

text: walls as possible. It is built at the end of a
label: Paragraph

text: block of conventional 19th-century attached
label: Paragraph

text: row houses, giving it views in three directions.
label: Paragraph

text: Rietveld exploited this to create a house in
label: Paragraph

text: which the volumes seem to be composed of
label: Paragraph

text: plains, some hanging free from the facade.
label: Paragraph

text: The principal colors were white and gray,
label: Paragraph

text: 17.135 Schroder House, Utrecht, Netherlands
label: Caption

text: with red, yellow and blue serving as accents.
label: Paragraph

text: The ground floor was relatively conventional
label: Paragraph

text: but the upper floor had numerous movable
label: Paragraph

text: walls that allowed for spaces to be opened or
label: Paragraph

text: closed as desired.
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Gropius rejected Van Doesburg’s
label: Title

text: position, as did architect Jacobus Johannes
label: Paragraph

text: Pieter Oud (1890-1963). They argued that
label: Paragraph

text: architecture needed to focus on social and
label: Paragraph

text: economic realities, rather than abstract
label: Paragraph

text: spiritual speculations.

text: RUSSIAN CONSTRUCTIVISM
label: Title

text: When Karl Marx, in the 1860s, critiqued
label: Paragraph

text: capitalist society and proposed an alternative
label: Title

text: world controlled by the proletariat, he
label: Paragraph

text: assumed that change would take place
label: Paragraph

text: in industrialized Europe. But when the
label: Paragraph

text: revolution did come in 1917, it was in
label: Paragraph

text: the under-industrialized country of Russia
label: Title

text: with a small working class. The Russian
label: Paragraph

text: Revolution capitalized on the prevailing
label: Title

text: anti-czarist sentiment to forge a communist
label: Title

text: vision that, like postcolonial modernist
label: Paragraph

text: attempts, sought to skip over the capitalist
label: Paragraph

text: age straight into communism. The Russian
label: Paragraph

text: avant-garde wanted a clean slate, seeing in
label: Paragraph

text: the new situation a singular opportunity for
label: Paragraph

text: manifesting the arts as politically purposeful
label: Paragraph

text: reality. Thus, the Soviet experiment, as long
label: Paragraph

text: as it lasted, was possibly modernism’s very
label: Paragraph

text: best opportunity to constitute and express
label: Title

text: itself as a cross-disciplinary social, political
label: Paragraph

text: and aesthetic rovement. It therefore
label: Paragraph

text: catalyzed modernists across Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: beyond and became, for a while, the
label: Paragraph

text: sounding board of international modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: The Russian Constructivists sought
label: Title

text: to push modernist claims to their limits.
label: Paragraph

text: The term Constructivism emerged at the
label: Paragraph

text: beginning of the 1920s and was closely
label: Paragraph

text: associated with the Society of Contemporary
label: Paragraph

text: Architects (OSA). This movernent was, arnong
label: Paragraph

text: the various tendencies, the closest to the
label: Paragraph

text: tenets of the European New Architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: and to the work of Le Corbusier in particular.
label: Paragraph

text: It was led by Moisei Ginzburg (1892-1946),
label: Paragraph

text: whose structures aimed to ernbody the ideals
label: Paragraph

text: of the new socialist order. For Ginzburg
label: Caption

text: and the Constructivists, art for art's sake
label: Title

text: was dead: art now had to reflect the newly
label: Paragraph

text: established truth of the world. To sever
label: Paragraph

text: art and by extension architecture from
label: Title

text: their subservience to the bourgecis class,
label: Paragraph

text: artists and architects had to draw their
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic from factory production, given
label: Paragraph

text: that industrialization, now controlled by the
label: Paragraph

text: communists, would, so it was presumed,
label: Paragraph

text: become the springboard for a truly universal
label: Title

text: human culture. Constructivism, though it
label: Paragraph

text: was grounded in an image of industrial labor,
label: Paragraph

text: was not a one-to-one translation of industry
label: Paragraph

text: into aesthetics, but it was the first modernist
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic that admitted, and in fact glorified,
label: Paragraph

text: the mass-produced object. Constructivists
label: Paragraph

text: used the term faboratory work to describe

text: Together with the Vesnin brothers and
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and other Cubists. During this period, his

label: Title

text: and gravity. Some of his more interesting

label: Paragraph

text: His artistic explorations and utopian
label: Title

text: theory coalesced in his project for a huge
label: Paragraph

text: that was meant to straddle the Neva River

text: in the center of Petrograd (St. Petersburg)

text: in celebration of the newly founded Third
label: Title

text: (Communist) International. The monument,

text: of which a 5-meter-high model was

text: built, consisted of three volumes of glass
label: Paragraph

text: suspended in a vast double spiral structure
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: The lower space, a cube, was to complete

text: one rotation per year on its axis to correspond

text: to the frequency of the Communist
label: Title

text: International General Assembly meetings.
label: Paragraph

text: The second space, a pyramid, was to rotate

text: on its axis once per month, corresponding

label: Paragraph

text: The third and smallest room, a cylinder,

text: There was a debate in the USSR

text: THE BAUHAUS
label: Title

text: In 1919 Walter Gropius (1883-1969)
label: Paragraph

text: was made the head of a new school of
label: Paragraph

text: architecture formed by the merger of two
label: Paragraph

text: older schools of arts and crafts. Significantly
label: Paragraph

text: less pragmatically oriented than the
label: Paragraph

text: Deutsche Werkbund, the Bauhaus sought
label: Title

text: to engender a new unified pedagogy and
label: Paragraph

text: vision that unified the arts and crafts, in
label: Paragraph

text: collaboration with industry. Though nominally
label: Paragraph

text: a national school, the Bauhaus was always
label: Paragraph

text: cosmopolitan in orientation, open to all
label: Paragraph

text: students regardless of gender, nationality, or
label: Paragraph

text: previous qualifications. Initially the Bauhaus's
label: Paragraph

text: purpose was to produce a new “guild of
label: Paragraph

text: craftsmen,” but that does not mean it was
label: Paragraph

text: reactionary, for Gropius also wanted a school
label: Paragraph

text: that could unify the arts and close the gap
label: Paragraph

text: between industry and craft. In that sense,
label: Paragraph

text: unlike William Morris, who saw craft as a
label: Paragraph

text: bulwark against industry, or the Werkbund,
label: Paragraph

text: which was seeking an industrialized craft,
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius was seeking to discover the internal
label: Paragraph

text: ethos of industrial production itself. The
label: Paragraph

text: question was not just how to make things,
label: Paragraph

text: but how to perceive and experience things
label: Title

text: as well. For that reason, Gropius brought in
label: Paragraph

text: painters, including Lyonel Feininger, Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Klee, and Johannes Itten. The celebration
label: Paragraph

text: of painters as form-makers reflected a
label: Paragraph

text: not-so-subtle shift away from the social
label: Paragraph

text: (and thus from the contentious political
label: Paragraph

text: issues of the time), toward the language of
label: Paragraph

text: abstraction and design. |tten was placed in
label: Paragraph

text: 17.146 The Bauhaus, Dessau, Germany
label: Caption

text: charge of the basic course required of all
label: Paragraph

text: incoming students. Its purpose was to free
label: Paragraph

text: the students’ creative powers and guide
label: Title

text: them toward a suitable direction in their later
label: Paragraph

text: studies.
label: Paragraph

text: In 1924, the reduction of funding from
label: Paragraph

text: Weimar, its host city, forced the school to
label: Paragraph

text: move to Dessau, where the Junkers aircraft
label: Paragraph

text: factory was located. Gropius used this
label: Paragraph

text: opportunity to reinvent the Bauhaus, purging
label: Paragraph

text: its faculty and stripping the curriculurn
label: Paragraph

text: of its more expressionistic and mystical
label: Paragraph

text: elements, to focus more single-mindedly on
label: Paragraph

text: an industrial aesthetic inspired in part by the
label: Paragraph

text: Junkers factory. Johannes Itten left and was
label: Paragraph

text: replaced by the Russian Wassily Kandinsky.
label: Paragraph

text: The city of Dessau helped finance a new
label: Paragraph

text: campus, which was designed by Gropius as a
label: Paragraph

text: signature, representative work. The program
label: Paragraph

text: of the Dessau building (1919-25) included
label: Paragraph

text: workshops, administrative offices, a lecture
label: Title

text: hall, and a stage, as well as workroorms,
label: Paragraph

text: a canteen, and student accommodations.
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius divided the program into two major
label: Paragraph

text: elements separated by a road and connected
label: Paragraph

text: by a bridge. The bridge, fittingly, was where
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius had his office: to go from the
label: Paragraph

text: classrooms to the studio spaces, one had to
label: Paragraph

text: pass by Gropius's office. The building was
label: Paragraph

text: not particularly unified in the classical sense,
label: Paragraph

text: for each element had its own programmatic
label: Paragraph

text: logic. The dormitory at the east end stood

text: the Nazis in 1933.

text: LE CORBUSIER AND VERS UNE
label: Title

text: ARCHITECTURE
label: Title

text: Due to the dominance of the Beaux-Arts system,
label: Paragraph

text: the innovations in design that were taking place
label: Paragraph

text: in other parts of Europe and in the United States
label: Paragraph

text: had only minimal resonance in France. For
label: Paragraph

text: modernism to develop it needed someone who
label: Paragraph

text: could break its cultural isolation and provide a
label: Paragraph

text: suitable alternative. That person was Charles-
label: Paragraph

text: Edouard Jeanneret-Gris, who later changed
label: Paragraph

text: his name to Le Corbusier (1887-1965). A
label: Paragraph

text: Swiss-born architect who worked briefly in the
label: Paragraph

text: offices of Auguste Perret and Peter Behrens,
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier moved permanently to Paris in
label: Paragraph

text: 1916, at the age of twenty-nine. Le Corbusier's
label: Caption

text: articles in L’Esprit nouveau, as well as his
label: Paragraph

text: epochal 1923 book Vers une architecture
label: Title

text: (Towards a New Architecture), became the most
label: Paragraph

text: significant summary statements of the ideals of
label: Paragraph

text: the modernist movement to appear since World
label: Title

text: War |.
label: Paragraph

text: Jeanneret began his career designing
label: Paragraph

text: houses in the Art and Crafts style in his native
label: Paragraph

text: city of La Chaux-de-Fonds in Switzerland. But
label: Paragraph

text: once in Paris, and after a travel tour to Turkey,
label: Paragraph

text: Greece, Italy, and other parts of Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: the Mediterranean in 1911, he allowed his
label: Paragraph

text: unique style to develop rapidly. He was strongly
label: Paragraph

text: influenced by the modern painters, particularly
label: Paragraph

text: the Cubists. In 1920, he took on the name
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier. Vers une architecture outlined
label: Caption

text: Five Points toward a New Architecture: the
label: Title

text: pifotis (stilts) that support the building, the free
label: Paragraph

text: plan with the only structural support coming in
label: Paragraph

text: the form of columns, the free facade, the strip
label: Paragraph

text: window, and the roof terrace. These features,
label: Paragraph

text: he argued, were based on structural properties
label: Paragraph

text: of reinforced concrete as well as the increasing
label: Paragraph

text: availability of mass-produced architectural
label: Title

text: elements. They also allowed the architect to work
label: Paragraph

text: with pragmatic forms. The idea of the pilotis
label: Paragraph

text: was to remain with Le Corbusier throughout his
label: Paragraph

text: career. Inspired by Rousseauesque thinking
label: Paragraph

text: that invested undisturbed nature with an ideal
label: Paragraph

text: of plenitude, Le Corbusier’s pilotis were meant
label: Paragraph

text: to liberate the land from the oppression of a
label: Paragraph

text: building that interrupted its flow and rhythm.
label: Paragraph

text: Villa Savoye
label: Title

text: In the 1920s, Le Corbusier designed a series of
label: Paragraph

text: houses in Paris and its suburbs that explored
label: Paragraph

text: and demonstrated the possibilities of his Five
label: Paragraph

text: Paints. The Maisons La Roche-Jeanneret (1923),
label: Caption

text: which now houses the Fondation Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: was a combined set of houses for two different
label: Paragraph

text: clients. Le Corbusier responded to the spatial
label: Paragraph

text: 17.152 Villa Savoye, Poissy, Paris
label: Caption

text: demands of the different households by designing interweaving layers of
label: Paragraph

text: spaces, connected by a central court. The house was painted white, but on
label: Paragraph

text: the inside, walls were painted in a variety of soft hues of red, yellow, and
label: Paragraph

text: blue, as well as white.
label: Paragraph

text: His most influential work from this time was the Villa Savoye (1931) at
label: Paragraph

text: Poissy, a suburb of Paris, where the client owned a large parcel of land that
label: Paragraph

text: swelled up to a gentle hill. At its apex, Le Corbusier placed a cubic volume,
label: Paragraph

text: lifted on pilotis, a column-and-slab construction in reinforced concrete. The
label: Paragraph

text: walls were built of brick and stuccoed over. The plans on every floor were
label: Paragraph

text: customized to their functional requirements, and a simple strip window was
label: Paragraph

text: the centerpiece of the elevation.
label: Caption

text: The ground-floor plan was designed around the turning radius of the
label: Paragraph

text: client's automobile, which, after dropping off his employer at the entry
label: Paragraph

text: on axis with the center, was to be parked by the chauffeur in parking
label: Paragraph

text: slots located around the curve. (In Vers une architecture, Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: ad praised the design of the modern French automobile as an aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: achievement as great as the Parthenon.) Inside the front door and past the
label: Paragraph

text: chauffeur’s quarters, a carefully designed ramp rises up the middle of the
label: Paragraph

text: villa. Living spaces were arranged around the ramp on three sides on the
label: Paragraph

text: irst floor. A terrace fills up the rest. The ramp reverses direction and ends
label: Paragraph

text: on the roof, where a freestanding wall with a single window self-consciously
label: Paragraph

text: rames the landscape. Although Le Corbusier celebrated the automobile, he
label: Paragraph

text: also designed the building as a prornenade with experiences unfolding at
label: Paragraph

text: every turn. Once again, though the exterior was white (apart from the red
label: Paragraph

text: entrance door), some of the interior walls were painted in pastel hues of
label: Paragraph

text: eige, rose, and blue.

label: Title

text: Modernist architecture did not produce any
label: Paragraph

text: major inroads in the United States until the
label: Paragraph

text: 1940s, with the arrival of Walter Gropius
label: Paragraph

text: and Mies van der Rohe. There are two
label: Paragraph

text: principal reasons for American resistance
label: Title

text: to modernism: Beaux-Arts architecture
label: Title

text: was still strong and taught in architecture
label: Paragraph

text: schools; and Frank Lloyd Wright, the
label: Paragraph

text: dominant American architect of the time,
label: Paragraph

text: was a trenchant critic of the Europeans’ boxy,
label: Paragraph

text: unadorned aesthetic.
label: Paragraph

text: Early examples of European modernist
label: Title

text: architecture in the United States are thus
label: Paragraph

text: few and center on the work of two architects,
label: Paragraph

text: Rudolf Michael Schindler (1887-1953) and
label: Title

text: Richard Neutra (1892-1970). Schindler,
label: Caption

text: whose work was very much underappreciated
label: Paragraph

text: at the time, was born in Austria but moved
label: Paragraph

text: to the United States in 1914. He found
label: Paragraph

text: employment in the office of Wright until
label: Paragraph

text: branching out on his own, setting the tone
label: Paragraph

text: for an architecture that had never been seen
label: Paragraph

text: in the United States with his Lovell Beach
label: Paragraph

text: House (1922-26). It was not a house in

label: Paragraph

text: Weissenhof Siedlung
label: Title

text: In the late 1920s, with the German economy
label: Paragraph

text: slowly gaining steam after the inflationary
label: Paragraph

text: crisis of 1923, housing projects sponsored
label: Paragraph

text: by municipal and state governments and
label: Paragraph

text: cooperative building societies had begun to
label: Paragraph

text: be built across Germany. To support these
label: Paragraph

text: efforts, the Deutsche Werkbund, at the time
label: Paragraph

text: under a pro-modernist leadership, sponsored
label: Paragraph

text: an exhibition of houses to be designed by
label: Paragraph

text: architects from all over Europe. Stuttgart was
label: Paragraph

text: chosen as the site because of the progressive
label: Paragraph

text: politics of its regional government. Ludwig
label: Paragraph

text: Mies van der Rohe headed the project,
label: Paragraph

text: which opened in 1927. What was presented
label: Paragraph

text: to the world was an entire housing estate
label: Paragraph

text: (or Siedfung) dedicated to avant-garde
label: Paragraph

text: European modernist thinking. Included in the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition were buildings by Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Gropius, Adolf Loos, J. J. P. Oud,
label: Caption

text: Hans Scharoun, and Bruno Taut, among
label: Paragraph

text: others. Initially, Mies even hoped that Erich
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn and Henry van der Velde would
label: Title

text: contribute—a wish that did not materialize.
label: Paragraph

text: Mies organized the buildings into a
label: Paragraph

text: loose rectangular composition above a
label: Paragraph

text: broad, S-shaped road that followed the
label: Paragraph

text: slope of the land, with the taller buildings
label: Paragraph

text: at the top. To create a unified image, all the
label: Paragraph

text: architects had to employ flat roofs and white
label: Paragraph

text: facades. Included in the exhibition were
label: Paragraph

text: rowhouses, duplexes, single-family houses,
label: Paragraph

text: and apartment buildings. The Weissenhof
label: Paragraph

text: Siedlung marked a turning point in the history
label: Paragraph

text: of modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the movement was hardly uniform—.
label: Paragraph

text: there were important differences among its
label: Paragraph

text: leading rembers—the exhibition created
label: Paragraph

text: for the public, and indeed for the architects
label: Paragraph

text: themselves, the appearance of a common
label: Paragraph

text: mission.
label: Paragraph

text: The building that Mies designed for the
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition, an apartment block, showcased
label: Paragraph

text: the earliest use of structural steel in an
label: Paragraph

text: apartment building in Europe. The steel
label: Paragraph

text: allowed Mies to create thin, non-load-bearing
label: Paragraph

text: 18.5 Mies van der Rohe’s apartment block, Weissenhof Siedlung
label: Caption

text: walls on the interior. As would become
label: Paragraph

text: his custom, he combined the walls that
label: Paragraph

text: contained the water and plumbing pipes with
label: Paragraph

text: stairwell walls to create a core that repeated
label: Paragraph

text: itself on the various floors. This core is in
label: Paragraph

text: the shape of a two-pronged fork, with the
label: Paragraph

text: staircase between the prongs. The walls
label: Caption

text: contained the plumbing and water pipes for
label: Paragraph

text: the kitchens and bathrooms. It was a brilliant
label: Paragraph

text: and simple compression—and unification—of
label: Paragraph

text: structure, space, and function.
label: Paragraph

text: 18.6 Two houses by Le Corbusier, Weissenhof Siedlung
label: Caption

text: Le Corbusier's building, by contrast, followed
label: Paragraph

text: the principles of his Five Points. It was
label: Paragraph

text: elevated against the slope of a hill and had
label: Paragraph

text: a roof terrace with a pergola and planters.
label: Caption

text: Much as in Mies’s plan, Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: interior is almost completely open, but in
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier's case the partition walls do
label: Paragraph

text: not reach the facade. There are no rooms
label: Paragraph

text: in the conventional sense, but rather a
label: Paragraph

text: typically French enfilade organization along
label: Paragraph

text: the facade. The kitchen, bath, and toilet are
label: Caption

text: lined up against the far wall, which might
label: Paragraph

text: seem reasonable given the need for pipes
label: Paragraph

text: and ventilation. But the wall is suspended in
label: Paragraph

text: space and thus the pipes had to be hidden
label: Paragraph

text: in the floor.
label: Paragraph

text: Both buildings speak to the image of
label: Paragraph

text: the new, modern man. Mies’s building
label: Caption

text: organizes the service elements around their
label: Paragraph

text: unctionality, separating the bodily functions,
label: Paragraph

text: ike eating and bathing, from empty space.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier organizes the space around
label: Paragraph

text: culturally based hierarchies, while bathing
label: Paragraph

text: and cooking areas are whittled down and
label: Paragraph

text: placed in marginal spaces. Although the
label: Paragraph

text: jouses of the Sied/ung ( twenty-one in all)
label: Caption

text: were designed for the working class—the
label: Paragraph

text: intended beneficiary of modernist politics—
label: Paragraph

text: the actual cost would have been way out
label: Paragraph

text: of reach for most workers. This disparity
label: Paragraph

text: etween the avowed politics of the modernist
label: Title

text: jouse and its actual consumption, only by
label: Paragraph

text: the rich elite, continues to dog it even today.

text: 18.9 Hanna House, Palo Alto, California
label: Caption

text: Usonian Houses
label: Title

text: Throughout the 1930s, Frank Lloyd Wright
label: Paragraph

text: continued to critique both the Beaux-Arts
label: Paragraph

text: and modernist styles. Instead, he tried to
label: Paragraph

text: infuse modernism with a national Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: sentiment—in his case holding out the ideal
label: Paragraph

text: of democracy rooted in a simple life closely
label: Title

text: connected with the land. The traditional
label: Paragraph

text: city, which derived from Europe, he argued,
label: Paragraph

text: would eventually be replaced by a dispersed
label: Paragraph

text: network of habitation. Anticipating this, he
label: Paragraph

text: designed a futuristic Broadacre City (1932)
label: Caption

text: that was to cover 10 square kilometers.
label: Paragraph

text: Though Broadacre remained a utopian
label: Paragraph

text: project, Wright was able to realize certain
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of it with his Usonian houses. The
label: Paragraph

text: origin of the name Usonian is unknown;
label: Paragraph

text: but it is likely derived from U_S.onia, the
label: Paragraph

text: name for a reformed American society that
label: Paragraph

text: Wright tried to bring about for twenty-five
label: Paragraph

text: years. In the United States there had been
label: Paragraph

text: a long tradition of pattern-book houses that
label: Paragraph

text: could be constructed without an architect
label: Paragraph

text: by local builders, such as the Arts and
label: Paragraph

text: Crafts bungalows. Wright's Usonian houses
label: Caption

text: extended that tradition, except that what was
label: Paragraph

text: imitated was not so much the individual plans
label: Paragraph

text: as the general idea.
label: Paragraph

text: The Great Depression of 1929 had left
label: Paragraph

text: millions homeless in the United States, and
label: Paragraph

text: Wright was eager to show that his housing,
label: Paragraph

text: in contrast to that of a Weissenhof, could
label: Paragraph

text: accommodate the changed economic
label: Title

text: conditions without loss of integrity. Wright
label: Caption

text: proposed a single-story house that did not
label: Paragraph

text: require expensive excavations for basements
label: Paragraph

text: or upper-floor framing. Steel, which was
label: Paragraph

text: expensive, was not used; instead, the houses
label: Paragraph

text: were to be made of wood, brick, local stone,
label: Paragraph

text: and prefabricated blocks. The bricks were
label: Paragraph

text: not covered with stucco and the wood was
label: Paragraph

text: left plain, thus reducing finishing costs. The
label: Paragraph

text: houses were sited not only to make optimal
label: Paragraph

text: use of the lot, but also to include as much
label: Paragraph

text: openness as possible frorn the living room to
label: Paragraph

text: the backyard. Heating was incorporated into
label: Paragraph

text: the concrete floor in the form of looped water
label: Paragraph

text: pipes buried under the slab. The elaborate
label: Paragraph

text: and expensive millwork needed to conceal
label: Paragraph

text: radiators in Prairie houses could thus be
label: Paragraph

text: eliminated.
label: Paragraph

text: Wright fused the dining and living rooms and
label: Paragraph

text: in some cases combined them into a single
label: Paragraph

text: space. This was a radical departure fromm his
label: Paragraph

text: earlier houses, and indeed from centuries of
label: Paragraph

text: tradition: because of noise, smells, and the
label: Paragraph

text: activities of servants, the kitchen was always
label: Paragraph

text: set apart from the dining room. But the
label: Paragraph

text: owners of these houses were not expected to
label: Paragraph

text: be wealthy enough to afford a maid. Wright
label: Paragraph

text: also wanted to create spaces that were
label: Paragraph

text: conducive to family conversation. The kitchen
label: Caption

text: was placed close to the carport as well,
label: Paragraph

text: minimizing the distance between the car and
label: Paragraph

text: the kitchen to facilitate the transportation of
label: Paragraph

text: groceries.
label: Paragraph

text: 18.11 Unité d'habitation, Marseille, France
label: Caption

text: Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture Moderne
label: Title

text: From the early 20th century onward,
label: Paragraph

text: European architects banded together in
label: Paragraph

text: various organizations to define their position
label: Paragraph

text: and forward their cause in political and
label: Paragraph

text: cultural matters. The Werkbund, which
label: Paragraph

text: still exists today, was founded in 1907 in
label: Paragraph

text: Munich and had among its members Peter
label: Paragraph

text: Behrens, Walter Gropius, and Bruno Taut.
label: Paragraph

text: The Novembergruppe, formed in Berlin in
label: Paragraph

text: 1918, though short-lived, was more clearly
label: Paragraph

text: pro-modern, seeing the postwar economy
label: Paragraph

text: as an opportunity to rethink social relations
label: Paragraph

text: and architectural expression. The group
label: Paragraph

text: that had the most important impact on
label: Paragraph

text: architectural thinking, however, was the
label: Paragraph

text: Congrés Internationaux d’Architecture
label: Title

text: Moderne (CIAM, 1928-45), which came
label: Paragraph

text: into being as a result of the competition for
label: Paragraph

text: the design of the Palace of the League of
label: Caption

text: ations in Geneva, Switzerland, in 1927.
label: Paragraph

text: The competition turned into a contest
label: Paragraph

text: tween modernists and traditionalists, with
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier's entry rejected in favor of a
label: Paragraph

text: Beaux-Arts project designed by Henri-Paul
label: Caption

text: Jénot. Though the membership of CIAM was
label: Paragraph

text: constantly changing—as were its priorities—
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier played the dominant role in
label: Paragraph

text: it, along with Walter Gropius and the Swiss
label: Paragraph

text: architectural historian Siegfried Giedion.
label: Paragraph

text: From its inception, there were arguments
label: Paragraph

text: about which direction to take, but the group
label: Paragraph

text: managed to hang together for almost two
label: Paragraph

text: decades. Nonetheless, in the five congresses
label: Paragraph

text: eld before World War ||, CIAM shifted its
label: Paragraph

text: position from an organization that encouraged
label: Paragraph

text: a plurality of views about modern architecture
label: Title

text: to one increasingly dominated by the ideas of
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier.
label: Paragraph

text: The first congress, in 1928, produced a
label: Paragraph

text: manifesto known as the Sarraz Declaration,
label: Paragraph

text: named after the Chateau de la Sarraz in
label: Paragraph

text: France, where the group met. Twenty-four
label: Paragraph

text: architects signed the document, which
label: Paragraph

text: attacked the academies for their sterilizing
label: Paragraph

text: grip on the architectural profession; it instead
label: Paragraph

text: promoted an architecture based on practical,
label: Paragraph

text: economic, and sociological considerations.
label: Paragraph

text: The document held that modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: had the obligation to satisfy not only the
label: Paragraph

text: material needs of the population but also
label: Paragraph

text: the spiritual and intellectual demands of
label: Title

text: contemporary life. Modern urbanism, it
label: Paragraph

text: argued, should be based not on arbitrary
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic principles but on a collective and
label: Paragraph

text: methodological land policy. This realism
label: Paragraph

text: was eventually replaced by a more utopian
label: Paragraph

text: ethos emphasizing the question of whether
label: Paragraph

text: architects should adopt a sociological
label: Paragraph

text: approach or a more formal one. The urban
label: Paragraph

text: designers with practical experience tended to
label: Paragraph

text: favor the former, whereas Le Corbusier, ever
label: Paragraph

text: the elitist, favored the latter.
label: Paragraph

text: At CIAM 3, held in Brussels, Le Corbusier
label: Caption

text: began to gain the upper hand in determining
label: Paragraph

text: the agenda and in promoting his Ville
label: Paragraph

text: Radieuse (“Radiant City"). At the fourth
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM congress, in 1933, the participants
label: Paragraph

text: published their conclusions as the Athens
label: Paragraph

text: Charter (so-called because the Congress
label: Paragraph

text: was held on board a ship that sailed from
label: Paragraph

text: Marseille to Athens). It committed CIAM
label: Paragraph

text: to rigidly functional cities, whose citizens
label: Paragraph

text: would be housed in high, widely spaced
label: Paragraph

text: apartment blocks based on CIAM planning
label: Title

text: principles that called for the separation of
label: Paragraph

text: living functions. Greenbelts would separate
label: Paragraph

text: each zone of the city. Generally speaking, it
label: Paragraph

text: was assumed, as Le Corbusier phrased it,
label: Paragraph

text: that the positions adopted by CIAM would be
label: Paragraph

text: accepted by “an enlightened population that
label: Paragraph

text: would understand, desire and demand what
label: Paragraph

text: the specialists have envisioned for it.”
label: Paragraph

text: 18.12 Le Corbusier’s vision for the residential quarter of the Radiant City
label: Caption

text: Pavilion Suisse
label: Title

text: Le Corbusier reinvented the ideal industrial
label: Paragraph

text: city of the modern age. He published his
label: Paragraph

text: ideas in the form of several utopian proposals
label: Title

text: to remake Paris, among which were The
label: Paragraph

text: Contemporary City (1922) and The Radiant
label: Title

text: City (1933). Drawn frorn the viewpoint of a
label: Paragraph

text: bird or a plane, these cities erased a huge
label: Paragraph

text: swath of the existing urban fabric of Paris,
label: Paragraph

text: leaving only some of the more respected
label: Paragraph

text: monuments and churches in place. The
label: Paragraph

text: new city consisted of rows of identical
label: Paragraph

text: cruciform skyscrapers clustered around an
label: Paragraph

text: airfield in the center. In later schemes, he
label: Paragraph

text: showed housing organized in long, multistory
label: Paragraph

text: blocks that twisted and turned to create
label: Paragraph

text: bounded fields between their curves. Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier also made a series of perspectives
label: Paragraph

text: from the human-eye level that showed a
label: Paragraph

text: continuous green landscape flowing under
label: Title

text: the skyscrapers, built on stilts, as far as the
label: Paragraph

text: eye could see. The audacity of Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: proposals—particularly the impunity with
label: Paragraph

text: which he proposed to erase the historic city—
label: Paragraph

text: provoked loud reactions, both of praise and
label: Paragraph

text: horror. For his defenders, his urban designs
label: Paragraph

text: catapulted him into the role of the messiah
label: Paragraph

text: of a new industrial age. Le Corbusier was
label: Paragraph

text: never able to realize any of his sweeping
label: Paragraph

text: urban plans as he wished, even though some
label: Paragraph

text: of the suggested features eventually came
label: Paragraph

text: to influence urban planning the world over,
label: Paragraph

text: especially after World War II.
label: Paragraph

text: The Radiant City was an example of social
label: Paragraph

text: functionalism. Each apartment block was
label: Paragraph

text: equipped with a catering section and laundry
label: Paragraph

text: in the basement. The space between
label: Paragraph

text: the blocks was dedicated to sports and
label: Paragraph

text: leisure, and the roof was for gardens and
label: Paragraph

text: day-care centers. Transportation systerns
label: Paragraph

text: were designed throughout the city. All this
label: Paragraph

text: was part of Le Corbusier's critique of the
label: Paragraph

text: horizontal spread of the Garden City and the
label: Paragraph

text: wasted cornmuting time that engendered.
label: Paragraph

text: The Pavilion Suisse (1932), a student
label: Paragraph

text: dormitory that he was able to build at the
label: Paragraph

text: Cité Universitaire in Paris, was intended
label: Paragraph

text: as a showpiece for his vision. Two rows
label: Paragraph

text: 18.14 Plan: Pavilion Suisse

text: j
label: Title

text: 18.13 Pavilion Suisse, Paris
label: Caption

text: of long and narrow rooms were arranged
label: Paragraph

text: around a central corridor, a plywood closet
label: Paragraph

text: separated the kitchen from the living area,
label: Paragraph

text: and the toilets and baths were shared. Most
label: Paragraph

text: importantly, the building was elevated off the
label: Paragraph

text: ground by columns that Le Corbusier called
label: Paragraph

text: pilotis.
label: Paragraph

text: At Marseille, Corbusier realized one of
label: Paragraph

text: several Unités d’Habitations (1947-52),
label: Paragraph

text: structures for up to 1,600 people designed
label: Caption

text: in the form of vertical village, complete with
label: Paragraph

text: an internal shopping street halfway up, a
label: Paragraph

text: recreation ground and children’s nursery on
label: Title

text: the roof, and a generous surrounding area of
label: Paragraph

text: parkland made possible by the density of the
label: Paragraph

text: accommodation in the slab itself.

text: Barcelona Pavilion
label: Title

text: Mies van der Rohe’s German National
label: Title

text: Pavilion, built for the 1929 Barcelona
label: Caption

text: nternational Exhibition, became an icon
label: Paragraph

text: of the madernist aesthetic almost from the
label: Paragraph

text: eginning. It was visited by people from all
label: Paragraph

text: over the world, showing a side of modernism
label: Paragraph

text: that many had not expected from Mies, who
label: Paragraph

text: was normally thought of as a defender of
label: Paragraph

text: arsh industrial architecture. Here they saw a
label: Paragraph

text: uilding that stressed the visual and sensual
label: Paragraph

text: aspects of surfaces and materials. The
label: Paragraph

text: uilding, which rested on a white travertine
label: Paragraph

text: platform, was entered from the west by a
label: Paragraph

text: path that led down a forested hill. The view
label: Paragraph

text: to the immediate left was of a nude female
label: Caption

text: statue by Georg Kalbe, standing in a pool of
label: Caption

text: water framed by walls clad in dramatically
label: Paragraph

text: veined green marble from the Greek island
label: Caption

text: of Tinos, contrasting with the green of the
label: Paragraph

text: forested hill above. The south-facing walls
label: Paragraph

text: would have received the bright Spanish sun,
label: Paragraph

text: contrasting with the cool hues of the interior
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces. There were no coors, only a set of
label: Paragraph

text: walls that defined spaces through which one
label: Paragraph

text: walked.
label: Paragraph

text: Not only was there the physical
label: Paragraph

text: impression of this free-flowing space but
label: Paragraph

text: also the visual sensation created by the
label: Paragraph

text: rich colors, the opulent surfaces, and the
label: Paragraph

text: dazzling play of reflections off the polished
label: Paragraph

text: materials; even the columns were encased
label: Paragraph

text: in highly reflective chrome sheathing. The
label: Paragraph

text: columns form a structural rhythm of two
label: Paragraph

text: rows of four, in syncopated relationship with
label: Paragraph

text: the walls, which are sometimes quite close
label: Paragraph

text: to the columns, sometimes farther away. It
label: Paragraph

text: is impossible to understand the columns as
label: Paragraph

text: part of a structural-rationalist systern; they
label: Paragraph

text: are, in essence, broken apart to stand in
label: Paragraph

text: dialogue with both the walls and the viewers
label: Title

text: of the space. The minimalism of the design
label: Paragraph

text: draws on the elementarist compositions of
label: Paragraph

text: Kazimir Malevich and other Constructivists,
label: Paragraph

text: but Mies was no socialist. The building is,
label: Paragraph

text: in fact, meant to appeal to an elite clientele.
label: Paragraph

text: Mies was doing something similar to what
label: Paragraph

text: Adolf Loos had cone in the previous decade:
label: Paragraph

text: unifying a language of stark modernism on
label: Paragraph

text: the exterior with lush and sensuous materials
label: Paragraph

text: on the interior. But unlike Loos, whose
label: Paragraph

text: 18.16 View from pool, Barcelona Pavilion
label: Caption

text: interiors were intimate, Mies’s are open and
label: Paragraph

text: mysteriously shimmering. The building does
label: Paragraph

text: have, however, a clear and identifiable spatial
label: Paragraph

text: focus defined by four different walls, the most
label: Paragraph

text: important one made of a rare marble called
label: Paragraph

text: onyx dorée, with veins that ranged from
label: Paragraph

text: dark gold to white. It was flanked by a wall
label: Paragraph

text: of milk-glass lit frorn within. In front of the
label: Paragraph

text: onyx wall was a table and, set side by side, a
label: Paragraph

text: pair of metal-frame chairs with white leather
label: Caption

text: cushions. Behind the chairs, through a wall
label: Caption

text: of green glass, glimmered the surface of the
label: Paragraph

text: pool. The view through the glass darkened
label: Paragraph

text: the marble rising behind the pool and
label: Paragraph

text: accented its veining.
label: Paragraph

text: 18.17 Wall and column juxtaposition, Barcelona Pavilion
label: Caption

text: Visitors saw a series of conjoining and overlapping
label: Paragraph

text: visual planes, starting with the horizontal view of the
label: Paragraph

text: trees behind the building, framed by the roof and the
label: Paragraph

text: top of the Tinian marble wall, and then descending
label: Paragraph

text: through various layers to the floor of the building.
label: Paragraph

text: The floor, surfaced in white travertine and matching
label: Paragraph

text: to some degree the whiteness of the roof, created for
label: Paragraph

text: visitors a floating sensation interrupted only in the
label: Paragraph

text: central room, where the space in front of the great
label: Paragraph

text: onyx slab was covered by a thin black carpet. On
label: Paragraph

text: the opposite wall, the glass was covered by drapery
label: Paragraph

text: of scarlet silk. The central space was thus a type
label: Paragraph

text: of stage set, with its single column off to one side, a
label: Paragraph

text: standing at a respectful distance from the onyx wall.

text: Palace of the Soviets Competition
label: Title

text: To celebrate the new Soviet state, Joseph
label: Paragraph

text: Stalin planned to build a huge Palace of the
label: Paragraph

text: Soviets in Moscow, Russia. A competition
label: Paragraph

text: was held in 1931 under the hopeful auspices
label: Paragraph

text: of the architectural community. It was
label: Paragraph

text: believed that Russia, as an emerging world
label: Paragraph

text: power, would continue the trend set by
label: Paragraph

text: Constructivists. Over 160 Soviet architects
label: Paragraph

text: and firms and 24 foreigners volunteered
label: Title

text: designs; among the latter were Le Corbusier,
label: Paragraph

text: Walter Gropius, Hannes Meyer, Erich
label: Caption

text: Mendelsohn, and August Perret.
label: Paragraph

text: The competition was carried out in four
label: Paragraph

text: phases. The first, open only to the Soviet
label: Paragraph

text: architects, assisted in the formulation of

text: Rockefeller Center
label: Title

text: By the late 1920s, New York had risen to
label: Paragraph

text: the level of a world metropolis. Dozens of tall
label: Paragraph

text: buildings had been constructed, including
label: Paragraph

text: new civic and institutional buildings.
label: Paragraph

text: Skyscraper architects had moved away from
label: Paragraph

text: overt historicism toward the elegant lines
label: Title

text: of Art Deco, as at the Chrysler Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1928-30). The Chanin Building (1927-29)
label: Caption

text: went even further, with a neutral, gridlike
label: Paragraph

text: facade. Rockefeller Center, designed by
label: Caption

text: Raymond Hood and Wallace K. Harrison,
label: Title

text: was nothing less than a city within a city,
label: Paragraph

text: composed of fourteen buildings between
label: Paragraph

text: Forty-Eighth and Fifty-First Streets in New
label: Caption

text: York City. At the core of the composition
label: Paragraph

text: was the seventy-one-story RCA Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1931-32), which faced onto a sunken plaza
label: Paragraph

text: defined on its flanks by low-rise buildings—
label: Paragraph

text: the British Empire Building and the Maison
label: Title

text: Frangaise. The RCA Building was sheathed
label: Paragraph

text: in a yellowish limestone with aluminum
label: Paragraph

text: trim, with the windows arranged vertically
label: Paragraph

text: in slightly recessed strips to emphasize the
label: Paragraph

text: structure’s soaring qualities. In its complete
label: Paragraph

text: avoidance of references to a classical past, as
label: Paragraph

text: well as the thinness of its central tower, this
label: Paragraph

text: building, in many respects, paved the way
label: Paragraph

text: for the skyscraper aesthetic developed by the
label: Paragraph

text: modernists. Radio City Music Hall, containing
label: Caption

text: the nation’s largest indoor theater, was on
label: Paragraph

text: the next block. A cross street, Rockefeller
label: Caption

text: Plaza, introduced an innovative division of the
label: Paragraph

text: central parcel.
label: Paragraph

text: Though rarely emulated, the center was much
label: Paragraph

text: admired for its urban design implications.
label: Paragraph

text: The setbacks, which were required by zoning
label: Paragraph

text: regulations, were woven so fluidly into the
label: Paragraph

text: design that they seemed to be an organic
label: Paragraph

text: part of the building—a quality different from
label: Paragraph

text: that found at the RCA Building, the Chanin
label: Paragraph

text: Building, or even the Empire State Building,
label: Paragraph

text: with its stockier base. To emphasize the
label: Paragraph

text: building’s towering quality, the lower buildings
label: Paragraph

text: were designed to look more substantial—
label: Paragraph

text: almost like stone volumes that also help frame
label: Paragraph

text: the views of the tower.
label: Paragraph

text: Artists were brought in to create sculptures
label: Paragraph

text: and murals—themselves excellent examples
label: Paragraph

text: of Art Deco—for placement over the entrance
label: Caption

text: doors and in the lobby. These included Paul
label: Paragraph

text: Manship, who designed a gilded statue of
label: Paragraph

text: a recumbent Prometheus. The Mexican
label: Paragraph

text: socialist artist Diego Rivera was commissioned
label: Title

text: to create a mural for the lobby, but when it
label: Paragraph

text: was discovered that it contained a portrait
label: Paragraph

text: of Vladimir Lenin and other anticapitalist
label: Title

text: imagery, it was removed.

text: Czechoslovakia
label: Title

text: In many places in Europe, national
label: Paragraph

text: Romanticism hindered the advancement
label: Title

text: of modernist architecture because many
label: Paragraph

text: nationalists saw modernism—and its
label: Paragraph

text: associations with industrialisrn and socially
label: Title

text: progressive politics—as antithetical to the
label: Paragraph

text: idyllic past that was central to Romantic
label: Paragraph

text: ideology. This explains to sorne extent
label: Paragraph

text: why the first true example of modernism
label: Title

text: as a state-sponsored aesthetic flourished
label: Paragraph

text: in Turkey and some other non-European
label: Title

text: countries, where Romanticism was not as
label: Paragraph

text: firmly developed. Nonetheless, nationalism,
label: Paragraph

text: even in Europe, began to turn to modernism
label: Paragraph

text: as an expression of a country’s search for
label: Paragraph

text: autonomy and capitalist strength. One of
label: Paragraph

text: the first places where this new equation was
label: Paragraph

text: manifest was Czechoslovakia, which in 1918
label: Paragraph

text: emerged as an independent state from the
label: Paragraph

text: dismembered Austro-Hungarian Empire. The
label: Paragraph

text: small Central European country inherited
label: Title

text: both a large portion of the former empire's
label: Paragraph

text: ethnic diversity and its economic strength.
label: Paragraph

text: In fact, Czechoslovakia became one of
label: Paragraph

text: Europe's most politically stable and democratic
label: Title

text: systems during the restless interwar years.
label: Paragraph

text: This stability is generally attributed to Tomas
label: Paragraph

text: Garrigue Masaryk (1850-1937), the first
label: Paragraph

text: president of the republic and an internationally
label: Title

text: respected scholar-statesman. Though
label: Paragraph

text: Czechoslovakian government officials never
label: Title

text: gave state sponsorship to modernism, this
label: Paragraph

text: did not hamper the younger generation and
label: Paragraph

text: the educated and prosperous middle class
label: Title

text: from seeing modernism as an articulation
label: Title

text: of Czechoslovakia’s political emancipation

label: Caption

text: from the old Austro-Hungarian Empire. The
label: Paragraph

text: teaching of Otto Wagner disciples like Jan
label: Title

text: Kotera and Joze Plecnik, who belonged to the
label: Paragraph

text: same generation as Josef Hoffman and Adolf
label: Paragraph

text: Loos, was immensely influential.
label: Paragraph

text: By 1937, the Bata Shoe Company had
label: Paragraph

text: become the world market-leader in shoe
label: Paragraph

text: production, becoming the first manufacturer
label: Paragraph

text: in Europe to mass-produce good-quality
label: Paragraph

text: shoes at an affordable price. The company’s
label: Paragraph

text: founder, Tomas Bata, invested in an extensive
label: Paragraph

text: building program, first in his hometown of Zlin,
label: Paragraph

text: where he located the company headquarters,
label: Paragraph

text: and later in factory towns that he and his
label: Paragraph

text: successor, Jan Bata, established on three
label: Paragraph

text: continents. Bata had factories and sales
label: Paragraph

text: organizations in thirty-three countries and
label: Paragraph

text: was at the time one of the most international
label: Paragraph

text: companies in the world. Bata systernatically
label: Paragraph

text: hired young Czech architects and engineers
label: Title

text: with international experience. One of these
label: Paragraph

text: young professionals was Vladimir Karfik, who
label: Paragraph

text: had worked for Le Corbusier and Frank Lloyd
label: Paragraph

text: Wright.
label: Paragraph

text: The Bata headquarters, a seventeen-
label: Paragraph

text: story building designed by Karfik (1937),
label: Paragraph

text: was one of the first high-rise buildings in
label: Paragraph

text: Europe. It was built with a structural frame of
label: Paragraph

text: reinforced concrete on a module of 6.15 by
label: Caption

text: 6.15 meters. This so-called Bata standard was
label: Paragraph

text: the basis for all Bata buildings, ranging from
label: Paragraph

text: factories and retail stores to various public
label: Title

text: buildings. Contrary to traditional dispositions
label: Paragraph

text: in skyscraper design, three service pods were
label: Paragraph

text: located on the perimeter of the building. This
label: Paragraph

text: created an unobstructed rectangle measuring
label: Paragraph

text: 80 by 20 meters organized as an open-plan
label: Paragraph

text: 18.25 Bata Shoe Factory
label: Caption

text: office in which reconfigurable office modules

text: were the only spatial dividers. Electricity and
label: Paragraph

text: telephone networks with plugs laid in the floor
label: Paragraph

text: on a 3-by-3-meter grid facilitated flexibility in
label: Paragraph

text: space organization. The most striking feature
label: Paragraph

text: of the building was Jan Bata’s office in the
label: Paragraph

text: form of an elevator. The vertically mobile unit

text: allowed Bata to dock on every floor—thereby
label: Paragraph

text: going wherever he was needed. Bata was

text: also able to communicate with his employees

text: throughout the building by means of an

text: ntercom. The interior of the office elevator,

text: designed with wood paneling and double

text: windows, was well lit by natural light. Among

text: possible and how to adapt the cabin to quick

text: temperature changes when moving in the
label: Paragraph

text: shaft.
label: Paragraph

text: By the end of the 1930s, European
label: Paragraph

text: modernism was not moving forward very well.
label: Paragraph

text: Gropius and Mies had all but disappeared
label: Paragraph

text: from the scene, and Le Corbusier received
label: Paragraph

text: few commissions, prompting him to seek
label: Paragraph

text: work outside of Europe, such as in Ankara,
label: Paragraph

text: Turkey; in Tel Aviv (then part of the Palestinian
label: Paragraph

text: Protectorate); and in Casablanca, Morocco,
label: Paragraph

text: which was a French colony. Though the
label: Paragraph

text: architects with whom he coordinated
label: Paragraph

text: in these cities are not well known, they
label: Paragraph

text: made major contributions to the cause of
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture. Turkey and Israel
label: Title

text: were particularly important in this respect,

label: Paragraph

text: a highly visible nation-building effort, rather
label: Paragraph

text: Casablanca.

text: Touba
label: Title

text: In 1887, Sheikh Amadou Bamba
label: Paragraph

text: (1853-1927), a Muslim mystic, founded a
label: Paragraph

text: homestead later called Touba in an isolated
label: Paragraph

text: place outside the town of Mbacké, in what is
label: Paragraph

text: now Senegal. He acquired a reputation as a
label: Paragraph

text: holy man, and soon followers began to seek
label: Paragraph

text: him out. He developed a form of Sufism,
label: Paragraph

text: known as Mouridism, according to which
label: Paragraph

text: the material world is not complete in and of
label: Paragraph

text: itself: matter, it teaches, is relevant to life only
label: Paragraph

text: insofar as it is infused by the divine. Bamba
label: Paragraph

text: perceived his mission as also a social one;
label: Paragraph

text: he wanted his adherents to return to the
label: Paragraph

text: “straight path” of Islam. So Touba became
label: Paragraph

text: a holy city in which everything frivolous—
label: Paragraph

text: laughing, dancing, drinking alcohol—was
label: Paragraph

text: forbidden.
label: Paragraph

text: At first the French colonial authorities
label: Paragraph

text: viewed Bamba’s growing popularity as
label: Paragraph

text: a threat to their authority and sent him
label: Paragraph

text: into exile, but since his position was one
label: Paragraph

text: of nonviolence, they released him and
label: Paragraph

text: eventually gave him their nominal support.
label: Paragraph

text: In the 1920s, Bamba launched the
label: Paragraph

text: construction of a large mosque; he was
label: Paragraph

text: assisted by thousands of faithful volunteers
label: Title

text: in its construction. The reinforced concrete
label: Paragraph

text: structure, which has been continuously
label: Paragraph

text: enlarged, has three domes and five minarets,
label: Paragraph

text: the central one being quite tall and visible
label: Paragraph

text: for miles in the flat Senegalese landscape.
label: Paragraph

text: The roofs of the domes are green and blue,
label: Paragraph

text: and the walls are clad in a rose-tinted stone;
label: Paragraph

text: the interior is richly decorated. Bamba died
label: Caption

text: in 1927 and his successors finished the
label: Paragraph

text: building in 1963. It was only then that a
label: Paragraph

text: city was laid out on a grid plan, with broad
label: Paragraph

text: radiating streets ernanating from the central
label: Paragraph

text: square where the mosque is located.
label: Paragraph

text: The cemetery is located opposite the
label: Paragraph

text: mosque and thus at the city center, which for
label: Paragraph

text: Islam is unusual, since cemeteries are usually
label: Paragraph

text: placed outside of a city. Here the cemetery
label: Paragraph

text: functions as the gate to the hereafter and
label: Paragraph

text: is an important part of the Sufi mystical
label: Paragraph

text: experience. It was designed symbolically
label: Paragraph

text: around an ancient sacred baobab tree
label: Paragraph

text: (which died in 2003). On the qibla side of
label: Paragraph

text: the mosque is another tree, a palm tree,
label: Paragraph

text: that marks the spot where the first birth in
label: Paragraph

text: Touba took place. These trees are called
label: Paragraph

text: palaver trees by the locals. (Palaver derives
label: Paragraph

text: from the Portuguese palavra, which means
label: Paragraph

text: speech or discussion.) Since ancient times,
label: Paragraph

text: palaver trees have served as the heart of
label: Paragraph

text: community meetings and been at the center
label: Title

text: of civic and religious functions; because
label: Paragraph

text: of their longevity, the trees are considered
label: Paragraph

text: the spiritual guarantors of a community's
label: Paragraph

text: life. The palaver tree tradition can be found
label: Paragraph

text: across central Africa. In Islamic areas, it is
label: Paragraph

text: the mosque that serves as the political and
label: Paragraph

text: social center of the Islamic community, which
label: Paragraph

text: can bring the mosque into competition with
label: Paragraph

text: this older tradition. Here, however, the old
label: Paragraph

text: and the new were fused, the ancient tradition
label: Paragraph

text: of the baobab tree blending with the Sufi
label: Paragraph

text: concept of a tree of paradise. Furthermore,
label: Paragraph

text: the tall minaret is itself meant to be seen as
label: Paragraph

text: treelike. Touba was recognized as a model
label: Paragraph

text: “peace city” by the United Nations Human
label: Title

text: Settlement Division in 1996.

text: National Modernism, Ankara
label: Title

text: The transition from the Ottornan Empire
label: Title

text: to modernity was completed when the
label: Paragraph

text: Turkish Republic was founded by Mustafa
label: Paragraph

text: Kemal (also known as Atattirk) in 1923.
label: Paragraph

text: Atattirk adopted modern architecture
label: Title

text: as the expression of this new secular
label: Paragraph

text: nation, starting what is now called national
label: Paragraph

text: modernism. In contrast to other localities,
label: Paragraph

text: such as Casablanca, where modernism was
label: Paragraph

text: imposed by colonial masters, in Ankara it
label: Paragraph

text: was a triumphant statement that announced
label: Paragraph

text: Turkey's independence. Atattirk’s ambition
label: Paragraph

text: was to achieve an industrialized nation based
label: Paragraph

text: on technical and scientific progress, with
label: Paragraph

text: institutions modeled after those in Europe.
label: Paragraph

text: Ankara, at that time a small town in
label: Paragraph

text: central Anatolia, was chosen as the new
label: Paragraph

text: capital since it was more or less in the center
label: Paragraph

text: of the nation. Its design in 1927 by the
label: Paragraph

text: German planner Hermann Jansen can be
label: Paragraph

text: considered, along with Canberra, Australia,
label: Paragraph

text: among the first in a long string of modernist
label: Paragraph

text: capitals that would include Brasilia, Brazil;
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh, India; and Islamabad, Pakistan.
label: Paragraph

text: The Austrian architect Clemenz Holzmeister
label: Caption

text: (1886-1983), for example, designed the
label: Paragraph

text: government district, including several
label: Paragraph

text: ministries, the presidential palace, and the
label: Title

text: Grand National Assembly Hall. Despite the
label: Paragraph

text: plain cubic facades, the overall organization
label: Paragraph

text: was often indebted to classical principles
label: Paragraph

text: and vocabulary. Nonetheless, the purpose
label: Paragraph

text: was to visibly and progressively champion
label: Paragraph

text: the ideals of the new Republic of Turkey.
label: Paragraph

text: New schools, especially for girls; houses;
label: Paragraph

text: centers of popular education; and places for
label: Paragraph

text: physical education, recreation, leisure, and
label: Title

text: entertainment were among the typologies
label: Paragraph

text: that became emblematic for the republic’s
label: Paragraph

text: stated aims. The Ismet Pasa Girls’ Institute
label: Paragraph

text: in Ankara, a vocational school, was designed
label: Paragraph

text: by the Swiss Ernst Egli in 1930. Modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture and planning was also employed
label: Paragraph

text: for model villages, factories, and large
label: Paragraph

text: infrastructural projects such as the Cubuk
label: Paragraph

text: Dam outside Ankara (1936). The exhibition
label: Caption

text: hall in Ankara, which also served as an opera
label: Paragraph

text: house, was designed by Turkish architect
label: Paragraph

text: Sevki Balmumcu, who won the commission
label: Paragraph

text: in a competition. It was erected to showcase
label: Paragraph

text: the technological accomplishments of the
label: Title

text: Turkish Republic, as were the structures built
label: Paragraph

text: for the Izmir International Fair.

text: After the economic crash of 1929, Brazil’s
label: Paragraph
