label: Paragraph

text: (r. 1930-45), created a developmentalist,
label: Paragraph

text: state-sponsored program of modernization.
label: Paragraph

text: Much as in Kemal Atattirk’s Turkey, modern
label: Paragraph

text: architecture was to be the visible imprint
label: Paragraph

text: of his nationalist project. In 1930, the
label: Paragraph

text: young architect Lucio Costa was appointed
label: Paragraph

text: director of the Escola Nacional de Belas
label: Paragraph

text: Artes. Though Costa initially knew little about
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture, he soon became its
label: Paragraph

text: leading advocate, bringing in a Russian
label: Paragraph

text: émigré, Gregori Warchavchik (1896-1972),
label: Paragraph

text: who presented his “modernist house” at an
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition that was opened to the public in
label: Paragraph

text: 1930. It had a white, cubic volume (though
label: Paragraph

text: a parapet concealed a pitched, tiled roof)
label: Paragraph

text: that earned the architect a place in the 1930
label: Paragraph

text: CIAM congress.
label: Paragraph

text: Early in his own career, Costa had little
label: Paragraph

text: work and had spent his time studying
label: Paragraph

text: books on the architecture of Walter Gropius,
label: Caption

text: Ludwig Mies van de Rohe, and, most of
label: Paragraph

text: all, Le Corbusier. Le Corbusier himself had
label: Paragraph

text: built little other than his “white” houses,
label: Paragraph

text: but his books Towards a New Architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: The Contemporary City, and Precisions
label: Title

text: were widely influential. In 1936, Gustavo
label: Paragraph

text: Capanema, the thirty-three-year-old minister
label: Title

text: of education and health, took the bald
label: Paragraph

text: step of commissioning Costa to build the
label: Paragraph

text: ministry's official headquarters. Costa's
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of Le Corbusier's competition entry for

text: the League of Nations project (1927). His

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: had proposed—vehemently lift the structure
label: Paragraph

text: off the ground. On the cross-axis, along one

text: technical systems that service them—and

label: Paragraph

text: virtue out of electrical wiring, outlets, lighting
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: and urban. Kahn continually downplayed

label: Paragraph

text: National Modernism, Chandigarh
label: Caption

text: When India attained independence in 1947 it
label: Paragraph

text: was divided into two countries along religious
label: Paragraph

text: ines, resulting in the creation of the new
label: Paragraph

text: slamic nation of Pakistan. In that division,
label: Paragraph

text: the Indian state of Punjab lost its capital,
label: Paragraph

text: Lahore, to Pakistan, so Jawaharlal Nehru,
label: Paragraph

text: the first prime minister of independent
label: Title

text: ndia, decided to construct a new capital,
label: Paragraph

text: Chandigarh. Like Brazil’s Getulio Vargas
label: Paragraph

text: and Juscelino Kubitschek, Nehru modeled
label: Paragraph

text: is development plans on Franklin Delano
label: Title

text: Roosevelt’s New Deal and initiated a series
label: Paragraph

text: of state-sponsored industrialization projects.
label: Paragraph

text: His sentiment was expressly anti-nostalgic.
label: Paragraph

text: He wanted Chandigarh to be a “new city,
label: Paragraph

text: unfettered by the traditions of the past, and a
label: Paragraph

text: symbol of the nation’s faith in the future.”
label: Paragraph

text: When Le Corbusier joined the project
label: Paragraph

text: in 1952, the urban plan had already been
label: Paragraph

text: prepared by Albert Mayer, an American town
label: Caption

text: planner, on the principles of the City Beautiful
label: Title

text: movement, with superblocks accessed by
label: Paragraph

text: gently curving roads. Le Corbusier shrunk
label: Caption

text: the superblocks into 800-by-1,200-meter
label: Paragraph

text: rectangular neighborhood units or sectors
label: Title

text: serviced by a diminishing hierarchy of
label: Paragraph

text: roads and bicycle paths, according to CIAM
label: Paragraph

text: principles. Within these sectors, Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: wanted to design multistory residential
label: Paragraph

text: units (perhaps like those in Brasilia, or in
label: Paragraph

text: his Unités d’Habitations, the first of which
label: Paragraph

text: had just been constructed in Marseille), but
label: Paragraph

text: that idea was immediately dismissed by the
label: Paragraph

text: officers in charge of the project who were
label: Paragraph

text: committed to a low-rise suburban image,
label: Paragraph

text: inspired in part by the sprawling cantonments
label: Paragraph

text: the British had built for their officers in
label: Paragraph

text: colonial India. The state housing, therefore,
label: Paragraph

text: was done not by Le Corbusier, but by his
label: Paragraph

text: cousin, Pierre Jeanneret (who was the project
label: Paragraph

text: architect), and the English husband-and-wife
label: Paragraph

text: tearn Maxwell Fry and Jane Drew (who had
label: Paragraph

text: been working in Africa), assisted by a team
label: Paragraph

text: of nine Indian architects and planners. Most
label: Paragraph

text: of the construction was made of load-bearing
label: Paragraph

text: exposed brick walls, accented by random
label: Paragraph

text: rubble-stone porticoes and concrete window
label: Caption

text: protectors, plastered and painted white.

text: Le Corbusier's Capitol Complex for
label: Caption

text: Chandigarh (1951-62)—containing the High
label: Paragraph

text: Court, Assembly, and Secretariat for the
label: Title

text: states of Punjab and Haryana—was located
label: Paragraph

text: at the northern end of the city on a vast
label: Paragraph

text: open plain, visually bound only by the distant
label: Paragraph

text: Himalayan foothills. The boundaries are
label: Paragraph

text: loosely defined by two adjoining 800-meter
label: Paragraph

text: squares that contain two 400-meter squares.
label: Paragraph

text: The vehicular roads are located sornewhat
label: Paragraph

text: below grade; the excavated earth was used
label: Paragraph

text: to create the artificial hills that screen the
label: Paragraph

text: Capitol from the rest of the city. An irregularly
label: Paragraph

text: shaped pedestrian plaza, linking the
label: Paragraph

text: Assembly and the High Court, studded with a
label: Paragraph

text: set of symbolic follies, forms the conceptual
label: Paragraph

text: center of the Capitol. The High Court, the
label: Paragraph

text: first building to be constructed, is contained
label: Paragraph

text: within a tight frame and endowed with a
label: Paragraph

text: second roof {with suspended arches) built 18.69 High Court, Chandigarh
label: Caption

text: above the first one to provide shade. Three
label: Caption

text: huge pylons create a monumental gateway
label: Paragraph

text: fronted by two reflecting pools. The building's
label: Paragraph

text: elevation has a rhythm determined by the
label: Paragraph

text: divisions of the nine courts. The elevation, in
label: Paragraph

text: fact, is almost the same as its plan. Although
label: Paragraph

text: made of cast-in-place rough concrete,
label: Paragraph

text: the High Court, with the pylons painted in
label: Paragraph

text: soft pastels, appears lightweight and airy,
label: Paragraph

text: particularly when reflected in the pools.
label: Paragraph

text: The Secretariat has a very different
label: Paragraph

text: character. In the context of the larger
label: Paragraph

text: composition, it functions as a backdrop to the
label: Paragraph

text: Assembly, taking the form of a long slab with
label: Paragraph

text: a dramatic roofline and a facade completely
label: Paragraph

text: composed of brise-sofeils. Staircases appear
label: Paragraph

text: as attached towers with small windows.
label: Paragraph

text: With its long double-loaded corridor, the
label: Paragraph

text: building was a restatement of Le Corbusier's
label: Paragraph

text: idea of a collective living solution, the Unité
label: Paragraph

text: d'Habitation. But while the Unité was raised
label: Paragraph

text: on robust concrete piotis, the Secretariat sits
label: Paragraph

text: directly on the ground.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier's Assembly Building (1953-63)
label: Caption

text: is a skillful essay in organization and
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality. On a trip to Anmedabad
label: Paragraph

text: in western India, Le Corbusier saw the
label: Paragraph

text: form of a hyperbolic paraboloid arch under
label: Paragraph

text: construction for a thermal power station and,
label: Paragraph

text: mesmerized, immediately decided to use it as
label: Paragraph

text: a motif in the Assembly Building. At this time
label: Paragraph

text: he was also working, in conjunction with the
label: Paragraph

text: mathematician and musician lannis Xenaxis,
label: Paragraph

text: on several projects in France, all of which
label: Paragraph

text: explored the sculptural possibilities of ruled
label: Paragraph

text: surfaces. For the design of the Assembly
label: Paragraph

text: Building, Le Corbusier seems to have literally
label: Paragraph

text: dropped the hyperbolic paraboloid arch into
label: Paragraph

text: a box. Around the hall, a forest of columns,
label: Paragraph

text: rising high into a black ceiling, created the
label: Paragraph

text: foyer. The three edges of the box were given
label: Paragraph

text: over to offices. Brise-soleils functioned as
label: Paragraph

text: the skin. On the fourth edge of the box, the
label: Paragraph

text: side facing the plaza, Le Corbusier built a
label: Paragraph

text: monumental portal, opposite to and facing
label: Caption

text: the portal of the High Court across the vast
label: Caption

text: plaza. A row of thin pylons holds up a free-
label: Paragraph

text: form roof that looks like the horns of a bull
label: Paragraph

text: in outline, giving the Assembly Building the
label: Paragraph

text: appearance of a majestic bull standing firm
label: Paragraph

text: on the vast Indian plain—quite in contrast to
label: Paragraph

text: Niemeyer’s palaces in Brasilia, which barely
label: Paragraph

text: touch the ground and seem to fly above it in
label: Paragraph

text: defiance of gravity.
label: Paragraph

text: Le Corbusier also gifted to Chandigarh the
label: Paragraph

text: Open Hand Monument, which he devised as
label: Paragraph

text: the city’ symbol. Standing in the Capitol, it is
label: Paragraph

text: a 23-meter-high sculpture of burnished steel.
label: Paragraph

text: While the aesthetic origins of the sculpture
label: Paragraph

text: are diverse, Le Corbusier articulated his most
label: Paragraph

text: ambitious hope for the Open Hand in a letter
label: Title

text: to Nehru from 1955, when he proposed the
label: Paragraph

text: sculpture as a symbol of the Non-Aligned
label: Paragraph

text: Movement (NAM). Nehru's brainchild, NAM
label: Paragraph

text: was an attempt to propose a third alternative
label: Paragraph

text: to the divisive two-world—communist versus
label: Title

text: capitalist—hegemony of the Cold War.
label: Paragraph

text: Although not adopted for NAM, the Open
label: Paragraph

text: Hand did become the symbol of Chandigarh
label: Paragraph

text: as a city embodying Nehru’s hopes for a
label: Paragraph

text: modern India.

text: Chapel at Ronchamp
label: Caption

text: Le Corbusier accepted two commissions
label: Paragraph

text: from religious institutions. One was for a
label: Paragraph

text: chapel, Notre Dame de Haut at Ronchamp
label: Caption

text: (1955), in the Jura Mountains of eastern
label: Paragraph

text: France. The other for a monastery at La
label: Paragraph

text: Tourette (1957-60), near Lyon, France. Both
label: Paragraph

text: commissions were made by a reformist wing
label: Paragraph

text: of the Catholic Church trying to reestablish
label: Title

text: the relevance of their institution in the wake
label: Paragraph

text: of faltering attendance. Appealing to the
label: Paragraph

text: younger generation by adopting modern
label: Title

text: architecture was part of this effort. It was not
label: Paragraph

text: only a bold experiment but also demonstrated
label: Paragraph

text: that modernism could indeed create the kind
label: Paragraph

text: of inward-oriented atmosphere conducive to
label: Paragraph

text: contemplation. Although Le Corbusier was
label: Paragraph

text: not a churchgoing Catholic, he welcomed
label: Paragraph

text: the commissions because they allowed him
label: Paragraph

text: to experiment with symbolic forms, which he
label: Paragraph

text: had never done before in a European context.
label: Paragraph

text: The chapel, which astonished many
label: Paragraph

text: people when it was built, is a singular and
label: Paragraph

text: memorable edifice and stands today, along
label: Paragraph

text: with the Rosaire Chapel (1949-51) by Henri
label: Caption

text: Matisse, as one of the outstanding modern
label: Paragraph

text: religious expressions of the 20th century.
label: Paragraph

text: Fundamentally, the building is a sculpture;
label: Paragraph

text: its principal design element is the curve
label: Paragraph

text: deployed repeatedly to form a dramatic set of
label: Paragraph

text: intersections and trapped, cavelike spaces.
label: Paragraph

text: Three continuous walls, changing direction,
label: Paragraph

text: thickness, and height, create a volume
label: Paragraph

text: that defies the conventional expectations
label: Paragraph

text: 18.74 Plan and section: Notre Dame de Haut
label: Caption

text: of facade and interior. Two convex curves
label: Caption

text: bulge out on the north and west, creating a
label: Paragraph

text: backside, while two concave indents to the
label: Paragraph

text: south and east represent the front. On top
label: Caption

text: of the walls, on columns hidden in the walls,
label: Paragraph

text: floats a thick, organic-appearing roof that
label: Paragraph

text: comes to a sharp point at one end. It has
label: Paragraph

text: been compared by some to a cushion, and
label: Paragraph

text: by others to a hat.
label: Paragraph

text: Three towers, clustered together with
label: Paragraph

text: hooded tops, rise above the roof, forming
label: Paragraph

text: vertical counterpoints to the general
label: Title

text: horizontality and earth-bound appearance.
label: Paragraph

text: Light washes down into the inner space
label: Paragraph

text: of these towers and spills into the inner
label: Paragraph

text: sanctum. Each tower has a specific function,
label: Paragraph

text: serving as chapel, sacristy, and baptistery,
label: Paragraph

text: respectively. The west wall is punctured by
label: Paragraph

text: a series of irregularly placed, punched-out
label: Paragraph

text: windows of various sizes and depth that bring
label: Paragraph

text: spots of intense light into the interior. Inside,
label: Paragraph

text: the roof hangs like a sail over the nave while
label: Paragraph

text: sloping gently to the south toward the altar. A
label: Paragraph

text: statue of the Virgin Mary stands in an alcove
label: Caption

text: in the eastern wall and was designed so that
label: Paragraph

text: it can be rotated to face both inside and
label: Paragraph

text: outside, for those occasions when church
label: Paragraph

text: services are held outdoors. Near the church,
label: Paragraph

text: using stones from the site, Le Corbusier
label: Paragraph

text: constructed a small, stepped pyramid. The
label: Paragraph

text: church bells are placed in a steel-framed
label: Caption

text: structure to one side. Sited on the flat top of a
label: Paragraph

text: hill in a forested area of the Jura Mountains,
label: Paragraph

text: the building is reached by a gently curving
label: Paragraph

text: road that leads up the hill and passes a low
label: Paragraph

text: meeting and service building. From the top,
label: Caption

text: serene views range in all directions, imparting
label: Paragraph

text: to the church the aspect of a pilgrimage
label: Title

text: site. (Indeed, on the site there once stood a
label: Paragraph

text: pilgrimage chapel, destroyed in World War Il,
label: Caption

text: that had been dedicated to the Virgin Mary.)
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: Guggenheim Museum
label: Title

text: After World War II, modern architecture's
label: Paragraph

text: insistence on a rationalized functional
label: Title

text: aesthetic ran up against the need to express
label: Paragraph

text: monumentality, particularly in large civic
label: Paragraph

text: structures. Frank Lloyd Wright's design for
label: Caption

text: the Guggenheim Museum (1956-59) in
label: Paragraph

text: Manhattan was particularly innovative in this
label: Paragraph

text: respect, with a dramatic exterior form and
label: Paragraph

text: the large interior space at its center that is
label: Paragraph

text: formed by a curving ramp. The sides of the
label: Paragraph

text: building are fully occupied by this gently
label: Paragraph

text: spiraling ramp, designed to allow visitors to
label: Paragraph

text: view art continuously, without interruption.
label: Paragraph

text: It also enables everyone viewing the art to
label: Paragraph

text: be seen, an idea close to the sensibility of
label: Paragraph

text: Charles Garnier’s Paris Opera House. The
label: Paragraph

text: ramp, expanding in diameter as it ascends—
label: Paragraph

text: or shrinking as it descends, as the case
label: Paragraph

text: may be—generates an external profile that
label: Paragraph

text: contrasts sharply with the rectilinear geornetry
label: Paragraph

text: of the surrounding Manhattan blocks. Wright
label: Caption

text: defended the spiral by arguing that abstract
label: Paragraph

text: art no longer needed to be seen in the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional framework of rooms and walls. But
label: Paragraph

text: as innovative and controversial as Wright's
label: Paragraph

text: exhibition ideas were, there is no debate
label: Paragraph

text: about the building's impressive central space.
label: Paragraph

text: Accessed virtually directly frorn the street,
label: Paragraph

text: it was conceived as an extension of the
label: Paragraph

text: urban site. In that respect it constituted an
label: Paragraph

text: important breakthrough in the relationship
label: Title

text: of modernism to civic space. Though the
label: Paragraph

text: Museum of Modern Art (1938-39) by Philip
label: Caption

text: Goodwin and Edward Durell Stone was
label: Paragraph

text: technically the first modern building in New
label: Paragraph

text: York, the Guggenheim was the city’s first truly
label: Paragraph

text: modernist civic structure.
label: Paragraph

text: The project went through several
label: Paragraph

text: permutations. At first the building was to be
label: Paragraph

text: a type of private gallery, showing the works
label: Paragraph

text: of Solomon R. Guggenheim, but later in
label: Paragraph

text: 1952 the museum expanded its definition to
label: Paragraph

text: become something much broader, rivaling
label: Paragraph

text: the Museum of Modern Art as an institution
label: Title

text: of experimentation and taste-making across
label: Title

text: the whole range of modern art. The expanded
label: Paragraph

text: program forced Wright to make amendments
label: Title

text: and concessions, but he did not change
label: Paragraph

text: his stance that flat paintings would be well
label: Paragraph

text: served by hanging against curving walls, and
label: Paragraph

text: the public's positive reception of the building
label: Paragraph

text: offset complaints by curators and painters.
label: Paragraph

text: The building was based on an innovative
label: Paragraph

text: structural system of radially splayed concrete
label: Paragraph

text: ribs that held the floor plates and came
label: Paragraph

text: together at the top to form the dome. While
label: Paragraph

text: the building soon became a Manhattan
label: Paragraph

text: landmark, the success of its functional
label: Paragraph

text: purpose—the display of paintings—remains
label: Paragraph

text: questionable and was never imitated. One
label: Paragraph

text: complaint is that the building competes by
label: Paragraph

text: claiming artwork status itself and thus may
label: Paragraph

text: distract from the display; another is that
label: Paragraph

text: visitors cannot really come to rest, as they are
label: Paragraph

text: is in motion on a ramp that urges movernent
label: Paragraph

text: rather than repose.

text: Ekistics
label: Title

text: Constantinos Doxiadis (1913-75), former
label: Paragraph

text: chief town planning officer of Athens, Greece,
label: Caption

text: started his own firm in 1951] and after that
label: Paragraph

text: built in dozens of countries, including India,
label: Paragraph

text: Bangladesh, Ethiopia, France, Ghana, lran,
label: Title

text: Iraq, Italy, Jordan, Pakistan, and Syria. His
label: Paragraph

text: was one of the largest international practices
label: Paragraph

text: at the time. Doxiadis introduced issues like
label: Paragraph

text: regional climate and geography into the
label: Title

text: discussion of modernism at a time when such
label: Title

text: considerations were still rare. He coined the
label: Paragraph

text: term ekistics, derived from the Greek ofkos,
label: Paragraph

text: meaning “house,” to refer to the science
label: Paragraph

text: of human settlements. Doxiadis aspired to
label: Paragraph

text: expand the scientific basis of architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: urban design, and planning in order to reject
label: Paragraph

text: arbitrary self-expression and monotonic
label: Title

text: versions of rationalism and also to embrace
label: Title

text: extratechnological and nonfunctionalist
label: Title

text: concerns. He soon surrounded himself
label: Paragraph

text: with an international and interdisciplinary
label: Paragraph

text: group that included global visionaries (like
label: Paragraph

text: Buckminster Fuller and Margaret Mead),
label: Paragraph

text: architects, planners, and United Nations
label: Title

text: consultants (such as Jaqueline Tyrwhitt
label: Paragraph

text: and Charles Abrams), economists and
label: Paragraph

text: environmental thinkers (including Barbara
label: Title

text: Ward and Renee Dubos)—all of whom, to
label: Paragraph

text: some degree, supported Doxiadis’s vision.
label: Paragraph

text: His planning model was called Dynapolis,
label: Paragraph

text: a term signifying a dynamic city that would
label: Paragraph

text: change over time and allow its urban core to
label: Paragraph

text: expand continually in a unidirectional manner
label: Paragraph

text: in order to avoid congestion and do away
label: Paragraph

text: with the permanence and monumentality of
label: Paragraph

text: stationary city centers. The business district
label: Paragraph

text: and residential areas would also grow along
label: Paragraph

text: this axis, and industrial areas would be
label: Paragraph

text: pushed to the edges. This logic of functional
label: Paragraph

text: separation extended to the system of social
label: Paragraph

text: ordering, so that each residential sector
label: Paragraph

text: was broken down into smaller communities
label: Paragraph

text: arranged hierarchically.
label: Paragraph

text: The model of Dynapolis informed
label: Title

text: many plans for urban restructuring—from
label: Paragraph

text: Baghdad, Iraq (1958), to Athens, Greece
label: Caption

text: (1960), to Washington, DC—and became the
label: Paragraph

text: basis for the creation of Islamabad, the new
label: Paragraph

text: capital of Pakistan (1960). Doxiadis designed
label: Caption

text: lslamabad's master plan and the prototypes
label: Title

text: of the major housing types, but the design
label: Paragraph

text: of the individual buildings was assigned
label: Paragraph

text: to local and foreign architects. The master
label: Paragraph

text: plan was based on his concept of a moving
label: Paragraph

text: core—the idea that the commercial hub of
label: Paragraph

text: the city would continue to move and grow as
label: Paragraph

text: necessary, creating a linear city in its wake.
label: Paragraph

text: Located right on the water's edge, with the

text: as a backdrop, Utzon's prizewinning entry
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: of ships’ sails through outright technological
label: Paragraph

text: virtuosity. Supported on 580 concrete piers
label: Caption

text: sunk up to 25 meters below sea level, the
label: Paragraph

text: shells are sheathed in white ceramic tile and
label: Paragraph

text: contain five performance spaces. Although
label: Paragraph

text: Utzon never completed the project himself,
label: Paragraph

text: it quickly became the signature project of
label: Paragraph

text: Australia and a national icon.

text: Eero Saarinen
label: Title

text: Born in 1910 in Finland, Eero Saarinen
label: Paragraph

text: injected poetry into the structural possibilities
label: Paragraph

text: of reinforced concrete. Though Erich
label: Paragraph

text: Mendelsohn had attempted this in the 1930s,
label: Paragraph

text: he had built relatively little during a time
label: Paragraph

text: when concrete was still rather experimental.
label: Paragraph

text: Eero Saarinen's career ended prematurely
label: Paragraph

text: with his death in 1961, but in the short
label: Paragraph

text: space of eleven years, he had already worked
label: Paragraph

text: on nearly thirty projects in Europe and
label: Paragraph

text: the United States, some of which became
label: Paragraph

text: international icons and symbols of the United
label: Title

text: States’ postwar identity as a technological
label: Title

text: superpower. Among his works are the St.
label: Paragraph

text: Louis Gateway Arch (1948-64), the General
label: Paragraph

text: Motors Technical Center (1948-56) in Detroit,
label: Paragraph

text: and the TWA Terminal (1956-62) at New
label: Paragraph

text: York’s John F. Kennedy International Airport.
label: Paragraph

text: Saarinen’s 1947 competition-winning
label: Paragraph

text: entry for the Gateway Arch at St. Louis,
label: Caption

text: Missouri (1961-66), was conceived as a
label: Paragraph

text: huge structure located on the banks of
label: Paragraph

text: the Mississippi River. It was a monument
label: Paragraph

text: meant to match—if not exceed—in scale,
label: Paragraph

text: technological prowess, and symbolic stature,
label: Paragraph

text: Paris's Eiffel Tower. Because it represented
label: Paragraph

text: the gateway to the West, it was seen as a
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic reference to America’s origins,
label: Paragraph

text: putting St. Louis on the international map. A

text: Steel and Glass Skyscraper
label: Title

text: Skyscrapers had long been the primary symbol of
label: Paragraph

text: the U.S. metropolis. In their early days, architects
label: Paragraph

text: sought out a great deal of differentiation, but by the
label: Paragraph

text: late 1920s, the look of tall buildings began to be
label: Paragraph

text: more standardized, with the exception perhaps of
label: Paragraph

text: a crowning element, like in the Chrysler Building
label: Paragraph

text: (1928). Skyscraper design underwent its most
label: Paragraph

text: dramatic change with Mies van der Rohe’s Seagram
label: Title

text: Building (1958) in Midtown Manhattan, designed
label: Caption

text: in collaboration with Philip Johnson and built as the
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters for the Canadian distillers Joseph E.
label: Paragraph

text: Seagram & Sons. The thirty-eight-story building is
label: Paragraph

text: a vertical box with clean and sharp edges. Unlike
label: Paragraph

text: early skyscrapers, whose bodies were punctuated by
label: Paragraph

text: windows, here glass reaches from floor to ceiling and
label: Paragraph

text: serves as the skin of the building. The visible edge of
label: Paragraph

text: the floor plate is covered by bronze spandrels that give
label: Paragraph

text: a light horizontal zippering effect to the floors during
label: Paragraph

text: the day, when light reflects off the glass—an effect
label: Paragraph

text: even more pronounced at night, when the reflection
label: Paragraph

text: contrasts with the interior illumination.
label: Paragraph

text: Although the building seems to be all structural
label: Paragraph

text: steel and glass, this is not exactly true. Fire code
label: Paragraph

text: prohibited exposed steel, meaning that the steel
label: Paragraph

text: supports had to be covered in fireproof concrete.
label: Paragraph

text: Since this is not how Mies wanted the building to read
label: Paragraph

text: on the outside, he used nonstructural, bronze-toned
label: Paragraph

text: Ibeams running vertically, like mullions, down the
label: Paragraph

text: facades. These vertical mullions are equally spaced
label: Paragraph

text: across the entire facade. Together with the horizontal
label: Paragraph

text: spandrels, they create a pronounced grid pattern. This
label: Paragraph

text: surfacing does not extend to the ground, however,
label: Paragraph

text: allowing the building's real structure—the concrete-
label: Paragraph

text: encased beams—to be visible in the lobby. The glass
label: Paragraph

text: is not purely transparent, but tinted bronze, so that
label: Paragraph

text: in certain lighting conditions, the whole building—its
label: Paragraph

text: structure and its glass—seem to have a golden hue,
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps, it has been argued, subtly suggesting the
label: Paragraph

text: color of whiskey, one of the building owner's products.
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: In many parts of the Latin American world,
label: Paragraph

text: modernism was not so much a state-
label: Paragraph

text: sponsored nationalist sentiment as a search
label: Title

text: for expression by the artistic avant-garde. It
label: Paragraph

text: was first propounded not by architects but
label: Paragraph

text: by poets and writers, including Rubén Dario
label: Paragraph

text: (Panama), José Asuncion Silva (Colombia),
label: Paragraph

text: Manuel Gutiérrez Najera (Mexico), José
label: Caption

text: Enrique Rodo (Uruguay), José Marti (Cuba),
label: Paragraph

text: Bienvenido Nouel (Dominican Republic), and
label: Paragraph

text: Luis Lloréns Torres (Puerto Rico). It was not
label: Paragraph

text: until the 1940s and 1950s that what is now
label: Paragraph

text: also sometimes called tropical modernism
label: Title

text: emerged as the language of autonomy and
label: Paragraph

text: independence. Though strongly influenced
label: Paragraph

text: by Le Corbusier, this Latin American rendition
label: Paragraph

text: of modernism emphasized not only clean
label: Paragraph

text: lines but also the need for shaded surfaces,
label: Paragraph

text: wide windows, surrounding gardens,
label: Caption

text: and lightweight construction. Among its
label: Paragraph

text: proponents were Guillermo Gonzalez-
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Nechodoma and Henry Klumb in Puerto
label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: near San Diego, California, is close to a bluff
label: Paragraph

text: overlooking the Pacific Ocean. Three floors of
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: mechanical ducts. As was typical of Kahn,
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: upon. In its final configurations it consisted of
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

text: jaboratories but sitting in the courtyard
label: Paragraph

text: space. Circulation towers were located on the
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Archigram
label: Title

text: Archigram was a publication, begun in 1961,
label: Paragraph

text: that quickly became known for its alternative
label: Paragraph

text: ideas. Short for “Architectural Telegram,”
label: Paragraph

text: Archigram was produced by the young English
label: Paragraph

text: architects Peter Cook, David Greene, Michael
label: Caption

text: Webb, Ron Herron, Warren Chalk, and Dennis
label: Title

text: Crompton. The full Archigram group later
label: Paragraph

text: included Colin Fournier, Ken Allison, and Tony
label: Paragraph

text: Rickaby. Though the actual collaborations
label: Paragraph

text: between these architects were often sporadic
label: Paragraph

text: and difficult, the magazine's agenda called
label: Paragraph

text: for a holistic vision of the city and its parts as
label: Paragraph

text: a living, flowing, pulsing, flexible organism.
label: Paragraph

text: Challenging the grid established by Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier, Archigram's texts, collages, and
label: Paragraph

text: comic book-style designs emphasized the
label: Paragraph

text: use of anything but 90-degree angles and
label: Paragraph

text: thematized the curving and twisting of Le
label: Paragraph

text: Corbusier's straight lines. Using bright colors, a
label: Paragraph

text: nonstandard format, and an explicitly cut-and-
label: Paragraph

text: paste style of assembly, Archigram delivered
label: Paragraph

text: visions of technologically advanced cities that
label: Paragraph

text: walked on four legs, so-called Plugin Cities
label: Paragraph

text: that could be stacked and changed like cords
label: Paragraph

text: in an outlet, and Instant Cities that could be
label: Paragraph

text: flown in and made to sprout like spring flowers
label: Paragraph

text: in the hands of any eager architect, critic,
label: Paragraph

text: or admirer. Though many of the Archigram
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: recently built Kunsthaus in Graz, Austria, with
label: Paragraph

text: its amorphous blue shape contrasting with the
label: Paragraph

text: traditional architecture around it, gives some
label: Paragraph

text: indication of the Archigram aesthetic and the
label: Paragraph

text: excitement that it can generate.

label: Paragraph

text: Buckminster Fuller
label: Title

text: Among the modernists, the one who most
label: Paragraph

text: radically rethought the question of technology
label: Title

text: was Buckminster Fuller (1895-1983). In
label: Paragraph

text: 1929, at the age of thirty-two, Fuller decided
label: Paragraph

text: to study what he called the ecological
label: Paragraph

text: principles of life. His goal was to analyze
label: Paragraph

text: nature's resources and think of ways to
label: Paragraph

text: make ther available to all of humanity
label: Paragraph

text: through an informed, efficient, flexible, and
label: Paragraph

text: responsible attitude toward design. His key
label: Paragraph

text: concepts were synergetics, which is what
label: Paragraph

text: he called the underlying coordinate system
label: Paragraph

text: of both physical and metaphysical nature;
label: Paragraph

text: and ephemeralization, which essentially is
label: Paragraph

text: doing more with less. Unlike some European
label: Paragraph

text: modernists, who saw housing as primarily a
label: Paragraph

text: question of social needs allied loosely with
label: Title

text: industrial realities, Fuller saw housing as
label: Paragraph

text: tightly interwoven with industrialization and
label: Paragraph

text: social utopian thinking.
label: Paragraph

text: What resulted in 1928, after a series of
label: Paragraph

text: experiments with large-scale towers and
label: Paragraph

text: multiple-family housing systerns, was the
label: Paragraph

text: project for a prefabricated, mass-produced
label: Paragraph

text: 4D Dymaxion House, in which plumbing and
label: Caption

text: electrical networks, as well as appliances,
label: Paragraph

text: were contained in the central mast. The
label: Paragraph

text: house could therefore operate independently
label: Paragraph

text: of any utility network, which made it flexible
label: Paragraph

text: enough to be located anywhere in the world.
label: Paragraph

text: lt was enclosed by transparent, shuttering
label: Paragraph

text: walls rade of vacuum-pane glass, which
label: Paragraph

text: eliminated the need for windows. A specially
label: Paragraph

text: designed ventilation system made dusting
label: Caption

text: unnecessary, as air drawn through vents was
label: Paragraph

text: filtered and then heated or cooled as desired.
label: Paragraph

text: An in-home laundry facility was designed
label: Paragraph

text: to wash, dry, fold, and place clean laundry
label: Title

text: in appropriate compartments. The entire
label: Paragraph

text: structure was to be mass-produced and
label: Paragraph

text: flown to its site by blimps, with installation
label: Paragraph

text: requiring only a single day. All of this, Fuller
label: Paragraph

text: estimated, would cost only slightly more than
label: Paragraph

text: a 1928 Ford or Chevrolet automobile. The
label: Paragraph

text: 4D Dymaxion House, however, was never
label: Paragraph

text: realized.

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Fuller influenced a whole generation of
label: Paragraph

text: architects, scientists, and visionary thinkers.
label: Paragraph

text: He was one of the earliest advocates of
label: Paragraph

text: renewable energy sources—solar, wind, and
label: Title

text: waves—and coined the term Spaceship Earth

text: Fuller's breakthrough discovery—and this
label: Title

text: one was fully practical—was the geodesic
label: Paragraph

text: dome, which was designed to have the best
label: Paragraph

text: possible ratio of volume to weight. Fuller
label: Paragraph

text: determined that a network of triangular struts
label: Paragraph

text: arranged on great circles (geodesics) would
label: Paragraph

text: create local triangular rigidity and distribute
label: Paragraph

text: the stress in a manner that would result in
label: Paragraph

text: the most efficient structure ever designed.
label: Paragraph

text: Geodesic domes, in fact, become stronger
label: Paragraph

text: as they increase in size. Industry and the
label: Paragraph

text: U.S. military immediately saw the potential of
label: Paragraph

text: geodesic domes, and they were built by the
label: Paragraph

text: hundreds around the world. The U.S. Pavilion
label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: Counterculture Architecture
label: Title

text: Beginning in the early 1960s and escalating
label: Paragraph

text: toward the end of the decade, numerous
label: Paragraph

text: young architects, builders, and artists—
label: Title

text: mainly in the United States—began to seek
label: Paragraph

text: out alternatives to professional architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: building with sod or discarded building
label: Title

text: elements and studying vernacular practices
label: Title

text: around the world. They were part of a
label: Paragraph

text: broader counterculture of the times that
label: Paragraph

text: criticized the social norms of the age,
label: Paragraph

text: including the suburban lifestyle and the
label: Title

text: exploitation of natural resources. Though
label: Paragraph

text: many of these people's names remain
label: Paragraph

text: obscure, their efforts were sometimes
label: Paragraph

text: spectacular, such as the house built by Bob
label: Paragraph

text: de Buck and Jerry Thorman in New Mexico,
label: Paragraph

text: a freeform maze of spaces gathered around
label: Paragraph

text: central shafts of concrete columns that are
label: Paragraph

text: actually the chimney flues. The structure
label: Paragraph

text: was decorated with hubcaps and built with
label: Paragraph

text: wood scavenged from construction sites. The
label: Paragraph

text: framing was plastered, giving it an organic
label: Paragraph

text: feeling. According to de Buck: “Tools not to
label: Paragraph

text: have: straightedge, square, level, plumb.”
label: Paragraph

text: 18.120 A homemade dome
label: Caption

text: In 1965, an artist community called Drop
label: Paragraph

text: City was founded in southern Colorado and
label: Paragraph

text: attempted to combine innovative architectural
label: Paragraph

text: form with social utopianism. The original
label: Paragraph

text: founders were Gene Bernofsky, JoAnn
label: Paragraph

text: Bernofsky, Richard Kallweit, and Clark
label: Title

text: Richert, art students and filmmakers from
label: Title

text: the University of Kansas and the University
label: Title

text: of Colorado. Their intention was to create a
label: Paragraph

text: live-in work inspired by the “happenings”
label: Paragraph

text: of painter and performance artist Allan
label: Title

text: Kaprow and the impromptu performances
label: Title

text: of John Cage, Robert Rauschenberg, and
label: Paragraph

text: Buckminster Fuller. Residents constructed
label: Caption

text: domes and zonchedra, using geometric
label: Paragraph

text: panels made from the metal of automobile
label: Caption

text: roofs and other inexpensive materials. The
label: Paragraph

text: property deed stipulated that the land on
label: Paragraph

text: which the commune was built was “forever
label: Paragraph

text: free and open to all people.” Eventually,
label: Paragraph

text: 18.121 Structures in Drop City, Colorado
label: Caption

text: tensions and personality conflicts developed,
label: Paragraph

text: leading many of the occupants to leave.
label: Paragraph

text: Nonetheless, there were several attempts to
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Cross artists’ colony in Colorado. Though
label: Paragraph

text: dispersed and fragmented, this movernent
label: Paragraph

text: played an important part in demanding
label: Paragraph

text: that architects developed greater ecological
label: Paragraph

text: awareness.

label: Title

text: architecture is a building that, once the

text: National Modernism, Nigeria
label: Title

text: World War II left England and France
label: Title

text: considerably weakened. By the mid-1960s,
label: Paragraph

text: almost all of the English colonies in Africa
label: Paragraph

text: had achieved independence, including
label: Paragraph

text: Uganda in 1962 and Zanzibar and Kenya
label: Title

text: in 1963. Most immediately embarked on
label: Paragraph

text: an aggressive campaign of modernization.
label: Paragraph

text: New capitals, schools, and hospitals had to
label: Paragraph

text: be built, but since traditional architecture
label: Paragraph

text: had been neglected, skilled builders and
label: Paragraph

text: craftspeople were rare. In 1945, in all of
label: Paragraph

text: Africa, including Egypt, there were only 26
label: Paragraph

text: cities with a population over 100,000. By
label: Paragraph

text: the 1970s there were 120 such cities, but
label: Paragraph

text: architectural development remained spotty.
label: Paragraph

text: After Nigeria’ s independence in 1960,
label: Paragraph

text: several modernists arrived in Lagos, including
label: Paragraph

text: the husband and wife team of Maxwell Fry
label: Title

text: and Jane Drew, who designed the University
label: Paragraph

text: of Ibadan in the early 1960s, after having
label: Paragraph

text: worked in Chandigarh, India. The university's
label: Paragraph

text: nucleus is a series of connected buildings
label: Paragraph

text: consisting of a ring of residential colleges
label: Paragraph

text: arranged around a core of buildings devoted
label: Paragraph

text: to teaching and administration. Open
label: Paragraph

text: balconies, screens, and covered passageways
label: Caption

text: make use of prevailing winds. The plan can
label: Paragraph

text: be described as loosely hierarchical, with
label: Paragraph

text: sports and residential complexes at one end
label: Title

text: and the class and administration buildings at
label: Title

text: the other.
label: Paragraph

text: Parliament's space
label: Title

text: By 1991 new oil revenues created wealth
label: Paragraph

text: and stability, and Nigeria’s capital was moved
label: Paragraph

text: to a new city, Abuja, located on the Gwanga
label: Paragraph

text: Plains in the middle of the country. Abuja’s
label: Paragraph

text: master plan (1976) was designed by Kenzo
label: Paragraph

text: Tange, blending Lucio Costa's airplane plan
label: Paragraph

text: for Brasilia with the circulation pattern of
label: Paragraph

text: Tokyo. Anthropomorphically conceived, it
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: arms, and tail. The head contained the three
label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: development of Brazilian modernism.
label: Paragraph

text: However, in South Asia, as in other parts
label: Paragraph

text: of the postcolonial world, a more regional
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture continued to flourish.
label: Paragraph

text: The Indian team of architects that had
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: continued to build throughout northern India.
label: Paragraph

text: Aditya Prakash, for instance, was responsible
label: Paragraph

text: for designing many new campuses and
label: Paragraph

text: universities, such as those in Ludhiana and
label: Paragraph

text: Hissar in the 1960s. Shivnath Prasad, in
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: (1966-72). In Bangladesh, Mazharul Islam
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: finishes.

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Title

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Caption

label: Paragraph

text: INTRODUCTION
label: Title

text: The awareness that we live in a world of
label: Paragraph

text: global relationships is now itself global. Fifty
label: Paragraph

text: years from now, it is likely that the end of the
label: Paragraph

text: Cold War, the rise of China, and the onset of
label: Paragraph

text: global warming will be remembered as the
label: Paragraph

text: definitive events of the late 20th century, not
label: Paragraph

text: the spectacle of 9/11 or the rise of ISIS. Since
label: Paragraph

text: the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, the fruits of
label: Paragraph

text: victory in the Cold War for the capitalist bloc
label: Title

text: led by the United States have taken the forrn
label: Paragraph

text: of globalization, or the determined push to
label: Paragraph

text: dominate global markets via the enforcement
label: Paragraph

text: of favorable trade and tariff regimes.
label: Paragraph

text: Unshackled by the structural reforms
label: Title

text: initiated by Deng Xiaoping in 1978, China has
label: Paragraph

text: stepped up to the opportunity of globalization
label: Paragraph

text: to corner much of the market, pioneering the
label: Paragraph

text: concept of the special economic zone (SEZ),
label: Paragraph

text: an updated version of the colonial port treaties
label: Title

text: that were once signed to enable special
label: Paragraph

text: places like Hong Kong to operate. Since the
label: Paragraph

text: mid-1990s, formerly Third World countries
label: Paragraph

text: have jostled to ernulate the Chinese economic
label: Paragraph

text: model, creating a new intermediate class of
label: Paragraph

text: nations in the global hierarchy. Today they are
label: Paragraph

text: known as the BRICS—Brazil, Russia, India,
label: Paragraph

text: China, and South Africa—but others, such as
label: Paragraph

text: Nigeria and Mexico, are clamoring to join in.
label: Paragraph

text: The keystone in the infrastructure of
label: Paragraph

text: globalization is the containerization that
label: Paragraph

text: has optimized international shipping in
label: Paragraph

text: an unprecedented way, accompanied by
label: Paragraph

text: massive purpose-built ships, automated
label: Paragraph

text: ports, and radically rationalized truck and
label: Paragraph

text: rail transport. None of this would have been
label: Paragraph

text: possible without the concomitant spread of
label: Paragraph

text: the new digital network, the Internet, which
label: Paragraph

text: has not only generated the sense of a self-
label: Paragraph

text: aware global community but has also enabled
label: Paragraph

text: instantaneous financial transactions across
label: Title

text: national boundaries, transactions that power
label: Title

text: the engines of globalization. To support this
label: Paragraph

text: network of global finance, a new empire of
label: Paragraph

text: global cities has emerged—maijor cities that
label: Paragraph

text: compete and collaborate to control global
label: Title

text: finance. Generic infrastructural buildings
label: Paragraph

text: such as airports, airport malls, transit
label: Paragraph

text: systems, and convention centers are also
label: Paragraph

text: being built around the world to smooth the
label: Paragraph

text: movement of the agents of global finance.
label: Paragraph

text: Global self-consciousness has also been
label: Paragraph

text: spurred by two global crises: climate change
label: Title

text: and terrorism. Two centuries of relentless
label: Paragraph

text: industrialization, powered by fossil fuels, has
label: Paragraph

text: produced more wealth than ever before but
label: Paragraph

text: has also ended up threatening the delicate
label: Paragraph

text: equilibrium that is the atmosphere of planet
label: Paragraph

text: 19.2 Container ships in port, Seattle
label: Caption

text: Earth. Architecture’s role in this process
label: Paragraph

text: is certainly not without blame; buildings
label: Paragraph

text: are the largest consumers of energy in the
label: Paragraph

text: United States, for instance. But the new
label: Paragraph

text: crisis of terrorism can only be indirectly
label: Paragraph

text: indexed to architecture. In the face of the
label: Paragraph

text: overwhelming military might of today’s
label: Title

text: dominant nation-states, insurgencies around
label: Paragraph

text: the world have found a way to use the power
label: Paragraph

text: of media—and more recently the Internet—
label: Title

text: to globalize the impact of guerilla warfare,
label: Paragraph

text: originally a very localized and supplementary
label: Paragraph

text: military tactic. Architecture plays the role
label: Paragraph

text: of collateral damage in this war. More than
label: Paragraph

text: the destruction of habitats that conventional
label: Title

text: warfare brings about, the bombing of iconic
label: Paragraph

text: architecture like the Twin Towers in New York
label: Title

text: captures global attention, reminding us that
label: Paragraph

text: architecture, in spite of all its materiality and
label: Paragraph

text: massive capital expenditures, is ultimately
label: Paragraph

text: just as subject to its media image as a
label: Paragraph

text: supermodel. Architecture's supermodel-like
label: Paragraph

text: qualities have resulted, on the one hand, in
label: Paragraph

text: the fortification of significant public buildings
label: Title

text: such as embassies with bollards, high-
label: Paragraph

text: perimeter walls, and other security features;
label: Paragraph

text: and, on the other hand, in a global obsession
label: Paragraph

text: with super-iconic buildings, recognizable
label: Paragraph

text: worldwide, designed by a dazzling class of
label: Paragraph

text: storied “starchitects.”
label: Paragraph

text: 19.3 Bollards protecting the U.S. Capitol in Washington, DC
label: Caption

text: In spite of all the razzle-cazzle, the critical
label: Paragraph

text: architectural response to globalization is
label: Paragraph

text: characterized by uncertainty and constant
label: Paragraph

text: reinvention. Every year a new conference
label: Paragraph

text: announces the establishment of a new ism;
label: Paragraph

text: if it is Deconstructivism one day, it is the
label: Paragraph

text: lew Pragmatism the next, and then a New
label: Paragraph

text: egionalism the day after. New Urbanism
label: Paragraph

text: wo
label: Title

text: is followed by New Landscape Urbanism,
label: Paragraph

text: lose on the heels of which comes Planetary
label: Paragraph

text: rbanization, accornpanied by the Global
label: Paragraph

text: occa
label: Title

text: ities Network. In a sense, this is a sign
label: Paragraph

text: a rich discourse and the abandoning of
label: Title

text: rthodoxies. And yet, while the certainties
label: Paragraph

text: modernism are routinely criticized, the
label: Paragraph

text: search for new ecological utopias is still a
label: Paragraph

text: aQo°0
label: Title

text: professional obsession. And while it is the
label: Paragraph

text: unknown possibilities of technologically
label: Title

text: imbued architecture that get the most press
label: Paragraph

text: and research funding, it is the postmodern-
label: Paragraph

text: like quests for identity, place, and local
label: Paragraph

text: empowerment that still find currency among
label: Paragraph

text: alternative designers.
label: Paragraph

text: If the psychological response to
label: Paragraph

text: uncertainty is preservation, it is no surprise
label: Paragraph

text: that the movement for preservation—or
label: Paragraph

text: conservation, as it is also termed—
label: Paragraph

text: has emerged as a major force in the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural community. Much more than
label: Paragraph

text: the old modernist distinction between
label: Paragraph

text: the new and the old, preservation today
label: Title

text: is a multivalent movement that includes
label: Paragraph

text: strategies as diverse as building resilient
label: Title

text: social networks and banking the world’s
label: Title

text: seeds to ensure biodiversity in the future.
label: Paragraph

text: From World Heritage to DOCOMOMO to local
label: Title

text: activist groups, preservation is enjoying an
label: Paragraph

text: unexpected renaissance. And in its midst,
label: Paragraph

text: the city—as the ancient, evanescent Greek
label: Paragraph

text: ideal of diverse communities sustained in
label: Paragraph

text: an egalitarian matrix—has emerged as the
label: Paragraph

text: focus of the civic objectives of professional
label: Title

text: architects. In 2009 half the world's population
label: Paragraph

text: lived in cities, indicating the global trend
label: Paragraph

text: toward urbanization—a statistic that was
label: Paragraph

text: celebrated by both advocates and critics of
label: Paragraph

text: globalization.
label: Paragraph

text: There is no one equation that can
label: Paragraph

text: describe today’s architecture, in spite of the
label: Paragraph

text: whitewashing of the world that is implied by
label: Paragraph

text: the term globalization. Instead, the global and
label: Paragraph

text: the local have become so intertwined that
label: Paragraph

text: perhaps the neologism g/oca/ best describes
label: Paragraph

text: the world that architects design for today.
label: Paragraph

text: Rather than painting global architecture with
label: Paragraph

text: a single brush, we would like to suggest an
label: Paragraph

text: overlay of seven different global trends, each
label: Paragraph

text: coming to terms with contemporary reality
label: Title

text: in a different way. And even though there
label: Paragraph

text: are overlaps, each is governed by a set of
label: Paragraph

text: circumstances, ideologies, and politics that
label: Paragraph

text: differentiates it from the others.
label: Paragraph

text: 19.4 Map of the Global Cities Network

label: Caption

text: A second way to map architecture at the
label: Title

text: global level is to follow the careers of those

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: Frank Gehry is the leader in this respect,
label: Paragraph

text: designing opera houses, museums, and
label: Paragraph

text: institutional headquarters the world over.
label: Paragraph

text: These buildings are meant to be high profile
label: Paragraph

text: and are readily used in tourist brochures.
label: Paragraph

text: They are prestige commissions. This
label: Paragraph

text: tendency began after World War II with such
label: Paragraph

text: commissions as J@rn Utzon’s Sydney Opera
label: Caption

text: House (1957-73), but the most recent
label: Paragraph

text: examples include the construction in Seoul
label: Paragraph

text: architect-engineer.

text: The global commodification of prestige
label: Title

label: Paragraph

text: where architects can experiment not only

text: ideas about program and function. For the

text: accessible and visible examples of avant-
label: Paragraph

text: garde architectural production. Nonetheless,
label: Paragraph

text: these projects are not unambiguous. The
label: Paragraph

text: Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, has
label: Paragraph

text: brought in millions in tourist dollars, and the

text: advantages and disadvantages need to be

label: Caption

text: Among the elite designers who work at the

text: Rem Koolhaas, a Dutch architect, has a well-

label: Paragraph

text: components is an inevitable consequence of

label: Caption

text: Despite this position, Koolhaas, like others,

text: or Prada, with its elegant store in New York
label: Paragraph

text: City. The difference between KPF and Rem
label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: seeks to articulate much more strongly than

text: symbolic celebration of the architect's name.

label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: Zaha Hadid (1950-2016) occupies a special

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

label: Paragraph

text: style that emphasized bold forms and
label: Paragraph

text: sensuous lines, which was at first described
label: Paragraph

text: as being deconstructivist but came into its
label: Paragraph

text: own with the ascent of computer-based
label: Paragraph

text: parametric modeling in the 1990s. As a
label: Paragraph

text: woman of color, Zaha Hadid gave expression
label: Paragraph

label: Title

text: worldwide, including those of earlier
label: Paragraph

text: generations such as Eileen Gray of France,
label: Paragraph

text: Minnette de Silva of Sri Lanka, and U. E.
label: Paragraph

text: Chowdhury of India.

label: Paragraph
