text: slum settlement. By 2020, that number
label: Paragraph

text: will increase to one in three. NGOs are an
label: Paragraph

text: important part of the solution to this pending
label: Paragraph

text: crisis, since they are more flexible than
label: Paragraph

text: government bureaucracies and thus often
label: Title

text: more capable of identifying problems and
label: Paragraph

text: suggesting solutions that are acceptable to
label: Paragraph

text: local cormmunities.
label: Paragraph

text: Though the idea of the NGO dates
label: Paragraph

text: to the early 20th century, the phrase
label: Paragraph

text: nongovernmental organization only care
label: Title

text: into broader use with the establishment
label: Paragraph

text: of the United Nations in 1945, when
label: Paragraph

text: provisions were made for the creation of
label: Paragraph

text: such organizations. Today, the amount of
label: Paragraph

text: unacknowledged work done by NGOs around
label: Paragraph

text: the world is staggering. An example is the
label: Paragraph

text: building effort undertaken by Kutch Nav
label: Title

text: Nirman Abhiyan, a collection of forty NGOs
label: Title

text: in Kutch, in western India, which came
label: Paragraph

text: together after the devastating earthquake
label: Title

text: of January 26, 2000, to undertake a range
label: Paragraph

text: of development initiatives in the areas of
label: Paragraph

text: social work, primary education, and disaster
label: Title

text: management. It has also helped construct
label: Paragraph

text: more than twenty thousand dwellings built
label: Title

text: by the local communities themselves.
label: Paragraph

text: The new structures used reinforcement
label: Title

text: techniques to make the buildings more
label: Paragraph

text: earthquake resistant. Such work by “barefoot
label: Paragraph

text: architects,” as they have sometimes been
label: Paragraph

text: called, is the other side of the world of global
label: Paragraph

text: capital. Another organization, Architecture
label: Paragraph

text: for Humanity, a San Francisco-based
label: Paragraph

text: NGO, provides volunteered professional
label: Paragraph

text: design services to community groups,
label: Paragraph

text: social entrepreneurs, and other not-for-
label: Title

text: profit organizations the world over. It helps
label: Paragraph

text: underprivileged communities plan and
label: Title

text: develop schools, clinics, and sports fields,
label: Paragraph

text: among other things.
label: Paragraph

text: A fourth type of architecture operating at the
label: Paragraph

text: global level is produced by local architects
label: Paragraph

text: with small firms that, despite varying design
label: Paragraph

text: methodologies, advocate a carefully crafted
label: Paragraph

text: and well-thought-out relationship between
label: Paragraph

text: program and the constraints formed by
label: Title

text: climate, site conditions, and materials.
label: Paragraph

text: Though explicitly local by orientation, these
label: Paragraph

text: architects constitute a global movement due
label: Paragraph

text: to their shared ethic of design, which can
label: Paragraph

text: be described broadly as one derived frorn
label: Paragraph

text: modern architecture. At Atelier Feichang
label: Caption

text: Jianzhu's Split House near Beijing, for
label: Paragraph

text: example, the architect uses rammed earth
label: Paragraph

text: not only for its natural thermal insulating
label: Paragraph

text: properties but also because rammed earth
label: Paragraph

text: has been a part of Chinese architecture in
label: Paragraph

text: history. Framed against the backdrop of the
label: Paragraph

text: nearby cliffs, it can even be seen through
label: Paragraph

text: a Ruskinian ethos as a commentary on the
label: Paragraph

text: nature of material and geology. In Adira
label: Paragraph

text: & Broid & Rojkind’s F-2 House, volcanic
label: Caption

text: basalt, a common local material in Mexico
label: Paragraph

text: City, is used as a visual and tactile contrast
label: Paragraph

text: to the cast-in-place concrete. The aesthetic
label: Paragraph

text: is close to that of Marcel Breuer, who helped
label: Paragraph

text: create a form of modernism compatible
label: Paragraph

text: with the open landscape and the need to
label: Paragraph

text: capture the breeze. Both these houses are
label: Paragraph

text: therefore high modernist in style—but that
label: Paragraph

text: should not be any reason to condemn them.
label: Paragraph

text: Designing within the context of “the local”
label: Paragraph

text: does not require using or replicating ancient
label: Paragraph

text: techniques or falsely aestheticizing local
label: Title

text: customs, as is so often done, for example,
label: Paragraph

text: by those who reduce the Chinese tradition of
label: Paragraph

text: screens to working with metal screens.
label: Paragraph

text: The architecture of small firms is
label: Paragraph

text: important to the development of architectural
label: Paragraph

text: thinking, as small firms can often be more
label: Paragraph

text: experimental and open-ended in their
label: Paragraph

text: approach. Atelier Bow Wow in Tokyo,
label: Caption

text: established by Yoshiharu Tsukamoto and
label: Paragraph

text: Momoyo Kaijima, made a name for itself
label: Paragraph

text: designing unusual structures like the
label: Paragraph

text: Mado Building in Tokyo (2006) in the tight
label: Caption

text: urban environments of Japanese cities.
label: Paragraph

text: Anupama Kundoo developed innovative
label: Paragraph

text: 19.20 Anupama Kundoo’s own house in Auroville, India
label: Caption

text: design techniques in Auroville, India. In
label: Paragraph

text: Barcelona, the mid-19th-century Santa
label: Title

text: Caterina Market was remodeled (1997-2005)
label: Paragraph

text: by architects Enric Miralles and Benedetta
label: Caption

text: Tagliabue of EMTB Associates. They added
label: Paragraph

text: a wavy wooden roof over the whole building,
label: Paragraph

text: practically filling the piazza. The colorful roof
label: Paragraph

text: tiles are decorated to emulate the vibrant
label: Paragraph

text: colors of the vegetables and fruits in the
label: Paragraph

text: market stalls. The structure has brought
label: Paragraph

text: new life to the economically depressed
label: Title

text: area of Barcelona’s Gothic Quarter. Another
label: Paragraph

text: architect, Teddy Cruz, works with the migrant
label: Paragraph

text: communities of Los Angeles, as well as the
label: Paragraph

text: Mexican communities across the border, to
label: Paragraph

text: develop innovative housing solutions.
label: Paragraph

text: lrony is particularly remote in today’s
label: Paragraph

text: aesthetic and will, sadly, rernain so, given
label: Paragraph

text: the penchant for appearing respectful to the
label: Paragraph

text: ideologies of tradition and inheritance. For
label: Paragraph

text: that reason, we would like to point to a fifth
label: Paragraph

text: global phenomenon: architecture produced
label: Title

text: locally but by amateurs and architects with
label: Paragraph

text: an open sensibility to the potential in ready-
label: Paragraph

text: mades—a house in Massachusetts made
label: Title

text: completely out of newspaper (including
label: Paragraph

text: the furniture), a house in Nevada using
label: Paragraph

text: automobile tires, cormplete buildings made
label: Paragraph

text: out cardboard tubes, squatter settlements in
label: Paragraph

text: Mexico that make use of discarded building
label: Title

text: materials, architects who use off-the-shelf
label: Paragraph

text: technologies to subvert expectations, and
label: Paragraph

text: those who build houses with shipping
label: Title

text: containers. This type of architecture burst
label: Paragraph

text: onto the scene in the late 1960s with Drop
label: Paragraph

text: City in Colorado, which was a center of the
label: Paragraph

text: counterculture movement. Since then, it
label: Paragraph

text: has expanded into an informal movement
label: Paragraph

text: all its own. Sean Godsell’s Future Shack, for
label: Paragraph

text: instance, combines a sun-shading device
label: Paragraph

text: with a shipping container to design a mass-
label: Paragraph

text: produced, relocatable house. The Rural
label: Paragraph

text: Studio, developed by Samuel Mockbee
label: Paragraph

text: (1944-2001) at Auburn University in
label: Paragraph

text: Alabama, is particularly exemplary. Working
label: Paragraph

text: with the basic principle that even the poorest
label: Paragraph

text: deserve the dignity of good architecture,
label: Paragraph

text: Mockbee and his students designed and
label: Paragraph

text: built a host of inexpensive and imaginative
label: Paragraph

text: structures, advancing the frontier of
label: Paragraph

text: architectural practice with such innovations
label: Title

text: as sidings made from salvaged automobile
label: Paragraph

text: windscreens and license plates.
label: Paragraph

text: A sixth category of global production revolves
label: Title

text: around the question of environment. It was
label: Paragraph

text: only recently that mainstream architectural
label: Paragraph

text: professionals began to acknowledge the
label: Paragraph

text: impact buildings have on the environment.
label: Paragraph

text: The production of materials like rubber,
label: Paragraph

text: steel, and glass is highly polluting. There are
label: Paragraph

text: also issues of how much energy a building
label: Title

text: requires for heating and cooling, and the
label: Paragraph

text: question of a building's life span. The U.S.
label: Paragraph

text: Environmental Protection Agency estimates
label: Title

text: that architectural debris comprises 25
label: Paragraph

text: percent of the nation’s overall waste stream.
label: Paragraph

text: This waste often contains materials such as
label: Paragraph

text: lead paint, asbestos, fluorescent light bulbs,
label: Paragraph

text: light ballasts, treated lumber, and other iterns
label: Paragraph

text: that pollute the environment.
label: Paragraph

text: The impact of industrialism on the
label: Title

text: environment and society began to be
label: Paragraph

text: critiqued in the late 19th century. Frederick
label: Paragraph

text: Law Olmsted designed parks that were
label: Paragraph

text: oases of nature in the urban context, and
label: Paragraph

text: Frank Lloyd Wright and others attempted to
label: Paragraph

text: integrate the mechanical and the natural.
label: Paragraph

text: But it was only with the ecology movement
label: Paragraph

text: of the 1960s that environmentalism becarne
label: Paragraph

text: a political issue. The slow success of that
label: Paragraph

text: movement led to the emergence of the field
label: Paragraph

text: of environmental management in the 1980s.
label: Paragraph

text: Most of the issues involved law, government,
label: Paragraph

text: and industry, and architecture has only
label: Paragraph

text: recently begun to find a role within the
label: Paragraph

text: debates. Today, some architects specialize in
label: Paragraph

text: low-budget design-build projects; others, in
label: Paragraph

text: green housing projects, self-sufficient houses,
label: Paragraph

text: solar houses, eco-villages, and now, so-called
label: Paragraph

text: health houses.
label: Paragraph

text: The central term in this movement is
label: Paragraph

text: the word sustainability, but it can mean
label: Paragraph

text: different things to different groups. In the
label: Paragraph

text: context of environmental management, the
label: Paragraph

text: issues revolve around questions of politics,
label: Paragraph

text: government, law, planning, and banking.
label: Paragraph

text: Architectural design, as such, is often left
label: Paragraph

text: until the end of the process. But this has
label: Paragraph

text: begun to change, and most large firms now
label: Paragraph

text: offer a specialization in green architecture.
label: Paragraph

text: As a common standard of measurement of
label: Paragraph

text: the sustainable character of a building, U.S.
label: Paragraph

text: architects now use the Leadership in Energy
label: Paragraph

text: and Environmental Design (LEED) Green
label: Title

text: Building Rating System.
label: Paragraph

text: at
label: Title

text: 19.21 Commerzbank, Frankfurt, Germany
label: Caption

text: The LEED system evaluates buildings along
label: Paragraph

text: a wide spectrum of criteria but usually favors
label: Paragraph

text: more technologically advanced solutions.
label: Paragraph

text: Among architects who work with low budgets
label: Paragraph

text: is Thomas Herzog in Germany, who combines
label: Paragraph

text: conventional methods of environmental
label: Title

text: design—high spaces to reduce air-
label: Paragraph

text: conditioning costs, for example—with high-
label: Paragraph

text: end technology such as specially designed
label: Paragraph

text: types of glass and cooling systems. William
label: Caption

text: McDonough has championed the ideological
label: Paragraph

text: imperative that sustainability should have
label: Paragraph

text: for the world’s leading corporations. His
label: Paragraph

text: headquarters for Volkswagen and his
label: Title

text: projected 65,000-square-meter plant, built
label: Caption

text: on 130 hectares of former rain forest in
label: Paragraph

text: Brazil, are just two of his larger commissions.
label: Paragraph

text: At the high end of green architecture
label: Title

text: is Foster & Partners’ design for the
label: Paragraph

text: Commerzbank in Frankfurt, Germany, now
label: Paragraph

text: the tallest building in Europe. Interspersed
label: Paragraph

text: throughout the tower are sky gardens. There
label: Paragraph

text: are now firms that specialize in the greening
label: Paragraph

text: of architectural projects, just as there are
label: Paragraph

text: firms that specialize in developing green
label: Paragraph

text: master plans that look to future needs.
label: Paragraph

text: 19.22 Cast of pollution from the Louis Vuitton factory in Paris, by Jorge Otero-Pailos
label: Caption

text: A final but increasingly important global
label: Title

text: formation centers on the World Heritage
label: Title

text: List to preserve buildings and building
label: Title

text: environments, created under the auspices
label: Paragraph

text: of the United Nations Educational, Scientific
label: Title

text: and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) in 1972.
label: Paragraph

text: Only forty-odd years old, the list now consists
label: Paragraph

text: of more than eight hundred properties in 134
label: Paragraph

text: countries. The list is continually expanded,
label: Paragraph

text: and even modernist sites like Chandigarh,
label: Paragraph

text: India have recently been added to it. The
label: Paragraph

text: amount of space worldwide that is now
label: Paragraph

text: curated, or under some form of protection,
label: Paragraph

text: has increased exponentially since the list’s
label: Paragraph

text: inception—entire valleys, villages, and
label: Paragraph

text: landscapes are now under protection.
label: Paragraph

text: As valuable as this movement for
label: Paragraph

text: preservation is, it is the lure of tourist dollars,
label: Paragraph

text: as much a need to preserve identity, that
label: Paragraph

text: drives the search for heritage. The Dogon
label: Paragraph

text: cities of Dienné were inscribed on the
label: Paragraph

text: UNESCO Heritage List in 1988, and now a
label: Paragraph

text: road is being planned to reach the remote
label: Paragraph

text: location. Being “protected” will certainly
label: Paragraph

text: be a mixed blessing, given that this is a
label: Paragraph

text: living community and not a set of fossilized
label: Title

text: ruins. More conventional is the protection of
label: Paragraph

text: archaeological sites. More than four hundred
label: Paragraph

text: thousand people visit the remote site of
label: Paragraph

text: Machu Picchu in Peru every year. A road has
label: Paragraph

text: now been built to carry tourists almost to the
label: Paragraph

text: top of this remote mountain. In 1994, a new
label: Paragraph

text: category was created by UNESCO: “cultural
label: Paragraph

text: landscapes” were introduced to broaden the
label: Paragraph

text: representation of what UNESCO calls human
label: Title

text: heritage, but the delimitations of this term
label: Paragraph

text: will become increasingly complex as such
label: Paragraph

text: cultural landscapes become increasingly
label: Title

text: entangled with politics.
label: Paragraph

text: The preservation of the modern
label: Title

text: architecture of the world has been
label: Paragraph

text: championed by DOCOMOMO, an organization
label: Paragraph

text: that started in Europe in 1988 and has
label: Paragraph

text: established itself as a major force worldwide.
label: Paragraph

text: As most of the world’s modern architecture
label: Paragraph

text: is now at least half a century old, it is
label: Paragraph

text: increasingly under threat of destruction.
label: Paragraph

text: Through publications, awards, conferences,
label: Paragraph

text: and local activism, DOCOMOMO’s regional
label: Paragraph

text: chapters have sought to make the case
label: Paragraph

text: that modern architecture is as deserving of
label: Paragraph

text: preservation as the pre-modern architecture
label: Title

text: of the world.
label: Paragraph

text: Preservation is a global force in the
label: Paragraph

text: architectural community today. While it
label: Paragraph

text: is largely devoted to fighting imminent
label: Paragraph

text: destruction, a more critical approach to
label: Paragraph

text: thinking about preservation can be found
label: Paragraph

text: in the work of people like Jorge Otero-
label: Paragraph

text: Pailos, who made the casting of pollution
label: Paragraph

text: into an interrogation of the conventions of
label: Paragraph

text: preservation practice.
label: Paragraph

text: Global heritage is most certainly a form of
label: Paragraph

text: global intermixing. Whether that intermixing
label: Paragraph

text: is to be understood as a form of cultural
label: Paragraph

text: liberation from the hegemony of the local or
label: Paragraph

text: as cultural contamination by the hegemony
label: Paragraph

text: of the global is a question that can only be
label: Paragraph

text: resolved in each particular situation.
label: Paragraph

text: In the last decade, architectural educators
label: Paragraph

text: have been asking for a textbook that looks
label: Paragraph

text: beyond the Eurocentric approaches of the
label: Paragraph

text: past. Ironically, recent decades have also
label: Paragraph

text: seen the rising specter of nationalism, which
label: Paragraph

text: has become a global phenomenon in its
label: Paragraph

text: own right as countries seek to establish their
label: Paragraph

text: credentials in global historical narratives. This
label: Paragraph

text: new nationalism, though it has played some
label: Paragraph

text: role in awakening an awareness about local
label: Paragraph

text: realities, has had, and continues to have, a
label: Paragraph

text: dampening effect on learning about what lies
label: Paragraph

text: over the horizon. The tension between the
label: Paragraph

text: global and the national is the fundamental
label: Paragraph

text: paradox of our age.
label: Paragraph

text: Today we live in a world that is significantly
label: Paragraph

text: more static than in centuries before—
label: Paragraph

text: boundaries are controlled by international
label: Paragraph

text: law and political alliances, UNESCO protects
label: Title

text: architectural and urban marvels of the
label: Title

text: past, and local and national regulations
label: Title

text: govern what can and cannot be built. We
label: Paragraph

text: control our actions for the sake of global
label: Title

text: tranquility. But inequities and injustices in
label: Paragraph

text: the location of boundaries persist, and so,
label: Paragraph

text: too, do the tensions that result from inward-
label: Paragraph

text: looking ideologies. In this environment,
label: Paragraph

text: the maxim “know your neighbor” is all the
label: Paragraph

text: more important but at the same time all the
label: Paragraph

text: more elusive, since we can all, no matter
label: Paragraph

text: our country of origin, easily revel in our
label: Paragraph

text: singularity—in the presumed uniqueness of
label: Paragraph

text: our history.
label: Paragraph

text: This is something we need to guard
label: Paragraph

text: against. A global history is not the history of
label: Paragraph

text: all the modern nations added up like beads
label: Paragraph

text: on an abacus, but neither is it a history that
label: Paragraph

text: assumes a universal aspect to mankind and
label: Paragraph

text: its productions. For a global history to be
label: Paragraph

text: more than just dates and facts, it has to be
label: Paragraph

text: rooted in the principle that each of us learns
label: Paragraph

text: how he or she is indeed different in the eyes
label: Paragraph

text: of others.
label: Paragraph
